input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Revenue totaled roughly $1.5 billion, showing a 7.5% decrease from the previous year, surpassing our projections and indicating ongoing gradual improvement.
As expected, the Aviation division remains the main cause of the revenue decline.
Both GAAP and adjusted earnings increased by over 160% compared to the same period last year.
GAAP continuing earnings per share rose to $1.10, or $1.01 on an adjusted basis.
Adjusted EBITDA margins grew by more than 400 basis points to 8.3% in comparison to the previous year.
These results were bolstered by high demand for more profitable Work Orders related to virus protection and our long-term EnhancedClean services.
Efficient labor management continued to contribute to profitability.
Most of our contracts are performance-based, so we benefit from any staffing efficiencies as occupancy decreases or schools adopt hybrid models.
This demonstrates the advantage of having a flexible workforce model.
Earl will provide more detailed information about our segments, but overall, our industry group trends are similar to what we observed throughout the latter part of last year.
As expected, our Aviation and Technical Solutions segments faced challenges due to the pandemic, resulting from reduced global travel and limited access to sites for retrofit projects and educational facilities.
However, the Education segment experienced growth in both revenue and profit during the quarter, demonstrating how well our team has adapted operationally to the hybrid learning system, while Business & Industry and Technology & Manufacturing continue to perform strongly.
We've managed to counterbalance COVID-related revenue decreases with higher-margin Work Orders, EnhancedClean contracts, and effective labor management.
We're approaching the one-year mark since the pandemic began, and I've just summarized our fourth consecutive quarter of strong performance.
This sustained success indicates that we've achieved a level of consistency in our results and stability across our client portfolio.
I'll now share some thoughts on where we believe the operating environment is heading, particularly in light of our full-year guidance.
Before discussing what the path to normalcy looks like in 2021, I want to emphasize that normalcy doesn't mean reduced vigilance regarding virus protection.
In recent months, numerous news outlets and scientific journals have reminded us that COVID-19 and its effects will persist for the foreseeable future.
Many experts believe it will become a permanent part of our lives, with people receiving regular vaccinations similar to how we handle flu shots.
We are very excited about the ongoing vaccine rollouts across the country.
Most importantly, the vaccines will save lives, but they will also drive momentum for returning to work, school, travel, and attending entertainment venues.
However, vaccine distribution has been inconsistent from state to state, as have state policies on mask-wearing, public gatherings, and other factors that impact infections and new cases.
These factors, along with the ongoing discovery of new variants, highlight how society's need to respond to COVID-19 at an elevated level will not end in the near future.
This is why it's crucial for us to collaborate with our clients, assess their evolving needs, and engage our expert advisory panel.
In the Business & Industry sector, vaccines will drive momentum for returning to work, which for us means a revival of more traditional janitorial work as well as continued disinfection due to higher occupancy.
Currently, average occupancy across the country is about 15%.
We expect this could increase to 25% by Labor Day and grow to over 50% by the end of the calendar year.
As clients plan their return, they are focusing on building trust in their facilities through health and safety protocols, with rigorous cleaning, disinfecting, and physical distancing being incorporated into their plans.
For this reason, we don't anticipate a near-term reduction in space utilization across commercial real estate, especially for Class A buildings and blue-chip clients.
In the education sector, we believe hybrid models will remain in effect for at least the rest of the school year.
Soon, if not already, institutions will begin planning for the fall 2021 semester, with a push for more in-person learning in both K-12 and higher education.
The implementation may vary by region.
We should have a clearer picture when we speak to you after Q2 earnings.
As vaccine adoption continues to expand, there's likely no sector more poised for a robust volume recovery than Aviation.
We're definitely hearing about pent-up demand for personal travel and at least a modest return of business travel.
For ABM, our aviation business portfolio includes both airlines and airports.
Since airports remained open during the pandemic, operations in areas like terminal cleaning, transportation, and shuttle services allowed us to mitigate reduced volumes on the airline side.
Ultimately, this diversification helped us break even last year, which was a significant achievement.
On the airline side, current travel volumes are approximately 50% of pre-COVID levels.
Assuming vaccine rollouts gain traction, we believe we could see that grow moderately by year-end.
As both airlines and airports experience increased traffic, the need for disinfection, virus protection, and EnhancedClean services will grow.
At an enterprise level, we conducted a Pulse Survey of about 200 clients last month that largely aligned with our own full-year expectations.
Most respondents anticipate their facilities will more fully reopen and their companies will endorse reoccupancy in various forms by September, and they plan to continue taking multiple measures to protect spaces against COVID-19 as they reopen, primarily in the areas of surface and air disinfection.
Even with the increase in flexible work schedules and work-from-home protocols, the vast majority of our clients expect the total amount of space utilization to remain largely the same.
While the size of our survey represents just a subset of our client base, it supports what we're hearing more broadly as we communicate with our customers about their future plans.
It also speaks to our confidence in providing full-year guidance today.
For fiscal 2021, we are introducing full-year guidance of earnings per diluted share of $2.85 to $3.10, or $3.00 to $3.25 on an adjusted basis.
Our outlook for adjusted EBITDA margins is 6.6% to 7%, compared to 6% last year.
We also expect to return to growth by the second half of this year and see consistent demand for high-margin Work Orders and EnhancedClean services through year-end.
We also anticipate retaining most of our labor arbitrage through year-end.
Our success will not lead to complacency.
We have been leveraging the pandemic's impact on our trajectory to boost our brand and business.
ABM debuted its first nationwide television commercial in late February.
The entire company celebrated this milestone achievement with great pride.
You can view the commercial on our investor relations website if you missed it on CNBC or Bloomberg TV.
As previously discussed, we plan to invest in our clients, employees, and infrastructure.
We're concentrating on enhancing client and employee experiences through technology and data analytics capabilities.
We're also emphasizing talent development to empower our staff and strengthen client relationships.
We are dedicated to enhancing our strong culture and creating an environment where team members feel included, appreciated, and motivated.
This aligns with our organizational mission and vision, leading to significant long-term business benefits.
Internal programs like our culture and inclusion council aim to drive meaningful social change and foster an inclusive workplace at ABM.
I'm pleased to announce that we've partnered with organizations dedicated to creating a more equitable society.
ABM has pledged support to the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Funds, Hispanic Scholarship Fund, Afterschool Alliance, and Thurgood Marshall College Fund.
We're collaborating with these organizations to make an impact in advocacy, civil rights, basic needs, education, and workforce development.
We had just begun discussing the coronavirus and its economic impact.
I emphasized how our diverse portfolio and adaptable business model have been key to our long-term success over the past 110 years.
Our performance over the last year has undoubtedly proven this, and our strong financial position makes us better equipped than ever to pursue growth and profitability, increasing shareholder value.
The commitment of the ABM team continues to drive our consistent quarterly performance.
Our company culture is unparalleled in the industry.
I'm proud that our results have clearly demonstrated our resilience, adaptability, and excellence.
Today marks my 100th day at ABM, and my initial impressions of the organization's collaborative and execution-driven culture have only been reinforced.
As I continue to assess our business needs, I will focus on identifying the right catalysts for strategic growth and ongoing improvement.
Our strong recent performance and market leadership position provide an excellent opportunity to invest in our future growth potential.
I look forward to finalizing our internal investment strategy and sharing it with you throughout the year.
Let's move on to the results.
Quarterly revenue was $1.5 billion, a 7.5% decrease from last year.
The revenue decline reflects COVID-19's ongoing impact across our business segments.
Remember, the pandemic didn't significantly affect operations until our second quarter last year, so this quarter shows the full year-over-year impact.
The revenue decline was partially offset by continued demand for higher-margin disinfection-related Work Orders and EnhancedClean services.
Work Orders were particularly strong in our Business & Industry and Technology & Manufacturing sectors.
Our GAAP income from continuing operations was $74.6 million or $1.10 per diluted share, compared to $27.9 million or $0.41 last year.
The increase was due to strong operational performance and favorable developments in prior year self-insurance adjustments.
We saw an $11.4 million benefit this year compared to $6.6 million in the first quarter of fiscal 2020.
We also recorded a positive insurance trend benefit of about $3 million for the second consecutive quarter.
Adjusted income from continuing operations increased to $68.3 million or $1.01 per diluted share, up from $26.2 million or $0.39 last year.
Our earnings growth was driven by significant increases in higher-margin Work Orders and EnhancedClean services.
As clients incorporate health and hygiene services into their operations, we continue to experience higher margins due to efficient labor management.
Results also reflect one less working day, saving approximately $6 million in labor expenses.
Other factors like reduced corporate discretionary expenses, amortization, and interest also contributed to the improved results.
These gains were partially offset by planned investments in infrastructure and organization, particularly in IT.
However, our investment spend for the quarter was about $4 million, lower than initially expected.
We generated adjusted EBITDA of approximately $124 million, with a margin rate of 8.3%, compared to $68.8 million or 4.3% last year.
Now, let's discuss our segment results.
These results reflect COVID-19's ongoing impact, which has led to revenue compression across our services.
Our diversified segment structure has been advantageous during the pandemic, with each segment affected differently.
Most segments show a mix shift towards higher Work Orders and EnhancedClean services, labor adjustments due to lower service demand, and operational investments in areas like EnhancedClean.
B&I revenue was $809.4 million, down $11.5 million or 1.4% from last year.
The parking and sports and entertainment businesses were the main drivers of the revenue decline due to the pandemic.
This decline was almost entirely offset by increased demand for higher-margin Work Orders and EnhancedClean services from national accounts and corporate clients, particularly financial institutions.
The segment's operating profit reflected this more favorable business mix, resulting in $85.7 million or a 10.6% margin, compared to last year's $38.2 million and 4.7% respectively.
Technology & Manufacturing remains one of our most resilient segments.
T&M delivered robust results for the quarter, maintaining its strong performance since the pandemic's onset.
The division reported $249.2 million in revenue, a 6.5% increase from the previous year, with an operating profit of $26.9 million, representing a 10.8% margin rate.
Demand for T&M services was driven by work orders and EnhancedClean offerings, particularly in industrial manufacturing, pharmaceuticals, and high-tech industries.
We also saw growth with our logistics clients as we assisted them during the busy holiday period.
Our Education division increased revenues to $209.4 million, with an operating profit of $21.5 million, equating to a 10.2% margin.
We believe these outcomes indicate some stabilization as schools have maintained the hybrid learning approach implemented since the latter half of last year.
The performance was mainly due to effective direct labor management resulting from adjusted staffing levels and other cost savings, as well as demand for disinfection and COVID-related work orders.
Going forward, we expect a partial return to a traditional selling season in 2021, which was largely absent last year due to the pandemic.
We are closely monitoring how schools will adapt their teaching methods in the current climate, especially as vaccine distribution progresses.
Aviation reported revenue of about $143 million with an operating profit of $3.2 million.
As expected, this segment remained the most affected by COVID-19 and its impact on global travel.
The quarter experienced a slight sequential increase in travel during the holiday season, but quickly reversed due to lockdowns in areas like the UK.
We continue to operate based on flight and passenger demand, offering advanced services such as electrostatic spraying while managing variable costs and expenses in real-time to match demand.
Technical Solutions reported revenue of $113 million compared to $142 million the previous year.
This decrease was caused by site access issues as clients, particularly in education, continued to restrict entry to their facilities to protect staff, teachers, and students.
However, the backlog remains strong at over $150 million, and we are focused on completing these projects as quickly as possible.
Operating profit was $6 million, representing a 5.3% margin.
Regarding cash and liquidity, we reported positive cash flow in the first quarter, despite this typically being a cash flow negative period.
This includes the deferral of approximately $31 million in payroll taxes from the CARES Act.
We generated over $45 million in cash flow from operations and approximately $39 million in free cash flow for the quarter.
Our strong performance allowed us to end the quarter with total debt, including standby letters of credit, of $851 million and a bank-adjusted leverage ratio of 1.8 times.
Additionally, we concluded the quarter with $378 million in cash and cash equivalents.
Given the consistency of our leverage and cash position over recent quarters, we believe we have achieved operational and financial stability.
As a result, we are reassessing our capital allocation priorities.
In addition to organic investments in our business, we are also exploring potential M&A targets to drive growth and build on our current momentum.
While cautiously re-entering the M&A market, we will also consider opportunistic share repurchases.
We currently have about $145 million remaining in our authorized share repurchase program and will balance any potential activity with our M&A efforts to maintain maximum flexibility.
During the quarter, we paid our 219th consecutive quarterly cash dividend of $0.19 per common share, totaling $12.7 million distributed to shareholders.
Regarding our guidance outlook, we are introducing a fiscal 2021 GAAP guidance range of $2.85 to $3.10 and an adjusted range of $3.00 to $3.25 per share.
Based on our first-quarter performance, we anticipate revenue will continue to improve sequentially, with a return to growth in the latter half of the year.
As growth improves and turns positive, we will need to increase staffing accordingly.
This may result in a partial reduction in the labor efficiencies we've experienced over the past year, but we expect to retain some of these savings based on new opportunities and labor management practices adopted during COVID.
We don't anticipate a significant decrease in demand for higher-margin Work Orders and EnhancedClean services for the remainder of the fiscal year.
We expect our investments to increase throughout the year as we support strategic initiatives, particularly in our IT transformation.
Year-over-year, we anticipate an increase in corporate expenses for the year, although timing may vary quarter-to-quarter, as seen in the first quarter.
Additionally, we implemented furlough and expense reduction measures during the third quarter of last year, so we expect to see a year-over-year increase in expenses as we've resumed some of those expenditures.
We are still planning and designing our technology roadmap and will provide updates as we finalize our plans.
It's worth noting that we will have an extra working day in Q2 and one less working day in Q3.
Each working day should represent approximately $6 million in labor expenses, similar to Q1.
We continue to expect an effective tax rate of about 30% for 2021.
This tax rate excludes discrete tax items such as the work opportunity tax credit and the tax impact of stock-based compensation awards.
At the end of December, WOTC was officially extended by Congress through 2025, with current estimates suggesting a $5 million or $0.07 impact on 2020.
While we're not providing guidance on free cash flow until we can determine the impact of our tech transformation on capital expenditures, I want to express my enthusiasm for the strong start to the year.
Given our strong cash flow performance to date, we believe we'll be able to achieve a range above our historical $175 million to $200 million and look forward to updating you as we finalize our longer-term plan.
In conclusion, we're excited about our quarterly performance and our outlook for the year, and we look forward to updating you on our continued progress next quarter.
Summary:
output:
q1 adjusted earnings per share $1.01 from continuing operations.
q1 gaap earnings per share $1.10 from continuing operations.
for fiscal 2021, company expects gaap income from continuing operations of $2.85 to $3.10 per diluted share.
for fiscal 2021, company expects adjusted income from continuing operations of $3.00 to $3.25 per diluted share.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:The COVID-19 pandemic has created immense challenges globally, and we continue to support those affected.
We appreciate our employees and sales teams in Japan and the US for their dedication in assisting policyholders and communities impacted by the pandemic.
Our focus remains on our core mission of offering protection products to help consumers in times of need.
While the pandemic has affected our backlog, we maintain robust capital and liquidity positions.
Our investments are well-diversified, high-quality, and generate some of the industry's best returns on capital with low costs.
This quarter was significantly influenced by new US tax regulations allowing greater use of foreign tax credits.
Our Japanese subsidiary is taxed as a US domestic company for US tax purposes.
We recorded a cumulative year-to-date benefit of $202 million or $0.28 per share from these regulations compared to our previous rate.
Regarding Aflac Japan, COVID-19 continued to impact our results, with sales declining 32% in the third quarter.
About half our Japanese workforce is still working remotely, and customer traffic at shops remains at 70% of pre-pandemic levels.
While sales have improved sequentially, reduced face-to-face interactions have clearly affected results, leading us to promote virtual sales methods.
Japan has experienced political changes, with Prime Minister Suga succeeding long-serving Abe.
We expect Suga's administration to maintain policy continuity, fostering a favorable business climate and focusing on COVID-19 response and economic policies.
Suga is pushing for regulatory reforms and digital transformation post-pandemic, aligning with Aflac Japan's ongoing paperless initiatives.
In Aflac US, COVID-19 also significantly impacted results, with third-quarter sales down 35.7% due to limited face-to-face interactions.
Business closures and restricted worksite access have particularly affected our career agents who rely on in-person meetings with small business owners.
We're cautiously optimistic for modest sales improvement in Q4, typically a strong period for broker-driven group market sales, which have been more resilient to remote conditions.
We're set to finalize our acquisition of Zurich's Group Benefits business, expanding our distribution reach to brokers and large employers.
To strengthen Aflac's position, we're balancing growth investments with long-term cost reductions.
We offered a generous voluntary separation package, resulting in a 9% reduction in US and corporate workforce, with expected one-time expenses of $45 million in Q4.
We launched a US initiative promoting wellness benefits to policyholders, reminding them of coverage for routine medical visits and COVID-19 testing.
This campaign and the separation program may create short-term profit margin pressures but should benefit us in 2021.
We're committed to meeting customers where they prefer to purchase insurance, which now includes accelerating investments in virtual sales tools for both Japan and US markets.
We maintain a strong focus on prudent liquidity and capital management, including robust capital ratios and strategic capital allocation.
We're proud of our 38-year track record of dividend growth, supported by our strong capital position and cash flows.
We repurchased $400 million of shares in Q3, maintaining a tactical approach to buybacks.
We're working to integrate our growth investments to emerge stronger from this period.
Our goal is to achieve our earnings per share targets while fulfilling our commitments to policyholders.
We look forward to discussing our strategic growth plans and efficiency initiatives at the upcoming Financial Analyst Briefing.
Japan has reported about 97,000 COVID-19 cases and 1,730 deaths.
Aflac Japan's COVID-19 impact includes 1,750 unique claimants with incurred claims of approximately JPY550 million in Q3 and JPY760 million year-to-date.
These figures are well below our stress test assumptions, with minimal impact from COVID-19 claims.
However, reduced sales and delayed product launches are pressuring revenue, partially offset by improved persistency.
The quarter saw COVID-related expenses of 1.7 billion yen, which included implementing virtual distribution tools, providing employee teller equipment, and supporting distribution
The situation in the United States is understandably more intricate
COVID-19 cases in the US have surpassed 8.5 million, with fatalities approaching 230,000
By the end of Q3, there were 12,800 COVID-19 claimants in the US, with incurred claims of about $23 million for the quarter and $57 million year-to-date
We're carefully observing the recent infection surge, but continue to see hospitalization rates, hospital stays, and ICU transitions below our projections
We attribute this to improved treatments and the generally younger, healthier workforce among policyholders
As Dan mentioned, we initiated a campaign early in Q3 to remind policyholders of their wellness benefits, leading to increased usage
This effort involved reaching out to 2.7 million accident and hospital policyholders through email and direct mail in August
This affected our benefit ratio for the period but aims to reinforce our products' value proposition
We've seen minimal impact on persistency so far, but believe this is partly due to state executive orders mandating premium grace periods
These executive orders remained in effect in 13 states at the quarter's end
In states where executive orders have expired, we've mitigated lapse rates through proactive outreach to policyholders and employers, converting policyholders from payroll deduction to direct billing, and notifying them of wellness benefits
Regarding key operational initiatives in Japan and the US, we're balancing growth investments while addressing our expense structure
A significant factor in elevated expense ratios in Japan and the US is revenue weakness, necessitating a balanced approach
In Japan, we're set to introduce a simplified cancer rider in Q4 and launch our updated medical product in Q1 2021
Implemented in late October, we have the technology to shift from face-to-face to virtual sales and offer a completely digital customer experience
We continue direct mail campaigns enhanced by data analytics to improve close rates
We anticipate that product development, pandemic recovery, and our alliance with Japan Post will be crucial growth drivers as we progress through 2021
We view the pandemic as a catalyst for accelerating investment in our digital roadmap and related process improvements
In our Q2 call, I mentioned our paperless initiative across all Japanese operations
This is a three-year, roughly 10 billion yen investment, with about 2 billion yen spent in Q3 and another 3.6 billion yen estimated for Q4
While increasing our 2020 expenses, this effort will reduce paper production and circulation by 80 million pieces annually, with projected annual savings of around 3 billion yen
Moving into Q4, we've budgeted a general and administrative expense increase of approximately 6 billion yen over Q3
This includes 50% of our 2020 annual advertising spend, concentrated in the quarter to raise awareness of new products, as well as increased investment in the paperless initiative
We're effectively accelerating investments in our digital platform into 2020 and 2021
In the US, the development of network, dental, and vision coverage is progressing as planned
We've successfully filed our new network products in 48 states, with approvals received in 37
We're operational with sales in 10 states and expect to expand this as we enter 2021
Our consumer markets platform remains on schedule, with hospital accident and cancer product filings expected to be completed in early 2021
We also plan to include life insurance in 2021, recognizing it as a natural product for digital sales, leveraging the Aflac brand
Lastly, we'll soon finalize our Zurich Benefits acquisition, having obtained the necessary regulatory approvals
Along with efforts to improve overall persistency, these are the three main drivers of earned premium growth in the coming years
Anticipating further pressure on near-term earned premiums as we enter 2021, we're addressing US expenses urgently
We're tackling expenses across two horizons
Horizon one focuses on the near term and includes a series of 2020 actions designed to reduce annualized run-rate expenses by approximately $100 million as we enter 2021
This encompasses both the US platform and corporate expenses
Early in Q4, we completed a voluntary separation plan for eligible employees, resulting in a 9% reduction in our US workforce
We expect to record a one-time separation expense of about $45 million in Q4 and realize annualized run-rate savings of $45-50 million
Horizon two expense initiatives increase near-term expenses until the investment is complete, legacy platforms are decommissioned, and business processes are adjusted
The most significant investment is in our group business, migrating from an old administrative platform to a new one
Additionally, we're completing a broader digital roadmap, which includes about $25 million of accelerated investment in 2020, much of it coming in Q4
As mentioned, we need to balance these expense initiatives with growth investment
We've adopted a buy-to-build acquisition strategy
While a tactical and prudent use of excess capital, this is not inexpensive in the early years
These build efforts include dental and vision, direct-to-consumer, and Group benefits, which collectively impacted our Q3 expense ratio by 110 basis points and are expected to impact Q4 by approximately 160 basis points
I'll conclude with investment conditions
Our global investment team remains focused on asset quality, monitoring economic conditions, and sourcing new investment opportunities in a low-interest-rate environment
We firmly believe we'll experience a check mark-shaped recovery, meaning a slow road to recovery with pockets of volatility along the way
Our pre-pandemic actions to tactically improve our portfolio's risk profile, combined with some additional de-risking earlier this year, have served us well, resulting in only modest losses on security sales, impairments, and loss reserve increases
These actions have also positioned the portfolio defensively, should a second virus surge impact economic conditions
We continue to closely monitor our middle market loan and transitional real estate portfolios
While we've seen credit rating downgrades, our middle market loan portfolio is more resilient, consisting of first-lien loans to high-quality borrowers backed by strong equity sponsors
Our transitional real estate portfolio also consists of only first-lien positions and is diversified with strong loan-to-value ratios
We continue to explore ways to optimize currency hedging
Overall, there's no material change, but we're further refining our approach to managing unhedged dollars in Japan
These unhedged dollars provide diversification and income benefits while lowering our enterprise exposure to the Yen
Looking towards 2021, we'll reset 2020 hedges on our floating rate portfolio and currency hedges at significantly lower rates
While we don't anticipate this significantly impacting net investment income, you'll see line item impacts on Japan's net investment income, hedge costs, and corporate investment income
To conclude, we are maintaining crucial investments for long-term growth and efficiency despite what we believe are temporary declines in sales and earned premiums.
We will provide more information about this at our upcoming Annual Financial Investor Conference, including details on investments and when we expect them to start positively impacting growth and profits.
I will now hand over to Max to provide a more detailed analysis of our financial performance.
I'll begin by reviewing our third quarter results, focusing on the development of our core capital and earnings drivers.
In the third quarter, adjusted earnings per share grew by 19.8% to $1.39, with foreign exchange having no significant impact.
Adjusted book value per share, including foreign currency translation gains and losses, increased by 17.4%, and the adjusted return on equity, excluding foreign currency impact, was a robust 16.8%, significantly higher than our cost of capital.
This quarter was notably affected by the release of favorable US tax regulations concerning the use of foreign tax credits.
As a reminder, for US tax purposes, our Japanese subsidiary is treated as a US domestic company.
We recognized a cumulative year-to-date benefit from these regulations in the quarter, which reduced our tax rate on adjusted earnings to 4.1%, providing a $0.28 benefit compared to our previous rate.
Our quarterly tax rate was further reduced by tax credits from our solar and historic rehabilitation investments, which lowered our tax expense by about $20 million more than usual.
Additionally, variable investment income exceeded our long-term return expectations by $6 million, and these two factors combined boosted our current quarter earnings per share by approximately $0.03.
Going forward, under the current US corporate tax system, we anticipate our tax rate on adjusted earnings to be around 20%.
Shifting focus to our Japan segment.
Total earned premium for the quarter decreased by 3.3%, primarily due to first sector policies pay up effects, while earned premium for third sector products declined by 1.7%.
Japan's revenue trends should be considered in the context of paid-up policy impacts.
For instance, year-over-year, earned premium dropped 3.3% in the quarter, while policies in force decreased by slightly less than 1%.
This discrepancy obscures the strength of persistency, which has been increasing during the pandemic.
In essence, expenses related to managing our in-force business tend to remain stable despite the decline in reported earned premium, putting pressure on our expense ratio.
Japan's total benefit ratio for the quarter was 71.3%, up 130 basis points year-over-year, and the third sector benefit ratio was 61.7%, up 170 basis points year-over-year.
The main reason for the increase was reduced lapses associated with policyholders updating their coverage.
Given the current lower new business activity, this naturally elevates our benefit ratio due to lower reserve releases, decreases back amortization, and improves reported persistency.
We experienced all of these effects in the third quarter, as evidenced by our persistency improving by 80 basis points year-over-year.
The IBNR was also less favorable this quarter.
We've observed a decrease in paid claims during the pandemic, particularly in our medical coverages.
Our IBNR estimate has only partially reflected this decrease due to limited data for making adjustments.
We continue to monitor the situation and will adjust our paid data as it becomes more complete.
Furthermore, for cancer claims older than three years, we extended the completion of claims, resulting in a smaller IBNR release compared to 2019.
Japan's expense ratio was 21.7%, up 110 basis points year-over-year.
Our paperless initiative has accelerated as we digitize our operations and improve efficiencies throughout the value chain, aiming for a future state with significantly reduced paper usage.
Overall, considering COVID-related expenses, promotional spending, and digital and paperless initiatives, we expect Japan's expense ratios to remain elevated around 22% for the rest of 2020.
Net investment income decreased by 0.2% in yen terms, despite higher variable investment income, as our yen-denominated portfolio generated lower yields due to reduced call income this quarter.
Japan's pre-tax margin for the quarter was 19.4%, affected by both the higher benefit ratio and increased expense ratio.
Moving on to US results.
Earned premium declined by 2.6% due to weaker sales performance.
Premium persistency improved by 80 basis points to 78.8%, as our efforts to retain accounts and key premium in-force show early positive results.
As Fred mentioned, 13 states still had premium grace periods in place at the end of Q3, so we are closely monitoring these developments.
Our total benefit ratio was 48.3%, which was 80 basis points lower than Q3 2019.
We have observed a normalization of claims activity across our portfolio compared to the second quarter.
To enhance customer experience and persistency, we conducted an extensive policyholder communication campaign highlighting the embedded wellness benefit in our accident product and encouraged policyholders to use this benefit.
We estimate this initiative generated additional claims of about $14 million and impacted our benefit ratio by approximately 100 basis points above normal expectations.
However, we believe our efforts will add value for customers, improve their experience, and enhance long-term persistency.
The US expense ratio was 37.3%, up 130 basis points year-over-year.
The inclusion of Argus added 80 basis points in the quarter, and the decline in revenues largely explains the remaining year-over-year impact.
The effect of declining revenues on our ratios has become more pronounced this quarter compared to previous quarters.
We anticipate US expense ratios to remain elevated around 39% for the full year 2020, driven by near-term revenue weakness, an increase in seasonal business activity, and the expected inclusion of the Zurich Group Benefits acquisition.
US net investment income decreased by 4.4% due to a 14 basis point contraction in portfolio yield year-over-year.
US segment profitability remains healthy at 20.5%, with the low benefit ratio as the primary driver.
In our corporate segment, amortized hedge income contributed $22 million on a pre-tax basis to the quarter's earnings, with an ending notional position of $5 billion.
Our capital position remains strong, ending the quarter with an SMR above 900% in Japan and an RBC of approximately 700% in Aflac Columbus.
Our RBC is temporarily boosted by delaying statutory subsidiary dividends to Q4.
We still expect to end the year with an RBC in the range of 550% to 600%.
Holding company liquidity stood at $3.8 billion, $1.8 billion above our minimum balance.
This is lower compared to earlier in the year but reflects our decision to delay regular Q3 subsidiary dividends to Q4.
On an annual basis, we expect uninterrupted dividend flows to continue from our subsidiaries.
Leverage improved to a comfortable 22.9% due to the increase in shareholders' equity driven by the release of the tax valuation allowance of $1.4 billion.
While we remain cautious in monitoring the pandemic, we are confident in the strength of our capital ratios, excess capital, statutory earnings, dividend capacity, and our ability to navigate current and future stresses brought on by the pandemic or associated economic conditions.
During the quarter, we repurchased $400 million of our own stock and paid dividends of $192 million.
We will continue to be flexible and tactical in managing the balance sheet and deploying capital to drive a strong risk-adjusted return on equity with a significant spread to our cost of capital.
Before we begin, please limit yourself to one initial question and one related follow-up question to allow other participants an opportunity to ask questions.
Adrian, we'll now take the first question.
Summary:
output:
q3 adjusted earnings per share $1.39.
in yen terms, aflac japan's net premium income was Â¥336.5 billion for quarter, or 3.3% lower than a year ago.
aflac - expect run-rate annual savings in range of $45 to $50 million, will record one-time expense associated with separation plan of about $45 million in q4.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:We're glad you could all join us today to review our Q2 fiscal 2021 results.
Notably, over two-thirds of our workforce are considered essential, and they've continued to show up daily, allowing us to maintain our service to customers.
I'm extremely grateful for the efforts of our entire staff.
Concerning our operations, as mentioned previously, we've observed a stabilization in our commercial volumes and continued robust performance in our government sector.
Although we're still facing challenging and unpredictable circumstances, we're optimistic about the stabilization and the promising vaccine developments, which will not only safeguard our employees but should eventually lead to increased travel and a revival in our commercial markets.
Our revenue declined by 28% year-on-year from $561 million to $404 million, while our adjusted diluted earnings per share from continuing operations fell by 52% from $0.64 to $0.31.
Sales to our commercial clients decreased by 48%, while those to government and defense customers rose by 13%.
During this quarter, sales to government and defense clients accounted for 52% of our total revenue.
Our Aviation Services division experienced a 6% growth compared to the first quarter.
This increase was due to higher volume in our MRO operations, which typically sees a seasonal uptick in Q2 compared to Q1, as well as the ongoing strength of our government business.
Our commercial parts volumes remained relatively steady throughout the quarter, staying above the lows experienced in April and May.
I'm particularly pleased with our progress in improving margins.
In recent quarters, we've streamlined our operations across the company, reduced indirect and overhead costs, restructured or terminated several underperforming contracts, and sold off a non-core business that was generating losses.
The effects of these actions are now becoming evident in our adjusted operating margins, which saw a significant improvement from 2.5% to 4% sequentially on stable revenue.
Regarding cash flow, we generated $28 million from continuing operations and decreased our accounts receivable financing program by nearly $7 million, further enhancing our already robust balance sheet and reducing our net leverage to less than 1 times EBITDA.
We continue to secure substantial new business opportunities that set us up for future growth.
Our partnership with Fortress for CFM56 engines ensures a reliable supply to meet the increasing need for used serviceable material on -5B and -7B variants.
We anticipate a rise in demand for USM across all sectors as we recover from the pandemic, with particularly high demand for these engine types.
The Navy's renewal of our contract to support C-40 aircraft acknowledges our excellent performance over the past five years and expands our responsibilities for the next five-year period.
It's significant that this contract was awarded to an incumbent for the first time, highlighting the exceptional quality of our service.
Furthermore, our decade-long agreement with Honeywell to be the exclusive authorized service center for 737 MAX Electronic Bleed Air System components puts us in a prime position to assist MAX operators globally when the aircraft resumes service.
These recent contracts, along with others announced in recent months like the Unison expansion, represent nearly $1.7 billion in total contract value secured this fiscal year so far.
This showcases the distinct value of our Aviation Services offerings, and these business successes will contribute to our faster recovery following the economic downturn.
Our quarterly sales of $403.6 million decreased by 28% or $157.3 million compared to last year, primarily due to the pandemic's impact on commercial air travel.
Comparing to the previous quarter, Aviation Services sales increased by 5.9% or $21.4 million, while Expeditionary Services sales decreased by 50% or $18.6 million.
The quarter-to-quarter decline in Expeditionary Services was attributed to two main factors.
Firstly, the composites business was fully discontinued at the end of Q1, which had generated $7 million in revenue during Q1 but none in the current quarter.
Secondly, as mentioned before, mobility experienced an exceptionally strong Q1 due to increased pallet shipments.
Within Aviation Services, our government and defense sector grew by 19% or $30 million year-over-year, reflecting strong performance on existing contracts.
During both this quarter and Q1, our program to deliver two C-40 aircraft to the U.S. Marine Corps generated substantial revenue due to increased activity.
The gross profit margin for the quarter rose to 17.2% from 15.3% in the same quarter last year, primarily due to CARES Act payroll support.
Compared to the first quarter's 12.1%, the gross profit margin increased, reflecting our efforts to reduce indirect costs and eliminate underperforming contracts and product lines.
Selling, general, and administrative costs totaled $43.4 million for the three-month period.
After adjustments, SG&A expenses amounted to $38 million, or 9.4% of revenue, which is $13 million less than the same period last year, demonstrating a reduction in our overhead expenses.
Of this cost reduction, roughly $3.2 million came from temporary cuts in pay and benefits, which were reinstated on December 1.
Regarding our previous statement, we have been negotiating with the Justice Department about an investigation into airlift under the False Claims Act.
We recorded an additional $6 million accrual in discontinued operations during the quarter, bringing our total reserve for this issue to $8 million based on our most recent settlement proposal.
Our continuing operations generated $27.6 million in cash from operating activities this quarter.
This includes a $6.8 million cash outflow as we continue to shrink our accounts receivable financing program.
Excluding the accounts receivable financing program, cash flow from continuing operations' operating activities was $34.4 million.
The value of inventory decreased by $12.7 million over the quarter.
Our net debt at the end of the quarter stood at $112.1 million, a reduction of $37 million from $149.3 million at the close of Q1.
Our financial position and liquidity remain robust with a net leverage of 0.95 times adjusted EBITDA, $110 million in unrestricted cash, and about $390 million in unused capacity on our revolving credit facility.
Consequently, we are in a strong position to fund what we anticipate will be unique opportunities for business growth in the upcoming quarters.
Generally, we are satisfied with our performance given the current circumstances and pleased with the improvements we've made in operational efficiency.
As I mentioned earlier, we are encouraged by the various vaccines entering the market and the plans for their distribution for several reasons.
We anticipate that as vaccines are distributed and infection rates decline, travel restrictions will be eased and air travel will resume.
Until that time, we expect revenue to remain relatively stable, and we will maintain our focus on generating cash flow and improving profit margins.
We will also continue to concentrate on securing new business opportunities, and I'm confident that our strong financial position, coupled with airlines' growing interest in our cost-effective value-added services, will lead to even more growth prospects.
Summary:
output:
second quarter sales of $404 million, down 28% from the prior year reflecting the impact of covid-19.
qtrly adjusted diluted earnings per share from continuing operations of $0.31, which excludes impact of cares act support, other items.
q2 adjusted earnings per share $0.31 from continuing operations excluding items.
q2 sales $404 million versus refinitiv ibes estimate of $409.4 million.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:These documents can be found in the Investor Relations portion of applied.com.
The call will employ non-GAAP financial metrics, which are subject to the qualifications mentioned in those documents.
We at Applied wish you and your loved ones good health, safety, and resilience during these times.
I'll begin with an update on our business, including our ongoing pandemic response, progress on internal projects, and insights into the external environment.
Dave will then present our financial results, specifics about our first quarter, and our outlook, after which I'll conclude with some final remarks.
As we enter early fiscal 2021, we're witnessing a slight upturn gaining traction and performing well.
The year's beginning is promising, and I believe we're well-positioned to build upon this positive momentum moving forward.
Our operations are running efficiently.
Our supply chain and stock levels are in good shape, and we're effectively meeting customers' growing needs as an initial demand recovery seems to be taking place.
Over the past few quarters, we've swiftly adapted to the changing landscape, implementing new procedures and methods to support our customers' requirements.
A crucial aspect of our message to all stakeholders during these changing times is how Applied is more robust now than in previous cycles.
This includes advantages from our expanded offerings, increased technical focus, and a more diverse end market mix.
We've also enhanced our marketing and sales efforts to highlight our comprehensive and leading technical offerings and to further develop our cross-selling opportunities.
We are increasingly vital to our customers as maintenance, production, and efficiency requirements begin to increase across their core operational infrastructure.
These factors are providing near-term sales support and make us increasingly optimistic about our growth potential going forward.
Furthermore, investments in systems, talent, analytics, and operational processes in recent years are yielding additional benefits in the current climate.
We swiftly adjusted our cost structure and are once again demonstrating our operational discipline and the resilience of our business model.
This is evidenced by better-than-expected decremental margins in the quarter and ongoing strengthening of our balance sheet following strong cash generation performance and a nearly 30% reduction in net debt levels compared to the previous year.
Our capabilities and company-specific opportunities, combined with the improving outlook, position us to be a growth leader with increasing earnings potential as we enter the next phase of recovery in the industrial economy.
This is demonstrated by our recent acquisition of Advanced Control Solutions earlier this month.
ACS represents the next step in expanding our automation offering, further differentiating our value proposition, diversifying our end market mix, and enhancing our growth profile to include next-generation industrial solutions.
Regarding the broader demand environment, underlying trends remained below prior year levels during our first quarter as business activity continued to adjust to the ongoing pandemic.
However, customer order activity improved sequentially throughout the quarter, and we continue to gain traction with our internal growth initiatives.
As a result, the year-over-year organic sales decline of 13.4% in the quarter improved significantly from the 18.4% decline in the previous quarter.
Year-over-year organic sales declines improved each month, and sequential trends in daily sales rates were seasonally strong.
We're beginning to see increased maintenance activity and break/fix requirements as customers allow greater access to their facilities and expand equipment utilization while production gradually ramps up, including at smaller local accounts.
Feedback from our sales leaders suggests order sizes are increasing, customer inventory levels are being replenished, and maintenance projects are being authorized as businesses increase activity and new safety protocols support a productive path forward.
Additionally, we saw several industry verticals return to growth during the quarter, with 10 of our top 30 verticals showing year-over-year increases compared to only two in the previous quarter.
Sectors such as Food & Beverage, Aggregates, Technology, Chemicals, and Transportation all demonstrated positive momentum.
While weakness remains most pronounced in heavy industries like Machinery, Metals, and Oil & Gas, demand within these verticals appears to be stabilizing and showing slight improvement.
We view these dynamics as a positive sign for the industrial economy and demand for our critical products and solutions.
Nevertheless, the pace of end market improvement remains gradual and at times inconsistent.
Organic sales through our first 18 business days of October are down by mid-teens percent compared to the prior year.
We experienced some softening in sales early in the month following a strong end to our fiscal first quarter.
Sales trends have improved each week in October, with order momentum increasing sequentially across both our segments month-to-date.
Nonetheless, it's crucial to recognize that visibility remains restricted as we approach the typically slower winter season, with customers continuing to navigate an uncertain economic and pandemic landscape in the short term
Customer purchasing behavior may be more conservative around election periods
As demonstrated in recent quarters, we are adept at managing and performing in this uncertain business climate and will maintain a cautious approach to costs and capital allocation in the near future while concentrating on our internal growth prospects
In general, we're observing indications that support our belief that the worst has passed, and a recovery is beginning to take hold
This is promising as we enter the traditionally stronger second half of our fiscal year, when comparisons become more favorable and we continue to implement our internal growth strategies
As a reminder, a supplementary investor presentation summarizing key financial performance and discussion points is accessible on our investor website for your reference
To elaborate on our first quarter results, total sales decreased by 12.7% compared to the same quarter last year
Acquisitions contributed 1.1% growth, which was partially counteracted by an unfavorable foreign currency impact of 0.4%
After accounting for these factors, sales declined by 13.4% on an organic basis, with an equal number of selling days year-over-year
Regarding sales performance by segment, as shown on slides six and seven
Sales in our Service Center segment decreased by 14.9% year-over-year, or 14.4% on an organic basis
The decline reflects the ongoing impact of COVID-19, including reduced industrial production activity and customer facility restrictions, which continues to affect MRO demand across our service center network
However, the 14% organic decline year-over-year shows an improvement from the 21% decline in the previous quarter
Furthermore, average daily sales rates increased by more than 4% sequentially, surpassing the normal seasonal progression
As Neil mentioned, we observed increased maintenance activity and break/fix demand
More customers are granting access to their facilities and releasing working capital spending following a slow period during the summer months
Year-over-year declines remain most significant in the Metals, Oil & Gas, and Machinery end markets, but were offset by underlying improvements in Food & Beverage, Pulp & Paper, Aggregates, Forestry, and Chemical Industries, as well as continued growth in our Australian operations
In our Fluid Power & Flow Control segment, sales decreased by 7.4% compared to the same quarter last year, with our August 2019 acquisition of Olympus Controls contributing 3.8 points of growth on approximately half a quarter of remaining inorganic contribution
On an organic basis, segment sales declined by 11.2%, reflecting lower demand across Industrial, Off-Highway Mobile, and process-related end markets
This was partially offset by sales growth in Technology, Life Sciences, Food & Beverage, and Chemical end markets during the quarter, as well as ongoing progress with our cross-selling initiatives and strong sales activity across our emerging automation platform
Regarding margin performance, as highlighted on Page eight of the presentation, gross margin of 28.9% decreased by approximately 50 basis points year-over-year, or 40 basis points when excluding noncash LIFO expense of $1.1 million in the quarter and $0.4 million in the prior year quarter
Year-over-year declines primarily reflect unfavorable mix tied to sales declines across our local service center accounts, although more modest relative to last quarter, as well as more subdued pricing opportunities given the softer demand environment
Nevertheless, on a sequential basis, gross margins improved by 13 basis points, or 17 basis points when excluding LIFO expense, and were slightly ahead of our expectations
While we anticipate some of the volume-driven year-over-year headwinds to persist in the near term, we remain focused on driving annual gross margin expansion as demand levels normalize, reflecting benefits from our systems investments, the positive contribution of expansionary products, strategic growth driven by our technical service-oriented solutions, and initiatives to expand business across our local customer base
Additionally, we are beginning to observe a slightly higher level of supplier price increase announcements, which, combined with firming demand, could provide some positive momentum for pricing contribution and margin expansion into the second half of our fiscal year
Regarding our operating costs, selling, distribution, and administrative expenses decreased by 13.4% year-over-year, or approximately 15% when excluding incremental operating costs associated with our Olympus Controls acquisition
Both of these figures exclude $1.5 million of nonroutine costs in the prior year quarter
The year-over-year decline reflects the ongoing benefit from various actions we've taken in recent quarters to align expenses with lower demand
This includes a mix of both structural and temporary cost actions as we continue to assess the environment
While we have begun to roll back some of the temporary actions, our team continues to demonstrate great discipline in controlling costs and identifying internal opportunities
Combined with improving sales trends during the quarter, we reported a 9.5% decremental margin on operating income during our recent fiscal first quarter, which exceeded our expectations and highlights the adaptability and durability of our operating model
Moving forward, we will remain prudent and disciplined in maintaining our cost structure as we continue to gradually roll off temporary cost actions to align with our recent performance, a more constructive outlook, and our growth initiatives
EBITDA for the quarter was $67.6 million, down 13.6% compared to adjusted EBITDA of $78.2 million in the prior year quarter, while EBITDA margin was 9%, down a modest 10 basis points over the prior year despite the double-digit sales decline
We reported net income of $34.8 million or $0.89 per share, down from adjusted net income of $39.9 million or $1.02 per share in the prior year quarter
Shifting our focus to cash flow performance and liquidity.
In Q1, operations generated $81.8 million in cash, with free cash flow at $78.2 million, equating to roughly 225% of net income.
These figures increased from $50 million and $45 million respectively compared to the same quarter last year, marking a record Q1 for cash generation.
The quarter's robust cash performance reflects ongoing benefits from our working capital strategies and the countercyclical nature of our business model's cash profile.
Due to strong cash flow in the quarter, we concluded September with over $271 million in cash, approximately 75% of which was unrestricted and held in the U.S.
Notably, this is after using $62 million in cash to reduce debt during the quarter.
Since early 2018, we've reduced our debt by over $200 million, including more than $80 million in the past year.
Our net debt has decreased by nearly 30% year-over-year, and our net leverage was 2.1 times adjusted EBITDA at quarter's end, lower than the previous year's 2.3 times and the year before at 2.6 times.
Furthermore, our credit line remains unused with about $250 million available and an additional $250 million Accordion option.
Combined with extra capacity on our uncommitted private shelf facility, we have ample liquidity and a strong balance sheet as we enter what seems to be a recovering market.
This financial flexibility allows us to fund increased working capital needs in upcoming quarters as customer demand improves and to pursue strategic acquisitions aligned with our growth plans when opportunities arise.
Our immediate acquisition strategy focuses on smaller, complementary targets that align with our growth priorities, particularly in automation and fluid power sectors.
Now, let's discuss our future outlook.
There's limited visibility on how customers will operate during the traditionally slower winter months.
However, to provide some near-term guidance based on October trends and assuming normal seasonal patterns in daily sales rates for the rest of the quarter, we anticipate fiscal Q2 2021 sales to decrease 13% to 14% organically year-over-year.
This projection includes an assumption of low-teen organic declines in both our Service Center segment and Fluid Power & Flow Control segment.
This guidance is intended to provide a starting point for how Q2 sales might develop if trends follow typical seasonality over the next two months.
If customers reduce production or extend plant closures, organic declines could exceed the 13% to 14% estimate.
Conversely, if industrial activity continues to improve and our internal growth initiatives gain traction, organic declines could be less severe than the 13% to 14% projection.
Additionally, we expect our recent acquisition of ACS to contribute approximately $6 million in sales during our fiscal second quarter.
Based on the projected 13% to 14% organic sales decline, we believe a low double-digit to low-teen decremental margin is a reasonable expectation for our second quarter.
This assumes gross margin will remain relatively stable compared to first quarter levels and accounts for the gradual reversal of temporary cost-cutting measures.
As mentioned, we will continue to manage our operating costs carefully, including ongoing focus on internal opportunities and margin initiatives, which we expect to balance our cost trajectory moving forward.
We're pleased with our cost and margin performance year-to-date, which provides flexibility to further reverse temporary cost-cutting measures as we take an proactive approach to an emerging recovery and our strategic growth targets.
We maintain that an effective tax rate of 23% to 25% is still a reasonable assumption in the near term.
Lastly, regarding cash flow, we anticipate a moderation from first quarter levels for the remainder of the year, given potential increased working capital requirements as we support growth and recovery throughout the year.
We remain confident in our cash generation potential over the business cycle and reaffirm our normalized annual free cash target of at least 100% of net income.
Overall, I'm pleased with our start to the year.
Our team has demonstrated remarkable resilience over recent quarters, driving improved performance into early fiscal 2021 and positioning us to respond to and capitalize on the ongoing recovery.
We've proven our business model's durability, strengthened our financial position, and optimized our cost structure.
We're leveraging our unique and differentiated industry position to lead industrial growth in the emerging recovery and in the years ahead.
These factors are reflected in our first quarter results and provide further evidence of our positive trajectory.
From our industry-leading technical MRO capabilities to our Engineered Solutions focus, multichannel cross-selling opportunity, and expanding automation platform.
We have multiple catalysts to expand our market potential and accelerate market share gains in coming years, while driving additional margin expansion.
This aligns with our long-term targets of $4.5 billion in sales and 11% EBITDA margins, which are achievable and provide the framework for accelerating earnings power and long-term stakeholder returns.
Summary:
output:
compname reports q1 earnings per share $0.89.
q1 earnings per share $0.89.
applied industrial technologies - due to ongoing uncertainty from covid-19 pandemic, continues to refrain from providing financial guidance for fy2021.
compname says project q2 sales to decline 13% to 14% year over year on organic basis.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Craig Lampo, Amphenol's CFO, is present alongside Adam Norwitt, the CEO.
The company achieved record-breaking sales of $2,323 million and unprecedented GAAP and adjusted diluted earnings per share of $1.12 and $1.09 respectively in the third quarter.
Compared to the same period last year, sales increased by 11% in US dollars and 10% in local currencies.
The third quarter saw a 9% organic growth in sales.
Sequentially, there was a 17% increase in sales in US dollars and a 15% rise in both local currencies and organic growth.
The interconnect division, accounting for 96% of total sales, grew by 11% in US dollars and 10% in local currencies compared to the same quarter last year.
The cable division, making up 4% of total sales, experienced a 2% growth in US dollars and a 5% increase in local currencies compared to the third quarter of the previous year.
Adam will provide more details on market trends shortly.
The third quarter of 2020 saw an operating income of $476 million.
Operating margins reached 20.5%, showing a significant sequential increase of 250 basis points and an 80 basis point improvement compared to the same period last year.
The substantial sequential margin improvement was due to efficient conversion of higher sales and an anticipated significant reduction in COVID-related expenses.
The year-over-year margin improvement was attributed to effective conversion of increased sales.
In the interconnect segment, third quarter 2020 margins were 22.4%, up from 21.7% in the same quarter of 2019 and 20% in the second quarter of 2020.
The cable segment saw margins of 10.7% in the third quarter of 2020, an increase from 10.2% in the same period of 2019 and 9.4% in the second quarter of 2020.
We are extremely proud of our performance this quarter, given the unprecedented challenges posed by the COVID-19 pandemic.
Our team's ability to navigate the impacts of this crisis is a direct result of our company's entrepreneurial management team's strength and dedication, which continues to foster a high-performance, action-oriented culture, enabling us to seize opportunities and maximize profitability in an uncertain market environment.
The quarter's interest expense was $28 million, down from $30 million in the same quarter of the previous year.
The company's GAAP effective tax rate for the third quarter of 2020, including an $11 million excess tax benefit from stock option exercises, was 22.1%, compared to 24.5% in the third quarter of 2019.
Excluding the mentioned excess tax benefit, the company's adjusted effective tax rate remained at 24.5% for both the third quarters of 2020 and 2019.
The adjusted net income of $336 million represented 14% of sales in the third quarter of 2020, further confirming the company's strong financial performance.
On a GAAP basis, diluted earnings per share grew by 22% to $1.12 in the third quarter of 2020, up from $0.92 in the same period of 2019.
Adjusted diluted earnings per share increased by 15% to $1.09 in the third quarter of 2020, compared to $0.95 in the third quarter of 2019.
Orders for the quarter totaled $2,275 million, a 9% increase compared to the third quarter of 2019 and a 15% sequential rise, resulting in a book-to-bill ratio of 0.98 to 1.
The company continues to demonstrate excellent cash generation abilities.
The third quarter saw strong cash flow from operations of $398 million, or 119% of adjusted net income.
Our free cash flow was $330 million, equivalent to 98% of adjusted net income.
At the end of September, inventory, accounts receivable, and accounts payable stood at $1.4 billion, $1.9 billion, and $1.1 billion respectively.
Inventory days, days sales outstanding, and payable days were 79, 72, and 61 days respectively, all showing improvement from the second quarter and falling within our normal range.
During the third quarter, our $398 million cash flow from operations, along with $104 million from stock option exercises, were primarily used to repurchase 1.9 million company shares for $202 million (average price of $108), pay $75 million in dividends, fund $68 million in net capital expenditures, finance $50 million in acquisitions, and make $9 million in net short-term investments.
This increase will take effect for payments starting in January 2021.
As of September 30, cash and short-term investments totaled $1.5 billion, with the majority held outside the US.
Total debt as of September 30 was $3.8 billion, with no maturities due before the third quarter of 2021.
Net debt as of September 30 stood at $2.4 billion.
At the end of the quarter, total cash on hand plus remaining credit facility availability amounted to $4 billion.
Third quarter EBITDA was $568 million, and our pro forma net leverage ratio was 1.2 times.
First and foremost, I hope that everyone on this call, along with your families, friends, and colleagues, is staying safe and healthy during the pandemic.
As Craig mentioned, I will highlight some of our third quarter achievements and, more importantly, discuss trends and progress across our served markets.
I will then comment on our outlook for the fourth quarter and the full year 2020.
Regarding the third quarter, in what has clearly been an unprecedented and volatile year, I'm truly proud that Amphenol achieved record sales and adjusted earnings per share, significantly surpassing the guidance we provided just 90 days ago.
Sales reached $2,323 million, representing an 11% increase in US dollars, 10% in local currencies, and 9% organic growth compared to the previous year.
This strong growth was driven by increases in mobile devices, IT-datacom, industrial, military, broadband, and automotive markets, partially offset by declines in commercial air and mobile networks markets.
We are particularly proud of achieving a robust 17% sequential growth from the second quarter, significantly exceeding our original expectations.
As Craig mentioned, the company received $2,275 million in orders, representing a book-to-bill ratio of 0.98 to 1.
Despite ongoing pandemic-related operational challenges, we achieved excellent third quarter operating margins of 20.5%, a significant 250 basis point improvement from the second quarter.
The company's financial position remains robust, with operating cash flow reaching $398 million, particularly noteworthy given the stronger-than-expected sequential growth from the previous quarter.
We continue to utilize our financial strength to benefit shareholders through stock repurchases and a 16% increase in our quarterly dividend, as announced today.
I'm immensely proud of the Amphenol team's accomplishments.
The record results this quarter undoubtedly demonstrate the value of our entrepreneurial organization's agility, discipline, and drive.
Regarding trends in our served markets, Amphenol's balanced and diverse end market presence proves to be an invaluable asset, especially during times of economic uncertainty.
As many markets began recovering in the third quarter, we swiftly capitalized on growth opportunities while maintaining our broad exposure to new developments across the electronics industry.
The military sector accounted for 12% of our third quarter sales.
This market's sales grew by 6% year-over-year, primarily driven by increases in military vehicles, naval, space, communications, and airframe applications.
Our sales increased sequentially by a robust 30% as we rebounded from the impact of production restrictions at certain facilities due to government-imposed COVID-19 control measures in the second quarter.
We anticipate a slight increase in sales for the fourth quarter compared to current levels.
For the full year 2020, we project a low-single digit sales increase compared to the previous year.
This annual performance reflects our strong market position and execution, partially offset by pandemic-related production constraints experienced in the first half of 2020.
I'm very impressed with our global military market team's efforts.
They've maintained unwavering focus on ensuring our defense industry clients have uninterrupted access to our cutting-edge interconnect products, which are vital to our customers' equipment.
We're encouraged by both the accelerating adoption of electronics in these systems and the generally favorable defense spending environment.
Our investments in new technologies and large-scale production capabilities over recent years have positioned us well to capitalize on these trends for the foreseeable future.
The commercial aerospace sector represented 2% of our third quarter sales.
Sales declined by a significant 40% as the commercial aircraft market again experienced unprecedented demand reductions for new aircraft due to pandemic-related disruptions in the global travel industry.
Sequentially, our sales performed slightly better than expected, increasing 4% from the second quarter.
Looking ahead, we anticipate the commercial air market will continue to be negatively impacted by the substantial reduction in global air travel demand.
Consequently, we expect an approximate 20% sequential decrease in our sales to this market in the fourth quarter.
For the full year 2020, we project a roughly 35% decline from the previous year due to the unprecedented demand disruptions our customers are experiencing.
Undoubtedly, these are challenging times for the entire travel industry, severely impacting the near-term commercial airplane market.
Nonetheless, our team remains committed to leveraging the Company's strong technological position across various aircraft platforms and next-generation systems integrated into those planes.
We remain well-positioned for when this market eventually returns to growth.
The industrial market accounted for 22% of our quarterly sales.
Our industrial market sales surpassed expectations, growing by 21% in US dollars and 18% organically, a very strong performance.
This robust growth was particularly driven by the instrumentation, medical, industrial battery, heavy equipment, alternative energy, and rail mass transit segments, reflecting broad-based growth in the industrial market.
Although we had anticipated slightly lower sales compared to the second quarter, we actually achieved 11% sequential growth in the third quarter, a very strong performance.
For the fourth quarter, we expect a slight decline from these third quarter sales levels.
Nevertheless, for the full year 2020, we project a low-double digit sales increase from 2019 levels, an outstanding performance given the overall market conditions.
I'm truly proud of our industrial market team's efforts.
Whether facilitating growth in various medical equipment volumes, managing significant demand increases for semiconductor capital equipment, or executing on unprecedented demand for next-generation batteries, our global organization has quickly adapted to fully support our worldwide customers, despite numerous operational challenges arising throughout the COVID-19 pandemic.
Looking long-term, I'm confident that our performance during this crisis has positioned us very strongly for the future.
Importantly, we continue to lead the development of next-generation interconnect, sensor, and antenna products to support our industrial market customers, who are accelerating their adoption of cutting-edge technologies.
The automotive sector represented 17% of our third quarter sales.
Following a truly challenging second quarter where the global automotive industry was severely impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic, we were pleased to see a strong recovery in the third quarter, with results significantly better than initially anticipated.
Our team's outstanding execution led to a year-over-year sales increase of 4% in US dollars and 1% organically, surpassing our expectations.
Sequentially, our sales grew by a remarkable 78% from the second quarter as our team swiftly capitalized on recovering demand from automotive customers across all regions.
Looking ahead to the fourth quarter, we expect automotive sales to further increase in the mid-single digits from these levels.
For the full year 2020, we anticipate a low-double digit sales reduction, reflecting the severe and sudden pandemic-related downturn in demand from automotive OEMs observed in the first half.
I'm extremely proud of our automotive market team, who has clearly demonstrated both agility and resilience in achieving these strong sequential growth levels.
In fact, our performance through this crisis strengthens my confidence in our long-term prospects in the automotive market.
We have consistently broadened our selection of interconnect, sensor, and antenna products through internal development and acquisitions, aiming to support a diverse range of onboard electronics in various vehicles produced by global automakers.
This ongoing approach is likely to continue providing advantages as the automotive industry recovers.
Mobile devices accounted for 16% of our quarterly sales.
Our sales to mobile device customers grew by an impressive 25% compared to last year, primarily due to increased sales of products used in laptops, tablets, and wearables, partially offset by slightly lower smartphone sales.
Our sales increased by a remarkable 37% compared to the previous quarter.
This growth was driven by higher sales across all product categories we serve.
We anticipate a slight increase from these already strong third quarter levels in the fourth quarter.
For the entire year, we expect sales to grow in the low double digits compared to 2019.
It's worth noting that this performance significantly exceeds our initial expectations before the pandemic hit.
Although mobile devices remain one of our most volatile markets, our exceptional and adaptable team is ready to seize any opportunities for additional sales that may arise in the fourth quarter or beyond.
Our leading range of antennas, interconnect products, and mechanisms continues to support a wide variety of next-generation mobile devices, positioning us well for the future.
The mobile networks market represented 6% of our quarterly sales.
Sales decreased as expected, dropping 19% in US dollars and 21% organically compared to last year, due to lower sales to wireless operators and continued impact from US government restrictions on certain Chinese entities.
We expect a further seasonal sales reduction of about 25% in the fourth quarter, affecting both OEMs and service providers.
For the full year, we anticipate a high-teens reduction in sales, reflecting the impact of US government restrictions and the COVID-19 pandemic.
Despite short-term challenges in the mobile networks market, we remain confident in our long-term position in this important and dynamic industry.
Our team continues to work diligently to expand our opportunities with next-generation equipment and networks.
As customers increase investment in these advanced systems, we look forward to benefiting from the increased potential that comes from our unique position with both equipment manufacturers and mobile service providers worldwide.
The information technology and data communications market accounted for 21% of our quarterly sales.
Third-quarter sales once again exceeded our expectations, increasing by a robust 24% in US dollars and 21% organically compared to last year.
This growth was driven by increased demand for data traffic, prompting both OEM and service provider customers to increase their demand across nearly all segments of the IT-datacom market.
Sequentially, sales decreased by less than expected, dropping 10% from our exceptionally strong second quarter.
