Looking ahead to the fourth quarter, we expect a mid-teens sequential decline from these very strong third-quarter levels.
For the full year 2020, we anticipate sales to increase in the low teens, reflecting the significant upside in demand we experienced in both the second and third quarters, partially offset by pandemic-related disruptions in the first quarter.
Our team supporting the IT-datacom market has clearly distinguished itself this year, quickly capitalizing on unprecedented demand for our industry-leading high-speed and power products.
Simultaneously, we've maintained our efforts to further develop our wide range of industry-leading interconnect products for data communications networks worldwide.
We remain very encouraged by our strong technology position in the global IT-datacom market.
Our customers continue to push their equipment to higher performance levels to manage the dramatic increases in bandwidth and processor power demand.
In response, our team remains focused on enabling this ongoing revolution in IT-datacom.
The broadband market represented 4% of our quarterly sales.
Sales increased by 5% compared to last year, driven by stronger demand for home installation-related equipment from broadband operators.
Sequentially, sales increased by a stronger-than-expected 13% as our customers continued to upgrade their networks to support increased demand for high-speed data.
We expect sales in the fourth quarter to moderate from these levels due to typical end-of-year seasonality.
For the full year 2020, we anticipate sales to be roughly flat compared to the previous year.
This reflects pandemic-related disruptions in certain regions, offset by increased customer investments to support higher bandwidth demand.
Looking ahead, while our third-quarter performance was very strong, significant uncertainties remain in the global market due to the COVID-19 pandemic, which appears to be worsening in some parts of the world.
Assuming no new major disruptions from the pandemic and constant exchange rates, we expect fourth-quarter sales between $2,160 million and $2,200 million, with adjusted diluted earnings per share between $0.98 and $1.00.
This represents both sales and adjusted diluted earnings per share growth of flat to 2% compared to last year.
Our fourth-quarter guidance also implies full-year sales of $8,333 million to $8,373 million and full-year adjusted diluted earnings per share of $3.59 to $3.61.
This outlook represents sales growth of 1% to 2% compared to last year and an adjusted diluted earnings per share decline of 3% to 4%.
The expected decrease in earnings is directly related to the significant costs and disruptions associated with the COVID-19 pandemic that the company faced, particularly during the first half of 2020.
I'm extremely pleased with Amphenol's third-quarter performance, especially our team's achievement of new quarterly records in both sales and earnings.
Most importantly, I remain very confident in our outstanding management team's ability to adapt to ongoing market challenges and capitalize on future opportunities to grow our market position and improve profitability.
I want to assure you that our entire organization remains committed to securing the company's financial performance while wholeheartedly dedicating ourselves to protecting the safety and health of each of our employees worldwide.
Summary:
output:
amphenol corp q3 adjusted earnings per share $1.09.
third quarter 2020 record results and dividend increase reported by amphenol corporation.
q3 adjusted earnings per share $1.09 excluding items.
q3 gaap earnings per share $1.12.
for q4 2020 expect adjusted diluted earnings per share in range of $0.98 to $1.00.
for full year 2020 expect adjusted diluted earnings per share to be in range of $3.59 to $3.61.
on oct 20, board approved 16% increase in co's quarterly dividend, from $0.25 to $0.29 per share to be first paid on jan 6, 2021.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Our website is broadcasting the current discussion.
Bob Wetherbee, Board Chair, President and CEO, and Don Newman, Senior Vice President and CFO, are joining today's call.
While focusing on second quarter highlights and key messages, Bob and Don may reference certain slides in their comments.
These slides can be found on our website.
The slides offer additional information and details about our results and outlook.
It's been over a year since the COVID-19 pandemic caused a global lockdown.
The past four quarters have seen numerous changes, and it's tempting to concentrate on the more difficult aspects of this time.
However, it's crucial to recognize that we also made positive changes to things within our control.
We quickly adapted our digital technology infrastructure to excel in remote collaboration, like many others.
Technology enabled us to optimize our processes and work more productively overall.
We plan to continue enhancing these improvements by using new skills and tools to offer more flexibility to our employees and build stronger connections with our customers, while also realizing the related structural cost savings.
I'm happy to see many people traveling by air again for the summer season.
Each day brings new signs of recovery in airframe and jet engine demand.
The current economic revival, from travel to consumer goods to energy, is genuine.
Despite ongoing pandemic-related uncertainties, I'm sure the desire to travel is strong and increasing worldwide.
This ultimately sustains the long backlog for commercial airliner programs.
ATI is prepared to meet our customers' production needs.
Given this context, our second quarter financial results demonstrate the improving trends in our end markets.
However, they also reflect the negative impact of the recent strike by the United Steelworkers at our Specialty Rolled Products (SRP) business.
Excluding the $40 million cost attributed to the strike and a minor adjustment to our restructuring reserves, we experienced a loss of $0.12 per share in the second quarter.
Despite the earnings loss, the aerospace recovery is clearly evident in the underlying numbers.
Our jet engine product revenues increased by over 20% compared to the first quarter of 2021.
The High Performance Materials & Components (HPMC) segment saw its margins improve by more than 200 basis points sequentially and nearly 300 basis points year-over-year.
Don will provide more detailed information on this positive news shortly.
As mentioned in our April first quarter earnings call, we were extremely disappointed that the union leadership decided to call a strike at our major SRP operating locations.
Our comprehensive continuity plans allowed us to maintain operations during the strike.
The new 4-year labor agreement was approved on July 13.
Many represented employees resumed their positions within a week of ratification.
We are safely and efficiently ramping up operations to their previous production levels.
We are on schedule and expect to return to full production capabilities in September.
Many people inside and outside of ATI have asked me some version of the question, "Was the strike worth it?"
Certainly, we would have preferred to continue negotiations to reach an agreement without a work stoppage.
A competitive cost structure for this business is crucial.
If left unresolved, we would have faced rapidly escalating healthcare costs that were projected to double every seven years.
Product pricing cannot increase fast enough to offset that level of healthcare inflation.
The SRP business would have fallen behind its competitors.
We were compelled to find a solution now.
Under this contract, annual healthcare cost inflation will be limited to 3.5%.
The represented employees are responsible for taking any necessary actions to cover annual overage amounts.
The SRP business is now appropriately focused on returning to full speed and providing our customers with the materials and components they need.
To conclude my comments about the SRP business, I have two pieces of good news to share.
Firstly, the transformation initiative to discontinue standard stainless sheet products is progressing as planned and will be completed by the end of 2021.
We are making excellent progress in consolidating our footprint.
Secondly, we recently entered into a long-term agreement with JSW Steel USA to toll convert a significant percentage of their Ohio-produced carbon steel slabs through our hot rolling and processing facility in Pennsylvania.
This multi-year agreement provides a significant opportunity to increase our asset utilization and cash flow.
We are pleased to collaborate with JSW to bring the exceptional quality and gauge control of our world-class HRPF to their customers.
We are currently increasing production.
Congratulations to the operating team for setting a production record for carbon steel toll conversion volume in June, even during the strike at this facility.
What are we observing in our key end markets?
For the first time in several quarters, the news is positive across most of our portfolio.
This excludes the strike impact from the comparison.
I believe this provides the most accurate view of our underlying performance and true market demand.
In this context, sales increased sequentially in each of our major end markets, except for electronics, which is being compared to record results in Q1.
We experienced year-over-year sales growth in most of our primary markets, with Energy increasing by 60% and Defense by 22%.
We're gaining traction in our biggest key market, commercial jet engines.
This is mainly due to the recovery of narrow-body platforms, especially engine programs for A320 and A321 aircraft.
As previously mentioned, the demand recovery started in our Forgings business, which has lead times 6-9 months ahead of engine production.
Our Forgings revenue surpassed both last year's and last quarter's levels due to market recovery and recent market share gains.
We anticipate this positive growth trend to continue and expand as increased 737 MAX production rates become a larger part of our order book.
The growth in Jet Engine Specialty Materials has been slower than Forgings, primarily due to excess inventory throughout the supply chain.
As anticipated, this inventory is being used up, though at an uneven pace depending on the customer and product type.
In Q2, sales of our Specialty Materials like Rene 65 for LEAP engines grew significantly compared to Q1, but were still lower than last year.
We expect demand for materials to keep increasing for narrow-body engines, but remain slow for wide-body engines.
This uneven demand, along with any remaining inventory, will result in somewhat irregular growth quarter-to-quarter for the rest of the year.
The airframe market in commercial aerospace continues to be weak.
This is mainly due to the well-known sluggish demand for wide-body aircraft caused by reduced international travel and excess supply chain inventory.
We expect this trend to persist throughout 2021 and possibly into early 2022 as the industry waits for a catalyst to increase wide-body production rates.
Our newly acquired European OEM Airframe business starts production in the second half of 2021, initially at low levels.
This will partly offset the expected inventory reduction pressure at our main domestic airframe customer.
As mentioned earlier, Defense remains a growth market for ATI.
Our diverse materials portfolio serves customers with a wide range of demanding applications, ensuring our success under almost any defense budget or economic conditions.
Our Q2 growth was driven by naval nuclear applications and rotorcraft products to support increased demand for U.S. Navy ships and heavy-lift helicopters.
We expect our Defense business to continue growing and are seeing titanium armor plate demand return in the second half of 2021, supporting a new U.K. armored vehicle program.
Regarding the Energy markets, we saw significant growth, mainly in our specialty energy portfolio.
These increases primarily supported land-based gas turbine production in Asia where energy demand is rising.
Sales to civilian nuclear customers contributed to this growth.
Looking forward, we anticipate continued improvements in Energy markets as the world gradually reopens from pandemic lockdowns and economic growth drives increasing energy needs.
To conclude the market discussion, results were mixed in our two smaller differentiated markets.
We observed the expected return to growth in medical applications as hospitals perform more elective surgeries and diagnostic testing procedures.
Both our MRI and Implant Materials sales increased sequentially.
We anticipate demand to improve moderately over the coming quarters, led by MRI.
In the Electronics market, sales decreased from record levels in Q1 2021, but grew year-over-year.
Sales of ATI's specialty alloy powders increased compared to both prior periods.
We expect demand for these products to remain strong for the rest of 2021.
I'd like to address several areas, including our Q2 financial performance, our balance sheet, and our outlook.
On a reported basis, ATI lost $0.39 per share in Q2.
Excluding $40 million of strike-related costs and a small favorable adjustment to our restructuring reserves, the company lost $0.12 per share in Q2.
To fully understand our performance, it's necessary to look beyond the headlines.
As we mentioned in the last two earnings calls, the commercial aerospace recovery, particularly in jet engines, is gaining momentum and becoming more widespread within our business.
This is evident in our HPMC segment results, where jet engines account for over 40% of overall segment revenues.
As Bob shared, jet engine revenues increased by more than 20% sequentially for ATI as a whole and for HPMC.
Volumes in our Forgings business continue to expand, building on growth from the previous two quarters.
Underlying demand for our Specialty Materials accelerated significantly for the first time since the pandemic began.
In addition to jet engines, revenues in each of HPMC's key end markets grew compared to Q1, led by specialty energy, including materials for land-based gas turbines produced in Asia.
Due to our profitable jet engine growth and increased asset utilization, HPMC EBITDA margins increased by 220 basis points compared to Q1 and nearly 300 basis points versus Q2 2020.
We anticipate Q3 growth across HPMC's key end markets, most notably jet engine and specialty energy, and further utilization benefits from increasing production rates across our network.
We expect robust incremental margins over the coming quarters as profitable jet engine revenues increase and structural cost improvements executed throughout 2020 are maintained.
Q2 financial results were clearly impacted by the 105-day strike in the SRP business.
It's worth noting that while we removed strike-related costs from segment earnings, segment revenues also declined nearly $140 million compared to Q1 due to plant outages and resulting production declines.
No adjustments were made for these revenue headwinds.
Despite the short-term impacts on 2021 performance, we achieved the necessary long-term cost structure changes that will help SRP compete more effectively in the specialty materials marketplace.
Regarding the AA&S segment, our Precision Rolled Strip business in Asia continues to operate at robust levels with revenues in line with its record-setting Q1, well above the previous year.
Earnings from this business were below Q1 levels due to unfavorable mix.
Earnings from our SA&C business were below Q1 and the previous year, largely due to unfavorable mix and elevated production costs.
Looking ahead in the AA&S segment, we expect the SRP business to begin recovering in August.
Due to the prolonged strike in July and inefficiencies in restarting production, we expect additional costs of about $25 million in the third quarter.
We anticipate strong performance from the Asian Precision Rolled Strip division during its typically busiest season, as device makers prepare for holiday sales.
The SA&C division is likely to see slightly lower earnings sequentially due to scheduled maintenance shutdowns in the third quarter.
It should be noted that corporate costs and closed company expenses in the second quarter were higher compared to the previous year and quarter.
Corporate expenses exceeded last year's figures primarily due to incentive compensation accruals, and were higher than the previous quarter mainly because of foreign exchange losses.
Closed company expenses surpassed both the first quarter and previous year, largely due to non-recurring benefits in those earlier periods.
As we've mentioned in recent quarters, our decisive cost-cutting measures from 2020 continue to benefit the company.
These actions help minimize decremental margins during periods of declining year-over-year revenue.
We anticipate these measures will positively impact the bottom line when revenues return to year-over-year growth.
The second quarter results of the HPMC segment provide a glimpse of what can be expected in upcoming quarters.
Despite flat HPMC revenues compared to the previous year, earnings increased by 30%.
This earnings growth was achieved primarily by increasing production rates at numerous segment facilities and streamlining cost structures.
Nevertheless, there is still room for improvement.
Some facilities, such as our nickel powder operations in Bakers, North Carolina, continue to operate on reduced schedules due to low demand.
Meanwhile, others are still producing large quantities of lower-margin transactional products as commercial aerospace markets recover.
Let's now discuss the balance sheet and liquidity.
As has been the case throughout the pandemic, we've taken steps to enhance our debt profile and have prioritized our balance sheet to ensure sufficient cushion against any potential challenges.
Despite the recent strike, we concluded the quarter with approximately $830 million in total liquidity, including at least $475 million in cash.
Our managed working capital levels increased in the second quarter, partly due to higher inventories in our SRP business resulting from strike-related inefficiencies.
Accounts receivable and accounts payable balances also contributed to the higher working capital levels in the second quarter.
We remain focused on improving inventory turnover as we increase production.
We anticipate working capital levels as a percentage of sales to improve significantly in the latter half of the year.
Looking forward, we plan to contribute up to $50 million to our U.S. defined benefit pension plan in the third quarter to enhance our funding status and long-term leverage profile.
This contribution exceeds minimum requirements but aligns with our goal to reduce pension exposure.
Furthermore, we will continue to actively manage our debt maturity profile in the coming quarters.
As mentioned earlier, we expect continued improvement in our Jet Engine business, driven by growth in Specialty Materials and ongoing benefits from our cost structure.
In the AA&S segment, we anticipate higher sequential SRP volumes.
We will also experience increased maintenance and production costs due to a temporary production shutdown related to our transformation efforts.
Our SA&C business will be negatively affected sequentially by its typical summer maintenance shutdowns, resulting in lower revenues and higher expenses compared to the second quarter.
We expect earnings from our Asian Precision Rolled Strip business to increase sequentially due to higher electronics volumes.
As a result of the new USW labor agreement, we have reduced our contractual funding requirements for post-retirement medical benefits.
This will result in a one-time non-cash pre-tax gain of approximately $65 million in our third quarter results.
This benefit and the associated $15 million tax charge will be excluded from our adjusted earnings.
Overall, we expect third quarter adjusted earnings to range between breakeven and a loss of $0.08 per share, excluding strike-related costs and the $65 million post-retirement medical accounting gain.
Gains in the HPMC segment will likely be partially offset by maintenance shutdowns and production expense challenges in the AA&S segment.
While we cannot accurately predict fourth quarter results due to ongoing uncertainties in the aerospace production ramp-up, we expect adjusted earnings to return to profitability in Q4 and continue improving in 2022.
Lastly, due to the negative impact of strike-related earnings, we now anticipate full-year free cash flow to be at breakeven to slightly positive levels.
We will work diligently to offset the strike's cash impact by maintaining discipline in capital spending and aggressively seeking working capital improvements throughout the latter half of the year.
I am confident we will achieve our goal of generating positive free cash flow in 2021.
We are eager to accelerate along this path of end market recovery and fully expect a leaner ATI to demonstrate its capabilities, expanding market shares and margins in the process.
Our second quarter financial results showed solid sequential improvement.
We are observing commercial aerospace recovery in our forward order load.
We sense momentum building at ATI, particularly within our HPMC segment.
Improving aerospace market conditions will greatly benefit ATI as we have streamlined our cost structures and have higher shares of critical, high-growth customer programs.
I am confident that when these volumes return to pre-pandemic levels, we will be an even stronger and more profitable company.
The AA&S segment will benefit from growth in defense, energy, medical, and electronics sectors.
Transformation is progressing as planned in our Specialty Rolled Products business.
We have made significant and structural changes to optimize our product portfolio, consolidate and upgrade our facilities, and align our cost structure for future success.
We are developing a leaner and more profitable SRP business that exceeds its cost of capital, has substantial profitable growth opportunities, and can successfully compete for investment within the company.
I'll conclude with three key points.
ATI is a growth-oriented company with the necessary cost structure for success.
We are well-positioned in key markets to achieve above-GDP growth over the long term.
The transformation of our product portfolio is on track and will yield significant benefits.
With a clear strategy and innovative team, we are accelerating our future.
Summary:
output:
q2 loss per share $0.39.
qtrly adjusted net loss attributable to ati was $0.12 per share.
anticipate continued recovery in our jet engine market in q3 driven by increasing narrow body aircraft production rates.
allegheny technologies - while we expect lingering effects on srp business, production will ramp back toward pre-strike levels across balance of q3.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Before we begin, there are a few matters to address.
We will be submitting our 10-Q report to the SEC today.
The SEC has experienced some delays.
However, we will complete this task today.
These cover the quarterly results and our strategic growth plans.
Those viewing online will see the slides appear on their screens.
Audio-only participants can access the slides via our website.
An icon on the homepage allows viewing of these slides.
We'll start with our standard precautionary statement.
Factors such as weather, regulatory changes, competition, and other risks outlined in our SEC filings may impact our performance.
The Company may not update this information in the future.
Our CFO will begin today's call by reviewing the quarter and nine-month results.
Eric Wintemute, our Chairman and CEO, will then discuss our strategic growth initiatives.
Bob Trogele is also available to answer any questions.
We plan to keep you updated on our progress towards these goals, similar to how we report on key business performance indicators like inventory and borrowing capacity.
As Bill mentioned, our 10-Q for the three and nine months ending September 30th, 2020 is scheduled to be filed today.
I'm aware that the agency assisting with our filing currently has a backlog of documents.
This document provides more detailed information on everything I'm covering here.
As previously stated, our Company operates in industries considered critical infrastructure in all our operating countries.
Consequently, our customers and suppliers have largely continued operations without interruption during the pandemic.
This trend persisted through the third quarter.
Nevertheless, the pandemic has affected us in certain ways, such as limiting our ability to present new sales and marketing ideas, including new products, to customers in person.
We've also noticed customer purchasing patterns seem to have moderated due to pandemic-related uncertainties.
Conversely, these restrictions have led to reduced operating expenses.
Managing these market changes has been challenging.
Despite this, we've maintained profitability throughout this difficult period.
For the quarter ending September 30th, 2020, our net sales decreased by 6% to $117 million, compared to $125 million in the same period last year.
Within this overall decline, US sales dropped by about $7.5 million while international sales remained stable.
International sales made up 43% of total net sales, compared to 41% in the same quarter last year.
The key factors influencing our third quarter sales performance are as follows.
In the US crop market, sales were impacted by reduced cotton acreage, which USDA statistics show has decreased by about 11% or 1.5 million acres in 2020.
Lower cotton commodity prices led growers to plant alternative crops.
Our market performance was also affected by severe drought in West Texas and frequent hurricanes in the Southeast USA, both limiting growers' ability to apply our products.
On a positive note, we saw stronger than expected demand for our fumigant products in the potato markets.
This better-than-anticipated performance is attributed to the cautious reopening of schools and restaurants across the United States.
In our domestic non-crop market, there were minor quarter-over-quarter changes, with some decline in pest strip products used in bars and restaurants affected by pandemic restrictions.
Regarding international sales, which were overall flat, three main factors were at play.
Firstly, we had very strong performance in Mexico, Central America, and Australia.
In contrast, our Brazilian sales declined in real terms due to reduced insect pressure and difficulties meeting with customers due to pandemic restrictions.
Additionally, sales translated from local currency to US dollars were further negatively impacted by declining local currency exchange rates quarter-over-quarter.
Lastly, while Mocap and Nemacur sales were lower in Europe, both products saw significant sales increases in other parts of the world.
The table shows that the US crop market experienced reduced sales.
This aligns with reports from other market participants for Q3 results.
Our international business increased as a percentage of consolidated net sales, and our relatively low exposure to foreign currency rate fluctuations was advantageous this quarter.
The nine-month performance reflects similar market dynamics to those described for the quarter.
Our US crop business was affected by reduced cotton acreage and cautious input decisions by growers as the pandemic's impacts unfolded.
To offset this, our fumigant sales performed better than expected as schools and restaurants reopened.
We also benefited from sales of products acquired in fall 2019.
Our non-crop mosquito control business has been slightly below expectations due to storm intensity in our main markets, primarily because vector control districts are using existing inventory.
Lastly, our international sales have performed well despite currency devaluation challenges in some key markets.
Regarding our gross profit performance, the trends are similar for both the quarter and year-to-date.
In our US crop business, the decline in gross profit was driven by lower cotton product sales, partially offset by strong fumigant sales.
In non-crop, reduced sales of Dibrom and pest strips negatively impacted the quarter, somewhat offset by strong sales in our horticultural business, which has slightly lower margins.
We also recorded higher royalty income from our Envance technology business this quarter.
For international business, the impact of declining foreign exchange rates was fully offset in the three-month period and partially offset in the nine-month period by strong performances in Central America, Australia, and Mexico.
As a result of these various factors, gross margin decreased from 38% to 37% for the quarter and from 39% to 38% for the nine-month period.
Our manufacturing performance was strong this quarter, with well-controlled factory operating costs and improved activity compared to 2019.
Generally, our long-term net factory costs amount to about 2.5% of net sales, reflecting some latent capacity in our plants for potential needs.
This available capacity is necessary for effective production planning management.
In the third quarter, our factories cost approximately 2.4% of sales, compared to 2% in the same period last year.
The third quarter is typically a strong manufacturing period for the Company.
During the initial nine-month period, net factory expenses totaled 1.6% compared to 2.4% of net sales in the equivalent timeframe of 2019.
Our operational costs decreased in the quarter ending September 30th, 2020, when compared to the same period in the previous year.
The actual performance surpasses its parent company's published reports because we received a benefit from adjusting earn-out liabilities on previous acquisitions in 2019.
This advantage did not occur again in the current year.
However, we recorded a benefit of about $1 million in the third quarter due to updating our environmental risk assessment for the Brazilian business acquired in early 2019, which reduced our liability in this area.
As previously reported this year, our operating expenses decreased due to lower travel and entertainment costs resulting from pandemic-related restrictions in all our operational jurisdictions.
Our expenses were also reduced due to currency devaluation effects in key markets for the Company, including Mexico, Brazil, and Australia.
For the nine-month period ending September 30th, 2020, our overall expenses have decreased compared to the same period in 2019.
The reported reduction actually underestimates the real improvement because we benefited from $3.5 million in earn-out liability adjustments related to past acquisitions in 2019, which did not recur this year.
Consequently, our underlying costs have decreased by approximately $5.5 million or 5% for the nine-month period.
The factors contributing to reduced costs are similar to those in the quarter.
We've spent less on travel and entertainment due to pandemic restrictions.
Both short and long-term incentive compensation, tied to financial performance, has decreased in 2020 compared to 2019.
Lastly, operating expenses incurred in non-US dollar currencies have decreased due to the devaluation of the previously mentioned currencies.
I've noted unfavorable exchange rate changes in three key currencies from the Company's perspective.
To provide more context on that comment:
If we had used the 2019 exchange rates for both the three and nine-month periods of 2020, our reported net sales would have increased by $3 million for the quarter and $7 million for the nine months.
Regarding gross margin, we would have recorded an additional $700,000 in the three-month period and $1.7 million year-to-date.
Despite these impacts, we've effectively implemented natural hedges.
This means that most of our operating expenses for businesses in each territory are also in local currency.
This mitigates the impact on sales and gross margin, resulting in relatively insignificant differences at the bottom line due to translation exposure.
The Company experienced significant transaction-related exposures during the first quarter of the year.
This has decreased as exchange rates have stabilized at new levels during the second and third quarters.
We recorded lower interest expense in the third quarter compared to the same period last year.
Our average debt was lower than the previous year, and we benefited from reduced borrowing rates in the US.
For the nine-month period, our average debt was slightly higher than the previous year, but we gained from the lower federal base rate, resulting in significantly lower interest expense.
Finally, our effective tax rate continues to decrease compared to the previous year as we have stronger international performance in jurisdictions with lower rates this year compared to last year.
In the three-month period, we earned $0.10 per share compared to $0.11 per share in the same period of the previous year.
For the nine-month period, we earned $0.25 per diluted share compared to $0.34 per share last year.
From my perspective, the Company's operating and financial focus remains as follows:
We continue to follow a disciplined approach in planning our factory activities, balancing overhead recovery with demand forecasts and inventory levels.
At the end of September 2020, our inventories were at $176 million compared to $186 million at the same time last year.
During the intervening periods, we have made acquisitions and added inventory as a result.
The underlying period-over-period improvement in our base inventory before the impact of recent acquisitions amounted to approximately $14 million or 7.5%.
We are highly focused on our balance sheet as we navigate through this pandemic period, and having lower inventories at this point of the year is pleasing to report.
As we look at the final quarter of the year and our target for December 31st, 2020 inventory, Eric will comment shortly about acquisitions that we closed in the first and second week of the final quarter of this year.
Consequently, our inventory forecast will now be amended to incorporate these new businesses.
In previous conference calls, we expected to end in the region of $145 million.
Given our latest operations planning assessment, we anticipate that our underlying inventory will increase slightly from our prior forecast.
Additionally, the new acquisitions that Eric will mention shortly are expected to add approximately $15 million at December 31st, 2020.
Accordingly, our latest forecast is to end the year at approximately $160 million to $165 million, effectively flat with 2019, but including the addition of inventory from recent acquisitions.
Our business has a distinct annual cycle, and we routinely experience expansion in working capital in the first part of the year and a reversal in the second part.
During 2020, like most businesses, we have been highly focused on working capital and its impact on debt levels.
During the period of the year when we typically expand working capital, we have contained the increase to only $5 million compared to adding $49 million in the same period of 2019.
This careful management of working capital is driving the improved cash generated from our operating activities.
In the first nine months of 2020, we have generated $19 million from operations compared to using $21 million in the first nine months of 2019.
Comparatively, that amounts to a positive change of $40 million period-over-period.
At September 30th, 2020, net indebtedness ended at $149 million compared to $165 million at the same time last year.
During the last year, in addition to paying down $16 million in debt, we have funded more than $27 million in investments, including fixed assets, product acquisitions, and technology investments from the cash generated from operations.
These investments are focused on developing our consolidated business for the future.
Regarding liquidity at the end of the third quarter, availability under our credit line was $45 million, which compares to $30 million at the same point in 2019.
In summary, for the third quarter and for the nine-month period, though our sales were down, selling prices and gross margins in each territory remained good.
We are seeing stronger international performance this year, and the mix of US sales (generally higher gross margin) and international sales (generally lower gross margin) is tending to bring the average down slightly.
Our factory performance improved compared to 2019, and our expenses for operating costs, interest, and tax are all lower in 2020 than in the comparable periods of the prior year.
From a balance sheet and cash perspective, we are doing very well, managing working capital, and our debt is lower than this time last year, notwithstanding our investments in long-term growth of our business.
Finally, availability under our credit line has improved.
With that, I will hand over to Eric.
Many of our investors have expressed interest in our strategic direction and longer-term prospects, particularly in light of our increased emphasis on technology innovation.
In that spirit, rather than delving into the details of market conditions over the past reporting periods, I would like to look forward to where we hope to be in the next three to five years.
We have three primary growth platforms within our business: our core business, our green product lines, and our precision application technology led by SIMPAS.
There are synergies between these platforms.
For example, SIMPAS is a market access tool for both core products and green solutions such as Agrinos biologicals.
There is some overlap between these platforms.
For guidance purposes, it's beneficial to examine each platform sequentially.
Our primary business is primarily comprised of our synthetic chemical products.
Let's create a model using a baseline of $468 million in annual sales, based on 2019 figures.
We've expanded our main business through three methods: organic growth via increased market penetration, developing new formulations or finding new uses for existing products, and through company acquisitions.
With a modest annual growth rate of 2%, we'd reach $507 million by the third year and $527 million by the fifth year through organic growth alone.
Now, let's consider our new product pipeline.
We typically introduce multiple new products annually.
In 2020, we released five new formulations.
As these new products gain popularity and we continue to introduce more, we anticipate adding $37 million by year three and $109 million by year five.
Combining our core business and new pipeline products, we project reaching $544 million by year three and $636 million by year five.
Now, let's factor in acquisitions.
While it's challenging to predict the acquisition market, it's currently very active.
We recently completed two acquisitions: Agrinos, a biologicals company, and AgNova, an Australian company that expands our presence in Australia and nearby regions.
If we conservatively estimate $20 million per year from acquisitions, this would add $60 million by year three and $100 million by year five.
Including core business, new product pipeline, and acquisitions, we project a three-year top-line target of $604 million and a five-year target of $736 million.
Let's now discuss our green solutions platform.
Before returning to the model, I'd like to update you on a recent acquisition.
In early October, we purchased Agrinos, Inc. and its sister companies at a favorable price during a liquidation auction by the Norwegian parent company.
Agrinos produces and markets unique biological product blends for various markets and operates three factories.
The Oregon facility ferments a 22-species bacteria consortium into a product that improves soil health and plant growth.
The Mexican facility produces a microbially enhanced chitin-based product with similar applications.
The Indian facility produces biologicals for that region, including sales to the Indian government.
This investment has led us to create a biologicals team to manage these green product offerings globally.
This effort will also include managing the advanced TyraTech business.
Returning to the model, some green solution businesses are already part of our core business.
For this discussion, we'll focus on the additional growth.
By the end of Q3 2020, we were on track to sell about $22 million in green products this year, including biologicals, bio-nutritional products, and essential oil products through Envance.
We'll use this figure as a baseline for our green products platform.
We're already in the consumer pest control market through P&G's Zevo product line and are expanding our essential oil products into other areas like lawn and garden, crop, and public and animal health.
With the addition of Agrinos, growth in other biologicals, and expansion of Envance/TyraTech, we expect incremental revenues of $48 million in year three and $118 million in year five.
Adding green products to our previous projection of core business, product pipeline, and acquisitions would bring us to about $70 million in year three and $140 million in year five.
Now, let's discuss our third platform: precision application.
We've been reporting on our SIMPAS technology, which we believe is at the forefront of prescriptive application systems.
To our knowledge, no other system allows a grower to apply multiple crop inputs variably in multiple rows automatically based on an agronomist's prescription.
Our Ultimus technology can trace products from factory to field and precisely measure usage in any application.
We're also enhancing this technology for seed treatment at planting time.
After positive field trial results in many states, several of our peers are conducting their own tests to make their products available in smart cartridges through SIMPAS.
Some investors have asked for a clearer picture of where SIMPAS could be in three to five years.
To answer this, we'll consider revenue from our existing products applied prescriptively, sales of licensed active ingredients, royalties from third-party products marketed through our smart cartridges, and a share in growers' incremental yield benefits.
Using conservative estimates for domestic market penetration, we're targeting a top-line contribution of $35 million in year three and $131 million in year five.
We're confident SIMPAS will be well-received internationally and are planning field trials in Brazil in 2021.
These figures don't include potential revenues from our seed treatment innovation.
Combining all platforms - Core, Green, and SIMPAS - we project roughly $687 million in year three and $985 million in year five, approximately doubling our current position.
There are many variables in this equation.
We'll continue to control what we can, such as managing working capital and operating expenses.
We're committed to maximizing our consolidated profit margin.
While expansion into international distribution has lowered our gross margin percentage, we expect introducing newer technologies in these markets will improve profitability.
I'll update you on our progress towards these targets in future calls.
Focusing on the present and near term, 2020 has been an unprecedented year for this industry.
Despite the pandemic, weather effects, and farm economy challenges, our Q3 2020 profitability matched Q3 2019, even with slightly lower sales.
Looking ahead to Q4, we're seeing increased optimism in the domestic agricultural sector, partly due to rising crop prices for corn, soybeans, and cotton, which could improve grower profitability.
In the Midwest, with less crop rotation and more continuous corn planting, we're seeing a resurgence of soil insect pressure.
Demand for our soil fumigant products is also increasing.
Based on these trends and current sales activity, we're optimistic about our prospects for the rest of this year and into the 2021 season.
We're now ready to take your questions.
Summary:
output:
compname reports qtrly earnings per diluted share of $0.10.
american vanguard corp qtrly net sales of $117 million, compared with $125 million.
american vanguard corp qtrly earnings per diluted share of $0.10.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Kindly be aware that the financial information presented in this commentary is tentative.
These and other hazards, ambiguities, and crucial elements are elaborated upon in Franklin's recent submissions to the Securities and Exchange Commission, particularly in the Risk Factors and MD&A portions of Franklin's latest Form 10-K and 10-Q filings.
Lexington's operations provide us access to a vital growth sector in the alternative asset industry, and we are thrilled with this new collaboration.
We will discuss this transaction in more detail shortly.
I'll begin by summarizing this year's key achievements.
Matthew will then present our financial performance for the quarter and fiscal year, and dedicate some time to elaborating on today's significant transaction.
Throughout Franklin Templeton's history, we have invested in our operations to create a truly diverse and robust organization that excels across market cycles, committed to serving our clients, employees, and shareholders.
The outcomes we announced today represent the first complete fiscal year since finalizing the Legg Mason acquisition, a transformative deal that established a more balanced business across asset classes, client mix, and geographical regions.
We are glad to report that the strategic and financial advantages from our Legg Mason acquisition surpassed our expectations, and we have incorporated important growth prospects.
We have preserved our culture while stimulating collaboration and innovation across the company.
Through our employees' hard work and dedication, we have successfully merged two firms to maximize our collective potential, combining global strength with boutique specialization.
We've made significant progress, yet in many ways, we're just beginning.
Regarding investment performance, there has been an improvement across a wide range of investment strategies.
As of September, 71%, 69%, 72%, and 77% of strategy composites outperformed their respective benchmarks across the four key time periods.
During the year, we focused on updating our global distribution efforts by enhancing our generalist-specialist model, reshaping client coverage, and deepening relationships in each sales region, especially with the largest global financial institutions.
The fiscal year's long-term inflows doubled to $365 billion from the previous year, notably, the U.S., our largest sales region with over $1.1 trillion in AUM, was net flow positive for the year.
In terms of notable organic growth, we observed positive net flows in our core growth areas, including alternatives, SMAs, wealth management, and ESG-specific strategies.
We executed important acquisitions to further expand and diversify our business in alternative assets, customization, and distribution of investment strategies.
Regarding other accomplishments, our alternative asset strategies, a key focus area for us, generated positive net flows each quarter during the year and grew by 19% from the previous year to $145 billion in AUM, with contributions from various strategies including real estate infrastructure, private debt, and hedge funds.
Several years ago, we announced our intention to create a comprehensive suite of alternative strategies, and we've been very deliberate in building our capabilities.
In 2018, the acquisition of Benefit Street Partners brought us a leading alternative credit manager.
In 2020, we added a world-class real estate manager with Clarion Partners.
This focus on alternatives led us to today's announcement of the acquisition of Lexington Partners, a leader in secondary private equity and co-investments.
We now have top-tier specialist investment managers in all key alternative categories, including Benefit Street Partners, Clarion Partners, Franklin Venture Partners, K2, and now Lexington Partners.
Specifically regarding the Lexington Partners transaction, I'm excited that Franklin will be collaborating with such an outstanding firm led by an experienced and talented team, immediately bringing scale and capabilities in an interactive and growing global market.
There will be no changes to the team or its independent investment management process, and they will continue to operate autonomously as Lexington Partners.
At the completion of this deal, we anticipate our alternative assets under management to reach about $200 billion and revenue to exceed $1 billion, not including performance fees.
Matthew will soon provide more specifics about the transaction.
An additional key growth sector is our individually managed account division.
We rank among the top three providers in separately managed accounts with $125 billion in managed assets, representing one of the fastest-growing areas in retail investing.
Our separately managed account business experienced a 22% year-over-year increase in assets under management and achieved positive net inflows each quarter during the fiscal year.
Our recent purchase of O'Shaughnessy Asset Management and its Custom Indexing Platform, Canvas, will elevate our existing expertise in separately managed accounts, improving our capabilities in tax management, factor-based strategies, and ESG customization.
Canvas, introduced in late 2019, has experienced robust growth since its launch and now accounts for $1.9 billion of the company's total $6.3 billion in assets under management as of September 30.
The acquisition will provide significant advantages to the clients served by both companies across various channels.
It's clear that investors are more concerned with ESG objectives than ever before.
Increasingly, investors consider three aspects of ESG: ESG factors as understood portfolio risks, ESG's contribution to overall returns, and the broader impact of ESG considerations on society and the environment.
As an active manager, about 95% of our assets under management represent strategies that incorporate ESG factors into the investment process, and ESG-specific strategies, accounting for over $200 billion in assets under management, experienced positive net flows each quarter this fiscal year.
Nevertheless, none of our achievements this past year would have been possible without our employees.
We are incredibly fortunate to have such committed colleagues who strive for investment excellence, cultivate lasting relationships, and provide exceptional service to our diverse global investor base.
Fourth quarter long-term net outflows totaled $9.9 million, partially offset by the acquisition of Diamond Hill's high yield-focused U.S. corporate credit mutual funds, which added $3.5 billion in assets under management and was completed in July.
This quarter included the previously announced $5.4 billion 529 plan redemption, comprising $4.7 billion in long-term assets and $2 billion fixed income institutional redemption with minimal revenue impact, as well as $800 million in fixed income outflows from non-management fee-earning India credit funds that are being liquidated.
Reinvested dividends amounted to $2.3 billion this quarter.
A 1% increase in average assets under management of $1.55 trillion compared to the previous quarter, plus $69 million in performance fees, generated $1.66 billion in adjusted revenue for the fourth quarter.
Investment management fees, excluding performance fees, were 3% higher than the previous quarter.
Adjusted operating expenses of $1.01 billion for the quarter were 3% lower due to reduced compensation and decreased general and administrative costs resulting from last quarter's upfront closed-end fund expenses.
This resulted in an 80% increase in adjusted operating income to $647 million and an adjusted operating margin of 39%.
Fourth quarter adjusted net income and adjusted diluted earnings per share rose 31% to $645 million, or $1.26 per share.
These results include favorable discrete tax items of $135 million or $0.30 per share for the quarter.
Regarding the 2021 fiscal year financial results, which benefited from favorable market conditions and a full year of Legg Mason versus two months last year.
For the entire year, adjusted revenues were $6.32 billion and adjusted operating expenses were $3.94 billion, increasing by 63% and 65% respectively.
This led to a fiscal year adjusted operating income of $2.38 billion, which was 60% higher than the previous year.
Our adjusted operating margin was 37.7%.
Relative to the previous year, adjusted net income for the fiscal year rose by 46% to $1.92 billion, while adjusted diluted earnings per share grew by 43% to $3.74, including the effect of favorable discrete tax items totaling $175 million or $0.34 per share for the entire year.
We have successfully reached 85% of our targeted $300 million in merger-related cost savings this year, as originally planned.
We expect to fully realize these synergies by the conclusion of fiscal year 2022.
It's important to note that none of these cost-saving measures affected our specialist investment managers or investment teams.
Regarding capital management, we believe our robust balance sheet continues to offer us financial and strategic flexibility to adapt our business.
We distributed $782 million to shareholders through dividends and share buybacks during the fiscal year ending September 30.
Throughout the year, we also refinanced a significant portion of Legg Mason's existing debt with lower-cost debt, reflecting our improved credit standing.
We issued $850 million of 1.6% senior notes maturing in 2030 and $350 million of 2.95% notes maturing in 2051.
On March 15, 2021, we redeemed $250 million of 6.38% Legg Mason Junior subordinated notes due in 2056, and on September 15, 2021, we redeemed $500 million of 5.45% Legg Mason Junior subordinated notes due in 2056.
We concluded the quarter with $6.93 billion in cash and investments.
We will continue to prioritize our dividend and aim to repurchase enough shares to at least counterbalance our employee equity grants.
The remaining capacity will be directed towards ongoing investments in our business and acquisitions to further diversify and boost our cash flow sources, while positioning our company for new growth opportunities as the industry continues to evolve.
As detailed in the transaction summary, Lexington Partners is a global leader in secondary private equity and co-investments, currently managing $34 billion in fee-based assets.
Since its establishment in 1994, Lexington has raised over $55 billion in total capital commitments and presently employs a team of 135 people across eight global offices.
The company is projected to generate revenue of approximately $350 million and EBITDA of around $150 million in 2022.
With this acquisition, we now possess strong and complementary capabilities in alternative credit, real estate, hedge fund solutions, and private equity-related activities.
Considering the overall size and growth of private equity and the potential for further expansion in private markets, having a specialist investment manager focused on this alternative asset sector is a logical step in diversifying our business.
Moreover, providing access to diversified versions of high-yielding investments will become increasingly important in meeting the savings and retirement objectives of our broad client base.
This could also play a significant role in both our multi-asset solutions business and the ongoing development of our customization capabilities.
As Jenny previously mentioned, this transaction represents an important step towards creating a larger and more diverse alternative asset business, resulting in pro forma fiscal year 2022 alternative asset AUM of approximately $200 billion, generating about $1 billion in annual management fee revenue, excluding performance fees, at a margin of roughly 40%.
We plan to continue adding complementary businesses in both wealth management and asset management, including expansion in asset classes and geographic reach.
This will involve both organic investment through allocating capital to our existing specialist investment managers and through acquisitions.
Given our global presence, financial flexibility, business model, and experience in execution, we can attract highly talented teams and partnerships seeking a combination of independence, support, and collaboration on a global and local scale to create new growth opportunities in a large and expanding segment of the asset management industry.
Regarding the financial aspects of the transaction, we are acquiring 100% of Lexington Partners for $1 billion in cash at closing, plus an additional $750 million in cash over the next three years.
We have structured this deal to ensure continuity and strong alignment of interests with Lexington's clients, partners, and employees over the long term.
In line with this approach, we will simultaneously issue grants equal to 25% of Lexington to its employees, subject to five-year vesting, and establish a performance-based cash retention pool of $338 million to be paid over the next five years.
The transaction is expected to be finalized by the end of our fiscal second quarter, pending customary approvals.
Summary:
output:
compname reports q4 adjusted earnings per share of $1.26.
q4 adjusted earnings per share $1.26.
qtrly total assets under management were $1,530.1 billion at september 30, 2021, down $22.0 billion during the quarter.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:These declarations should not be overly relied upon as they do not guarantee future results.
For a more comprehensive analysis of potential risks affecting our company's future performance and financial status, please refer to B&G Foods' latest Annual Report on Form 10-K and subsequent SEC filings.
Bruce will now present our financial results for the third quarter and provide insights into our expectations for 2021.
The company exhibited robust performance in the third quarter.
Excluding Crisco, our base business net sales increased by 9.2% compared to the same period two years ago, showing improvement from the 7% growth in Q2.
Our Q3 2021 net sales, including Crisco, surpass last year's figures during the COVID period.
Bruce will later discuss specific categories and brands, but we're generally observing strength across our product range.
When compared to pre-pandemic results from the third quarter of 2019, most of our key categories performed well.
Green Giant and spices & seasonings saw double-digit increases in net sales compared to 2019.
Net sales of our leading Mexican food brands, Ortega and Las Palmas, increased by high single digits compared to 2019.
Our baking brands, led by Crisco, Clabber Girl, Baker's Joy, and others, also demonstrated strong performance for the quarter compared to 2019.
While demand remained high, resulting in increased sales.
We are also navigating through many of the same supply chain and cost challenges that have affected the industry.
Inflation for the full year 2021 is in the mid-single digits, with the second half seeing a double-digit increase across the portfolio.
As mentioned in our previous call, inflation on Crisco is significantly higher than the base portfolio due to major increases in soybean and canola oil prices.
We have responded by implementing significant price increases where appropriate, either by raising list prices or optimizing trade to directly offset higher input costs.
Although we accurately identified and addressed inflationary pressures, most of our price increases take effect in the second half, with the largest increase on Crisco becoming effective at the end of September.
We anticipate continued inflationary pressure into the first half of 2022 and will adjust prices to recover year-over-year cost increases.
Additionally, we are implementing aggressive cost optimization measures to counteract ongoing inflation.
Regarding supply, we continue to face shortages in packaging materials, freight delays, and contract manufacturing capacity constraints.
However, overall customer service levels have been improving in recent weeks, aided by lifting allocations on Green Giant SKUs with the new crop pack.
Our aim is to manage our business to maintain stable, steady margins.
For the current portfolio, we target an adjusted EBITDA margin of approximately 18%, using pricing and productivity actions to offset cost pressures on margins.
In the long term, we aim to improve to a 20% adjusted EBITDA margin through accretive M&A, efficiencies, and some organic growth in our base business.
While inflation will make this more challenging in the near term, we believe this is the appropriate target for our business.
During the third quarter, we successfully completed the integration of Crisco.
I want to commend our team for executing a smooth transition.
Crisco is our second-largest acquisition, and we are pleased with its performance year-to-date under our ownership, despite some volatility in commodity prices.
In August, we announced an agreement to sell our Portland, Maine manufacturing facility.
We expect the sale to close during Q1 2022.
Although closing a factory is never an easy decision, it became evident that the 100-year-old Portland facility had reached the end of its useful life and was no longer cost-competitive.
The site will become the future home of the Roux Institute at Northeastern University, which is a positive outcome for the Portland community.
We continue to invest in our existing facilities, including a new high-tech automated line in the Ankeny, Iowa spices and seasonings facility, as well as new lines at our Hurlock, Maryland and Yadkinville, North Carolina facilities to increase our capacity for Ortega Taco Sauces and Taco Shells, respectively.
After four months in the business, I wanted to share the key priorities and choices that the B&G team is focused on.
First, effectively managing B&G Foods through the current inflationary and pricing environment; second, improving organic growth performance beyond COVID recovery; third, focusing on brands and categories where we have the capabilities, scale, and right to win in terms of both resources and structure; fourth, making disciplined acquisitions that are accretive to our portfolio and align with our core expertise in center store dry distribution; and fifth, accelerating cost savings and productivity efforts to eliminate non-value-added costs and strengthen margins. We will provide more details on these initiatives in future calls and discussions, including specific plans and updates.
As Casey mentioned, we achieved strong financial performance during our third quarter, despite a very challenging operating environment.
Net sales remain elevated and are tracking closely to the initial assumptions we used to create our annual budget for fiscal 2021.
In line with our plan for the year, we are showing an acceleration in net sales growth as we progress through the year when compared to last year and our pre-pandemic 2019 numbers.
As we work through the remainder of the year, we are approaching a period that we expect to be more similar to last year â still not quite normal, with more Americans eating at home more frequently than they did pre-pandemic, but also no longer experiencing the height of pantry loading that coincided with the early days of the pandemic.
After adjusting for the impact of Crisco and the extra week in last year's third quarter, we have achieved a net sales increase compared to 2018.
We have observed sales patterns that closely resemble those from the previous year's COVID-19-influenced third quarter.
Industrywide supply chain issues and increased input costs have limited some of the potential gains we would have seen from strong demand.
Some of our brands could have higher sales if certain items weren't out of stock.
Many of our brands have good sales, but profit margins are lower than what we typically expect from our portfolio.
Input costs across our product range are generally up by mid-single digits, with some products like soybean oil, canola oil, transportation, and napkins seeing double-digit increases.
Similar to other food manufacturers, we are actively raising prices where appropriate and reducing costs where possible to maintain profitability and ensure our long-term margin structure.
Let's review the highlights of the third quarter 2021.
We reported $515 million in net sales, $96.4 million in adjusted EBITDA before COVID-19 expenses, $96.2 million in adjusted EBITDA, and $0.55 in adjusted diluted earnings per share.
Adjusted EBITDA, both before and after COVID-19 expenses, was 18.7% of net sales.
Net sales of $550 million increased by $19.2 million or 3.9% from Q3 2020, and by $108.7 million or 26.7% from pre-pandemic 2019.
Crisco, which we acquired in December 2020, generated $71.2 million in net sales in Q3 2021, surpassing our quarterly forecast and significantly outperforming its 2018 sales under previous ownership.
Excluding Crisco, base business net sales decreased by $52.1 million or 10.5% in Q3 2021 compared to Q3 2020.
It's important to note that Q3 2020 included both COVID-19-enhanced sales and an extra week due to the 53-week fiscal year, which we estimate boosted net sales by about $35 million.
The negative comparison to 2020 is due to a $68.5 million decline in unit volume, partially offset by a $14.5 million benefit from increased net pricing, including list price increases, trade spend optimization, and slight mix changes.
Foreign exchange provided a $1.9 million benefit.
Year-to-date, the cumulative benefit of net pricing changes is approximately $27.3 million.
Excluding Crisco, base business net sales increased by 9.2% compared to 2019, representing a two-year compound annual growth rate of 4.5% over pre-pandemic sales.
Our base business net sales growth in Q3 this year shows continued acceleration compared to 2019, improving upon our performance in Q1 and Q2 this year.
We generated $96.2 million in adjusted EBITDA in Q3, down $8.4 million or 8.1% from last year, but up $10 million or 11.5% compared to 2019.
The decrease in adjusted EBITDA versus Q3 2020 was primarily due to reduced base business volumes and increased input costs, including higher raw material prices, factory labor costs, transportation and warehouse expenses, and one fewer reporting week.
These costs were partially offset by locking in prices through short-term supply contracts, advanced commodity purchase agreements, cost-saving initiatives, price increases, trade spend optimization, and the addition of Crisco to the portfolio.
Adjusted diluted earnings per share was $0.55 in Q3 2021, compared to $0.74 in Q3 2020 and $0.54 in Q3 2019.
Most of our key brands saw decreased net sales when comparing Q3 2021 to Q3 2020, with about two-thirds of the decline due to one fewer reporting week in Q3 2021.
However, most brands showed significant increases in net sales when comparing Q3 2021 to Q3 2019.
For some brands like Ortega and our spices and seasonings business, growth compared to 2019 was limited by production constraints.
Other brands like Back to Nature and New York Style experienced sales declines compared to previous years due to supply chain issues.
Ortega's net sales were $37.6 million in Q3 2021, up $1.6 million or 4.2% from Q3 2020 and up $2.6 million or 7.3% from Q3 2019.
With unlimited manufacturing capacity, Ortega's sales growth would have been even higher.
Demand for Ortega taco sauce, shells, seasonings, and salsa remains strong, and we plan to continue investing in this brand and category.
Las Palmas net sales were $9.1 million in Q3 2021, up $2.5 million or 37.1% from Q3 2020 and up $0.6 million or 7.3% from Q3 2019.
Last year, Las Palmas experienced supply chain issues that limited our ability to meet demand for tomato sauces, but these problems have been resolved this year.
Spices & Seasonings continues to be a major driver of our portfolio.
Net sales of our spices and seasonings brands, including Accent, Dash, Tones, and Weber, were approximately $92.9 million, accounting for nearly 20% of our total company net sales for the quarter.
Spices & Seasonings sales were down by about $14 million or 13.1% compared to Q3 2020, primarily due to capacity constraints as demand exceeded our supply and manufacturing capacity.
Although this issue is improving and we anticipate it will be partly resolved by additional capacity coming online in late 2021 or early 2022, we are also comparing against an exceptionally strong quarter for spices & seasonings last year.
Compared to Q3 2019, spices & seasonings sales were robust, increasing by about $10.3 million or 12.5%.
We have largely completed the 2021 packing season and have fully caught up on Green Giant supply.
This has led to improved performance starting in the latter half of Q3 and continuing to the present.
Green Giant's Q3 2021 sales of $141.2 million, while down $17 million or 10.7% from Q3 2020, are up $20.9 million or 17.4% compared to Q3 2019.
With an expected strong holiday season in November and December, we anticipate continued robust Green Giant sales through Q4 this year.
For other major brands, Maple Grove Farms generated $20.2 million in Q3 sales, down $0.5 million or 2.4% from Q3 2020 but up $2.7 million or 15.3% from Q3 2019.
Likewise, Cream of Wheat's Q3 sales of $15.2 million were down $1.2 million or 7.4% from Q3 2020, but up $1.2 million or 8.5% compared to Q3 2019.
Our gross profit for Q3 2021 was $105.7 million, or 20.5% of net sales.
Excluding a $14.1 million accrual for an expected multi-employer pension plan withdrawal liability and $2.8 million in acquisition and non-recurring expenses, Q3 2021 gross profit would have been $122.6 million or 23.8% of net sales.
Q3 2020 gross profit was $136 million or 27.4% of net sales, which would have been $136.1 million or 27.5% excluding $0.1 million in acquisition and non-recurring expenses.
Q3 2021 gross profit was negatively affected by higher than anticipated input costs, including significant increases in raw materials, factory expenses, and transportation costs.
We've tried to mitigate inflation's impact on gross profits through short-term supply contracts, advanced commodities purchases, and cost-saving measures.
As mentioned earlier, we also implemented price increases and reduced promotions for certain products.
The immediate effect is that margins have been compressed relative to what we expect the business to generate in the short term.
While this trend may persist into Q4 and early 2022, we anticipate our efforts will eventually restore the business to its historical margin profile.
Q3 selling, general, and administrative expenses were $46.4 million, or 9% of net sales.
This compares to $43.4 million (8.8%) last year and $38.1 million (9.4%) in Q3 2019.
The increase in SG&A from last year is primarily due to a $3.5 million rise in warehousing costs and $3.3 million in additional acquisition-related and non-recurring expenses, mainly related to the Crisco brand acquisition and Portland facility sale.
The warehousing cost increase was largely driven by the Crisco acquisition and customer fines related to COVID-19 shortages and delays.
As previously stated, we generated $96.4 million in adjusted EBITDA before COVID-19 expenses and $96.2 million in adjusted EBITDA for Q3 2021.
This compares to adjusted EBITDA of $104.6 million in Q3 2020 and $86.2 million in Q3 2018.
Q3 interest expense was $26.6 million, compared to $26.4 million in Q3 last year.
The slight increase in interest expense was primarily due to the Crisco acquisition, which was financed entirely with a combination of revolver draw and incremental term loans.
The revolver currently has an interest rate slightly below 2%, while the term loans are just under 2.75%.
Depreciation and amortization have also increased year-over-year, mainly due to Crisco.
Q3 2021 depreciation expense was $15.3 million, compared to $10.9 million in Q3 last year.
Q3 2021 amortization expense was $5.4 million, compared to $4.7 million in Q3 last year.
We expect an effective tax rate of approximately 26% to 26.5% for the year, with slightly higher taxes in Q3 this year due to some discrete tax items, resulting in an effective rate of 26.8% for the quarter compared to 24.7% in Q3 last year.
We generated $0.55 in adjusted diluted earnings per share in Q3 2021, compared to $0.74 per share in Q3 2020 and $0.54 per share in Q3 2018.
We are optimistic about these trends.
Although adjusted EBITDA margins will remain challenged this year due to higher than expected input cost inflation, including increased costs for raw materials, factory expenses, transportation, and warehousing, we still expect to generate adjusted EBITDA of $358 million to $365 million for the year.
Similar to last quarter's discussion, we expect the following for full-year 2021: interest expense of $105 million to $110 million (including cash interest of $100 million to $105 million), depreciation expense of $60 million to $65 million, amortization expense of $21 million to $22 million, and an effective tax rate of approximately 26% to 26.5%.
As mentioned at the start of the call, we had a relatively strong quarter despite comparing against elevated COVID-19 demand and an extra week in Q3 2020.
We remain on track to achieve the mid to high single-digit growth against 2019 that we set as a target for the year, and we continue to implement pricing actions to offset inflation in our portfolio.
This concludes our prepared remarks.
We will now begin the Q&A portion of our call.
Summary:
output:
q3 adjusted earnings per share $0.55.
q3 sales $515 million.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:In today's conference call, we'll be discussing the third quarter results for 2020. Joining me are several key executives from our leadership team.
Our actual performance may differ significantly from our projections, and the full impact of COVID-19 remains uncertain.
We can't guarantee that our strategies for addressing the pandemic will be effective, that the demand for our COVID-19 products will continue, or that we'll be able to meet market needs.
During this call, we'll mention non-GAAP financial metrics that aren't defined under standard accounting practices.
I'll now hand over to Ilan Daskal, our CFO, to continue the presentation.
Before delving into the quarterly details, I'd like Andy Last, our COO, to provide an update on how Bio-Rad is managing operations globally during the current pandemic situation.
I'd like to take a moment to outline our current operational status worldwide.
To begin, we want to acknowledge the exceptional efforts of our global workforce in serving our customers throughout this pandemic.
We're truly grateful for the commitment and hard work demonstrated across our company.
As we navigate these challenging times, we're focusing on three key areas: ensuring employee safety, maintaining production to meet customer needs, and advancing our core strategic initiatives.
We've implemented standard safety protocols globally to protect our employees.
We've tailored our approaches to local requirements and are pleased with our productivity levels.
Remote work continues where necessary, and for on-site staff, we've implemented extensive safety measures, resulting in minimal COVID-19 cases.
In the United States, we've introduced rapid testing for suspected cases using Droplet Digital PCR, allowing for quick results and minimizing work disruptions.
Our manufacturing teams have shown great flexibility in adapting to pandemic-driven demand shifts.
We've ramped up production of PCR products to meet increased demand and scaled back where necessary, particularly for Diagnostics products.
We've largely overcome the initial supply chain issues encountered early in the pandemic and are well-prepared to meet future demands.
We continue to progress on our core initiatives, particularly in R&D, with all our laboratories now operational.
Let me now review our third quarter performance.
Q3 2020 net sales were $647.3 million, a 15.5% increase from $560.6 million in Q3 2019. Excluding currency effects, sales grew by 14.9%.
We experienced currency-neutral growth across all regions.
We saw strong demand for COVID-19 testing and related research products, but lower demand in other areas.
Overall, Q3 showed gradual improvement in demand for both Life Science and Diagnostics products across all regions compared to Q2.
Most academic and diagnostic labs are now operating at 70-90% capacity and slowly improving.
Biopharma labs are running at a slightly higher 80-90% capacity. We're closely monitoring the situation.
We estimate COVID-19-related sales were approximately $98 million this quarter.
Life Science Group sales in Q3 2020 were $324 million, up from $215.7 million in Q3 2019, representing a 50.2% increase as reported and a 48.8% increase when adjusted for currency effects.
The majority of year-over-year growth was driven by our core PCR products, Droplet Digital PCR, and Process Media.
Both core PCR and Droplet Digital PCR revenue increases were largely COVID-19-related.
Process Media, which can fluctuate quarterly, saw strong double-digit growth compared to the same quarter last year.
Excluding Process Media sales, the Life Science business grew 53% on a currency-neutral basis compared to Q3 2019.
The expansion in the overall Life Science sector was counterbalanced by ongoing weakness in academic research demand, with laboratories worldwide operating at reduced capacity.
We anticipate a steady rise in laboratory usage and are vigilantly monitoring the situation.
Across all regions, Life Science sales increased on a currency-neutral year-over-year basis.
We remain optimistic about our Droplet Digital PCR business, which is gaining wider acceptance in wastewater testing as the industry benchmark.
Droplet Digital PCR technology is now employed by the Environmental Protection Agency, The Water Research Foundation, and over two dozen laboratories worldwide for wastewater analysis, including Michigan's statewide standardized and coordinated COVID-19 monitoring network.
Furthermore, we recently introduced two new PCR systems, the CFX Opus 96 and CFX Opus 384, bolstering our global response and contribution to combating the pandemic.
Alongside the CFX Opus systems launch, Bio-Rad also unveiled access to a cloud-based platform for instrument connectivity, data management, and analysis.
These new PCR systems, combined with our Droplet Digital PCR offering, provide a comprehensive solution for our clients.
Clinical Diagnostics product revenue in the third quarter totaled $322.2 million, compared to $341.8 million in Q3 2019, representing a 5.7% decrease on a reported basis and a 5.9% decline on a currency-neutral basis.
We observed improved performance across all regions and product lines sequentially, which we believe indicates a recovery in routine testing trends.
During the third quarter, robust performance in our quality controls products was offset by weakness across other Diagnostics portfolio areas.
