Although clinical laboratories have been significantly impacted by the pandemic, we are now seeing a gradual recovery from the Q2 low point and expect continued improvement through year-end.
We will carefully monitor the potential impact of the recent pandemic resurgence.
The Diagnostics Group reported declines across all geographic regions.
The reported gross margin for the third quarter of 2020 was 56.7% on a GAAP basis, compared to 54.8% in Q3 2019.
The current gross margin primarily benefited from improved product mix, increased manufacturing utilization, and reduced service costs, partially offset by higher logistics expenses.
Amortization related to previous acquisitions recorded in cost of goods sold was $4.8 million, compared to $3.9 million in Q3 2019.
SG&A expenses for Q3 2020 were $198.2 million or 30.6% of sales, compared to $201.6 million or 36% in Q3 2019.
We are continuing our cost-saving initiatives to reduce SG&A expenses.
Total amortization expense related to acquisitions recorded in SG&A for the quarter was $2.3 million, versus $1.9 million in Q3 2019.
Research and development expense in Q3 was $59.5 million or 9.2% of sales, compared to $47.9 million or 8.6% of sales in Q3 2019.
Q3 operating income was $109.6 million or 16.9% of sales, compared to $57.5 million or 10.2% of sales in Q3 2019.
Examining items below the operating line, the change in fair market value of equity securities holdings added $1,580 million of income to the reported results, primarily related to holdings of Sartorius AG shares.
Additionally, interest and other income resulted in a net expense of $5.5 million during the quarter, compared to $2.1 million of expense last year.
The effective tax rate for the quarter was 21.9%, compared to 22.8% in Q3 2019.
Reported net income for the third quarter was $1,315 million, with diluted earnings per share of $43.64.
This represents an increase from last year, largely due to changes in the valuation of Sartorius Holdings.
Turning to the non-GAAP results.
In our non-GAAP analysis, we have excluded certain unusual and unique items that impacted gross and operating margins as well as other income.
Examining the non-GAAP results for the third quarter, we have excluded $4.8 million of amortization of purchased intangibles and a small restructuring benefit from cost of goods sold.
These exclusions resulted in a non-GAAP gross margin of 57.5% for the third quarter of 2020, compared to 56% in Q3 2019.
Non-GAAP SG&A in the third quarter of 2020 was 29.4%, versus 35.5% in Q3 2019.
In our non-GAAP SG&A calculations, we have excluded $2.3 million in amortization of purchased intangibles, $6 million in legal-related expenses, and less than $1 million in restructuring and acquisition-related benefits.
Non-GAAP R&D expense in the third quarter of 2020 was 9.2%, versus 8.5% in Q3 2019.
In research and development, we've omitted minimal restructuring gains from our non-GAAP calculations
The aggregate of these non-GAAP modifications increases the quarterly operating margin from 16.9% (GAAP) to 18.8% (non-GAAP)
This non-GAAP operating margin is comparable to the 12% non-GAAP operating margin in the third quarter of 2019
We've also eliminated certain items below the operating line, including the 1,580 million increase in Sartorius Equity Holdings value and a minor loss related to venture investments
The non-GAAP effective tax rate for the quarter was 22.5%, down from 25.5% in Q3 2019
This quarter's lower rate was mainly due to changes in our geographical earnings distribution and the taxation of our overseas profits
We now project the full-year non-GAAP tax rate to be around 24%
Non-GAAP net income for Q3 2020 reached $90.3 million, or $3 per diluted share, up from $48.6 million and $1.61 per share in Q3 2019
Turning to the balance sheet
Total cash and short-term investments at Q3's end were $1,160 million, up $123 million from Q2 2020
Our inventory grew by approximately $12 million from Q2 to Q3 2020
The Q3 2020 inventory increase was due to anticipated higher demand for COVID-19 related products
We anticipate inventory levels will decrease over the next two to three quarters
We intend to use available cash to pay off the $425 million of outstanding senior notes in December
Moreover, the increased market value of our Sartorius AG holdings may technically classify us as an investment company under the 1940 Investment Company Act
While we work on resolving this issue, our access to capital markets may be limited
We believe we have sufficient resources to effectively manage our business in the short term
We did not repurchase any of our stock during Q3, with $273 million still available for potential share buybacks
Q3 2020 net cash from operating activities was $135.7 million, compared to $99.8 million in Q3 2019
Q3 2020 adjusted EBITDA was 22.9% of sales
Q3 2019 adjusted EBITDA was 17%
Q3 2020 net capital expenditures were $20 million, with depreciation and amortization at $33.7 million
We expect full-year capex to be between $80 million and $90 million
Regarding guidance
We remain uncertain about the COVID-19 pandemic's duration and impact, though we assume a gradual return to pre-pandemic activity levels and business mix
We currently project full-year 2020 currency-neutral sales growth of 5.9% to 6.3%
We forecast 27% to 28% currency-neutral revenue growth for Life Science and about 7% currency-neutral revenue decline for the Diagnostics Group in 2020
This assumes Q4 will see gradual improvement in non-COVID-19 related product sales and a smaller relative benefit from COVID-19 related product sales compared to Q3
Full-year non-GAAP gross margin is expected to be between 56.5% and 57%
R&D is projected at around 9%
Full-year GAAP operating margin is estimated between 16% and 16.5%, with full-year adjusted EBITDA margin between 21% and 21.5%
Our significantly higher operating profit over the last year resulted from discretionary cost control measures and improved product mix
As operations normalize, we expect a gradual reversal of the benefits experienced in 2020
Due to the pandemic's uncertainty, we won't host an Investor Day this year, aiming to do so in 2021 when business activity normalizes
We plan to provide updated revenue growth and margin targets in December
Summary:
output:
q3 earnings per share $43.64.
q3 sales $647.3 million versus refinitiv ibes estimate of $570.6 million.
bio rad laboratories - currently believes full-year 2020 yoy currency-neutral sales may be up 5.9 to 6.3 percent.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Today's discussion includes certain non-GAAP financial metrics that provide extra insights we believe are valuable to our investors.
These metrics have been aligned with corresponding GAAP measures as per SEC guidelines.
Please be aware of the risks and uncertainties mentioned during this call, which are detailed in our regular SEC filings.
Barnes Group had an excellent start to 2021, with the anticipated recovery beginning earlier than expected.
Continued strong order intake, sequential revenue growth for three consecutive quarters, and better-than-expected earnings performance strengthen our belief in significant recovery progress in the latter half of the year.
In the first quarter, organic sales decreased by 10% year-over-year due to lower Aerospace volumes.
However, our Industrial segment achieved high single-digit organic growth, surpassing our February forecast thanks to robust orders and sales in March.
While we initially expected business improvement as the year progressed, the stronger momentum at the end of the first quarter has led us to raise our annual outlook.
Earnings per share were $0.38, a 46% decrease from last year's adjusted $0.71, but significantly exceeding our February projection's upper limit.
Let's now examine end market dynamics, starting with Industrial.
Our Industrial segment performed strongly in the first quarter, with all SBUs showing year-over-year organic sales and revenue growth.
The segment's orders increased by 25% organically, with a book-to-bill ratio of approximately 1.1.
Sequential orders rose by 7%, further demonstrating the momentum we're experiencing.
At a macro level, manufacturing PMIs in the US and eurozone remain particularly strong.
China, though slightly softer, continues to show expansion.
Despite the semiconductor issue affecting automotive production, IHS still forecasts global production to increase by 12% over last year.
Within the segment, our Molding Solutions business saw strong orders across all brands, with a 35% organic increase.
Our major end markets - automotive, medical, packaging, and personal care - each experienced over 25% order growth, some significantly higher.
Orders improved sequentially by high single digits, marking the fourth consecutive quarter of sequential growth.
Organic sales increased by mid-single digits, while sequential sales rose by low single digits.
The book-to-bill ratio was approximately 1.1.
Backlog, primarily consisting of our longer-cycle mold systems, grew by about 25% year-over-year and low double digits from Q4 2020.
Molding Solutions' activity is very encouraging, and the business has been recruiting more talent for the sales and marketing team, focusing on driving long-term growth and margin expansion.
While short-term investments in talent and our innovation and digital initiatives may temporarily impact margins, we anticipate long-term performance benefits.
We've improved our 2021 outlook for Molding Solutions, now forecasting organic sales growth in the low teens.
In Force & Motion Control, organic orders increased by low double digits, with organic sales up by high single digits.
FMC is benefiting from its automotive customers' shift towards electric and hybrid vehicles in the sheet metal forming market.
Year-over-year orders have increased across our primary geographic markets: North America, Europe, and China.
We're also seeing strong demand in our general industrial end markets, particularly in heavy-duty trucks and industrial equipment.
We've raised our FMC sales growth expectation and now anticipate organic sales to increase by mid-teens in 2021.
Engineered Components achieved organic order growth exceeding 25% and organic revenue growth in the low double digits.
We saw modest sequential growth in orders and sales, somewhat constrained by automotive semiconductor concerns.
We estimate a first-quarter impact of about $1 million due to this issue, with a potential second-quarter impact of $4 million to $5 million before recovery in the second half.
General industrial markets remain very robust.
We've also increased our 2021 outlook for this business, now forecasting organic sales growth in the mid-teens.
In Automation, we continue to see sequential improvement in both orders and sales, up low teens and high single digits, respectively.
Year-over-year organic sales increased by high single digits, and organic revenues grew by mid-teens.
The Automation team had a very good quarter of growth and execution.
Demand for our end-of-arm tooling solutions in automotive, medical and pharma, and industrial automation applications remains strong, continuing the trend from recent quarters.
We now expect 2021 to deliver total growth of 20%, with organic growth in the mid-teens, surpassing our February projection.
For the entire Industrial segment, we anticipate 2021 organic growth in the mid-teens, with operating margins of approximately 13%.
Shifting our focus to the Aerospace sector.
The Aerospace division continued to feel the effects of the pandemic, with OEM sales declining 32% and aftermarket sales dropping 48% compared to the previous year, as commercial aviation remained significantly disrupted.
Nevertheless, we believe the worst is behind us and we are gradually recovering.
As evidence, we have observed a sequential improvement in total Aerospace sales for three consecutive quarters.
In the initial quarter, our MRO business drove the sequential improvement.
Our outlook for the Aerospace industry remains unchanged.
We anticipate modest improvement in narrow-body OEM production levels, while wide-body production will continue to face challenges.
We observed strong orders for the second consecutive quarter, with an OEM book-to-bill ratio of approximately 1.5.
In the aftermarket sector, challenges persist, including reduced aircraft usage, diminished airline profitability, and government-imposed travel restrictions.
The speed and efficacy of vaccine rollouts will determine the recovery timeline.
Domestic travel is expected to rebound before international travel improves.
We anticipate a gradual improvement in aftermarket activity beginning in the latter half of 2021.
In the interim, the Aerospace team is implementing various measures to position our business for recovery.
For instance, in the first quarter, we expanded our West Chester, Ohio facility, enhancing our capabilities, received supplier recognition from Boeing and Rolls-Royce, and secured a significant B-2 Bomber Exhaust System contract from Northrop Grumman.
Our 2021 projections remain unchanged, with OEM sales expected to increase by mid-single digits compared to 2020, and spare parts sales anticipated to decrease in the mid-teens.
We have slightly improved our MRO forecast, now expecting a low single-digit decline instead of the previously projected mid-single-digit decrease.
We anticipate the segment operating margin to be around 13%.
Julie is an accomplished executive with extensive experience in managing financial operations for global enterprises.
Her comprehensive background and proven strategic leadership in corporate finance, financial planning and analysis, mergers and acquisitions, and risk management will contribute to advancing our long-term profitable growth strategy.
To conclude, we have begun 2021 on a positive note.
Encouraging macroeconomic indicators and our robust order generation provide us with strong confidence in our improved outlook for the year.
Nevertheless, we acknowledge that challenges persist, and our teams are proactively developing risk mitigation strategies.
As we progress, we will continue to recruit the necessary talent and skills to drive growth and enhance profitability.
These efforts will be supported by our organic investments in innovation, digitalization, and strategic marketing.
Our primary focus remains on controlling our own destiny and positioning the company to thrive as global markets recover.
Let's begin by examining the highlights of our first quarter results, as shown on Slide 4 of our supplement.
First quarter revenue totaled $302 million, a 9% decrease from the same period last year, with organic sales declining 10% due to ongoing pandemic impacts on our Aerospace end markets.
The sale of the Seeger business negatively impacted sales by 2%, while favorable exchange rates contributed a positive 3% impact.
Operating income amounted to $32.4 million, compared to $49.3 million in the previous year.
Relative to last year's adjusted operating income of $51.7 million, the first quarter saw a 37% decrease, with an operating margin of 10.7%, down 490 basis points from the adjusted 15.6% of the previous year.
It's worth noting that this outcome was anticipated.
The first quarter of the previous year saw record-breaking performance in the Aerospace aftermarket, which generated exceptionally strong margins.
Interest expense decreased by $400,000 to $3.9 million, resulting from lower average borrowings, partially offset by a higher average interest rate.
Our effective tax rate for the quarter was 28.1%, lower than the 31.5% rate from the previous year.
This decrease is primarily attributed to the absence of tax expenses related to the completed Seeger business sale and a reduction in the statutory tax rate at one of our international operations, both of which occurred in the first quarter of 2020.
These factors were partially offset by the impact of the global intangible low-taxed income (GILTI) tax on foreign earnings in the first quarter of 2021.
Net income totaled $19.4 million, or $0.38 per diluted share, compared to $29.7 million, or $0.58 per diluted share, in the previous year.
On an adjusted basis, net income per share decreased by 46% from $0.71 in the previous year.
The previous year's first quarter adjusted net income per diluted share excluded $0.13 of Seeger divestiture adjustments.
Now, let's examine our segment performance, starting with the Industrial division.
First quarter sales for the Industrial segment reached $220 million, a 10% increase from the previous year.
Organic sales grew by 8%.
The divestiture of the Seeger business negatively impacted sales by 3%, while favorable foreign exchange rates, primarily driven by the euro to US dollar exchange, increased sales by 5%.
Compared to the fourth quarter of 2020, consecutive sales increased by 5%.
There's positive news regarding revenue, with three consecutive quarters of growth and a favorable year-over-year outcome.
The Industrial segment's operating profit for Q1 was $21.3 million, an increase from $17.9 million in the same period last year.
The rise in operating profit was due to increased volume and improved productivity.
These gains were partially offset by higher staff expenses, including performance-based compensation.
The previous year saw a reduction in quarterly incentive compensation, while this year anticipates an increase based on 2021 performance expectations.
Excluding $2.4 million in Seeger divestiture adjustments from last year, the adjusted first quarter operating income grew by 5% from the previous year's $20.3 million.
The adjusted operating margin decreased by 50 basis points from 10.2% compared to the previous year.
One factor contributing to this is the additional investments being made in the Industrial segment.
As Patrick mentioned, these investments are firmly focused on our long-term growth strategy.
While our Industrial end markets and businesses are showing signs of strong recovery, there are concerns about supply chain issues related to raw material availability, inflation, and increased shipping costs.
Regarding raw materials, we've observed some customers extending their order commitment timelines to ensure supply availability and acknowledging the longer lead times required for certain materials.
In Q1, we experienced about $1 million in combined freight and material inflation in the Industrial segment.
We anticipate an impact of approximately $6 million for the full year, which is incorporated into our outlook.
Our teams are addressing these issues, seeking to reduce risk exposure and take measures to counter inflation where appropriate.
In the Aerospace segment, Q1 sales were $82 million, a 38% decrease from the previous year.
Operating profit fell by 65% to $11.1 million, primarily due to lower sales volume.
The operating margin was 13.6%, compared to a strong 23.9% a year ago.
It's worth noting that last year's margin was exceptionally high, driven by aftermarket contributions.
The Aerospace OEM backlog at the end of the quarter was $600 million, a 5% increase from Q4, and we expect to fulfill 45% of this backlog in the next 12 months.
Cash provided by operating activities in Q1 was $36 million, $12 million less than the previous year, while free cash flow was $28 million, down from $35 million last year, and capital expenditures decreased by about $4 million to $8 million compared to a year ago.
Regarding the balance sheet, our debt-to-EBITDA ratio, as defined by our credit agreement, was 3.1 times at the end of the quarter, virtually unchanged from the previous quarter.
The Company is fully compliant with all credit agreement covenants and maintains sufficient liquidity to fund operations.
Although we expected the leverage ratio to peak with our Q1 2021 results, we performed better than anticipated due to stronger financial results in the first quarter.
We anticipate further reduction in leverage from this point, barring any acquisition activity.
Our average diluted shares outstanding for Q1 was 51 million shares.
We now plan to resume some share repurchase activity to offset equity compensation dilution, with additional share repurchases depending on various factors related to capital deployment and available growth opportunities.
Referring to Slide 5 of our supplement, let's discuss our updated 2021 financial outlook.
We now project organic sales growth of 10% to 12% for the year, an increase from our previous estimate of 6% to 8%, driven by stronger industrial growth.
Foreign exchange is expected to have a 2% positive impact on sales, while divested Seeger revenues will have a minor negative effect.
The forecasted operating margin is approximately 13%.
At present, we don't anticipate significant residual restructuring charges, so there are no forecasted adjustments to 2021 net income.
Earnings per share are expected to range from $1.78 to $1.98, a 9% to 21% increase from 2020's adjusted earnings of $1.64, which is higher than our previous projection of $1.65 to $1.90, and we anticipate the first half of the year to contribute about 43% of 2021's earnings.
A few additional outlook items: Interest expense is expected to be around $16 million, while other expenses are forecasted at $8 million, both slightly better than our previous estimate.
We now expect capital expenditures to be approximately $50 million, down $5 million, with average diluted shares of 51 million and cash conversion over 100% remaining consistent with our prior outlook.
Lastly, we forecast a full-year tax rate of about 30%.
However, we continue to analyze potential tax planning strategies to manage and reduce our overall tax expenses.
In conclusion, 2021 has started very well, supported by healthy orders for both segments.
With our focus on driving growth across the organization, we'll continue to invest in the business through capital expenditures and funding key strategic initiatives.
We believe these investments will help accelerate the recovery in our financial performance.
Leverage remains very manageable and should improve from this point, allowing the balance sheet to accommodate our approach.
Summary:
output:
q1 gaap earnings per share $0.38.
q1 sales fell 9 percent to $302 million.
2021 earnings per share outlook increased to $1.78 to $1.98.
now expects 2021 organic sales to be up 10% to 12%.
company forecasts 2021 capital expenditures of approximately $50 million.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:To start, I want to commend all Church & Dwight staff worldwide for their ongoing commitment to maintaining our Company's operations during the pandemic, particularly our supply chain and R&D teams who overcame raw material shortages in Q1 due to the Texas freeze.
Let's discuss the outcomes.
The first quarter was remarkably successful.
We saw a 6.3% increase in reported sales, with adjusted earnings per share at $0.83, exceeding our projection by $0.03.
Organic sales increased by 4.9%, propelled by higher consumption.
The growth of e-commerce continues unabated.
Our online sales in Q1 grew by 54% compared to the previous year, accounting for 14.8% of total sales, up from 10.2% in Q1 2020.
We anticipate online sales will constitute 15% of total sales for the entire year.
The rollout of vaccines will significantly shape consumer behavior.
The United States is gradually reopening, leading to increased consumer mobility.
According to an IRI study, 60% of vaccinated consumers are hopeful about returning to normal or a new normal, as we observe initial signs of consumers' willingness to spend more time in stores.
In contrast, many non-U.S. countries are still experiencing lockdowns.
As mentioned in the release, we've been facing raw material shortages due to the Texas freeze.
Raw material and transportation costs surged in February, further exacerbated by the Texas freeze.
We expect supply constraints and higher input costs to persist throughout the year.
To offset these cost increases, we've announced price hikes in laundry products and across our international portfolio, while reducing couponing and promotional spending.
Rick will provide more details on this shortly.
At our January Analyst Day, we outlined which categories and brands we expected to remain elevated, recover from COVID lows, decline from COVID highs, or remain steady throughout 2021.
Our overall outlook for the full year remains unchanged.
To highlight a few categories, we expect demand for vitamins, laundry additives, and cat litter to remain high in 2021.
As society reopens and consumer mobility increases, we anticipate year-over-year growth for condoms, dry shampoo, power flossers, and women's grooming products.
We expect baking soda, pregnancy test kits, and oral analgesics to decline from their COVID-induced highs.
Of the 16 categories we compete in, 8 experienced consumption growth in Q1, some building on significant gains from Q1 2020.
Among these 8 categories, 5 saw double-digit growth: gummy vitamins, toothache remedies, battery-powered toothbrushes, pregnancy test kits, and women's electric grooming products.
Household categories like laundry detergent and baking soda declined in the quarter, unable to match the substantial COVID-19 sales spikes seen in Q1 2020.
Regarding Q1 market shares, 8 out of our 13 power brands either maintained or gained share within our U.S. Consumer Domestic business, which saw 5.1% organic sales growth.
I'll now comment on a few specific brands.
Health and wellness have become a priority for consumers.
VITAFUSION and L'IL CRITTERS gummy vitamins experienced impressive consumption growth of 24% in Q1, aided by new product launches mentioned in the release.
It seems new consumers are entering the category and staying, with one survey indicating a 90% repeat rate among new category entrants.
WATERPIK saw 15% consumption growth in Q1 as it recovers from COVID lows and benefits from increased consumer focus on health and wellness.
WATERPIK is also benefiting from dental offices returning to pre-COVID patient levels.
We expect our lunch 'n learn program frequency to normalize in the second half of this year.
Although BATISTE continues to be affected by social distancing, consumption increased by 6%, and we achieved a record high quarterly balance share of 39%, driven by our International Women's Day campaign.
Now, let's discuss the International division.
Despite European lockdowns, our International business achieved 3.2% organic growth in the quarter, primarily driven by strong performance in our Global Markets Group.
Asia continues to be a key growth driver for us.
WATERPIK, FEMFRESH, and ARM & HAMMER led the growth for the International division this quarter.
Our Specialty Products division experienced a positive quarter with 6% growth, mainly attributed to increased pricing.
The price of milk remained steady in the first quarter and is expected to rise later in the year due to increased demand.
Let's now discuss New Products.
Novel and innovative products will continue to draw in consumers.
We are launching OXICLEAN Laundry and Home Sanitizer in our household products line.
This product is unique as the first and only laundry additive that enhances stain removal while eliminating 99.9% of bacteria and viruses.
The product is also suitable for cleaning various surfaces throughout the home.
In personal care, VITAFUSION introduced Elderberry, Super Immune, and POWER ZINC gummies to meet growing consumer interest in immunity-boosting products.
WATERPIK introduced ION, a compact water flosser that is 30% smaller, features a long-lasting lithium-ion battery, and is designed for smaller bathrooms.
Building on its previous success, WATERPIK upgraded its SONIC-FUSION flossing toothbrush to version 2.0, now offering two brush head sizes and two speed settings.
FLAWLESS is capitalizing on at-home beauty and self-care trends by introducing a facial cleansing system, a shower wand for a spa-like experience, and at-home nail care solutions.
Let's now discuss the future outlook.
We've had a promising start to Q1.
We maintain our projection of 6% to 8% growth in adjusted earnings per share for the full year, aligning with our Evergreen target, despite increased input costs.
Based on our expectations for consumer consumption, we've increased our full-year reported sales growth forecast from 4.5% to a range of 5% to 6%.
We've also raised our organic sales growth expectations from 3% to a range of 4% to 5%.
Consumption trends through mid-April show year-over-year growth in 14 out of our 16 categories.
In conclusion, I'd like to highlight the many reasons to be confident in Church & Dwight.
Our track record demonstrates our ability to perform well in both favorable and challenging economic conditions, including uncertain times like the present.
The categories we operate in are essential to consumers.
We offer a mix of value and premium products.
Our power brands hold the top one or two positions in their respective categories.
We have minimal exposure to private label products.
With our strong financial position, we remain open to acquiring businesses that can enhance our Total Shareholder Return.
Rick will now provide details on Q1.
We'll begin with earnings per share.
The first quarter's adjusted EPS, excluding the positive earn-out adjustment, was $0.83, unchanged from the previous year.
As mentioned in earlier calls, the quarterly earn-out adjustment will continue until Q4, which marks the end of the earn-out period.
The $0.83 EPS exceeded our $0.80 projection, primarily due to sustained increased consumer demand for many of our products.
Reported revenue increased by 6.3%.
Organic sales grew by 4.9%, driven by a 3.1% increase in volume and a 1.8% positive price mix.
Let's examine the segments.
Organic sales rose by 5.1% due to higher volume and positive price mix.
Growth was led by VITAFUSION and L'IL CRITTERS gummy vitamins, WATERPIK oral care products, FLAWLESS beauty products, ARM & HAMMER clumping cat litter, KABOOM bathroom cleaners, and VIVISCAL hair thinning products.
Consumer International achieved 3.2% organic growth due to higher volume, partially offset by lower price and product mix.
This was an impressive result despite European writedowns.
Our SPD business saw a 6% increase in organic sales due to higher pricing, partially offset by lower volume.
Milk prices have remained stable month-to-month and are projected to increase as 2021 progresses.
Now let's discuss gross margin.
Our initial quarter's gross margin was 44.5%, showing a decrease of 120 basis points compared to the previous year.
The decline in gross margin was influenced by a 350 basis point increase in manufacturing expenses, mainly due to commodity costs, distribution, tariffs, and COVID-related impacts.
The Texas freeze exacerbated commodity issues, causing a 90 basis point reduction in margin.
Tariffs had a negative effect of 40 basis points on the gross margin.
These negative impacts were partially mitigated by a 190 basis point increase from price/volume mix, a 170 basis point improvement from productivity initiatives, and a 10 basis point positive effect from favorable currency exchange rates.
We had previously projected a 50 basis point decrease in gross margin for the quarter.
The entire discrepancy was attributed to a sudden rise in commodity prices and a constrained transportation market.
We anticipate margin improvement in the latter half of the year, driven by pricing and promotional strategies outlined in our release, as well as the anniversary of higher inflation and tariffs experienced in the latter half of 2020.
We increased our marketing expenditure by $2.3 million compared to last year to support our brand.
Marketing expenses as a proportion of net sales decreased by 30 basis points to 8%.
First quarter adjusted SG&A increased by 60 basis points year-over-year, primarily due to amortization of acquisition-related intangibles.
We also increased investments in IT and R&D, and incurred some transition costs from the ZICAM acquisition.
Other expenses totaled $11.6 million, a $3.6 million reduction due to lower interest rates resulting in decreased interest expenses.
Our effective tax rate for the quarter was 24.2%, an increase of 100 basis points from 23.2% in 2020, mainly due to fewer stock option exercises.
In the first three months of 2021, cash from operating activities fell by 57% to $100 million due to higher cash earnings being offset by an increase in working capital.
Inventory levels are higher to support increased sales and improve customer fill rates.
Accounts payable and accrued expenses decreased due to the timing of payments.
As of March 31st, we had $128 million in cash on hand.
We maintain our full-year capital expenditure plan of approximately $180 million, focusing on expanding manufacturing and distribution capacity, particularly for laundry, litter, and vitamins.
For the second quarter, we project reported sales growth of about 4.5%, organic sales growth of roughly 4%, and a gross margin contraction of 350 basis points due to ongoing higher input costs and comparison to artificially low promotional levels from the previous year.
We expect adjusted earnings per share to be $0.69, a 10% decrease from last year's adjusted second quarter EPS.
As mentioned in our release, we conducted a voluntary recall of selected products in our vitamin business.
We anticipate the earnings per share impact in Q2 to be approximately $0.04, and we are seeking insurance reimbursement.
For the full year 2021, we now expect reported sales growth of 5% to 6%, surpassing our previous 4.5% outlook.
We've also increased our full-year organic sales growth projection to approximately 4% to 5%, up from the previous 3% outlook.
We now anticipate full-year gross margin to be flat, primarily due to higher raw material and transportation costs, and the impact of the Texas freeze in March.
We previously expected a gross margin expansion of 50 basis points for the year.
Recently, we've observed a significant increase in raw materials and transportation costs.
We're absorbing $90 million in additional costs for the full year.
Higher sales, reduced promotions, and price increases across all three divisions, representing about one-third of our portfolio, offset a large portion of the cost increases.
We price our products to protect gross profit dollars, not necessarily margin.
Our full-year tax rate expectations have increased to 22% due to fewer stock option exercises, representing a $0.02 headwind compared to our previous full-year outlook.
We maintain our adjusted earnings per share expectations in the range of $3.03 to $3.06, a 6% to 8% increase year-over-year.
Our cash from operations outlook remains at $1 billion, while we continue to seek accretive acquisitions.
As Matt mentioned, the company has had a strong start, and we anticipate 2021 to be another robust year.
Summary:
output:
church & dwight co q1 adjusted earnings per share $0.83 excluding items.
q1 adjusted earnings per share $0.83 excluding items.
sees q2 adjusted earnings per share $0.69.
sees fy adjusted earnings per share $3.00 to $3.06.
sees fy sales up 5 to 6 percent.
sees q2 sales up about 4.5 percent.
sees fy organic sales growth to be 4-5%.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Scott Oaksmith, Senior Vice President of Real Estate & Finance, will be accompanying them
We're pleased you could attend and trust everyone is doing well
The COVID-19 pandemic continues to significantly affect our company and the hospitality industry as a whole
Our franchisees, their hotel employees, and Choice associates have shown exceptional resilience
Despite the ongoing pandemic, I'm happy to announce that Choice Hotels has continued to deliver results that greatly exceed industry standards in the third quarter
Domestic systemwide RevPAR outpaced the industry by almost 20 percentage points, only decreasing 28.8% compared to the third quarter of 2019
All our limited service brands experienced considerable RevPAR index improvements against local competitors
We managed to increase our effective royalty rate, indicating an continuously improving value proposition for our franchisees
We expanded our total system size, particularly in our higher revenue-generating upscale, mid-scale, and extended-stay segments
We attribute this success to Choice's key differentiators, such as our varied brand portfolio, the geographic distribution of our domestic system, our core customer profile, and our franchise-centric business model
These fundamental strengths have positioned us favorably to capitalize on the shifts in consumer demand that have occurred over the past eight months
We believe our strategy of expanding our limited service brands in appropriate segments and locations will enable us to continue increasing our share of travel demand in the long run
As we enter the ninth month of the pandemic, we're starting to observe trends that are likely to have a lasting impact on the travel industry
Let's start with the trend of remote work and virtual learning
Substantial investments in remote access technology by businesses, schools, and consumers are creating more options for where and when traditional activities occur
In a post-pandemic world, this may provide Americans with even more flexibility in their schedules to travel for leisure
For the past few years, we've noticed a trend of leisure travel demand spreading more evenly throughout the year, which we partly attribute to changing school schedules and an increase in baby boomers retiring with more time and disposable income to travel
More employees can now work from any location with internet access, while their children attend virtual classes
Over the past two months, we observed continued leisure demand extending into weekdays
Another trend is the rise in road trips
We're benefiting from this trend due to our high concentration of hotels in drive-to markets
Since the pandemic began, consumers' preference for road trips has only grown as Americans show a clear inclination for trips closer to home
Destinations that may have been overlooked before COVID-19 are now being reconsidered
With over 4,000 domestic hotels located within a mile of an interstate exit, our properties are well-positioned to serve travelers embarking on road trips
Additionally, with more than 2,000 domestic hotels near beaches and national parks, our properties are situated in the right markets to capture growing demand from travelers increasingly looking to explore the great American outdoors
Another emerging trend is the economic disruption caused by the pandemic and its effect on consumers as recovery takes place
We believe that during uncertain times, as in previous economic downturns, consumers will seek more affordable limited service hotel options, presenting an opportunity for our portfolio to capture this demand
Another anticipated economic effect of the pandemic is higher relocation rates
As people change jobs and industries, demand for longer-term hotel stays increases, a trend we believe will benefit our brands, particularly those in the moderately priced extended-stay segment
Lastly, there are indications that consumers' risk tolerance is increasing, even before a vaccine becomes available
According to a recent survey, the perception of travel safety has improved, and Americans' likelihood to take a domestic leisure trip and stay in a hotel within the next six months is at its highest since mid-March
As a result of these trends, we've witnessed an increase in our weekday occupancy quarter-over-quarter, on top of the existing weekend leisure demand we've historically enjoyed
In fact, our weekday RevPAR index rose by eight percentage points year-over-year in the third quarter
Our year-over-year RevPAR change continued to improve month-over-month during the third quarter
At present, we remain optimistic about seeing sequential month-over-month improvements in our year-over-year RevPAR change
Our loyalty program has remained a key driver of our business throughout the pandemic, enhancing our ability to boost franchisees' top-line revenue
We particularly benefited from Choice Privileges Diamond Elite members, our most valuable customers, who contributed an even higher percentage of overall revenue year-to-date compared to last year
We anticipate this foundation of loyalty business to deliver even greater value in the future as more Americans resume travel and enrollments in our award-winning Choice Privileges loyalty program continue to grow
Our long-term strategy of expanding the right brands in the appropriate segments and markets has allowed Choice brand hotels to consistently outperform the competition
Throughout the third quarter, we achieved significant month-over-month increases in our proprietary revenue contribution to our hotels
Specifically, our website contribution increased by 400 basis points and our loyalty contribution rose by 120 basis points quarter-over-quarter
This has helped drive RevPAR index share gains against our local competitors across all location types, as reported by STR
For the 34 weeks leading up to October 31, we observed substantial RevPAR share gains compared to the competition
In the third quarter, all of our select service brands achieved significant RevPAR index gains versus their local competitors, with each of our upscale and extended-stay brands experiencing share gains exceeding 10 percentage points
I will now provide a brief update on our segments
Our high-end portfolio experienced significant year-on-year expansion in Q3, with our domestic luxury room count rising by 33%
Ascend Hotel Collection stands as the first and largest soft brand in the industry
Ascend Hotels, now boasting nearly 300 properties worldwide and soon to reach its 200th domestic location, delivered outstanding Q3 results: RevPAR growth surpassed the upscale segment by over 26 percentage points; RevPAR share gains against local rivals reached nearly 19 percentage points; and average daily rate index improved by about nine percentage points
For the last six months, Ascend has consistently outperformed both upscale soft brands and the segment overall in terms of year-over-year RevPAR growth
Our extended-stay properties are specifically designed for long-term visitors
Choice Hotels' brands in this recession-resistant category continue to excel in the current unprecedented climate, with our portfolio of over 420 extended-stay hotels growing 6% year-over-year in Q3
WoodSpring Suites achieved a 77% average occupancy rate in Q3, maintaining monthly occupancy levels above 75% since late June
Suburban extended-stay brand saw year-over-year occupancy improvements in Q3, enhancing its appeal to developers seeking a smart extended-stay conversion opportunity
Meanwhile, our MainStay Suites mid-scale extended-stay brand gained over 16 percentage points in RevPAR index compared to local competitors in Q3
We remain positive about the growth prospects of our extended-stay portfolio, which saw a 9% year-over-year increase in its pipeline during Q3
From January through September, Choice has awarded more than 40 extended-stay franchise agreements, showing continued interest in both new construction and conversion opportunities during a challenging period for the industry
Turning to our mid-scale segment, these brands make up 2/3 of our total domestic portfolio and over half of the franchise agreements signed year-to-date
All our select-service mid-scale brands achieved year-over-year gains in RevPAR index and average daily rate index compared to local competitors through Q3
The Comfort brand gained over seven percentage points in RevPAR share versus local competitors in Q3
Clarion Pointe, a conversion brand extension of Clarion launched less than two years ago, recently opened its 20th U.S. hotel and now has over 50 properties open or in development, demonstrating strong growth as it expands coast-to-coast
Despite the challenging environment, demand for Choice's brands persists, supported by our strong value proposition and recent performance
Developers select our brands to increase the value of their hotels
We offer conversion brands to suit most developers' budgets, which has driven our development growth through past downturns
From January through September, we've awarded over 230 new domestic franchise agreements, with nearly 70% being for conversion hotels
In Q3 alone, we executed over 80 domestic agreements, of which nearly 3/4 were for conversions and over 40% were signed in September
We have a long history of increasing the diversity of our ownership base through our unique emerging markets development team, which assists underrepresented individuals like minority and veteran entrepreneurs in entering the hotel franchising business
Almost 70% of our hotels have minority ownership
Despite the pandemic, we've awarded and financially supported 17 franchise contracts with black and Hispanic entrepreneurs year-to-date
Recently, we entered into the largest minority-owned multi-unit franchise agreement in the program's history
Our long-standing commitment to diversity and further details about our efforts to improve the communities we serve will be outlined in our upcoming ESG report
While this year's challenges have been unique, the cyclical nature of our industry is well-known
It's something our experienced and disciplined management team, many of whom have guided the company through previous downturns, has planned for
Our resilient franchisee base also has extensive experience in leading their small businesses through down cycles, and they are central to everything we do
Throughout the pandemic, we have supported our franchisees in several ways
First, by reducing costs through extending brand program deadlines, implementing cost-saving operational initiatives, reducing certain fixed fees, offering a tailored fee deferral program, and modifying brand standards
Second, by attracting business through our global sales efforts targeting first responders and other essential travel; a multichannel, multi-brand marketing campaign; and tailored promotional programs
Finally, by collaborating with hygiene and infection prevention experts like Ecolab to launch our Commitment to Clean initiative, ensuring their hotels are clean and safe
We have been and will continue advocating with policymakers for additional relief measures to assist small businesses and provide targeted help for the travel industry
Specifically, we're urging the creation of a second draw loan program for existing Paycheck Protection Program borrowers, greater accommodation and streamlining for borrowers to obtain forgiveness, and liability protections for hotel owners who comply with health and safety protocols during the pandemic
We've also called for additional stimulus to support American discretionary spending, including in areas such as travel
In conclusion, Choice Hotels is positioned to emerge from these challenging times stronger, as we have done before in our 80-year history
Our proven portfolio of well-segmented brands, geographic footprint, and asset-light business model position us well to benefit from current consumer trends as they continue to evolve
I'll now invite our CFO to provide his update
I hope you and your families are well and healthy
Today, I'd like to provide additional insights into our third quarter performance, update you on our balance sheet and liquidity, as well as our approach to capital allocation, and finally, share our thoughts on the outlook for the future
Let's now examine our results more closely
For the third quarter of 2020, total revenues, excluding marketing and reservation system fees, were $103.6 million
Adjusted EBITDA totaled $74.9 million, representing an adjusted EBITDA margin of over 72%, and adjusted earnings per share were $0.66
Our domestic systemwide RevPAR for the third quarter outperformed the overall industry by nearly 20 percentage points, declining only 28.8% from the same quarter of 2019
Additionally, our results exceeded the primary chain scale segments in which we compete, as reported by STR, by six percentage points
Our brand strategy has consistently prioritized growth in the more lucrative upscale, extended-stay, and mid-scale segments, which is proving successful
During the third quarter, these three segments outperformed their respective industry chain scales and local competitors in terms of year-over-year RevPAR
Our upscale portfolio's RevPAR change surpassed the overall segment by 14 percentage points and outperformed its local competition by over nine percentage points
With an average domestic systemwide occupancy rate of 74%, our extended-stay portfolio's RevPAR change exceeded the industry by 40 percentage points and its local competitors by 14 percentage points
The RevPAR change for our mid-scale portfolio was nearly eight percentage points higher than the segment average
This RevPAR outperformance can be attributed to continued occupancy improvements and our franchisees' ability to maintain rates
Our domestic systemwide occupancy rate has improved since its lowest point of 28% in early April
From late June through October, our average weekly occupancy rates have consistently been above 50%
We've also seen improvements in our average daily rate index, which increased by 1.7 percentage points against local competitors in the third quarter
These specialists have been guiding our franchisees on optimizing their pricing strategies and providing advanced market intelligence and channel management
Despite challenging conditions, we managed to expand our system size, with domestic hotels growing by 0.7% and rooms by 1.9% year-over-year
Our more revenue-intensive brands in the upscale, extended-stay, and mid-scale segments saw even greater growth, with hotels increasing by 2.1% and rooms by 3.4% year-over-year
We're particularly pleased that Comfort, our flagship brand, continued to show positive unit and room growth in the third quarter following its brand transformation
Comfort's development success during these unprecedented times strongly validates the brand's value proposition
Comfort now accounts for nearly one-third of our total domestic pipeline, which will drive revenue-intensive growth in the coming years
Additionally, the brand's conversion pipeline grew by almost 50% in the third quarter compared to the previous year
We are especially satisfied with the company's performance regarding our effective royalty rate, which is driven by the attractive value we offer our franchisees, their ongoing desire to be associated with our strong brands, and our current pipeline
Our royalty rate continues to be a significant driver of our revenue growth
The company's domestic effective royalty rate increased by seven basis points year-over-year to 4.91% in the third quarter and has risen nine basis points year-to-date compared to the previous year
We anticipate continued growth in this area for the rest of the year as owners seek the security of a large, proven franchisor that delivers strong top-line results and helps maximize their return on investment
I'd like to discuss our balance sheet and capital allocation strategy
Throughout the third quarter, we maintained our focus on reducing discretionary costs, exercising discipline in capital allocation, and effectively allocating resources to drive top-line outperformance, all of which improved our cash position and strengthened our liquidity
We reduced our net debt by approximately $50 million during the third quarter and are pleased to report cash flow from operations of $70 million for the nine months ended September 30, with over $68 million generated in the third quarter alone
Our cash and liquidity profile remains exceptionally strong
At the end of the third quarter, the company had over $790 million in cash and available borrowing capacity through our revolving credit facility
We are on track to achieve our previously announced SG&A cost savings of nearly 25% in 2020 and expect to maintain a run rate of SG&A cost savings of approximately 15% in 2021 and beyond
The decisions we've made to better align our cost structure in the post-pandemic environment position us well to capitalize on opportunities as travel demand recovers, while allowing us to continue investing for the long term
Our capital allocation approach, characterized by prudence and discipline, remains key to our success
Choice's primary focus in this area has always been to increase organic growth by strategically investing back into the business, and that will not change
We are confident that our capacity and cash flows will allow us to weather the storm and increase the organic growth of our business by strategically investing in growing our brands and system size, executing our technology roadmap, and delivering proprietary franchisee-facing tools that help drive top-line revenues
Based on our proven track record of success in organic growth, we believe these internal investments will drive attractive returns for years to come
We will continue to evaluate other investments and capital return opportunities in the context of evolving market conditions and our overall capital allocation strategy moving forward
I'd like to share some thoughts on what lies ahead
The full and precise impact of the pandemic on our business for the remainder of 2020 and beyond remains largely unknown, as does the exact trajectory of our industry's recovery
While we are not issuing formal guidance today, we currently expect that the impact of COVID-19 on the company's year-over-year RevPAR change will be less significant for the fourth quarter compared to the third quarter of this year
Our outlook is based on the following factors
First, we are observing continued resilience in leisure demand and continue to outperform the industry relatively
Second, despite entering the fall season when demand is historically lower, we are pleased that our fourth quarter domestic RevPAR change has continued the pattern of sequential quarterly improvement through the week of October 24
In fact, we expect our October 2020 RevPAR to decline by approximately 25% compared to the same period in 2019
The final reason for our optimism is the nature of the current environment
Unlike the Great Recession, which was caused by underlying fundamental economic problems, the current economic downturn is tied to the course of the COVID-19 pandemic, which we believe could contribute to a faster recovery
We will continue to evaluate the impact of COVID-19 across the business and provide further updates in February during our next earnings call
In conclusion, we are optimistic that Choice Hotels is well-positioned to succeed for the remainder of 2020 and beyond
We continue to benefit from our resilient, primarily asset-light, franchise-focused business model, which has historically delivered stable returns throughout economic cycles and provided a degree of protection from market risks
While we are not immune to the pressures faced by the industry, we believe that our long-term focus and prudent, disciplined capital allocation strategy will allow us to continue capitalizing on opportunities during the recovery
Pat and I are now ready to answer any questions you may have
Summary:
output:
choice hotels international q3 adjusted earnings per share $0.66.
q3 adjusted earnings per share $0.66.
domestic systemwide revpar decreased 28.8% for q3 2020 compared to q3 2019.
not providing formal guidance for 2020 at this time.
currently expects impact of covid-19 on its year-over-year revpar change will be less significant for q4 than q3.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:The presentation slides for today's conference call can be found on our website, and we encourage you to view them as we proceed.
We caution listeners not to rely too heavily on these statements, which reflect management's views only as of today, April 29, 2020.
Our SEC filings contain information about potential factors and risks that could impact our actual operational results.
The company is not obligated to revise or publicly announce any changes to statements made during this call, except through filings related to this reporting period.
Today's discussion will reference non-GAAP financial measures.
Clean Harbors believes these metrics provide an additional way to measure and compare its performance consistently over time.
Let's begin with Slide 3.
Before we discuss our first quarter results, I want to address the coronavirus outbreak and our response to it.
The pandemic has created a global health crisis and economic turmoil, and I hope you and your loved ones are staying healthy.
At Clean Harbors, employee safety is ingrained in our culture and is our top concern during this pandemic.
As an essential service provider with teams working on the front lines of the COVID-19 crisis, we've implemented strict safety measures and worked closely with suppliers to ensure our employees have the necessary protective equipment.
Throughout the crisis, our field and plant workers have continued to support our customers' needs across North America.
Employees in critical administrative roles have supported our field teams remotely, with our robust systems enabling a nearly seamless transition.
We anticipate the virus will negatively impact our business in the second quarter, particularly in the Safety-Kleen division.
Safety-Kleen has been affected by reduced driving and business activity across North America, as well as the steep decline in base oil prices.
In summary, we're facing challenging short-term market conditions and are taking significant measures in response.
Let me highlight some of those actions.
We're aligning our cost structure with current demand by adjusting our workforce through furloughs and other reductions, implementing a freeze on non-essential hiring and wages, and restricting all travel.
We've also renegotiated with many vendors and suppliers for cost savings or improved payment terms.
Additionally, we've temporarily shut down half of our re-refining capacity due to the current base oil demand and anticipated decrease in used motor oil availability in Q2 and beyond.
To strengthen our financial position, we've drawn $150 million from our credit line in case the crisis worsens.
We've revised our net capital expenditure plans for 2020, reducing expected spending by over $50 million to conserve capital and support our free cash flow for the year.
Nevertheless, I believe our strong financial position puts us in a good place to succeed.
Moving to our Q1 financial results on Slide 4.
Revenue increased 10% compared to last year, with both operating segments showing solid growth.
Our adjusted EBITDA reached a record $122.6 million, driven by high-value waste streams, high utilization, and contributions from projects and emergency response work.
Our adjusted EBITDA margin improved by 130 basis points to 14.3%.
Turning to our segment results, starting with Slide 5.
Environmental Services revenue grew 11%, supported by contributions from our facilities network and Field Services group, and aided by mild weather throughout most of the quarter.
Adjusted EBITDA growth of 22% was due to business mix, disposal volumes, and emergency response revenue.
Emergency response work totaled $21 million, including COVID-19 decontamination efforts and cleanup of a chemical plant fire.
Our disposal facilities saw impressive volumes this quarter, with incinerator utilization increasing to 86% and landfill tonnage growing 39%.
Our average incineration price per pound in Q1 rose 11%, reflecting the record level of high-margin direct burn streams we collected.
The Environmental Service segment had another exceptional quarter.
Let's move on to the next slide.
Safety-Kleen's revenue increased by 8%, mainly due to growth in the SK Oil division.
Adjusted EBITDA and margin improved due to lower transportation costs for SK Oil and higher rerefining production compared to last year when volumes were affected by frozen rivers and floods.
The SK branch business's core services performed well.
Parts washer services remained stable compared to the previous year, waste oil collection increased slightly to 55 million gallons, blended products made up 25% of volume in the quarter, and our direct volume was 7%.
The first quarter started with promising signs that IMO 2020 would allow us to expand our refining spread as high sulfur fuel oil values decreased and base oil prices rose in early January.
However, the oil shock caused by the global coronavirus outbreak has largely sidelined IMO 2020, and base oil prices have dropped by $1 per gallon.
We entered the second quarter facing significant pressure on our rerefining spread.
In the current market conditions, used motor oil is in a charge-for-oil state.
We have significantly increased our charge-for-oil program in response to the current market situation.
Driving in the U.S. and Canada must return to normal levels before our spread and lubricant demand can recover.
We will consider reopening our closed rerefineries when we see conditions improve.
Let's look at the next slide.
Our capital allocation strategy is more crucial than ever in the current environment.
As mentioned earlier, we are cutting our planned net capital expenditure by over $50 million.
We sold two businesses in Western Canada during the first quarter as we continued to reduce our direct exposure to the energy sector.
Since starting our divestiture program several years ago, we have sold seven businesses for about $120 million in total.
Regarding mergers and acquisitions, we are unlikely to be active in the near future.
We believe that in the long term, we will emerge from this market downturn in a stronger position, both financially and operationally, compared to some of our competitors, which will allow us to take advantage of opportunities.
We will likely pause our stock buyback program until we are certain that the domestic economy is clearly on the path to recovery.
We also plan to repay the $150 million on the revolving credit facility as soon as this crisis shows signs of ending.
Looking ahead to our business segments, although we have experienced some cancellations and project delays due to COVID-19, we expect our Environmental Service segment to perform relatively well during the current downturn.
We anticipate that our decontamination work and increasing volumes of infection waste will help offset what would otherwise be a larger decline.
In the Safety-Kleen segment, we expect both our branch business and SK Oil to be significantly impacted, particularly in the second quarter, as stay-at-home orders greatly reduce vehicle travel and generate less used motor oil.
Our SK branch business should recover as shelter-in-place mandates are lifted and low gasoline prices encourage people to drive more.
In SK Oil, our rerefining spread has narrowed due to the drop in crude oil prices, and we have aggressively increased our charge-for-oil pricing, but volumes are down and near-term demand for base oil has decreased.
To summarize, our first quarter results demonstrated the strength of our business model, the value of our assets, and our frontline role in emergency response.
Our market leadership, financial liquidity, and positive free cash flow will enable us to navigate this global crisis.
I want to reiterate Alan's comments about the outstanding work of our team and everyone on the front lines of the crisis.
The unprecedented events of the past few weeks have given us all a deeper appreciation for the professionals, especially healthcare workers, who risk their lives daily to help those in need.
Let's move on to Slide 9 and our income statement.
As Alan mentioned, we achieved record first quarter results.
Sales increased by approximately $78 million, with adjusted EBITDA rising by about $21 million.
The quarter's performance was influenced by the variety of services provided, project activities, and favorable weather conditions.
In terms of gross profit, we experienced a significant increase in both total amount and percentage, attributed to improved utilization, better pricing, and a beneficial comparison to the previous year.
Our gross margin saw a rise of 160 basis points compared to last year.
Selling, general, and administrative expenses increased by $14.5 million during the quarter due to higher revenue, investments in personnel, and some non-recurring expenses from the previous year.
Moving forward, we are concentrating our cost-cutting efforts in this area to align expenses with our revenue.
Depreciation and amortization in the first quarter decreased slightly to $47.5 million.
We acquired two small complementary businesses in 2019 while also selling off several operations.
For 2020, we anticipate depreciation and amortization to be between $285 million and $295 million, which is slightly lower than the previous year.
Operating income grew by 92% to $45.5 million, setting a first-quarter record, reflecting our revenue growth and enhanced gross profit.
According to GAAP, earnings per share were $0.21 in the first quarter, compared to $0.02 in the same period last year.
Our adjusted earnings per share amounted to $0.28.
Let's examine the balance sheet on Slide 10.
As Alan mentioned, we borrowed $150 million from our credit line during the first quarter, which increased our cash and short-term marketable securities to $494.3 million at the end of the quarter.
We observed reasonable accounts receivable collection towards the end of March, contributing to a healthy cash balance.
Our strong liquidity position further safeguards our company and provides additional financial flexibility if needed.
Our balance sheet remains in a good position.
Current and long-term debt obligations at the end of the quarter increased to $1.7 billion, reflecting the drawdown on our credit line.
Our weighted average cost of debt is now 4.3%, with a balanced mix of fixed and variable debt.
Leverage on a net debt basis was 2.2 times for the trailing 12 months ending March 31.
Looking at our most recent cash balance from yesterday, our cash remains essentially unchanged from the end of the first quarter.
The team has done an excellent job maintaining focus on collections and managing our expenses.
Let's review cash flows on Slide 11.
Cash from operations in the first quarter increased slightly to $33.7 million.
Capital expenditures, net of disposals and the purchase of our headquarters, were $59.9 million, higher than last year, resulting in adjusted free cash flow for the quarter of negative $26.2 million, which aligns with the previous year and our expectations.
For the year, we are now targeting capital expenditures, net of disposals and purchase of our headquarters, to be between $140 million and $160 million.
During the quarter, we bought back approximately 300,000 shares of our stock at an average price of $57.41 per share, totaling $17.3 million.
As Alan mentioned, we will be cautious in our approach to buybacks until we see evidence that markets are well into their recovery phase.
As Alan also noted, given the uncertain market conditions, we are withdrawing our 2020 guidance.
We hope to reinstate guidance with our second-quarter earnings announcement, provided markets have stabilized.
To summarize, the first quarter was strong, marked by several financial records, including adjusted EBITDA.
If not for COVID-19, our first-quarter results would have set us up for the fourth consecutive year of profitable growth.
We have implemented significant measures in response to the pandemic and are prepared to take additional steps if the recovery is prolonged.
We are focusing on factors within our control, including careful cost management and seeking new waste streams for our landfills and incinerators.
Summary:
output:
compname posts q1 earnings per share of $0.21.
q1 earnings per share $0.21.
q1 adjusted earnings per share $0.28.
withdraws 2020 adjusted ebitda and adjusted free cash flow guidance.
downsizing its workforce through furloughs and other actions.
lowering its expected 2020 net capex spend by more than $50 million.
drawing down $150 million on its revolving credit facility.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Accompanying me on the call are Arsen Kitch, our CEO and President, along with Mike Murphy, our CFO.
The company released its Q4 2020 financial results shortly after the market closed today.
Overall, the company reported Q4 net sales of $453 million and adjusted EBITDA of $72 million.
This represents year-over-year growth of about 4% and 38%, respectively, compared to Q4 of the previous year.
I'd like to highlight a few key points from our business performance.
Our tissue division drove results with increased sales and production volumes compared to last year, meeting unpredictable demand that surpassed our expectations.
Our sales volume in the quarter matched our production levels.
Our paperboard division also delivered strong results.
We have substantial order backlogs, which influenced our decision to implement a $50 per ton price increase across our SBS product range, effective February 2.
During Q4, we utilized the generated free cash flow to further reduce our net debt by $58 million.
On the fourth slide, as I've mentioned in previous quarters, we continue to prioritize our employees' health and safety, as well as maintaining safe operations to serve our customers during the COVID-19 pandemic.
Our risk mitigation strategies are proving effective in reducing COVID-19 risks at our facilities.
Our HR and manufacturing leadership teams are doing an outstanding job of proactively monitoring our workforce's health and ensuring adequate staffing levels.
The dedication of our employees has been crucial to our success thus far and will continue to be essential.
To acknowledge our entire team's efforts during these challenging times, we distributed a one-time discretionary bonus of $1,000 to over 2,800 employees in November.
We're also actively encouraging all our staff to receive the COVID-19 vaccine by offering a $200 incentive.
I want to express my sincere appreciation to our entire team for their exceptional efforts and resilience during this difficult period.
As we begin to see the positive effects of widespread vaccine distribution, I urge everyone to remain vigilant until COVID-19 is under control and behind us.
I will now provide an overview of our tissue and paperboard divisions' performance in the fourth quarter.
Let's begin with our Consumer Products division, as shown on slide five.
As previously mentioned, at-home tissue demand was unpredictable during the quarter.
New waves of the pandemic led to significant demand spikes from mid-November through mid-December.
While we initially expected demand to be at or below Q4 2019 levels, we were reminded of the unpredictability of essential product demand during this time.
Mike will provide more details on Q4 demand patterns during his remarks.
Our team and customers are effectively managing this volatility, and we benefited from higher-than-expected sales and production volumes in Q4.
Our industry outlook remains largely unchanged, which I'll summarize in a few key points for context.
Firstly, remember that the U.S. tissue market is traditionally split 2/3 at-home and 1/3 away-from-home, with limited manufacturing flexibility to switch between the two.
With consumers spending more time at home, there has been a shift towards at-home consumption.
Demand fluctuations have been and will continue to be driven by consumer behavior.
We anticipate that as COVID-19 vaccines are administered and infection rates decrease, there will be a shift back to away-from-home consumption, which we expect will negatively impact us as we primarily focus on the at-home market.
However, it's uncertain whether there will be lasting changes in consumer behavior post-COVID.
Secondly, while it's too early to determine private brand share trends, we continue to observe that paper towel demand is outpacing the overall tissue category, while facial tissue demand is lagging.
Private brands have consistently gained market share relative to branded products over the past decade, a trend we expect to continue.
We will continue to monitor these trends in the coming months and quarters due to ongoing uncertainty in consumer demand related to COVID-19.
Thirdly, as noted in previous quarters, SKU rationalization has occurred, facilitating increased production.
We believe that reduced SKU counts benefit both retailers and manufacturers like us.
Although some customers are expressing interest in recovering SKUs, we don't expect SKU counts to return to pre-COVID levels in the near to medium term.
Our tissue division performed strongly in Q4.
We shipped 13.9 million cases, up approximately 5.3% compared to Q4 2019.
Sales decreased by 4.2% compared to Q3 2020.
As mentioned during our Q3 earnings call, we ended relationships with several customers to reduce complexity and improve our network, which impacted Q4 results and is expected to affect Q1 2021 results as well.
We are optimistic about our sales pipeline for the remainder of 2021.
As a reminder, we estimate that roughly 2/3 of paperboard demand comes from products that are more recession-resistant, while 1/3 is driven by more economically sensitive or discretionary products.
Our folding carton customers, particularly those focused on food or healthcare packaging, continue to experience strong demand, while our food service customers, especially those concentrated in quick-service restaurants and away-from-home dining, continue to face weaker demand.
We are pleased with the market reception of our sustainability-focused brands, Nuvo Cup and ReMagine folding carton.
Both are playing a significant role in our favorable market position.
We're encouraged by our solid performance in the quarter and continued strong demand for our products.
We recently announced a temporary suspension of production at our Cypress Bend facility due to natural gas curtailment in Arkansas.
Natural gas deliveries were reduced to the point where we could no longer operate.
We estimate that the costs associated with the weather event across our paperboard system, including lost production, repairs, and spikes in natural gas prices, could impact us in Q1 by approximately $6 million to $8 million.
We continue to experience the same fundamental supply and demand dynamics that led us to announce a $50 per ton price increase in January.
Demand remains robust and our backlogs have grown since the beginning of the year.
The implementation of price increases has begun and is expected to take several more months to fully complete.
The consolidated company summary income statement displays fourth quarter results as well as full year figures for 2020 and 2019.
For the fourth quarter, diluted net income was $1.34 per share and adjusted EBITDA reached $71.6 million, while full year diluted net income was $4.61 per share with adjusted EBITDA of $283.2 million.
These figures show substantial growth compared to previous periods, largely due to increased tissue demand from COVID-related consumer behavior, benefits from the Shelby investment, favorable raw material costs, and the absence of a major planned outage in the paperboard division.
The relevant segment results can be found on slide eight.
The paperboard business maintained strong adjusted EBITDA performance, while consumer products saw benefits from significant sales growth and fixed cost leverage related to production increases and favorable input costs.
Before delving into divisional performance details, it's worth noting changes in how we present our financial bridges.
We have altered our approach to include production volume changes in the volume category rather than the cost category as previously done.
We believe this modification will help investors better understand sales changes, as we expect to produce similar quantities to what we sell, which will all fall under the volume category.
The cost category will now more accurately reflect changes in raw material input pricing and inflation.
This sheeting service distorts the sales price of our base paperboard products.
We have also decided to implement some accounting changes that will affect our financials starting in 2021, which we want to bring to your attention today.
These changes and their pro forma impact can be reviewed in our 8-K filing.
Bail pulp sales from our Lewiston mill to third parties, previously recorded in our tissue business, will now be recorded in our paperboard business.
Bail pulp sales from Lewiston to our tissue operations will be transferred at market price going forward, rather than at cost.
We believe this change will more accurately reflect the economics of the business.
We will continue to transfer pulp from the Lewiston pulp mill to the Lewiston tissue operations at cost due to the co-located nature of these assets.
As a reminder, we started our new Shelby, North Carolina paper machine in the second quarter of 2019, incurring expected start-up costs related to lower production throughput, higher waste, and other expenses throughout 2019.
We reached the targeted production rate for our new paper machine in the second quarter of 2020 and continue to reap the benefits of the project, including ramping up our converting lines, realizing supply chain savings, and achieving sales wins and mix improvements.
While we're not providing specific dollar amounts for these costs and benefits, the ongoing realization of the Shelby investment is a key factor in our performance improvement.
Our product mix continues to improve as Shelby has come online, more than offsetting some year-over-year price impacts.
We're benefiting from volume increases related to the production ramp, which helped meet elevated demand.
Overall, lower input costs, improved mix, and fixed cost leverage from increased production positively impacted our tissue business in the fourth quarter of 2020 compared to the same period in 2019.
A comparison of our fourth quarter 2020 performance to the third quarter of 2020 can be found on slide 17 of the appendix.
Slide 10 provides additional context on tissue related to demand volatility and its impact on our financial performance.
The IRI panel data, which shows retail sales of tissue in dollars, illustrates what our customers and we have observed in consumer demand patterns, with the line showing year-over-year changes and the box data showing quarterly comparisons to the previous year.
As we ended the third quarter, we anticipated elevated but stable demand.
Based on that demand profile, sufficient inventory levels at our customers, and slowing demand from customers in October, we expected softness in our fourth quarter sales.
However, a consumer-driven demand spike in mid-November through December rapidly changed this outlook.
This period of volatility, including the October pullback mentioned in our third quarter earnings call and strong orders in November and December, serves as a reminder that we may not return to a stable order pattern until COVID-related volatility subsides, affecting our ability to forecast the business.
