We've included an additional slide in the appendix of the supplemental materials detailing the weekly volatility in IRI panel data experienced by our customers and supply chain.
Our fourth quarter sales were 13.9 million cases, representing a 4.2% unit decline from the third quarter but a 5.3% unit growth compared to the previous year.
Production in the quarter was 13.9 million cases, down 9% from the third quarter but up 2.4% from the previous year.
Production levels have benefited from the Shelby ramp and SKU rationalization.
The cost leverage from the significant increase in production, along with improved costs in freight and logistics, led to continued strong year-over-year results.
Slide 11 shows a year-over-year adjusted EBITDA comparison for our paperboard business.
Lower pricing, as reported by RISI in February 2020, was partially offset by favorable mix.
The absence of a planned major outage at our Cypress Bend mill also contributed to year-over-year improvement.
Overall, our team operated our facilities well in the quarter and continued to deliver strong results.
A comparison of our fourth quarter 2020 performance to the third quarter of 2020 can be found on slide 18 in the appendix.
Slide 12 provides insight into our first quarter outlook and some key drivers for the full year 2021.
As previously discussed, the tissue outlook is largely dependent on sales demand.
Tissue shipments in January were 4.6 million cases, with February shipments trending below 4 million cases.
At this pace, we expect first quarter shipments to be lower than levels seen in the first quarter of 2020, when COVID initially impacted consumer buying patterns, and down compared to the fourth quarter of 2020.
As mentioned earlier, our paperboard business announced a price increase of $50 per ton across our SBS grades, effective February 2.
Given the nature of our agreements and customer discussions, we expect the benefits of this increase to be reflected over the next couple of quarters, with limited benefit expected in Q1.
The unexpected weather-related outage at our Arkansas mill, which caused lost production and repairs as well as natural gas price increases across our paperboard system, is expected to negatively impact the quarter by approximately $6 million to $8 million.
If our assumptions are correct, we anticipate first quarter adjusted EBITDA to be in the range of $51 million to $59 million.
This range assumes we continue to operate our assets without significant COVID-related disruptions.
While we are not prepared to provide specific annual guidance for 2021, there are several drivers, assumptions, and variables we would like to address.
The previously announced SBS price increases are expected to have a favorable effect.
We anticipate tissue volumes will decrease by high single to low double-digit percentages.
This prediction is based on the assumption that consumer purchasing habits will continue to normalize, but it heavily depends on how the pandemic progresses.
Our sales pipeline appears promising and is expected to positively influence the latter half of the year.
Paperboard volumes are predicted to remain relatively stable.
We foresee increased costs for inputs such as pulp, packaging, energy, and freight.
While these factors are challenging to predict currently, the total impact of raw material inputs could be a $40 million to $50 million setback this year, with pulp accounting for more than half of this amount.
In our paperboard division, scheduled major maintenance shutdowns are projected to reduce our 2021 earnings by $25 million to $30 million compared to 2020.
We have revised this guidance on slide 23, breaking down the timing by quarter to reflect our current plan.
In response to the Cypress Bend weather event, we are reassessing the timing of our outage schedule and may provide updates in future quarters.
For the entire year of 2021, we also anticipate the following: interest expense between $38 million and $40 million.
Depreciation is projected to be between $106 million and $110 million.
Capital expenditures are expected to range from $60 million to $65 million, aligning more closely with historical trends as we plan to execute projects that were delayed in 2020.
We anticipate an effective tax rate of 25% to 26%, and we plan to use some of our current tax attributes, amounting to $60 million, to reduce cash taxes.
Slide 13 provides an overview of our capital structure.
We used approximately $50 million of free cash flow to decrease our net debt, including making voluntary prepayments on our term loan, and our liquidity stood at $250 million at year-end.
We continue to make progress in reducing our net debt and enhancing our financial flexibility as we aim for a net debt to adjusted EBITDA ratio of 2.5 times, assuming adjusted EBITDA after COVID benefits and with a normal amount of outages.
Before concluding with our value proposition, I wanted to highlight some of our key achievements in 2020 on slide 14.
Our team excellently managed the challenges posed by COVID.
We minimized risks in our facilities by prioritizing health and safety while continuing to operate our assets and serve our customers.
We swiftly adapted to demand fluctuations to strengthen customer relationships.
We successfully launched our new Shelby paper machine and are on track to fully ramp up the entire site by the end of this year.
We delivered exceptional financial results, reduced net debt by $200 million, refinanced our near-term debt maturities, and strengthened our balance sheet.
Simultaneously, we underwent several leadership changes, including my promotion to CEO, hiring a new CFO, and appointing a new leader for our CPD business.
It was undoubtedly an eventful year, to say the least, and I'm proud of the numerous changes we implemented while maintaining high performance levels.
We believe we are well-positioned entering 2021 to continue improving our business and focusing on our near-term strategy of debt reduction while developing options for long-term capital allocation.
I'd like to reemphasize our value proposition, which we discussed in our previous earnings call and mentioned to investors throughout the quarter.
We believe Clearwater Paper is well-positioned across two attractive and complementary businesses.
Our Consumer Products division is a leader in the growing private branded tissue market.
From our perspective, we believe the key strengths of this business are as follows: firstly, we have a national footprint with the ability to supply a wide range of product categories and quality tiers.
This is an attractive sales proposition for our customers.
Our expertise in manufacturing, supply chain, and transportation is a key differentiator, especially during challenging times like today.
Secondly, there are long-term trends shifting from branded products to private brands.
These trends have typically been amplified during economic downturns.
Private brand tissue share in the U.S. increased to over 30% in 2019, up from 18% in 2011.
While these trends are impressive, we're still far from the levels seen in many European countries where private brands represent over half of total tissue share.
Lastly, tissue is an economically resilient and essential product.
Historically, demand has not been negatively affected by economic uncertainty.
Regarding our paperboard division, we believe the key strengths of this business are as follows: firstly, we operate well-invested assets with a geographic footprint that allows us to efficiently serve customers on both coasts.
We have a diverse customer base serving end markets with largely stable demand.
Secondly, not being vertically integrated enables us to focus on independent customers with unparalleled service and quality commitments.
Thirdly, we believe the business is well-positioned to capitalize on trends towards more sustainable packaging and food service products.
Lastly, our paperboard business has demonstrated the ability to generate good margins and solid cash flows.
Overall, our major capital investments are behind us, and we're prioritizing cash flows to reduce debt.
As we demonstrated in the fourth quarter, with a net debt reduction of approximately $58 million, bringing our net reduction in 2020 to over $200 million.
We intend to continue deleveraging by delivering benefits from our Shelby investment, continuing operational improvements, aggressively managing working capital, and prudently allocating capital.
While we expect lower tissue shipments in the first part of the year, we're making sound strategic moves to support our customers and their success and continue to position our business for long-term success.
We believe this strategy is the best way to create shareholder value.
With an adjusted EBITDA impacted by normal outages and reduced COVID benefits, we do not anticipate achieving our 2.5 leverage target this year.
We continually engage with our Board on future capital allocations.
Beyond deleveraging, we expect to explore various means of creating shareholder value, including: firstly, internal investments in our operations that improve competitiveness.
Secondly, external investments that deliver synergies and improve our market position; and thirdly, returning capital to our shareholders.
Summary:
output:
q4 earnings per share $1.34.
q4 sales $453 million versus refinitiv ibes estimate of $449.3 million.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:John Faucher, the Chief Investor Relations Officer, is speaking.
The actual outcomes may significantly deviate from these projections.
I'll discuss our fourth quarter and annual results, as well as our 2021 forecast, before handing over to Noel to share his thoughts on maintaining our growth momentum in 2021.
We'll then commence the question and answer session.
As is customary, we kindly request that you stick to one question to allow as many participants as possible to inquire.
We concluded 2020 on a high note, achieving our highest quarterly organic sales growth in over a decade and our strongest annual organic sales growth since the financial crisis.
Notably, we continue to achieve balanced growth, which we consider crucial for sustained strong performance.
Both the quarter and the year saw growth in volume and pricing, organic growth across all four of our divisions: oral care, personal care, home care, and pet nutrition, and organic sales growth in every division with strong performances in both emerging and developed markets.
Our strategy to deliver more impactful premium innovation is in its early phases, but we believe the results are starting to become evident.
Significantly, this growth is positively impacting our income statement.
We achieved substantial gross margin expansion for both the quarter and the year, enabling us to deliver profitable growth despite significant investments for future growth and foreign exchange headwinds.
Our net sales increased by 7.5% in the quarter.
The 8.5% organic sales growth was composed of 5% organic volume growth and a 3.5% price increase.
Acquisitions contributed an additional 100 basis points to volume growth, while foreign exchange had a 2% negative impact.
In Q4, our gross profit margin was 61.1% on both a GAAP basis, up 100 basis points year-over-year, and a base business basis, up 90 basis points.
For Q4, pricing had a 130 basis point positive effect on gross margin, while raw materials had a 320 basis point negative impact due to increased costs of materials like fats and oils and the transactional impact of foreign exchange.
Productivity provided a 280 basis point benefit.
On a GAAP basis, our SG&A increased by 260 basis points as a percentage of sales for Q4 and 100 basis points for the full year.
On a base business basis in Q4, our SG&A rose by 310 basis points as a percentage of sales.
This was primarily due to a 210 basis point increase in advertising to sales ratio as we heavily invested in brand building, innovation, and e-commerce.
Our SG&A ratio was also affected by higher logistics costs, mainly in the U.S., and investments in growth and innovation.
For the full year on a base business basis, our SG&A ratio increased by 150 basis points, primarily due to a 100 basis point increase in advertising to sales ratio and higher logistics costs.
For Q4 on a GAAP basis, our operating profit grew by 4% year-over-year, while it increased by 3% on a base business basis.
Our earnings per share remained flat on a GAAP basis but increased by 5% on a base business basis.
For the full year, our earnings per share growth was 14% on a GAAP basis and 8% on a base business basis.
We achieved 18% growth in free cash flow for the full year.
As discussed at the start of 2020, we used some of the free cash flow to reduce debt, primarily related to the Filorga transaction, with the remainder used for dividends and share repurchases.
Regarding our divisional performance, North America achieved 10% net sales and 8.5% organic sales growth in the quarter, driven by premium innovation and increased consumption in categories affected by the COVID pandemic.
We also saw improved performance in our skin health businesses during the quarter.
Our e-commerce business in North America ended the year strongly, with Q4 sales more than doubling compared to the previous year.
North America significantly increased brand support for the hum by Colgate Electric Brush, the Colgate Optic White Overnight Teeth Whitening pen, our toothpaste business, and Irish Spring.
Latin American net sales decreased slightly as double-digit organic sales growth was offset by the negative impact of foreign exchange.
The strong organic sales growth was widespread, with organic sales growth in every hub for both the quarter and the year.
Oral care innovation has been a key growth driver, with Colgate Tartar Control, Luminous White Charcoal, and our Natural Extracts line all contributing to incremental growth.
Europe achieved double-digit net sales growth in the quarter.
Organic sales growth of 4.5% was driven by volume growth across all three segments - oral care, personal care, and home care - and in every hub.
Strong oral care volume growth for the Colgate and elmex brands was accompanied by significant brand-building investment in traditional and digital media.
Filorga experienced a return to organic growth, with strong performance in China offsetting weaknesses in travel retail.
Asia Pacific saw 7% net sales and 5% organic sales growth, driven by volume increases in major markets like Greater China, India, the Philippines, and South Pacific.
Improved toothpaste performance in India and China was achieved through strategic product launches and relaunches.
Personal care and home care products benefited from increased demand due to COVID-19 in the South Pacific region.
Despite foreign exchange challenges, Africa/Eurasia achieved organic sales growth across all categories and hubs, although net sales declined 1.5%.
Colgate Herbal, Colgate Maxfresh, and Colgate Total led toothpaste organic sales growth.
Meridol showed strong growth, aiming to increase market share in the pharmacy channel.
Hill's delivered another quarter of strong net sales and organic sales growth, despite challenging comparisons.
The US led organic sales growth, with e-commerce showing significant increases, while Europe achieved double-digit growth.
The Prescription Diet business is showing signs of recovery as veterinary channel traffic improves.
Organic sales growth is projected to be within the 3% to 5% long-term target range.
Foreign exchange is expected to provide a low-single-digit benefit for the year, though currency volatility may continue.
Net sales are anticipated to increase by 4% to 7%.
Gross profit margin is expected to improve year-over-year in 2021, despite challenging comparisons and increased raw material costs.
Advertising expenditure as a percentage of sales is projected to increase, though less than in 2020.
The tax rate is estimated to be between 23.5% and 24.5% for both GAAP and base business.
GAAP earnings-per-share growth is expected in the low-to-mid single digits.
Base business earnings-per-share growth is anticipated in the mid-to-high single digits.
The wider guidance range reflects heightened uncertainty in planning for the year.
Several factors could impact performance within this range, including changes in pandemic-related consumption patterns and foreign exchange movements in emerging markets.
The company is optimistic about pricing plans for 2021, considering recent raw material trends, competition, and foreign exchange.
Increased raw material costs are budgeted, but faster-than-anticipated price acceleration could pressure gross margin expansion.
Logistics costs have risen, particularly in the US and for shipping containers in Asia, and are expected to remain high in the near term.
The company expresses hope for a return to normalcy over the course of the year.
Stan has joined the company and has quickly become involved in operations.
The company is proud of its employees' accomplishments in 2020.
Three key topics guided crisis management: adhering to values and purpose, adapting strategies with agility, and planning for the future.
Employee safety measures were implemented while maintaining supply chain and laboratory operations, resulting in record output.
Safeguarding Colgate employees' wellbeing remains our top concern, and we'll maintain this priority throughout 2021.
This year, we collaborated with the World Health Organization and local medical facilities to provide complimentary health and hygiene products worldwide, aiming to curb COVID's spread and enhance people's wellbeing, initiatives that Colgate staff take great pride in.
In the second area, we're implementing our growth-oriented strategy to achieve sustainable, lucrative expansion through more effective premium innovations, which will be elaborated on at CAGNY, enhancing our global brand development, and carrying out our digital transformation plan.
As John outlined, we accomplished this while delivering robust and balanced growth in organic net sales, net sales, operating profit, earnings per share, and free cash flow.
We managed to achieve these outcomes despite numerous operational challenges and a substantial negative impact from currency exchange rates.
However, most crucially, while we've been meeting our 2020 targets, we've been intensely focused on setting ourselves up for growth in 2021 and beyond by capitalizing on our momentum, which was the third topic, navigating through this crisis with an eye on the future.
Now I'll share some thoughts on why I believe our actions last year position us well to continue our growth trajectory in 2021 and beyond.
There are three reasons: firstly, as an organization, we've fundamentally altered our approach to growth.
As a company with leading brands, we must focus on driving category growth, which we can achieve in various ways.
Naturally, we can increase our customer base, we can raise the price customers are willing to pay for our products, and we can boost the frequency of product usage.
We've enhanced existing tools and, importantly, developed new capabilities to drive this growth.
For example, with Hill's, we're reaching a broader consumer base through increased advertising to expand our reach and improving our digital targeting to raise brand awareness and household penetration for a truly differentiated brand.
This involves finding the right person with the right message at the right time.
It's not just about spending more, but spending more intelligently.
In Latin America, we've utilized revenue growth management tools to drive value with price/mix improvement in a challenging operating environment.
For instance, our share of the premium toothpaste segment in Brazil has grown by three points over the past two years, driven entirely by skillful and strategic revenue growth management.
As I discussed at the Barclays Conference, we've revamped our innovation processes to focus on breakthrough and transformational innovation, enabling us to increase the frequency of product usage and purchases.
Superior performance, new forms, delivery systems, and innovation for new channels all allow us to expand our availability to consumers so they can choose our products more frequently.
Given that the Colgate brand has the highest household penetration of any consumer brand globally, we have a unique ability to leverage our presence for faster growth.
The second reason is that we're developing a balanced approach to delivering profitable growth.
We recognize that to achieve a top-tier Total Shareholder Return among our peer group, we can't focus solely on top-line growth.
We need to deliver profitable growth.
This is evident in our 2020 results, where we achieved 8% earnings-per-share growth despite negative foreign exchange, while increasing brand building and investing in capabilities across the entire organization.
We're accomplishing this by leveraging all available tools: premium innovation, revenue growth management, funding growth, overhead discipline, and intense focus on all cost elements throughout the income statement.
Looking ahead, we must do more than offset the expected increases in raw material costs, logistics, and other areas so we can continue investing in the transformation capabilities we're deploying, which will depend on more effectively pairing growth and productivity.
The third reason is that we're making necessary cultural changes to unleash the true potential of Colgate employees.
As anyone who has joined us from outside can attest, Colgate employees' desire to succeed is unparalleled.
In 2020, we took several steps to accelerate change and build an organization for future growth.
To that end, we made significant progress in e-commerce, bringing in more external talent while upskilling existing talent across the enterprise, launching more online-specific innovations like the Optic White pen and the Miracle Repair serum, and investing broadly in enhanced digital capabilities.
This all resulted in over 50% online growth in the fourth quarter, and we'll end the year with e-commerce at a double-digit run rate as a percentage of total sales.
Lastly, it's about building the right team.
You need to provide them with the right tools and technology to digitally transform the organization.
We continue to invest in systems to enable this transformation.
Our transition to SAP S/4HANA is providing better system speed, improved reporting, streamlined processes, and simplified transactions.
We've developed our cloud capabilities, giving us greater agility, speed, and ability to develop applications faster and realize their value more quickly; and with our partners, we're supporting our data and analytics journey ahead.
We also recently implemented a new global system with our Colgate Business Planning process.
You'll recall this was called CBP, which will significantly reduce process time, providing greater opportunity for our teams to conduct analytics, particularly in the commercial area and especially around revenue growth management.
In conclusion, when I reflect on 2020 as a year where our company navigated through uncertainty to deliver strong results, I'll also view it as a year where we elevated our performance and capabilities, positioning ourselves to deliver sustainable, profitable growth in the future.
Summary:
output:
providing financial guidance for full year 2021.
expects fy net sales to be up 4% to 7% including a low-single-digit benefit from foreign exchange.
expects 2021 organic sales to be up within its long-term targeted range of 3% to 5%.
as we enter 2021, expect volatility in raw material and logistics costs and foreign exchange.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:To join the call online, please visit Capital One's website at capitalone.com and use the provided links.
Capital One reported earnings of $3.3 billion or $7.03 per diluted common share in the first quarter.
Pre-provision earnings grew by 1% to $3.4 billion in the quarter, and we noted a provision benefit of $823 million.
Following $535 million in gains from our Snowflake investment in 2021, we experienced a $75 million loss on our position in the first quarter, equivalent to $0.12 per share.
We have completely divested our position, resulting in a total gain of $460 million.
On Slide 4, I will provide a more detailed explanation of the quarterly allowance changes.
We released $1.6 billion of allowance in the first quarter.
The release was prompted by strong credit performance across all business segments and an improved economic outlook, including the $1.9 trillion stimulus package passed in March.
Our allowance continues to assume that the connection between economic indicators and credit performance will return to historical trends.
Despite improved credit performance and a more positive economic outlook, we maintain substantial qualitative factors to account for various remaining uncertainties.
On Slide 5, I will break down the allowance coverage by segment.
Following the $1.6 billion allowance release, our coverage levels decreased slightly across all segments compared to the previous quarter but remain significantly higher than pre-pandemic levels.
Our domestic card coverage is now 10.5%, down from 10.8% in the previous quarter.
Our branded card coverage stands at 12.1%.
The difference between branded and domestic coverage is due to the loss-sharing agreement in our partnership portfolio.
Coverage in our consumer business decreased by 38 basis points to 3.6%.
Coverage in our commercial banking business dropped by 23 basis points to 2%.
Moving to Slide 6, I will discuss liquidity.
Our preliminary average liquidity coverage ratio for the first quarter was 139%, well above the 100% regulatory requirement.
Our liquidity reserves from cash, securities, and federal home loan bank capacity ended the quarter at approximately $151 billion.
The $7 billion increase in total liquidity is primarily due to strong inflows of consumer and commercial deposits in the final weeks of the quarter.
On Slide 7, I will address our net interest margin.
NIM decreased by six basis points compared to the previous quarter, mainly due to a 14-basis-point impact from having two fewer days in the quarter and a higher proportion of cash.
These factors were partially offset by the full quarter effect of deposit pricing actions taken in the fourth quarter and a slight increase in loan yields.
Lastly, on Slide 8, I will discuss our capital position.
Our common equity Tier 1 capital ratio was 14.6% at the end of the first quarter, an increase of 90 basis points from the fourth quarter and 260 basis points higher than a year ago.
We continue to estimate that our CET1 capital requirement is around 11%.
In January, our board of directors approved a repurchase plan of up to $7.5 billion of the company's common stock.
We repurchased $490 million of common stock in the first quarter at an average price of approximately $114 per share.
Due to the Fed's extension of the trailing four-quarter average earnings rule, our share repurchase capacity will be limited to approximately $1.7 billion in the second quarter.
The timing and amount of future stock repurchase activities will depend on regulatory restrictions, stock trading volumes, and our overall view of our capital position.
I'll start with Slide 10, which covers our credit card business.
Credit card loan balances and revenue decreased year-over-year in the first quarter due to the ongoing effects of the pandemic.
Purchase volume showed improvement compared to the first quarter of 2020.
The provision for credit losses, which saw significant improvement, was the primary factor influencing quarterly results.
The outcomes of the credit card segment are primarily determined by the performance and trends of our domestic card business, as illustrated on Slide 11.
For the third straight quarter, our domestic card business continues to exhibit two contrasting aspects of the same situation.
Unusually high payment rates, intensified by government stimulus effects, continue to impact loan balances negatively.
Conversely, these same factors are resulting in exceptional credit performance.
Let's first examine growth.
We observed a continued rebound in purchase volume from the sharp declines experienced early in the pandemic.
In the first quarter, domestic card purchase volume increased by 8.4% compared to the previous year, with growth accelerating in March.
When compared to the first quarter of 2019, purchase volume has risen by 17%.
Most spending categories now surpass the pre-pandemic levels observed in 2019.
Travel and entertainment spending still lags behind pre-pandemic levels, but it's catching up.
Travel and entertainment purchase volume is growing at a faster rate than overall purchase volume.
The historically high payment rate continues to put pressure on loan balances, despite the increase in consumer spending.
At the conclusion of the first quarter, domestic card ending loan balances had decreased by $18.5 billion, or approximately 17%, compared to the previous year.
Excluding the impact of a partnership portfolio moved to held-for-sale last year, first-quarter ending loans declined by about 15% year over year.
The year-over-year percentage change in ending loan balances this quarter was roughly the same as the previous quarter.
Remarkably strong credit performance was the main factor driving domestic card financial results in the quarter, as it had been for the two preceding quarters.
The domestic card charge-off rate for the quarter was 2.54%, showing a 214-basis-point improvement compared to the previous year.
The 30-plus delinquency rate at the end of the quarter was 2.24%, which is 145 basis points better than the prior year.
The provision for credit losses in the first quarter improved by nearly $4 billion compared to the same period last year.
We experienced a substantial allowance release in this year's first quarter, contrasting with a large allowance build in the first quarter of last year.
Robust credit performance and purchase volume growth were also key factors in the domestic card revenue margin, which increased by 229 basis points year over year to 17.2%.
Total company marketing expenses increased slightly compared to the first quarter of 2020.
Our decisions regarding card marketing are the primary influence on overall company marketing trends.
Despite the ongoing pandemic, we're identifying opportunities to continue growing the business and maintaining our focus on marketing efforts.
Overall, our domestic card business is generating significant value and gaining momentum.
Slide 12 provides an overview of the first-quarter results for our consumer banking business.
The main themes in the first-quarter consumer banking results are continued growth in auto loans, strong performance in retail deposits, and exceptional auto credit.
Primarily due to auto loans, first-quarter ending loans in the consumer banking business increased by 10% compared to the previous year.
Average loans grew by 9%.
Auto loan originations increased by 16% year over year and by 20% compared to the previous quarter.
We've observed an increase in competitive intensity during the second half of 2020 and in the first quarter of 2021.
Given that most competitors are holding excess deposits, we anticipate that competitive intensity will continue to rise in the future.
First-quarter ending deposits in consumer banking increased by $36.4 billion, or 17%, compared to the previous year.
The average deposits experienced a 16% increase.
Compared to the previous quarter, ending deposits grew by 2% while average deposits remained stable.
The year-over-year deposit growth is being driven by high consumer savings rates, which are fueled by ongoing government stimulus measures.
Consumer banking revenue in the first quarter saw a 22% rise compared to the same period last year, primarily due to growth in auto loans and retail deposits.
The provision for credit losses in the first quarter showed a $986 million improvement year-over-year, mainly due to an allowance release and reduced charge-offs in the auto business.
The auto business is showing remarkably strong credit results, benefiting from historically high auction values and government stimulus.
Compared to the previous year, the first-quarter charge-off rate improved by 104 basis points to 0.47%, while the delinquency rate improved by 217 basis points to 3.12%.
A significant increase in used car values, along with a stimulus-driven increase in customer payments, led to a negative net charge-off rate in March.
We anticipate the auto charge-off rate to rise from its unusually low level as auction prices normalize and the effects of stimulus measures diminish.
The consumer banking division continues to show resilient growth in auto loans and retail deposits.
Let's move on to Slide 13.
I will now discuss our commercial banking operations.
First-quarter ending loan balances decreased by 9% compared to the previous year.
Average loans declined by 3%.
In the C&I sector, we've observed a reduction in commercial line utilization, which reached its peak early in the pandemic when customers facing heightened uncertainty drew down their credit lines.
This behavior has since subsided.
In our commercial real estate division, originations decreased, and paydowns increased compared to the first quarter of 2020.
Quarterly average deposits rose by 24% from the first quarter of 2020 and 4% from the previous quarter, as middle market and government clients continued to maintain high levels of liquidity.
First-quarter revenue increased by 4% compared to the same period last year.
Higher loan and deposit spreads and growth in average deposits were partially counterbalanced by lower average loan balances.
The provision for credit losses showed significant improvement compared to the first quarter of 2020, driven by a shift from an allowance build to an allowance release and reduced net charge-offs.
For the first quarter, the commercial banking annualized charge-off rate was nine basis points.
The criticized performing loan rate was 9.2%, while the criticized nonperforming loan rate was 0.9%.
Our commercial banking division is delivering robust performance as we continue to navigate the pandemic and enhance our commercial capabilities.
I'll conclude tonight by sharing some thoughts on our results and strategic position.
Three key themes are evident in our first-quarter results.
High payment rates continue to exert short-term pressure on loan balances and revenue growth, particularly in our domestic card business.
On the other hand, remarkably strong credit led to a third consecutive quarter of record earnings per share.
Our investments in transforming our technology and work processes are yielding positive results.
Our modern technology is driving our response to the pandemic and positioning us strongly for opportunities that arise as sweeping digital changes transform the banking industry.
Taking a broader perspective, we continue to focus on elements that create lasting value when delivered and maintained over the long term, including ongoing transformation of our technology from the ground up, leveraging our transformation to drive innovation and growth, generating positive operating leverage and improving efficiency over time, and managing capital efficiently and effectively, including significant planned capital distribution.
We will now begin the Q&A session.
To be considerate of other investors and analysts who may want to ask questions, please limit yourself to one question and a single follow-up.
If you have additional questions after the Q&A session, the investor relations team will be available following the call.
Keith, please initiate the Q&A.
Summary:
output:
compname reports q1 2021 net income of $3.3 bln, or $7.03 per share.
compname reports first quarter 2021 net income of $3.3 billion, or $7.03 per share.
q1 revenue fell 3 percent to $7.1 billion.
qtrly earnings per share $7.03.
common equity tier 1 capital ratio under basel iii standardized approach of 14.6 percent at march 31, 2021.
qtrly benefit for credit losses $823 million versus provision for credit losses of $5,423 million.
qtrly net interest income $5,822 million, down 3%.
capital one financial qtrly earnings per share $7.03.
q1 revenue fell 3% to $7.1 billion versus q4 2020 .

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:We are grateful for your presence today as we discuss our Q1 2021 results.
We released our quarterly financial report yesterday.
Our robust financial performance demonstrates continued growth and effective operations, while serving customers, finalizing new investments, and prioritizing employee safety.
Joining me on this call are Jeff Householder, our President and CEO, and Jim Moriarty, our Executive VP, General Counsel, Corporate Secretary and Chief Policy and Risk Officer, as shown on Slide 2.
Additional management team members are participating remotely.
We've begun 2021 strongly with profitable growth across our business segments.
Slide 4 shows our earnings per share from continuing operations reached $1.96, a 10.7% or $0.19 increase compared to $1.77 in Q1 2020.
Our gross margin grew by over $17 million compared to the first quarter of last year.
Growth across all company divisions drove our results.
We also saw higher consumer usage due to weather conditions more in line with typical temperatures.
Key factors contributing to our margin growth included pipeline expansions, the Hurricane Michael regulatory agreement, organic growth in natural gas distribution customers, contributions from recent acquisitions, increased propane retail margins, and growth in Marlin Gas Services.
As our General Counsel Jim Moriarty often notes, we benefit from our geographical positioning.
We are fortunate to serve rapidly growing communities with our energy delivery services.
[Technical difficulties] initiatives indicating support for further expansion of our Florida systems.
Demand for natural gas, propane, and electricity is at an all-time high in all our service areas.
We continue to add customers at more than double the national average rate.
In the last year, our utility distribution and customer base grew by 7.4%.
The main driver of our Q1 capital investment was growth opportunities to serve new customers.
We're on track to meet our projected 2021 capital investments of about $200 million.
Our first quarter capital expenditure totaled just under $49 million.
Our Board of Directors approved an annual dividend of $1.92 per share earlier today, a 9.1% or $0.16 per share increase.
As shown on Slide 5, this $0.16 increase in the annual dividend aligns closely with our five-year earnings growth rate of 9.4% through December 31, 2020, and our five-year dividend growth rate of 9.5%, including this latest increase.
The Board's decision to raise the dividend reflects our ongoing commitment to dividend growth supported by earnings growth, while maintaining a payout ratio that allows for reinvestment in growth and ensures operational liquidity.
Chesapeake Utilities has consistently paid dividends for 60 years and has increased its annual dividend every year since 2004.
I'll discuss our ongoing growth initiatives and capital investment projects across our business units shortly.
Slide 6 shows our net income from continuing operations for the quarter was $34.5 million, compared to $29 million for the same period last year, representing a growth of $5.5 million or about 19%.
As you may recall, we exited the natural gas marketing business in Q4 2019, recognizing gains from those sales.
There were minor lingering effects from this business sale in both 2020 and Q1 2021.
Therefore, I'll focus our discussion today primarily on continuing operations.
EPS from continuing operations for Q1 grew by $0.19 to $1.96 per share from $1.77, a growth of nearly 11% compared to Q1 last year.
Growth initiatives and customer consumption drove the 19% increase in net income, while the 11% EPS growth reflects the significant equity we issued in Q3 and Q4 2020 through the ATM program and various stock plans.
Higher income resulted from improved performance across the company, as Jeff mentioned earlier, along with continued expense management, business efficiencies, and standardization and collaboration across the organization.
Gross margin increased 17.1% compared to Q1 last year, while operating income grew by 22.5% due to these factors.
As Slide 7 highlights, the growth in operating income was fairly evenly split between the Regulated Energy and Unregulated Energy segments for the quarter.
Slide 8 outlines the key drivers of gross margin and expenses for Q1 compared to Q1 last year.
Gross margin net of specific expense attributes grew $0.65 per share after tax.
Higher earnings for the quarter reflect increased earnings across the business from various factors.
These increases were offset by the absence of property sales from Q1 last year, representing $0.14 per share, and the increased shares we added, another $0.12 per share, given our opportunistic equity issuances over the past 12 months to capitalize on our strong equity market position.
Finally, depreciation, payroll, and facilities expenses reduced our earnings per share by $0.20 due to business growth.
I'd like to discuss our capital spending so far in 2021.
As shown on Slide 9, our 2021 capital expenditure forecast remains at our previously announced guidance of $175 million to $200 million.
Approximately 80% of the investment is budgeted for new regulated energy assets.
Year-to-date, as Jeff mentioned, we've invested just under $49 million in new capital investments.
Some key 2021 projects include our Delmarva Natural Gas Distribution expansion into Somerset County, Eastern Shore's Del-Mar Energy Pathway project, Florida's Western Palm Beach County expansion, our Florida GRIP program, and other natural gas distribution and transmission system projects.
We also have expenditures for infrastructure improvements, Marlin Gas Services expansion, and technology systems supporting our business transformation and other strategic initiatives.
To support our growth and ensure capital capacity for future growth, we maintain a strong balance sheet with access to sufficient competitively priced capital.
Slide 10 shows that as of the end of March, our total capitalization was $1.4 billion, comprised of approximately 52% stockholders' equity at $726 million, 37% in long-term debt at an average fixed rate of 3.62%, and $156 million in short-term debt under our revolver at an average interest rate of 1.2%.
Our recent equity issuance moved this further along within our target equity to total capitalization range.
We continue to use our traditional equity plans this year to issue stock and increase equity beyond our retained earnings reinvested in the business.
Chesapeake Utilities' current market capitalization is approximately $2 billion.
As Beth noted, our capital capacity and balance sheet strength continue to support growth.
We're confident that our previously updated capital guidance remains on target.
Slide 11 reminds us of the key strategic initiatives guiding our project development and transaction interests from earlier earnings calls.
As I mentioned earlier, we continue to see significant demand for energy services provided by our existing business units.
Let me highlight a few of our major initiatives on Slide 12.
A large part of planned capital investment is allocated to growing our primary business areas.
Several small-scale pipeline projects are in development, potentially increasing investment in this sector.
Our propane business is expanding and we'll continue seeking acquisition opportunities in the Mid-Atlantic and Southeast regions.
We anticipate growth in Marlin Gas Services and the emerging renewable natural gas market, which I'll elaborate on shortly.
This margin table displays key projects and initiatives, including pipeline expansion, CNG, RNG transportation, acquisitions, and regulatory efforts, as shown on Slide 13.
Major projects are predicted to yield approximately $60 million and $67 million in gross margin for 2021 and 2022, respectively.
Pipeline expansions are expected to generate an additional $6.7 million in margin in 2021.
The Hurricane Michael proceeding settlement will again produce $11 million in gross margin in 2021, remaining at that level in 2022.
We're pleased with the complete integration of margin estimates of $5.8 million and $6.1 million for 2021 and 2022, respectively, from the Elkton Gas and Western Natural Gas acquisitions.
In total, the additional margin growth from these key projects and initiatives amounts to about $14.1 million for 2021 and $7.5 million for 2022.
We only include definitive projects in this table once they're fully developed, and don't include organic margin growth from our traditional distribution, customer additions, rate adjustments in our unregulated businesses, and so on.
As such, the RNG transportation margin will be updated as new projects become definite and are announced.
We've included a $1 million placeholder for RNG transportation on the slide for a few quarters, without yet disclosing the extent of anticipated RNG production-related investments.
These projects require significant time to develop, particularly in securing full project financing.
This situation reminds me of the early stages of solar and wind project financing.
However, RNG project financing is gaining momentum as interest grows among both financial and strategic participants, and we hope to make more details of our involved projects public in the coming weeks.
The Auburndale Pipeline ($679,000) and Boulden acquisition ($3.9 million) became fully operational in 2020, so these mature projects have been removed from this table.
In recent quarters, we've outlined several renewable natural gas initiatives.
Slide 14 presents the types of projects and ownership structures we're actively considering.
Let me update you on our progress for several of these initiatives.
We're continuing to collaborate with CleanBay renewables on two large-scale poultry waste, RNG and organic fertilizer production facilities on the Delmarva Peninsula.
We previously mentioned our agreement with CleanBay to own the gas processing equipment at the Westover Maryland facility, with an option to convert the equipment investment to equity in the entire plant.
Last month, our Board Investment Committee authorized management to negotiate economic and governance terms with CleanBay regarding Chesapeake's equity participation in the project.
We aim to finalize an agreement with CleanBay and other equity providers soon, ensuring that the projected Q4 2023 in-service date remains feasible.
Besides the Westover RNG facility, we're discussing with CleanBay and other potential investors about a second Delmarva RNG facility under development in Sussex County, Delaware.
Like the Westover plant, the Sussex facility will produce large-scale RNG along with organic fertilizer.
The property for the Sussex plant has been acquired and most land use permits have been approved.
Once completed, the Westover and Sussex plants will be among the largest RNG facilities nationwide.
We have several additional investments either under contract or in final negotiations related to the Westover plant.
The Marlin Gas Transport agreement is in place, an interconnect agreement with our Eastern Shore Natural Gas transmission pipeline has been finalized, and the interconnect is scheduled for construction to coincide with the Westover plant's in-service date.
Our Delmarva distribution business has finalized an agreement to purchase non-fossil RNG molecules from Westover for distribution to our customers.
In addition to buying RNG from Westover's production, our Delmarva distribution operations will provide conventional gas supply service to Westover to support the organic fertilizer production at the plant.
Westover is likely to become our largest Maryland gas distribution customer.
Eastern Shore Natural Gas Del-Mar Energy Pathway expansion project, currently under construction, and our related distribution system expansion will bring our pipelines within 1.5 miles of the Westover plant, and we'll extend the distribution system to provide service.
We expect to provide similar Marlin and conventional gas distribution services to the CleanBay Sussex site.
Chesapeake is exploring opportunities to develop renewable electric micro-grids at both the Westover and Sussex RNG sites.
We're working with a third party to potentially develop solar photovoltaic generation systems to meet the electric needs of the RNG facilities.
Property suitable for solar PV installation is owned by the third party near the Westover site, and by Chesapeake close to the Sussex site.
Chesapeake has engaged Southern Company Energy Services and Southern's PowerSecure Company to assist in preliminary design and engineering of the solar PV systems, battery storage, protection protocols for the plants and related facilities to support a renewable electric micro-grid at each facility.
On Delmarva, we continue to work with Bioenergy DevCo as they progress on developing a poultry waste RNG facility in Sussex County, Delaware.
The County Commission has recently approved Bioenergy DevCo's conditional land use permit.
Chesapeake will own and operate the gas processing equipment at the plant site.
We've ordered the processor, hired an EPC contractor, and are finalizing design on various other components.
Our investment in the project is estimated at about $12 million, with service expected to begin in late 2022.
Construction of our Savannah public compressed natural gas vehicle fueling and Marlin staging facility is proceeding on schedule for an October 2021 launch.
The station will be the largest CNG fueling facility on the East Coast, capable of fueling approximately 185 semi-trucks daily.
We recently met with representatives from several Georgia-based trucking firms, where interest in CNG was high and interest in potentially providing renewable CNG at that facility was even higher.
We're collaborating with several RNG marketers and exploring opportunities to develop regional CNG production to serve the Savannah station.
Regarding Marlin, we're concluding an eight-month deployment serving the City of Miami transit bus fleet.
At peak, we were fueling 160 CNG buses daily before the permanent pipeline and CNG fueling facilities were installed.
Marlin CNG Service enabled early delivery of the buses and an earlier than anticipated significant reduction in diesel emissions.
Marlin has also received its new four-stage compressor unit.
The compressor allows Marlin to offer a methane capture service to pipelines and utilities that need to remove a pipeline segment for maintenance or system integrity work.
Instead of releasing methane into the atmosphere, Marlin can receive the gas at almost any line pressure, compress it to CNG pressures, and transfer it to a tanker.
The gas can then be reintroduced at another point in the pipeline system.
Marlin has also received its first four LNG tankers.
The increased LNG transport capacity provides an expanded range of services for customers requiring larger gas quantities.
We are continuing to convert our fleet at Marlin from diesel fuel to compressed natural gas.
In July, we will receive eight new tractor cabs that run on compressed natural gas.
During our previous quarterly call, I noted our involvement in a hydrogen research project submitted to the Department of Energy by Solar Turbines.
We have proposed using our Eight Flags CHP turbine on Amelia Island as a testing location and are collaborating with several of our current industrial clients to explore opportunities for hydrogen blends at their sites.
We are in the early stages of learning about hydrogen usage, including safety considerations, operational impacts, measurement methods, availability, and effects on downstream customer equipment.
It's a pleasure to be here with you all today.
I'd like to start by updating you on some recent legislative developments in Florida.
As illustrated on Slide 15, the energy pre-emption bill is crucial legislation that preserves consumer choice and ensures the continued availability of natural gas as an affordable, dependable, and resilient energy source.
Natural gas will be accessible to meet growing customer needs.
Furthermore, we backed a renewable energy bill that has passed both chambers of the Florida Legislature and awaits the governor's signature.
This legislation defines biogas and renewable natural gas.
It encourages the use of RNG in transportation, electricity generation, and injection into gas distribution networks.
The bill also allows the PSC to approve cost recovery for RNG contracts that exceed market rates under specific circumstances.
Once signed by the governor, Florida will join twelve other states in recognizing the important role of natural gas in meeting the nation's growing energy demands.
We are pleased with our governmental affairs team's efforts in driving and supporting such important legislation in Florida to ensure natural gas availability for customer demand and to provide a mechanism for renewable natural gas to become a viable part of the state's natural gas portfolio.
We are at various stages of working on similar legislation in our other jurisdictions and will keep you informed of future developments.
As shown on Slide 16, Chesapeake Utilities continues to build upon our fundamental commitment to ESG, focusing on environmental stewardship, dedication to social justice, and sound governance principles.
Our recognition as a top workplace for nine consecutive years in the areas we serve, as well as our recognition in the inaugural top workplace awards, speaks volumes about our diverse and inclusive culture, which continues to foster employee growth and development and active community engagement.
Robust corporate governance has been crucial in creating long-term value and upholding our commitments to all stakeholders.
Our Board and its committees have adopted guidelines and policies that provide a framework for ongoing effective governance.
Active and informed engagement, which is ingrained in our people from the Board of Directors throughout the Company, is essential as we continue to chart our future course together.
Strong corporate governance also involves listening to our stockholders and monitoring annual vote results.
This year's results show that over 90% of the votes cast were in favor of the proposals presented, demonstrating our stockholders' continued strong support for the Company's performance and future strategy.
Our commitment to operating safely and in an environmentally friendly manner furthers our stewardship and promotes sustainable practices across our organization.
Our team, with input from the Board of Directors, discusses key risks and mitigating factors identified as part of our comprehensive Enterprise Risk Management program.
ESG-related focus areas and emerging risks are integrated into our ERM program.
Regarding safety, as shown on Slide 17, we are dedicated to providing a safe workplace for employees and prioritizing safety in our interactions with each other, our customers, and the communities we serve.
Achieving superior safety performance is a critical strategic initiative, both in the short and long term.
Safety is not only our top priority and first strategic objective, but it is also central to our identity.
One of our recent accomplishments in this area is the completion of our safety town facility in Dover, Delaware, which provides hands-on and classroom training for our operations technicians.
We are also diligently working on our inaugural Corporate Responsibility and Sustainability report, to be released in 2021, which will provide additional information and insights on our long-standing ESG stewardship.
We are committed to fostering a work environment that values the diversity of backgrounds, experiences, and skills of all our employees, as highlighted on Slide 18.
In continuing our fundamental commitment to equity, diversity, and inclusion, our Equity, Diversity and Inclusion (EDI) Council supports all our employees, encouraging them to share their diverse experiences and backgrounds with the goal of improving the communities we serve and making us a better company.
The EDI Council is integral to our identity and aspirations, and we will further enhance collaboration around our workplace culture that drives our business.
The EDI Council was extremely active in 2020, facilitating the launch of five employee resource groups throughout the Company, as shown on Slide 18.
We are enthusiastic about these teams' accomplishments in a short time and look forward to their increasing role and the creation of additional ERGs.
The talent, skills, and ideas that these groups have brought to the forefront have been inspiring and provide channels for our employees to feel included and supported by the Company.
We strive daily to ensure that the communities we serve continue to receive the benefits of clean, abundant, affordable, and resilient energy delivery services, so that no one is left behind.
We continue to take various internal actions to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, including completing our pipeline replacement program and implementing improved detection technology at our compressor stations.
We are also collaborating with our suppliers and contractors to encourage their environmental efforts.
We are excited about ongoing projects by our diverse and engaged teams to reduce the carbon footprint of the communities we serve, including conservation programs that promote high-efficiency appliances and technical assistance for large volume customers to identify emission reduction opportunities.
We remain committed to taking necessary steps to deliver energy where and when needed while advancing our environmental stewardship.
Our announced projects in renewable natural gas (RNG) are just the beginning.
They clearly demonstrate our efforts to lower the carbon footprint and ensure a more sustainable future for our local communities.
While we're starting fiscal year 2021 with strong financial performance, as evidenced by our earnings-per-share growth, capital investments, key projects and initiatives, and dividend growth, as shown on Slides 19 and 20, we're confirming our five-year capital guidance for 2021 to 2025 at $750 million to $1 billion.
I'm pleased that our latest strategic plan update gives us high confidence in significant future investment opportunities.
This confidence in our growth prospects has allowed us to extend and expand our capital guidance.
Our 2025 earnings per share guidance range of $6.05 to $6.25 represents an average earnings per share growth of approximately 10% since we initiated guidance at the end of 2017.
We believe natural gas is a crucial component of the country's long-term energy strategy.
We also believe that the markets we serve value the energy services we provide, whether it's natural gas, propane, or electricity, as our customers have clearly indicated.
At the same time, given our business mix, expertise, and strategic approach, we have opportunities to capitalize on new renewable energy prospects that move us toward a more sustainable future.
We're committed to our growth strategy.
We focus on delivering top-quartile performance, including shareholder returns, which have exceeded 16% compound annual growth for each period of one, three, five, 10, and 20 years through April 30, 2021.
Our investment proposition is based on a commitment to superior performance, as outlined on Slide 21.
Our foundation, financial objectives and targets, as well as the initiatives and strategies we pursue, support achieving this level of performance.
We take great pride in the work done on the front lines and our ongoing commitment to identifying and delivering innovative solutions for providing clean, reliable, and safe energy to our customers.
We are now ready to address any questions you may have.
Summary:
output: q1 earnings per share $1.96 from continuing operations.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Carter's is experiencing a recovery from pandemic-related market disruptions.
The company achieved its highest-ever gross profit margin in the quarter through improved pricing and more focused promotions.
Expenditures and inventory levels were reduced below those of the previous year.
The company enhanced cash flow and liquidity while gaining market share during the quarter.
Business trends in July started positively, with sales reaching over 90% of the previous year's levels.
Nearly all stores were operational before the July 4th weekend, with retail sales during that holiday period increasing by 7% compared to the previous year.
In August, sales decreased to about 87% of the previous year's levels due to delayed school reopenings.
The shift to virtual learning at home reduced the need for back-to-school clothing purchases.
September was the most significant month of the year so far in terms of sales and earnings contributions.
September sales reached 95% of the previous year's levels.
This performance is the strongest since the pandemic's impact began in March.
Labor Day holiday sales were the best in three years, with comparable retail sales increasing by 15% during that period.
October sales are trending above 90% of the previous year's levels.
The company continues to see strong demand for its baby apparel and sleepwear products.
Baby apparel and sleepwear accounted for approximately 70% of total apparel sales.
The company holds five times the market share of its nearest competitors in these product categories.
Playwear sales improved in July as families prepared for the new school year.
Sales declined in August when it became clear schools wouldn't reopen, but rebounded in September as consumers shopped for cooler weather clothing.
The company introduced its Little Baby Basics product line in late June to coincide with store reopenings.
This core baby product offering is the best-selling newborn apparel in the United States.
The Little Baby Basics line is a high-margin replenishment program and one of the company's most successful recent launches.
Replenishment trends since the launch have been significantly better than the previous year.
In the third quarter, retail sales improved to 97% of the same period last year.
This recovery in sales was the strongest compared to the Wholesale and International segments.
The pandemic has accelerated the shift towards online purchases.
Store operation hours were reduced by over 20% in the quarter due to fewer store visits.
On a per-hour basis, store sales were better than the previous year.
Despite lower store traffic, conversion rates and units purchased per transaction increased.
These improved metrics are believed to reflect strong product offerings, compelling value, and high-quality service from store associates.
Stores that typically benefited from tourism, including international visitors, experienced the largest decline in traffic.
These stores represent about 11% of U.S. locations but accounted for approximately 40% of the decline in comparable sales for the quarter.
These stores are likely to underperform others until tourism and cross-border travel return to pre-pandemic levels.
Due to the mix and level of eCommerce inventories, the company was less promotional than the previous year.
This resulted in significantly improved price realization and eCommerce profitability for the quarter.
Similar to in-store experiences, online demand from international customers continues to trend lower than the previous year.
The largest declines in demand were from Brazil, Argentina, and Europe.
These markets have historically been among the best sources of international demand on U.S. websites.
These markets were particularly affected by the pandemic and a stronger dollar.
The company continues to benefit from significant investments made in recent years to enhance the online shopping experience.
In the third quarter, stores fulfilled 24% of eCommerce orders.
The company has invested in technology to optimize profitability and delivery speed for these purchases.
To improve shopping convenience, same-day pickup and curbside pickup services are now offered at over 600 U.S. stores.
These new omni-channel services are more profitable than shipping from distribution centers to consumers' homes.
Omni-channel customers, who use both online and in-store services, are the highest value customers, spending more than twice as much as single-channel customers annually.
The company expects stores to play an important role in supporting eCommerce customers in the future.
Currently, about 85% of U.S. stores are located in open-air centers, which is believed to provide an advantage over mall-based competitors.
Open-air centers offer a more convenient experience for same-day pickup and curbside pickup of online purchases.
The company plans to continue opening stores in densely populated areas and close stores in more remote and declining centers.
The plan is to open fewer than 100 co-branded stores over the next five years.
The company also plans to close about 25% of its stores as leases expire.
Nearly 60% of these closures may occur by the end of next year.
80% of the planned closures are expected to be completed by the end of 2022.
The stores slated for closure are generally older, lower-margin locations in declining centers that are less likely to support the focus on high-value omni-channel customers.
Carter's is considered an attractive tenant in shopping centers.
The company's brands are viewed as traffic drivers, bringing families with young children into shopping centers.
As other retailers struggle and downsize, new and more attractive real estate opportunities become available.
It's currently a buyer's market, and the company plans to pursue better opportunities in improved centers that offer convenience for consumers and high returns for shareholders.
The Wholesale business also showed good progress in recovering from earlier store closures.
Third-quarter sales were about 86% of the previous year's sales.
The operating margin on these sales was better than the previous year.
In the third quarter, the company experienced growth with three of its top five wholesale customers.
The company continues to see good growth with its exclusive brands, with sales collectively up 10%.
E-commerce demand for the company's brands through wholesale customers increased by over 40% in the third quarter, including triple-digit growth rates for some exclusive brands.
The trend in online demand improved each month during the quarter.
Combined with wholesale customers, online purchases of the company's brands are up over 50% year-to-date.
The company expects to achieve a new milestone within the next few weeks, with annual online purchases of its brands exceeding $1 billion this year.
Carter's brand wholesale sales were down about 25% in the quarter, due to retailers cautiously planning for second-half sales and the company's decision to curtail fall and holiday inventory commitments.
Most wholesale customers have lean inventories, seeing better sell-throughs, higher margins, and are in a chase mode given better-than-expected demand for the company's brands.
Given pandemic-related uncertainty in consumer demand, operating with leaner inventories is considered a better strategy through the balance of the year, even if it results in fewer sales.
The decision to run lean on inventories may impact second-half wholesale sales by up to $50 million, or less than 3% of total second-half sales.
One benefit of running leaner inventories this year is fewer low-margin sales to off-price retailers.
Sales to off-price retailers were down 18% in the quarter and over 50% year-to-date.
The company used its stores and websites in the U.S. and Canada to sell through excess inventories caused by store closures and related wholesale order cancellations earlier in the year.
This strategy allowed the company to offer consumers compelling value through its stores and websites while avoiding losses that would have been incurred by selling excess inventory to off-price retailers.
International sales in the quarter were about 90% of the previous year's sales and contributed over 13% of total company sales, comparable to the previous year.
The strength of the International segment is in the direct-to-consumer business, which represented over two-thirds of international sales in the quarter.
The company saw high single-digit growth in retail sales, driven by a nearly 70% increase in eCommerce sales in Canada and Mexico.
Many of the company's international wholesale relationships are with smaller retailers representing its brands worldwide.
These retailers have historically been a good source of sales and profitability but have been particularly affected by the pandemic, stronger dollar, and other local market challenges.
Sales to these wholesale customers are expected to be the slowest to recover from the global pandemic.
For context, these customers contributed less than 2% of the company's annual sales in 2019.
We anticipate improved performance from our global retailers, such as Walmart, Costco and Amazon.
The expansion of our Simple Joys brand in Europe over the past year has yielded positive results for Amazon.
This should provide us with a significant growth opportunity in the coming years.
Our team did an outstanding job collaborating with our suppliers to minimize our exposure to excess inventory in our supply chain.
Compared to last year, inventories at the end of September were reduced by more than 10%.
As we informed you in July, we are experiencing delays in receiving products from Asia.
We believe these delays were caused by carriers reducing capacity earlier this year when demand decreased due to store closures.
The delays also reflect insufficient capacity to handle the surge in demand when stores reopened this summer and the precautions being taken to protect manufacturing and transportation workers from the coronavirus.
They have been very understanding and recognize that the delays are a result of market disruption.
As we approach the holiday season, the flow of products has improved, and we do not anticipate shipping delays to significantly impact fourth quarter sales.
We are also managing our exposure to freight surcharges imposed by inbound and outbound carriers due to the increase in eCommerce sales and limited capacity.
Our best analysis suggests these surcharges may affect fourth quarter earnings by approximately $2 million.
Our supply chain team has negotiated lower product costs for spring 2021 due to reduced input costs and excess manufacturing capacity in Asia.
Demand for that product line is expected to be similar to last year, with related shipments beginning later this quarter.
In conclusion, we are making good progress in recovering from the disruption caused by the pandemic.
We have endured an exceptionally challenging market this past year, with unprecedented store closures, record unemployment, and a highly contagious and deadly virus.
We anticipate that the path forward will be challenging.
However, we believe we have a strong product offering and effective marketing strategies as we enter the final weeks of the year.
It is uncertain how long the market disruption will persist.
What we do know is that the inherent strength of our brands and business model should help us continue to navigate through these difficult times.
We hold the largest market share in children's apparel in the United States and Canada, with twice the share of our nearest competitors.
Children's clothing is considered a less discretionary purchase.
We concentrate on essential core products that are bought in multiple quantities on a frequent basis during the early years of a child's life.
Our average price points are under $10, offering excellent value to consumers in a weaker economic climate.
We are the largest supplier of children's apparel to the biggest retailers in the United States.
We are also the largest children's apparel specialty retailer with one of the strongest and most profitable eCommerce platforms in the industry.
I am thankful for their dedication to enhancing our brands and meeting the needs of families with young children.
In the coming months, we will update our growth plans based on our experiences this year.
According to our current projections, we are planning for significant growth in sales and earnings next year.
I will start on Page 2 with our GAAP income statement for the third quarter.
As Mike mentioned, our third quarter results significantly exceeded our expectations.
Net sales for the quarter were $865 million, an 8% decrease from last year.
Reported operating income was $114 million, a 35% increase.
Reported earnings per share were $1.85 compared to $1.34 a year ago, representing 38% growth.
Our third quarter and year-to-date results for both 2020 and 2019 included unusual items, which we have detailed on Page 3.
We have treated these items as non-GAAP adjustments to our reported results to allow for better comparison.
My comments today will address our results on an adjusted basis, excluding these unusual items.
Moving to Page 4 and our adjusted P&L for the third quarter.
Net sales decreased 8% to $865 million, which is a substantial improvement over the 30% decline we experienced in the second quarter.
We continue to see strong online demand with our U.S. eCommerce business achieving a 17% comp and eCommerce comps in Canada increasing by nearly 60%.
While gross profit dollars declined 5% due to lower sales, gross margin rate improved by 180 basis points compared to last year, reaching 44.4%.
This represented a record quarterly gross margin and was driven by improved price realization and continued progress in reducing excess inventory.
Royalty income was approximately the same as last year at $9 million.
Spending was very well managed during the quarter.
Adjusted SG&A decreased by $24 million or 8% across various expense categories.
Adjusted operating income grew 4% to $120 million and adjusted operating margin expanded 160 basis points to 13.8%, driven by our strong gross margin performance and effective management of spending.
Below the line, we had higher net interest expense than last year due to the $500 million in new senior notes we issued earlier this year.
We had other income of approximately $3 million in the quarter, primarily from foreign currency gains.
Our effective tax rate was about 19% in the quarter, up from about 18% last year.
Average share count declined 2%, driven by share repurchases in 2019.
Remember that we suspended share repurchases earlier this year as part of our liquidity improvement initiatives.
In summary, adjusted earnings per share grew 5% to $1.96, up from $1.87 last year.
Turning to Page 5 with some balance sheet and cash flow highlights.
Our balance sheet and liquidity remain very strong.
Total liquidity at the end of the third quarter was nearly $1.6 billion, with over $800 million in cash on hand and almost all of the borrowing capacity under our $750 million credit facility available to us.
Given the uncertainty of the current environment, we believe that having substantial liquidity, as we clearly do, is a strategic advantage for Carter's.
As Mike mentioned, we ended the quarter with inventories 11% lower than a year ago.
We believe the overall quality of our inventory is high.
We've made good progress in reducing excess inventory, although we're still working through some excess spring product, particularly in our stores.
We're currently planning for net inventories at the end of the year to be roughly comparable with a year ago.
Our Q3 accounts receivable balance declined 10% compared to last year, reflecting lower wholesale sales.
Accounts payable were $473 million at quarter-end compared to $206 million a year ago.
This increase reflects the successful extension of payment terms and rent deferrals.
We continue to receive strong support from our vendors and landlords as we collectively manage through the disruptions caused by the pandemic.
Long-term debt was $1 billion, up from $770 million in the third quarter of last year, which reflects our successful senior notes financing transaction in May and lower revolver borrowings.
In the third quarter, we repaid $244 million, which represented all of the outstanding borrowings under our credit facility.
Considering our significant cash position, net debt at the end of the third quarter was $158 million compared to over $600 million at the end of Q3 last year.
Based on our current outlook, we believe we will have ample liquidity for the foreseeable future as our business continues to recover from the pandemic.
Despite year-to-date net income being lower than last year, our operating cash flow was very strong at $320 million compared to $73 million last year.
This increase reflects improved working capital, including lower inventory and the successful extension of vendor payment terms, which I've described.
Turning to Page 7 with a summary of our business segment results for the third quarter.
While sales were down, profitability in each of our business segments improved in the third quarter, and our consolidated adjusted operating margin expanded by 160 basis points over last year.
Turning to Page 8, with third quarter results for our U.S. retail segment.
Total segment sales declined 3% compared to last year.
As Mike mentioned, we saw good demand over the Fourth of July and Labor Day holiday selling periods.
For the quarter, total retail comparable sales declined 3.5%, reflecting strong eCommerce growth of 17% and lower store sales.
September, which is the largest month of the year in our business, had particularly strong performance, with comparable store sales down only slightly versus last year.
Store traffic continued to be a challenge for us and the broader industry.
Consumers are understandably cautious, especially as we see virus counts rising again in many areas of the country.
Our store traffic in the third quarter exceeded the industry benchmark, which we follow.
While traffic was down, we saw improved conversion and higher transaction values in our stores in the third quarter.
The adjusted operating margin of our retail segment improved by 50 basis points to 11.4%, driven by improved price realization, especially online, and our improved inventory position and good control of spending.
Please refer to Page 9.
Clients continued to utilize our multi-channel options during Q3.
We've enhanced our stores to allow customers to quickly collect their online purchases.
Numerous customers are also utilizing our new curbside pickup service.
In general, the coordination between our online business and our extensive network of convenient stores continues to improve.
On Page 10, our recent marketing campaigns remain closely integrated with our social media presence.
During Q3, we surpassed our main competitors in children's clothing by gaining more Instagram and Facebook followers combined.
