On Page 11, we saw exceptionally high engagement with two specific promotional events in September.
Due to the pandemic, many families were unable to take their usual Labor Day vacation.
Recognizing this, we organized a promotion offering staycation packages to families.
This campaign generated the highest social engagement ever for the Carter's brand.
We also celebrated the 125th anniversary of the OshKosh B'gosh brand, which included releasing Special Limited-edition vintage overalls for the whole family.
This promotion was highly successful, with the children's sizes of these special overalls selling out within a few weeks.
Please turn to Page 12.
Another family tradition that has gone digital is the announcement of an expected baby.
During our Baby Love event in September, we distributed 10,000 Carter's bodysuits with the message "2021, Looking Bright" to celebrate the joyous news of babies due in 2021.
Moving to Page 13.
Since the pandemic started, we've been providing families with activity ideas for their increased time at home.
We recently launched a twice-weekly email series for parents of toddlers and babies, offering new ideas and tips for fall.
These communications have strengthened our relationships with our customers and reinforced that Carter's understands parenthood better than any other brand.
On the following page, it appears that social distancing will remain a reality for some time.
Like many other traditions, children visiting Santa will be different this year, so we've partnered with the innovative Cameo platform to deliver personalized virtual messages from Santa to thousands of children for Christmas.
The next several pages showcase examples of our holiday marketing.
This year, families may be particularly looking forward to being together and celebrating the holidays.
On Page 15, we've observed strong demand for our holiday products.
On Page 16, Carter's is renowned for our pajamas, especially Christmas PJs, available in sizes for the entire family.
On Page 17, we also offer a wide range of special outfits for formal holiday occasions.
This year, on Page 18, we have toys from Skip Hop and Carter's.
In most of our stores, we will introduce special Santa's toy shops for the holiday season.
Moving to Page 19, we'll review U.S. wholesale results for Q3.
Although net sales were lower than last year, they significantly exceeded our expectations.
The improvement over our forecast was due to several factors.
We observed earlier demand for fall products from several retailers, strong replenishment demand for Little Baby Basics, and the impact of delayed product arrivals mentioned in our previous call was less severe than anticipated.
All our wholesale customers are expanding their online businesses, resulting in strong demand for our brands.
Demand for our exclusive brands at Target, Walmart, and Amazon was robust in Q3, with combined sales growing 10% compared to last year.
Our Skip Hop brand experienced good growth in the wholesale channel this quarter.
With consumers spending more time at home, Skip Hop's Home Gear, Playtime, and Bath Time products have become very popular.
As Mike mentioned, sales of the Carter's brand decreased in the quarter, partly because we proactively canceled a significant amount of fall and winter inventory commitments early in the pandemic, and many customers have understandably chosen to maintain leaner inventories in the current environment.
Shipments to the off-price channel decreased significantly in Q3, as we're more effectively using our own retail channels to clear excess inventory.
U.S. Wholesale adjusted segment income was $67 million in Q3 compared to $73 million a year ago.
Adjusted segment margin improved by 140 basis points to 22.3%, reflecting lower inventory-related charges partially offset by higher bad debt expense.
On Page 20, we launch our core Little Baby Basics collection annually.
This year, we did so in late June, which is somewhat later than usual.
These products are the essential items that every parent of a newborn needs.
We're seeing very strong performance of Little Baby Basics this year.
We sell these signature products through multiple channels, including some of our largest wholesale accounts like Kohl's and Macy's.
Performance in our own stores, on carters.com, and in our International business has also been strong.
Starting on Page 21, we've included several slides highlighting our exclusive brands available at Target, Walmart, and Amazon.
The Just One You brand continues to perform well.
Target has invested in several digital campaigns promoting Just One You.
These campaigns have increased brand awareness among new and existing Target customers.
Sleepwear for infants and toddlers has been particularly successful, with plans for continued momentum in Q4 with Christmas pajamas and a wide assortment of sibling dressing products.
On Page 22, regarding the Child of Mine brand at Walmart.
In Q3, eCommerce sales of Child of Mine more than doubled compared to last year.
Here too, investments in brand marketing have driven good productivity and momentum for Child of Mine, which we expect to continue into the holiday selling period.
Lastly, on Page 23, our Simple Joys brand continues to resonate with consumers.
We have a strong partnership with Amazon for Simple Joys, which has grown to be one of our largest brands.
We participated in another successful Prime Day recently, where we achieved a significant increase in sales.
The Simple Joys assortment has expanded over the past few years and now includes Baby, Toddler, and Pajamas up to size-eight, as well as shoes and accessories.
Moving to Page 24 and Q3 results for our International segment.
International net sales declined 10% to $114 million.
This decrease was primarily due to lower wholesale shipments to markets outside North America, partly due to the stronger U.S. dollar and disruptions caused by the global pandemic.
Canada had a very good quarter overall, with retail comparable sales growing 7%.
Online demand remained strong with eCommerce comps up 58%.
Store comps in Canada were slightly down, but the arrival of colder weather and strong back-to-school demand helped boost sales.
Net sales in our Mexico business decreased year-over-year, reflecting a weaker peso and lower wholesale sales.
We're making good progress in the retail portion of the business in Mexico.
Our new larger co-branded stores are performing well, and eCommerce, which we launched late last year, continues to show strong growth.
International adjusted operating margin expanded 270 basis points to 15.8%, driven by strong performance in Canada that was partially offset by a lower contribution from our partners business.
On Page 25, we've included a photo of one of our newest stores in Mexico.
The store is our sixth larger format co-branded store.
Initial consumer reaction has been very positive.
In Q3, this store quickly became one of our best-performing locations in Mexico.
On Page 26, we've included pictures of the first three stand-alone Carter's stores in Brazil, two in Sao Paulo and one in Rio de Janeiro.
These stores are operated by Riachuelo, our exclusive partner in Brazil.
As many of you know, we've had a strong following among Brazilian consumers shopping with us in the United States over the years, so establishing a direct presence in this important market is a positive step forward.
Early consumer reaction to these new stores has been very positive.
Turning to Page 27 with our outlook for the rest of the year.
As with last quarter and given the ongoing market disruption caused by the pandemic, we're not providing sales and earnings guidance today.
We expect COVID-19 to continue significantly impacting our operations in Q4.
We're assuming that store traffic will remain lower than last year, and we're mindful of the risk of COVID-19 resurgence in key North American markets.
We anticipate continued strong online demand in Q4 and are planning for further gross margin expansion.
We're monitoring several other risks for the remainder of Q4, including the broader macroeconomic environment, such as unemployment and consumer confidence, as well as developments related to possible additional economic stimulus and the upcoming elections.
Summary:
output:
compname reports q3 earnings per share of $1.85.
q3 adjusted non-gaap earnings per share $1.96.
q3 earnings per share $1.85.
q3 sales $865 million versus refinitiv ibes estimate of $878.5 million.
qtrly u.s. retail comparable sales down 3.5%.
not providing fiscal 2020 sales and earnings guidance at this time.
$1.6 billion in liquidity at quarter end.
continues to believe has sufficient liquidity for foreseeable future.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:I'll start by offering some insights on our company's performance and operations.
We anticipated an improvement in sales for the third quarter, as stated in our previous earnings call.
Revenue for the quarter reached $113.8 million, representing a 2% decrease from the third quarter of 2019 but a 35% increase from the previous quarter.
The gross margin for the third quarter stood at 32.4%, showing a slight increase of 40 basis points compared to the same period in 2019 and an 80 basis point improvement from the second quarter of this year.
Adjusted earnings per share for the third quarter were $0.34, marking a 17% increase from $0.29 in the same quarter last year and a rise from $0.18 in the second quarter of 2020.
We achieved an adjusted EBITDA margin of 19%, which is 230 basis points higher than the 16.7% recorded in the second quarter of 2020.
The third quarter saw new business contracts worth $127 million and the addition of seven new clients.
At the end of the quarter, our cash reserves stood at $132 million, with a debt of $106 million.
From an operational standpoint, all of our facilities are currently functioning.
We're still facing some difficulties at our Mexican locations.
These facilities have improved their capacity from about 60% to around 90% since the last quarter.
We're keeping a close eye on local COVID-19 restriction changes at one of those facilities and at our Ostrava plant in the Czech Republic.
Ashish Agrawal is joining me for today's call and will guide us through the safe harbor statement.
If today's discussion mentions any non-GAAP measures under Regulation G, the necessary explanations and reconciliations can be found in the Investors section of the CTS website.
I'll now hand the conversation back to our CEO, Kieran O'Sullivan.
As we deal with the COVID-19 situation, our staff are providing support and assistance to those in need within our local communities, which is a source of great pride for us.
Our employees continue to show adaptability and quick response throughout our operations to meet all customer needs.
Our top priority remains ensuring the safety of our employees and adhering to state and local regulations.
We are modifying our business and processes to concentrate on our key objectives: driving profitable growth, enhancing our market approach, improving our operational capabilities, and developing our leadership talent and culture.
The restructuring plan we announced in the previous earnings call is proceeding as expected and is projected to yield an annual earnings per share improvement of $0.22 to $0.26 by the latter half of 2022.
More crucially, we are concentrating on returning to growth, aiming for 10% in line with our strategic plan - 5% organic growth and 5% through strategic acquisitions.
We maintain our focus on strategic growth investments as part of our 2025 planning.
Our main priority is expanding our business and broadening our range of products that sense, connect, and move.
New business contracts totaled $127 million for the quarter, marking the best quarterly performance this year.
We welcomed seven new customers in the quarter: four in the industrial sector, and one each in defense, medical, and telecom.
In the transportation sector, we secured a major passive safety sensor contract for an electric vehicle application in the Chinese market.
We also won multiple accelerated OEM contracts with customers in Asia and Europe, as well as a global platform deal with a North American OEM.
These recent wins leverage our inductive technology, which is crucial for growth in meeting mid- and high-end product requirements.
We obtained an additional ride height sensing contract with the same customer.
Cumulative electric and hybrid vehicle wins this year amount to approximately $75 million, and we anticipate further gains.
In the previous quarter, we reported our first win in current sensing, and we aim to expand this application to other regions.
In the defense sector, we were awarded contracts with several Tier one customers for sonar applications.
More recently, we developed and secured a new sample order for an ordinance application.
In Europe, we're working to increase our market share by building relationships with new customers.
We're leveraging our presence and capabilities in Denmark and the Czech Republic, where we recently received sample orders from two new Tier one defense customers.
We obtained a small initial order for temperature sensing technology in electric vehicle applications.
The battery management system's charging circuit incorporates the sensor.
We won a design contract for a 5G small cell application in multiple countries' systems within the precision frequency product line, and also received the distribution order.
A multiyear design contract was awarded to us for a low-power crystal product in a defense application.
We persistently advance our product innovations.
Our strategy in the transportation sector is to create sensor solutions that are compatible with various propulsion technologies, enhancing our growth potential as hybrid and electric vehicles become more prevalent in the coming decade.
By 2025, electric vehicles are anticipated to be more affordable than internal combustion engines due to decreasing battery costs.
Fifteen countries and two U.S. states have announced plans to phase out internal combustion engines between 2030 and 2040, with Norway aiming for 2025.
We anticipate electric vehicle market penetration to reach 9% by 2025 and 22% by 2030.
Our innovative efforts focus on electronic braking, new accelerator interfaces, and high-performance temperature applications.
We continue to explore new material formulations as we target growth in defense, industrial, and medical markets.
Our primary focus in the defense sector is on the solar market for forward and towed arrays.
In the industrial sector, we target in-jet printing, flow and position, as well as nondestructive testing.
Our main focus in the medical sector is on medical ultrasound, intravascular medical ultrasound, ultrasonic therapy, and scalpel applications.
We continue to improve our traditional position sensing for industrial applications and develop new encoder products for medical equipment.
We are progressing with developments for ultra-low life high frequency TCXOs and OCXOs for millimeter wave and sub-6 gigahertz systems, continuing to gain design awards through a major telecom OEM.
Although COVID-19 and associated travel restrictions have made the M&A environment more challenging, we are adapting and continuing to strengthen our pipeline of opportunities.
We aim to broaden our range of technologies, products, customers, and geographic reach.
We are making progress on our foundry operations and expect to complete the improvements this year.
The team is steadily improving process controls and subsequent efficiencies.
The Focus 2025 initiative emphasizes building stronger customer relationships.
As part of this initiative, we are enhancing our go-to-market capabilities, skills, and sales incentive plans to place greater emphasis on profitable growth.
We are striving to improve the quality of our sales funnel, optimize our end market approach, target new accounts, and align our functional areas to be more responsive and solution-oriented in line with our core values.
As part of our realignment on profitable growth, we are assessing the product portfolio for long-term growth and margin expansion.
We have transitioned from a period of sharp decline in the second quarter to a time of uncertainty as inventory levels are rebalanced and the market responds to high unemployment and other economic challenges.
In the U.S., the seasonally adjusted growth rate for 2020 is approximately 13 million units, a 21% decrease from last year.
We anticipate next year to be in the 14 million unit range.
On-hand days of supply are currently at 55 days, down from 65 days of supply in the third quarter of 2019.
European sales are projected to decrease by 24% from last year, and we expect 18.7 million unit levels in 2021.
The China market continues to show more resilience, with volumes predicted to decrease by 9%, ranging from 21 million to 22 million units this year and up to 24 million units next year.
There are indications that the commercial vehicle market may be improving as freight fundamentals continue to strengthen.
It's too early to determine the sustainability of this improvement.
We continue to observe stronger growth in industrial and defense markets.
We remain cautious about market conditions in the upcoming quarters.
We plan to resume providing annual guidance for fiscal year 2021 in February.
Our financial liquidity remains strong.
We perceive this difficult period as a chance to enhance our abilities.
Ashish will now provide a more detailed explanation of our financial results.
Revenue for the third quarter was $113.8 million, a 2% decrease from the previous year.
Sales bounced back significantly from the second quarter, increasing by 35%.
Year-over-year sales to transportation clients declined by 9%.
Nevertheless, we experienced a 71% sequential growth.
Compared to Q3 2019, sales to other markets grew by 10%, and sequentially by 5%.
Our temperature sensing acquisition performed well, contributing $6.6 million.
Non-transportation customer organic sales increased by 4% compared to last year.
We saw substantial growth in both defense and industrial sector sales.
As anticipated, the medical sector experienced a downturn.
Our third quarter gross margin was 32.4%, an improvement of 80 basis points from last quarter and 40 basis points from last year.
The impact of COVID continues to create uncertainty.
We are maintaining our focus on cost efficiency and the ability to adjust production levels as needed.
Improved revenue and careful cost management resulted in adjusted operating earnings of 13%, up 170 basis points from last year and 450 basis points sequentially.
As Kieran mentioned, we are making headway on the restructuring plan we initiated recently.
We will provide updates on improvements as we complete various aspects of the plan in upcoming quarters.
Our year-to-date tax rate was about 24%, and we anticipate the full-year rate to be between 23% and 25%, excluding one-time items.
Earnings for the third quarter of 2020 were $0.34 per diluted share.
Adjusted earnings per diluted share were also $0.34, compared to $0.16 last quarter and $0.29 in the third quarter of 2019.
Turning our attention to the balance sheet.
Our controllable working capital as a percentage of sales was 15.6% at the end of the third quarter.
This is a significant improvement from 21.2% last quarter, though we acknowledge there is still much to be done to further enhance our working capital performance.
We generated $25.6 million in operating cash flow during the third quarter.
Year-to-date, we have generated $49 million in operating cash flow, a 21% increase compared to 2019.
The strong cash performance in the third quarter allowed us to reduce our debt by $35 million.
Capital expenditures totaled $3.2 million.
We expect capital expenditures for the full year to be less than 4% of sales.
Regarding liquidity, our net cash position was $25 million, an improvement of about $20 million from the second quarter.
We have access to an additional $192 million through our revolving credit facility.
At present, we expect to remain comfortably within our debt covenants.
We are continuing to implement SAP.
As previously communicated, over 80% of our revenues come from sites using SAP.
We anticipate completing the implementation around mid-2021.
However, COVID-related travel restrictions may cause some delays.
This concludes our prepared remarks.
Summary:
output:
compname reports q3 earnings per share $0.34.
q3 adjusted earnings per share $0.34.
q3 earnings per share $0.34.
q3 sales $113.8 million versus refinitiv ibes estimate of $104.1 million.
management is not providing revenue or earnings guidance.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Susie Lisa, the senior vice president of investor relations at CVS Health, is speaking.
This presentation is being streamed on our website and will remain available for a year.
CVS Health has achieved another impressive quarter, surpassing expectations.
We are increasing our adjusted earnings per share guidance for the third consecutive quarter.
Throughout 2021, we have advanced our strategy of providing an integrated healthcare experience focused on the consumer.
We maintained robust revenue growth across our primary business segments, improved health outcomes, and reduced expenses by expanding access to quality care.
We assisted in combating the pandemic and reached millions of consumers with convenient, accessible care across American communities.
In the third quarter, we achieved a 10% increase in revenue.
This significant growth was driven by increased membership in healthcare benefits and pharmacy services, as well as higher retail volume.
We increased adjusted operating income by 12.5%.
We produced adjusted earnings per share of $1.97 and generated strong operational cash flow of $5.5 billion.
Based on these results and our outlook, we are elevating our adjusted earnings per share guidance to between $7.90 and $8.
This improved guidance reflects the quarter's exceptional performance and ongoing positive momentum, which Shawn will elaborate on soon.
The third quarter results once again show that our customers appreciate how we combine our unique set of assets, extensive healthcare knowledge, and numerous consumer touchpoints to address health needs.
There is high demand for our integrated solutions across the healthcare spectrum, including chronic condition management programs, mental health support, pharmacy services, and health and wellness products.
We gained over 1.3 million new integrated pharmacy and medical members during the 2021 and 2022 selling seasons.
More customers are seeking interconnected health services, such as virtual care.
CVS Health introduced the first nationwide Virtual Primary Care program earlier this year.
This industry-leading solution provides access to a national network of physicians virtually and convenient in-person care at our MinuteClinic locations when necessary, often with no co-pay.
Our program has expanded to 30 customer accounts with more than 750,000 eligible members as of January 1, 2022.
This demonstrates our ability to scale nationally and introduce innovative products to the market.
Our customers recognize the value of CVS Health Care Solutions and the easy access we now provide in communities, homes, and virtually.
Our high customer retention rates and new business acquisitions demonstrate the strength of our business model.
Healthcare benefits revenue grew by 9.5% compared to the previous year.
Strong performance in government services contributed to a 2.4% increase in adjusted operating income compared to the previous year, despite higher COVID-19 related costs, net of deferred care, primarily within our commercial segment.
We achieved sequential membership growth across all three product lines in the quarter: commercial, Medicare, and Medicaid.
Our medical benefit ratio of 85.8% exceeded our expectations, driven by COVID-related costs, mainly in the commercial sector.
Non-COVID costs developed in line with our projections.
We anticipate that total medical costs will slightly surpass baseline levels for the full year.
We delivered strong results in our Medicare business and increased membership both sequentially and year-over-year across all Medicare products.
This reflects our robust product portfolio, Stars performance, and reputation for excellent service.
Year-to-date, Medicare Advantage membership has grown by 9.2%.
In 2022, we expect to achieve double-digit growth in individual Medicare and generate strong momentum in dual eligibles.
Our strong performance in Stars continues, as evidenced by our 2022 results, with 87% of our members in Star plans rated four and higher, up from 83% in 2021.
In our commercial business, we anticipate moderate growth in 2022 for national accounts, driven by both increased sales, which are up approximately 50% year-over-year, and a 95% client retention rate.
As we mentioned earlier this year, we are re-entering the individual exchanges in eight states starting January 2022.
Enrollment began on Monday, and we expect our co-branded CVS Aetna offering and benefit design focused on consumer choice will result in gains of at least 100,000 new members in 2022.
Regarding pharmacy services, we achieved third quarter revenue growth of 9.3% and adjusted operating income growth of 9.5% compared to the previous year.
For the 2022 selling season, we achieved a 98% retention rate.
We generated $10.4 billion of new business growth, resulting in $8.9 billion of net new business wins, demonstrating our market-leading trend management, transparency, customer service, and integrated offerings.
We continue to lead in specialty pharmacy with programs that create value in the market, provide significant savings to customers, and set us apart as we enhance our programs with digital assets.
We maintained strong momentum this quarter with specialty revenue up 8.7% compared to the previous year.
Our service excellence and top-tier execution are key differentiating factors.
Our retail segment continues to play a crucial role as a local health destination for millions of Americans.
Retail outperformed both expectations and the industry in the third quarter.
We achieved 10% revenue growth and 22% adjusted operating income growth compared to the previous year.
Pharmacy sales and prescriptions filled both increased by 8% year-over-year, largely driven by COVID-19 vaccine administration and core pharmacy services.
Our patient satisfaction scores remain high, with approximately 90% of customers satisfied with their experience at CVS Health locations.
We continue to support millions of Americans with COVID-19 testing and vaccine administration.
We administered 11.6 million COVID-19 vaccines and 8.5 million COVID-19 tests in the quarter.
Since our program began, we have administered 43 million vaccines and approximately 38 million tests.
We also expanded our digital capabilities to provide universal access to CVS Health vaccination records for the millions of adults we have vaccinated.
This new feature has driven over 1 million visits per month to vaccination records on cvs.com.
This provides another opportunity for us to build deeper engagement with our customers while simplifying and connecting their health experience.
Front store sales momentum also continued with revenue growth of 13% compared to the previous year.
Front store sales were driven by consumer demand for COVID-19 home testing kits, as well as cough and cold products, with year-over-year volume increases across most front store categories.
Our CVS Health retail presence consistently serves as a strong channel for acquiring new customers.
In fact, this year, 12.5% of new COVID-19 testing customers chose to fill new prescriptions or receive a COVID-19 vaccination with CVS Health.
Lastly, we anticipate that the benefit from administering boosters and pediatric doses to eligible consumers will primarily occur in the fourth quarter of this year.
We continue to make significant progress with our strategy to deliver a superior customer experience and address the total cost of care.
We have focused on several key areas.
First, with our unique portfolio of businesses, we continue to expand our role in care delivery designed around the customer.
We're taking a proactive stance to address the evolving requirements of our customers, clients, and communities.
We're enhancing accessibility, reducing expenses, and integrating local care points to streamline the consumer health experience.
Our extensive network of physician assistants, combined with our nationwide presence, allows us to provide localized care on a national scale.
We plan to increase customer engagement by transforming select CVS locations into community health hubs, offering three distinct models: primary care centers, enhanced health and wellness stores, and traditional CVS Pharmacy outlets.
Our standard CVS Pharmacy stores will continue to offer prescription services along with health, wellness, and convenient retail products.
Our diverse business portfolio and widespread community presence enable us to meet consumers where they are, enhancing their well-being and playing a larger role in their wellness journey.
We're enhancing the consumer experience by expanding digital services and platforms that connect to health services and physical locations for our over 35 million unique digital customers.
Currently, more than 70% of CVS Pharmacy customers are signed up for our text messaging services.
Among this group, our adherence outreach efforts led to a 10% increase in filled prescriptions this quarter.
Improved adherence results in better health outcomes and lower overall costs.
In today's digitally connected, consumer-driven world, the demand for omnichannel pharmacy services is at an all-time high.
We're continuously modernizing our operating systems and improving our pharmacy model integration to simplify customer interactions and boost engagement.
We're investing in our employees as a key part of our workforce strategy.
We recently announced a gradual increase in the minimum wage to $15 per hour by July 2022.
We've invested in updating our training programs and technology for our frontline and clinical staff.
Despite a competitive job market and anticipated increased demand for health services, we've bolstered our workforce across all business areas.
We hired a record number of employees in the third quarter to support open enrollment and customer service, as well as enhance our technological and clinical capabilities.
Nearly 20,000 pharmacists, pharmacy technicians, and nurses recently joined CVS Health to support flu season and COVID-19 vaccinations and testing.
Our pharmacists and pharmacy technicians play a crucial role in our overall workforce strategy.
We're committed to supporting our pharmacists, including providing immunization bonuses in the latter half of this year.
We look forward to sharing more about our strategy to improve access, quality, and customer engagement at our investor day on December 9.
We remain steadfast in our commitment to shareholders, customers, and communities.
Health equity is crucial as the pandemic continues to disproportionately affect certain communities.
In addition to targeted vaccine and booster education efforts, we've provided 31 million meals to those experiencing food insecurity and invested in 2,800 affordable housing units across 30 cities this year.
Addressing social determinants of health through permanent housing can reduce healthcare costs by 59%.
We've hired Dr. Joneigh Khaldun to build on our efforts to promote health equity and better support underserved communities, and our increased wages and bonuses support our employees, their families, and their communities.
For the third consecutive quarter, we've exceeded our plan and raised our adjusted earnings per share guidance.
We continue to enhance our diverse portfolio of assets to serve our customers.
We anticipate a strong year-end, made possible by the leadership and commitment of our over 300,000 CVS Health colleagues who bring their heart to every moment of our customers' health journey.
Our third quarter results show a continuation of the strong performance seen in the first half of 2021, exceeding our expectations in revenue, cash flow, and adjusted earnings per share.
These results stem from our unique portfolio of capabilities and strong focus on operational execution.
This performance momentum allows us to once again raise our outlook for 2021.
Looking at the enterprise as a whole, total revenues of $73.8 billion increased 10% year over year with robust growth across all three segments.
We reported adjusted operating income of $4.1 billion, a 12.5% increase compared to the previous year.
This growth in adjusted operating income was also reflected in strong cash flow generation in the third quarter, with year-to-date cash flow from operations now exceeding $14 billion.
Adjusted earnings per share of $1.97 represent a nearly 19% year-over-year increase, driven by our adjusted operating income growth and lower interest expense resulting from our ongoing debt reduction efforts.
Examining the segments, Healthcare Benefits revenue increased by 9.5% year over year, driven by sustained growth in our Government Services business, slightly offset by the repeal of the health insurance fee.
In the third quarter, we saw Medicaid membership grow sequentially by 67,000 members across multiple regions.
Medicare Advantage membership also continued to grow, increasing by 42,000 members sequentially and representing year-over-year growth of 9.8%.
Our Medicare Advantage franchise continues to be a powerful growth engine, with membership more than doubling since the third quarter of 2015, representing a 15% compound annual growth rate.
Our focus has now shifted to ensuring a successful 2022 annual enrollment period for Medicare, which began on October 1.
While still early in the process, we are pleased with the results we've seen so far.
Healthcare Benefits adjusted operating income grew modestly year over year but fell below our expectations for the quarter due to higher-than-expected COVID-related medical costs in our commercial business.
With the surge in nationwide COVID cases stemming from the Delta variant, we experienced higher-than-anticipated COVID-related medical costs in August and September.
Three key factors contributed to this difference from our expectations.
First, commercial COVID inpatient admissions in August and September were comparable to the peak levels experienced in January 2021 and were nearly three times the average of the second quarter of 2021.
Second, COVID testing costs, which we had expected to moderate during the third quarter, also approached January 2021 levels and were more than 1.5 times the average we experienced in the second quarter.
It's important to recognize the significant impact of COVID testing on overall claim costs, as testing expenses represented approximately 35% of gross COVID costs in the quarter.
Lastly, while non-COVID deferred care was better than we had forecast, it was not enough to fully offset these higher COVID costs in commercial.
The resulting medical benefit ratio for the quarter of 85.8% was above our forecast and driven almost entirely by the higher-than-expected commercial COVID testing and treatment costs.
Two important aspects of HCB's third quarter performance should be noted.
First, aside from these COVID dynamics, underlying performance in our commercial book of business continues to align with our expectations.
Second, in our government services business, we also saw an increase in COVID treatment and testing costs, but it was far less pronounced than in commercial.
This lower level of increase was fully offset by better-than-expected deferred care.
As a result, the overall performance of our Government Services business met expectations.
To conclude the HCB segment overview, we experienced favorable prior period development in the quarter for both commercial and government products.
Days claims payable of 51 at the end of the third quarter is three days higher sequentially and two days above the prior year.
While influenced by many factors, with the anticipated decrease in COVID-related claims in the fourth quarter, we expect DCP to return to more typical levels in Q4.
Overall, we remain confident in the adequacy of our reserves.
Shifting our focus to pharmacy-related services.
Our capacity to achieve sustainable and profitable growth remains evident.
We anticipate that 2021 will mark the second consecutive year of over 10% growth in adjusted operating income.
This continued expansion is attributed to our consistent delivery of industry-leading drug trend for our clients, our proven top-tier capabilities, particularly in specialty pharmacy, and our exceptional customer service, as evidenced by our over 98% renewal rate for 2022.
In the third quarter, pharmacy revenues grew by 9.3% compared to the previous year, driven by increased pharmacy claim volumes, specialty pharmacy growth, and brand inflation.
The total number of pharmacy members increased by 1.6 million sequentially, primarily due to growth in government programs.
The total number of processed pharmacy claims grew by nearly 7% compared to the previous year.
Almost half of this growth was due to new business in 2021, with COVID vaccine administration and new therapy prescriptions also contributing to the year-over-year increase.
It's worth noting that new therapy prescriptions were negatively affected in the third quarter of 2020 due to the pandemic.
Pharmacy adjusted operating income surpassed expectations in the quarter, increasing by more than $150 million or 9.5% compared to the previous year.
The three main factors driving this increase remain consistent with the second quarter.
These factors include improved purchasing economics reflecting the products and services of our group purchasing organization launched in the second quarter of 2020, continued strength in our specialty pharmacy business driven by 340B administration, and increased pharmacy claims volumes, all of which were partially offset by ongoing but stable client pricing pressure.
Our retail division delivered strong results this quarter, once again exceeding expectations.
Total revenue of just under $25 billion increased by $2.3 billion or 10% compared to the previous year.
This increase can be attributed to two main components.
Approximately half, or $1.2 billion, is due to the administration of over 11 million COVID vaccines and more than 8 million COVID tests, combined with strong front store sales driven by demand for over-the-counter COVID test kits and related treatment categories.
Based on this quarter's results, we are now on track to administer about 44 million to 49 million COVID vaccines and 28 million to 33 million COVID tests for the full year 2021.
The remaining half, or $1.1 billion, was driven by a combination of sustained pharmacy growth and broad strength in front store trends across various categories, partially offset by continued pharmacy reimbursement pressure.
This strong revenue growth, combined with a 70-basis-point improvement in adjusted operating margin, resulted in adjusted operating income that exceeded our forecast and led to a year-over-year increase of $300 million.
This growth in adjusted operating income, driven by COVID testing, vaccines, and front store sales, was partially offset by continued pharmacy reimbursement pressure, business investments including minimum wage increases and other performance incentives, and increased staffing to provide expanded levels of service.
Focusing on cash flows and the balance sheet.
Our liquidity and capital position remained excellent at the end of the third quarter, with cash from operations of $5.5 billion for the quarter and $14.3 billion year to date.
Through our proactive liability management transaction in August, we reduced our net long-term debt by $1.1 billion in the quarter.
As of the end of the third quarter 2021, we have repaid a net total of $18.7 billion in long-term debt since finalizing the Aetna transaction.
Additionally, we returned over $650 million to shareholders through our quarterly dividend.
Let me now discuss our revised 2021 guidance.
This increase reflects strong performance in pharmacy services and retail, partially offset by expected COVID-related pressure in our healthcare benefits business, specifically in the commercial sector.
We are raising our total revenue outlook to between $286.5 billion and $290.3 billion, and our adjusted operating income outlook to between $16.4 billion and $16.6 billion.
We are also increasing our expected full year cash flow from operations to a range of $13 billion to $13.5 billion.
Note that this increased cash flow forecast is actually lower than our September year-to-date figure, reflecting expected payments in the fourth quarter that were accrued in 2020, including FICA taxes and increased minimum loss ratio rebates, as well as the timing of receipts and payments between the third and fourth quarters.
I'll now highlight some key points related to the segments and full year guidance.
For the healthcare benefits segment, we are lowering our full year adjusted operating income guidance from $5.25 billion - $5.35 billion to $4.9 billion - $5 billion.
We expect the full year medical benefit ratio to be in a range of 84.4% to 85.6%, an increase of 30 basis points from our previous range.
This reflects the higher-than-expected commercial COVID medical costs observed in the third quarter and our expectation that these will continue, although at a lower level, into the fourth quarter.
Early October operational data indicates that COVID inpatient admissions are tracking at approximately half the levels of September.
It's important to remember the significant impact of testing costs on expenses.
While we expect Q4 testing expenses to be lower than Q3, we do not anticipate they will decline as much as inpatient expenses.
Lastly, recall the normal seasonality of the healthcare benefits segment, with fourth quarter operating income typically being the lowest of the year due to deductible satisfaction producing the highest quarterly medical costs.
For pharmacy services, given the continued strength in the quarter and our visibility for the remainder of the year, we are increasing full year 2021 adjusted operating income guidance to $6.85 billion - $6.94 billion, representing year-over-year growth of 20.5% to 22%.
We anticipate that the strength in third quarter pharmacy services results will largely continue into the fourth quarter.
In the retail/long-term care segment, we are also increasing our full year 2021 adjusted operating income guidance to $6.98 billion - $7.07 billion.
As you consider the fourth quarter, we currently expect vaccinations to continue, although at a lower rate than the third quarter.
We have also taken into account the impact of the CDC's COVID booster recommendations, as well as a modest impact from pediatric vaccinations.
We expect testing to decline modestly compared to the levels experienced during the third quarter.
Given retail's Q3 outperformance and Q4 outlook, we now expect the full year 2021 COVID impact to be neutral.
This compares to our previous guidance in August for an overall modest negative net impact.
As we concluded the third quarter, we are very pleased with the performance of our businesses, which provides us with a strong foundation as we look ahead to 2022.
While we plan to share more details at our upcoming investor day in early December in New York, I want to update you on our thoughts regarding the 2022 outlook.
Although many factors are still to be determined, we believe that current analyst estimates for 2022 adjusted earnings per share of approximately $8.20 are within our anticipated initial guidance range.
As discussed last quarter, there are significant factors to consider when determining an appropriate baseline for 2021.
In 2022, we will incur a full year of expenses related to our minimum wage increase announced last quarter.
We estimate these factors combined represent approximately $0.40 per share.
Using the midpoint of our updated 2021 adjusted earnings per share guidance range, which is $7.95, these adjustments create a 2021 baseline of $7.55.
Another significant factor in considering 2022 performance is the effect that COVID will have on our retail and healthcare benefits businesses.
For retail, we expect that COVID-19 vaccine and testing volume, which is expected to generate over $3 billion of revenue in 2021, will decline significantly in 2022 to 30% to 40% of the volume we administered in 2021.
Additionally, we expect COVID-driven front store sales to decline in 2022.
For HCB, we expect to see a significant improvement in results in 2022, as treatment and testing costs decline with COVID cost estimates and improved risk-adjusted revenue reflected in our pricing.
Overall, we estimate the COVID-driven impact in HCB will largely be offset by the expected decline in COVID-related retail performance.
It's important to note that forecasts of future COVID impacts on our business remain extremely difficult and are subject to change as circumstances dictate.
Beyond these considerations, other factors affecting our growth for 2022 remain consistent with the commentary we provided last quarter regarding headwinds and tailwinds.
Considering all of this, the current consensus of analyst estimates of approximately $8.20 for adjusted earnings per share would represent about an 8% increase over the 2021 baseline.
To summarize, CVS Health's strong performance in the first half of 2021 continued in the third quarter, producing strong revenue, adjusted operating income, and cash flow results, and we are pleased to again raise our full year 2021 adjusted earnings per share guidance.
During the pandemic, we have solidified our opportunity to become a national leader in healthcare delivery, which fundamentally involves lowering the cost of care, improving access and convenience, ultimately enabling people to live healthier and more fulfilling lives.
At our investor day in a few weeks, we look forward to sharing more about our strategy for the coming years to deliver on this ambition and to position CVS Health to generate sustainable, low double-digit adjusted earnings per share growth.
Summary:
output:
compname posts q3 adjusted earnings per share $1.97.
q3 adjusted earnings per share $1.97 .
sees fy adjusted earnings per share $7.90 to $8.00.
qtrly total revenues increased to $73.8 billion, up 10.0% compared to prior year.
raised 2021 cash flow from operations guidance range to $13.0 billion to $13.5 billion from $12.5 billion to $13.0 billion.
qtrly adjusted operating income increased 12.5% primarily due to administration of covid-19 vaccinations and diagnostic testing.
administered more than 8 million covid-19 tests and more than 11 million covid-19 vaccines nationwide in q3.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Information about Dollar General can be found on dollargeneral.com in the News & Events section.
We may reference certain non-GAAP financial measures.
Information about Dollar General can be found on dollargeneral.com in the News & Events section.
Our team remains committed to our mission of providing affordable essentials close to home, despite challenging conditions. I'm extremely proud of their dedication.
Throughout the pandemic, we've prioritized employee and customer safety while meeting community needs as an essential business.
We took measures like providing protective equipment, offering dedicated shopping hours for vulnerable groups, and supporting employee vaccination.
We invested about $248 million in pandemic response in 2020, including around $167 million in bonuses for frontline staff to recognize their exceptional work during a difficult year.
Dollar General aims to support customers through our extensive network of over 17,000 stores located near most of the U.S. population.
We're focused on advancing our key strategies and initiatives to meet evolving customer needs and drive sustainable long-term growth.
We're excited to provide an update on some of our plans for 2021.
We'll continue expanding several key initiatives like our non-consumables initiative, Fast Track, and completing the initial DG Fresh rollout.
Our new pOpshelf stores have exceeded expectations for sales and margins. We plan to accelerate pOpshelf openings in 2021 and incorporate the concept into some larger Dollar General locations.
We're introducing changes to our store development strategy, including expanding our Dollar General Plus format and testing two new larger store formats.
Most new stores will use our new larger base prototype, replacing traditional formats and allowing for optimized product assortment and future growth.
We've identified more potential locations for small-box stores in the continental U.S. than previously estimated.
The fourth quarter saw strong top and bottom line growth.
Non-consumable categories again outperformed consumables, marking the 11th straight quarter of growth.
Monthly comps increased high single digits in December and mid-teens in November and January.
Q4 net sales rose 17.6% to $8.4 billion, driven by 12.7% comp sales growth.
We gained market share in consumables, with increases in both units and dollars sold.
We attracted more new customers, who tend to be younger, higher-income and more diverse.
Operating margin expanded significantly, contributing to Q4 earnings per share of $2.62, up 24.8%.
Full year net sales increased 21.6% to $33.7 billion, with 16.3% comp sales growth.
We opened our 17,000th store and launched the pOpshelf concept in 2020.
We completed a record 2,780 real estate projects, exceeding our initial target.
We made strategic investments to strengthen our competitive position in the discount retail sector.
Our results reflect strong execution and validate our growth strategies.
We're laying groundwork for future initiatives to drive additional growth.
We believe our unique store network provides competitive advantages in the current retail environment.
I'm proud of our team's achievements and excited about future opportunities.
Gross profit margin increased 77 basis points to 32.5%, our seventh straight quarter of expansion.
This was driven by reduced markdowns, higher initial markups, more non-consumable sales, and lower shrink.
These were partially offset by increased transportation and distribution costs.
SG&A as a percentage of sales increased 48 basis points to 22.2%, mainly due to COVID-19 related expenses.
Q4 operating profit rose 21% to $872 million, or 10.4% of sales.
COVID-19 positively impacted operating profit through higher sales, partially offset by $96 million in pandemic-related investments.
The Q4 effective tax rate was 22.7%, compared to 23% last year.
Q4 earnings per share increased 24.8% to $2.62, contributing to full year EPS of $10.62, up 59.9%.
Our strong balance sheet and cash flow provide flexibility to support stakeholders, invest for growth, and return value to shareholders.
At year-end, merchandise inventories reached $5.2 billion, showing an overall increase of 12.2% and a 6.3% rise per store.
We are making good progress in improving our in-stock position and are satisfied with our overall inventory levels, although some high-demand products still have higher stock than desired.
Operating cash flow in 2020 was substantial, totaling $3.9 billion, which represents a $1.6 billion or 73.2% increase.
The year's total capital expenditures were $1 billion, encompassing planned investments in new stores, remodels, relocations, distribution and transportation projects, and spending on strategic initiatives.
During the quarter, we bought back 4.3 million shares of our common stock for $900 million and distributed a quarterly dividend of $0.36 per outstanding common share, totaling $87 million.
With the recent announcement of additional share repurchase authorization, we now have approximately $2.4 billion remaining under the repurchase program.
Our capital allocation priorities continue to be effective and remain consistent.
Our top priority is investing in high-return growth opportunities, including expanding our store network and advancing our strategic initiatives.
We remain dedicated to returning significant cash to shareholders through planned share repurchases and quarterly dividends, while maintaining our current investment-grade credit rating and managing a leverage ratio of about 3 times adjusted debt to EBITDA.
We now turn to our financial outlook for 2021.
We continue to operate in uncertain times regarding the COVID-19 pandemic's severity and duration, including its impact on the economy, consumer behavior, and our business.
Despite ongoing uncertainty, we are providing select annual guidance to offer the best perspective we can, based on current information.
However, several potential factors not incorporated into our guidance could affect our business this year, as their timing, extent, and potential impacts are unclear. These include, but are not limited to: the recently approved government stimulus package, other unknown external factors related to the ongoing health crisis and its impact on consumer behavior, and potential changes to minimum wage rates.
With this in mind, our expectations for 2021 include: net sales ranging from a 2% decline to flat; same-store sales declining 4% to 6%, reflecting 10% to 12% growth on a two-year stack basis; and earnings per share between $8.80 and $9.50, representing a compound annual growth rate of 15% to 20% (or 14% to 19% on an adjusted basis) over two years, surpassing our long-term goal of at least 10% annual adjusted earnings per share growth.
Our earnings per share guidance assumes an effective tax rate between 22% and 23%.
We expect capital spending to range from $1.05 billion to $1.15 billion as we continue investing in our strategic initiatives and core business to support and drive future growth.
We plan to repurchase approximately $1.8 billion of our common stock this year, reflecting our strong liquidity position and confidence in our business's long-term growth potential.
Let me provide additional context for our expectations.
Given the unusual circumstances, I'll elaborate on our Q1 comp sales trends.
Despite losing about 8,400 store operating days due to winter weather closures across the country, February same-store sales increased 5.7%, reflecting a healthy 11.2% increase on a two-year stack basis.
From late February through March 16, comp sales decreased approximately 16% as we face our most challenging monthly comp sales comparison of the year. For reference, March 2020 comp sales growth was 34.5%.
Looking ahead, we remain cautious about our 2021 sales outlook due to continued significant uncertainty and unique comparisons to last year.
We expect stronger performance in the second half of 2021, given more difficult sales comparisons in the first half, particularly in Q1.
Regarding gross margin, 2020 benefited from a higher proportion of sales from our higher-margin non-consumable categories, with full-year net sales percentage increases in these categories significantly exceeding our consumables business.
We anticipate our sales mix will shift towards consumables categories in 2021, pressuring our rate. However, the timing and impact of this shift are currently uncertain.
Gross margins in 2020 also benefited from reduced markdowns, including higher sell-through rates in seasonal and clearance-sensitive non-consumable categories due to significant customer demand.
We expect markdown rates to increase somewhat from the abnormally low levels of 2020, likely creating some gross margin pressure compared to last year.
While we continue to see higher carrier rates and fuel costs, our ongoing efforts to improve efficiencies and reduce expenses, including further expansion of our private fleet, are expected to help partially offset these cost pressures in 2021.
Keep in mind that the second and third quarters represent the most challenging comparisons for gross profit rate, following improvements of 167 basis points in Q2 2020 and 178 basis points in Q3 2020.
Regarding SG&A, we expect ongoing pandemic-related expenses in 2021, but anticipate a significant reduction in COVID-19-related costs compared to last year.
However, the leverage from these reduced costs is expected to be offset by deleverage from lower comp sales and approximately $60 million to $70 million in incremental year-over-year investments related to our strategic initiatives as we expand their rollouts.
We anticipate our strategic initiatives will positively contribute to operating profit and margin in 2021, driven by NCI and DG Fresh, as we expect the gross margin benefits will outweigh the associated expenses.
We estimate Q1 operating profit will be negatively impacted by approximately $35 million to $40 million due to lost sales from store closures and expenses related to February's widespread winter weather.
In conclusion, we are proud of our team's execution and performance, resulting in exceptional fourth quarter and full year results.
We continue to manage expenses and capital disciplined, aiming to deliver consistent, strong financial performance while strategically investing for the long term.
We remain confident in our business model and ongoing financial priorities to drive profitable same-store sales growth, healthy new store returns, strong free cash flow, and long-term shareholder value.
Let me update you on our operating priorities, including strategic initiatives and plans for 2021.
Our first operating priority is driving profitable sales growth. The team performed exceptionally well in 2020.
NCI, which consists of new and expanded product offerings in key non-consumable categories, was available in over 5,800 stores by the end of 2020, including nearly 400 stores in our light version. This exceeded our prior expectation of more than 5,600 stores.
Given our strong performance, we plan to expand this offering to about 5,700 additional stores this year, bringing the total number of NCI stores to over 11,000 by year-end. This includes over 2,100 stores in our light version, which incorporates most of the NCI assortment through a more streamlined approach.
Our newest concept, pOpshelf, builds on our success and learnings with NCI. pOpshelf aims to engage customers with a fun, affordable, and differentiated treasure hunt experience, offering continually refreshed merchandise, a unique in-store experience, and exceptional value with about 95% of items priced at $5 or less.
We opened our first five pOpshelf locations in 2020. Given strong results, we're accelerating the rollout in 2021, targeting up to 50 pOpshelf stores by year-end, up from our previous goal of about 30.
Additionally, we plan to incorporate this concept in up to 25 Dollar General stores in 2021 as a store-within-a-store format. These smaller footprint pOpshelf shops will be prominently positioned in the center of the store, with both Dollar General and pOpshelf branding on exterior entrances to build awareness.
Our goal is to test, learn, and expand to more locations over time, leveraging the unique strengths of these complementary formats and building on pOpshelf's early success by making it available to a broader customer base.
Regarding DG Fresh, our strategic shift to self-distribution of frozen and refrigerated goods, we continue to be pleased with the product cost savings. DG Fresh remains the largest contributor to the gross margin benefit from higher initial markups on inventory purchases, and we expect this benefit to grow as we scale this initiative.
Another important goal of DG Fresh is to increase sales in these categories. We're pleased with our success, driven by higher overall in-stock levels and the introduction of new products in select stores serviced by DG Fresh.
Given our success, we're accelerating the rollout of additional offerings, recently introducing more products, including national and private brands, to optimize our assortment and increase relevance with customers.
While produce isn't included in our initial rollout plans, we believe DG Fresh provides a potential path to expanding our produce offering to more than 10,000 stores over time, capitalizing on our extensive self-distribution capabilities.
By the end of 2020, we were self-distributing to over 16,000 stores from 10 facilities.
This exceeded our earlier projection of more than 14,000 stores by year's end.
We are on schedule to finish our initial rollout across the chain in 2021.
Our cooler expansion program continues to be our most significant merchandising initiative.
We installed over 62,000 cooler doors across our stores in 2020.
We plan to add more than 65,000 cooler doors in 2021, continuing our multi-year growth trend in cooler doors and related sales.
In 2019, we began using high-capacity coolers in most new, remodeled, and relocated stores, creating more opportunities to improve on-shelf availability and offer a wider product range, facilitated by DG Fresh.
Our FedEx partnership now offers package pickup and dropoff services in over 8,500 stores, with plans to expand to over 9,500 stores by year-end, furthering our history of serving rural areas.
We are pursuing additional ways to improve gross margin, including boosting private brand sales, global sourcing, and enhancing supply chain efficiency, alongside the benefits from NCI and DG Fresh.
Our 2021 supply chain plans include expanding our private fleet, which made up over 20% of our outbound fleet at the end of 2020.
The new Walton, Kentucky dry distribution center is expected to increase efficiency by reducing stem miles.
We plan to open two more DG Fresh facilities in 2021 to optimize our fresh network and support future growth.
Our combination DG Fresh and dry distribution center in Blair, Nebraska is expected to be completed soon and will help further reduce stem miles over time.
While we made good progress in 2020, reducing shrink remains a key opportunity area.
We continue to expand our use of electronic article surveillance by tagging more items and using technology to improve in-store execution.
Our high-return, low-risk real estate model remains a core business strength.
In 2020, we completed 2,780 real estate projects, including 1,000 new stores, 1,670 remodels, and 110 relocations.
We now offer produce in more than 1,100 stores.
For 2021, we plan 2,900 real estate projects: 1,050 new stores, 1,750 remodels, and 100 relocations.
We aim to add produce to about 700 stores, bringing the total number of stores with produce to over 1,800.
We're evolving our store base by expanding our DGP format and introducing two new format types.
Our first new format and DGP concept, with about 8,500 square feet of selling space, allows for more high-capacity coolers, an extended queue line, and a broader product range.
We expect over 550 of our real estate projects this year to use one of these format types to enhance our value and convenience proposition, especially in rural America.
The second new format has about 9,500 square feet of selling space, featuring an extended queue line, broader assortment, nearly 50 high-capacity coolers, expanded produce, fresh meat, and additional checkout lanes, including self-checkout.
We believe this larger format better meets our customers' growing needs, particularly in underserved markets, and we aim to have over 100 locations by year-end.
These larger formats incorporate our best initiatives and are designed to expand high-growth categories in a customer-friendly way while maintaining strong returns.
We now estimate there are approximately 13,000 additional small-box store opportunities in the Continental U.S. for Dollar General stores, up from our previous estimate of nearly 12,000.
We estimate pOpshelf could add about 3,000 additional store opportunities, with another 1,000 for our smaller DGX format.
In total, we estimate about 17,000 new store opportunities across our format types, indicating significant potential for new unit growth.
Our digital initiative complements our physical stores by using technology to enhance the in-store customer experience.
We aim to create a digital ecosystem tailored to provide customers with a more convenient, frictionless, and personalized shopping experience.
In 2020, we rapidly rolled out DG Pickup to over 17,000 stores, offering a contactless shopping option.
We saw increased customer engagement across our digital platforms, including our digital coupons, shopping list feature, cart calculator, eCommerce site, DG Go! mobile checkout, and mobile app, which had nearly 4 million monthly active users by year-end.
Our future plans include offering more relevant and personalized options to increase customer engagement and loyalty.
We maintain a disciplined approach to spending through our Save to Serve zero-based budgeting process, keeping the customer central to all decisions while reinforcing cost control.
Our Fast Track initiative aims to increase store labor productivity, improve customer convenience, and enhance on-shelf availability.
We've seen labor productivity improvements from rolltainer and case pack optimization, leading to more efficient store stocking.
Self-checkout, part of Fast Track, offers customers a flexible checkout option while increasing store associate efficiency.
Self-checkout was available in over 1,600 stores at the end of 2020, with plans to introduce it in most stores by the end of 2022.
We aim to keep business simple, move quickly on growth opportunities, control expenses, and remain a low-cost operator.
As we grow, we continue to create new jobs and offer career advancement opportunities.
Over 12,000 of our current store managers were promoted internally.
We offer development opportunities through our private fleet expansion, DG Fresh, and pOpshelf.
In 2020, we transitioned to virtual learning, providing nearly 3 million training hours for employees through our award-winning programs.
These efforts have resulted in record low store manager turnover, high staffing levels, strong applicant flows, and a robust internal promotion pipeline.
We believe offering career development opportunities with a growing, purpose-driven company helps us attract and retain talent.
We're making significant progress on our operating priorities and strategic initiatives.
We have a strong set of initiatives for 2021 and are confident in our plans for long-term sustainable growth and shareholder value creation.
Our unique combination of value and convenience continues to resonate with customers, positioning us well for the future.
Summary:

q4 earnings per share $2.62.
q4 same store sales rose 12.7 percent.
q4 sales $8.4 billion versus refinitiv ibes estimate of $8.28 billion.

sees fiscal year 2021 net sales in range of a 2% decline to flat.
sees fy 2021 earnings per share $8.80 to $9.50.
