input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:The precise impact of COVID-19 on our operations remains unclear at this point.
We will be discussing both GAAP and non-GAAP financial metrics during this conference call.
Kevin will begin by providing an overview of the business, followed by Lewis who will present Dolby's financial results and projections for the third quarter and latter half of fiscal 2021.
We've had a promising start to our fiscal year with another robust performance in licensing revenue this quarter.
Our revenue for the first half of fiscal 2021 has increased by approximately 10% compared to the same period in fiscal 2020, with an even higher growth rate in earnings.
The strength of Dolby's business model and the widespread adoption of our technologies across consumer devices and services are reflected in our financial performance.
I'd like to highlight some areas of progress and recent examples of how Dolby is expanding its content offerings before Lewis delves into the financial details.
As more content experiences become Dolby experiences, we enhance our value proposition for deeper adoption in existing device categories and address use cases for adoption in new device categories, collectively driving our growth opportunities.
Dolby Atmos for music represents a significant advancement in how people can enjoy their favorite songs, creating new opportunities to expand Dolby Atmos adoption across a wider range of devices and services.
Lucid Motors has announced that they will be introducing the first car to market featuring Dolby Atmos.
The Lucid Air will offer the Dolby Atmos music experience in-car, marking the first example of addressing a key entertainment use case in the automotive sector.
Lucid is just one illustration of how we're creating more ways for consumers to enjoy an expanding library of Dolby Atmos music.
We're collaborating closely with top artists worldwide as more songs and albums become available in Dolby Atmos, including recent Grammy nominees like Taylor Swift, Lady Gaga, and Megan Thee Stallion.
This quarter, Hungama, a leading music streaming service in India, began offering Dolby Atmos support.
They join TIDAL, Amazon Music, and Anghami in streaming music in Dolby Atmos.
As we continue to build momentum for Dolby Atmos in music, we anticipate more services adopting it and deeper integration across mobile devices, PCs, cars, and headphones.
Gaming is another area where we see significant potential to bring Dolby Vision and Dolby Atmos to a growing number of experiences.
Microsoft Xbox will be the first gaming console to support both Dolby technologies for games.
Xbox gamers will have more options to enjoy the Dolby experience with new gaming headsets released this quarter from Microsoft and Bang & Olufsen that feature Dolby Atmos support.
Lenovo recently launched a new gaming-focused mobile phone, the Legion Phone Duel 2, which highlights Dolby Atmos support.
We also witnessed the first eSports event in Dolby Vision and Dolby Atmos this quarter.
As part of Blizzard Entertainment's BlizzConline, we enabled viewers to watch Overwatch matches in the combined Dolby experience through PCs and gaming consoles.
eSports offers unique opportunities to engage gamers by bringing Dolby Vision and Dolby Atmos to the experiences they're passionate about.
As we increase the number of Dolby experiences in games, we enhance our existing value proposition and create more reasons for adoption on gaming consoles, PCs, and mobile phones.
By expanding our presence in music and gaming, we address two primary use cases for mobile devices.
Simultaneously, we're discovering more ways for Dolby to enable the highest quality experiences across a broader range of content enjoyed on mobile devices.
In recent quarters, we've highlighted how we're enabling new mobile experiences, such as recording in Dolby Vision with the iPhone 12 or enjoying live sports content in Dolby Atmos through a mobile app.
This quarter, Earshot, a leading podcast service in India, became the first podcast app to support Dolby Atmos.
They will offer Dolby Atmos content across various podcast genres and in multiple languages.
As we continue to expand the relevance of Dolby Vision and Dolby Atmos across a wider range of content, we address more use cases for mobile devices, driving reasons for deeper adoption with our partners.
This quarter, Xiaomi launched their first mobile phones supporting both Dolby Vision and Dolby Atmos.
This adds to the growing number of partners offering the Dolby experience on mobile, highlighted by the Apple iPhone 12 lineup featuring the combined Dolby Vision and Dolby Atmos experience.
Additionally, Samsung, OPPO, and Sony continue to emphasize Dolby Atmos with the launch of their latest flagship models.
All of this progress enhances our strong position in movie and TV content, which continues to drive more device adoption in the living room.
This quarter, Samsung released their Q7 soundbar, featuring Dolby Atmos support.
In the TV market, our global partners, including Xiaomi, Changhong, and Skyworth, released new models supporting the combined Dolby experience.
In addition to Dolby Atmos support, TCL and Hisense also highlighted Dolby Vision IQ support in their recent TV launches.
Despite this momentum, we still see significant opportunities to achieve higher adoption levels for Dolby Vision and Dolby Atmos in the living room, similar to the widespread presence of our core audio technologies.
The adoption of Dolby Vision and Dolby Atmos on devices is driven by a steady stream of new titles enabled in the combined Dolby experience.
Our streaming partners, including Netflix, Disney+, Apple TV+, and HBO Max, continue to make a wide range of titles available in Dolby, consistently highlighting the combined experience with the release of their latest major titles.
Turning to cinema, as consumers return to movie theaters, they're seeking premium experiences, and Dolby Cinema offers the best way to enjoy a movie.
Currently, about 90% of our Dolby Cinemas worldwide are open, subject to certain capacity restrictions.
Our engagement with exhibitor partners remains strong, as we recently added a new Dolby Cinema partner in China and opened four new Dolby Cinema locations during the quarter.
We're also seeing initial signs of strong box office performance from titles like Godzilla vs. Kong and successful local content in China, including Detective Chinatown 3 and Hi, Mom, all available in Dolby Cinema.
We look forward to anticipated titles later this year, including Top Gun: Maverick, A Quiet Place II, and Black Widow, which will all be available in Dolby Cinema.
Over the past year, we've begun to bring the Dolby magic that powers the best movie, TV, and music experiences to a much broader range of content and interactions through Dolby.io, our developer platform.
We're focusing on deepening our engagement with the developer community, increasing the number of developers on the platform, and building their engagement with our APIs.
Just last week, we completed an integration between Box.com and Dolby.io.
Box users can now enhance their audio quality directly within their file storage, powered by Dolby Media APIs.
We're thrilled to offer unique solutions to Box's diverse customer base and increase engagement with Dolby.io.
Our interactive APIs support various applications across industries, from online education to fan engagement platforms and even live streaming for medical teams.
Looking forward, we see potential in combining real-time interactions with recorded media, allowing us to provide comprehensive solutions by integrating both our interactivity and media APIs.
As Dolby.io enables more new experiences, we're learning from developer interactions and adapting our offerings to support use cases with significant potential for high-quality media and superior real-time interactions.
We're gaining momentum in expanding Dolby Vision and Dolby Atmos experiences to new content forms like music and gaming.
By extending our technologies to a wider range of content, we strengthen our position in movies and TV while creating more reasons for adoption across devices and services.
Dolby.io is allowing our technologies to address a broader spectrum of content experiences and interactions.
This gives us confidence in our ability to drive future revenue and earnings growth.
I'll now turn it over to Lewis to discuss the financial details.
May the fourth be with you.
Our financial performance was strong this quarter, with revenue and earnings exceeding our previous guidance.
Let me provide some details for everyone.
Second quarter revenue reached $320 million, surpassing our guidance range of $280 million to $310 million, due to higher-than-anticipated volumes in several end markets and a $15 million true-up for Q1 shipments.
Year-over-year, second quarter revenue decreased from $352 million last year, attributed to lower recoveries and reduced cinema-related business, partially offset by increased adoption of Dolby Technologies and higher market volume in areas like PC and TV.
Sequentially, total revenue declined from Q1 due to expected lower recoveries and seasonality.
Q2 revenue consisted of $304 million in licensing and $16 million in products and services.
Let's examine licensing revenue trends by end market, starting with broadcast.
In the second quarter, GAAP income tax was 10.6% while non-GAAP income tax was 16%.
GAAP net income for Q2 was $76.2 million ($0.73 per diluted share), compared to $88.5 million ($0.86 per diluted share) in the same quarter last year.
Non-GAAP net income for Q2 reached $94.8 million ($0.91 per diluted share), versus $106.6 million ($1.04 per diluted share) in Q2 of the previous year.
Both GAAP and non-GAAP net income surpassed our guidance due to higher-than-expected revenue.
We generated approximately $83 million in cash from operations in Q2, up from $66 million in the same period last year, ending the quarter with roughly $1.2 billion in cash and investments.
During Q2, we repurchased about 760,000 shares of our common stock, leaving approximately $76 million in stock repurchase authorization.
We have declared a cash dividend of $0.22 per share.
The dividend will be distributed on May 25, 2021, to shareholders on record as of May 17, 2021.
Let's discuss our future outlook.
Three months ago, I predicted second-half revenues could reach the mid- to high 500s based on various factors and assumptions.
With Q2 completed, we now project second-half revenue between $560 million and $600 million.
For Q3 specifically, we expect total revenue to range from $260 million to $290 million.
Within this range, licensing could be between $250 million and $275 million, while products and services revenue might fall between $13 million and $18 million.
Regarding market conditions, industry reports suggest PC TAMs could increase year-over-year in the second half.
However, TVs and other consumer devices may see decreased TAMs in the second half due to last year's pandemic-driven demand spike, which may not recur this year.
We anticipate year-over-year organic growth in the second half, driven by wider adoption of our Dolby technologies across various markets.
We also expect higher revenue from our cinema-related businesses as the industry begins to recover.
Let's examine the rest of the Q3 P&L outlook.
Q3 GAAP gross margin is estimated between 88% and 89%, while non-GAAP gross margin is projected between 89% and 90%.
Products and services gross margin is expected to range from breakeven to $1 million positive on a GAAP basis and from $1 million to $2 million positive on a non-GAAP basis.
Q3 GAAP operating expenses are estimated between $210 million and $220 million, while non-GAAP operating expenses are projected between $185 million and $195 million.
The increase in Q3 operating expenses is primarily due to marketing programs scheduled for the second half of this year, suggesting Q4 expenses could be at least as high as Q3.
However, annual marketing expenses at the high end of our opex range would be similar to last year, just differently timed.
We'll provide an update when we report Q3 results.
Other income for Q3 is projected between $1 million and $2 million.
The effective tax rate for Q3 is expected to range from 20% to 21% on both GAAP and non-GAAP bases.
Based on these factors, we estimate Q3 diluted earnings per share could range from $0.15 to $0.30 on a GAAP basis and from $0.37 to $0.52 on a non-GAAP basis.
We announced today that Lewis has decided to retire later this year.
Lewis has been instrumental in strengthening our financial position, adapting to new business models, and supporting the expansion of Dolby experiences over the past nine years.
He has built a strong team and mentored many employees across the organization.
Lewis will work closely with me to ensure a smooth transition as we search for our next Chief Financial Officer.
We'll continue to benefit from Lewis's expertise during the transition period before he focuses more on his family.
Kevin jokingly suggested he said "good riddance" when first informed of Lewis's retirement.
Lewis acknowledged that his jokes might fall into the "Dad Jokes" category but expressed gratitude for the privilege of serving as CFO and the unique Dolby experience he's had.
He looks forward to a smooth transition and will happily watch the company's continued success from the sidelines.
Kevin agreed that no one has disputed the quality of Lewis's humor and assured that they would make the most of his remaining transition time.
Summary:
output:
q2 non-gaap earnings per share $0.91.
q2 gaap earnings per share $0.73.
sees q3 gaap earnings per share $0.15 to $0.30.
sees q3 revenue $260 million to $290 million.
sees q3 2021 non-gaap earnings per share $0.37 to $0.52.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:We are currently experiencing the COVID-19 pandemic.
Various factors, including the pandemic's intensity, duration, and scope, as well as governmental, corporate, and consumer responses, will determine its ongoing impact on our operations.
These aspects continue to develop and remain unclear at present.
Lewis will review Dolby's financial performance and provide our fiscal 2020 forecast, followed by Kevin's discussion of business operations.
I trust you're all taking necessary precautions.
I'm pleased to announce that Q3 revenues reached the upper limit of our projected scenario from three months ago, and our earnings surpassed the expected range due to a substantial tax benefit and lower-than-anticipated operating costs.
Although we outperformed our Q3 outlook, it's important to note that the figures were lower than initial projections made at the year's start, before COVID-19 became a factor.
Let's examine the figures.
Revenue for the third quarter was $247 million, compared to $352 million in Q2 and $302 million in Q3 of the previous year.
Our Q3 revenue forecast entering the quarter ranged from $225 million to $250 million.
Comparing our actual results to our guidance, revenues from TVs, PCs, and mobile devices were at the higher end, while consumer electronics and set-top boxes were at the lower end of our projected scenario.
Products and services reached the upper end of the range, but it's worth remembering that we had reduced our expectations by 70% to 80% due to COVID-19's significant impact on the cinema industry.
Examining the total company performance quarter-over-quarter, revenue decreased by approximately $105 million from Q2, with about half attributed to timing of contract revenue and lower recoveries, and the other half due to COVID-19 impacts, including reduced royalties from unit shipments across various devices, decreased sales of cinema products and services, and lower revenue from Dolby Cinemas' box office share.
Comparing total company performance year-over-year, revenue dropped by about $55 million compared to last year's Q3, primarily due to COVID-19, with similar factors as mentioned earlier: reduced unit shipments, lower products and services sales, and decreased Dolby Cinema revenue.
Q3 revenue consisted of $235 million in licensing and $12 million in products and services.
Let's break down the licensing revenue by end market, beginning with Broadcast.
Broadcast accounted for about 38% of total licensing in the third quarter.
Broadcast revenues decreased by approximately 34% year-over-year, driven by lower recoveries and reduced unit volume due to the pandemic, despite increased adoption of Dolby Vision and Dolby Atmos in TVs and set-top boxes compared to last year.
Sequentially, Broadcast declined by about 31% due to lower recoveries and reduced unit volume.
Mobile represented roughly 33% of total licensing in Q3.
Mobile increased by about 65% compared to last year, due to higher recoveries and revenues from patent programs, partially offset by pandemic-related unit volume impacts.
Sequentially, Mobile grew by about 3%, driven by recoveries but partially offset by pandemic-related unit volume impacts.
PC accounted for approximately 10% of total licensing in the third quarter.
PC decreased by about 4% year-over-year, due to lower recoveries and reduced unit volume, although it's worth noting that adoption of Dolby Vision and Dolby Atmos in PCs has increased since last year.
Sequentially, PC declined by nearly 50%, due to timing of contract revenue and lower recoveries.
Consumer electronics represented about 9% of total licensing in the third quarter, with year-over-year CE licensing down by approximately 29%, driven by lower volume and reduced recoveries.
Sequentially, CE decreased by nearly 60%, due to timing of contract revenue and lower unit volume.
Other markets accounted for about 10% of total licensing in the third quarter.
They decreased by approximately 34% year-over-year due to significantly lower revenues from Dolby Cinema, as nearly all screens were closed for the quarter, and reduced revenues from gaming due to console life cycles.
Sequentially, Other Markets declined by about 16%, driven by lower revenue from Dolby Cinema and via admin fees (fees in the patent pool program we administer).
This was partially offset by higher recoveries in automotive and gaming sectors.
Beyond licensing, our products and services revenue was $11.8 million in Q3, compared to $23 million in Q2 and $30.3 million in last year's Q3.
We anticipated a significant decrease in sales in this category, as most of this revenue comes from equipment sold to cinema exhibitors, who continue to be negatively affected by the pandemic.
Let's review margins and operating expenses for Q3.
Total gross margin in the third quarter was 87.9% on a GAAP basis and 89% on a non-GAAP basis.
Products and services gross margin on a GAAP basis was negative $5.5 million in the third quarter, due to fixed costs not fully covered by the lower volume we experienced.
As a reminder, our guidance at the quarter's start projected GAAP gross product margin to range from negative $6 million to negative $9 million.
Products and services gross margin on a non-GAAP basis was negative $3.5 million in the third quarter for the same reasons mentioned in the GAAP discussion.
Our guidance for non-GAAP product gross margin was negative $5 million to negative $8 million.
Operating expenses in the third quarter on a GAAP basis were $182.9 million, compared to $209 million in Q2.
Q3 operating expenses were about $8 million less than the low end of our guided range, primarily due to timing of certain marketing programs pushed into Q4, lower legal expenses, and reduced travel and outside services costs.
Operating expenses in the third quarter on a non-GAAP basis were $159.2 million, compared to $188.4 million in the second quarter.
The Q3 non-GAAP total was also below our projected range for the same reasons discussed in the GAAP expenses.
Operating income in the third quarter was $34.1 million on a GAAP basis, or 13.8% of revenue, compared to $34.3 million or 11.3% of revenue in Q3 of last year.
The third quarter of the previous year included a $30 million restructuring expense, largely due to prematurely ending a facility lease
Non-GAAP operating income for Q3 was $60.5 million (24.5% of revenue), compared to $85.9 million (28.4% of revenue) in the same period last year
Q3 saw a tax benefit of $27.4 million on a GAAP basis and $21.2 million on a non-GAAP basis
The Q3 tax figures include about $36 million in specific one-time benefits resolved during the quarter
GAAP net income for Q3 was $67.3 million ($0.66 per diluted share), up from $39.6 million ($0.38 per diluted share) in Q3 of the previous year
Non-GAAP net income for Q3 reached $87.5 million ($0.86 per diluted share), an increase from $79.3 million ($0.76 per diluted share) in the same quarter last year
Both GAAP and non-GAAP Q3 net income surpassed initial projections due to higher revenue, lower operating costs, and favorable tax outcomes
Q3 cash flow from operations was approximately $134 million, compared to $91 million in the same period last year, with quarter-end cash and investments totaling over $1.1 billion
During Q3, the company repurchased about 500,000 shares of common stock, leaving roughly $230 million available for future buybacks
A $0.22 per share cash dividend was declared, payable on August 26, 2020, to shareholders of record as of August 17, 2020
Let's examine the Q4 forecast
Three months ago, when discussing Q3 guidance, I emphasized the current market challenges
Consumer demand was declining, visibility was limited, and industry reports were inconsistent and outdated
Currently, we have updated TAM data for some markets, but not all
Customers still have limited visibility, and we won't have actual June quarter shipment data until reports come in over the next few months, plus economic uncertainty persists
Given this context, here's our Q4 scenario with key assumptions
Regarding products and services revenue, primarily for the cinema industry
Theaters are reopening more slowly than anticipated, so we don't expect significant equipment purchases from exhibitors in Q4
We project Q4 products and services revenue between $10 million and $15 million
Concerning licensing
We estimate Q4 licensing revenue between $215 million and $240 million, compared to $235 million in Q3
The transition from Q3 to Q4 shows a downward trend due to revenue timing under customer contracts
This is typical Dolby seasonality, with higher revenue in Q2 and Q3, and lower in Q1 and Q4, largely due to contract revenue timing
We assume a modest increase in total unit shipments for Q4 compared to Q3 as consumer spending improves
Our Q4 scenario assumes roughly a 5% increase in unit shipments across all device categories
We anticipate minimal revenue from Dolby Cinema box office share in Q4
In summary, our Q4 total revenue projection ranges from $225 million to $255 million
Compared to last year's Q4 revenue of $299 million, the potential decline is mostly attributable to pandemic-related economic effects and lower recoveries
Q4 GAAP gross margin is estimated between 85% and 86%, with non-GAAP gross margin about 1 percentage point higher
Products and services gross margin will remain negative in Q4, mainly due to fixed costs not fully covered at lower revenue levels
At the projected revenue range, Q4 GAAP products and services gross margin could be between -$6 million and -$9 million, and non-GAAP between -$5 million and -$8 million
Q4 operating expenses are estimated between $187 million and $197 million on a GAAP basis, and between $167 million and $177 million on a non-GAAP basis
Other income is projected between $2 million and $3 million for the quarter
The Q4 income tax rate is projected between 19% and 21% on both GAAP and non-GAAP bases
Based on these factors, we estimate Q4 GAAP diluted earnings per share between $0.05 and $0.20, and non-GAAP between $0.22 and $0.37
For the full fiscal year 2020, revenue could range from $1,115 million to $1,145 million, GAAP diluted earnings per share from $2.04 to $2.19, and non-GAAP diluted earnings per share from $2.76 to $2.91
Dolby's strong financial model, balance sheet, and value proposition position us well to navigate these challenging times
Our team continues to innovate and expand Dolby experiences worldwide
While Q3 revenues were at the high end of our projections, uncertainty remains in many of our markets
The pandemic has led to reduced consumer spending and shifts in new customer acquisitions and revenue timing
However, our partners remain committed to enabling new Dolby Vision and Dolby Atmos experiences
As consumer spending recovers, our strong position across various devices and services will help us resume revenue and earnings growth
Our growth strategy has always focused on increasing the availability of compelling Dolby content
The adoption of Dolby Vision and Dolby Atmos in movies and TV has driven increased adoption across a wide range of devices
We're expanding the Dolby experience into new areas like gaming and music, enhancing our value and creating more opportunities in mobile, PC, and automotive devices.
We're also starting to address a wider range of content beyond premium entertainment, recently launching our development platform Dolby.io.
These factors give us assurance in our capacity to achieve long-term growth.
Now, let's review some key points from this quarter.
As streaming content consumption increases, Dolby Vision and Dolby Atmos continue to be featured in the most popular content.
The much-anticipated releases of Hamilton on Disney Plus and Greyhound on Apple TV Plus are both offered in Dolby.
This quarter marked the debut of Dolby Vision titles on Google Play.
Hotstar, India's largest streaming service, began offering Dolby Vision for Disney Plus content.
Several partners incorporated Dolby Vision and Dolby Atmos into their products this quarter.
Apple, which supports these technologies across most of its devices, announced that AirPods Pro will support Dolby Atmos with iOS 14.
Sonos introduced the Sonos Arc, their first Dolby Atmos-compatible soundbar.
Free, a major French Internet service provider, launched their first set-top box supporting both Dolby Vision and Atmos.
Last month, Xiaomi released their first TV supporting both technologies.
The adoption of Dolby Vision and Atmos in TVs is growing globally, particularly in India.
This quarter, TCL, Sony, OnePlus, and Nokia all announced new TV models in India supporting both technologies.
Panasonic also expanded their use of Dolby Vision IQ to more models.
In FY '19, Dolby Vision was included in about 10% of 4K TV shipments, and we're on track to significantly increase that rate for fiscal '20, with substantial growth potential still ahead.
Our strong presence in movie and TV content has facilitated the initial adoption of Dolby Vision and Atmos in PC and mobile devices.
We see a significant opportunity to accelerate adoption by enabling more experiences on these devices, including gaming and music.
Recently, Tidal significantly expanded the number of devices supporting Dolby Atmos music to include compatible soundbars and home theater equipment.
We're seeing examples of how Dolby Atmos can create unique experiences across various music genres.
This quarter, we saw classical music from John Williams and recordings from the London Philharmonic Orchestra mixed in Dolby Atmos.
Empire, an independent label, began releasing music in Dolby Atmos from artists like Fat Joe and Remy Ma.
The Dolby music experience enhances our engagement with partners and strengthens the value proposition for Dolby Atmos in existing device categories like mobile phones, while creating new opportunities in areas such as automotive and smart speakers.
Regarding cinema, most theaters remained closed during the quarter, with a few regions slowly beginning to reopen.
The closure of cinemas worldwide has significantly reduced demand for our cinema products.
We believe that when cinemas reopen, exhibitors will highlight their premium offerings, and consumers will seek out the best experience, which is Dolby Cinema.
Last month, the first Dolby Cinema in South Korea opened with our partner Megabox.
We've also added a second partner to bring Dolby Cinemas to Saudi Arabia, where our first site opened just last week.
Looking ahead, we're excited about the unique opportunity to significantly broaden the content experience addressed by Dolby technologies.
We launched our developer platform Dolby.io this quarter, enabling developers to access Dolby technology to enhance media and communications experiences in their apps and services.
Initial customers have applied our technology across various use cases, including podcasts, e-learning, and telehealth.
Recently, artists can optimize their music recordings' quality with mastering on SoundCloud powered by Dolby's platform.
We're excited by the initial reception of Dolby.io and its potential to bring Dolby technology to the growing amount of media and communications content in our daily lives.
In conclusion, Dolby has a solid foundation with a strong business model, and people increasingly want immersive entertainment and communications experiences.
The quality of these experiences is crucial.
We continue to focus on increasing the number of devices supporting Dolby Vision and Atmos.
We aim to accelerate adoption and expand the device categories supporting the Dolby experience by enabling new forms of content like music and gaming.
We're excited about the opportunity to enable an even broader range of Dolby experiences, most recently with the launch of Dolby.io.
All these factors reinforce our belief in future opportunities and give us confidence in our ability to drive revenue and earnings growth.
Summary:

q3 non-gaap earnings per share $0.86.

fy diluted earnings per share is anticipated to range from $2.76 to $2.91 on a non-gaap basis.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:I am Pankaj Gupta, the vice president of investor relations at Dow.
Jim Fitterling, Dow's CEO and chairman, and Howard Ungerleider, the president and CFO, are also participating in this call.
Dow's 10-Q and 10-K forms provide comprehensive analyses of key risks and uncertainties that may lead to discrepancies.
All financial information, where relevant, excludes notable items unless stated otherwise.
We will also discuss non-GAAP measurements.
The agenda for our call is displayed on Slide 2.
Jim will start by discussing our third-quarter highlights and segment performance.
Howard will provide modeling guidance and projections, followed by Jim's summary of our value growth strategy outlined at our recent investor day and why Dow remains an attractive investment option.
Let's begin with Slide 3.
Dow achieved year-over-year and sequential growth in both top and bottom lines during the third quarter.
Our proactive approach to storm preparation ensured the safety of our team and community, allowing for swift recovery.
We saw a 53% increase in sales compared to last year, with double-digit growth across all segments, businesses, and regions.
Sales also increased by 7% compared to the previous quarter.
We capitalized on strong pricing momentum, driven by tight supply-demand dynamics in our key value chains, and achieved 2% volume growth both year-over-year and sequentially, supported by robust end-market demand despite supply and logistics challenges.
Our operating EBIT increased by over $2.1 billion year-over-year, with improvements across all segments and businesses, and $58 million higher sequentially.
Key factors included year-over-year margin expansion of 1,170 basis points, driven by pricing momentum and demand growth, as well as increased equity earnings of $189 million from margin expansion at our Sadara and Kuwait joint ventures.
Our ongoing focus on cash generation and balanced capital allocation resulted in operating cash flow of $2.7 billion, up $958 million year-over-year, driven by margin expansion from pricing momentum in key value chains.
We returned $918 million to shareholders through our industry-leading dividend of $518 million and $400 million in share repurchases.
We also reduced gross debt by over $1.1 billion during the quarter.
Our proactive liability management actions, including tendering existing notes, have resulted in no long-term debt maturities until 2026 and reduced annual interest expense by more than $60 million.
Overall, Dow continues to deliver on its priorities, and we anticipate further strength ahead as we benefit from a favorable macro environment and execute our disciplined strategy to decarbonize our operations and grow earnings, creating significant value for all stakeholders.
Moving to our segment performance on Slide 4.
The packaging and specialty plastics segment reported operating EBIT of $2 billion, compared to $647 million in the same period last year.
Sequentially, operating EBIT decreased by $60 million.
Price gains in both businesses and all regions led to improved margins in the core business and increased equity earnings.
Sequentially, operating EBIT margins declined by 300 basis points due to higher feedstock and energy costs.
The packaging and specialty plastics business reported increased net sales year-over-year, driven by local price gains in industrial and consumer packaging, as well as flexible food and beverage packaging applications.
Volumes decreased year-over-year due to lower polyethylene supply resulting from planned maintenance turnarounds and weather-related outages during the quarter.
Compared to the previous quarter, the business achieved price and volume gains due to strong demand in industrial and consumer packaging applications, partially offset by hurricane-related outages.
In the industrial intermediates and infrastructure segment, operating EBIT was $713 million, up $609 million year-over-year, primarily due to continued tight supply and demand in both businesses.
Sequentially, operating EBIT increased by $65 million, and operating EBIT margins expanded by 50 basis points on volume and price gains in both businesses.
The polyurethanes and construction chemicals business increased net sales compared to the same period last year, with price gains in all regions due to tight supply-demand balances.
Volume declines year-over-year primarily reflected the planned transition of a low-margin coproducer contract, as well as weather-related outages and third-party supply constraints.
Sequentially, the business achieved sales growth due to increased local price and volume from additional supply availability to meet resilient demand.
The industrial solutions business reported improved net sales compared to the same period last year, with local price gains in all regions.
Volume increased year-over-year due to strong demand for materials in industrial manufacturing and energy applications.
Net sales also increased sequentially, driven by volume growth, primarily in coatings and industrial applications from increased supply and local price gains in all regions.
Lastly, the performance materials and coatings segment reported operating EBIT of $284 million, up $209 million compared to the same quarter last year, as margins increased by 750 basis points due to strong price momentum and robust demand recovery for silicones and industrial coatings offerings.
Sequentially, operating EBIT increased by $59 million on price gains, leading to margin expansion of 210 basis points.
The consumer solutions business achieved higher net sales year-over-year with price gains in all regions.
Volume increased over the prior year due to stronger consumer demand for personal care, mobility, and electronics offerings.
Sequentially, sales decreased as price increases in all regions were more than offset by volume declines resulting from planned maintenance and third-party supply and logistics constraints.
The coatings and performance monomers business delivered increased net sales year-over-year as higher raw material costs and tight supply-demand balances led to price gains in all regions.
Year-over-year volumes decreased as the recovery in demand for industrial coatings was outweighed by weather-related disruptions and constraints in third-party supply and logistics.
The company achieved local price increases across all regions in succession, bolstered by higher volume due to sustained strong demand for acrylic monomers and architectural coatings, as well as improved supply availability.
Let's move on to Slide 5.
The fourth quarter shows a continuation of strong demand growth across our packaging infrastructure, consumer, and mobility end markets.
Inventory levels for brand owners remain low.
Consequently, we expect higher than usual seasonal demand to persist into this year's holiday season.
In the packaging and specialty plastics sector, we continue to observe resilient demand for packaging applications and our specialized functional polymers.
Global polyethylene supply remains limited as the industry completes increased maintenance activities and supply chains recover from weather events in the U.S. Gulf Coast.
We concluded the third quarter experiencing higher costs for raw materials and energy, which we expect will likely continue through the fourth quarter.
We anticipate these costs to result in an approximately $350 million sequential increase.
Dow will continue to leverage our extensive geographic presence and industry-leading feedstock flexibility to help offset these impacts.
We also expect a $175 million benefit from turnarounds in the quarter as we finished our planned maintenance at our cracker in Canada.
In the industrial intermediates and infrastructure segment, ongoing consumer demand for furniture, bedding, appliances, pharmaceuticals, and home care products is expected to keep supply tight in our key value chains.
Due to weather-related outages in the third quarter, some of our planned maintenance activities were postponed to the fourth quarter.
Sadara will also begin a turnaround at its isocyanate facility in the fourth quarter.
In total, we anticipate $100 million in turnaround impacts for this segment.
Short-term increases in energy costs in the U.S. Gulf Coast and Europe are expected to result in an additional $100 million headwind in the quarter.
We continue to observe sequential recovery in industrial activity, particularly for energy applications.
We expect this recovery to persist at least through the fourth quarter as industrial production continues to ramp up from very low inventory levels to meet demand.
In the performance materials and coatings segment, demand for electronics, mobility, building, and construction continues to exceed supply.
Demand for architectural coatings is also expected to remain high due to consistently low inventory levels throughout the value chain.
Global production of silicones has been affected by recent dual control policy enforcement actions in China, with silicone metal prices nearly tripling from their previous levels.
We plan to advance a scheduled turnaround at a siloxane facility in Zhangjiagang, China, to coincide with government actions to restrict power usage.
Our current estimate for the quarter includes $125 million from increased raw material costs and turnaround impacts.
We will continue working to mitigate the effects of rising raw material costs through our integrated position in both businesses.
Despite higher raw material and energy costs in the fourth quarter, Dow will continue to capitalize on its advantaged global footprint, structural cost and feedstock advantages, and our diverse range of differentiated products to meet growing demand.
On Slide 6, looking ahead, we anticipate robust economic growth to continue.
With the Delta variant slowing the reopening of economies worldwide, there remains significant pent-up demand globally, particularly across our industrial and consumer end markets.
Many industries continue to experience elevated order backlogs and low inventory levels as supply chains struggle to keep pace with strong demand.
These supply chain disruptions are expected to persist, which will likely prolong the ability to replenish inventories across most value chains.
As a result, we expect market conditions to remain tighter than forecasted, a view reinforced by China's recent dual control policy that has impacted both coal olefins and methanol to olefins-based capacity, which account for over 30% of China's total polyethylene production.
GDP growth forecasts for 2022 are well above historical averages in most regions of the world as industries increase production to match robust consumer demand, with further potential upside as global chip shortages continue to extend the recovery in manufacturing.
Collectively, G7 countries have not yet fully recovered to pre-pandemic GDP levels.
This suggests additional growth potential as economies return to more normal consumption levels with increasing vaccination rates, particularly in Asia, where levels remain low compared to the rest of the world.
Moving to Slide 7.
At our recent investor day, we outlined how our differentiated portfolio and focus on sustainability-driven innovation will enable more than $3 billion in underlying EBITDA improvement across the cycle.
Our restructuring program and digital investments will yield $600 million in increased EBITDA.
Both initiatives are in progress, and our restructuring program is on track to achieve its $300 million run rate by year-end.
We also have a range of higher return, lower risk, and faster payback capital and operating investments that will enable an additional $2 billion in EBITDA in the near term.
Our investments to decarbonize and expand at our Fort Saskatchewan site in Alberta, Canada are also expected to generate approximately $1 billion in increased EBITDA.
As we've already mentioned, we're executing our strategy against a favorable macro backdrop that we expect will continue to support constructive market fundamentals for our key value chains.
Turning to Slide 8.
You'll find a detailed list of these low-risk growth investments.
Our capital investments are projected to generate $1 billion in EBITDA through incremental capacity expansions, debottlenecking, and enhanced feedstock flexibility across our operating segments.
We are making substantial progress already.
Our Fort Saskatchewan expansion, which adds 65,000 metric tons of annual ethylene capacity to meet growing polyethylene demand, is now finished and will be fully operational by the end of the fourth quarter.
In 2022, our FCDH pilot plant in Louisiana will begin operations, offering 20-40% lower capital expenses and 5-7% lower operating expenses while reducing CO2 emissions by up to 20% compared to other PDH technologies.
By year's end, our debottlenecking project to increase aniline production by 60,000 metric tons annually will be fully operational.
Earlier this year, we signed a memorandum of understanding for a new South China hub to improve local supply and formulation capabilities for the rapidly expanding Asia-Pacific market.
We recently completed a capacity expansion at one of our silicone polymer facilities.
By the end of the year, we will finish a new silicone sealant compounding unit to enable sustainable solutions for high-performance building and infrastructure applications.
We are advancing our 50 kt methacrylate investment on the U.S. Gulf Coast to support global end markets like inks, resins, and packaging materials, which is set to begin operations in the first half of next year.
Additionally, our operational investments are projected to generate another $1 billion in EBITDA as we enhance our production capabilities and shift our product mix towards higher growth and higher value markets.
In industrial intermediates and infrastructure, we're enhancing capabilities and shifting our focus towards higher-margin polyurethane systems for mobility and consumer applications.
Our industrial solutions business is improving its ability to provide specialized materials for the textile industry.
Our collaboration with Ralph Lauren on ECOFAST reduces energy usage by 40% and water usage by 50% in fabric dyeing.
Ralph Lauren aims to incorporate this technology in over 80% of its solid cotton products by 2025.
In performance materials and coatings, we're expanding our capacity to formulate specialized silicones for various attractive markets, including silicone adhesives for foldable displays in consumer electronics, thermal conductive silicone solutions for electric vehicles, and silicone solutions for 5G, where the market is expected to more than double in the next decade.
We recently partnered with customers on high-value innovations such as paper barrier coating applications using our award-winning Rhobarr polyolefin dispersion technology and Callaway's Supersoft golf balls, which feature a new hybrid cover made with Dow's paraloid-impact modifier.
In packaging and specialty plastics, we're improving our extensive conversion and testing capabilities to commercialize resins through packaging design, accelerating the innovation process, and expanding the addressable market for higher margin and more sustainable products.
We're already benefiting from the nine-layer blown film extrusion line project completed this year.
We're also investing to improve asset reliability, which will increase output and expand margins.
We're utilizing digital technology for customer trials and process automation to accelerate catalyst development for new resins and processes like FCDH, where we can typically be 100 times more efficient than conventional experimentation.
Collectively, our near-term investments will generate an increase of approximately $2 billion in underlying EBITDA, and we plan to achieve this growth with a disciplined and balanced approach, maintaining our top quartile performance in cash flow, cost structure, debt reduction, and shareholder remuneration.
Let's move on to Slide 9.
The strategy we outlined at our investor day builds upon our long-standing industry leadership.
Our plan enables us to meet demand driven by sustainability factors, achieve zero Scope 1 and 2 carbon emissions, and deliver significant underlying earnings and cash flow growth for years to come.
Our approach to decarbonize our footprint and grow earnings involves a phased, site-by-site strategy that both retrofits and replaces end-of-life assets with low-carbon-emission facilities while also expanding our capacity.
This plan will achieve a 30% reduction in our CO2 emissions between 2005 and 2030 through a disciplined approach that considers timing based on affordability, macro and regulatory drivers worldwide.
Our Texas 9 cracker demonstrates our ability to execute this plan effectively.
Texas-9 has 60% lower carbon intensity than any asset in our fleet, without any specific design for carbon capture or hydrogen.
The project was completed with 20% better capital efficiency and 12 months faster than other crackers built during that period.
Overall, the project has 65% lower conversion costs, consistently operates at over 110% of nameplate capacity, and has delivered a return on invested capital exceeding 15% since start-up.
We will apply key lessons from Texas-9 as we plan to construct the world's first net-zero carbon emissions ethylene cracker and derivatives complex in Fort Saskatchewan, Alberta, generating approximately $1 billion in EBITDA, as Howard mentioned earlier.
This project will more than triple our ethylene and downstream derivative capacity at the site while decarbonizing emissions for 20% of our global ethylene capacity.
We chose this site due to the availability of carbon capture infrastructure, advantaged feedstocks, and supportive government policies and incentives.
On Slide 10, as we pursue these attractive growth opportunities, we will maintain our balanced and disciplined financial approach since the spin-off.
We are committed to keeping capital expenditures at or below depreciation and amortization, well below pre-spin levels, while targeting return on invested capital above 13% across the economic cycle.
We will continue to align our capital spending with the macroeconomic environment, our affordability, and return targets.
Our investments fall into three categories: First, we'll maintain our foundation and maximize the return of our existing assets while ensuring safe and reliable operations.
Second, we'll execute our pipeline of faster payback, lower-risk incremental growth projects for downstream and sustainability-driven applications growing faster than GDP.
Third, we'll invest approximately $1 billion per year to decarbonize our footprint and grow earnings.
These investments allow us to meet increasing demand for low carbon footprint products while reducing enterprise risk through lower emissions assets.
In conclusion, on Slide 11, Dow is well-positioned to deliver significant long-term value for shareholders.
We have plans in place to both decarbonize our footprint and grow the enterprise as we achieve an additional $3 billion in underlying EBITDA, maintain industry-leading cash flow generation, and progress toward zero Scope 1 and 2 carbon emissions.
Our balanced capital allocation approach targets more than 13% return on invested capital, keeps capital expenditures within depreciation and amortization, and returns 65% of net income to shareholders across the economic cycle.
All of this is supported by our industry-leading portfolio, cost position, and strong track record of innovation that enables us to deliver differentiated products and solutions for our customers and a more sustainable world.
Operator, please provide the Q&A instructions.
Summary:
output: continue to see robust end-market demand that is expected to extend into 2022.

Context:Rick Muncrief, our president and CEO, Clay Gaspar, our chief operating officer, Jeff Ritenour, our chief financial officer, and several other senior management team members are also participating in today's call.
We're grateful to everyone who has taken the time to join us for this call.
For Devon Energy, 2021 was a year of transformation, characterized by our pioneering approach to bold strategic consolidation.
Our commitment to operational excellence, strict capital discipline, and the introduction of our industry-leading cash return business model, featuring our fixed plus variable dividend, were key highlights.
This deal was perfectly timed at the market's lowest point, laying the foundation for Devon's significant value creation throughout the year.
With this enhanced platform, we implemented our Delaware-focused operating strategy and achieved cost synergies resulting in $600 million in annual cash flow improvements.
These efforts to expand margins, combined with a disciplined capital allocation framework prioritizing value over volume, resulted in Devon generating the highest free cash flow in our esteemed 50-year history.
This substantial free cash flow allowed us to deliver on the primary goal of our shareholder-friendly business model: leading the industry in cash returns.
As illustrated in the graphic, we provided shareholders with substantial dividends, strategic share repurchases, and took significant steps to reinforce our investment-grade balance sheet.
The market rewarded this disciplined execution, with our stock price achieving the highest return of any company in the entire S&P 500 index during 2021.
I'm extremely proud of our achievements and want to express my deepest gratitude to everyone involved.
Our team comprehensively executed our strategy while responsibly providing our nation with a low-cost and reliable energy source, which is vital to our modern economy.
While 2021 was a record-breaking year for Devon, the outlook for 2022 is even more promising.
Building on our operational momentum, we've designed a capital program to efficiently maintain production at a very low WTI breakeven funding level of around $30 per barrel.
Combined with the full benefit of merger-related cost synergies and a significantly improved hedge book, we're positioned to increase free cash flow by more than 70% compared to 2021.
As shown in the graph, this strong outlook translates to a free cash flow yield of 14%, assuming an $85 WTI price.
Clay will provide details of our operating plan later, but in short, we anticipate 2022 to be another excellent year for Devon.
The primary use of our substantial free cash flow is funding our fixed plus variable dividend.
This cash return strategy is central to our capital allocation process, enabling us to return significant and appropriate amounts of cash to shareholders across various market conditions.
With this unique approach, we've increased Devon's dividend payout for five consecutive quarters, and in total, we distributed $1.3 billion in dividends in 2021, representing a per-share increase of about two times that of 2020.
Importantly, we expect our dividend growth to accelerate further in 2022.
As illustrated in the bar chart, we're on track to roughly double our dividend again in the coming year, equating to around 8%.
I'd like to highlight that this attractive yield includes a substantial increase to our fixed dividend announced yesterday.
The 45% increase in the fixed dividend reflects our confidence in our underlying business and financial performance as we enter 2022.
I'd like to briefly demonstrate how our unique dividend policy offers a compelling alternative for yield-seeking investors.
To illustrate this point, we've included a simple comparison of our estimated dividend yield in 2022 to other commonly referenced yields in financial markets.
As shown, Devon's yield of 8% is about six times higher than the S&P 500 index and significantly exceeds the current interest rate on a 10-year treasury.
In addition to our market-leading dividend payout, we're pleased to announce a 60% increase in our share repurchase authorization to $1.6 billion.
Trading at less than five times cash flow, we believe our business is significantly undervalued, especially considering the structural improvements we've made to expand margins and returns.
Given this favorable situation, we've put our money where our mouth is by aggressively repurchasing $589 million of shares in the fourth quarter alone.
With the board expanding our repurchase program's capacity, we will continue to be opportunistic buyers of our stock throughout the upcoming year.
Finally, I believe the diagram effectively summarizes what we've created at Devon.
We've assembled a high-quality asset portfolio and a team that has worked tirelessly to deliver on our commitment to expand margins, generate free cash flow growth, accelerate cash returns with our market-leading dividend payout, enhance per-share growth through opportunistic buybacks, and consistently strengthen our financial position.
While 2021 was a record year, we're just getting started.
At Devon, we have the ideal combination of assets, proven management, the right team, and a shareholder-friendly business model designed to continue leading the energy industry in capital discipline and cash returns.
With that, I'll now hand it over to Clay to provide an overview of our recent operational results and upcoming capital plan.
As Rick mentioned, 2021 was a crucial year for Devon, showcasing the strength of our asset portfolio and the capabilities of our talented organization.
Our team delivered results that surpassed production and capital efficiency targets across the portfolio while continuing to reduce per-unit operating costs and improve margins.
Results are important, and while I don't take any of these accomplishments lightly, I'm equally proud of how we achieved these financial metrics.
Despite the challenges of the merger, pandemic, and supply chain issues, we built a unified culture, adopted best practices from both legacy companies, and are now positioned to further leverage these collective wins.
The first key point is that there is no change to the upstream capital budget of $1.9 to $2.2 billion as disclosed last quarter.
While inflation is undoubtedly a reality, our teams have done an excellent job working with our service companies, mitigating cost increases where possible, and quantifying the remaining impact on our forecast.
A great aspect of a cyclical business is that if you're attentive, you should have a good idea of the most critical areas to focus on in anticipation of the next phase.
At this point in the cycle, we're focused on listening to our service company partners and helping them help us be successful.
In this very tight supply chain market, the key phrase we hear is "predictable and reliable."
You'll notice that our 2022 program closely resembles our 2021 program.
This consistency allows us to signal to our service companies, midstream partners, and other key stakeholders to expect more of the same.
This predictability enables them to organize their supply chain operations, while the dependability assures them that we will fulfill our commitments.
At Devon, we value relationships deeply, and this practice of engaging with and responding to our key partners exemplifies this core principle.
The consistent level of operations in 2022 is expected to maintain our production at a range of 570,000 to 600,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day throughout the year.
Our capital program in 2021 was highly successful, resulting in a 34% production growth rate compared to the first quarter of 2021.
This high-margin growth was achieved through consistent execution and exceptional well productivity, highlighted by several notable projects such as Danger Noodle, Boundary Raider, and Fiscal Cobra.
Each of these successful projects surpassed 30-day rates of over 5,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day on average, demonstrating the world-class reservoir potential in the Delaware Basin.
It's noteworthy that the strong volume performance in 2021 was accompanied by excellent capital efficiency and significant additions to our proven reserves.
While a single year's reserve bookings shouldn't be considered the sole measure of success, consistent and reasonably conservative booking processes can provide insight into the quality of underlying assets.
By the end of the year, our proven reserves in the Delaware increased by 18% on a pro forma basis, with these additions replacing over 200% of our annual production.
It's particularly impressive that our team added these reserves at an extremely low finding and development cost of only $5 per barrel of oil equivalent.
This outcome further demonstrates the advantageous and sustainable nature of our resources in the Delaware Basin.
Looking at the map on the right, you can anticipate similar performance from us in 2022.
We have an excellent lineup of projects to execute, with most of our program focusing on high-impact opportunities in developing Upper Wolfcamp and Bone Spring zones, and to a lesser extent, the Wolfcamp and Avalon targets.
To implement this plan, we anticipate operating 14 rigs and 4 [inaudible] throughout the year.
This capital activity will be spread across our acreage, with prime locations in Southern Lea and Eddy County, and the state line receiving the majority of funding.
This level of activity will not only continue to boost Delaware production in 2022, but the advantages of our operational scale and best practices from the merger integration position us well to further enhance our execution capabilities.
As shown on the slide, the efficiencies gained in the Delaware have essentially doubled the productivity of our rig and frac equipment compared to just a few years ago.
These operational improvements have also significantly reduced our costs over time to approximately $550 per lateral foot in 2021, which is highly competitive in the industry.
Looking ahead to 2022, I anticipate our operational performance will continue to improve.
Our team consistently identifies new ways to leverage technology, operational breakthroughs, and industry best practices.
Inflationary pressure and supply chain disruptions are a reality in the current market.
Based on current industry activity and commodity price projections, we've factored in approximately 15% higher costs compared to 2021.
We have been and continue to focus on consistency, planning, and staying ahead of these issues to react to any unforeseen challenges.
This approach will be even more crucial as the market continues to tighten.
On Slide 17, I want to highlight the momentum we're building in the Anadarko Basin, where we have a concentrated 300,000 net acre position in the liquids-rich window of the play.
Leveraging the benefits of our $100 million Dow joint venture, we drilled over 30 wells in 2021 and initiated production on 16 of those wells during the year.
As illustrated in the charts on the right, the initial capital efficiency is excellent.
Utilizing state-of-the-art completion designs and appropriately spaced developments, per-well capital costs have decreased by 25% compared to legacy activity, and well productivity to date has exceeded type curve expectations by 35%.
Given this strong execution, the returns we're seeing from this activity are competitive with any asset in our portfolio.
Based on this success, we've decided to increase activity in the Anadarko Basin to 3 rigs in 2022.
This program will result in approximately 40 new wells coming online in 2022, allowing us to maintain a steady production profile throughout the year and generate significant free cash flow.
Collectively, these assets generated over a billion dollars of free cash flow in 2021, and we're on track to produce a similar amount in 2022.
They also continue to offer some of the best returns in our portfolio.
The team has continued to identify additional locations and has leveraged company best practices to significantly improve our ESG footprint.
Our Eagle Ford asset continues to deliver solid returns.
The team is doing some exciting work to unlock additional locations and significant refracturing potential.
The Powder River Basin has the most upside yet to be realized.
Our team is making great progress in this regard by extending laterals to three miles and revamping the stimulation design, yielding very promising results.
I'm proud of what these assets are delivering, and I appreciate the team's hard work and effort in fulfilling this important role within our portfolio.
As many of you know, we set ambitious emissions reduction targets last year covering various near, mid, and long-term priorities.
To ensure organizational alignment, we directly linked progress on these targets to our annual compensation program.
We've also dedicated a board committee to engage in our ESG goal-setting process, performance, and reporting.
Since announcing these environmental targets, we've taken immediate action and delivered results.
Although we don't have finalized figures for the past year yet, I can tell you our scope 1 and 2 greenhouse gas emissions will improve by approximately 20% in 2021 compared to our 2019 baseline, well ahead of the goals stated last summer.
Two key successes in reducing overall emissions are decreasing methane emissions and reducing flaring.
In 2020, we reduced methane emissions by 47% and flaring by 33%.
I expect this positive trend to continue.
Examining 22 specifically, numerous visible catalysts will drive significant outcomes, including advancing technologies for improvements and leak detection, enhanced facility designs, retrofitting facilities, widespread implementation of air-powered pneumatic controllers, and electrifying certain field operations.
It's crucial to emphasize that these initiatives aim to enhance both our ESG metrics and overall operational efficiency.
By concentrating on these operational achievements, we further align our organization's focus and enthusiasm towards ESG improvement.
My remarks today will concentrate on the primary factors influencing our 2021 financial performance and provide some perspective on our 2022 outlook.
Our total production volume in the fourth quarter averaged 611,000 barrels of oil equivalent (Boe) per day, surpassing the midpoint of our guidance by 3%.
This production increase was observed across all products, with NGLs showing the most significant outperformance due to exceptionally strong processing and economics during the quarter.
We anticipate production to be approximately 570,000 Boe per day in the upcoming quarter.
We expect this to be our lowest production quarter of the year due to winter weather-related downtime that reduced volumes by about 15,000 Boe per day.
All winter-related curtailments have been resolved, and we don't anticipate any impact on our full-year production estimates.
Regarding expenses, our lease operating GP&T costs exceeded 2021 at a rate of $7.25 per barrel.
This outcome represents a 1% decrease compared to the beginning of the year but was slightly higher than our forecast.
As anticipated, we experienced moderate pricing pressures across several service and supply cost categories in the quarter, and we also incurred a non-recurring charge to GP&T expense in the Eagle Ford.
An additional key variance was increased work-over activity, which contributed to our strong production results in the quarter.
Overall, our exposure to higher-value production, combined with the low-cost structure, expanded Devon's field-level cash margin to $42.37 per barrel, a 14% increase from the previous quarter.
Regarding corporate costs, we made significant improvements in this expense category in 2021.
In total, G&A and financing costs decreased by 31% year-over-year on a pro forma basis due to reduced personnel costs and the company's ongoing debt reduction program.
These structural improvements will continue into 2022 and provide ongoing benefits for years to come.
Looking at the bottom line, Devon's core earnings increased for the sixth consecutive quarter to $1.39 per share.
This earnings momentum translated into an operating cash flow of $1.6 billion in the fourth quarter.
After funding our disciplined maintenance capital program, we generated $1.1 billion of free cash flow in the quarter.
This represents a growth in free cash flow of over 400% compared to the start of the year following the WPX merger.
The primary use of our free cash flow is funding our dividend.
As Rick mentioned earlier, we announced a fixed plus variable dividend of $1 per share, payable in March, which includes a 45% increase to the fixed dividend.
This payout is the highest quarterly distribution in Devon's history.
We're also returning cash to shareholders through our share repurchase program.
Since initiating the program in November, we've made a strong start by repurchasing 14 million shares at a total cost of $589 million.
This equates to an average price of $42 per share, approximately 25% below our current trading levels.
With the board expanding our share repurchase program to $1.6 billion, we now have roughly $1 billion remaining on this authorization, and we plan to continue opportunistically buying back stock in 2022.
We've also returned value to shareholders through our efforts to reduce debt and strengthen the balance sheet.
In 2021, we made substantial progress in improving Devon's financial position by retiring over $1.2 billion of outstanding notes, and we achieved our net debt to EBITDA target ahead of schedule, ending the year with less than a turn of leverage.
At current pricing, we expect our leverage to decrease further in 2022, potentially reaching a zero net debt balance by year-end.
Lastly, I want to highlight that our disciplined strategy is also resulting in excellent returns on capital employed.
We achieved a 20% return on capital employed in 2021, and we are positioned for this measure to increase significantly in 2022.
The rapid improvement we are delivering in ROCE, combined with our cash return framework, further distinguishes Devon from other opportunities in the market today.
To summarize, 2021 was an exceptional year for Devon.
We delivered on all our promises and more.
As we look to the upcoming year, I want to emphasize that our cash return strategy remains unchanged.
We will continue to focus intensely on delivering high returns on capital employed, expanding margins, accelerating free cash flow growth, and returning excess cash to shareholders.
Our talented team at Devon takes great pride in leading the industry with this disciplined operating framework, coupled with the development and deployment of new technologies.
In simple terms, we are enthusiastic and prepared for 2022.
I hope you can now appreciate how we've fulfilled the vision that Dave Hager and I, along with our respective teams, had when we announced our merger in September 2020.
We aimed to create something truly exceptional, and we believe we've accomplished that goal.
We'll now open the call for Q&A.
Please limit yourself to one question and a follow-up.
Operator, we'll take our first question.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Management may discuss certain non-historical items during our conversation.
We might reference non-GAAP financial measures that management uses to assess the business and believes will offer insights into ongoing operations.
We'll present highlights of our fourth-quarter results and current quarter trends.
You've likely heard from most of our industry peers by now.
It's encouraging to see positive movement in our category and industry, despite the current instability.
We'll touch on similar topics as others, such as gradual improvements as dining rooms reopened, off-premise growth, and digital expansion.
The main difference you'll notice is in our performance level.
Our team has managed this pandemic exceptionally well by adhering to our strategy and taking bold steps to expand the business.
Chili's achieved substantial top-line progress throughout the quarter.
We generated positive cash flow for the quarter through our operators' careful margin management, which we used to reduce debt.
Our debt is now lower than it was before the pandemic.
We maintained this momentum into July, with Chili's down only 10.9% by the end's month.
In the 84% of our company-owned restaurants with open dining rooms, we were down just 3.8%, and 36% of our company-owned Chili's locations had positive comparable sales for the month.
These results weren't due to a swift response to the crisis.
They were achieved by remaining committed to the strategy we've been implementing for over two years.
We had already made considerable progress in areas crucial for success in this environment: off-premise, digital, value, and scale.
We didn't need to scramble when the pandemic hit.
We entered it with seven strong quarters of performance.
We simply needed to maintain focus and push a bit harder.
As a result, we led casual dining, ranking first in sales and traffic for three consecutive months according to KNAPP-TRACK, and we're well-positioned for continued success.
You've heard how many restaurant companies are embracing digital to navigate this crisis.
While Chili's is no exception, we've been at the forefront of the digital space long before the pandemic.
We've invested heavily in our digital infrastructure over the past decade, building guest connections and enabling quick responses to changing dining preferences.
Enhancing convenience is a major aspect of how we utilize our digital capabilities.
We can tap into our 8 million member loyalty database, gain detailed purchasing insights from our tabletop devices, and continue enhancing our highly-rated app with features like one-tap reordering of frequently ordered items.
Last year, we integrated DoorDash into our POS system and e-commerce platform, allowing us to shift our marketing focus from national TV ads to our digital platform, where we constantly test and refine to improve e-commerce conversions.
Consequently, our digital sales of off-premise meals have grown from low teens to over 50% in the fourth quarter, with only a slight decrease as dining rooms reopened.
We've increased the frequency of our takeout and delivery services at a much lower marketing cost.
This exemplifies the advantages of a digital approach that enhances convenience for customers.
Our ability to cater to customers wherever they are leads to increased usage of our services.
Here's a unique achievement in our industry that you haven't heard from our competitors.
During the final week of fiscal 2020, we accomplished an unprecedented feat in the restaurant industry.
We simultaneously launched our first virtual brand, It's Just Wings, in 1,050 Chili's and Maggiano's locations nationwide in a single day.
Revenue is growing weekly, and we anticipate exceeding $150 million in the first year, potentially placing It's Just Wings among the top 200 restaurant brands.
The casual dining sector has long been considered oversaturated.
We see this as a chance to demonstrate that it might not be oversaturated, but rather underutilized.
It's Just Wings utilizes existing infrastructure, equipment, and workforce.
Despite competitive pricing, marketing efforts, high-quality ingredients, packaging costs, and delivery partner fees, we're achieving strong profitability.
The brand attracts mostly new customers to Brinker concepts and receives highly positive feedback.
Customer satisfaction ratings are among the highest for restaurants on DoorDash, with high repeat business, and we're only at the beginning.
We developed this business within six months and launched it overnight with minimal investment in a consumer segment experiencing over 100% annual growth.
Given our scale, kitchen capacity, and exclusive partnership with DoorDash, we believe our potential for success in this area is unparalleled.
We're experimenting with additional virtual concepts and learning how to increase visibility among DoorDash users seeking food delivery options, while continuously improving our operations to meet consumer demands for speed, quality, and value.
We're proud to have two brands among the most popular on DoorDash, and we're enthusiastic about future opportunities.
While normalcy hasn't returned for anyone yet, we anticipate a promising future for all Brinker brands.
Last quarter, we committed to prioritizing the safety of our guests and staff while continuing to perform and gain market share, regardless of circumstances.
I'm immensely proud of how our operators and support teams have fulfilled both commitments and how we're creatively and boldly shaping our future together.
Whatever challenges lie ahead, our team's talent, brand strength, and operational scale position us advantageously.
Regardless of how one might describe the recent quarter's operating environment, with several unfavorable terms coming to mind, our operators swiftly adapted to the pandemic's realities and exceeded expectations with their performance.
In the fourth quarter of fiscal year 2020, Brinker reported overall comparable sales decline of 36.7%, though sales improved significantly as the quarter progressed, with June's consolidated results down 19%.
Both brands showed progressive improvement throughout the quarter, with Chili's leading the casual dining sector in comparable sales.
While Chili's quarterly comparable sales declined by 32.2%, performance improved from a 51% drop in April during peak dining room closures to only a 13% decline in June.
Chili's outperformed competitors throughout the quarter, with comparable sales approximately 13% above the casual dining sector and traffic about 18% higher.
Over 25% of our corporate Chili's locations reported positive comparable sales for June, a percentage that increased to 36% in July, as Wyman mentioned earlier.
The quarterly financial highlights included total revenues of $563 million, a restaurant operating margin of 6.4%, and an adjusted loss per diluted share of $0.88.
The $0.88 loss includes an additional $0.18 burden due to the timing of recording expenses for annual and long-term incentive compensation plans in G&A expenses, which is atypical for the fourth quarter.
During this crisis, our team has excellently cared for guests and employees while effectively managing expenses despite significant sales decreases.
Our managers have efficiently used scheduling tools to optimize labor hours in the current business climate.
Hourly labor and payroll tax showed favorable year-over-year variability, but total labor, including restaurant management, was unfavorable by 260 basis points due to sales deleverage.
The restaurant expense margin increased by 6.2% in the quarter, primarily due to sales deleverage.
Despite reducing year-over-year spending by over $29 million, we achieved significant savings in advertising, repair and maintenance, and supplies related to on-premise dining, some of which we expect to continue.
Cost of sales improved by 30 basis points compared to the previous year, mainly due to favorable menu mix.
As mentioned earlier, our restaurant operating margin for the quarter was 6.4%.
However, our operating margin improved throughout the quarter, reaching 12.2% for the June period, in line with our progress in top-line performance.
We anticipate further margin improvement as we maintain identified efficiencies, increase dining room capacity, and leverage sales from our virtual brand, It's Just Wings, assuming an improving operating environment.
Strengthening the balance sheet is a crucial part of our financial strategy, and we are currently directing free cash flow towards debt reduction and liquidity enhancement.
To boost our liquidity, we conducted an equity offering in the quarter, raising about $139 million, which was used to pay down revolving credit debt.
Our total debt balance at the fiscal year-end was approximately $1.2 billion, a reduction of over $220 million from the end of the third quarter, with revolving credit borrowings decreasing from $700 million to less than $473 million.
Our liquidity, comprising cash balances and revolving credit availability, now exceeds $575 million.
We recently extended our revolving credit facility by 15 months, now maturing in December 2022.
As sales and cash flows improved, we resumed new restaurant development activities that were temporarily suspended early in the quarter.
We intend to open or relocate four new Chili's restaurants during the current quarter.
Regarding operating guidance, due to potential volatility and uncertainties in the current operating environment, we are providing limited guidance for Brinker's consolidated performance for the current first quarter instead of our typical annual guidance.
For Brinker in the first quarter, we expect consolidated comparable store sales to decrease in the low to mid-teens range.
We estimate adjusted earnings per diluted share to be a loss between $0.25 and $0.40.
We anticipate positive operating cash flow, with weighted average shares estimated at 45 million to 46 million.
It's worth noting that fiscal year 2021 includes a 53rd week, which occurs during the fourth quarter.
Despite pandemic-related challenges, our team has risen to the occasion.
Our strategy focusing on value, convenience, and safety has been well-received by guests, allowing us to outperform competitors and positioning us favorably to continue gaining market share throughout the fiscal year.
