I deeply appreciate the hard work and dedication of our team members, especially those serving guests on the front lines every day.
I am confident we will continue to demonstrate our ability to maintain progress and achieve long-term growth in both revenue and profitability.
Summary:
output:
chili's total comparable restaurant sales decreased 10.9% in fiscal 2021 q1-to-date.
sees q1 adjusted net loss per diluted share to be in range of $0.40 to $0.25.
comparable restaurant sales are expected to be down low to mid-teens in q1.
operating cash flow is expected to be positive in q1.
brinker international - during q1 of fiscal 2021 chili's and maggiano's continue to operate with reduced dining room capacities.
qtrly adjusted loss per share $0.88.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:I'm Patrick Burke, and I oversee investor relations for the company.
Present today for the Q&A session are Artie Starrs (Topgolf CEO), William Davenport (Topgolf CFO), and Jennifer Thomas (Callaway's chief accounting officer).
GAAP.
The second quarter results were exceptional, and I'm immensely proud of our global team's efforts in building this business into the powerhouse it is today.
Throughout today's call, you'll hear about the strong momentum across all our business segments and our outstanding operational performance despite challenging circumstances.
Our quarterly revenue surged 208% to $914 million, while the first half of 2021 saw a 112% increase to roughly $1.6 billion, both setting new records for our company.
We achieved record profitability, with adjusted EBITDA reaching $164 million for the quarter and $292 million for the first six months of the year.
Despite ongoing COVID-related challenges, we remain confident in the long-term strategic position and impressive growth potential of this unique business.
Before delving into specific areas of our business, I'd like to commend our tour team for their outstanding performance this year.
We extend our congratulations to Phil and John for their victories at the PGA Championship and U.S. Open earlier this season, to Xander for his gold medal win in Tokyo, and to Annika for her commanding victory at the U.S. Senior Women's Open.
Callaway Golf's tour staff has had an remarkable summer.
It's thrilling to see our players representing Callaway and our other brands, including TravisMathew and Topgolf, on golf's biggest stages.
From a business standpoint, I'm certain this exposure is beneficial for our brands and will contribute to long-term shareholder value.
Let's start by examining our golf equipment business.
The demand for clubs and balls remains robust as the sport continues to attract new players, driving unprecedented growth in package sets, junior clubs, and women's clubs, while core golfers are playing more frequently and showing strong enthusiasm for the game.
Golf Datatech reports that rounds played in June remained at an all-time high, and retail demand continues to be elevated.
Datatech's Q2 hardgoods sell-through increased by an impressive 40% compared to 2019, and retail inventory levels remain extremely low, with only 2.2 months on hand at the end of June as the industry supply chain struggled to keep up with the past 12 months of unprecedented demand.
With more activity options available this spring and summer compared to last year, we were cautious about a potential decline in golf participation or demand.
However, we're pleased to report that we haven't observed this trend from our perspective in the market.
We're also monitoring supply chain disruptions caused by the resurgence of the coronavirus Delta variant.
While the resurgence hasn't affected demand yet, it has caused further supply disruptions in factories based in and around Southeast Asia, primarily Vietnam.
The safety of workers in these regions is our top priority, and we're collaborating with suppliers to ensure operating conditions are and remain as safe as possible.
We've become accustomed to adapting to these circumstances over the past 18 months and can shift some production to less-affected factories.
However, given the current lean inventories, the fact that nearly all our factories are operating at full capacity, and the need to shift production to next year's launches soon, these shutdowns will have an estimated $55 million negative impact on second-half revenues, primarily in our golf equipment segment and mainly in Q3.
While disappointing, I view this disruption as a short-term issue that won't have a long-term impact on our value or strategy.
On a positive note, and I recognize this is an optimistic view, we now believe field inventory levels will almost certainly remain lower than expected throughout this year, which is generally a healthy market dynamic that bodes well for 2022.
Overall, we're very satisfied with the strength of this category and our position in it.
We anticipate delivering record performance for our golf equipment segment this year, and perhaps most importantly, we continue to believe the outlook for the golf equipment category is highly positive, with both a larger total market and a higher embedded growth rate.
Now let's discuss our apparel and soft goods segment.
The business had another strong quarter, surpassing our expectations as retail locations reopened worldwide and our brands remained top of mind for consumers.
This business significantly outperformed during the quarter and continues to see remarkable growth as we enter the second half of the year.
To provide context, in the second quarter, we saw more than 30% comp store growth in our own retail stores compared to 2019, the last period unaffected by COVID, as well as strong growth in sell-through at wholesale accounts and e-commerce.
An interesting fact is that we're not only seeing brand momentum among our target male audience buying for themselves, but approximately 30% of the direct-to-consumer sales we track are women buying for men.
While I'm no expert, I believe it's a very good sign when women are choosing the brand for their partners.
Jack Wolfskin also performed well this quarter.
The business has faced additional challenges due to longer COVID shutdowns in Europe compared to the U.S., but the team has managed the issues brilliantly and is on track for a strong year.
As our owned stores in Europe reopened during the quarter, retail activity picked up significantly, almost reaching 2019 revenue levels.
Most importantly, we experienced strong sell-through of the spring/summer 2021 line and strong pre-bookings for the spring/summer 2022 line, two crucial indicators of the brand's health.
Our stores in China also continued to perform well as the brand maintains strong awareness and positioning within the outdoor apparel market there.
The Jack Wolfskin team has done an excellent job revitalizing this business and positioning us for strong top and bottom-line growth as COVID restrictions ease in the brand's key markets of Europe and China and as the brand grows and strengthens its appeal.
Lastly, our Callaway-branded soft goods business also showed strength, particularly in Japan, as the sport's popularity drove consumer spending.
Additionally, toward the end of the quarter, we reclaimed the Korea apparel business, which had been licensed to a third party for several years.
Although that business is just starting up, we're very excited about the long-term opportunity it will provide to our soft goods segment, and the team did an excellent job managing this transition given the COVID travel restrictions and challenges.
With high demand levels across this business segment, we expect to enter 2022 with low retail inventory across all of our soft goods brands.
In summary, we are fortunate to be in excellent categories and are on track to deliver a strong 2021 in this segment as well as future growth.
Now let's discuss Topgolf.
Q2 marked the first full quarter of Callaway results with Topgolf included in our numbers, and they exceeded our expectations.
While COVID concerns remain a challenging variable for venue operations, the team delivered outstanding numbers even as other options became available to consumers.
We continue to be energized by the momentum this business has brought to both Callaway's portfolio and to the game of golf.
Same venue sales percentage compared to 2019 levels continued an encouraging trend of recovery, with Q2 results in the low 90s, up substantially from the low 80s in Q1 of this year.
Results were driven by a combination of strong walk-in sales and continued recovery in the event business.
Looking ahead, assuming no major restrictions from COVID upticks, we anticipate same venue sales for Q3 will surpass Q2 results, while we expect Q4 sales to be slightly lower than Q2 due to the corporate events mix in that quarter, with the full year ending at approximately 90%.
To provide context, this is considerably above our expectations for the year and, we believe, a strong performance.
Domestic venue expansion continued as planned during the quarter, with four new venues opening.
Another venue, Holtsville, Long Island, opened recently, and Colorado Springs will open later this week.
We then expect to open one more venue in Q4 for a total of nine new domestic venues this year.
By the end of the year, we will have 70 owned venues in operation, including 67 domestic locations across three owned UPA venues.
Our international business saw strong performance, with UK venues reopening successfully after Q1 COVID closures and our franchise venues building momentum despite ongoing pandemic challenges.
The overall venue business is performing exceptionally well, with profits surpassing our projections.
Toptracer had an outstanding quarter, installing over 2,000 bays and setting a new record as demand remains high and customer feedback is positive.
Despite some COVID-related installation hurdles, we anticipate meeting or exceeding our goal of 8,000 new bays this year.
A notable achievement this quarter was the installation of Toptracer at Golf Club Daiju near Nagoya, Japan, believed to be the world's largest driving range.
Topgolf continues to serve as an entry point for new golfers, and we see great potential in marketing to these newcomers and creating synergies across our growing customer base both on and off the course.
I remain optimistic about our future prospects as we move into the second half of the year and beyond.
We operate in thriving sectors with a diverse portfolio of businesses that are all surpassing our expectations.
While we face macroeconomic challenges like supply chain issues, increased freight costs, staffing difficulties, and inflation, we view these as manageable given current and anticipated demand levels, and we expect to deliver strong financial results.
We estimate a $55 million negative impact on our top-line growth, primarily in Q3, due to current supply chain disruptions.
To address inflation, we have begun implementing price increases and believe we can adjust prices as needed.
Given the various factors at play for the rest of the year, we are providing guidance for both the third quarter and full year.
Brian will provide more detailed figures, but the key takeaway is that we expect our full-year 2021 sales to exceed 2019 by over $1.3 billion, with adjusted EBITDA between $134 million and $149 million higher than 2019.
Our 2021 EBITDA will be very close to our 2022 projection from last fall's long-term guidance, putting us roughly a year ahead of schedule.
As Chip mentioned, we are very pleased with our second quarter and first-half performance.
All of our operating segments exceeded expectations, leading to record results despite a challenging business environment.
The pandemic continues to present some short-term challenges, including supply chain constraints, higher freight costs, staffing issues, and inflationary pressures.
However, we believe current demand levels and our ability to take action will mitigate these factors' impact, and we anticipate strong financial results for the year and foreseeable future.
We are excited about the opportunities ahead and feel well-positioned to navigate an extended pandemic.
Our operating segments cater to outdoor, active, and healthy lifestyles that align with social distancing requirements, and we maintain a strong liquidity position.
As of June 30, 2021, our available liquidity, comprising cash on hand and credit facility availability, was $877 million, up from $483 million on June 30, 2020.
When assessing our second quarter and first half results, consider the following: Our non-GAAP results exclude various non-cash expenses and one-time items related to acquisitions, impairments, and tax adjustments.
We have provided reconciliation tables detailing these items' impact on Q2 and H1 GAAP results.
Remember that our first-half financials include Topgolf for only four months, as the merger was completed on March 8, 2021.
Examining Slides 10 and 11, our Q2 2021 revenues set another company record, following a record-breaking Q1.
Q2 2021 revenues benefited from the Topgolf merger, while Q2 2020 revenues were significantly impacted by pandemic-related business closures.
In Q2 2021, sales increased across all product segments and major regions compared to both 2020 and 2019.
Consolidated Q2 2021 revenues were $914 million, a $617 million or 208% increase from $297 million in Q2 2020.
This growth was driven by a 98% increase in golf equipment and soft goods businesses, plus $325 million from Topgolf.
Favorable foreign currency rates contributed $18 million to Q2 2021 revenues.
Compared to Q2 2019, consolidated Q2 2021 revenues increased by $467 million or 105%, including a 37% increase in golf equipment and 21% increase in soft goods.
First-half 2021 consolidated revenue rose $826 million or 112% compared to 2020 and $602 million or 63% compared to 2019.
Total costs and expenses in Q2 2021 were $806 million, up from $474 million in Q2 2020.
On a non-GAAP basis, excluding items like the $174 million non-cash impairment charge in Q2 2020, total costs and expenses increased by $503 million to $796 million in Q2 2021, compared to $293 million in Q2 2020.
Topgolf added $301 million in total costs and expenses.
The remainder includes increased variable expenses, restored pandemic-reduced expenses, planned investments, increased corporate costs for a larger organization, and higher freight and inflationary pressures.
So far, the company's strong performance has generally outpaced cost increases.
Q2 2021 operating income was $107 million, a $285 million increase from a $177 million loss in Q2 2020.
On a non-GAAP basis, excluding the 2020 impairment charge, Q2 2021 operating income was $118 million, a $114 million increase from $4 million in Q2 2020.
This growth was led by a $96 million increase in golf equipment and soft goods segment operating income, plus $24 million from Topgolf.
First-half 2021 non-GAAP operating income increased by $167 million to $215 million, compared to $47 million in the first half of 2020.
Other expense in Q2 2021 was $31 million, compared to $2 million of other income in Q2 2020.
On a non-GAAP basis, other expense was $27 million in Q2 2021, compared to $3 million of other income in Q2 2020.
The $30 million decrease was primarily due to $14 million higher interest expense from Topgolf in Q2 2021 and an $11 million gain from settling a cross-currency swap in Q2 2020.
First-half 2021 non-GAAP other expense, excluding items like the $253 million non-cash gain from the Topgolf investment write-up, was $33 million, compared to $1 million of income in the first half of 2020.
Q2 2021 earnings per share were $0.47 on approximately 194 million shares, compared to a $1.78 loss per share on about 94 million shares in Q2 2020.
Non-GAAP earnings per share were $0.36 in Q2 2021, up from $0.06 in Q2 2020.
Q2 2021 non-GAAP fully diluted shares were 194 million, compared to 95 million in Q2 2020, primarily due to additional shares issued for the Topgolf merger.
Full-year estimated diluted shares are approximately 178 million, including the weighted average of merger-related shares over about 10 months.
As of June 2021, we had approximately 186 million shares issued and outstanding.
Q2 2021 adjusted EBITDA was $164 million, compared to $29 million in Q2 2020 and $66 million in Q2 2019.
Adjusted EBITDA from Topgolf was $57 million.
In the initial six months of 2021, adjusted EBITDA reached $292 million, compared to $89 million in the same period of 2020 and $159 million in 2019.
Topgolf contributed $17 million in adjusted EBITDA over four months.
Let's move to Slide 12.
I will now discuss some important balance sheet and other financial items.
Accessible liquidity, comprising credit facility availability and cash reserves, stood at $877 million as of June 30, 2021, up from $483 million at the end of Q2 2020.
This liquidity increase reflects strong performance across all business segments and improved working capital liquidity.
Total net debt was $1.1 billion as of June 30, 2021, including $652 million related to Topgolf.
The Topgolf debt includes $263 million in deemed landlord financing for venue operations.
Our leverage ratios have significantly improved, with funded debt now below three times.
Consolidated net accounts receivable grew 52% to $325 million, compared to $214 million at the end of Q2 2020.
Days sales outstanding for the legacy business decreased to 58 days on June 30, 2021, down from 79 days a year earlier.
The rise in net accounts receivable mainly stems from increased Q2 revenue and includes an additional $9 million from Topgolf.
We remain confident in the quality of our accounts receivable.
Our inventory balance decreased 12% to $335 million at the end of Q2 2021, compared to $379 million the previous year.
This $44 million reduction was due to high demand in golf equipment and better-than-expected performance in soft goods.
Topgolf contributed approximately $14 million to inventory this quarter.
Capital expenditures for the first half of 2021 totaled $96 million, net of expected REIT reimbursements, including $66 million related to Topgolf.
The full-year 2021 forecast for golf equipment and soft goods remains at $65 million.
The combined 2021 forecast for Callaway and Topgolf is approximately $243 million, net of reimbursements, mainly for new venue openings.
This excludes about $33 million in Topgolf capital expenditures from January and February before the merger.
Q2 2021 depreciation and amortization expense was $43 million.
Non-GAAP depreciation and amortization expense for Q2 2021 was $36 million, up from $8 million in 2020, including $27 million related to Topgolf.
We anticipate full-year 2021 non-GAAP depreciation and amortization expense of about $133 million, with $95 million for Topgolf.
This excludes roughly $18 million of Topgolf non-GAAP depreciation and amortization for January and February combined.
Moving to Slide 13.
We are providing revenue and adjusted EBITDA guidance for Q3 and full-year 2021, including 10 months of post-merger Topgolf results.
Full-year revenue is expected to range from $3.025 billion to $3.055 billion, compared to $1.590 billion in 2020 and $1.701 billion in 2019.
This forecast assumes continued strong demand for golf equipment and soft goods, no further COVID-related disruptions, and Topgolf's 10-month segment sales approaching 2019's full-year level of $1.06 billion.
The outlook factors in $55 million of supply chain risk due to Southeast Asian COVID shutdowns, mostly affecting Q3 2021.
Full-year 2021 non-GAAP operating expenses for golf equipment and soft goods are estimated to be about $100 million higher than 2019, $20-30 million more than previously guided.
This increase relates to variable costs tied to strong performance, accelerated investments in TravisMathew, and additional corporate infrastructure costs.
Approximately 85% of the extra $100 million in expenses is expected in H2 2021, partly due to the Callaway apparel business takeover in Korea and normalized spending to support all businesses.
We anticipate continued cost pressures from increased freight and inflationary pressures through H1 2022.
Full-year adjusted EBITDA is projected between $345 million and $360 million, assuming Topgolf contributes over $100 million for the 10 months post-merger.
For Q3, we expect revenue between $775 million and $790 million, compared to $476 million in 2020 and $426 million in 2019.
Q3 2021 adjusted EBITDA is forecast between $51 million and $58 million, versus $87 million in 2020 and $57 million in 2019.
This growth reflects Topgolf revenue addition and soft goods segment growth.
Q3 golf equipment revenue is expected to be below 2020 levels but above 2019 due to supply constraints and extraordinary 2020 H2 performance.
These Q3 supply constraints are not expected to significantly affect Q4 2021 or 2022.
In conclusion, while short-term COVID-related headwinds are frustrating, they won't impact our long-term value or strategy.
We're having an exceptional year, meeting financial goals ahead of schedule despite challenges.
All segments are performing well, the Topgolf merger has been highly successful, and we're well-positioned for the future in both COVID and post-COVID environments.
We remain excited about our growth prospects and opportunities ahead.
Summary:
output:
q2 2021 consolidated net revenue increased $617 million (+208%) to $914 million.
qtrly earnings per share $0.47.
qtrly adjusted earnings per share $0.36.
sees q3 net revenue $775 million - $790 million.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Today, I'm accompanied by Lal Karsanbhai, our President and CEO; Frank Dellaquila, our CFO; and Ram Krishnan, our COO.
Colleen, who comes from Automation Solutions finance, will be your primary contact moving forward as I shift to a new position in the operating business units.
I sincerely wish you good health and success in your endeavors.
Let's move on to the second slide.
I definitely have a tough act to follow.
As Pete noted, I'm transitioning from my role in Automation Solutions finance, where I've worked at Emerson for over 13 years.
I'm both thrilled and honored to join the Investor Relations team during this transformative period for our company.
I'm eager to connect with all our investors and partners in the near future.
I'd like to take a moment to highlight two significant ESG initiatives at Emerson.
On slide three, in line with our environmental sustainability framework of greening of, by and with Emerson introduced in February, we'll first discuss greening by Emerson.
This exemplifies how Emerson's solutions are crucial in supporting our customers' sustainability efforts.
Emerson recently entered a multi-year agreement with PureCycle Technologies, which has developed an innovative process for fully recycling plastic number five polypropylene into clear pellets.
For those unaware, polypropylene is a common plastic that has lacked effective recycling options until now.
Emerson will serve as their digital automation partner for upcoming plant projects in Ohio, Georgia, and a remote operation center in Florida.
Let's move to slide number four.
Our second topic demonstrates greening with Emerson.
Using our Helix Innovation Center in Dayton, Ohio, Emerson has partnered with the Department of Energy and Oak Ridge National Laboratory to develop next-generation HVACR technology.
Some key areas of collaboration include expanding heat pump applications, redesigning refrigeration systems for maximum efficiency in food retail, and minimizing energy consumption and leaks in commercial HVAC systems.
We have numerous ongoing collaborations with the Department of Energy and their laboratories.
We're committed to strengthening these partnerships and supporting the creation of innovative solutions and practical sustainability strategies in the future.
Best wishes and good fortune in your new role.
We're delighted to have you on board.
Colleen and I worked together in Automation Solutions for a couple of years, and we're fortunate to have her join our Investor Relations team.
We have considerable momentum and enthusiasm, which was evident in our performance over the past three months.
I've had the chance to meet many of you over the last six months and look forward to connecting with more of you in the coming months.
I appreciate your continued trust, your constructive feedback, and of course, your investment.
I'd like to mention a few non-financial updates to the team.
Firstly, we're making progress on our cultural initiatives.
We'll be announcing our new Chief People Officer later this month.
We're excited about the selection process.
It will be an external hire who will play a crucial role in helping us navigate challenges and create pathways as we evolve Emerson's culture for the future.
Secondly, we've completed our portfolio review.
We're preparing to present it to the Board at the October meeting.
We briefly discussed it with the Board yesterday.
In essence, we've identified multiple strategies to drive higher underlying sales growth and diversify our portfolio.
We're all enthusiastic about the thorough process we undertook.
We explored many options, identifying broad markets with high growth potential and numerous opportunities for M&A and organic growth.
Regarding M&A, industrial software remains crucial as we consider market share, potential for accelerating underlying growth, and various growth avenues.
Our SI acquisition is performing exceptionally well, surpassing our internal synergy targets.
However, what impresses me most is the team's execution.
While market tailwinds played a role, particularly in Automation Solutions and across our Commercial & Residential businesses, the execution was truly outstanding.
The team overcame numerous challenges during the quarter, including material inflation, supply issues, logistics complications, and labor shortages in the US.
Despite these operational hurdles, we're seeing the value of this work reflected in the company's incremental profits.
The strong operating profit leverage of 34% has created room to accelerate investment in differentiating technologies, which will further increase our relevance to our customer base.
We've already begun these investments, and I'll share more details about them as we progress through the year.
We're particularly pleased with the quarterly results, especially considering the operational challenges Lal described and Ram will discuss later in the call.
Please turn to slide six.
The ongoing recovery in our end markets, combined with the benefits of our cost reset actions, led to strong operational performance and financial results in the third quarter.
Adjusted earnings per share reached $1.09, a 36% increase from last year.
Demand continues to strengthen, with sales exceeding our expectations, showing 15% underlying growth, and June trailing 3-month orders at 26%.
Notably, Automation Solutions turned positive this quarter in both sales and orders, with 9% sales growth and 17% underlying order growth.
Commercial & Residential Solutions continues to experience robust demand across all businesses and regions, with 29% sales growth and 43% order growth on an underlying basis.
We continue to realize the benefits of our cost reset initiatives as planned, which, along with increased volume and leverage, drove adjusted segment EBIT growth of 40% and a 280 basis point increase in margin to 19.6%.
Cash flow remains very strong, with operating and free cash flow up approximately 30% year-over-year and free cash flow conversion exceeding 150% of net earnings.
We're continuing to implement the remaining elements of the cost reset program.
This quarter, we initiated $32 million in restructuring actions.
The program is on schedule and delivering the projected savings as planned.
This chart bridges the earnings per share increase from the previous year.
Operational performance was very strong, as evidenced by the green bar.
Operations contributed 33% to adjusted EPS, with balanced performance between the platforms.
Both divisions achieved substantial profit leverage due to increased volume and cost reduction benefits, as mentioned by Lal.
The enterprise-wide leverage was 34%.
Factors such as taxes, currency fluctuations, pension costs, and stock compensation resulted in a $0.05 negative impact, while share repurchases had a small positive effect.
Overall, adjusted earnings per share grew by 36% to $1.09.
Please refer to Chart 8 for the next section.
As previously stated, underlying sales increased by 15%.
Gross profit rose by 90 basis points to 42.4%, primarily due to cost reduction measures and volume leverage across the company.
We managed to offset the impact of price/cost pressures, which are intensifying and will be more evident in the coming quarters, as we'll discuss later in this call.
The adjusted EBIT margin improved by 310 basis points to 18.4%.
The effective tax rate was 19.2% compared to 11% in the previous year.
Last year, we benefited from several favorable discrete items, mainly related to R&D credits, which we explained at the time.
This resulted in a $0.10 year-over-year headwind that we were able to overcome.
As mentioned earlier, adjusted EPS reached $1.09, up from $0.80 last year.
Let's move to slide nine to discuss earnings and cash flow.
Adjusted segment EBIT grew by 40%, with margins improving by 280 basis points.
Volume leverage and cost reset benefits offset material cost headwinds in the Climate Technologies division.
Adjusted pre-tax earnings increased by 350 basis points to 17.6%.
Operating cash flow was robust, rising 31% to $1.1 billion.
Free cash flow reached $977 million, also up by over 30%, driven by strong earnings growth and effective working capital management.
Finally, the trade working capital ratio improved to 15.4% of sales.
Now, let's examine Automation Solutions on slide 10.
Underlying sales turned positive this quarter, growing by 8%.
Trailing 3-month orders accelerated to 17%.
The improvement in the Americas is particularly encouraging, with continued momentum in life sciences, food and beverage, and medical markets, as well as renewed growth across traditional process automation markets and sustainability-related business.
We're observing increased KOB three activity among our process automation customers, primarily driven by shutdown turnaround and outage activity and operational expenditure.
MRO spending is returning to pre-pandemic levels due to pent-up demand and delayed STOs.
Capital expenditure is recovering at a slower pace, with positive influences from site-based emissions and optimization projects.
The platform continues to implement comprehensive restructuring actions, and the benefits are reflected in the financial results.
Adjusted EBIT margin increased by 320 basis points, and adjusted EBITDA improved by 310 basis points, mainly due to cost reset savings and volume leverage.
The integration of OSI is progressing exceptionally well.
We're very satisfied with the acquisition and its results so far, and we have growing confidence in our synergy plan.
Backlog increased to $5.5 billion, up 17% year-to-date.
We'll discuss the project pipeline and other opportunities later in the call.
Let's review Commercial & Residential Solutions on slide 11.
Underlying sales grew by 29% compared to the previous year.
Orders continue to be strong and broadly based.
The June trailing 3-month underlying orders were up 43%, with balanced growth across both Climate Technologies and Tools & Home products.
All our businesses and regions experienced strong double-digit growth.
Residential markets remain robust, and growth has accelerated in Cold Chain and Professional Tools.
The Americas saw a 29% increase, with continued strength across all end markets.
Europe grew by 37%, driven by ongoing heat pump demand and rising sales of professional tools.
Asia, Middle East, and Africa increased by 25%, propelled by Cold Chain and various heating technologies.
Margins improved by 170 basis points for adjusted EBIT and 120 basis points for adjusted EBITDA, driven by strong volume leverage and cost reset savings, which more than offset the price/cost headwinds in the business.
I'll now hand over to Ram, who will discuss operations, our quarterly performance, and some of the challenges we face.
Our operating environment remains challenging due to commodity inflation, electronic supply issues, and labor availability affecting our global operations.
Steel prices have reached record highs after 11 consecutive months of increases and, in our estimation, have not yet peaked.
Plastic resin prices remain high as our global teams work quickly to find alternatives to maintain supply.
Although copper prices have decreased from record highs, they are still up over $1.40 per pound year-over-year.
Our hedge positions mitigated the impact in 2021, but the inflationary effect of copper will continue into most of 2022.
Electronics shortages are widespread in most of our businesses, impacting both platforms, and supply is expected to remain constrained well into 2022.
There is very little component inventory for microprocessors, controllers, and linear integrated circuits in the open market, and our EMS suppliers are facing an increasing number of shortages, severely impacting lead times.
Labor availability continues to be a challenge across many U.S. industries, including our businesses.
The rapid demand recovery in many of our Commercial & Residential Solutions businesses, local competition driven by tight labor markets in many cities, and intermittent labor constraints due to COVID-19 disruptions have added complexity to our operational plans.
It's important to note that the unfavorable price/cost impact remains at $75 million, as estimated last quarter.
This hasn't changed, but we expect the maximum impact of commodity inflation to be felt in the next two quarters.
Despite these challenges, I'd like to highlight some of the outstanding work by our global supply chain and operations teams on slide 13.
They have combated these challenges and helped deliver exceptional operational results to date by remaining flexible, creative, and agile in a dynamic environment to meet our customers' needs.
Our supply chain teams have worked tirelessly to ensure continuity of material supply to our global plants.
As shown in the chart, many innovative solutions are being implemented quickly and effectively in real-time.
Our regional footprint in both manufacturing and supply chain, which we've developed over many years, has been a significant advantage during these challenging times.
Many of our global plants are producing at record levels while increasing capacity to meet surge demand and, in many cases, in-sourcing critical elements of the supply chain to address sudden disruptions.
Now, let's turn to slide 15 for our updated outlook for the year.
We are improving our sales forecast based on the continued strength in orders, business pace, and year-to-date profit performance.
We now expect underlying sales growth to be near the top of our May guidance of approximately 5% to 6%.
Commercial Residential is projected to exceed their May range at 15% to 16%, while Automation Solutions is expected to be closer to the top of its range at 0% to 1%.
The strong volume and improved cost base will translate into better margins.
Our estimates are now 50 basis points above the previous guidance, increasing adjusted EBIT margin and adjusted EBITDA by 0.5% to approximately 18% and 23%, respectively.
There are no changes to restructuring, tax rate, capital expenditure, or dividend projections.
Robust profitability and working capital performance led to a $300 million increase in both our operating cash flow and free cash flow projections.
We are elevating our adjusted earnings per share guidance to $4.07, give or take $0.01.
Our estimated price/cost headwind of $75 million for 2021 remains unchanged from Q2 despite current challenges.
We are addressing this through containment and targeted price adjustments, but upcoming market developments will pose challenges in the next two quarters.
The impact of stock compensation is now projected to be $125 million.
Let's examine Chart 16 to review the order trends over the past three months.
Emerson's three-month order rates remain robust, with Commercial & Residential Solutions continuing to improve and Automation Solutions showing significant positive growth in June.
Commercial & Residential Solutions continues to exhibit strength in Residential, Cold Chain, and Professional Tools sectors, all approaching the 43% average.
Automation Solutions sees ongoing strength in discrete and hybrid markets, with recovery in process automation, particularly in North America.
KOB three and two are leading the recovery, with some KOB one activity emerging in chemicals, power, and biofuels.
The Americas region showed significant improvement, up 29%, driven by deferred maintenance demand and increased site access.
The life sciences sector continues to demonstrate exceptional momentum.
Now, let's review Chart 17 for the underlying sales growth outlook.
Q3 underlying sales increased by 15% year-over-year, surpassing management expectations due to strong performance in Commercial & Residential Solutions and North American recovery.
We project full-year underlying sales growth between 5% and 6%, at the upper end of our previous 3% to 6% guidance, with total sales of about $18.4 billion.
We anticipate fourth-quarter growth in the high single to low double-digit range.
For the remainder of the year, we expect continued recovery in North American Automation Solutions and broad strength in Commercial & Residential Solutions, though supply chain and labor issues will present challenges.
For the full year, we project Automation Solutions sales to be flat to 1% growth, and Commercial & Residential Solutions to grow between 15% and 16%, resulting in our overall 5% to 6% underlying sales growth expectation.
In the Americas, we anticipate strong Q4 growth of about 20% in Automation Solutions, with broad-based recovery across industries, led by discrete and hybrid sectors.
Process automation shows uneven recovery, with domestic oil demand strength offset by reduced midstream investment and continued upstream fiscal restraint.
We expect increased KOB 3 spending for deferred maintenance and site access, with a strong fall shutdown and turnaround season anticipated.
Latin America should see continued strength in mining industries.
In Commercial & Residential, we expect ongoing momentum in residential markets, driven by DIY trends, home starts, and HVAC seasonality, as well as strength in Professional Tools and Cold Chain.
Europe will see continued demand in life sciences and biofuels for automation, with project wins in power, midstream, downstream, and sustainability driving low to mid-single-digit Q4 growth.
Commercial & Residential will experience robust demand for heat pumps and professional tools, along with continued refrigeration market recovery.
In Asia, Middle East, and Africa, automation business is seeing healthy project activity in marine, nuclear, life sciences, and semiconductors, with positive site-level spending trends in the Middle East.
Commercial & Residential is experiencing commercial recovery across the region, particularly in commercial AC and cold chain solutions.
Ongoing COVID restrictions remain a challenge, especially in this region.
Let's review Chart 19 for the Automation Solutions business funnel.
Our traditional large project funnel, valued at $6.4 billion in February, has seen approximately $80 million in bookings, including LNG and a notable project in Mexico.
New projects added include clean fuels, hydrogen, renewable diesels, lithium mining, and LNG, while removed projects were mostly oil and gas and downstream refining.
The August 2021 funnel is now valued at $6.3 billion across about 180 projects.
We've identified new decarbonization opportunities worth $400 million across approximately 120 projects, bringing the combined funnel value to $6.7 billion.
The OSI acquisition has introduced opportunities in transmission and distribution automation, valued at $1.5 billion across 530 projects.
About 15% of this $1.5 billion is valued at over $5 million, and 50% is between $1 million and $5 million.
The funnel is global, with approximately $1 billion in North America and Europe.
Overall, we have strong opportunities ahead as we diversify and expand into new areas.
Chart 20 highlights our robust cost reset plan, which began in late 2019 and will be fully realized by 2023.
The plan involves over $600 million in spend and approximately $650 million in savings.
We're on track to reach our midrange targets of 24% adjusted EBITDA margins and $4.75 to $5 in adjusted EPS by 2023.
Recent outperformance is creating room for critical investments in key technologies.
Revenues, margins, and cash flow are exceeding February expectations, enabling acceleration in technology investments.
Examples include the Copeland K7 scroll for air conditioning, Greenlee remote cutters for underground cable cutting, the Gemini next-generation pressure and temperature device, and Plantweb Optics, an integrated operational performance platform.
Summary:
output:
compname reports q3 adjusted earnings per share of $1.09.
q3 adjusted earnings per share $1.09.
qtrly net sales were $4.7 billion up 20 percent from year prior.
sees 2021 net sales growth 9% - 10%.
sees 2021 gaap earnings per share $3.79 +/- $0.01.
sees 2021 adjusted earnings per share $4.07.
expect overall continued improvement in industrial and commercial demand over remainder of 2021.
expect operational, supply chain, and materials inflation environment to remain challenging through remainder of fiscal year.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:A recording of today's discussion will be accessible via telephone and our website.
In fairness to all participants, please restrict yourself to a single inquiry and one additional follow-up question.
I'd like to inform you that we're organizing an Investor Day in early April, with more details to be provided in the near future.
I'll now hand over the conversation to Phil Snow.
Allow me to begin by extending a warm welcome to Kendra, who has recently taken on the role of FactSet's Head of Investor Relations.
Kendra has been with FactSet for over 20 years, most recently serving as my Chief of Staff.
She brings extensive company knowledge and industry insight to her new position.
I'm eager to collaborate with Kendra in further developing our Investor Relations program.
We're thrilled to have her on board and have already started utilizing her profound financial and operational expertise as we continue to implement our growth strategy.
Moving on to our results.
FactSet has begun fiscal 2022 on a strong note, and I'm delighted to report that this quarter saw the highest Q1 incremental ASV ever recorded.
Continuing the momentum from Q4, we achieved a 9% year-over-year growth in organic ASV plus professional services in Q1.
The impressive performance of our sales and client-facing teams carried over from Q4, accelerating the implementation of our go-to-market strategy.
These teams continue to drive higher retention and expansion rates among existing clients, while also securing a significant number of new business deals.
Institutional asset management clients were the primary contributors to this quarter's growth, as we continue to see strong performance in our workstation and accelerating growth in our analytics workflow solutions.
The past two years of accelerated investment in content and technology continue to drive top-line growth.
We're experiencing increased demand for unique content and workflow solutions.
FactSet's leading open content and analytics platform is enabling us to meet this demand and capture a larger share of our clients' budgets.
Across client types, our wins were widespread.
We observed double-digit ASV growth rates from our banking, wealth, hedge fund, and corporate clients, as well as private equity and venture capital funds and partners.
Our investments in content and technology, including deep sector, wealth, and analytics solutions, continue to support client retention rates and renewals across all sectors.
Overall, we're pleased that our performance resulted in a 13% increase in adjusted earnings per share compared to the same period last year.
Our adjusted operating margin of 33.6% exceeds our projected guidance.
Linda will provide more details shortly.
We're now in the final year of our multi-year investment plan and remain on track to achieve our objectives.
Our focus is on our digital platform, scaling our content refinery, and creating highly personalized workflow solutions.
Within our content refinery, ESG, data for wealth, private markets, and deep sector are all driving workstation growth.
We continue to expand our deep sector data, launching real estate and technology, media, and telecom in November.
Deep sector and our investments in private markets have led to growth and high retention within sell-side firms.
Our recent acquisition of Cobalt further advances our private market strategy by linking unique data with tracking and portfolio monitoring, providing value to our private equity and venture capital clients.
Our workflow solutions, which enhance efficiencies across front, middle, and back offices, continue to contribute significant ASV.
Our analytics APIs are resonating with clients, and we're increasingly integrating with cloud-based platforms.
Earlier this month, we introduced over 90 datasets and numerous APIs on Amazon Data Exchange, becoming the first major data and analytics provider to do so.
Our trading business continues to grow, bolstered by the recent addition of fixed income support for trade execution.
This enables our clients to uncover new insights and trade across asset classes with greater speed and efficiency, significantly contributing to the growth of our analytics and trading business during the quarter.
Our product teams are concentrating on creating, developing, and implementing customized workflow solutions tailored to each client type.
This approach has proven highly effective in the wealth sector, with our Advisor Dashboard maintaining a strong pipeline and robust client engagement for the fiscal year 2022.
We view this level of customization as a key competitive advantage and are dedicated to collaborating with our clients to enhance our offerings.
Across all our regions, we observed sustained strength in ASV growth throughout our markets.
The Americas made the largest contribution, with organic ASV growth accelerating to 9%, supported by widespread strength across our business lines.
This growth was fueled by high retention rates and expansion among asset managers and asset owners.
The region also benefited from successfully implementing higher price increases.
In EMEA, growth picked up to 7%, showing consistent improvement over the last three quarters.
Research and advisory services had a particularly positive impact, driven by improved retention among asset managers and wealth clients, as well as strong workstation sales to new customers.
Asia Pacific experienced another strong quarter with growth accelerating to 14%, primarily driven by CTS.
We continued to secure wins across numerous countries, with hedge funds, asset managers, and asset owners driving ASV growth.
To summarize, I'm impressed with the FactSet team for delivering such strong results at the beginning of the year.
The first quarter is typically a slower start to the fiscal year and doesn't necessarily indicate our performance for the remainder of the year.
Nevertheless, our momentum from Q4 has persisted, and we are well-positioned to achieve our targets for the year.
Consequently, we are reaffirming our fiscal 2022 guidance and remain confident in our pipeline and the value we are providing to our clients.
Moving forward, we continue to focus on three strategic priorities: expanding our content refinery, improving the client experience through highly personalized solutions, and delivering next-generation workflow solutions for clients.
We believe that our people, culture, and performance-driven mindset will enable us to execute these priorities as we accelerate the pace of change.
We are dedicated to investing in and developing our team's talent, experience, and skills as we build the industry's leading open content and analytics platform.
Lastly, an important milestone in our company's history occurred earlier this week when FactSet was included in the S&P 500 Index.
Our addition was actually predicted by our S&P 500 constituents prediction signal on October 1st.
Our inclusion is a proud moment for FactSet and a testament to our significant growth and our efforts to help our clients perform their best work.
Our team's creativity, dedication, and collaborative spirit make us a trusted partner, and I'm extremely proud of their drive to create smarter, more innovative solutions for our clients.
I'm delighted to be here today as part of the FactSet team.
Although I've only been with FactSet for a few months, it's become evident that the company has been performing exceptionally well, from accelerating top-line growth and strong free cash flow generation to its long history of consistent and growing shareholder returns, and there's still significant potential ahead as the investments made over the past two years are paying off and driving growth.
There is undoubtedly a wealth of talent throughout the organization.
I'm excited to work with the team to build upon FactSet's history of outstanding performance while generating substantial value for shareholders.
I will now provide more details on our first quarter performance.
Starting with ASV, we achieved 9% growth in organic ASV plus professional services.
As Phil mentioned earlier, we typically experience a seasonal slowdown in Q1.
Our performance reflects increased demand for our content and products, higher retention rates, and our ability to implement higher pricing.
The market has been favorable, with solid workstation growth in banking and increased demand for our portfolio analytics solutions, as market conditions continue to evolve, our subscription-based ASV will continue to support value-based pricing.
GAAP revenue increased by 9% to $425 million, while organic revenue, which excludes any impact from foreign exchange and acquisitions, increased 9% to $423 million, with growth primarily driven by analytics, trading, and research and advisory services.
All regions experienced significant year-over-year growth.
For our geographic segments, on an organic basis, Americas revenue grew 9%, EMEA also grew 9%, and Asia Pacific revenues increased by 14%.
The main drivers in the region were analytics, CTS, and workstation growth.
Let's now discuss expenditures.
In Q1, GAAP operating costs increased by 13% to $302 million, affected by expected changes during this time frame.
We implemented a $9 million restructuring charge to create a more streamlined and empowered organizational structure.
The ongoing benefits from this reorganization will mainly be used to reinvest in products and retain key employees.
We also recorded $4 million in expenses related to vacating certain office space in NYC.
We recently surveyed our employees about preferred work arrangements, and in line with market trends, a large majority favor hybrid or remote work models.
Based on this preference, we're reevaluating our real estate requirements to align with new work arrangements.
During Q1, we established the FactSet Charitable Foundation to support our corporate social responsibility initiatives.
Our GAAP operating margin decreased by 230 basis points to 29% year-over-year, while our adjusted operating margin fell by 70 basis points to 34%.
As previously mentioned, this surpasses our guidance for this metric.
The rise in expenses was somewhat mitigated by reduced compensation costs.
Our cost of sales as a percentage of revenue was 32 basis points higher than last year on a GAAP basis, but 72 basis points lower on an adjusted basis.
This reflects higher data and infrastructure costs, as well as increased compensation for our current workforce.
These expenses also include our ongoing migration to the public cloud, part of our digital transformation and multi-year investment strategy.
Lower personnel costs partially offset these increases.
SG&A expenses, when expressed as a percentage of revenue, were 198 basis points higher year-over-year on a GAAP basis and 145 basis points higher on an adjusted basis.
The main factors include higher employee compensation, increased bonus accrual, and real estate exit costs.
This was partially counterbalanced by lower stock compensation compared to the previous year.
Regarding taxes, our quarterly tax rate was 10%, down from 16% last year.
This lower rate resulted from a tax benefit due to stock option exercises, prompted by our record stock price.
This led to a higher-than-expected annual estimated benefit.
The reduced annual rate was partially offset by higher-than-anticipated U.S. income.
GAAP earnings per share rose 7% to $2.79 this quarter, compared to $2.62 in the prior year.
Adjusted diluted earnings per share increased by 13% to $3.25, driven by higher revenues and a lower tax rate.
Free cash flow, defined as cash generated from operations minus capital spending, was $64 million for the quarter, a 9% decrease from the same period last year.
This was mainly due to the timing of tax payments, higher year-over-year employee bonus payments, and reduced capital expenditures related to facilities improvements.
Our ASV retention remained above 95%.
We increased our total number of clients by 14% compared to the previous year, primarily due to the addition of more wealth and corporate clients.
Our client retention improved to 92% year-over-year, demonstrating the success of our products, investments, and sales team efforts.
In Q1, we bought back 46,200 shares of our common stock for a total of $19 million at an average price of $403 per share.
We maintain a disciplined approach to our buyback program and are committed to delivering long-term value to our shareholders.
We are reaffirming our 2022 guidance, and as we often state, our business performance is typically split between two halves of the year.
Although it's evident that our momentum from Q4 has continued and we believe we're well-positioned to meet our targets, it's still early in the fiscal year.
We remain committed to developing our content, technology, and people, as well as delivering value for our shareholders.
Summary:
output:
qtrly diluted gaap earnings per share of $2.79.
qtrly adjusted diluted earnings per share of $3.25.
reaffirms its annual outlook for fiscal 2022 as provided in september 2021.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:To begin, our Chief Executive Officer, Bryan Jordan, and Chief Financial Officer, BJ Losch, will provide an overview of our results before opening the floor for questions.
We are delighted to have our Chief Credit Officer, Susan Springfield, joining us to assist with this process.
Our current statements reflect our present views and we are not obligated to provide future updates.
I will now turn the floor over to Bryan.
This quarter has been highly significant for our organization.
We finalized our merger of equals with IBERIABANK and acquired 30 branches from SunTrust Truist, which is an exciting development.
The integration of these branches was completed in mid-July.
We've made considerable advancements during this quarter.
We are very satisfied with the organization's performance and the outstanding efforts of our employees in serving their customers and communities during these challenging times.
Our business is showing positive momentum, and we've once again demonstrated the counter-cyclical benefits of our operations in mortgage, mortgage warehouse lending, and fixed income.
Our balance sheet continues to exhibit strong performance.
Over the past decade or so, we have significantly restructured our balance sheet, with a greater emphasis on Commercial and Industrial lending.
We experienced net charge-offs of 44 basis points this quarter and observed a slight increase in nonperforming assets, but we concluded the period with approximately $1.3 billion in loss-taking capacity.
We had a successful quarter in terms of deposit activity.
We saw favorable customer inflows and the balance sheet appears healthy, with some progress made in adjusting our pricing to offset the lower interest rate environment.
During the quarter, we also made significant progress on our expenses.
We achieved an additional $8 million in run rate savings towards our goal of $170 million plus in expense reductions.
We are confident in our progress in managing costs and planning for the integration.
The investor deck includes informative slides detailing expectations for expense efficiencies in the coming quarters and year.
Our capital foundation remains robust.
We are very pleased with our positioning.
Our Common Equity Tier 1 (CET1) ratio was 9.15%.
The dilution of our tangible book value due to the branch acquisition and merger completion was minimal, largely counterbalanced by our quarterly earnings.
Our integration planning continues to progress well, with major integration work expected to be completed by early fall 2021.
We are on schedule for completing this integration.
There is considerable work to be done between now and then.
Employees across the organization are working to ensure a seamless transition, minimizing any negative impact on our customers and communities.
The progress of the PPP programs and fiscal stimulus has been positive for the economy so far, but uncertainty remains.
We believe we are well-positioned with a strong balance sheet, robust loss-taking capacity, and solid capital, as well as benefiting from our counter-cyclical businesses and the potential for significant cost savings over the next 18 to 24 months.
I will conclude my remarks here.
It's crucial to note that the impact of merger accounting on our financials aligns with the estimates we provided during the second quarter call and in the pro forma released during the quarter.
We have included detailed information on the marks and other merger-related impacts in the appendix for your review.
Slide 6 presents a summary of our adjusted financials for the quarter compared to FHN stand-alone adjusted results from previous quarters.
The trends here primarily reflect the net impact of the IBERIA merger and the branch acquisition.
Moving to Slide 7, we'll examine net interest income and net interest margin.
We generated net interest income of $532 million this quarter, an increase of $227 million from the previous quarter, primarily due to the merger.
Net interest income remained relatively stable compared to the second quarter's combined levels, despite the challenging interest rate environment.
The third quarter results included a $44 million advantage from accretion, equating to roughly 12 basis points on the NIM, which was slightly higher than initially anticipated due to increased prepayments.
The reported NIM decreased by 6 basis points to 2.84% in the quarter, reflecting the effects of low rates and high liquidity levels, partially counterbalanced by accretion.
We are continuously working to enhance our deposit pricing structure.
This quarter saw another reduction in our deposit rate, with interest-bearing deposit expenses dropping to 36 basis points.
We aim to reduce interest-bearing deposit costs to levels similar to those seen during the previous zero interest rate period in 2015, around 24 basis points.
We intend to standardize our deposit pricing across the expanded franchise in the current quarter, which should yield additional benefits as we enter 2021.
Our NIM continues to be affected by significantly higher liquidity levels.
We estimate that excess cash reduced the third quarter margin by approximately 12 basis points.
Our average excess cash was about $3 billion, increasing to $4.5 billion by the end of the quarter.
Although this excess cash position lowers the margin, it does not affect our net interest income.
We are actively seeking more attractive reinvestment options for the future and expect to utilize more of that money over time.
We anticipate further margin pressure in the fourth quarter, likely in the high single-digit to low double-digit range, but expect this to be the lowest point for NIM going forward.
On Slides 8 and 9, we've presented our results compared to the combined previous period results for FHN and IBERIA.
We achieved strong performance in fee income again in the third quarter, with relatively stable results compared to the previous quarter and a 23% year-over-year increase, as our counter-cyclical businesses in fixed income and mortgage banking helped offset COVID-related pressure in some of our more traditional banking fee income streams.
Fixed income results met expectations, remaining relatively stable compared to the previous quarter and showing a $33 million increase year-over-year, with average daily revenues of $1.5 million.
Mortgage banking once again delivered outstanding results, with a $13 million increase from the previous quarter and almost $40 million year-over-year.
Secondary originations of $1.2 billion were up 3% from strong second quarter levels, while gain on sale margins expanded over 100 basis points to 3.93%.
Looking ahead to the fourth quarter, we anticipate a seasonal slowdown in volumes for both of these businesses, but expect overall market conditions to remain favorable for the foreseeable future.
As shown on Slide 9, we continue to maintain our commitment to expense discipline.
Expenses decreased by $15 million compared to the previous quarter, as reductions in personnel and other non-interest expenses were partially offset by an expected increase in intangibles amortization from the Merger and Branch acquisition.
Salaries and benefits increased by $7 million, driven by the alignment of benefits across the combined platform, the addition of personnel from the 30 acquired branches, and an increase in healthcare costs following the pandemic-driven slowdown.
This increase was more than offset by a reduction in revenue-based incentives and commissions, as well as lower deferred comp costs.
Our results this quarter also reflect the benefit of $8 million in net merger cost savings, bringing our year-to-date total to $18 million.
We recognize the importance of maintaining a strong focus on cost control as a lever in this environment.
We have unique advantages to do so given our merger and will continue to seek further expense reductions beyond our targeted merger savings.
Slides 13 and 14 provide a review of our loan growth and funding profiles relative to combined First Horizon and IBERIA results.
As anticipated, period-end loan growth was modest due to subdued customer demand, ongoing payoffs, and utilization rates returning to more normal levels.
A highlight of the quarter was the continued strong mortgage warehouse demand, which led to a $1.6 billion increase in loans to mortgage companies on a spot basis and approximately $430 million on average.
Similar to fixed income and mortgage banking originations, loans to mortgage companies serve as a counter-cyclical, high-return specialty business for us, and we expect continued strong performance.
On the liability side, period-end deposits increased by $2.3 billion, primarily driven by the branch acquisition and continued strong customer inflows, allowing us to reduce higher-cost non-customer balances.
Given current levels of excess liquidity and our enhanced market presence, we expect to further lower our interest-bearing deposit costs, particularly as we move to align our pricing strategies across the footprint.
We also improved our funding profile with a $1.2 billion reduction in borrowings from 2Q combined levels, leveraging our excess liquidity to pay down legacy IBERIA Federal Home Loan Bank advances.
Turning to Slide 12, we'll cover asset quality over the next few slides.
Our results this quarter clearly reflect the impact of the merger, with many moving parts.
However, broadly speaking, overall asset quality remains relatively stable outside of energy, despite the impacts of COVID-19.
Net charge-offs increased to 44 basis points, up from 20 basis points for legacy FHN, driven by energy-related losses.
We saw a relatively modest 6 basis point increase in NPLs to 75 basis points of total loans, despite the impact of the merger.
Slide 13 shows that we continued to add reserves this quarter, with the merger and branch acquisition adding $475 million to the allowance for credit losses.
Beyond merger-related changes, we also increased reserves by a modest $13 million.
We concluded the quarter with $1.1 billion in reserves, equal to 2.15% of the loan portfolio, excluding low-risk PPP and mortgage company loans, and roughly four times annualized net charge-offs.
Including the unrecognized discount on acquired loans, our total loss absorbing capacity reaches $1.3 billion or over 2% of total loans.
Slide 14 provides an updated perspective on portfolios most impacted by the pandemic, as identified by investors.
We conducted thorough reviews of $9 billion in commercial loans across various sectors affected by the current situation.
Based on these assessments and broader portfolio evaluations, we estimate that just under 11% of our total loans require heightened monitoring.
We've highlighted potentially stressed sub-sectors such as real estate lending, energy, retail, trade, and non-fast food accommodation and foodservice.
It's worth noting that sectors like essential services, recreational goods, manufacturing, and home improvement continue to perform well, as does our high-quality consumer portfolio with an average refreshed FICO score of 750.
So far, customers have shown more resilience than initially anticipated, and overall stress appears to be decreasing.
The appendix contains information on reserve coverage across our portfolio and deferrals, which have significantly decreased to about 2.4% of federal loan balances from a peak of nearly 13%.
We remain confident in our risk profile and reserve levels, especially after thoroughly marking the IBERIA loan book, which comprises about 45% of the portfolio.
Regarding capital and tangible book value per share on Slide 15, TBV per share remained relatively stable at $9.92 compared to the second quarter, with strong earnings offset by the IBERIA merger, Truist branch acquisition impacts, and the CET1 ratio ending at 9.15%.
In the short term, we aim to maintain a CET1 ratio between 9% and 9.25%.
Slide 16 provides a Merger Integration Update, highlighting our continued enthusiasm for the opportunities arising from our merger of equals.
We've established a robust integration framework to capitalize on these opportunities efficiently, despite the pandemic.
Significant progress has been made in aligning cultures, processes, and systems for successful integration.
Much of the HR-related integration is complete, including leadership identification and payroll system conversion.
On the customer side, we've developed go-to-market and organizational models, and finalized our customer experience dashboard.
We're on schedule to convert various platforms and plan for full systems conversion in fall 2021.
Third quarter cost savings totaled $8 million, bringing the year-to-date total to $18 million.
We've provided an updated view of expected savings over time and remain confident in delivering at least $170 million of annualized savings in 2022, with a slight shift in the savings timeline.
The table on the right shows estimated timing of merger savings on an annualized basis.
Our third quarter 2020 annualized expense base, excluding incentives and commissions, was about $1.52 billion, and we expect a low single-digit decrease in 2021 expenses based on merger savings timing.
Slide 17 summarizes our position to leverage our diversified business model across attractive southern markets, with a revenue mix offsetting NII pressure from low rates.
We benefit from merger cost savings and have demonstrated commitment to expense control through prior acquisitions and efficiency initiatives.
Our risk management approach should help mitigate credit losses, supported by the marked loan book and significant loss absorption capacity.
While economic challenges persist and loan demand is needed, we can focus on merger integration for the next year, expecting our business model to drive outperformance and shareholder value creation.
I want to acknowledge the extraordinary efforts of our teams across various departments in navigating this complex and unique quarter and year.
Our strong balance sheet, capital, and liquidity position us well in this challenging environment.
We've maintained robust underwriting standards and built a diversified portfolio focused on downturn performance and profitability.
Despite economic headwinds, we're uniquely positioned to capitalize on merger opportunities, enhancing scale, efficiency, and earning power to create significant shareholder value.
We remain committed to supporting our associates, communities, and customers in overcoming COVID-19 impacts and revitalizing the economy.
We're well-positioned and excited about the combination of IBERIABANK and First Horizon, with unprecedented opportunities ahead.
Summary:
output:
first horizon national corp - qtrly net interest income $532 million versus $301 million.
first horizon national corp - three-year strategic plan to be finalized in q4 2020.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:My name is Ian Hudson and I serve as the Chief Financial Officer for the Company.
Joining me on today's call is Jennifer Sherman, who holds the positions of President and Chief Executive Officer.
These materials can be accessed on our company's website.
We will be submitting our Form 10-Q later today as well.
I'll start by providing a detailed overview of our first quarter performance, then hand it over to Jennifer to discuss current market conditions, our progress on strategic initiatives, and our outlook for the rest of the year.
We had another excellent quarter with record-breaking orders and operational results, surpassing our expectations despite ongoing challenges related to the pandemic.
We also had to contend with the February ice storms in the southern states, which forced us to temporarily shut down our facilities in Texas, Alabama, and Mississippi.
Luckily, we didn't suffer any major damage, but we did lose several days of production.
Despite these obstacles, our teams bounced back well, with both divisions achieving adjusted EBITDA margins that matched or exceeded those from the first quarter of last year.
This achievement is particularly noteworthy given the strength of the previous year's quarter, which saw record production at our largest facility and minimal impact from the pandemic.
Looking at the figures, our consolidated net sales for the quarter were $279 million, compared to $286 million in the same period last year.
The consolidated operating income for the quarter was $27.8 million, down from $32.3 million in the previous year.
Our consolidated adjusted EBITDA for the quarter stood at $41.2 million, compared to $43.9 million in the same quarter last year.
This translates to a margin of 14.8% in Q1 this year, slightly down from 15.3% last year.
The net income for the quarter was $22.2 million, a slight decrease from $23.4 million in the same period last year.
This equates to GAAP earnings of $0.36 per share for the quarter, compared to $0.38 per share in the previous year.
After adjustments, our earnings per share for the quarter were $0.38, slightly down from $0.39 per share in the same quarter last year.
We saw exceptional order intake this quarter, with orders totaling $384 million, setting a new quarterly record and representing an increase of $80 million or 26% compared to Q1 of last year.
Our consolidated backlog at the quarter's end also set a new company record at $410 million, which is $9 million higher than Q1 last year and $106 million or 35% more than at the end of 2020.
Regarding our group performance, ESG's net sales for the quarter were $228 million, slightly down from $233 million last year.
ESG's operating income for the quarter was $27.1 million, a decrease from $29.4 million in the previous year.
The adjusted EBITDA for ESG this quarter was $39.3 million, compared to $40 million in the same period last year.
This translates to an adjusted EBITDA margin of 17.2%, which is consistent with last year's figure.
ESG reported orders of $324 million in Q1 this year, a significant improvement of $87 million or 37% compared to the previous year.
SSG's net sales for the quarter were $51 million, slightly lower than the $53 million recorded last year.
The operating income for the quarter was $7.2 million, a slight decrease from $7.4 million in the previous year.
SSG's adjusted EBITDA for the quarter remained steady at around $8.2 million, while its adjusted EBITDA margin improved to 16.2%, an increase of 80 basis points from Q1 last year.
SSG's orders for the quarter totaled $60 million, down from $66 million in the same period last year.
Corporate operating expenses for the quarter increased to $6.5 million from $4.5 million last year.
This increase was mainly due to an unfavorable year-over-year variance of $2.6 million related to changes in mark-to-market adjustments of post-retirement reserves.
These market-based adjustments positively impacted our earnings by about $0.02 per share in Q1 last year but had a negative effect in Q1 this year.
Examining the consolidated income statement, the decrease in sales led to a $6 million reduction in gross profit.
The consolidated gross margin for the quarter was 24.7%, down from 26.1% in the previous year.
As a percentage of sales, our selling, engineering, general and administrative expenses for the quarter decreased by 20 basis points compared to Q1 last year, despite the unfavorable mark-to-market variance mentioned earlier.
Other factors influencing the quarterly results include a $700,000 increase in other income and a $400,000 decrease in interest expense.
Tax expense for the quarter decreased by $2.2 million, primarily due to lower pre-tax income levels and higher excess tax benefits from stock compensation activity.
Our effective tax rate for the quarter was 18.4%, down from 23.5% last year.
The lower tax rate in Q1 of this year aligned with our expectations, as we had factored in an estimate of excess tax benefits.
At present, we still anticipate our full-year effective tax rate to be approximately 24%.
Overall, on a GAAP basis, we earned $0.36 per share in Q1 this year, compared to $0.38 per share in Q1 last year.
To enable more accurate earnings comparisons, we typically adjust our GAAP earnings per share to exclude unusual items recorded in the current or prior year quarters.
For this quarter, we made adjustments to GAAP earnings per share to exclude acquisition-related expenses, coronavirus-related expenses, and purchase accounting expense effects.
After these adjustments, our earnings for the quarter were $0.38 per share, compared to $0.39 per share in the same period last year.
Regarding cash flow, we generated $26 million from operations during the quarter, a $21 million improvement over Q1 last year.
We concluded the quarter with $168 million of net debt and $270 million available under our credit facility.
Our current net debt leverage ratio remains low, even after funding the acquisition of OSW during the quarter for approximately $53 million.
Our robust financial status enables us to invest in organic growth and pursue strategic acquisitions such as OSW.
We remain dedicated to seeking strategic acquisitions and returning value to shareholders through dividends and opportunistic share buybacks.
During the quarter, we distributed $5.5 million in dividends, reflecting an increased payout of $0.09 per share.
We have recently announced a comparable dividend for the second quarter.
It has been more than a year since the onset of the pandemic.
Despite numerous challenges, I continue to be impressed by our teams' adaptability in modifying work practices for employee safety, managing uncertain market conditions, and innovating to serve customers.
While some COVID-related disruptions persist, the situation is gradually improving.
Our company-wide efforts to promote vaccine awareness, facilitate employee access to vaccines, and encourage participation are yielding positive results, with our domestic employee vaccination rates exceeding the national average.
In Illinois, where we have three major facilities and the corporate office, over 60% of our employees have completed their vaccination.
We've observed an increase in our sales resources traveling, reinforcing our customer-focused value proposition and contributing to higher order intake.
As in the previous two quarters, we experienced increased demand for our products, with first-quarter order intake setting a new company record, surpassing the previous high by more than $50 million.
Our first quarter orders indicate strength across most of our end markets and growing confidence in a post-pandemic recovery, further bolstered by recent economic stimulus.
This sentiment appears to be widely shared by our dealer partners and customers across most of our businesses.
Demand for sewer cleaners remains robust, with first quarter orders up 30% year-over-year, and nearly double the amount recorded in the previous quarter.
Safe digging continues to gain acceptance in the market.
In recent years, approximately 70% of our sewer cleaner orders have included an optional safe-digging package, allowing the equipment to be used for hydro or vacuum excavation purposes.
We observed similar trends this quarter, with customer appreciation for the safety and efficiency benefits of safe digging gaining momentum.
At MRL, our road marking and line removal business, first quarter orders reached the highest quarterly levels since we acquired the business in 2019.
With its planned expansion now complete, we are well-positioned to benefit from potential infrastructure investment.
Our road marking services business, Highmark, also secured an $8 million striping contract during the quarter.
Since the fourth quarter of last year, we've noticed an uptick in our industrial end markets, with improved orders for our Guzzler and JetStream products as we approach the spring-cleaning season.
Additionally, our dump bodies and trailer businesses reported strong organic order growth of 28% across our end markets, achieving record backlog.
While our backlog is at an all-time high, several factors may limit our ability to fully realize the benefits of the operating leverage we typically experience with backlog at these levels.
The first factor, which many of you may be aware of, is the impact of the global semiconductor shortage on chassis availability.
