We began noticing supply tightness late last year, and our teams proactively secured additional chassis and advised our customers and dealer partners to do the same for orders where they supply the chassis.
As a reminder, customers supply the chassis about 50% of the time for our ESG businesses, excluding TBEI, where the customer almost always provides the chassis.
We were recently informed by one of our chassis suppliers that they are temporarily halting production of certain chassis for up to 90 days due to the semiconductor shortage.
This issue primarily affects our sewer cleaners, safe digging trucks, and certain street sweeper models.
The situation remains fluid, and our teams have been working diligently to mitigate the impact of this short-term disruption.
Based on the information we've received, we expect the situation to be resolved during the third quarter, with production expected to ramp up quickly thereafter.
Because we don't rely on a single TSC manufacturer, and due to our proactive measures, we've been able to adapt quickly to minimize the financial impact.
For example, at Elgin, our team adjusted production schedules to build a higher concentration of three-wheel Pelican sweepers during the expected impact period.
As a reminder, we manufacture the chassis ourselves for that product line.
At our Streator facility, where we produce sewer cleaners and safe digging trucks, we've been working to secure additional chassis from other manufacturers.
However, due to lead times on certain chassis, there will be a period of approximately two weeks where we face a shortage at Vactor.
To optimize efficiency, our teams have carefully managed the schedule so that this brief pause will coincide with the July 4 holiday.
With the additional chassis supply we've secured, we anticipate a production ramp-up thereafter.
Like many companies, we are also experiencing rising commodity costs.
As our teams have done in the past, we took proactive measures such as locking in pricing and securing steel availability based on forecasted needs.
Our teams are working diligently to mitigate the impacts of rising commodity costs by implementing price increases and surcharges where possible.
Regarding labor availability, our ongoing commitment to environmental, social, and governance principles continues to benefit our company.
Investment in our employees sets us apart and enhances our ability to attract labor at the majority of our facilities.
I'd like to take a few moments to provide an update on our strategic growth initiatives.
We remain optimistic about the prospects for safe digging, and with the observed recovery in industrial end markets and infrastructure spending optimism throughout the channel, we are confident that safe digging trends will continue to improve.
Our TRUVAC safe digging product line portfolio includes a comprehensive range of truck-mounted safe digging equipment with applications across various end markets.
We were pleased to see that TRUVAC product demonstrations for the quarter increased by 70% compared to last year.
Education initiatives are positively influencing demand for sewer cleaners, with the optional safe digging package transforming them into versatile vehicles.
Aftermarket revenue has shown improvement, increasing by 6% and comprising a larger portion of ESG's quarterly earnings at approximately 27%.
We are vigilantly monitoring rental fleet usage and exercising caution in decisions regarding the fleet's size and composition.
Recently, we've observed robust sales of used equipment and an increase in rentals.
We're keeping a close eye on the COVID-19 situation in Canada, where Ontario and other provinces are implementing some of the strictest stay-at-home measures since the pandemic began.
Although we haven't experienced significant financial impacts yet, our Canadian markets may be affected in the coming months, which is typically a strong season for equipment rentals and parts sales.
We have several new product launches planned for organic growth, and I'll discuss a few of them today.
Street sweeper electrification remains a key focus for investment within ESG.
We've previously discussed our initial orders for the hybrid electric broom bear street sweeper, expected to be shipped later this year.
This hybrid model utilizes both battery power and either CNG or diesel for sweeping, designed to match or surpass current sweeper performance.
Our dealer network is currently demonstrating the hybrid broom bear, starting on the West Coast and moving to the Southeast, with positive feedback so far.
We're also developing a hybrid version of our most popular street sweeper, the Pelican.
The plug-in hybrid electric Pelican sweeper is assembled and undergoing testing, with product demonstrations scheduled for the latter half of this year.
We're seeing benefits from new product introductions in our dump body and trailer product line.
Products launched in the past year contributed to about 4% organic growth this quarter.
In SSG, our innovation pipeline typically includes numerous new product introductions and enhancements that, while individually may not have a significant financial impact, collectively contribute to meaningful organic growth.
We began production of our MicroPulse line this quarter, a low-profile, high-performance LED lighting product for first responders and work truck vehicles.
This line includes both new product models and previously outsourced ones.
In-sourcing this line, which uses automated laser technology, is expected to improve related margins and generate annual savings exceeding $1 million.
We're on track to launch a low-cost light power in the second quarter.
In addition to organic growth initiatives, M&A will continue to play a significant role in our future growth.
We acquired OSW, a leading dump body manufacturer and truck equipment and trailer upfitter, during the quarter.
This acquisition presents substantial opportunities for long-term value creation through the application of our 80/20 improvement principle, organic growth initiatives, and additional bolt-on acquisitions.
We recently held an initial 80/20 improvement training session at OSW, which was well-received by the teams.
Integration is progressing well, and although it's early, OSW had a strong start in the first quarter.
Our M&A pipeline has been very active, and it's been exciting to visit potential targets in person again.
As Ian mentioned, our strong financial position and liquidity allow us to pursue strategic acquisitions, and our teams are currently reviewing several M&A opportunities.
We've continued to make significant investments in our existing facilities to increase capacity for long-term growth and improve operational efficiency through automation.
As we optimize our manufacturing footprint, we're evaluating our long-term strategy for our Elgin and University Park production facilities in Illinois.
Both properties are currently leased at above-market rates with leases ending in 2023.
We're exploring opportunities and alternative facilities in the surrounding areas as we proactively plan for a potential relocation.
The American Rescue Plan, a COVID relief package, includes approximately $1.9 trillion in economic stimulus, with about $350 billion allocated to state, local, and territorial governments to maintain frontline workers, distribute vaccines, increase testing, reopen schools, and sustain essential services.
We're actively educating our dealer network about the stimulus program and have shared the latest estimated allocation of the $350 billion in state and local government support by jurisdiction with our dealers to pass on to their customers.
As a provider of equipment used for essential services like sewer cleaning and street sweeping, Federal Signal is well-positioned to benefit significantly from additional aid that may be provided to state and local sources for these purposes.
Our first-quarter order intake showed that our dealer partners remain optimistic about market conditions in 2021, noting that both corporate and sales tax collections have held up better than initially expected, which should provide stability to their revenue sources.
We anticipate that a long-term infrastructure bill will provide visibility for project planning and could lead to increased capital equipment demand in areas such as roads, bridges, broadband, clean energy, and public transportation development.
We expect this to benefit the majority of our product offerings, including equipment sales and rentals of dump trucks and trailers, safe digging trucks, road marking equipment, sewer cleaners, and street sweepers.
We have positioned Federal Signal to fully participate in the post-pandemic recovery by increasing capacity within our facilities, reducing lead times to better respond to customer needs, investing in new product development, and gaining market share.
Regarding our outlook for the rest of the year, orders so far have exceeded our expectations, driven by new product launches, ongoing execution of our strategic initiatives, and strong recovery in our end markets.
We're currently facing some short-term production challenges at our largest facility due to temporary impacts on certain chassis manufacturers from the global semiconductor shortage.
Our teams are working diligently to navigate this disruption, as they have in similar situations in the past.
After considering the expected impact over the next couple of months, we're maintaining our adjusted earnings per share outlook for the year at $1.73 to $1.85.
With our recently completed capacity expansion at several facilities, we're well-positioned once the current chassis uncertainty subsides.
Demand for our products is at an all-time high, with the recent federal stimulus and potential infrastructure investment offering further momentum, which we haven't factored into our current outlook.
Summary:
output:
compname reports q1 revenue $228 mln.
q1 adjusted earnings per share $0.38.
q1 gaap earnings per share $0.36.
q1 revenue $228 million.
compname says maintaining adjusted earnings per share outlook for fy 2021 $1.73 to $1.85.
compname reports q1 gaap earnings per share of $0.36.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Details required by SEC Regulation G for these non-GAAP financial measures can be found in the Investors area of our website, www.fortive.com, under the Investors Quarterly Results section.
We finalized the division of our Industrial Technologies segment by spinning off Vontier Corporation on October 9, 2020, and have consequently included the Industrial Technologies segment's results as discontinued operations.
All mentions of year-over-year increases or decreases and financial metrics pertain to continuing operations.
Let's begin with slide three.
Our Q1 performance continued to showcase the advantages of our efforts to improve our portfolio's growth and resilience, substantially expanding our presence in software and healthcare while adding significant sources of higher-growth recurring revenue.
Consequently, our portfolio has been well-positioned to drive rapid sequential improvement in recent quarters as markets have started to reopen.
In the first quarter, we continued to observe significant improvement, not only in our short-cycle businesses, mainly Fluke Instruments and Tektronix, but also in many businesses that have faced COVID-related challenges, such as Advanced Sterilization Products.
Now, let's look at the quarter's results.
We achieved total revenue growth of 13.6% and core revenue growth of 9.1%, surpassing the upper end of our guidance.
Adjusted earnings per share reached $0.63, representing a 37% year-over-year increase.
The combined outperformance in core growth and earnings contributed to another strong quarter of free cash flow.
Our SaaS offerings at Accruent, Intelex, Censis, eMaint, and Gordian continued to perform well, generating double-digit growth in the quarter, with Gordian experiencing better overall top-line momentum.
These software offerings play a crucial role in our strategy to leverage leading hardware positions to provide broader software-enabled solutions that address pain points in our customers' critical workflows and their ongoing digital transformation priorities.
Despite the challenges posed by the COVID environment, we continued to use FBS tools to drive performance improvements across our portfolio.
ASP is expanding the implementation of the Fortive Business System more broadly, driving strong improvements in working capital turns and progress in accelerating commercial efforts, delivering its fifth consecutive quarter of growth in its global installed base.
Intelex also continues to benefit from the application of FBS tools to enhance its sales process, leading to better lead generation, improved customer win rates, and stronger sales pipeline creation.
While these are just a couple of examples, we are highly focused on building FBS capability across our newer businesses to deliver accelerated growth, innovation, and market share gains.
Regarding organic growth, we continue to invest in strategic initiatives across our operating companies and build additional capacity to drive future innovation.
With the FORT, we are scaling our data analytics capabilities, providing leverage to our operating companies to pursue key AI and machine learning applications.
In 2020, we more than doubled the number of projects conducted and expect to do the same this year, targeting over $250 million in potential revenue opportunities.
Our acquisition of ehsAI significantly expanded our machine learning expertise to help grow our position within EHS workflows and generate learnings that can be applied more broadly within Fortive.
We've also made several additional investments to expand our partnership with Pioneer Square Labs, with three startup opportunities currently in different phases of incubation.
These investments enhance our ability to generate disruptive innovation that will deepen our competitive advantage and increase our customer value proposition.
Regarding performance across major geographies, core growth was led by low 20% growth in Asia.
This included approximately 30% growth in China and low double-digit growth in Japan.
Elsewhere, our core revenue grew by low double-digits in Western Europe and by low single-digits in North America.
Taking a closer look at segment performance on slide seven, Intelligent Operating Solutions posted a total revenue increase of 9.5%, with core revenue increase of 5.5%.
This included high-teens growth in China, high single-digit growth in Western Europe, and flat top-line performance in North America.
Fluke's core revenue continued to improve in the first quarter, increasing by high single-digits.
This performance was highlighted by low double-digit growth at Fluke Industrial and high-teens growth at Fluke Calibration.
Fluke's growth included the launch of the 377 and 378 Fluke Connect plant meters for non-contact voltage testing.
These introductions incorporate Fluke's FieldSense technology and extend its leadership position in safer non-contact measurement tools.
At Fluke Industrial, point-of-sale in North America turned positive in the first quarter, increasing by low single digits.
Meanwhile, point-of-sale in both Western Europe and China continued to improve, rising by mid-single digits and mid-teens, respectively.
Strong performance at Fluke Digital Systems continued this quarter, increasing by mid-single digits as eMaint saw strong demand with mid-teens growth in SaaS bookings.
Industrial Scientific declined single-digits in the first quarter due to continued weakness in instrument sales.
The company's iNet offering continued to demonstrate its resilience, increasing by low single-digits.
iNet also registered an 18% increase in bookings while driving a more than 500 basis point improvement in net retention.
ISC's rental business saw strong bookings growth, signaling improving stability in its end-markets with customers beginning to restart maintenance project activity.
Simultaneously, we're observing ongoing success from implementing FBS growth strategies at Intelex to boost sales pipeline generation, resulting in a record-breaking revenue quarter with growth in the low double digits.
The incorporation of ehsAI is progressing smoothly.
Although its revenue contribution remains minimal, product integration is on track, and the Intelex team has begun to speed up new customer acquisition.
Accruent experienced low single-digit growth in the first quarter, with SaaS growth standing out at high single digits.
Accruent continues to experience positive momentum in its Industrial and Life Science divisions.
This included a recent contract with BioMarin, which incorporated Accruent's Meridian solution as a crucial tool for managing their pharmaceutical manufacturing facilities, facilitating communication with contractors and supporting FDA validation.
Accruent is also witnessing increasing demand across various end markets for its facility planning and resource scheduling solutions as customers prepare their facilities for future workforce needs as they emerge from the pandemic.
Accruent's growth in the quarter was boosted by the resumption of some on-site service, implementation, and project-related activities, with further improvements expected as the year progresses.
Following challenges during the latter half of 2020, Gordian's top-line improved to break even in the first quarter.
Gordian's job order contracting procurement business grew by low single digits and is anticipated to accelerate as recovery from COVID continues to ramp up.
The company's estimating business continued to perform well, growing by high single-digits and experiencing strong renewal momentum and conversion rates for the SaaS version of its RSMeans product line.
Gordian observed signs of improvement regarding site access issues during the first quarter.
We anticipate this improvement will persist in the upcoming quarters.
The Precision Technology segment recorded a total revenue increase of 14.3% with a 12.1% rise in core revenue.
This included growth in the mid-30s percent in China, mid-teens in Western Europe, and mid single-digit in North America.
Tektronix generated high-teens growth, driven by strength in its general industrial and semiconductor markets.
Point-of-sale continued to accelerate, rising over 40% in China, over 20% in Western Europe, while North America turned positive with a mid single-digit increase in the quarter.
Tektronix has observed strong demand in China as economic recovery continues, driven by government investment in 5G, electric vehicles, and IoT solutions.
Examining Tektronix's product lines, both mainstream oscilloscope and Keithley had an outstanding first quarter.
Mainstream oscilloscope posted high 30% growth, driven by strong demand trends across most of its key product segments, particularly our six series and four series scopes.
Keithley grew mid-teens, while the Tektronix service business continued to show stability, reporting mid single-digit growth in the first quarter.
Tektronix also saw outperformance across a range of recent new product introductions, including its new ISO view probe solution for semiconductor and automotive market applications.
Sensing Technologies grew by low double-digits, driven by broad strengthening across end markets, including industrial and electronics customers.
Sensing witnessed accelerating demand in China as it secured a number of key wins with strong momentum among factory automation OEM customers.
Sensing also generated strong growth from its critical environment products, etc, with mid-30% growth for the quarter.
Pacific Scientific EMC returned to growth, increasing by low single-digits in the first quarter.
The business continued to see good order trends with a book-to-bill of 1.2 over the trailing 12 months and has a strong backlog that we expect to support improving growth in the coming quarters.
Shifting focus to Advanced Healthcare Solutions.
Total revenue increased 20.3% with a 10.9% increase in core revenue.
This included low 40% growth in China, low 20% growth in Western Europe and low single-digit growth in North America.
ASP returned to growth in the first quarter, increasing by mid single-digits.
Growth at ASP was driven by a greater than 40% increase in capital equipment sales as it continued to expand its global installed base.
This momentum in capital sales more than compensated for the fact that electric procedures were 91% of pre-COVID levels globally and continue to impact ASP's consumable revenue.
Stronger capital sales indicate the progress ASP is making in its FBS journey by improving sales execution and enhancing funnel management at priority independent delivery network accounts.
ASP continued to perform well in Western Europe, marking its fifth consecutive quarter of growth.
ASP was also recently designated as the Preferred Supplier by the National Health Service in the UK for a large multiyear tender for terminal sterilization capital and services.
Censis also had a strong first quarter, growing by low-teens with low-double-digit growth in its CensiTrac SaaS offering.
Censis has experienced improved upselling momentum across its business and is also seeing evidence of US hospitals transitioning to post-COVID operations and making faster purchasing decisions.
Fluke Health Solutions increased by low-teens in the first quarter, with broad strength across its product lines.
FHS continues to successfully deploy FBS to drive growth and margin improvements at LANDAUER by leveraging global go-to-market scale and accelerating cross-selling of products and services.
Landauer has seen its operating margins improve by approximately 2.5 times since being acquired.
Invetech reported growth of around 45% as it fulfills a large backlog of diagnostic product orders from 2020.
I will now hand over to Chuck, who will provide more information on our margins and free cash flow for the quarter.
Excellent execution across all areas allowed us to achieve strong margin performance in the first quarter.
In Q1, adjusted gross margins increased by 90 basis points to 57%, driven by strong growth at Fluke and Tektronix, as well as improved gross margins at ASP after transitioning from service agreements.
This also reflected effective implementation of FBS throughout the company, including continued price realization of 90 basis points during the quarter.
Our adjusted operating profit margin for Q1 was 22.7%, slightly higher than expected, partly due to stronger volume in the quarter.
We achieved 40% adjusted incremental operating margins, 240 basis points of core operating margin expansion, and over 200 basis points of core operating margin growth in each of our three segments.
In the first quarter, we generated $144 million in free cash flow, a 50% increase compared to the same period last year.
We are pleased with the consistent growth in free cash flow over the past year, with the first quarter bringing our trailing 12-month free cash flow to $950 million.
Along with significant earnings growth, disciplined working capital management at ASP, Fluke, and Tektronix contributed to this free cash flow performance.
At the beginning of Q1, we efficiently monetized our remaining 19.9% stake in Vontier, generating about $1.1 billion in proceeds, which we used to repay debt.
Based on this transaction and our Q1 free cash flow, we ended the first quarter with a net leverage ratio of 1.2 times.
Our strong free cash flow and significant balance sheet capacity position us well to pursue our key capital allocation priorities, and we are maintaining an active pipeline of potential deals.
We continue to see numerous opportunities to deploy capital to strengthen our core hardware and instrumentation positions while also leveraging our expertise to expand into adjacent high-value software and data-driven opportunities.
Let's now look at the guidance on slide 11.
Due to strong first quarter performance and an improved outlook for the rest of the year, we are raising our 2021 guidance.
For the full year, we now expect adjusted diluted net earnings per share to be between $2.50 and $2.60, representing 20% to 24% year-over-year growth on a continuing operations basis.
This projection assumes total revenue growth of 10% to 13%, core revenue growth of 7% to 10%, adjusted operating profit margins of 22% to 23%, and an effective tax rate of about 14%.
It also assumes core revenue growth of 5% to 7% in the second half of 2021.
We continue to expect free cash flow conversion to be approximately 105% of adjusted net income for the year.
We are introducing second quarter adjusted diluted net earnings per share guidance of $0.56 to $0.60, representing 30% to 40% year-over-year growth.
This assumes total revenue growth of 20% to 23%, core revenue growth of 16% to 19%, adjusted operating profit margins of 19.5% to 20.5%, and an effective tax rate of about 14%.
For the second quarter, we expect free cash flow conversion to be approximately 85% of adjusted net income.
The full-year guidance includes $35 million of additional investments to drive innovation and enhance our capabilities for future growth, with $15 million allocated to the second quarter.
This includes funding for the FORT to expand our analytic capabilities and talent base, as well as to accelerate the development of AI and machine learning offerings for our customers.
It also includes funding for investments in our partnership with Pioneer Square Labs, where we have seen good early progress.
I'll now hand it back to Jim for some closing remarks.
Before we move to questions on slide 13, I wanted to highlight our ongoing progress regarding key sustainability goals.
In Q1, we completed an updated materiality analysis, providing valuable insights that we used to define new pillars of our sustainability strategy, which will guide our future efforts.
We've made significant progress implementing the Intelex sustainability performance indicators platform across the portfolio, which we used to collect 2020 emissions data with new, more aggressive carbon emissions targets.
We look forward to discussing our progress and evolving sustainability goals at our upcoming Investor Day.
Today's announced results demonstrate the depth and dedication of our teams and our relentless focus on continuous improvement principles that drive our culture.
Looking ahead, we are excited about the strength of our portfolio, the quality of our market opportunities, and the significant organic and inorganic growth prospects before us.
As macro indicators continue to recover from the COVID-19 pandemic, we will focus on driving strong core growth, margin expansion, and free cash flow generation, while investing in innovation and deploying capital for acquisitions that accelerate our strategy and increase customer value.
We're eager to share more details about our future plans at our Investor Day on May 19.
In the nearly five years since our spin-off, we have positioned our portfolio for higher growth, improved profitability, and stronger free cash flow generation.
This sets us up well for accelerated growth across our businesses, which we look forward to discussing with you.
That concludes our formal comments.
Summary:
output:
sees fy adjusted earnings per share $2.50 to $2.60 from continuing operations.
sees q2 adjusted earnings per share $0.56 to $0.60 from continuing operations.
qtrly adjusted diluted net earnings per share from continuing operations were $0.63.
qtrly revenues from continuing operations increased 13.6% year-over-year to $1.3 billion.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Details regarding non-GAAP financial measures required by SEC Regulation G can be found in the Investors section of our website, www.fortive.com, under Financial Information.
We divested the automation and specialty business on October 1, 2018, and have treated its results as discontinued operations for past periods.
All mentions of changes and financial metrics compare year-over-year continuing operations.
Our third quarter results exceeded initial expectations, with strong execution across the portfolio leading to better-than-anticipated revenue and a return to growth in adjusted operating profit and earnings per share.
Adjusted diluted net earnings per share grew 8% year-over-year to $0.94 for the quarter.
Despite ongoing challenges in Q3, we effectively managed near-term obstacles by employing the Fortive Business System.
We expanded core operating margins by 160 basis points and delivered another quarter of robust free cash flow while prioritizing growth investments across our portfolio to continue gaining market share.
We successfully completed the spin-off of Vontier Corporation, a global industrial technology company focused on mobility infrastructure, on October 9.
I'm very proud of our team's dedication throughout the year leading up to the separation, and I'm excited about the future prospects for both companies.
Our ability to remain prepared and execute this complex transaction despite the challenges posed by COVID-19 demonstrates our people's resilience and adaptability, as well as the strength of FBS.
As independent entities, both Fortive and Vontier are well-positioned to pursue their strategic objectives and create increasing value for all stakeholders.
With Vontier's spin-off complete, Fortive is well-positioned as a provider of crucial technologies for connected workflow solutions across various attractive markets.
We have strong market positions with leading brands that benefit from long-term growth trends and opportunities to increase recurring revenue.
We have a proven track record of disciplined capital allocation, significant financial capacity, strong free cash flow, and numerous opportunities for organic investment and strategic acquisitions across our portfolio.
Most critically, we have the Fortive Business System, the foundation of our culture and a lasting competitive advantage that drives our commitment to continuous improvement.
Since Vontier was part of Fortive during the third quarter, the financial results we'll discuss today include the Vontier businesses.
The guidance we provide today will only cover Fortive's continuing operations.
Let's now examine the details of the quarter.
Adjusted net earnings increased by 8.8% to $338.5 million compared to last year, with adjusted diluted net earnings per share at $0.94.
Total sales grew by 2.3% to $1.9 billion, with core revenue remaining essentially flat, showing significant sequential improvement from the previous quarter.
Acquisitions contributed 220 basis points of growth, while favorable foreign currency exchange rates added 20 basis points to growth.
Third quarter adjusted gross margins increased by 50 basis points year-over-year to 51.8%.
Gross margins benefited from a 50 basis point price increase, increased contribution from our higher-margin software businesses, and disciplined supply chain management.
We also achieved 160 basis points of core operating margin expansion, resulting in an adjusted operating profit margin of 22.7% for the quarter.
Our ability to drive strong core operating margin expansion despite ongoing pandemic-related challenges reflected our teams' solid execution and disciplined application of FBS.
We continue to effectively manage the business through this uncertain environment, adjusting cost actions as needed while investing in our strategic product development and innovation priorities to position us well for the future.
In the third quarter, we generated $455 million of free cash flow, representing a conversion rate of 134% of adjusted net earnings and a 31% increase year-over-year.
This performance brought our year-to-date free cash flow to approximately $1.1 billion, representing a year-over-year increase of about 48%.
Despite a challenging environment in recent quarters, our operating companies continue to use FBS to effectively manage their working capital in the short term, improving inventory turns and minimizing headwinds from the sequentially improving top line.
Let's now look at our segments.
Professional Instrumentation reported a total revenue increase of 0.9% despite a 3.5% decline in core revenue.
Purchases added 3.7 percentage points, while favorable currency exchange boosted growth by 0.7 percentage points.
The core operating margin rose by 0.9 percentage points, leading to an adjusted segment operating margin of 22.8%.
Industrial Technologies had a strong third quarter, particularly due to the performance of Gilbarco Veeder-Root and Matco in North America.
Overall revenue grew by 4.5%, with core revenue increasing by 5.5%.
The core operating margin improved by 2.9 percentage points, resulting in a segment-level adjusted operating margin of 25.9%.
The growth rates presented in the slide reflect Fortive's consolidated Q3 growth, including the results from Vontier businesses.
However, we will primarily discuss the operational details of the businesses remaining with Fortive.
In Asia, core revenue decreased slightly despite China experiencing mid-single-digit growth.
China's strength was widespread, with Fluke growing mid-teens year-over-year, Advanced Sterilization Products seeing double-digit growth, and Sensing expanding by over 20%.
Western Europe's core revenue declined by mid-single digits in Q3, with ASP showing low double-digit growth.
ASP has shown year-over-year growth in each quarter of 2020 so far, due to effective sales strategies.
Accruent also performed well in Western Europe, led by its Meridian engineering information management solution, reflecting the company's growing momentum in the region.
Although point-of-sale remained negative for both Fluke and Tektronix, the trend improved throughout the quarter, with revenue at these businesses increasing by mid-teens compared to the previous quarter.
North America's core revenue grew slightly in Q3, showing broad-based sequential improvement compared to Q2.
Growth in North America was primarily driven by a strong performance from the Vontier businesses.
Within new Fortive, several software businesses continued to perform well, with growth seen in Intelex, eMaint, Censis, Industrial Scientific's iNet business, and Qualitrol.
Similar to Western Europe, Fluke and Tektronix saw improving point-of-sale trends, though still negative as we enter Q4.
In recent quarters, we have categorized our portfolio into groups based on their sensitivity to pandemic-related disruptions and resulting declines in end-market demand.
As depicted on Slide 11, the relative performance of these groups largely aligned with expectations for the quarter.
Group I, accounting for about 20% of new Fortive revenue in Q3, continued to demonstrate significant resilience, achieving low single-digit growth.
The group's performance was bolstered by strong contributions from software businesses, particularly Intelex, which saw high single-digit growth due to continued robust growth in North America and successful expansion into Western Europe.
Censis achieved low single-digit growth, supported by the momentum of its SaaS offerings.
Accruent benefited from the stability of its SaaS business, which saw a slight increase in the quarter with continued growth in annual recurring revenue due to improved retention and increased net retention.
Fluke Industrial Imaging had another strong quarter, though its growth slowed as some of the initial COVID-related demand began to stabilize.
Gordian experienced a slowdown in project work among state and local governments and higher education customers, resulting in a slight decline for the quarter.
Despite continued strong order flow, EMC saw a mid-teens decline due to certain COVID-related supply chain issues and some customer delays.
Group II, representing about 32% of new Fortive revenue in Q3, experienced a slight decline.
ISC's iNet subscription business grew by high single digits, while Fluke Health Solutions achieved mid-single-digit growth driven by ventilator tester demand and support from Landauer's high recurring revenue business model.
ASP reported a mid-single-digit decline due to decreased performance in North America and pressure in Japan, which experienced a resurgence of COVID cases and a corresponding reduction in elective procedures.
However, we are pleased to see this partially offset by strong growth in both China and Western Europe during the quarter.
We now estimate that elective procedures in the U.S. have returned to approximately 90% of pre-COVID levels, and to about 95% in both China and Europe.
Group III, accounting for about 12% of new Fortive in Q3, experienced a high single-digit decline in the quarter.
The Sensing portfolio experienced a decline in the mid-single digits, showing sequential improvement compared to the previous quarter.
The Sensing division saw positive results in semiconductors and electronics, as well as benefiting from COVID-related advantages in medical markets.
In Group III, Accruent's professional services and licenses segments continued to face negative impacts due to ongoing difficulties accessing customer locations.
Group IV, comprising about 36% of new Fortive Q3 revenue, saw a decrease in the high single digits but demonstrated significant sequential improvement, surpassing expectations.
Fluke Industrial and the Tektronix Instruments business both exhibited widespread sequential improvement.
Fluke Industrial experienced a slight decline in the low single digits, led by Fluke Calibration, which achieved mid-single-digit growth.
Keithley, part of the Tek Instruments business, stood out by recording mid-single-digit year-over-year growth.
The business observed improved order activity as the quarter progressed, including initial orders for the new six and eight-channel versions of the six Series oscilloscope.
Although encouraged by the performance of Fluke Industrial and the Tektronix Instruments business in Q3, we remain cautious about key macro trends as we work towards returning to year-over-year growth in both divisions.
We have continued to decrease our net debt since the end of Q2 using our strong free cash flow and the proceeds from the Vontier separation.
Our net debt has been reduced to approximately $2.8 billion from over $5.1 billion at the end of 2019, including the recent proceeds from Vontier.
We anticipate generating solid free cash flow in the future, allowing us to further reduce our net debt.
We plan to monetize our remaining 19.9% stake in Vontier in a tax-efficient manner, with timing dependent on market conditions.
While Q3 showed continued improvement in operating performance since the lifting of economic lockdowns in spring, we remain vigilant about macro conditions due to the ongoing fight against COVID-19.
For Q4, we project total revenue to increase between 0% and 3% year-over-year.
We expect to achieve incremental margins of about 35%.
We plan to implement approximately $30 million in strategic productivity initiatives before year-end, aligning with our previous expectation of making some temporary actions permanent as we enter 2021.
The resegmentation emphasizes our strong position in providing essential technologies for connected workflow solutions across various attractive markets.
This perspective helps frame our portfolio strategy for both organic and inorganic opportunities.
The Intelligent Operating Solutions segment includes Fluke, Industrial Scientific, Intelex, Accruent, and Gordian, representing about 40% of new Fortive total revenue and addressing a market exceeding $15 billion.
The Precision Technologies segment comprises Tektronix, Pacific Scientific EMC, Sensing businesses, and Qualitrol, representing approximately 35% of new Fortive total revenue and addressing a market over $10 billion.
The Advanced Health Care Solutions segment includes Advanced Sterilization Products, Fluke Health Solutions, Censis, and Invetech, representing about 25% of new Fortive total revenue and addressing a market exceeding $5 billion.
We will report based on this new segmentation from Q4 onward and plan to release supplemental financial information to help you adjust your models.
I want to express gratitude to the Fortive and Vontier teams for their continued effort and strong execution in 2020 despite the challenging year.
Our Q3 performance demonstrated how our team continues to meet challenges, completing Vontier spin-off preparations while navigating a difficult macro environment to deliver improved top-line performance and strong free cash flow.
Despite near-term uncertainties, we will benefit from our increasingly resilient portfolio, established through efforts to transform it over the past four years.
With consistent free cash flow, a strong M&A pipeline, and expanding organic innovation capabilities, we are well-positioned to capitalize on future opportunities.
Summary:
output:
compname posts qtrly rev from continuing oper up 2.3% to $1.9 bln.
qtrly diluted net earnings per share from continuing operations $0.61; qtrly revenue from continuing operations up 2.3% to $1.9 billion.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Jim Owens, President and CEO of H.B. Fuller, and John Corkrean, Executive VP and CFO, are our presenters today.
We'd like to remind you that our remarks today will include mentions of organic revenue, which doesn't account for currency exchange effects on our earnings or the impact of buying or selling businesses.
We think discussing these metrics is valuable for investors to help them understand our operational performance and how we stack up against other firms.
Unless stated otherwise, when we talk about sales and revenue, we mean organic revenue, and when we discuss EPS, margins, or EBITDA, we're referring to adjusted non-GAAP figures.
COVID-19 and its effect on the global economy and business environment have intensified many of these risks and uncertainties.
Yesterday evening, we announced another quarter of robust revenue and profit growth.
In the second quarter, organic revenues grew by 19% compared to last year, adjusted EBITDA increased by 21%, and adjusted earnings per share rose by 38% to $0.94.
We successfully navigated significant supply chain challenges and swiftly increased prices during the quarter.
We achieved our highest-ever quarterly revenue as we met growing customer demand and expanded our market share.
During the quarter, H.B. Fuller faced shortages in raw materials and containers, but thanks to strong support and worldwide collaboration with key suppliers, as well as the creativity of our technical and supply chain teams, we ensured our customers remained supplied.
H.B. Fuller's ability to guarantee the supply of essential adhesives and provide innovative solutions that meet customer needs continues to be a competitive advantage for our company, as evidenced by our top-line growth.
H.B. Fuller's revenue growth was widespread across all segments and geographical regions.
Compared to the second quarter of 2020, organic revenues increased in each segment, with strong double-digit growth in both Engineering and Construction Adhesives segments, and solid growth in Hygiene, Health and Consumable Adhesives, despite a very strong second quarter in 2020.
Revenues also grew in each geographical area, with organic growth of 19% in the Americas, 27% in EMEA, and 9% in the Asia-Pacific region.
Notably, our revenues have also surpassed pre-COVID levels.
Compared to the second quarter of 2019, which was unaffected by COVID-19, total organic revenues increased by 9.5%, with double-digit growth in HHC and Engineering Adhesives and mid-single-digit growth in Construction Adhesives.
The quarter's strong volume leverage, combined with pricing benefits and operational efficiencies we're implementing in the business, offset significantly higher raw material costs and led to a 21% year-over-year increase in EBITDA dollars.
Raw material input costs rose by about 10% in the second quarter compared to the end of 2020, with some raw materials increasing more rapidly than we had anticipated.
We have implemented $150 million in annualized price adjustments so far and will implement an additional $75 million in the third quarter.
We are prepared to take further action if necessary.
These price adjustments will counteract the impact of raw material increases in this fiscal year.
Suppliers have made significant progress in restoring capacity for the commodity and specialty chemicals we purchase.
However, the recovery rate going forward will likely be uneven until inventory levels are rebuilt to fully meet demand.
Our planning assumptions anticipate that the current supply volatility will decrease and pricing will begin to stabilize in the fourth quarter.
We now expect year-on-year raw material inflation to exceed 10% and anticipate that our pricing will fully offset raw material increases by the end of the third quarter.
We anticipate gross margin headwinds in the third quarter, which typically has slower volumes, and we expect to see additional pricing and margin benefits in the fourth quarter, which is usually our strongest volume quarter.
Our global sourcing expertise, innovative chemistries, and operational agility were more crucial than ever this quarter and continue to provide a competitive edge.
The actions we've taken on pricing and to drive efficiencies across our business allowed us to seamlessly serve our customers and meet our profit targets for the quarter, while also increasing our debt reduction compared to last year, in line with our goal of $200 million in debt reduction for 2021.
Let's now examine the performance of each segment during the second quarter, as shown on Slide 4.
Hygiene, Health and Consumable Adhesives experienced a 3.3% year-over-year increase in organic sales for the second quarter, which is remarkable given the comparison to last year's robust quarter when the business saw 7% organic growth.
The majority of our HHC markets saw increased sales compared to the previous year, with notable growth in packaging applications, beverage labeling, multiwall bags, and tape and label.
HHC's segment EBITDA grew by 11%, surpassing the top-line growth, and EBITDA margin was impressive at 14.7%, showing a 70 basis point improvement from last year.
The margin enhancement was attributed to strong volume leverage, benefits from restructuring, and effective expense management.
Construction Adhesives reported a 23% increase in organic revenue compared to the previous year, with significant growth in both flooring and commercial roofing as market share gains and improving demand led to substantially better top-line performance than in 2020.
Compared to the strong, non-COVID affected second quarter of 2019, organic revenue still showed a 4% increase.
The impact of pricing adjustments implemented in this segment was not fully reflected in the second quarter due to the fulfillment of backlogged Construction Adhesives orders following the temporary disruption caused by Storm Uri.
We have observed increased pricing taking effect in the initial weeks of the third quarter and anticipate further pricing realization in the P&L throughout the remainder of the year.
Construction Adhesives EBITDA rose by 4% compared to last year, as robust volumes were counterbalanced by increased raw material costs, unfavorable mix, and some temporary manufacturing expenses required to restore normal service levels after the extreme weather event in the first quarter.
Engineering Adhesives delivered exceptionally strong results, with organic revenue growing by nearly 40% compared to last year, reflecting market share gains and improving end market demand.
Sales increased across all 14 of our Engineering Adhesives end markets compared to last year, with remarkable growth in adhesives for automotive, recreational vehicles, woodworking, electronics, and insulating glass.
Compared to the non-COVID affected second quarter of 2019, organic revenues showed an 11% increase.
We anticipate continued strength and double-digit full-year growth in this segment.
Engineering Adhesives' second quarter EBITDA grew by 42% year-on-year, driven by exceptional volume performance.
We expect EBITDA margins to improve in the coming quarters as pricing actions are fully implemented and offset the impact of raw material cost increases.
Looking ahead to our full-year results, we assume economies will continue to reopen as vaccines are distributed globally.
Raw materials are expected to remain tight for most of the year, with prices staying elevated as supply chains begin to normalize and demand remains strong.
We anticipate continued robust demand and market share gains in each of our business units, driving strong volume growth in 2021 compared to 2020.
Revenue in most of our end markets is expected to surpass 2019 levels.
Overall, considering our strategic pricing actions, combined with solid volume growth in HHC, ongoing improvement in Construction Adhesives, and strong demand in Engineering Adhesives, we now project full-year double-digit revenue growth compared to 2020.
Let's begin with Slide 5, which provides additional financial details for the second quarter.
Net revenue increased by 22.7% compared to the same period last year.
Currency had a positive impact of 3.9%.
Adjusting for currency, organic revenue grew by 18.8%, with volume up 17.4% and pricing up 1.4%, most of which was realized in the latter half of the quarter.
All three GBUs demonstrated strong growth compared to both 2020 and the non-COVID affected second quarter of 2019, which we believe validates the strength of our top-line performance.
When compared to Q2 2019, organic revenue increased by 9.5% for the entire company, with strong organic growth across all three GBUs.
Adjusted gross profit rose by 17.4% year-on-year, while gross profit margin decreased by 120 basis points as volume growth and pricing gains were offset by higher raw material costs.
Adjusted SG&A expenses decreased by 130 basis points as a proportion of revenue, due to volume leverage, business reorganization savings, and overall cost management, counterbalanced by increased variable compensation compared to the previous year.
Overall, the adjusted operating income margin saw a 20 basis point improvement year-over-year.
Net interest expenses reduced by $1.3 million, attributed to lower debt levels.
The quarter's adjusted effective income tax rate was 26.8%, down from 27.6% in the same period last year.
Quarterly adjusted EBITDA of $122 million increased by 21% compared to the same period last year, propelled by robust volume growth, price increases, and restructuring savings, partially offset by higher raw material costs and variable compensation.
Adjusted earnings per share rose by 38% to $0.94 compared to the second quarter of last year, reflecting strong income growth and reduced interest expense due to debt reduction.
Operating cash flow in the first half of the year was $80 million, compared to $108 million in the same period last year, due to working capital requirements supporting strong top-line performance and increased raw material costs.
We continue to reduce our debt, repaying $62 million in the first half of 2021 compared to $51 million during the same period last year, keeping us on track for our annual debt reduction goal of $200 million.
Regarding our future outlook, based on current information, we now anticipate full-year revenue growth to be in the low double-digits.
We maintain our previously increased adjusted EBITDA guidance range of $455 million to $475 million, considering our expectations for continued strong volume growth and accelerating pricing offsetting raw material cost increases, which we now expect to surpass 10% for the fiscal year.
Given our business seasonality and the timing of raw material and price increases, we expect third-quarter revenues to increase by about 15% compared to the third quarter of 2020, maintaining strong top-line growth.
EBITDA margin in the third quarter is projected to be approximately 100 basis points lower than the second quarter sequentially.
As pricing actions are fully implemented, margins are expected to improve in the fourth quarter, which is also our strongest quarter in terms of volume.
We anticipate strong cash flow for the remainder of the year, allowing us to maintain our goal of reducing debt by approximately $200 million during 2021.
During our previous conference call, I outlined three critical priorities for 2021 in the current supply-constrained, inflationary COVID recovery environment.
These priorities are volume growth, pricing strategy, and increased productivity, and we performed well against each of these key imperatives in the second quarter.
Our primary focus is to drive volume growth by supporting our customers in the current high-demand and supply-constrained environment.
Volume growth and market share gains are fundamental to creating lasting shareholder value.
Our 19% second quarter organic revenue growth is particularly impressive considering our HHC business had a strong 7% organic growth in the second quarter last year.
Overall, our business grew 9.5% compared to pre-COVID levels in the second quarter of 2019.
Our second imperative is to strategically manage pricing, aligned with the value we provide, in this inflationary environment.
We implemented $150 million in price increases, effective from March 1 through July 15, and we're planning an additional $75 million in price increases later in Q3.
We are also fulfilling our third priority to increase productivity and capacity through our operational excellence programs.
In the second quarter, we outperformed competitors and supported customers, while our factory labor and overhead costs as a percentage of revenue decreased compared to the same quarter last year.
COVID-19 has transformed business operations, and supply constraints and pricing volatility are challenges affecting our industry today.
In this environment, H.B Fuller's strategic priorities, the advantages of our robust global operations and supply chain, our collaborative culture and market-based innovation, and the speed and agility we've developed across our company are delivering results for our customers and shareholders.
We will continue to navigate the challenges of a constrained supply environment, grow our business, and strengthen our leadership position in the global adhesive industry while delivering strong results for our customers and shareholders.
Let's now open the call for questions.
Summary:
output:
q2 adjusted earnings per share $0.94.
full year 2021 revenue growth is anticipated to be in low double-digits versus 2020.
full year adjusted ebitda in range of $455 million to $475 million remains unchanged.
expects 2021 raw material cost increases to exceed 10% on a full year basis versus 2020.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Bill Furman, Greenbrier's executive chairman, Lorie Tekorius, CEO and president, Brian Comstock, executive vice president and chief commercial and leasing officer, and Adrian Downes, senior vice president and CFO, are accompanying me today.
Recent weeks have been eventful both globally and at Greenbrier.
Lorie Tekorius took on the role of Greenbrier's CEO on March 1st.
Our board of directors recently appointed Lorie as our newest board member.
As we commence today's call, I'd like to extend my congratulations to Lorie on her new positions at Greenbrier.
We take pride in how the board has managed this significant transition at Greenbrier.
I'm glad to continue serving as executive chairman for the remainder of our fiscal year and as a board member and investor until 2024.
Lorie's appointment has increased our board's gender diversity, with four out of eleven directors now being female.
Additionally, three of our directors identify as people of color.
Although Omicron continues to affect our operations, as you'll hear today, the situation is improving significantly.
Just as those impacts begin to accumulate, the conflict in Ukraine has affected economies in all our operational areas.
We're witnessing a terrible tragedy, and I hope for a quick resolution to the conflict and an end to human suffering.
While the war presents short-term challenges for everyone, it also creates opportunities for major changes in freight routes and transportation networks that will benefit Greenbrier's business as the world enters a new order.
Historical evidence shows the crucial role of railroads in supporting civilian life and economies, especially during wartime.
The ongoing war in Europe has directly impacted the availability and cost of various commodities, from minerals to food, fertilizer, crude oil, coal, and natural gas.
Railways and their suppliers will play a key role in maintaining civilian life and economic function during this crisis.
Commodity markets typically serve as leading indicators for growth in rail freight.
Most rail-transported commodities are experiencing upward price pressure due to sanctions on Russia or reduced production from Russia and Ukraine.
We anticipate that rising global commodity prices and shifting trade patterns will boost railcar demand in North America, Brazil, and other parts of the world.
Evolving energy policies in North America and Western Europe are already creating opportunities for rail transport of oil, ethanol, and other products.
A similar impact is expected for fertilizers and other food production necessities.
Lastly, rising diesel costs present a significant opportunity for a shift from road to rail transport.
Rail freight is one of the most sustainable and fuel-efficient modes of surface transportation.
U.S. freight trains with diesel-electric power generation are three to four times more fuel-efficient than trucks.
Consider this: one ton of freight can be transported by rail for nearly 500 miles on a single gallon of fuel.
Moreover, transporting freight by train instead of truck reduces greenhouse gas emissions by up to 75% per ton-mile and lessens congestion and wear on roads and bridges.
As more freight moves to rail, this may lead to longer railcar dwell times and reduced railroad speed in many cases.
In turn, railroad congestion necessitates more railcars to improve railroad service efficiency, notwithstanding the expected increase in demand for major commodities like fertilizer, food products, and other goods.
We acknowledge the role and responsibility our industry must fulfill during times of crisis and as the geopolitical landscape changes.
The cruel irony of this war in Ukraine is that there will ultimately be beneficiaries.
While we can't choose the external factors that affect our business, we must always be prepared to face the challenges and seize the opportunities that come with them.
Greenbrier has demonstrated its ability to thrive in adversity and capitalize on opportunities.
I'm confident this legacy will continue under Lorie's leadership for years to come.
I'll now hand over the call to Lorie to discuss our strong performance this quarter.
Before delving into our quarterly results, I'd like to express my appreciation to Bill and the rest of the Greenbrier Board for the opportunity to serve as CEO.
We have an exceptional team at Greenbrier who work diligently and intelligently every day.
Although it's challenging to predict specific opportunities or challenges that may arise, I'm confident that the Greenbrier team has the experience, knowledge, and determination to make the most of any situation while focusing on increasing shareholder value.
Greenbrier achieved strong results in this second quarter.
Despite not all of our operating segments performing as expected, our highly diverse business performed very well overall.
We delivered 4,800 railcar units this quarter, a 17% increase from the previous quarter, driven by our core North American market.
Our lease fleet utilization rose to 98%, and our leasing team generated substantial cash proceeds and gains through regular lease fleet optimization and monetization transactions.
Our leasing business is surpassing our expectations as we achieve growth at scale.
We achieved our strong quarterly performance as the Omicron variant of COVID-19 reached its peak in the United States.
Tragically, in February, we lost Charles Wallace, a long-time employee in our maintenance services group, to COVID.
Charles leaves behind a son and four sisters.
We extend our sympathies to them in their time of grief.
Additionally, we faced significant staff shortages this quarter as roughly 12% of our employees contracted the virus.
Lately, the number of infections has decreased, and we're optimistic that the pandemic's worst phase is now over.
Our manufacturing gross margin percentage fell short of our expectations this quarter, affected by challenges in the supply chain and workforce.
Our global procurement team continues to excel in managing severe disruptions to maintain increasing production rates while minimizing delays.
We have managed to avoid any production line closures across our network due to material shortages.
Extra costs were incurred to source materials on the spot market and expedite deliveries.
Business momentum is growing, and we anticipate better performance in upcoming quarters due to improved pricing and overhead absorption on higher production levels.
The situation in Europe is uncertain.
The time before and after the outbreak of war in Ukraine has created a highly unstable environment for many European manufacturers.
Our operations have been affected by rapidly increasing energy costs and now finished steel and components in our supply chain.
Ukraine and Russia are among the largest providers of iron ore, finished steel, and wheelsets to European mines and welders.
As Bill pointed out, railways play a crucial role in supporting the economy during wartime.
Our leadership team is collaborating with our customers and suppliers to maintain production and ensure the best outcomes for all involved parties.
Our maintenance service business continued to be affected by higher material costs and labor shortages during the quarter, with the omicron variant having a particularly strong impact on the network of smaller workforces.
We are starting to see improved financial results from the action plan implemented to address these challenges in Q1.
We expect to maintain our momentum in the latter half of the year as we stay focused on executing our plans while also seeking additional ways to cut costs and improve margins.
Our leasing and management services division had another successful quarter, driven by higher fleet utilization and regular asset optimization and monetization transactions.
Our owned fleet has increased by over 25% since the end of fiscal 2021 to approximately 11,000 units.
In addition to managing our lease fleet, our management services, or GMS group, continues to offer innovative railcar solutions for over 25% of the North American rail freight fleet.
Within GMS, we're initiating a project to upgrade the service platform used to manage equipment and data.
One of the aims of this important project is to ensure scalable support for our leasing and syndication business as well as our external customers as we continue to implement our leasing strategy.
Looking forward, we anticipate strong operating momentum to continue throughout fiscal 2022 and beyond.
We've managed to maintain our market-leading positions through disciplined execution and by preserving our strong liquidity position.
These were key aspects of our management team's plans at the beginning of the pandemic and they continue to serve us well.
There's no question that the market environment will remain dynamic, especially with the war in Europe.
Inflation, supply chain issues, and the ongoing human impact of the pandemic will persist for some time.
We are managing the business accordingly and maintain our optimistic market outlook.
We expect our operating metrics to continue improving as we progress through the next several quarters and beyond.
As we've mentioned before, market recoveries won't follow a straight path, and there will be obstacles along the way.
We're managing our business to anticipate these challenges wherever possible to continue providing solutions to our customers and ultimately, deliver value to our shareholders.
As I've said before, our leadership team has the experience, knowledge, and determination to make the most of any situation.
With that, I'll pass the call to Brian Comstock to provide an update on the current railcar demand environment and our leasing activity.
Greenbrier secured new railcar orders for 8,500 units valued at $930 million.
With deliveries of 4,800 units in the quarter, the book-to-bill ratio increased to 1.8 times.
Orders for the first half of the year have already surpassed 85% of fiscal 2021 activity.
The new railcar backlog of 32,100 units has a market value of $3.6 billion and provides multi-year visibility.
This is Greenbrier's largest backlog in six years.
Historically, when our backlog reaches this level, it includes several multi-year orders.
In this instance, there are few multi-year orders, which demonstrates the strength of the overall demand environment.
From an operational standpoint, this means that a larger portion of our backlog is scheduled to enter production in the near term and translate to revenue sooner.
Additionally, as production space becomes more valuable, we anticipate multi-year orders to follow and pricing could continue to improve.
As a reminder, our new railcar backlog doesn't include 3,200 units valued at $180 million that are part of Greenbrier's refurbishment program.
Due to the large scale and nature of this work, it takes place at our manufacturing facility, absorbing production capacity while contributing to overhead absorption.
Our renovation initiative plays a crucial role in maintaining rail as the most eco-friendly form of land transportation.
We're thrilled about this expanding collaboration with our clients to sustainably modernize North America's aging rail vehicle inventory.
The fleet usage rate reached 98% by the end of the quarter.
Rental prices and conditions are progressively getting better, and we're observing high demand for both new and pre-owned leased equipment.
As a component of our improved leasing approach, GBX Leasing completed our first asset-backed securitization by issuing $323 million in investment-grade rated notes with an average interest rate of 2.9% and a projected repayment date of January 2029.
Our financial team performed exceptionally this quarter, syndicating 1,400 units, the highest level of activity in almost two years.
Syndication is a vital source of cash flow and earnings, and we anticipate continued robust syndication activity in the latter half of the year.
As many are aware, syndication and asset sales are crucial leasing activities that will continue to expand in the future.
Looking forward, I remain positive about the building momentum, particularly given the strong demand environment in North America.
Greenbrier is in an excellent position for a period of robust growth.
I believe the combination of market dynamics, our focused management team's ability to capitalize on them, and their experience will yield results in this early stage of the railcar cycle that are significantly better than previous cycles.
Today, I will highlight the quarter's achievements and reaffirm our guidance for the 2022 fiscal year.
Second-quarter highlights include $683 million in revenue, delivery of 4,800 units, including 400 units from our unconsolidated joint venture in Brazil.
The overall gross margin of 8% reflects ongoing effects from ramping up new railcar production, the impact of the omicron variant, efforts to mitigate supply chain and labor shortages, and an additional warranty provision for certain older railcars.
Selling and administrative expenses of about $55 million increased sequentially, reflecting higher employee-related costs, consulting, travel, and legal expenses due to increased business activity.
We realized a $25 million net gain from equipment sales.
This activity was part of our ongoing strategy to optimize and monetize our leasing portfolio.
Non-controlling interest provided a $1.6 million benefit, mainly due to the impact of production line changes and ramp-ups at our Mexican joint venture.
This showed improvement sequentially, and we expect our Mexican JV to be profitable in the second half of the year.
Net earnings attributable to Greenbrier were approximately $13 million or $0.38 per diluted share, with EBITDA of about $52 million or 7.6% of revenue.
During the quarter, we incurred $2.1 million in gross costs specifically related to COVID-19 employee and facility safety measures.
This expense increased by almost 75% sequentially and was our highest level in the last 12 months.
Greenbrier's liquidity grew to $804 million at the end of Q2, comprising $587 million in cash and $217 million in available borrowings.
Our strong balance sheet positions us well to navigate any market conditions.
We anticipate receiving a large portion of our $106 million tax refund in fiscal Q4, reflecting processing delays at the IRS.
This refund will be in addition to Greenbrier's existing cash and borrowing capacity.
During and shortly after the quarter, Greenbrier entered into additional interest rate swaps to fix long-term floating rate debt for the next several years, reducing the risk of rising interest expenses in an increasing interest rate environment.
By the end of the second quarter, effectively all of our outstanding leasing debt was at fixed interest rates, and approximately 90% of our corporate non-leasing long-term debt was fixed.
Combined with executing over $2 billion of new and refinanced borrowing facilities over the past year, including the ABS lease financing completed in Q2, this puts Greenbrier in a strong position moving forward.
On March 31, Greenbrier's board of directors declared a $0.27 per share dividend, our 32nd consecutive dividend.
Based on yesterday's closing price, our annual dividend represents a yield of approximately 2.3%.
Since reinstating the dividend in 2014, Greenbrier has returned nearly $380 million of capital to shareholders through dividends and share repurchases.
Based on current business trends and production schedules, we're reaffirming Greenbrier's fiscal year 2022 outlook to include: deliveries of 17,500 to 19,500 units, including approximately 1,500 units from Greenbrier-Maxion in Brazil.
As a reminder, in fiscal 2022, approximately 1,400 units are expected to be built and added to our lease fleet.
These units are not included in the delivery guidance provided.
We consider a railcar delivered when it leaves Greenbrier's balance sheet and is owned by an external third party.
Selling and administrative expense guidance remains unchanged and is expected to be approximately $200 million to $210 million.
Gross capital expenditures are projected to be approximately $275 million in leasing and management services, $55 million in manufacturing, and $10 million in maintenance services.
Net of proceeds on equipment sales of $150 million, leasing capex is expected to be $125 million.
Gross margin percentage is anticipated to increase sequentially in Q3 and Q4, with Q4 margins between low double digits and low teens.
In conclusion, I want to echo the sentiments expressed by our colleagues earlier.
Specifically, Greenbrier will successfully navigate the challenges we face in the second half of the fiscal year.
Greenbrier's highest backlog in more than half a decade, ample liquidity, and strong balance sheet make this possible.
Despite the lingering effects of the multi-year pandemic and the impacts of war on an already stressed global supply chain, we are better positioned than ever to achieve our ambitious goals.
Summary:
output:
q2 earnings per share $0.38.
q2 revenue $683 million.
sees 2022 deliveries of 17,500 - 19,500 units including about 1,500 units in greenbrier-maxion.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:I am called Matt Eichmann.
Pete Watson, Greif's president and CEO, Larry Hilsheimer, Greif's CFO, and Ole Rosgaard, Greif's COO, are accompanying me.
Questions will be accepted at the conclusion of today's call.
To comply with Regulation Fair Disclosure, please inquire about matters you deem significant, as we are not permitted to discuss material non-public information with you individually.
Kindly restrict yourself to a single question and one follow-up before rejoining the queue.
The actual outcomes may vary significantly from those discussed.
We value your interest in Greif, as always.
The group achieved outstanding results despite a challenging operating environment complicated by the pandemic, supply chain issues, and inflation beyond our control.
The 2021 fiscal year was remarkable, with record-breaking financial performance.
We substantially reduced our debt, enhanced shareholder returns, attained top-tier employee engagement, and were acknowledged as a premier workplace in the US.
Looking forward, these achievements position us for an even brighter future, with our fiscal 2022 guidance indicating performance aligned with the commitments we set in 2019.
Lastly, over the past year, we made significant improvements to our already robust sustainability performance and have further integrated ESG into our business strategies.
I'd like to invite Ole Rosgaard, our chief operating officer, to share some thoughts on ESG, which can be found on Slide 4.
I trust you and your loved ones are doing well.
In my view, sustainability isn't an afterthought or corporate function, but a leadership priority that generates business value by minimizing risks and costs while creating new growth opportunities.
We reached several notable ESG milestones in 2021.
For instance, we diverted at least 90% of waste from landfills at over 140 of our global facilities, boosting our global diversion rate to approximately 85% from about 70% the previous year.
Even more impressively, by year-end, 50 of our global facilities had achieved zero waste to landfill status.
We introduced our fourth Colleague Resource Group to offer professional development opportunities and further cultivate a more diverse and inclusive culture across Greif.
Lastly, we connected ESG KPIs to the Greif business system, enhancing our performance management capability to further advance this crucial work.
The key takeaway is that Greif's strong ESG focus is central to our plans for sustainable value creation.
I'm eager to share additional highlights with you in the future.
Now, I'll hand it back to Pete to discuss our business results on Slide 5.
The global industrial packaging division delivered exceptional fourth quarter results.
Our overall global primary product line was robust and boosted sales by nearly 3% compared to the previous year.
EMEA and ongoing recovery in our industrial end markets.
Global steel drum volume decreased by 1.5% per day compared to the previous year.
The largest decline was in APAC, reflecting our decision to implement strategic pricing actions and supply chain disruptions that negatively affected our customers' operations.
Fourth quarter global steel drum volume was also impacted by performance in EMEA where volumes remained steady through most of the quarter but slowed in October as customers in this region encountered their own supply chain challenges.
The Americas region recorded strong mid-single-digit growth during the quarter.
Generally, our industrial end markets remain healthy.
Customers report solid order backlogs and strong underlying demand, but they face external supply chain disruptions.
Across GIP, we see little evidence of customers building inventory, but some are carrying more stock than usual due to supply chain disruptions affecting their ability to ship to their customers.
GIP's generally higher volumes and increased average selling prices led to significantly higher segment sales and gross profit year over year.
GIP's fourth quarter adjusted EBITDA increased by approximately $47 million due to higher sales, partially offset by increased raw material, manufacturing, and transportation costs.
The business also benefited from a $3 million FX tailwind.
Looking ahead, we anticipate GIP's fiscal 2022 profits to be lower year over year, although we expect volume growth, contributions from new capex projects, and beneficial efficiency gains.
Earnings will decrease due to the exceptional rise in steel prices providing a one-time benefit of approximately $100 million to GIP's fiscal 2021 results, which won't happen again
We expect GIP's usual profit pattern throughout the year to continue
Sales in paper packaging for the fourth quarter increased by about $120 million compared to the previous year, driven by higher volumes and increased published prices for containerboard and boxboard
Adjusted EBITDA grew by approximately $10 million compared to the previous year, due to higher sales that were largely offset by increased costs in raw materials, manufacturing, and transportation, including a significant $51 million impact from higher OCC index costs and an unexpected $8 million increase in natural gas costs
The company received a one-time benefit of $4 million from a legal settlement reported in SG&A, which won't recur
Demand for our paper products remains robust, with our combined mill backlogs exceeding eight weeks
Our CorrChoice sheet feeder system experienced a 2.4% increase in fourth quarter volumes compared to the previous year
Demand for durables, e-commerce, and the automotive supply chain for OEMs remains strong, with no signs of slowing down
Tube and core volumes in the fourth quarter increased by 7% per day compared to the previous year
Most key end markets, including film, paper cores, textiles, and protective packaging, showed strong demand
For fiscal 2022, we anticipate significantly higher profits in paper packaging due to strong demand and continued implementation of published price increases
Overall, our team delivered outstanding fourth quarter results despite significant external challenges
Fourth quarter net sales, excluding foreign exchange effects, increased by 35% compared to the same quarter last year due to higher volumes and selling prices
Adjusted EBITDA increased by $57 million, including a $7 million combined benefit from foreign exchange and a one-time legal settlement
It's worth noting that our adjusted EBITDA result was achieved despite a $51 million OCC index headwind and approximately $40 million in non-volume related transportation and manufacturing inflation, including an unexpected $8 million natural gas cost increase
Interest expenses decreased by $9 million compared to the same quarter last year due to lower debt balances
We also benefited from reaching a lower interest rate tier in our credit facility as a result of our substantial debt repayments
Both our fourth quarter GAAP and non-GAAP tax rates were approximately 11%
Fourth quarter adjusted Class A earnings per share more than doubled to $1.93 per share
