For fiscal 2021, we achieved adjusted Class A earnings per share of $5.60, a 74% improvement over the previous year and significantly exceeding our Q3 guidance
Part of the earnings improvement was due to a lower-than-expected non-GAAP tax rate of 18.1%, which benefited from reserve releases due to audit settlements and statute of limitation expirations
We estimate that the lower tax rate compared to our guidance contributed $0.15 to fiscal 2021 results
The majority of our year-over-year earnings improvement came from disciplined operational execution
Fourth quarter adjusted free cash flow decreased by approximately $79 million compared to the previous year
Although profits improved significantly, capital expenditures increased and working capital negatively impacted cash flow, primarily due to higher-than-anticipated raw material costs
Working capital was also negatively affected by lower-than-expected October volumes outside the U.S., as customers faced external challenges and ordered fewer drums
Nevertheless, our team is managing what it can control, with strong results and a significant 140 basis point improvement in trailing 12-month average working capital as a percentage of sales, decreasing to 10.8% year-over-year
Our main capital priorities remain consistent: invest in the business as needed to create value and support growth, provide shareholders with an attractive and growing dividend, and reduce our debt while maintaining a compliance leverage ratio between 2 and 2.5 turns
Our financial position is solid
We plan to invest between $150 million and $170 million in capital expenditures for fiscal 2022 and aim to increase our dividend in 2022, as mentioned in previous calls
We are currently in our strategic planning process to determine the focus and extent of future growth activities to responsibly leverage our strong financial position for the benefit of our shareholders
We are pleased to introduce fiscal 2022 guidance that fulfills the commitments we made over two years ago
Our guidance reflects the significant improvements we've made in our core business over the past few years, including the successful integration of Caraustar and realization of synergies, and demonstrates Greif's resilience in overcoming unforeseen and substantial external challenges posed by COVID and dramatic inflationary pressures beyond our control
At the midpoint, we expect to generate $6.15 of adjusted Class A earnings per share in 2022
Overall, we anticipate that lower profits in GIP in fiscal 2022 will be more than offset by higher profitability and EPS, once again highlighting the advantage of our diversified portfolio
Interest expenses will be significantly lower in fiscal 2022 due to our aggressive debt reduction, and we expect further improvements when we refinance our 6.5% 2027 senior notes sometime in the first half of calendar year 2022
We project adjusted free cash flow for 2022 to be between $400 million and $460 million
Along with higher capital spending, we expect a substantial increase in cash tax for fiscal '21, primarily due to greater pre-tax earnings.
We expect working capital to become a source of cash again.
In 2021, it consumed $222 million as the cost of raw materials rapidly increased.
Let me share some thoughtful observations for you to ponder.
In my view, today's Greif is vastly different from the company it was six years ago.
Our profit margins have become more stable and grown, our earnings have significantly increased, and we've been praised for improving our transparency and communication.
We've maintained a consistent, disciplined, and predictable approach to capital allocation.
We've fulfilled our promises and continue to create greater value for our shareholders.
Despite these improvements, our stock still trades at a discount compared to our historical valuations and the broader market.
For instance, using our historical free cash flow yield of 11% and the midpoint of our 2022 free cash flow guidance would suggest a total market value of about $3.9 billion, which is roughly 30% higher than our current valuation.
While we can't control our stock price, we believe our company deserves more attention given the current discount in our shares.
I'm going to deviate from my prepared remarks for a moment.
As most or all of you know, this is Pete Watson's final earnings call.
Pete exemplifies leadership and has formed personal connections with many Greif employees through direct interaction.
He's a modest and respected leader who draws on his background in athletic coaching to build a unified team.
When Pete took over leadership at Greif, many aspects of the company were in disarray.
Since becoming CEO in November 2015, the results have been remarkable.
Safety has steadily improved, and employee engagement has dramatically increased, placing us in the top 10% of Gallup's industrial sector.
These engaged employees have provided outstanding customer service and driven a significant improvement, doubling our Net Promoter Scores during this time.
This focus on the virtuous service profit chain has led to exceptional financial improvements.
From 2015 to 2021, [inaudible] and EBITDA have roughly doubled.
Adjusted EBITDA earnings per share has increased from $2.18 to $5.60 without any stock buybacks.
Adjusted free cash flow, which was $70 million in 2015, has averaged nearly $300 million in the last three years and will surpass $400 million in 2022.
Pete has worked diligently to ensure a smooth succession plan, leaving Greif in capable hands going forward, securing his legacy as an outstanding leader.
You certainly did deviate from the script, and it's much appreciated.
Thank you, Larry, for your comments and thoughts.
You're a good person.
As Larry mentioned, this is my last earnings call as President and CEO of Greif.
It's a great company, and it's been my honor to serve our global Greif team.
I'm extremely proud of what we've accomplished together over the past six years, as Larry described.
I'm incredibly grateful to all our colleagues for their passion, dedication to excellence, and commitment to our team and customers.
While fiscal 2021 was a record year for our company, I'm even more excited about what the future holds.
We're well-positioned to benefit from ongoing strength and improving trends in our key markets, and our extensive global portfolio, differentiated service capabilities, and focus on operational execution allow us to best serve our customers' needs and generate significant shareholder value.
The board and I are confident in Ole Rosgaard's ability to lead Greif going forward.
His operational background, strategic mindset, and passion for team building and customer service will be beneficial to Greif's future.
I look forward to seeing the company thrive under his leadership.
It has been a pleasure working with all of you, and we appreciate your interest in Greif.
Summary:
output:
q4 earnings per share $1.93 excluding items.
sees fy 2022 adjusted free cash flow $400 million - $460 million.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Additional information that may be useful can be found on our website, where we have uploaded our conference call slides.
This quarter's revenue amounted to $367 million, representing a 14% decline compared to the same period last year.
Growth from acquisitions contributed two percentage points this quarter, while fluctuations in currency exchange rates reduced sales by about one percentage point.
The quarter's net earnings were $29 million, or $0.17 per diluted share, including $30 million or $0.20 related to impairment charges from the sale of the Alco business.
After accounting for the impairment and other tax adjustments, net earnings came to $62 million, or $0.37 per diluted share.
We began discussions to sell the U.K. valve business, Alco, which is heavily exposed to oil and natural gas markets, during the second quarter.
The Process segment includes Alco operations, which contributed $7 million in sales and $2 million in operating losses year-to-date.
Due to the sale negotiations, we reassessed our investment in Alco in the second quarter, resulting in non-cash impairment charges of $34 million after tax, including $24 million of previously unrecognized foreign currency translation losses recorded in accumulated other comprehensive income.
The $24 million loss reserve for previously unrecognized foreign currency translation is recorded as other current liability at the end of the second quarter and will be cleared through accumulated other comprehensive income in the third quarter, as the sale was completed in early July.
In the second quarter, our gross margin rate was 49.8%, about three percentage points lower than the same period last year.
This was mainly due to changes in product and channel mix, with increased sales in the Contractor segment and double-digit declines in the Industrial and Process segments, as well as reduced factory output and currency translation rate changes.
Pricing improvements were favorable.
Unabsorbed factory costs will continue to impact gross margin rates in the second half if sales volumes don't recover, although strong pricing improvements partially offset this effect.
Gross margin rates can be influenced by shifts in product and channel mix.
Our global procurement team has been collaborating closely with our supply chain to ensure continuous operation throughout the quarter.
We are closely monitoring the supply chain for certain components, which is under pressure due to growth in specific products in the Contractor segment, particularly those for the home center channel.
Excluding the impact of the impairment, operating expenses decreased by $12 million compared to the second quarter of last year, as reductions in volume and earnings-based expenses outweighed increased product development costs.
The reported income tax rate for the quarter was 31%, which is 13 percentage points higher than the same period last year, primarily due to non-deductible impairment charges.
After adjusting for the impairment effect, excess tax benefits from stock option exercises, and other non-recurring tax benefits, our tax rate for the quarter was 19%, one percentage point lower than last year.
Operational cash flows amounted to $143 million for the year so far, compared to $164 million in the previous year, due to decreased revenue.
Year-to-date capital investments reached $33 million as we continue to enhance our production capabilities and expand various facilities.
Dividend payments totaled $58 million year-to-date.
During the second quarter, we acquired a company for $27 million, which will be integrated into the Process division.
For the entire year of 2020, we anticipate capital expenditures to reach approximately $80 million, with about $50 million allocated for facility expansion projects.
This quarter, we bought back $17 million worth of shares, net of issuances, bringing our total net share repurchases to $62 million for the year.
We may consider additional opportunistic share buybacks in the future.
Let's discuss a few final points regarding the remainder of the year.
Our presentation's eleventh slide displays the six-week average bookings for each segment.
These booking averages cover the six weeks leading up to July 17.
Given current exchange rates and assuming similar volume, product mix, and sales distribution by currency as last year, we expect the exchange rate impact to be insignificant on sales but to negatively affect earnings by about one percent in 2020.
We project unallocated corporate expenses to be around $30 million for the full year 2020, with potential quarterly variations.
The expected effective tax rate for the full year is approximately 20% to 21%, excluding one-time items and any impact from excess tax benefits related to stock option exercises.
Considering the tumultuous second quarter, I'll focus my remarks on our operational status, strategic priorities, sales trends throughout the quarter, and provide some observations on end markets.
Our primary factories and distribution centers remained fully functional during the second quarter.
Employees at high risk stayed home, and we managed positive COVID-19 cases at various facilities without disrupting operations.
We've largely avoided layoffs or pay cuts by reducing temporary labor in certain factories and reassigning our workforce to areas of greater need.
All our major factories had sufficient work to keep our full-time employees productive.
Overall, I'm very impressed with the resilience our employees have demonstrated and continue to show throughout this pandemic.
We've maintained momentum on our growth strategies, as mentioned in our previous quarterly update.
Second quarter cost reductions were primarily due to variable expenses like rebates and incentives, decreased travel costs, and careful management of discretionary spending.
Our investment in future initiatives for 2021 and beyond has remained steady.
While this approach may impact our near-term financial performance, it will enable us to take advantage of improved market conditions when they occur.
Overall order trends showed sequential improvement throughout the quarter.
However, this improvement varied between different segments of our business.
Our Contractor business recovered strongly in June after a dismal April, resulting in modest growth for the quarter.
The professional paint channel saw improvement as paint stores reopened for in-person shopping.
The Home Center business has been exceptionally busy for most of the quarter, leading to operational challenges in meeting the surge in demand.
We anticipate a positive outlook for the Contractor business in the latter half of the year.
In contrast, our Industrial business only saw slight improvement following a significant downturn in April.
While access to customer facilities is gradually improving and we're seeing increased quoting activity in many sectors, we haven't yet observed a significant rebound in orders.
The global automotive industry is struggling, industrial production has decreased, the oil and gas sector is weak, and ongoing uncertainty is affecting most end users' willingness to invest in capital equipment.
The future of our Industrial segment remains uncertain, and I'm not particularly optimistic about its performance in the second half of the year.
Our Process business didn't experience as severe a decline in April.
Although it was down by double digits for the quarter, we've observed some positive trends in certain end markets.
Within this business, we have stronger performing sectors like semiconductor and environmental, as well as weaker ones such as our lubrication business, which has performed similarly to our Industrial segment.
Given the diverse range of end markets we serve, our outlook for the second half of the year remains uncertain.
I'm confident that our strategy of continuing to invest in growth initiatives, such as developing new products and entering new markets, will position us well to achieve strong results once conditions normalize.
We employed a similar strategy during the 2008-2009 economic crisis, which ultimately benefited our investors, and we aim to replicate this success.
Summary:
output:
qtrly earnings per share $0.17.
qtrly adjusted earnings per share $0.37.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:My name is Patrick Suehnholz and I serve as the head of investor relations at Greenhill.
Scott Bok, our chairman and CEO, will also be participating in this call.
These declarations are founded on our present expectations concerning future occurrences which, due to their nature, lie beyond the company's control and are susceptible to known and unknown risks, uncertainties, and suppositions.
To understand some of the risks and elements that could impact the company's future outcomes, please refer to our submissions to the Securities and Exchange Commission, including our yearly report on Form 10-K, quarterly reports on Form 10-Q, and current reports on Form 8-K.
We announced fourth-quarter earnings of $106.7 million, with a 39% operating margin and $1.05 per share in net income.
The company's full-year results showed revenue of $301 million, a 15% operating margin, and net income of $0.45 per share.
Our quarterly earnings increased by 20%, and our earnings per share grew by 133% compared to the same time last year.
For the entire year, our revenue decreased by 14%, and our earnings per share dropped by 68%.
Overall, we concluded the year strongly, yielding satisfactory full-year results in terms of both revenue and profit, aligning with our statements from recent quarterly investor discussions.
Although industry data indicates a reduction in global transaction activity compared to the previous year, and nearly all of our competitors have reported decreases in advisory revenue, the main reason for our reduced annual revenue was that lower earnings in Europe outweighed increases in North America, Australia, and other regions.
Regarding the types of advice we provide, we saw a significant boost in restructuring advisory revenue compared to recent years, as our newly expanded team gained more traction throughout the year.
Our capital advisory team performed well again, though it didn't reach the record revenue level of the previous year.
In terms of M&A, results were relatively robust almost everywhere except Europe.
Across industry sectors, we achieved good results in consumer products, financial services, and media, which were offset by weaker performance in energy, healthcare, and technology.
Regarding expenses, our compensation ratio for the year was 59%, slightly above our target due to lower annual revenue.
For the quarter, the compensation ratio was an unusually low 42% to balance out the exceptionally high ratios in the first two quarters of the year.
Our management goal, as always, is to achieve a reasonable compensation ratio for the entire year while ensuring our team receives competitive compensation relative to their individual performance.
Our non-compensation operating costs for the quarter totaled $21 million, exceeding last year's figure by $3.7 million due to foreign currency losses and a charge for an uncollectible account from a financially troubled client.
The annual non-compensation operating expenses remained relatively unchanged from the previous year, as unusual costs this year roughly equaled the accounting charge related to the Cogent acquisition earnout in the prior year.
We are closely tracking non-compensation expenses and aim to reduce the annual amount in 2020.
This quarter's interest expense decreased slightly compared to last year, as the cost of increased borrowing was offset by lower market interest rates and a reduced coupon premium following our advantageous refinancing in early 2019.
We anticipate a continued decline in our interest expenses in the future.
The effective tax rate was 33% for the quarter and 40% for the year.
Both periods' tax rates were adversely affected by an unusually low proportion of revenue and profit from lower-tax regions, particularly the U.K., and a higher proportion from higher-tax areas like Australia and Brazil.
The annual tax rate was further negatively impacted by an unfavorable difference between grant and market prices for vesting restricted stock units.
We anticipate the tax rate to generally remain in the mid-20% range in the future.
Regarding capital returns, we've been actively repurchasing shares, believing the market undervalues our earnings potential and noting our stock's lower valuation multiple compared to peers and historical levels.
We bought 1.5 million shares and equivalents at an average of $15.98 per share during the quarter.
Throughout the year, we acquired 3.8 million shares and equivalents at an average of $18.04 per share.
Our Board has approved $60 million for share and equivalent purchases in 2020, compared to $69 million spent in 2019.
So far this quarter, we've repurchased 345,723 common stock shares at an average of $16.47 per share, totaling $5.7 million, leaving $54.3 million in repurchase authority for the rest of the year.
We've also declared a quarterly dividend of $0.05 per share.
We concluded the year with $114 million in cash and $365.6 million in debt, resulting in a net debt of $251.6 million.
As of yesterday, our cash balance increased to $133.9 million despite January's additional share repurchases, while the debt amount remained unchanged.
Our principal debt payments are relatively small until our debt matures in 2024.
Given our business prospects, as outlined below, we aim to significantly reduce our debt in 2020 while also increasing share buybacks as mentioned earlier.
We begin 2020 with a positive outlook across all our business segments.
The climate for mergers and acquisitions appears promising in the regions that were successful for us in 2019, and our current European project pipeline suggests the potential for a substantial revenue increase there this year.
In restructuring advisory services, we concluded 2019 with significantly higher monthly retainer fees and a much larger backlog of projects expected to be completed in 2020.
Recent tightening of credit availability and rising costs for less creditworthy borrowers should also benefit this business segment.
In capital advisory, the ongoing growth of private equity funds and increased market liquidity for chief investment officers invested in these funds should create a favorable operating environment for that business as well.
I'll conclude with a brief overview of our strategy.
We continue to focus on building a business with more diverse revenue streams and higher overall revenue.
This was the rationale behind our acquisition of capital advisory specialist Cogent Partners nearly five years ago, the recent expansion of our restructuring advisory team, last year's growth in Singapore and France, and our ongoing recruitment of M&A specialists across various industry sectors.
Recruitment will remain crucial to our growth plans, as will the continued internal development of talent.
In the past year, we added a net five client-facing managing directors, bringing our total to 79, and increased our overall professional headcount by 11%.
We have all the necessary resources to continue successfully implementing our strategy.
Our culture makes our firm an excellent workplace, leading to both recruitment success and very high retention rates for top performers.
Our reputation for providing high-quality and independent advice has been established through decades of client service, and our team collectively owns 48% of the economic value of our firm through common stock and restricted stock, providing strong incentives to generate solid results and create value for all shareholders.
I'm now ready to answer any questions.
Summary:
output:
compname reports q4 earnings per share of $1.05.
compname reports fourth quarter earnings per share of $1.05 and full year earnings per share of $0.45.
q4 revenue $106.7 million versus refinitiv ibes estimate of $86.9 million.
board authorized up to $60 million of purchases of shares and share equivalents in 2020.
qtrly earnings per share $1.05.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:We truly value your time and interest in Graham Corporation today.
Dan Thoren, our president and CEO, and Jeff Glajch, our chief financial officer, are participating in this call with me.
You should have received the third quarter fiscal 2022 financial results, which were released moments ago.
The release and accompanying slides for our discussion can be accessed on our website, grahammanufacturing.com, or our new investor relations site, ir.grahamcorp.com.
These materials are also available on the SEC website.
We will discuss some non-GAAP financial measures during this call, which we believe are helpful in evaluating our performance.
We have provided reconciliations of these non-GAAP measures to comparable GAAP measures in the tables accompanying today's release and slides for your reference.
I'm beginning on Page 3.
As a new CEO who took on the role in September, presenting this fiscal third quarter's results is somewhat challenging.
While revenue increased to $28.8 million, we experienced a loss of $0.35 per share.
The loss stemmed from cost overruns on Navy projects at our Batavia operations, resulting from decisions made to ensure timely completion of crucial submarine and carrier projects.
These decisions, which prioritized long-term benefits over short-term gains, were carefully considered.
Our Navy business is crucial for our future, and we needed to protect it by demonstrating our commitment to meeting deadlines, despite the significant financial impact on this quarter and fiscal year 2022.
Jeff and I will provide more details in the following slides.
Due to the quarterly loss, we breached our financial covenants, necessitating the suspension of our dividend.
Jeff will elaborate on the waiver we obtained and the upcoming amendment to our credit facility.
Despite this disappointing quarter and challenging year, we remain committed to our strategy of diversifying beyond refining and petrochemicals through our defense work.
Our pivot towards defense has been successful, as evidenced by our bookings and revenue, with defense revenue now comprising over half of our total revenue.
We had an exceptional bookings quarter, totaling $68 million, with over half coming from Barber-Nichols.
Now that we have secured these bookings, our focus is on executing this work profitably.
Lastly, Barber-Nichols' performance is surpassing our expectations, building a larger backlog and delivering strong margins.
Jeff will provide more financial details, but first, I'd like to elaborate on our Navy challenges in Batavia.
Let's move to Slide 4.
I'll begin by explaining the factors leading to our third quarter performance.
To date, Graham Manufacturing has successfully earned the trust and confidence of the U.S. Navy and its prime shipbuilders with high-quality heat exchange and vacuum products for nuclear Navy power plants.
Navy orders and backlog continue to grow, now significantly exceeding our commercial backlog and soon to surpass our commercial revenue.
As of December 31, 2021, our Navy backlog in Batavia exceeded $100 million.
These orders come with high expectations.
As we've worked to win new business and meet these expectations over the past two years, a perfect storm developed in our third quarter.
Several events necessitated adjustments in Q3.
After beginning work on Colombia, a Navy-wide reset of quality requirements caused delays in welder and quality recertification.
This was followed by COVID-19 impacts, ongoing shortages of skilled welders, and the sheer volume of work in our shop, combined with first article learning curves, all contributing to delays in our Navy jobs.
We continue to face first article challenges, which is typical for defense projects and expected for the Columbia project.
While the CVN-80 work isn't a true first article job for us, the lack of process documentation from previous work, combined with severe labor challenges and the use of new contract welders, caused difficulties with the carrier work as well.
Even as we worked to catch up on hours, our equipment became the critical factor in our nation's most strategic ship and submarine build schedules.
The pressure to expedite was intense.
Let's turn to Page 5.
The chart on Page 5 illustrates our labor plan with blue bars, actual labor application in gray bars, and the resulting deficit of hours caused by actual being less than our planned hourly expenditure.
The labor deficit peaked around May 2021.
In previous calls, we discussed redirecting commercial welders to Navy work and hiring contract welders to address this deficit.
In the third quarter, we further redirected commercial welders, outsourced more commercial work, hired additional contract welders, and added new welders who completed our training programs.
These actions helped reverse the Navy labor deficit but came at additional costs.
Outsourcing commercial work resulted in lower margins.
We also saw reduced third quarter revenue as outsourced suppliers couldn't ramp up quickly.
Contract welder costs were high, specialized Navy training took time, and retention of contract welders was poor.
Ultimately, we've managed to reduce our Navy program labor deficit by doubling our Navy workforce, mitigating schedule slips, and maintaining strong customer relationships.
We expect to eliminate the deficit in the first half of fiscal '23 and begin reducing high-cost contract welders as we enter the next fiscal year.
The actions taken to stay on track last quarter led to revised estimates on labor hours and materials, and we booked loss conversion costs that impacted our quarterly results.
Jeff will provide more details in the financial briefing.
We've learned valuable lessons from this experience and have implemented or will implement corrective and preventative measures to ensure continued growth in our Navy business, timely delivery of quality products, and fair returns for our efforts.
Our customers have appreciated our efforts, and we don't anticipate negative consequences if we maintain current deliveries.
This equipment is integral to these ships and will remain in place permanently.
Quality is of utmost importance, and Graham has met expectations.
As we address these programs and reduce our workforce shortage, we can improve margins by removing temporary welders, reassigning our commercial welders to their original roles, and decreasing our current outsourcing.
Maintaining our employee pipeline remains crucial, and we will continue our welder training initiative.
In hindsight, we could have better anticipated and addressed the situation with more developed financial planning, analysis, and project management capabilities.
We are bringing in new personnel with defense experience in Batavia to enhance management of these processes.
We are creating a new role, and Batavia will have a Navy business leader starting on February 28.
Moving forward, we need to improve our processes to better document and optimize all our fabrication methods to avoid repeating the initial article issues we've encountered.
We see potential to boost future earnings by investing in time-efficient automated welding, and we're reassessing current contract margins and reconsidering pricing for upcoming production opportunities.
In conclusion, our Batavia defense operations faced a combination of challenges at a very unfortunate time.
We made choices to safeguard our strategic Navy business.
This resulted in short-term losses but demonstrated our commitment to our customers in the long run.
As Dan noted, our third quarter results were very disappointing.
Revenue was $28.8 million, an increase of $1.6 million compared to the same quarter last year.
Barber-Nichols contributed $12 million in sales for the quarter, helping to counterbalance the weak sales performance of our traditional Graham manufacturing business.
Our Batavia operations were affected due to the need to prioritize catching up and executing the two major Navy projects.
These projects will require more labor and material expenses to finish than initially projected at the beginning of the quarter.
The additional labor hours needed to complete the projects impacted the quarter's revenue as we didn't progress the projects as far as anticipated.
The increased labor and material costs, including the use of more expensive contract workers, required us to record higher reserves.
The combination of these factors affected both revenue and gross margin.
The impact of the cost increases and required fully burdened contract costs in the quarter amounted to $2 million.
Additionally, the delayed revenue was approximately $6 million, and the delayed operating profit is around $750,000.
Moreover, to get back on schedule with the Navy projects, we reassigned our commercial labor to Navy work, resulting in increased cost estimates for those jobs, which have now been outsourced.
All of these factors contributed to an adjusted EBITDA of negative $2.6 million in the quarter and an adjusted net loss of $0.27 per share.
On a positive note, with the addition of Barber-Nichols, 58% of our sales were to the defense industry, along with 5% or $1.5 million to the space industry.
Let's move on to Slide 7.
The impact of the third quarter results, combined with a challenging first half of the year, has resulted in an unacceptable loss despite sales increasing by 16% or $11.3 million to $83.1 million.
There is a bright spot within the results, which has been the contributions of Barber-Nichols, acquired on June 1.
In the seven months since the acquisition, BN has contributed $31.9 million in sales, offsetting significant declines in refining and petrochemical markets.
Our diversification into defense, which is less cyclical than our commercial business, has resulted in 52% of our year-to-date revenue coming from that industry.
The shortfall in commercial sales in the first nine months of the fiscal year reflects the very low order levels we experienced in the second half of fiscal 2021.
The two Navy projects in our Batavia operations will continue to convert over the next three quarters, and we expect this to be resolved by mid-fiscal 2023.
As of December 31, we have recorded all known expected costs on these large projects.
We are implementing expanded processes within our project management group to better review all of Batavia's major projects.
The year-to-date impact of increased costs on these two jobs is approximately $4.5 million.
Additionally, the delayed revenue was approximately $12 million and the delayed operating profit is an additional $1.5 million.
These latter amounts will be recognized over the next three quarters as the jobs are completed.
We've had to outsource more commercial work and have also faced cost challenges on a couple of projects.
This has also impacted financial results.
The increased cost of outsourcing and higher costs has impacted the commercial business by $3 million.
All of these factors contributed to an adjusted EBITDA of negative $5.4 million year-to-date, and a year-to-date net loss of $0.70 a share and an adjusted loss of $0.60 per share.
Barber-Nichols continues to be a strong positive in the first three quarters.
In the seven months since the acquisition, BN sales are on track at $31.9 million, and EBITDA margins are well ahead of expectations.
I have mentioned in previous calls that we were expecting $45 million to $48 million in sales and low double-digit EBITDA margins.
The sales number is on target, and we are now seeing mid-teen EBITDA.
In fact, through seven months since the acquisition, BN has achieved our targeted EBITDA for the full fiscal year.
So its Q4 EBITDA will exceed our expectations.
Let's move on to Slide 8.
Given the weak financial performance in the first three quarters, we have not met our debt covenant related to debt-to-EBITDA and fixed cost charges.
This miss was due to the EBITDA loss.
We received a waiver from our lender for Q3 and are actively negotiating to amend our existing bank agreement.
Due to the covenant misses, we had to suspend our dividend.
As part of the waiver agreement, we have agreed not to use more than $15 million of our revolver.
I want to emphasize that the issues we are facing are related to P&L profit, not liquidity.
We have sufficient liquidity from cash generated from operations to address our challenges.
In fact, in January alone, we reduced our revolver debt from $9.75 million to $6 million.
We expect to lower it further between now and the end of March.
Discussions with our lender have been very positive.
I'm pleased with the bank's willingness to understand the details and not overreact to the numbers.
They recognize that the near-term challenges are primarily related to profitability and delayed revenue.
While there are certainly some significant cash cost increases, the costs booked in Q3 and the extension of project revenue and profit recognition into future quarters have compounded the impact on our year-to-date P&L.
Both the bank and I anticipate the lending amendment to be completed by the end of Q4.
Here are the paraphrased sentences:
We have some excellent news regarding orders to share on Slide 9.
As mentioned by Dan, Q3 orders totaled $68 million.
Barber-Nichols contributed slightly more than half of this amount, with the majority of their orders coming from key defense projects.
They also continue to secure a good quantity and range of space-related orders.
Graham manufacturing experienced another robust quarter for aftermarket and short-cycle orders in the commercial sector.
This is encouraging as historically, growth in these areas has often preceded a revival in capital investment from our clients.
We also secured a major refinery contract in China.
Our end-of-Q3 backlog stands at a record $272.6 million, with both Barber-Nichols and the original Graham business showing significant increases in their respective backlogs during the quarter.
Defense accounts for 77% of the total backlog.
This defense backlog extends over the next six years, although a large portion will be converted in the next three to four years.
Furthermore, we are observing growth in our commercial backlog.
The commercial backlog was significantly low at the start of the fiscal year.
It has increased from $33 million at the end of March to $63 million currently.
Approximately one-quarter of this increase occurred when we incorporated BN, while the remainder was due to orders received in the first nine months of the year.
Another positive aspect of the commercial backlog and its growth is its much shorter conversion cycle compared to the defense backlog, typically 12 to 18 months.
Despite a challenging fiscal 2022, the outlook for the future appears much more promising.
Let's proceed to Slide 10.
We have revised our guidance for fiscal 2022 downward.
Our updated revenue guidance is now $120 million to $125 million, implying $37 million to $42 million in Q4.
We anticipate a break-even adjusted EBITDA in Q4.
Although this falls short of our previous expectations, it's considerably better than Q3 results, and we believe we've overcome many of the challenges we faced this fiscal year.
I'll now hand the call back to Dan to discuss our future strategy.
We're now on Slide 11.
At a broad level, we've been discussing a strategic shift towards defense for several years, and we've been making good progress.
The long-term visibility of strategic naval programs provides stability and allows us to invest wisely in our business, offsetting the cyclicality and challenges of our refining and petrochemical markets.
The acquisition of Barber-Nichols reinforced this strategy and brought additional market expertise to our company.
As with any new venture, we've learned some lessons and identified opportunities to further strengthen our strategy.
I'd like to share some insights on how our strategy is evolving going forward.
Let's move to Page 12.
Graham Corporation is a group of related mission-critical engineered product companies that excel through superior quality, performance, and customer trust.
Our corporate role is to enhance our member companies with best practices, leader rotation, and board expertise while providing value-adding services and core collaboration to secure large programs.
We are currently filling critical leadership positions and upgrading talent to meet the future needs of Graham Corporation.
Our board took on this requirement themselves last year after the BN acquisition, initiating a search for director candidates with strong defense experience.
Our Batavia operations, now referred to as Graham manufacturing, will continue to serve the Navy, refining, and petrochemical markets with high-quality, highly engineered heat transfer and vacuum systems.
It is expanding into new energy and will now focus more on aftermarket opportunities to become a life cycle partner with our customers.
Internally, we are restructuring to accommodate significant Navy growth and will leverage our large installed base for growth capital.
Our strengths will help us achieve our goals.
In Batavia, we aim to achieve strong margins in all our markets, improve our operational effectiveness, and develop capabilities to provide more value to our customers.
We need to establish clear roles and responsibilities aligned with a structure designed to be responsive, analytical, and forward-thinking.
We must create an organization that is accountable and can diagnose problems, evaluate alternatives, improve, develop, reshape, and quickly redirect as needed.
Crucially, we need to ensure our people have the necessary tools, materials, and information to perform their jobs effectively.
Barber-Nichols continues to focus on intelligent full life cycle turbomachinery systems in identified high-growth potential markets.
BN has largely established the necessary people, technology, and customer relationships.
They are advancing to the next level in teams, processes, and improvements to optimize business performance, while working even more closely with customers to develop new products and ensure year-over-year growth.
Our future opportunities will result from proper execution of our plans, which will help us overcome these short-term challenges.
We believe this is the turning point.
We have undoubtedly reached the bottom, so I'm confident we can only go up from here.
I understand that we need to demonstrate our ability to drive earnings and generate cash.
As Jeff mentioned, we have already begun to do so in the first month of 2022.
Looking to our future, we view the BN acquisition as a model to replicate.
Several novel approaches were used that we believe can attract the best and brightest small independent companies to join us.
We are an organization undergoing dynamic change.
We serve excellent markets.
We have earned our customers' confidence.
Our orders and backlog serve as proof.
We have faced execution challenges but have identified the issues and implemented corrective measures.
We have a growth plan in place.
We believe we have a robust business model with excellent earnings potential and cash generation capabilities.
Although we have several quarters of work ahead to complete these projects, we are on an upward trajectory.
Jeff and I will now take questions from the audience.

Context:The potential hazards encompass, but are not restricted to, dangers linked with pricing, volume, market conditions, unfavorable developments in the worldwide economy as well as the public health emergency related to COVID-19 and its subsequent effects on demand for new and pre-owned vehicles and associated services.
Ambiguity regarding the length and intensity of COVID-19 and its effect on U.S. and international authorities' ability to relax current restrictions on various commercial and economic activities.
Lack of clarity concerning the timing, speed, and extent of economic recovery in the U.S. and elsewhere from the unknown present and future impacts of COVID-19 and unforeseen future effects of oil producers and their influence on travel, transportation, and oil prices, which will likely negatively affect demand for our vehicles and service.
Additionally, our capability to acquire a desired inventory of new and pre-owned vehicles and the impact of supply chain disruptions, which may happen periodically.
Furthermore, our ability to sustain vehicle profit margins and implement and maintain cost controls and preserve sufficient liquidity for operations.
These dangers and other risks are outlined in the company's submissions to the Securities and Exchange Commission over the past 12 months.
Duplicates of these filings are accessible from both the SEC and the company.
As mandated by applicable SEC regulations, the company provides reconciliations of any such non-GAAP financial measures to the most directly comparable GAAP measures on its website.
I would now like to pass the call over to Earl.
I'm happy to announce that for the quarter, Group one produced adjusted net income of $103 million.
This translates to adjusted earnings per share of $5.57 per diluted share, a 236% increase compared to the previous year and a 170% rise over the pre-pandemic first quarter of 2019.
Our adjusted net income results exclude non-core items of $1.7 million in after-tax disaster pay given to employees who were unable to work during our February Texas store closures, partially offset by an $800,000 after-tax benefit from legal settlements and a $200,000 after-tax net gain on dealership and real estate transactions.
These profit outcomes were particularly remarkable considering that our Texas operations, which typically account for around 40% of our total revenues, were severely affected due to a record-breaking February winter weather event.
Our stores effectively lost approximately the equivalent of a full week of business.
It is probable that vehicle sales were largely postponed to subsequent months, but the available service shop hours were permanently lost.
Additionally, the U.K. remained under lockdown throughout the entire first quarter.
With numerous restrictions in all our markets in 2020, it was challenging to generate revenue growth.
This improvement was driven by new and used vehicle revenue increases in the U.S., well exceeding 20% in the first quarter.
Naturally, we should remember that the pandemic began to negatively impact traffic and sales during the second half of March last year.
However, the crucial point is that consumer demand for vehicles in the U.S. remains exceptionally strong and reached an even higher level in March.
It is true that sales have been and will be hindered to some extent by low inventory levels.
Nevertheless, this continues to support above-average margin levels.
Daryl will discuss our inventory situation in more detail shortly.
Our aftersales business has suffered throughout the pandemic from reduced driving and various lockdown conditions in all our markets.
Specifically, our U.S. business began 2021 very slowly in January and February but surged in March.
Again, Daryl will provide more details, but this gives us great confidence that we will experience very strong parts and service business this spring and summer in both the U.S. and likely the U.K. as those facilities are now fully operational.
In the U.S., we are particularly pleased that our service results have now returned to pre-pandemic levels.
On a same-store basis, our U.S. total aftersales gross profit increased 3% compared to the first quarter of 2019, and customer-paid gross profit rose 14% over that same pre-pandemic period.
These are very encouraging indicators for continued aftersales improvement in 2021.
Daryl will provide more information on our U.S. results momentarily.
Regarding the U.K., mandatory lockdowns began on November 5, 2020, and persisted through the entire first quarter.
They have since been lifted as of April 12.
Similar to the United States, our United Kingdom business has predominantly moved to online sales through our Acceleride system, as our physical locations have been shut for five months.
Though we lacked in-person sales teams and couldn't offer test drives, we managed to sell over 13,000 new and pre-owned vehicles in the quarter.
The scarcity of new vehicles boosted our same-store new vehicle profit margins by 160 basis points to 5.6% in Q1.
Our aftermarket service profit margin rose by nearly 400 basis points to 58.4%, as most work at our dealerships involved major repairs, with customers postponing routine maintenance until after lockdown restrictions eased.
The combination of robust new vehicle and aftermarket service margins, along with strict cost management, as shown by an 1,800 basis point improvement in same-store SG&A compared to the previous year, allowed us to generate significant profit in the UK despite closed showrooms.
Since we were allowed to reopen showrooms on April 12, we've witnessed very high levels of sales and service activity in our dealerships.
This gives us great optimism for our UK operations for the remainder of 2021.
Several elements contributed to our exceptional US first quarter results, including growth in new and used vehicle sales, aftermarket services expansion, and ongoing strong cost control, all of which continue trends from the latter half of 2020.
In comparison to the pre-pandemic first quarter of 2019, our same-store new and used unit sales grew by 11% and 5%, respectively.
This 11% increase in new vehicle sales outperformed the retail industry average.
US new vehicle inventory levels ended the quarter at 14,500 units, representing a 34-day supply.
We expect inventories to remain limited and will continue to adapt our operations as needed.
Our same-store used vehicle unit sales improved by 14% sequentially, along with a 5% increase over the first quarter of 2019.
Used vehicle inventories remain constrained as well.
Nevertheless, we've implemented several changes in our merchandising, sourcing, reconditioning, and acquisition processes that have resulted in higher turnover and better inventory management.
Although we are near record-high monthly levels of 90 units sold per core location in the quarter, we still believe there is substantial opportunity for growth in used vehicle sales at our dealerships in the future.
The second and most encouraging profit driver was our aftermarket service performance.
Warranty and collision repair sales were still very low in January and February, but we observed improvement in March.
Our customer-paid business is very robust.
As Earl mentioned, our same-store customer-paid gross profit increased by 14% compared to the first quarter of 2019.
This allowed us to grow total aftermarket service gross profit by 3% compared to pre-pandemic levels, despite significant challenges in warranty and collision repair, both of which will recover over time.
We observed a substantial increase in gross profit per repair order in the quarter, offsetting declines in repair order volume.
In March, customer traffic increased and our same-store customer-paid repair order count grew 23% compared to March 2020.
We anticipate aftermarket services will continue to improve in the near future.
The third major factor driving our outstanding profit performance was continued cost discipline.
Our first quarter adjusted SG&A as a percentage of gross profit was 63%, down from 74% in the pre-pandemic first quarter of 2019.
Part of the decrease is certainly due to higher vehicle margins, which we don't believe will be fully permanent, but a significant portion of the improvement is due to productivity gains.
For instance, because of tools like Acceleride, our salespeople are more efficient.
Due to our higher proportion of flat-rate technicians, our technicians are more productive.
These examples of permanent productivity improvements will allow for a significant ongoing reduction in our cost structure.
I would like to provide another quarterly update on Acceleride, our digital retailing platform.
We maintained our upward trajectory in the first quarter by selling a record 4,000 vehicles through Acceleride, an increase of 124% over the previous year and 7% of total retail units sold.
Clients who opt for Acceleride continue to finalize deals at a significantly higher frequency compared to other channels.
I'd like to inform you about several improvements we've implemented or will soon introduce to the Acceleride system.
We've now incorporated instant loan payoff estimates within the platform.
We've released an Android application to complement our existing iOS app.
Users can now switch between English and Spanish languages.
In addition to reserving vehicles with credit cards, customers can now process down payments of any amount directly through the application.
In the coming months, we'll introduce variable delivery fees integrated into the customer's experience.
This will present delivery charges earlier in the process and include them in monthly payment calculations based on the customer's delivery location.
We're developing numerous other upgrades and will provide updates as appropriate.
We consider our digital retail process unparalleled in the industry, and we're continuously enhancing it to maintain our leading position in this revolutionary technology.
Briefly discussing Brazil.
Despite a 7% drop in new vehicle industry sales due to limited inventory and additional COVID restrictions, our team excelled at increasing margins and aggressively reducing costs to achieve a remarkably strong quarterly profit during the typically weakest quarter of the year.
We easily broke the record for the most profitable first quarter in Group 1's eight-year ownership and are well-positioned to benefit from a sales recovery as the pandemic subsides.
As of March 31, we had $83 million in cash and an additional $245 million in our floorplan offset accounts, bringing total cash liquidity to $328 million.
There was also $283 million of additional borrowing capacity on our U.S. syndicated acquisition line, bringing total immediate liquidity to over $600 million.
We also generated $157 million in adjusted operating cash flow in the first quarter and $134 million in free cash flow after deducting capital expenditures.
Our rent-adjusted leverage ratio, as defined by our U.S. syndicated credit facility, decreased to two times at the end of March, providing ample flexibility for capital deployment.
On a net basis, considering all U.S. cash on hand, our leverage was 1.6 times as of March 31.
Regarding interest expenses.
Our quarterly floorplan interest of $7.6 million decreased by $5.3 million or 41% compared to the first quarter of 2020.
This reduction was mainly due to lower inventory levels and related borrowings.
Non-floorplan interest expense decreased by $4.3 million or 24% from the previous year, primarily due to last year's bond debt refinancing.
As a reminder, we continue to manage our interest risk conservatively.
We have floorplan swaps averaging $550 million in place through 2026.
Considering our mortgage swaps on bond debt, over 75% of our debt is at fixed rates.
Consequently, a 100-basis point increase in interest rates would only have an approximate $0.20 negative impact on our annual earnings per share.
Our balance sheet and liquidity position have never been stronger, and we look forward to expanding the company through mergers and acquisitions.
We are observing a strong flow of potential deals and expect to close or enter into contracts to acquire additional dealerships this year.
Regarding our corporate development efforts, we previously announced the March acquisition of two Toyota franchises on Cape Cod, expanding our New England platform to 10 stores and adding $120 million in incremental annual revenues.
We also previously announced the January dispositions of the Cadillac franchise in the Dallas-Fort Worth market area and a Mini franchise in the El Paso market.
We've also completed the termination of the U.K. Ford franchise in March and the sale of a Mississippi Kia franchise in April.
As Daniel mentioned, we continue to prioritize external growth in our capital allocation process and are optimistic about beneficial opportunities as the year progresses.
Summary:
output:
compname announces record first quarter 2021 financial results.
q1 adjusted non-gaap earnings per share $5.57.
compname says q1 revenue increase driven by u.s. new and used vehicle revenue growth of more than 20 percent.
quarterly new vehicle revenue increased 15.0 percent, on a 4.3 percent increase in unit sales.

Context:We have no obligation to openly revise or update these declarations.
Our Chief Financial Officer and President of Global Development, Kevin Jacobs, will subsequently present our third quarter performance.
We are happy to announce another quarter of robust results showcasing ongoing recovery and the durability of our business approach.
Rising vaccination rates and consumer expenditure, along with improving business conditions, continued to fuel strong travel demand throughout summer and into autumn.
As international borders open and travel conditions improve, we remain highly optimistic about people's eagerness to travel and interact more than ever.
In the third quarter, systemwide RevPAR increased 99% compared to the previous year.
Relative to 2019, RevPAR decreased by approximately 19%, an improvement of 17 percentage points from the second quarter, with systemwide rates only 2.5% lower than 2019.
Adjusted EBITDA reached about $519 million, a 132% increase year-over-year and a 14% decrease compared to 2019.
Performance was mainly driven by strong leisure trends, with leisure room nights approximately equal to 2019 levels and leisure rates surpassing 2019 figures.
Business travel continued to gain traction, with midweek occupancy and rates showing significant improvement compared to the second quarter.
During the quarter, business transient room nights were approximately 75% of previous peak levels.
Group bookings still lagged but showed considerable sequential improvement from the second quarter, bolstered by strong social event bookings.
For the quarter, group RevPAR was about 60% of 2019 levels, a 21 percentage point improvement from the second quarter.
Overall systemwide RevPAR compared to 2019 reached its highest point in July at 85%, with rates just below previous peaks.
As anticipated, recovery slowed slightly later in the quarter due to typical seasonality and changes in customer mix, but overall trends remained positive.
Both August and September RevPAR reached approximately 80% of 2019 levels, driven by continued strength in leisure and increases in business travel after Labor Day as offices and schools reopened.
These trends improved slightly into October, with month-to-date RevPAR at about 84% of 2019 levels and rates in the U.S. nearly back to previous peaks.
Approximately 40% of systemwide hotels have surpassed 2019 RevPAR levels in October month-to-date.
Moreover, bookings for all future periods are only 8% below 2019 levels.
With easing travel restrictions and strong forecasts for nonresidential fixed investment, we remain optimistic about future travel demand.

With approximately 80% of our typical corporate mix coming from small- and medium-sized businesses and the slower recovery of larger corporate travel, we've taken the opportunity to continue our pre-COVID efforts to further increase our focus on this demand segment.
This demand is higher-rated and more resilient, which has helped us recover more quickly in business transient and should drive rate compression in the future as larger corporate travel increases.
Regarding group bookings, our position for the remainder of the year remains relatively stable, with forward booking sentiment improving as concerns about variants decrease.
Additionally, the recent reopenings of some of our large urban properties, such as the New York Hilton Midtown, have increased our confidence in our positioning as group travel recovers.
We added nearly 100 hotels and 15,000 rooms across all major regions and achieved strong net unit growth of 6.6% in the third quarter.

Year-to-date, we've added more than 42,000 net rooms globally, surpassing all our major branded competitors.
Our performance demonstrates the success of our disciplined growth strategy, the strength of our brands, network effect, and commercial engines worldwide.
It also reflects our growing confidence in a strong recovery of global tourism in the coming months and years.

Following our recently announced exclusive licensing agreement with Country Garden, we were excited to open our first Home2 Suites in China with plans to expand to more than 1,000 locations.
We are eager to utilize our partnership to meet the rapidly increasing demand for mid-scale hotels in China.
We also marked the opening of our 500th Home2 Suites just 10 years after the brand's launch, making it one of the industry's fastest-growing brands and boasting North America's largest pipeline with over 400 hotels in development.
Our luxury and lifestyle presence continued to grow globally with the introduction of Canopy by Hilton in Spain and the highly anticipated opening of Mango House LXR in the Seychelles.
LXR celebrated its debut in Asia Pacific with the opening of ROKU KYOTO, marking another significant milestone in its global expansion.
In the quarter, we signed agreements for nearly 24,000 rooms, an increase of about 40% year-over-year, driven by strong performance in the Americas and Asia Pacific regions.
Contributing to our positive momentum in luxury, we announced the signing of Conrad Los Angeles, the brand's first property in California.
The 300-room hotel is set to open in 2022 as part of The Grand LA mixed-use development.
With roughly 404,000 rooms in development, more than half of which are under construction, we anticipate positive development trends to continue, driven by both new construction and conversion opportunities.
For the full year, we project net unit growth between 5% and 5.5%, and we expect mid-single-digit growth to continue for the next several years.
For our guests, flexibility has always been important, but the pandemic has made choice and control even more essential.
We were pleased to introduce several new commercial programs and loyalty extensions, including the launch of Digital Key Share, a first for a major hospitality company.
This feature allows multiple guests to access their room's digital key.
Additional technological improvements have enabled our elite Honors members to begin enjoying automatic room upgrades.
Gold and Diamond members may receive notification of a complimentary upgrade before arrival, allowing guests to select their upgraded room directly using the Hilton Honors app.
We continue to explore new opportunities to further engage our 123 million Honors members and are delighted to see engagement is almost back to 2019 levels.
During the quarter, membership increased by 11% year-over-year.
Honors members accounted for 59% of occupancy, with the U.S. at 66%, just two percentage points below 2019 levels.
During the pandemic, approximately 23 million U.S. households adopted a new pet, including my own.
Like many others, my family enjoys traveling with our new dog, Miller.
In the coming months, Homewood Suites will join Home2 in becoming 100% pet-friendly in the U.S., with plans for all limited service brands to be pet-friendly by the first quarter of next year.

By simplifying this process, we're able to attract new business and meet demand.
As the global travel environment improves, I continue to be impressed by our team members' commitment to providing exceptional experiences for our guests.

We firmly believe that Hilton continues to be a source of opportunity for all of our stakeholders worldwide and are very optimistic about the future.

A 93% growth in management and franchise fees was driven by significant RevPAR improvements and Honors license fees.

Our ownership portfolio exceeded expectations in the third quarter, propelled by the accelerating recovery in Europe, the Tokyo Olympics, and continued cost control measures.
The quarter's diluted earnings per share, adjusted for special items, amounted to $0.78.
Let's examine our regional performance.

Strong performance in July was driven by robust leisure demand and improving business transient trends.
Later in the quarter, trends slightly decelerated due to seasonal factors.
The U.S. maintained an average occupancy of nearly 70% for the quarter, with overall rates generally matching 2019 levels.
In the Americas outside the U.S., third quarter RevPAR rose by 168% year-over-year but was 30% below 2019 levels.
The region benefited from relaxed travel restrictions and strong leisure demand during the summer months.
Canada experienced a notable increase in demand in August after opening their borders to vaccinated Americans.
Europe saw RevPAR grow by 142% year-over-year, though it remained 35% below 2019 levels.
Travel demand accelerated across the region in the third quarter as vaccination rates increased and international travel restrictions eased.
The Middle East and Africa region experienced a 110% increase in RevPAR year-over-year, but it was still 29% lower than 2019.

In the Asia Pacific region, third quarter RevPAR grew by 5% year-over-year but was 41% lower than 2019.
China's RevPAR was 25% below 2019 levels due to reimposed restrictions and lockdowns across the country following a rise in COVID cases.
