In the rest of the Asia Pacific region, extended lockdowns in Australia and New Zealand offset the positive impact of the Tokyo Olympics.
As Chris mentioned, we achieved a 6.6% net unit growth in the third quarter.
Our pipeline expanded sequentially, reaching 404,000 rooms at the quarter's end, with 62% of pipeline rooms located outside the U.S. Development activity is gaining momentum globally as the recovery progresses, demonstrating the confidence owners and developers have in our strong commercial engines and industry-leading brands.
For the full year, we now anticipate signings to increase in the mid- to high teens range year-over-year and expect net unit growth of 5% to 5.5%.
Regarding our balance sheet, we concluded the quarter with $8.9 billion in long-term debt and $1.4 billion in total cash and cash equivalents.
We take pride in the financial flexibility we've demonstrated over the past 18 months.
Looking ahead, we remain confident in our balance sheet management as we progress through the recovery and move closer to our target leverage.
We would now like to open the line for any questions you may have.
[Operator Instructions] Chad, can we have our first question, please?
Summary:
output:
q3 adjusted earnings per share $0.78.
for three months ended september 30, 2021, system-wide comparable revpar increased 98.7%.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Jeff Jones, our President and CEO, and Tony Bowen, our CFO, are participating in today's conference call.
We will be discussing some figures today that are presented on a non-GAAP basis.
These statements are based on current information and management's expectations as of today, and do not guarantee future performance.
Consequently, our actual outcomes and results may differ significantly.
You can find more information about these risks in our Form 10-K for fiscal 2020 and other SEC filings.
We request that participants restrict themselves to one question with a follow-up during Q&A, after which they may rejoin the queue.
We sincerely hope you and your loved ones are remaining safe and well during these unprecedented times.
We are deeply saddened by the continuing acts of racial injustice in our country that have tragically claimed lives.
We are dedicated to fostering a culture of inclusion at H&R Block and contributing to necessary change in our communities.
I will begin by explaining our response since the pandemic's onset.
I will then offer our perspective on the industry and our results, followed by our plans for executing the remainder of the tax season.
Next, I will discuss Wave, including an exciting new product that was introduced to more small business owners last week.
Lastly, I will share our future outlook, and Tony will review our fiscal '20 results, capital allocation, and thoughts on fiscal '21.
The pandemic has presented business challenges unlike any we've encountered before.
Our financial performance has been affected.
We have utilized our full line of credit and demonstrated flexibility and innovation by swiftly implementing significant changes to our operating model to continue serving clients.
In doing so, we have accelerated our efforts to transform H&R Block.
Our purpose has never been more crucial as we assist consumers in accessing their much-needed refunds and support small business owners navigating financial uncertainty caused by the pandemic.
In mid-March, as the virus's spread began impacting our business, we promptly implemented our crisis management plan, enabling us to react effectively and efficiently to an extremely challenging situation.
In our retail locations, nearly every state implemented lockdown policies that affected our ability to operate and prevented people from leaving home to receive service in their preferred manner.
At the peak, almost 20% of our office network was closed to the public.
For offices that remained open, we made significant changes by limiting in-person service, requiring drop-off in nearly half the network, and increasing the use of our virtual capabilities.
In essence, our obligation to comply with local orders is subject to much greater scrutiny than local independent businesses.
Regardless of our operational approach, one of our top priorities has been ensuring the health and safety of our associates, franchisees, and clients, while helping clients access their refunds.
Our teams worked diligently to maintain clean offices, follow social distancing protocols, and comply with constantly changing city and state guidelines.
Due to these changes, providing digital solutions to our clients became more crucial than ever.
As you may recall, our primary objective at the beginning of this year was to digitally enable every aspect of our business to deliver our expertise to consumers in innovative ways.
These efforts have been instrumental in allowing us to meet our clients' needs using methods we didn't have previously.
We have observed a significant increase in returns utilizing our digital capabilities, including Tax Pro Go, Tax Pro Review, and the Approve Online feature.
Approve Online allows filers to review their returns, approve them, and pay their fees from their mobile devices.
With a substantial portion of our clients historically visiting offices multiple times to complete their returns, this capability offers tremendous convenience, especially during these uncertain times.
We also enhanced our digital capabilities for our tax professionals, as many of them couldn't serve clients from our offices.
Within two weeks, we established a work-from-home model, allowing thousands of tax professionals to prepare returns without coming into the office.
This capability will be invaluable moving forward.
Our efforts during this crisis to continue meeting client needs, digitally enable our business, and serve clients according to their preferences have resulted in positive feedback, with service quality scores improving by 2 points in Assisted and 5 points in DIY, building on significant increases in both areas in fiscal '19.
Beyond taking care of our clients, we also implemented significant measures to support our associates.
Our tax professionals are our most valuable asset, and I'm proud of the investment we made to create a leading benefit program for our seasonal associates directly impacted by the situation.
I'm also proud of our response and ongoing commitment to our communities.
We joined the American Express 'Stand for Small' coalition in support of small businesses.
At Wave, we provided instant payouts to all our payments customers for free, giving them immediate access to their money.
We also offered free tax preparation to frontline workers through Tax Pro Go in May and June, which received overwhelmingly positive feedback.
With this context on our operations, I'd like to briefly discuss what we're observing in the industry as a result of the pandemic, as well as our results.
Industry return volume has been unusual due to the filing extension and the stimulus package.
Through June 5, the IRS reported total filings down 6%.
The IRS's volume includes millions of returns completed by those who typically don't file.
They did so this year to receive stimulus payments.
We believe the vast majority of these returns were completed through the IRS's fillable form site, which is inflating the number of DIY returns in the market.
DIY electronic tax filings have decreased by about 4%, while assisted filings have dropped 15% as of June 5, not including certain returns.
We anticipate this difference will lessen as tax season concludes and will provide more information during our Q1 earnings call.
Our market share in DIY filings has remained steady through early June.
For assisted filings, we gained market share through April's end, but this trend is slowing during the extended filing period.
It's crucial to note that such an extension is unprecedented in U.S. history, making it difficult to predict consumer behavior.
Although states are beginning to lift restrictions, normal business operations have not resumed.
We have more offices open and extended hours compared to a typical first quarter, but many locations are not serving clients in person.
We continue to assist clients virtually or through drop-off services.
While we have more tax professionals working than usual for this time of year, it's significantly fewer than during a normal April tax season.
These factors may affect client volumes.
We've adjusted our marketing strategies for the quarter to inform consumers about our availability and various drop-off and digital options.
We're using multiple channels to target those who haven't filed yet.
In addition to assisting consumers, we're also supporting small business owners during these challenging times.
We've created a free Small Business Resource Center on our website to provide updates on government assistance programs.
In May, we introduced our recovery action plan service to help entrepreneurs navigate the CARES Act, including loan programs and tax credits.
This showcases our advantage in providing human expertise.
Regarding Wave, after strong revenue growth exceeding 40% through mid-March, we've seen flat revenues in April and May due to the pandemic's impact on small businesses.
We've taken steps to limit Wave's operating losses while maintaining key investments in the business.
Despite these measures, we expect the near-term performance and valuation of Wave to be negatively impacted, similar to many businesses during this pandemic.
Consequently, we've recorded a non-cash impairment of goodwill, which Tony will discuss later.
Although there's been a short-term impact, we remain optimistic about Wave's long-term viability and future growth.
One reason for this confidence is Wave's innovation and upcoming products and services.
A prime example is Wave Money, which was recently expanded to more customers.
Wave Money is a unique business bank account that automatically manages all aspects of bookkeeping, allowing entrepreneurs to focus on their business.
This first-to-market, software-powered small business bank account offers several benefits to Wave customers, including no monthly fees or minimums, seamless integration with Wave's accounting platform for expense categorization and tax preparation, and instant access to funds via Wave payments.
We're excited about this product as we continue to innovate to simplify small business owners' lives.
In conclusion, as we adapt to this new normal, we remain focused on our achievements this year and the significant progress we've made towards our strategic goals in unexpected ways.
We're taking this opportunity to thoroughly evaluate our progress, identify areas for improvement, and reinforce our sense of urgency in these efforts.
We remain committed to transforming our business.
We're currently evaluating and reprioritizing our strategic imperatives while examining our expense structure to identify potential savings to fund future initiatives.
This work is ongoing and will remain flexible given our current operating environment.
We'll provide more details later this year.
I'll now hand the call over to Tony.
During our last conversation, we were on track to meet our tax season and fiscal year outlook.
However, like many companies, the pandemic has negatively impacted our business and financial performance.
Due to the pandemic's timing coinciding with the period in our fiscal year when we recognize most of our revenue, we withdrew our fiscal year 2020 financial outlook.
As such, I won't be comparing our performance against those expectations as I normally would.
Instead, I'll provide insights into our fiscal year 2020 financial results, how we anticipate the remainder of the tax season will impact our fiscal year 2021 financial performance, and the actions we're taking to enable continued investment for future growth.
In fiscal year 2020, we recorded revenues of $2.6 billion, representing a 14.7% decrease from the previous year, primarily due to lower tax return volumes resulting from the extended federal tax filing deadline, partially offset by Wave's contribution.
Regarding expenses, total operating expenses increased by 3.4%, driven entirely by Wave's goodwill impairment and operating expenses.
Excluding Wave, our total operating expenses would have decreased, though at a lower percentage than the revenue decline due to legal fees, COVID-19 related benefits, and planned technology investments.
We recorded a $106 million non-cash goodwill impairment for Wave due to the pandemic's impact on small businesses.
As Jeff mentioned, we've been pleased with Wave's performance since acquisition, with solid growth through mid-March.
However, revenue growth has slowed during the pandemic, affecting small businesses' invoicing and payment volumes.
We remain confident in Wave's future and our ability to continue providing significant value to small business owners through Wave's innovative platform.
Regarding the rest of the income statement, interest expense increased by $9 million.
About 50% of this rise was attributed to increased usage of our credit line during regular business operations through our third fiscal quarter, while the remaining 50% was due to extra interest related to the $2 billion withdrawal in late March.
The fluctuations in income and expenditures led to a $3 million pre-tax deficit from ongoing operations.
The GAAP earnings per share was a positive $0.03 owing to beneficial discrete tax items.
The adjusted earnings per share, which does not include the effect of impairment and amortization of intangibles related to Wave and tax office acquisitions, amounted to $0.84.
No alterations were made to accrued contingent liabilities associated with Sand Canyon in discontinued operations throughout the year.
I will now address capital allocation and the balance sheet.
Despite the unique challenges posed by COVID-19, our capital allocation priorities remain unchanged.
The primary focus is maintaining sufficient liquidity for our operational requirements.
Our current liquidity status remains robust, concluding the year with $2.7 billion in cash, which includes the entire $2 billion drawn from our credit line.
As announced in late March, we believe we have adequate funds to support operations at the beginning of the 2021 tax season.
Our credit line is subject to various conditions, including a covenant requiring us to maintain a debt-to-EBITDA ratio of 3.5 times on April 30.
Based on our fiscal year 2020 financial results, we did not meet this covenant, but we have obtained a waiver from our lenders without any changes to our credit line terms.
After ensuring adequate liquidity, we make strategic investments back into the business that we believe will foster sustainable growth, ultimately benefiting our shareholders.
As Jeff mentioned, given the pandemic's impact on our business, we have initiated a review of our expense structure to eliminate unnecessary spending while continuing to fund initiatives that will drive future growth.
I will discuss these expense measures shortly.
The final step in our capital allocation process involves distributing excess capital through quarterly dividends and share repurchases.
I'm pleased to announce that despite the financial impact of COVID-19 and the extended tax season, our Board of Directors has declared a $0.26 per share dividend payable on July 1.
We have consistently paid dividends since going public in 1962.
We remain committed to conducting an annual review of the dividend after each fiscal year.
Regarding share repurchases, in fiscal 2020, we bought back a total of 10.1 million shares for $247 million at an average price of $24.36.
We did not repurchase any shares in the fourth quarter.
For the past two years, we have committed to, at minimum, repurchasing shares to offset dilution from equity grants and making opportunistic share repurchases thereafter.
Given the uncertainty created by COVID-19, we have not yet determined our share repurchase approach for fiscal 2021.
I will now discuss our thoughts regarding fiscal 2021.
As a reminder, last year we provided our fiscal year financial outlook on our Q4 call.
Since we haven't yet completed the current tax season and uncertainty remains due to the pandemic, we will not be providing a financial outlook at this time.
Instead, we plan to provide a tax season recap on our first quarter call in September and our full financial outlook for fiscal 2021 on our second quarter call in December.
Let me share some general thoughts on how we expect to conclude the tax season and our efforts to mitigate cost increases resulting from the extension.
First, while it's natural to expect all volume lost in Q4 of fiscal 2020 to shift into the first quarter of fiscal 2021, that may not necessarily be the case.
As Jeff mentioned, during this quarter, we are still operating under a modified model.
Although we have more offices open than usual, we are still operating with just half of our total network and a substantial portion unable to serve clients face-to-face.
This may affect our ability to retain clients and attract new ones to the brand.
Regarding expenses, due to the extension of the tax season, we anticipate additional costs during the first quarter.
We expect an increase of approximately $10 million in marketing expense and about $10 million in interest expense.
Additionally, we expect variable expenses related to compensation, benefits, and bad debt to be approximately 40% of incremental Assisted revenues generated.
We are actively exploring ways to mitigate any additional costs by closely examining all spending categories and making prudent reductions across our business.
We're still finalizing these plans, but I can highlight a few areas of focus, including renegotiating rents with landlords across our retail footprint, implementing a hiring freeze, eliminating merit increases for fiscal 2021, examining vendor spend to renegotiate existing contracts, and reducing capital expenditures to only what is necessary.
In addition to these savings, we have entered into a non-binding letter of intent with MetaBank to be the provider of our financial products, including Refund Transfer, Refund Advance, Emerald Advance, and Emerald Card, which will result in savings.
MetaBank is a leader in providing financial solutions to consumers and has significant experience in the tax preparation industry.
We're excited to partner with them to continue offering valuable products to our clients.
In conclusion, we've taken prudent steps to adjust to the pandemic, including our modified operating model, line of credit draw, and cost reduction efforts.
These measures will allow us to operate effectively while enabling continued investments in our future.
We've faced unprecedented challenges during the last few months.
The resilience and dedication of our team, our strong financial foundation, and our ability to adjust our operating model has enabled us to continue delivering tremendous value to our clients when they need us most.
I am confident we'll emerge from this crisis stronger than ever as we continue the work to transform our business.
I look forward to speaking with you in September.
Summary:
output:
announced a quarterly dividend of $0.26 per share.
h & r block - have adequate liquidity to meet anticipated operating cash needs through start of tax season 2021.
evaluated wave's goodwill during q4, which resulted in an impairment of $106 million.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:You may start, Neil.
Ash will provide additional information about our recent fundraising efforts, the newly modified credit agreement, and our portfolio's performance so far this year and in the first quarter.
The fourth quarter's end marks the most difficult year in Hersha's existence.
Our dedicated team members, many present in our offices today, allowed us to remain adaptable, make wise choices, and implement various strategies to ensure financial stability for the foreseeable future.
Jay, Ash, and I are proud to represent our team as we share some positive news today.
We enter 2021 with a positive outlook on recovery as vaccine distribution gains traction and more individuals choose to travel.
The year began stronger than expected for our portfolio, with RevPAR exceeding $60, as South Florida and Washington DC compensated for restrictions on the West Coast and in the Northeast.
We achieved our first month of positive hotel-level EBITDA in January and are encouraged by February's performance thus far.
Bookings for President's Day weekend across the portfolio were the highest since the pandemic began a year ago.
We believe that leisure demand, supported by ongoing government stimulus, will lead the recovery, but with significantly more pent-up demand than was realized last summer.
We are also optimistic based on airline data.
The majority of corporate accounts expect to return to at least half of pre-COVID travel levels by the end of 2021, with over 40% anticipating a full recovery in corporate travel by 2022.
While leisure travel will initiate this year's recovery, the industry should experience significant acceleration with the return of business travel, potentially beginning as early as the second quarter and increasing throughout the latter half of the year.
Drive-to resorts have been our top performers since the pandemic's onset.
This hotel portfolio, representing about 25% of our pre-pandemic EBITDA, achieved a weighted average occupancy approaching 40% and realized 2% ADR growth for the full year 2020.
Government-mandated closures in California affected our coastal properties' performance in December and January, but we're seeing immediate improvements in February with the lifting of these restrictions.
We're not only seeing leisure travelers return but also early signs of business and small group activity.
New corporate accounts for upcoming projects and deposits for spring and fall weddings are building a foundation at the Sanctuary Beach Resort and Hotel Milo.
On the other side of the country in Key West, the Parrot Key Hotel and Villas was our top-performing asset during the fourth quarter, achieving 55% occupancy and 8.4% year-over-year ADR growth to $306 for the period.
The holiday weeks were particularly strong, especially the period between Christmas and New Year's, which saw occupancy exceed 90% and ADR surpass 2019 levels at the hotel.
We anticipate several strong quarters ahead at this exceptionally positioned resort.
Our largest property, the Cadillac Hotel and Beach Club on Miami Beach, is experiencing increased demand on weekends and during special events, generating occupancies approaching 90% with rates expected to improve incrementally throughout the rest of the quarter.
Momentum has been building in Miami since the start of the year due to leisure demand, and recent announcements about major corporate relocations highlight the region's tremendous appeal, making us optimistic about this year's recovery and substantial market growth in the coming years.
Urban destinations were essentially closed from March to September last year and again from November through January.
We anticipate that the reopening of museums, national parks, theaters, sports venues, and more bars and restaurants in the coming months will lead to an increase in both pent-up leisure and business demand in our major cities.
As travel resumes, which we've already observed in warmer climates like South Florida and even at our lifestyle hotels up north over President's Day weekend, our diverse portfolio provides us multiple opportunities to capture market share while maintaining cost-efficient operations as occupancy builds towards normalization.
Washington DC has been a very strong performing market, despite significantly reduced inauguration activities.
Although the public couldn't attend the event, the St Gregory Hotel contracted with media outlets including CBS, BBC, and Al Jazeera.
The Hilton Garden Inn, M Street, and the Hampton Inn Mason accommodated the National Guard members deployed to the city leading up to and during the event.
The Ritz Carlton Georgetown maintained a $1,000 ADR for peak nights for the few leisure guests in town.
Washington has started 2021 strongly, ending January with portfolio revenues more than double our initial expectations for the month.
The new presidential administration is expected to lead to increased activity among lobbying, federal government, and diplomatic segments, and we're also looking forward to the upcoming Cherry Blossom Festival in the coming quarter.
One of our better-performing markets during the fourth quarter, from a forecast perspective, was our New York City portfolio, finishing the quarter with nearly 40% occupancy, despite few leisure-oriented attractions being open in the city.
We continue to see strong performance from our JFK submarket, but also saw an increase in first responder business at our Brooklyn and lower Manhattan properties.
These customers, including the New York Fire and Police Departments and some medical groups, continue to use the nu hotel Brooklyn and the Hampton Inn Seaport, resulting in January occupancies of 97% and 51% respectively.
Although this business is temporary and related to the ongoing COVID-19 spread, we're grateful that these frontline workers can use our hotels to stay safe and guide us through the final stretch of this pandemic.
Urban market recovery is driven not only by vaccine distribution and the return of business and international travel but also significantly enhanced by reductions or deterioration of supply.
In markets across the country, aging hotels are becoming obsolete, such as the Wardman Park in D.C., the Embassy Suites in Philadelphia, and the Buckminster in Boston.
New York, more than anywhere else, has seen consultants forecast a range of figures regarding permanent supply reduction.
While it may not reach as high as 25% as some have predicted, the confirmed closures in 2020 alone provide concrete evidence that the supply will contract.
Adding to this is the newly announced proposal by the Department of Planning requiring special permits for new hotels and expansions in zoning districts throughout the city.
Public meetings have begun to discuss this proposal, which, if approved, will significantly affect hotel development across all five boroughs and provide substantial benefits to hotel owners for years to come.
I'd like to discuss our capital allocation strategy and additional sources of liquidity before Ash delves into our balance sheet and burn rates.
As mentioned in previous earnings calls, we determined that selling assets was the most cost-effective way to raise funds and improve our financial flexibility.
We initiated extensive marketing campaigns with multiple brokers starting in the fall.
Our prime locations in major gateway markets generated significant interest from private equity firms, family offices, and residential developers.
These hotels were fee-simple properties that remained operational throughout the pandemic, free from management and restrictive labor agreements, and many were unbranded, leading to a highly competitive bidding process.
We aim to generate between $150 million and $200 million from asset sales to reduce our senior credit facility debt.
The six recently announced asset sales will yield net proceeds of about $191 million.
The Sheraton Wilmington was sold in December, and the Courtyard San Diego transaction was completed last week.
The sales of the residences in Coconut Grove, Capitol Hill Hotel Washington, and Holiday Inn Express Cambridge are expected to finalize by the end of the first quarter, while the Duane Street Hotel sale should close in early Q2.
Many of these hotels had significant upcoming capital projects, and their successful sale will reduce our capital expenditure budget by approximately $20 million in the coming years.
As part of a long-term strategy to recycle capital, these sales provide liquidity and flexibility at a reasonable cost.
We sold at a discount compared to pre-COVID values, but focused on mature properties we've owned for nearly a decade, hotels requiring additional investment during recovery, and the slowest-growing hotels in each of our geographic clusters.
The successful sale of these properties slightly improves the absolute RevPAR and EBITDA per key of the remaining portfolio, while significantly enhancing overall quality, EBITDA growth rate, and reducing capital expenditure and disruption at these assets during the recovery.
We were pleased to announce and fund a strategic financial agreement with Goldman Sachs Merchant Bank affiliates, providing a $150 million unsecured term loan, expandable to $200 million.
This capital injection, combined with asset sales, led to the successful amendment of our credit facility, extending our covenant waiver until June 2022 and eliminating term loan maturities in 2021.
We're glad to have cleared the path and provided financial flexibility to focus on our portfolio's recovery in the coming year.
As discussed in previous calls and investor meetings, we've maintained a consistent approach to capital allocation.
Considering our assets' cash flow profile and liquidity, and the upcoming recovery in travel and lodging, we were reluctant to pursue a transaction that would unnecessarily dilute shareholders or limit our future strategic options.
We conducted a comprehensive process for this capital raise.
We were impressed by the number and quality of investors interested in financing our portfolio and look forward to future collaborations with many of them.
Ultimately, Goldman Merchant Bank offered prepayment flexibility, draw and pick features, and importantly, the potential for future partnership in the coming cycle.
As we approach the end of the crisis and move into recovery, we remain optimistic about our portfolio's position in our operating markets, which include innovation-oriented urban gateway markets and nearby regional resorts.
The appeal of drive-to resorts for all traveler segments was evident in 2020, and we believe this trend will persist, but we remind investors that innovation markets performed strongly before the pandemic and have the most to recover with vaccine rollout.
Since the pandemic began, Facebook and Google have expanded office space near our hotels on Manhattan's West side, and our Tribeca, Union Square, and Midtown East hotels will all benefit from major new office developments opening in the coming years.
Amazon has announced the addition of 3,000 jobs in the Boston Seaport, within walking distance of our Envoy Hotel.
Our Courtyard LA is well-positioned in Culver City for the growing tech and studio-related office expansion.
Philadelphia has attracted several new life science and pharma companies to state-of-the-art downtown spaces.
Even our Miami locations are attracting new Class A office space in Coconut Grove and Miami Beach, with increasing interest from Northeastern asset management firms and West Coast technology companies.
All of this demonstrates that corporate expansion remains strong and will contribute to the already robust demand generators in our gateway markets, particularly in our carefully selected submarkets and locations.
Our recent disposition announcements highlight the high quality of our portfolio.
Our hotels are exactly the type that sophisticated investors seek.
They have high absolute RevPAR while still producing industry-leading margins.
The properties are relatively new and designed for today's traveler, with minimal capital expenditure requirements in the near future.
Our hotels are fee simple with prepayable financing and few management or brand restrictions, all located in the most valuable markets in the United States.
Our portfolio has proven attractive to a wide range of buyers and still offers significant operational and financial leverage for this recovery.
With increased financial flexibility from our capital infusion and no near-term constraints following our credit facility amendment, we can focus on gaining market share and operating our hotels efficiently to drive cash flow.
As Neil mentioned, I'll provide a more detailed analysis of our recently announced capital transactions, bank amendment, and their impact on our balance sheet and interest expense before concluding with an update on our operating results and current outlook.
Last week, we announced a strategic financing agreement with Goldman Sachs Merchant Bank affiliates to provide $150 million in unsecured notes, which can be increased to $200 million at any time on or before September 30th of this year, with a maturity date in February 2026.
We successfully closed this financing yesterday and look forward to strengthening our partnership with Goldman Sachs Merchant Bank.
When we initiated our capital raising process earlier this year to secure additional liquidity and flexibility, we prioritized two factors: non-dilutive capital and significant prepayment flexibility. This tailored solution met both of these key criteria and several others we had prioritized.
This funding is unsecured, subordinate to our bank facility, and permits deferring cash interest on half our financing for the first year, yielding significant short-term cash savings and extending our financial runway during recovery.
The capital doesn't restrict additional junior funding and allows more unsecured debt as long as we meet certain financial criteria.
These unsecured notes don't impose any additional limitations on our business operations or potential strategic partnerships.
Recently, we announced agreements to sell two more hotels, bringing our total asset dispositions for the year to $178.5 million.
The completion of these sales, along with the Sheraton Wilmington and anticipated Duane Street Hotel sale, will generate $216 million in total proceeds. After repaying a $25 million mortgage on the Capitol Hill Hotel, net proceeds will be about $191 million, which we'll use with our unsecured note proceeds to clear our 2021 term loan and reduce overall debt by roughly $150 million.
The debt reduction and payment structure of our unsecured notes are expected to reduce our cash interest expense by about $4 million in 2021, while our total interest expense, including deferred interest from the notes, should remain similar to 2020 levels.
We finalized these property sales and unsecured note placement simultaneously with amending our revolving credit facility, and we're grateful for the ongoing support from our group of over 15 bank partners.
The amendment eliminates all term loan due dates until August 2022 and prolongs our covenant-waiver period, with our next financial covenant evaluation occurring on June 30, 2022.
The initial test will be based on the annualized second quarter performance, with the third quarter test annualizing the second and third quarter results, and so forth.
The amendment allows us to clear our preferred dividend backlog and maintain quarterly preferred dividend payments going forward.
We expect to clear the accrued preferred dividends by the end of the first quarter.
Finalizing these financial transactions enables us to concentrate on our operational performance and advantageous opportunities that may arise during the recovery.
Our properties have shown gradual improvement over the last six weeks, confirming our break-even projections for January. In this traditionally slow month, our properties achieved positive property-level cash flow with 40% occupancy and RevPAR levels 60% below January 2020.
In January, 20 of our 36 operational hotels reached break-even on the GOP line, with 14 achieving EBITDA break-even. This represents a 75% increase and 40% increase in properties breaking even on the EBITDA line compared to November and December, respectively.
Based on January's performance and our Q1 forecast, we're confident in our previous estimates that the entire portfolio breaks even at the property level with GOP at a 60% RevPAR decline. At the corporate level, our RevPAR break-even occurs at a 40% decline.
Our franchise operating model allows us to run our hotels with minimal staff until increased demand justifies additional hiring.
We employ various cost-cutting strategies like cross-utilizing management personnel, outsourcing, and job-sharing within hotels and across clusters to reduce overall expenses.
This model provides flexibility to maintain current staffing levels at our break-even occupancies of around 30% up to 55-60% at some properties.
As occupancy increases at our hotels, we're seeing GOP flow-throughs as high as 70%, and we expect to maintain these levels for the rest of the year as we boost both rate and occupancy.
The model's flexibility and resulting cost efficiencies justified continuing operations at our urban independent resort destinations throughout the pandemic, minimizing cash burn in 2020.
Our total property-level cash burn for Q4 was $5.9 million, and in January, properties generated positive cash flow for the first time since March 2020.
Corporate cash burn of $4.3 million in January represents a 60% reduction compared to April 2020, at the height of the crisis.
We anticipate February performance to match January, with March results expected to surpass both as vaccination distribution accelerates, government restrictions ease, spring break travel increases, and warmer weather in the Northeast should boost bookings across the portfolio.
Regarding our New York City joint venture with Cindat Capital Management, following our 2016 transaction where we sold most of the portfolio for a $213 million gain, we maintained a subordinated minority interest. Recently, the equity interests were transferred, and we no longer have any equity interests or economic or legal commitments to the venture.
We've removed these seven hotels from our portfolio count, and they won't be included in our operating results after Q1.
We concluded Q4 with $23.6 million in cash and cash equivalents and deposits.
During the quarter, we received $8.1 million in business interruption proceeds related to Hurricane Irma's impact on our South Florida portfolio, positively affecting our Q4 AFFO performance.
We invested $4.3 million in capital projects last quarter, bringing our 2020 total to $26 million, about $15 million below our initial forecast.
Our 2021 capital expenditure will primarily focus on maintenance and life safety renovations, expected to be roughly 35% less than our 2020 spending.
With minimal future capital expenditure needs after investing $200 million since 2017 and recently divesting lower-growth, higher-cost hotels, our portfolio will experience little disruption or capital spending in the coming years.
The unsecured note facility from Goldman Sachs Merchant Bank, combined with announced asset sales, will be used to reduce leverage, provide liquidity, and clear the accrual on our preferred dividends.
These actions have extended our weighted average debt maturity to 3.6 years, with over 88% of our debt now either fixed or swapped.
Over the past year, we've taken aggressive action to minimize operational losses.
We successfully implemented zero-based budgeting at our hotels, allowing for margin improvement well into the recovery.
We've reopened all our wholly-owned hotels and progressively reduced our cash burn rate to its lowest level since the pandemic began, demonstrating our effective asset management and adaptable franchise operating model.
Following recent strategic transactions, we've optimized our balance sheet and shifted our focus to the portfolio's operational performance as demand resurfaces and profitable opportunities emerge during the recovery.
We're now ready to take your questions.
Summary:
output:
will forego providing full-year 2021 guidance at this time.
completed full year and q4 2020 with approximately $23.6 million of cash & cash equivalents and deposits.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:We trust you are all doing well.
We will also mention certain non-GAAP metrics.
We think these metrics offer valuable supplementary information that, while not replacing GAAP measures, allows for greater clarity in reviewing our financial and operational results.
I'm now pleased to hand things over to Philippe Krakowsky.
I'll begin with a broad overview of our performance this quarter.
Ellen will then provide more details.
I'll then wrap up by highlighting developments at our agencies, followed by a Q&A session.
First and foremost, as Jerry mentioned, I hope you and your loved ones are staying healthy.
As we're all aware, the pandemic continues to significantly affect many parts of the world.
Given the circumstances, it's worth noting that our staff continue to deal with numerous personal and professional challenges posed by the health crisis.
Their remarkable resilience, innovative spirit, care for each other, and dedication to our clients are truly inspiring.

Regarding operating expenses and profitability, our teams again showed outstanding discipline.

We're still benefiting from cost improvements from last year's strategic restructuring, especially in payroll and occupancy expenses.
We also continue seeing benefits from low variable expenses due to highly restricted global travel and cost efficiencies of a largely remote workforce.
Looking ahead to post-pandemic work life, we expect expenses for travel, meetings, office utilities etc. will start returning in H2, most notably in Q4 and into next year.
Our Q2 net income was $263.3 million as reported.
Adjusted EBITDA was $405.8 million with a 17.9% margin on net revenue.
Our results show significant operating leverage versus both last year and 2019 on base payroll and office/other expenses.

Looking to the rest of the year, recall that in April we shared a full-year 2021 outlook assuming reasonably steady public health and economic recovery progress.
We projected 5-6% full-year organic growth and ~15.5% adjusted EBITDA margin.
Given our very strong Q2 and recently refreshed H2 outlook based on client/team conversations, we believe it's appropriate mid-year to upgrade those expectations.
We must acknowledge the COVID pandemic and related macro risks aren't fully behind us.
Looking ahead, we recognize lagging vaccination rates globally and new variants may increase COVID risk.
We'll watch this closely entering H2, especially our seasonally important Q4.
Assuming continued public health progress, we believe we can deliver 9-10% full-year organic growth.

We see this as another year of strong value creation for all stakeholders.
We'll keep you updated as the year progresses and look forward to those discussions.
With that, I'll hand over to Ellen for a deeper look at our results.
I hope everyone is safe and healthy.
Adjusted EBITDA before a small restructuring adjustment was $405.8 million, with a 17.9% margin.
These levels compare very favorably to any previous Q2.
With accelerated growth, some variable expenses still lag and we're seeing structural benefits from last year's restructuring.

These actions involved eliminating certain positions and reducing headcount, which will not return with revenue growth.

We are currently experiencing the benefits of most of these actions, and at full implementation, they will generate $160 million in annual cost savings.

We made several announcements at the holding company level that set us up for future success.
The most significant announcement was the recent launch of IPG Health.
This initiative will bring together our top-performing companies, FCB Health and McCann Health, under a new global network called IPG Health, led by a dynamic and experienced CEO along with a skilled executive team.
In this new structure, the individual agency brands within FCB Health and McCann Health will maintain their identities and continue to operate independently in the market.
These agencies will also gain access to additional specialized services, knowledge exchange, proactive career development, shared investment in new capabilities and skills, complementary geographic coverage, and enhanced collaboration.
Healthcare and well-being are becoming increasingly important areas for our clients and society as a whole.
The healthcare sector is becoming an increasingly vital part of the economy, with innovation playing a more crucial role in driving success.
Consolidating IPG's dedicated healthcare networks under IPG Health reinforces our leading position in this dynamic sector.
The combination of our scale, reach, and most importantly, the quality of our people and work is exciting.
We believe this new offering will continue to deliver exceptional results in the coming years.
This month, we expanded our portfolio of marketing technology and e-commerce providers by launching Performance Art, a data-driven creative CRM agency with leadership known for developing platform-level creative ideas suitable for both e-retail flows and traditional 30-second commercials.
Regarding our agencies' performance, IAN's growth in the quarter was once again led by media, data and tech, and FCB, particularly in healthcare.
UM secured significant new clients this quarter, including Enterprise Holdings, Behr Paint, and most recently, NYC & Company, New York City's official marketing and tourism organization.
UM also successfully retained the Australian government account.
At the Campaign Agency of the Year Awards, UM was named Global Media Agency of the Year, and UM APAC was recognized as the Best Media Network in that region.
Initiative was named 2020's Most Competitive Network Globally in Media Pitches and won a major account in the UK with banking and insurance company NatWest Group.
Reprise continues to show impressive momentum, especially in its growing e-commerce capabilities.
Acxiom, Kinesso, and Matterkind are performing well and are crucial in helping clients succeed in the addressable media market, which requires flexibility due to the rapidly changing landscape.
Acxiom continues to invest in innovative new products and services, such as customer data platforms and identity resolution, which are seeing increased client adoption.
Acxiom also deployed its latest customer intelligence platform on the cloud for a key financial services client.
FCB, McCann, and MullenLowe Group were recognized in the ACT Responsible 2020 Good Report, a unique ranking of the world's best creative communications promoting sustainability and social responsibility.
FCB Global continues to invest in talent and new offerings, hiring a head of data science and connections to expand its expertise in commerce, data, and technology-driven creativity.
McCann continues to demonstrate its creative prowess, recently being named Webby Network of the Year, with McCann New York named Webby Agency of the Year.
MRM is leveraging its Martek expertise and experiencing strong growth with its MRM commerce division, which helps marketers drive engagement, interaction, and conversion on commerce platforms.
MullenLowe Group's Mediahub continues its strong new business momentum, adding Hallmark's parent company, Crown Media, and Tally Financial during the quarter.
MullenLowe is also a global leader in purpose-driven work, partnering with governments worldwide to promote the benefits of COVID-19 vaccination.
R/GA's London office was named the UK's Digital Agency of the Year by Campaign, and added two new clients: financial services company Allianz and Vollebak Clothing.
We appointed a new CEO at Huge, who joined the digital agency after a successful tenure at Initiative, where he helped transform the agency into a leader in the media space.
Huge also saw strong new business activity, adding Sub-Zero Appliances, Wakefern, Tezos Foundation, and Nikko Asset Management.
The Martin Agency continues to impact culture and drive strong business results for its clients, notably selling the city's short film for DoorDash at the Tribeca Film Festival, which captured the resilience of New York City's restaurants and their role in the city's life.
At IPG DXTRA, several companies were recognized for their ability to deliver creative solutions.
Weber Shandwick was the most awarded PR agency at Cannes this year.
Current Global demonstrated their commitment to closing the disability and inclusion gap by creating guidelines and toolkits for marketers to make content more accessible for consumers with sight, hearing, or other cognitive impairments.
Jack Morton launched a return-to-live dashboard, a tool for brand marketers to assess where, when, and how businesses in the US can safely resume hosting live experiences.
Golin continued its strong performance in new business, being selected as LinkedIn's Global Social Media Agency of Record and Agency of Record for Yamaha Music.
Golin was also named PRWeek's Global Agency of the Year.
Returning to the holding company, our long-term focus on ESG, including diversity, equity, and inclusion, is a key area worth mentioning.
We are working to strengthen this commitment in all our operations and activities, including reassessing how we hire, train, and promote a diverse workforce, incorporating rigorous practices around data ethics and media responsibility, and further reducing our greenhouse gas emissions worldwide.
IPG was recently named by Forbes to their top ten list of America's Best Employers for Diversity.
We created a new position, our industry's first culture officer, to focus on long-term thought leadership relating to social justice issues for underserved and underrepresented communities.
As part of our integrated ESG efforts, we announced an action plan consisting of three climate goals: committing to set a science-based target, sourcing 100% renewable electricity by 2030, and joining the Climate Pledge co-founded by Amazon and Global Optimism.
We published our first SASB report, becoming the first company in the advertising and marketing sector to align with SASB's industry standards.
Our agencies also contribute significantly to our ESG profile, with media brands taking a leading role in promoting greater media equity by committing to invest at least 5% of client budgets in black-owned media by 2023.
Octagon launched an accelerator program with historically black colleges and universities for students interested in sports and entertainment careers.
R/GA created an innovative program to raise money for environmental organizations through a dedicated YouTube channel playing nature videos, directing all ad revenues to environmental NGOs.
Many of us look forward to working live with colleagues and clients, given that we're an ideas-driven service business.
We expect to have more people returning to our offices in a flexible hybrid model in the US, beginning in mid-September, as is already the case in certain other parts of the world.
We will be mindful of the public health situation and the lessons learned during the past 16 months regarding flexible work practices.
The costs associated with live collaboration and travel will begin to return as a normal part of our work and be reflected in our operating results.
We expect an increase in travel costs in the fourth quarter, potentially returning to levels consistent with the fourth quarter of 2019.
These are unprecedented times, and none of us has experience in emerging from a pandemic.
We shared our perspective on the balance of the year, assuming a reasonably steady course of macro recovery, continued vaccinations, and adequate mitigation of dangerous new variants.
We've delivered a very strong first half of the year on top of the most challenging comparisons in our industry.
Despite continued macro uncertainty, we have greater clarity for the balance of 2021.
We believe that current performance, combined with the continued execution of our long-term strategy, are significant drivers for sustained value enhancement for all our stakeholders.
We remain committed to sound financial fundamentals, including debt reduction and continuing to grow our dividend.
We also focus on resuming our share repurchase program and will keep you informed of our progress as the year develops.
Summary:
output:
compname announces q2 adj earnings per share of $0.70.
q2 adjusted earnings per share $0.70.
q2 net revenue was $2.27 billion, an increase of 22.5% from a year ago, with organic growth of 19.8%.
interpublic group of companies - upgrades expectation for fy 2021 performance to organic growth of 9%-10% and adjusted ebita margin of about 16.0%.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:We're all eager to move past the difficulties of 2020, and although the pandemic remains widespread, there's hope on the horizon as we cautiously approach 2021 with expectations of improvement.
In 2020, we maintained our long-term strategic focus while prioritizing employee wellbeing, adapting work methods, and meeting client expectations.
Our decade-long investment strategy has positioned us well to capitalize on future industry trends by anticipating shifts in client needs.
Our investment in capabilities and client-centric approach has generated positive momentum in our business, becoming more evident as the year progressed by better addressing client needs during challenging times.
We've experienced six consecutive months of positive net long-term inflows, amounting to nearly $18 billion in the latter half of 2020, with progress across various sectors, regions, and asset types.
The retail sector saw significant improvement in flows during the second half.
Our institutional pipeline, supported by our solutions, remained near peak levels.
We observed net inflows of $17 billion in the Asia Pacific region during the second half, with improving flows in EMEA and the Americas, while fixed income continued to show robust net long-term flows.
These combined factors create a strong foundation as we enter 2021, with several notable fourth quarter highlights.
Investment performance for many of our high-demand capabilities ranked in the top quartile during the quarter.
We experienced net long-term inflows of nearly $10 billion in the quarter, with continued inflows in fixed income and increased demand for equities, particularly in ETFs, quantitative, and index strategies.
The Asia-Pacific region maintained strong inflows, while flows in the Americas turned positive.
We also enhanced our operating leverage, cleared our credit facility, and improved our cash position during this period.
Our competitive strengths and key capabilities align well with areas of high client demand, positioning us for growth in 2021.
We aim to expand our market-leading position in ETFs, particularly in the US and EMEA, and build our passive presence in Asia-Pacific.
As the fourth-largest global ETF provider, we offer a range of passive and active strategies, including ESG ETFs, and continue to innovate as demonstrated by our recent product launches.
We're focused on growing our private markets business, led by our strong real estate and bank loan sectors, while active fixed income and global equity remain key opportunity areas with strong performance and high demand.
Our solutions efforts continue to be a priority, as clients value our comprehensive capabilities and services.
We're investing in our leadership position in Greater China, leveraging our long-standing experience and early mover advantage in the onshore market.
Given our investments and recent organizational alignment, we're confident in our ability to drive future growth and success.
We remain committed to helping our clients achieve their goals regardless of market conditions.
Our actively managed funds show strong performance, with 61% and 70% in the top half of peers over 5-year and 10-year periods, respectively.
We ended the quarter with $1.35 trillion in AUM, with $132 billion in growth, of which $95 billion came from increased market values.
The fourth quarter saw net long-term inflows of $9.8 billion, representing 3.9% annualized organic growth, with positive inflows in both active and passive AUM.
Our ETFs experienced $6.1 billion in net inflows, including strong performance in US-listed ETFs and growing interest in ESG-related funds.
Retail net outflows amounted to $800 million during the quarter, offset by positive flows in ETFs.
The institutional side experienced net inflows of $10.6 billion.
The growth in our passive and institutional AUM is significant for the company and contributed to the positive operating leverage generated during this period.
As mentioned earlier, we are observing a trend where ETF inflows are leaning towards products that generate higher fees.
Examining flows by region, the Americas saw net inflows of $2.2 billion in the quarter, showing a $6.6 billion improvement from the previous quarter.
This enhancement was attributed to net inflows into ETFs, institutional investments, various fixed income strategies, and notably, focused sales efforts and improved redemption rates.
Our global equity products saw an improvement of over $1 billion or 37% from Q3, driven by our developing market fund, which returned to positive net flows in the fourth quarter after experiencing negative net flows in the first three quarters of the year.
The UK experienced net outflows of $100 million during the quarter, as positive flows into our institutional quantitative equity capability were counterbalanced by net outflows in multi-asset and UK equities.
EMEA experienced net outflows of $1.4 billion due to institutional lumpiness and ETF outflows, primarily in our S&P 500 and Nasdaq-100 use ETF.
I mentioned last quarter that Asia Pacific had one of its strongest quarters ever with net inflows of $8 billion.
In the fourth quarter, net inflows were even higher, reaching $9.1 billion.
Net inflows were spread across various countries in the Asia Pacific region.
Of the total net flows, $4 billion came from Japan, $3.8 billion from our China JV, and the remaining $1.3 billion was generated from several other countries in the region.
It's noteworthy that we continued to see strength in fixed income across all channels and markets in the fourth quarter, with net long-term inflows of $8.2 billion.
This follows net long-term inflows of $8.8 billion in the third quarter and $6 billion in the second quarter.
It's also important to highlight that of the $26.1 billion in fixed income net inflows in 2020, $25 billion came from active fixed income capabilities.
Active fixed income has been a growth area for us in 2020 and remains a key investment focus for 2021.
Let's move on to slide 10.
Our institutional pipeline remains strong at $30.5 billion, following significant progress in the institutional pipeline during the fourth quarter.
This pipeline is diverse across asset classes and regions, and our solutions capability has contributed significantly to growth across our institutional network, justifying our continued investment in this key capability in 2021.
Looking at slide 11, you'll notice that our revenues increased by $135 million or 12.4% from the third quarter, driven by higher average AUM in Q4 and a substantial increase in performance fees.
Net revenue yield excluding performance fees was 36 basis points, unchanged from the Q3 yield level.
The impact of rising markets on our yield was offset by a slight fee rate decline due to the mix shift we experienced across products in the quarter, as well as the impact of non-management fee earning AUM.
We recorded performance fees of $78 million in the fourth quarter, with $48 million coming from our real estate business and $21 million from our institutional business and China JV, two of our key growth areas.
Typically, we tend to see higher performance fees in the fourth quarter.
Total adjusted operating expenses increased by 8.3% in Q4.
The $57 million increase in operating expenses was primarily due to higher variable compensation resulting from both market growth and compensation related to the performance fees in the quarter.
Operating expenses remained lower than historical activity levels due to pandemic-driven impacts on discretionary spending, travel, and other business operations that continued in the quarter.
However, we did observe a seasonal increase in marketing expenses as anticipated.
Moving to slide 12, we want to update you on the progress we've made with our strategic evaluation.
As previously mentioned, we conducted a strategic evaluation across four key areas of our expense base: our organizational model, our real estate footprint, management of third-party spend, and technology and operations efficiency.
Through this evaluation, we will invest in key growth areas, including ETF, fixed income, China solutions, alternatives, and global equities, while creating a permanent net improvement of $200 million in our normalized operating expense base.
As we noted, a significant portion of the savings will come from compensation, which includes realigning our client-facing workforce to support key growth areas and relocating to lower-cost locations.
In the fourth quarter, we realized $7.5 million in cost savings, with $7 million related to compensation expense as shown on slide 12.
The remaining $500,000 in savings were related to facilities, which are reflected in the property, office, and technology category.
The $7.5 million in savings, which amounts to $30 million annually, represents 15% of our projected $200 million net savings goal.
We expect about half of the remaining $170 million in net savings to come from reductions in compensation expenses.
The other half will be distributed among occupancy, technology expenditures, and general administrative costs.
Regarding the timeline, we anticipate achieving approximately $150 million or 75% of the run rate savings by year-end, with the rest realized by the conclusion of 2022.
We project that about 75% of the planned compensation cuts, 50% of the expected reduction in occupancy costs, and all of the G&A reductions will be implemented in 2021.
Most of the efficiencies identified in our technology spending won't be realized until 2022.
In Q4, we incurred $104 million out of our estimated total restructuring costs of $250 million to $275 million.
We anticipate the remaining transaction costs for implementing this program to range from $150 million to $175 million over the next two years, with roughly two-thirds of this occurring in 2021.
It's important to note that the expenses related to the strategic evaluation are not included in our non-GAAP results.
Regarding Q1, following improved market performance and asset inflows in Q4, we begin the year with over $1.3 trillion in assets under management.
Given the market improvement was more concentrated towards the end of the quarter, we expect both operating revenues excluding performance fees and the associated variable expenses to be slightly higher in the first quarter.
This reflects the impact of market growth and slow growth that occurred throughout Q4, even if we assume market conditions remain unchanged from year-end.
On the expense side, this will include higher associated variable compensation due to the seasonal increase in payroll taxes, partially offset by lower compensation related to the seasonal decline in performance fees and the implementation of our targeted cost savings.
Adjusted operating income increased by $78 million to $485 million for the quarter, driven by the factors we just discussed.
Adjusted operating margin rose by 230 basis points compared to Q3, reaching 39.5%, demonstrating the operating leverage in our business model.
This contributed to a 19% increase in adjusted earnings per share to $0.72.
We also benefited from higher non-operating income and lower non-operating expenses in the quarter.
Non-operating income included $31.9 million in net gains for the quarter, up from $15.2 million in net gains last quarter.
The increase was primarily due to unrealized gains in our seed money holdings.
Interest expense of $24.4 million was 28% lower than the previous quarter.
Q3 was the final quarter in which we paid dividends related to our forward purchase agreements, with a portion settled in January and the remainder to be settled in April 2021.
Our tax rate for Q4 was 21.7%.
The lower rate reflects reduced taxes on unrealized gains in our seed portfolio due to the location of our holdings.
We estimate our 2021 non-GAAP effective tax rate to be between 23% and 24%.
The actual effective tax rate may differ from this estimate due to the impact of non-recurring items on pre-tax income and discrete tax items.
We reduced our revolver balance by $90 million to zero in the quarter, in line with our commitment to improve our leverage profile.
In addition to using excess cash to reduce leverage, we aim to enhance liquidity and financial flexibility.
Our balance sheet cash position improved to $1.4 billion in Q4 from $1.1 billion at the end of Q3, with $764 million of this cash held for regulatory requirements.
We paid $117 million in early January to settle a portion of the forward share repurchase liability, with the remaining $177 million to be settled in April.
We believe we're making good progress in our efforts to build financial flexibility.
We remain committed to a sustainable dividend and to returning capital to shareholders in the long term through a combination of modest dividend increases and share repurchases.
In conclusion, Marty will discuss our key capabilities, the organic growth opportunities each presents, and our focus on executing the strategy aligned with these areas.
We're also focused on our strategic evaluation and reallocating resources to position ourselves for growth, while maintaining a prudent and cautious approach to capital management.
Our efforts to improve efficiency and effectiveness in our platform, combined with our work in building a global business with a comprehensive range of capabilities, puts Invesco in a strong position to meet client needs, operate a disciplined business, and continue investing in and growing our franchise over the long term.
Summary:
output:
quarterly adjusted earnings per share $0.72.
long-term net inflows of $9.8 billion in q4-20 compared to $7.8 billion in q3-20.
qtrly adjusted net revenues $1,228.4 million versus $1,267.8 million.
qtrly operating revenues $1,630.1 million, down 6.5%.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:We have presentation materials for our teleconference available on our website's Investor Relations page.
The world has undergone significant transformations in 2020 due to the COVID-19 outbreak.
Our main focus has been safeguarding the wellbeing of our staff and clients while maintaining operational continuity to meet customer demands.
All 34 of our global facilities are functional, and we're meeting all client requirements.
I'm impressed by our team's efforts in maintaining customer service and progressing with integration plans, which are proceeding smoothly.
Considering the weak second quarter, we're satisfied with our third-quarter performance.
Our sales increased by 28% from the previous quarter but decreased 5% year-over-year on a pro forma basis.
Let me provide more details about our performance by segment and region.
The Americas experienced the largest sequential sales growth, with a 48% increase primarily driven by higher volumes.
Asia Pacific, EMEA, and Global Specialty Businesses showed similar trends, with volume improvements leading to net sales increases of 24%, 21%, and 16% respectively compared to the second quarter.
We observed good sequential improvement across all business segments.
Another way to illustrate this quarterly sales trend is by examining our three main customer industry groups globally.
Metalworking showed the highest growth, increasing 39% sequentially from the second quarter, mainly due to automotive OEMs and related suppliers resuming operations after prolonged shutdowns or significantly reduced production in the second quarter due to COVID.
Our other industry groups, metals and Global Specialty Businesses, also grew by 21% and 16% respectively.
These various perspectives on our significant sequential sales increases should provide insight into the quarter's developments.
Overall, our sequential volumes rose 27%, but pro forma volumes were still down about 10% year-over-year, excluding the positive impact of Norman Hay, which we acquired last October.
This roughly 10% decline was observed across all regions and segments.
Asia Pacific was less affected since China actually showed modest year-over-year growth.
Despite weakness in our end markets, we continued to gain market share, with our analysis showing approximately 2% organic sales growth due to net share gains this quarter compared to the third quarter of last year.
I'm pleased with this strong rebound from last quarter, but we haven't fully recovered yet.
As previously stated, we estimate it will take at least two more years for our markets to fully recover, with some markets like aerospace, comprising about 3% of our sales, requiring even more time.
However, we expect our sales to rebound more quickly due to projected continued market share gains and potential future smaller bolt-on acquisitions.
Regarding third-quarter gross margins, they improved significantly compared to both the second quarter and last year.
The sequential increase is mainly attributed to higher volumes and their impact on fixed manufacturing costs.
The year-over-year increase was primarily due to realizing our manufacturing and raw material cost synergy savings.
The current pandemic and its effects are comparable in many aspects to the situation we experienced in late 2008.
Similar to that time, we implemented rapid measures to reduce costs in various areas.
We've eliminated virtually all discretionary spending, halted new hiring where feasible, furloughed certain positions, and reduced our planned capital expenditures by more than 30%.
Crucially, we reassessed our integration and synergy strategies in light of the current circumstances, taking additional steps and expediting other synergies when possible.
This has resulted in further cost synergies, leading us to increase our synergy achievement forecast once again this quarter.
Our revised estimate for cost synergies in 2020 is now $58 million, up from our previous projection of $53 million.
Additionally, we've increased our projected total synergies for 2021 from $65 million to $75 million, with 2022 expected to reach $80 million.
We achieved $17 million in synergies this quarter and anticipate progressive improvements in the coming quarters.
Considering the challenging operating environment, we're satisfied with the quarter's performance, noting significant sequential improvements in sales, gross margins, and adjusted EBITDA.
Our cash flow remains robust, and we've reduced our net debt by 7% or $58 million.
The ability of our business to generate positive cash flow during severe economic downturns, which we've previously discussed with investors, is once again proving beneficial in these difficult times.
We expect our markets to show gradual sequential improvement over the next year or two.
However, predicting improvement on a quarterly basis is challenging due to ongoing uncertainty in our operating environment.
We anticipate our fourth-quarter adjusted EBITDA to be comparable to the third quarter, and we expect our full-year adjusted EBITDA to surpass $215 million.
Our increased expected synergies, additional cost-saving measures, improvements in product margins, and cash flow management are expected to continue supporting us during this period of market decline compared to pre-COVID levels.
Looking ahead to 2021, we project our adjusted EBITDA to increase by over 20% as we continue to realize integration savings, gain market share, and benefit from an anticipated gradual recovery in demand.
I'm extremely proud of our team's performance in serving our customers, meeting their needs, and successfully continuing our integration efforts, which have been both crucial and challenging for us this year.
Our employees are our most valuable asset, and ensuring their safety and well-being remains a top priority for us.
I'm proud and very pleased with our Quaker Houghton team and what we have accomplished and will continue to achieve for our customers and investors, both now and in the future.
I'll now turn it over to Mary to review some key financial details for the quarter.
These are accessible on our website.
Please note that we continue to update our risk factors in our Form 10-Q to address evolving COVID-19-related issues, and these risk factors should be reviewed along with those in our 2019 Form 10-K.
Reconciliations are provided in the appendix of this investor presentation.
In this review, our comparison periods show actual and non-GAAP results, as well as pro forma sales and pro forma adjusted EBITDA as if we had been combined with Houghton throughout the periods presented.
Keep in mind that we finalized the Combination on August 1, 2019, so our actual reported and non-GAAP Q3 2019 results only include two months of Houghton.
Please refer to slides 6 through 10 as I review some highlights.
Mike reported a sales recovery of $367 million in Q3, a 28% increase from Q2's $286 million, yet still 5% below Q3 2019's pro forma sales of $386 million, primarily due to COVID-19-related volume reductions.
The gross margin of 38.2% showed significant improvement from Q2's 34% and last year's Q3 32.3%, which would have been around 35.5% without a purchase accounting adjustment.
This quarter's gross margin benefited from an estimated 0.5% increase attributed to a unique price mix.
As previously mentioned, the advantages of procurement synergies and manufacturing optimization became more evident with increased volumes, contributing to the sequential improvement.
Furthermore, cost synergies in these areas continue to grow, as reflected in our updated estimates.
Non-GAAP operating income bounced back to $43.2 million from Q2's $11.2 million, also surpassing last year's Q3 figure of $34.5 million by 25%, mainly due to the inclusion of Houghton and Norman Hay and realized cost synergies, partially offset by COVID-19's negative impact.
Non-GAAP earnings per share rose significantly to $1.56 from Q2's $0.21, remaining flat compared to last year due to additional shares issued at the Combination's close.
The current quarter's effective tax rate was an 8.1% expense, contrasting with a 27.6% benefit in Q3 of last year.
Quarterly effective tax rates have been highly volatile due to COVID-19-related profitability changes and ongoing updates to the 2017 tax law.
Excluding unusual items, we estimate Q3 effective tax rates would have been approximately 24% and 20% for 2020 and 2019, respectively.
For the full year, we anticipate an effective tax rate between 23% and 25%, excluding all unusual items.
Adjusted EBITDA nearly doubled to about $64 million in Q3 from Q2's $32 million and increased by approximately 5% compared to last year's pro forma adjusted EBITDA of $61 million.
This improvement is primarily due to realized cost synergies and the inclusion of Norman Hay, which more than offset COVID-19's negative impact.
Cash flow was a notable highlight this quarter.
As previously discussed, our asset-light business model, with investments primarily in working capital rather than fixed assets, typically results in significant positive cash flow from working capital releases during major downturns.
This was evident in both Q2 and Q3, with year-to-date operating cash flow more than tripling compared to last year, reaching $112 million.
Our low capital intensity allows flexibility in capital spending, and we're on track to reduce capex by over 30% compared to our original pre-COVID estimate.
Strong cash flow enabled us to decrease net debt by $58 million, a 7% reduction from Q2.
This improved our leverage ratio to 3.4 times from 3.7 times at the end of June, with our bank-calculated leverage at about 2.9 times versus the covenant maximum of 4.25 times.
Overall, our liquidity and leverage showed significant improvement from already solid levels.
We have increased our expected Combination cost synergy estimates to $58 million in 2020, $75 million in 2021, and $80 million in 2022.
Our history of successfully navigating challenging economic environments through market share gains, disciplined cost management, and strong cash flow generation during major downturns gives us confidence in our ability to overcome current challenges.
The strong core operating performance is further enhanced by realized cost synergies from the Combination, which are significantly impacting our financial results.
We anticipate a greater than 20% increase in adjusted EBITDA for 2021.
The company is well-positioned to capitalize on the expected upturn in business activity.
Summary:
output:
q3 non-gaap earnings per share $1.56.
full year 2020 adjusted ebitda guidance increased to exceed $215 million.
expects reductions in headcount and site closures to continue during 2020 and into 2021.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Presentation materials for our conference call can be accessed in the Investor Relations portion of our website.
The COVID-19 pandemic has brought about significant changes in the past year.
Our main focus has been safeguarding the wellbeing of our staff and clients while maintaining business operations to fulfill customer demands.
All 31 of our global facilities are functional and we continue to meet our customers' requirements.
I'm extremely impressed by the Quaker Houghton team's efforts in maintaining customer service and progressing with our integration.
We were satisfied with our fourth quarter performance.
Our overall sales increased by 5% sequentially, with growth observed across all regions and segments, primarily due to higher volumes as our businesses recover from the negative effects of COVID-19 on our end markets.
The sequential increase was most pronounced in EMEA, where we witnessed a 13% rise in sales compared to the third quarter.
It's noteworthy to compare our revenue changes to the fourth quarter of 2019, which was before the COVID-19 pandemic.
Our overall sales decreased by only 1% and our volumes remained relatively stable, but there were variations when examined by region or segment.
Asia Pacific was the sole area showing an increase in volume sold, with an 8% rise compared to the previous year, mainly driven by higher sales in China and India.
EMEA's volumes were relatively unchanged, largely due to an unusually weak fourth quarter in 2019.
Americas experienced a 2% decrease in volumes, primarily due to ongoing COVID-19 impacts on our end markets.
Our global specialty business volumes dropped by 9%, mainly due to reduced aerospace maskant sales.
It's important to highlight that our ability to secure new business and increase market share significantly contributed to our performance, with our analysis showing approximately 4% organic sales growth due to net share gains in the fourth quarter of 2020 compared to the same period in 2019.
