So while our overall volumes remained relatively flat, the 4% net share gains made a significant difference, as did our growth in Asia Pacific, helping to offset the negative impact of COVID-19 on our end markets.
I'm very pleased to see continued improvement from the previous quarter, but we haven't fully recovered yet.
As previously stated, we estimate it will take about two more years for our end markets to fully recover, with some markets like aerospace, which accounts for about 3% of our sales, potentially taking longer.
However, we anticipate our sales will rebound more quickly due to projected continued market share gains and acquisitions, which I'll discuss further.
Since our last conference call, we've completed two small bolt-on acquisitions.
In mid-December, we acquired a private US-based company called Coral Chemical for $53 million net of cash acquired.
Coral provides technical expertise and product solutions for pre-treatment, metalworking, and waste treatment applications in the beverage can and general industrial end markets.
Coral reported approximately $37 million in net sales and about $5.5 million of adjusted EBITDA in 2020.
We expect to achieve annualized synergies of approximately $3 million over the next two years from this acquisition.
In February, we purchased assets related to tin-plating solutions, primarily for the steel end markets, for $25 million, which will add full-year net sales of approximately $8 million and about $4 million of full-year adjusted EBITDA going forward.
We're pleased with these strategic additions to our product portfolio, which we estimate will contribute about $11 million of EBITDA in 2021, equating to an approximate 7 times EBITDA multiple purchase price for these two acquisitions combined.
Overall, we were satisfied with the quarter's performance given the current operating environment, and we observed good sequential improvement in our sales and adjusted EBITDA.
Synergy achievement also impacted our results, as we realized $18 million this quarter compared to $5 million in the fourth quarter of last year.
Additionally, our strong operating cash flow of $66 million in the quarter allowed us to further reduce our net debt by $24 million for the full year.
For the entire year, we reduced debt by about 12%, in addition to acquiring Coral.
The positive cash flow nature of our business during severe downturns is a characteristic we've previously discussed with investors, and we've observed this positive impact again over the past year.
Reflecting on the full year, the past 12 months have been challenging due to COVID-19, but I'm very pleased with our overall performance.
Throughout the past year, we've continued to service and supply our customers despite difficult economic conditions.
We've continued to gain market share and have completed a significant portion of our integration activities.
We managed to achieve $58 million in cost savings, surpassing our initial projection of $35 million.
We also completed two additional small acquisitions, which are expected to contribute roughly $11 million to our adjusted EBITDA in 2021.
Despite these acquisitions, we succeeded in lowering our debt by 12%, equivalent to $94 million.
In essence, we are realizing the significant advantages we anticipated from our merger with Houghton.
Looking ahead to 2021, we anticipate some temporary challenges due to increased raw material expenses and reduced automotive market volumes caused by the semiconductor shortage.
We hope these are merely timing issues that will primarily affect the first half of the year.
Notwithstanding these short-term obstacles, we remain optimistic about 2021 and still expect a substantial improvement in our profitability, with our adjusted EBITDA increasing by over 20% from 2020 as we finalize our integration cost savings, continue to gain market share, benefit from an expected gradual recovery in demand within our target markets, and see positive results from our recent acquisitions.
Regarding the timing and rationale for my decision now, I wanted to ensure Quaker Houghton was in a strong position for this transition, which it is.
This year, we will see a significant boost in our profitability.
We will largely complete our integration, reduce our debt further, and reach our target leverage ratio.
We have implemented the right strategy, assembled a capable management team, have exceptional employees throughout the organization, and see strong potential for above-market growth in our businesses for the foreseeable future.
From my perspective, our future looks very promising.
This is the ideal moment to make this transition.
I am excited to continue my involvement in the company's bright future as Chairman of the Board following my retirement.
I am incredibly proud of how our team has performed in serving our customers, meeting their needs, and successfully continuing our integration process, which was both crucial and challenging for us this past year.
Our employees are the cornerstone of our business.
By far our most valuable asset, ensuring their safety and well-being is and will remain our top priority.
I am proud of them and very pleased with our Quaker Houghton team, as well as what we have achieved and will continue to accomplish for our customers and investors, both now and in the future.
I will now pass the floor to Mary to review some of the key financial details for you.
This information can be found on our website.
Please note that updated risk factors will be included in our 2020 Form 10-K, which we plan to submit next week.
We have used a similar format for this presentation as we did for our Q3 call, where our comparison periods display actual and non-GAAP results, as well as pro forma sales and adjusted EBITDA as if we had been combined with Houghton throughout the periods shown.
Our Q4 comparisons of 2020 and 2019 in this presentation reflect actual results, not pro forma, as we finalized the merger with Houghton in Q3 of 2019.
For the full year comparisons, I will generally compare 2020 to pro forma 2019 results to provide an accurate year-over-year comparison.
As Mike mentioned, the gradual recovery in our business that began in Q3 of 2020 continued through Q4.
Q4 net sales increased 5% sequentially as all segments benefited from a gradual increase in volumes, and net sales were only down 1% compared to Q4 2019.
However, it's worth noting that Q4 2019 was a relatively weak quarter, negatively impacted by a widespread slowdown in industrial production, especially in Europe.
For the full year, reported net sales increased 25% in 2020 due to the inclusion of Houghton and Norman Hay.
However, on a pro forma basis, sales were down 9%, primarily due to lower volumes resulting from the global downturn in economic production caused by the COVID-19 pandemic.
Gross margin of 36.8% in Q4 is up from 34.8% in Q4 of 2019, which was somewhat deflated due to inventory adjustments for purchase accounting for Norman Hay.
Excluding these adjustments, we estimate Q4 of 2019's gross margin would have been about 35.3%.
The increase in gross margin Q4-over-Q4 is primarily a result of our progress in achieving combination-related synergies in logistics, procurement and manufacturing.
Our sequential gross margin was down slightly from Q3, reflecting a one-time benefit to gross margin in Q3 of approximately 0.5% and current quarter pressure from rising raw material costs and product mix.
On a full-year basis, gross margin was 36.2% versus 2019's 34.6%.
Without considering comparable expense adjustments from the fourth quarter, we estimate our gross margins for 2020 and 2019 would have been 36.3% and 35.7% respectively.
We anticipate achieving additional merger-related cost savings throughout 2021, which should lead to a steady improvement in gross margin.
We anticipate approaching a 38% gross margin area by the end of this year as we further realize our merger synergies and adjust prices to counteract increasing raw material costs.
Our fourth quarter operating income showed significant improvement on both GAAP and non-GAAP bases, with our non-GAAP operating margin of 11.3% being 1.7% higher than the same quarter last year, reflecting a sequential recovery in sales this year, our merger synergies, and the cost-saving measures we implemented to mitigate the impacts of COVID-19.
Annual GAAP and non-GAAP operating income also showed significant improvement.
Nevertheless, the annual operating margin decreased due to the COVID-related sharp decline in sales and volumes in the second quarter and the resulting pressure from fixed cost absorption, which we addressed in our second quarter earnings call.
Our reported effective tax rate was an expense of 4.9% in the fourth quarter of 2020 compared to a benefit of 18.2% in the fourth quarter of 2019.
Disregarding various one-time items, our fourth quarter effective tax rates would have been approximately 30% and 24% respectively.
For the full years of 2020 and 2019, we estimate that our effective tax rates, excluding non-core and one-time items, would have been approximately 25% and 22% respectively, aligning with our guidance for this year.
For 2021, we anticipate our full-year effective tax rate will fall between 24% and 26%.
Our non-GAAP earnings per share of $1.63 for the fourth quarter is a 22% increase from $1.34 in the fourth quarter of 2019, primarily due to the improved operating income I mentioned earlier.
Our full year non-GAAP earnings per share of $4.78 was lower than last year's $5.83 but surpassed the consensus estimate of $4.67.
Slide 11 displays the trend in our pro forma adjusted EBITDA.
Our fourth quarter adjusted EBITDA of $65 million is $4 million higher than the same quarter last year and $1 million higher sequentially.
Our full-year adjusted EBITDA of $222 million exceeds consensus expectations.
Additionally, our adjusted EBITDA margins improved for both the quarter and the full year.
Our fourth quarter adjusted EBITDA margin of 17% is 1.5% higher than last year's 15.5%, and on a full year basis, our adjusted EBITDA margin increased to 15.7% from our 2019 pro forma margin of 15%.
The improved margins are mainly due to the merger-related synergies we've achieved, partially offset by the impact of lower sales due to COVID-19.
Slide 12 provides an update on our leverage and liquidity.
As Mike pointed out, cash flow was the standout performer in 2020.
We've often discussed how the asset-light nature of our business helps us navigate downturns as our main investment is in working capital rather than property, plant and equipment, and we release working capital and generate increased cash flow during economic downturns.
We observed this in 2020 during the financial crisis and again this year during the COVID pandemic.
Operating cash flow for the full year reached a record $178.4 million, enabling us to reduce net debt by 12% to $717.3 million, pay $53 million for the Coral acquisition, net of cash acquired, and distribute approximately $7 million in dividends.
We're fulfilling our commitment to prudently allocate capital by prioritizing debt reduction, while maintaining our dividend payments and seizing strategic growth opportunities.
As a result of our prudent capital allocation, our primary leverage covenant of net debt to trailing 12 months adjusted EBITDA continues to improve and was 3.2 times at the end of 2020 compared to 3.5 times last year.
We expect to reach our target level of 2.5 times net debt to adjusted EBITDA by the end of 2021.
Furthermore, our cost of debt continues to benefit from the current interest rate environment with our borrowing cost under 2%.
In conclusion, Quaker Houghton continued to deliver on its commitments in 2020 despite facing very challenging market conditions.
At that time, we were in the very early stages of the pandemic with no way of knowing what was to come.
It undoubtedly turned out to be a very difficult year, but we concentrated on what we could control.
We kept our integration, execution and synergy capture on track and in fact ahead of schedule, we implemented additional cost savings measures to mitigate the decline in sales and we continued to achieve market share gains.
Consequently, we achieved record cash flow during the year and were able to reduce debt while continuing to execute strategic acquisitions that make financial sense.
In 2021, we anticipate seeing a greater than 20% increase in adjusted EBITDA and further expansion of our margins as we realize the full synergy benefits toward the end of the year.
I'll now hand it back to you, Mike.
Summary:
output:
michael f. barry will retire from his role as ceo on december 31, 2021.
michael f. barry will retain role of chairman of board following his retirement.
q4 non-gaap earnings per share $1.63 excluding items.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Alexandra Deignan serves as the company's Head of Investor Relations.
Our discussion today includes certain non-GAAP financial measures that we consider important for evaluating the company's performance.
Kenneth Jacobs, Lazard's Chairman and CEO, and Evan Russo, CFO, are leading our call today.
Lazard reported impressive results for Q4 and the full year 2020.
We reached a new high in quarterly operating revenue.
Financial Advisory experienced its best quarter ever, with strong results across all areas and regions.
Asset Management's revenue grew by 12% in Q4 and reached a record year-end AUM level.
We began 2021 with considerable momentum as we assist clients in preparing for post-pandemic recovery.
Our M&A activities in Financial Advisory progressed throughout 2020.
Our global announcement volume grew by 3% despite a 10% decline in market volume.
This growth was particularly strong in both the US and Europe.
Notably, our French and UK announcement volumes increased by 34% and 37% respectively compared to the previous year.
Our leading global restructuring practice continued to handle a diverse range of complex assignments.
In 2020, Lazard topped the league tables for completed restructurings worldwide.
As expected, the rate of new restructuring assignments in Europe increased.
Our sovereign capital and private capital advisory divisions all had successful years advising governments, corporations, and partnerships on financing strategies and fundraising.
Our private equity secondary business is expanding, and we're advising on numerous growth equity investments globally.
We continue to see growth opportunities in Financial Advisory and have accelerated our lateral hiring.
In 2020, we recruited 12 new Managing Directors globally, with two more joining in January 2021.
Additionally, we're promoting 15 new Managing Directors in Financial Advisory this month.
Ten of these promotions began their careers with us as analysts or associates.
Our ability to develop talent internally remains a significant competitive advantage.
Our Asset Management division also had a strong fourth quarter, with increased management and incentive fees reflecting AUM growth and strategy performance.
Our assets under management grew by $31 billion or 14% during the fourth quarter.
Our investments in new strategies and product extensions continue to create new growth opportunities.
Our quantitative business achieved net inflows for both Q4 and the full year, as did our global equities and global and multiregional fixed income platforms.
We're also seeing an increase in solution-oriented mandates as we serve more clients with customized strategies.
We continue to invest in Asset Management's growth through investments in people, technology, and distribution, as well as developing new funds and expanding existing platforms.
In 2020, we introduced eight new strategies for clients across our traditional and alternative platforms.
Three of these strategies come from independent teams we recently recruited.
As the asset management industry undergoes consolidation, we see significant opportunities to accelerate our recruitment of talent and investment teams, adding strategies that complement our existing platforms.
We also continue to develop our talent pool internally.
Asset Management will appoint seven new Managing Directors this year as part of its yearly promotion cycle.
Lazard's record-breaking quarterly results highlight the robustness of our varied business model, worldwide presence, and deeply ingrained culture of customer service.
We began 2021 with positive momentum across all our business sectors.
We recognize significant growth potential in both Financial Advisory and Asset Management and are making investments to take advantage of these opportunities.
Evan will now provide additional insights on our performance, after which I will discuss our future outlook.
Lazard's year-end and fourth quarter results demonstrate the resilience and continued excellent performance of our business divisions.
Our fourth quarter operating revenue reached a record-breaking $849 million for the company, a 20% increase compared to the same period last year.
The fourth quarter's adjusted earnings per share rose by 82% to $1.66, showcasing the considerable operating leverage in our business model.
Annual revenue of $2.5 billion remained roughly the same as 2019, indicating a robust recovery from the unpredictable market conditions of 2020.
Our Financial Advisory division achieved an exceptional fourth quarter, with record-breaking quarterly revenue of $509 million, surpassing our previous peak in 2018 by 23%.
The impressive performance of Financial Advisory in this record quarter was driven by strong contributions across various advisory practices and geographical regions.
Our revenue performance showcases the earning potential of the diverse advisory business we have developed.
In Asset Management, we saw a similar trend, generating $336 million in revenue for the fourth quarter, a 12% increase from the previous year.
This reflected contributions from our global platforms, with accelerating momentum during a year of extreme market volatility.
Management and other fees in the fourth quarter increased by 10% compared to the third quarter, reflecting higher average Assets Under Management (AUM).
Fourth quarter incentive fees significantly increased from the previous year, primarily due to strong performance in our alternative investment strategies.
Average AUM for the fourth quarter was $246 billion, representing a 3% increase from the same period last year and a 9% increase from the third quarter of 2020.
The sequential increase was attributed to market appreciation of $25.4 billion and foreign exchange appreciation of $5.8 billion, partially offset by net outflows of $0.3 billion.
For the entire year, we experienced net outflows of $11.4 billion, mainly in our value strategies within emerging markets and local equities.
Platforms with net inflows for the year included global and quantitative equities, as well as our global and multiregional fixed income strategies.
We concluded 2020 with AUM of $259 billion.
As of January 28, AUM stood at approximately $258 billion.
The decrease was due to foreign exchange depreciation of $1.3 billion and net outflows of $1 billion, partially offset by market appreciation of $1.3 billion.
Looking ahead across our organization, client activity in Financial Advisory is robust across our advisory practices globally in an improving economic environment.
Asset Management has started 2021 well, with AUM significantly higher than its average level for 2020.
We have a substantial pipeline of unfunded mandates.
We continue to observe demand for both our quantitative and fundamental strategies across our platforms, as well as growing interest in our sustainable and customized solutions.
Regarding expenses, our compensation ratio for 2020 on an adjusted basis was 59.5%, an increase from 57.5% in 2019.
On an awarded basis, our annual compensation ratio was 59.8% compared to 57.7% for 2019.
The increase reflected our investments for growth as well as the change in business mix this year.
We are maintaining our cost discipline while navigating a volatile market environment.
Non-compensation expense of $117 million in the fourth quarter was 10% lower than the same period last year, primarily due to continued global travel restrictions and reduced business development costs.
Our fourth quarter adjusted non-compensation ratio was 13.7%, while the full year ratio stood at 17.1%.
Non-compensation expenses increased in proportion to the uptick in business activity during the fourth quarter, particularly for variable costs.
The effective tax rate for 2020 decreased to 20.2% from 24.1% in the previous year.
We anticipate an annual effective tax rate between 20% and 25% for 2021.
Our company continues to generate substantial free cash flow, supporting our aim to return excess capital to shareholders through our capital allocation strategy.
We have maintained a consistent approach to returning capital via our quarterly common dividend throughout the year.
We returned $51 million to shareholders in the fourth quarter.
A quarterly dividend of $0.47 per share on our common stock was declared yesterday.
We have restarted our share repurchase program in 2021 to at least counterbalance dilution from year-end equity grants.
Our remaining repurchase authorization stands at $267 million.
Lazard maintains a robust financial position with sufficient liquidity and balance sheet flexibility.
Our cash and cash equivalents amounted to approximately $1.4 billion as of December 31.
Ken will now wrap up our remarks.
Let's discuss our outlook briefly before we take questions.
The short-term macroeconomic outlook remains unclear due to the ongoing health crisis.
Nevertheless, fiscal and monetary stimulus in developed nations and global vaccine distribution are fostering expectations of a recovery in the latter half of this year.
Both of our business segments are already seeing benefits from growing optimism among boardrooms and investment committees.
The factors driving global strategic activity in Financial Advisory have intensified.
Technological disruption continues to fuel M&A across various industries.
Shareholder activism has resumed its growth trajectory after a brief lull in the first half of 2020, with increasing impact in Europe.
The rapid proliferation of SPACs, alongside strategic and private capital, adds considerable dry powder to the M&A market.
Climate risk is becoming increasingly significant in company valuations and is emerging as a catalyst for strategic activity.
Our ESG expertise is well-established in our Asset Management business and increasingly in our Financial Advisory segment.
The expectation of prolonged low interest rates benefits our Asset Management business.
Investors' need for income and returns is driving increased demand for risk assets, including equities, corporate and emerging market debt, as well as alternative investments.
Institutional investors are seeking sources of differentiated alpha, including ESG, thematic, and alternative strategies.
We are well-positioned to meet this demand with our world-class investing franchise in markets that reward deep fundamental research, and our quantitative strategies are competing effectively in the market for low-cost products.
We see significant growth opportunities across our businesses and continue to invest in our people, capabilities, and technology infrastructure to enhance our competitive edge.
We remain committed to serving all our clients effectively while managing the firm for long-term profitable growth and shareholder value.
Our team excelled in one of the most challenging environments in modern history, providing outstanding financial advice and solutions to our clients and strengthening this great franchise.
I am honored to work alongside them.
Let's now open the call for questions.
Summary:
output:
q4 adjusted earnings per share $1.66.
q4 revenue rose 20 percent to $849 million.
for q4 of 2020, financial advisory operating revenue was $509 million, 29% higher than q4 of 2019.
aum as of december 31, 2020 was of $259 billion, up 4% from december 31, 2019, and up 14% from september 30, 2020.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Tim Crew, the CEO, John Kozlowski, the CFO, Maureen Cavanaugh, the Chief Commercial Operations Officer, and Steve Lehrer, who oversees insulin biosimilar initiatives, are participating in today's call.
The recording will be accessible on Lannett's website for at least three months.
Tim will shortly provide a brief overview of the company's financial performance, recent developments, and ongoing initiatives.
Following that, John will provide a more detailed analysis of the financial results.
We wish you continued health and safety as we all navigate the ongoing challenges of the pandemic.
I'll begin by highlighting some of last year's key achievements that are relevant to our future before discussing the main aspects we anticipate moving forward.
In 2021, we continued to introduce new products and expand our future portfolio as our primary focus.
We introduced approximately twelve new products, with notable contributions from Levothyroxine tablets, Levothyroxine capsules, and Clarithromycin.
The newly launched products from last year created additional revenue streams and further diversified our offerings, reducing our dependence on key products.
We also expanded our base product pipeline by maintaining investment in a comprehensive internal product development program.
For instance, our recent Mycophenolate approval was obtained in just under 10 months, marking the third product we've developed to achieve first-cycle approval in recent years.
We've made significant progress in our internal efforts, including major changes to our portfolio selection process.
While these changes take time to fully reflect in our financial statements, we believe they are creating substantial value.
Additionally, we are collaborating with our existing strategic alliance partners to broaden our agreements to include new products.
For example, Insulin Aspart was added to our HEC agreement last year, and more recently, generic Spiriva Handihaler was included in our Respirent agreements.
These products combined represent multi-billion dollar markets with relatively few anticipated competitors.
We also established a new strategic alliance partnership to launch Sevoflurane, a product with limited competition and a market size of approximately $190 million according to IQVIA data.
We plan to introduce Sevoflurane in the latter half of the fiscal year.
The second major achievement last year was maintaining strict control over expenses and demonstrating operational discipline while launching new products and expanding our pipeline.
We implemented and completed a cost reduction plan that involved consolidating our R&D functions to a single location and reduced operating costs by about $15 million annually.
The third significant accomplishment was the substantial improvement of our capital structure.
Over the past year, we paid off our Term A loans using available cash and later successfully refinanced our Term B loans.
The refinancing transaction was important for several reasons, as we've often emphasized.
We extended our debt maturity to 2026 from 2022, which is now after several of our larger and more significant pipeline assets are expected to launch and contribute to debt reduction.
We increased our credit facility and significantly freed up cash flow, primarily by eliminating mandatory principal payments until maturity.
The new debt has no leverage covenants.
As a result of this refinancing, combined with working capital initiatives, we have improved our cash position.
Consequently, we now have more readily available resources to invest in growth opportunities.
Another noteworthy achievement was that our teams, particularly those in our plants and labs, continued to work daily throughout the pandemic, ensuring a reliable supply of our affordable medicines.
This was accomplished despite the additional challenges faced during the past year.
We are extremely proud of all these accomplishments.
However, we also faced significant challenges.
While competition is a normal part of the generic industry, the competitive environment we encountered last year was particularly impactful as it involved some of our most profitable products.
We offset some of these pressures with the aforementioned new product launches and cost reductions, but the decline significantly exceeded the offsets.
In addition to a particularly competitive environment, COVID-19 continued to affect our financial performance with more downstream influences.
For instance, as we've mentioned, the pandemic led to fewer elective medical procedures being performed, which reduced sales and use of our cocaine-based product.
As a branded product, our Numbrino NDA has a higher than average gross margin for us, so fluctuations in sales have a disproportionate impact on our bottom line.
Fortunately, we believe many of the negative factors from the past year are beginning to diminish, while the positive factors continue to indicate significant opportunities.
With that background, and leaving John to discuss the specific financial results, I'll now address our outlook for the upcoming years.
We anticipate our overall net sales and gross margin will continue to face pressure due to recent and expected competitive pricing of certain key products, partially offset by the benefits of new product launches.
We also expect sales of our Numbrino NDA to be affected by the ongoing reduction in elective surgeries.
Once the pandemic subsides, we anticipate an increase in these types of procedures and, consequently, an increase in sales.
Although we anticipate a decline in revenue and earnings this fiscal year, we view it as the lowest point.
Our primary offerings have already experienced significant competitive price pressure, limiting further downside potential.
Concurrently, the future prospects of our product pipeline continue to improve.
It's worth mentioning that while we believe our generic version of ADVAIR DISKUS could be released in 2022, we haven't included any sales from this product in our fiscal year 2022 projections.
Likewise, zolmitriptan isn't factored into our fiscal 2022 forecast due to ongoing delays from our active pharmaceutical ingredient supplier.
However, we anticipate both products will significantly contribute to our fiscal 2023 performance.
Let's now discuss our product pipeline.
We continue to introduce products with approximately 13 Abbreviated New Drug Applications awaiting FDA approval, including partner products, plus four additional approved products pending launch.
We also have over 20 products in development and plan to add more through both external partnerships and internal efforts.
Our focus remains on targeting more valuable products compared to our historical average.
Regarding our portfolio of large, sustainable products, we currently have five disclosed assets.
In partnership with HEC, we have two insulin products: Insulin Aspart, a rapid-acting insulin, and Insulin Glargine, a long-acting insulin.
Together, these products compete in a U.S. market worth billions of dollars, according to IQVIA data.
Our respiratory drug-device portfolio, developed with our partner Respirent, now includes three products: generic ADVAIR DISKUS, which has been submitted to the FDA, along with generic Flovent Diskus and generic Spiriva Handihaler.
The combined sales of these products also represent a multi-billion dollar U.S. market, as reported by IQVIA.
As we've mentioned, all these products differ from traditional generics due to the significant technical expertise required for development and the substantial manufacturing investments made by our partners.
Consequently, we anticipate only a few competitors for each of these products.
Next, I'll discuss the significant progress we're making in advancing these large, sustainable product opportunities.
Regarding generic ADVAIR DISKUS, we've been in regular communication with the FDA about this priority application since its acceptance in May of this year.
We're encouraged by their level of engagement.
We expect to receive a mid-cycle review update from the FDA in the coming months.
Thus, we anticipate providing a clearer picture of the application's progress during our next investor call in November.
At present, we still expect more than one FDA review cycle and believe, as mentioned earlier, that approval and U.S. launch of the product is possible in calendar year 2022.
For those unfamiliar with Lannett's story, generic ADVAIR DISKUS is one of the larger assets in our submitted pipeline.
It's also currently the closest to expected commercialization in our partnered respiratory portfolio.
The second most advanced product in our respiratory portfolio is generic Flovent Diskus.
The final patient in the pivotal clinical trial for this product has been dosed, and we expect the trial analysis to be completed within a few months.
We're currently planning to submit an ANDA before the end of this fiscal year, with a potential launch in calendar year 2023.
As mentioned, we recently expanded our partnership with Respirent to include generic Spiriva Handihaler.
The development timeline for this product is expected to be about 12 to 18 months behind the generic Flovent Diskus product.
However, due to various intellectual property considerations, we're not commenting on specific launch timing expectations at this time.
Lastly, as we've previously stated, we're evaluating and negotiating additional product opportunities in the inhalation respiratory space, particularly dry powder inhalers and metered dose inhalers.
There continue to be additional multi-billion dollar market opportunities to pursue with both current and future partners.
Now, let's turn to our two biologic insulin products, starting with biosimilar Insulin Glargine.
Clinical material for the drug product has now been manufactured in the new dedicated manufacturing facility, which is a significant milestone.
We still plan to submit an Investigational New Drug application around the end of this calendar year and begin the pivotal clinical trial early next calendar year.
However, we've recently added a few months to the clinical timeline due to current COVID-19 restrictions at the study site in South Africa.
We've also added a few more months to our timelines to address interchangeability with the FDA, which I'll discuss shortly.
As a result, we currently expect to file the biologics license application in the first half of calendar year 2023 and anticipate launching in the first half of calendar year 2024.
It's worth noting that China's equivalent of the FDA, the NMPA, has approved HEC's Insulin Glargine for use in China.
That product is manufactured in the same new facility where we've just produced our Insulin Glargine for clinical trials.
The additional time we've added to the development plan to address interchangeability with the FDA is related to an important recent FDA approval of the first biosimilar and interchangeable Insulin Glargine.
We believe that this interchangeability approval is positive news for Lannett and HEC's insulin products.
This demonstrates the FDA's willingness to approve interchangeable insulin products, which should eventually improve affordable access to these crucial medications.
The development of biosimilar Insulin Aspart is ongoing, and we presently expect a potential product launch approximately 15 months after Insulin Glargine.
Insulin Aspart was manufactured in the same facilities, using the same teams and technologies as Insulin Glargine, allowing us to capitalize on earlier Glargine investments in development and production made by both Lannett and HEC.
Similar to our respiratory portfolio, we identify multiple opportunities to capitalize on our insulin assets.
There are additional dosage forms for both Glargine and Aspart, such as vials and other specific insulin products.
These opportunities once again represent multi-billion dollar markets, as reported by IQVIA.
We also recognize opportunities to leverage our USA clinical data, development, and related intellectual property, along with HEC's manufacturing capacity, to establish strategic alliances with third parties seeking to expedite their access to insulin products in international markets like Europe.
While discussions about such opportunities are in their early stages, these partnerships could generate significant value for both ourselves and our partners.
To conclude, a few brief remarks on Made in America and ESG.
Although we envision a future that includes several high-technology products from overseas sources, we are currently primarily a US-based generic medicines company.
Lannett adheres to stringent US laws and environmental guidelines regarding development and manufacturing compliance for our US-made products.
Most of our large generic competitors are already based overseas and are not subject to the same regulations, shipping most of their products from across the globe.
We take pride in serving the US market from within the US, with an admirable track record and reputation as a high-quality and dependable manufacturer.
We highlight these characteristics that make Lannett increasingly unique as a generic supplier so that our investors and customers consider Lannett when thinking about Made in America and various ESG-related initiatives.
To summarize today's remarks, our achievements in fiscal 2021 were substantial.
We directly confronted a highly competitive market environment.
We introduced new products and made significant progress in developing key products in our pipeline.
We expanded existing agreements, adding three large, durable assets to our respiratory and insulin franchises.
We refinanced our debt, improving free cash flow and extending our maturities beyond the expected launch dates of our major pipeline assets.
We maintain our belief that the promising products in our advancing and expanding pipeline have the potential to transform our company into a $1 billion enterprise by 2025.
I'll start with our financial results on a non-GAAP adjusted basis.
For the 2021 fourth quarter, net sales were $106.0 million, compared to $137.9 million for the same quarter last year.
Gross profit was $26.4 million or 25% of net sales, compared to $48.9 million or 35% of net sales for the prior year's fourth quarter.
R&D expenses decreased to $6.0 million from $6.6 million.
SG&A expenses decreased slightly to $15.5 million from $15.6 million.
Operating income was $4.9 million, compared to $26.7 million.
Interest expense increased to $12.1 million from $11.3 million in last year's fourth quarter.
Net loss was $7.4 million or $0.19 per share compared to net income of $13.4 million or $0.31 per diluted share.
Adjusted EBITDA was $12.1 million.
Regarding our balance sheet, as of June 30, 2021, cash and cash equivalents totaled approximately $93 million, up from $81 million on March 31.
Cash increased during the fourth quarter due to several factors.
Firstly, as a result of the refinancing, we did not have a principal payment on our debt.
Secondly, we continued to see working capital improvements from the third quarter.
Thirdly, we received income tax refunds.
Looking ahead, we anticipate receiving additional income tax refunds, continuing to benefit from initiatives to improve our working capital, and we have no mandatory principal payments on our debt until maturity.
Consequently, we expect to maintain a healthy cash position throughout the year and end fiscal 2022 with approximately $80 million or more.
Regarding our liquidity, we also have access to our $45 million credit facility, which we have not yet utilized.
Turning to our guidance, which as Tim mentioned earlier, does not include sales of generic ADVAIR DISKUS or zolmitriptan.
For fiscal 2022, we anticipate net sales in the range of $400 million to $440 million, adjusted gross margin as a percentage of net sales of approximately 23% to 25%, adjusted R&D expense in the range of $26 million to $29 million, adjusted SG&A expense ranging from $58 million to $61 million, adjusted interest expense of approximately $52 million, a full year adjusted effective tax rate in the range of 21% to 22%, adjusted EBITDA in the range of $40 million to $55 million, and lastly, capital expenditures to be approximately $12 million to $18 million.
Regarding the phasing of the quarters, we expect net sales and adjusted EBITDA in Q1 to be lower than Q4, increasing slightly in Q2 and continuing to rise more in the second half of fiscal 2022.
The increase is related to expected new product launches.
We anticipate gross margin in the first half of the fiscal year to be in the lower range of our outlook, increasing to the upper end of the range in the second half of fiscal 2022, and operating expenses to remain relatively consistent throughout the year, though we expect Q1 to be slightly higher than the other quarters, as it includes certain compensation-related expenses that are only recorded at the beginning of our fiscal year.
With that overview, we are now ready to address any questions you may have.
Summary:
output:
q4 adjusted loss per share $0.19.
completed re-financing transaction, debt maturity extended to 2026.
sees fiscal 2022 gaap net sales $400 million to $440 million.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Lexington thinks these claims are founded on sensible presumptions.
In these documents, any mention of adjusted company FFO pertains to the adjusted company funds from operations accessible to all equity holders and unitholders on a fully diluted basis.
Performance metrics for individual investments are not meant to be interpreted as a numerical representation of Lexington's past or future financial results, position, or cash flows.
During the question-and-answer segment of our call, Executive Vice Presidents Lara Johnson and James Dudley will be on hand to respond.
We experienced an excellent first quarter overall and are continuing to make significant headway in implementing our business strategy.
The quarter saw adjusted company FFO of $0.22 per diluted common share, which included $10.9 million in lease termination income, primarily related to a legacy industrial property in Durham, New Hampshire.
We acquired three industrial properties for about $51 million and finished a fully leased development project in the Columbus area during the quarter.
On average, these investments yielded estimated stabilized GAAP and cash cap rates of 6.1% and 5.9% respectively.
Our portfolio experienced continued growth in market rents.
Occupancy remains strong, and our industrial assets accounted for over 91% of gross real estate assets at the end of the quarter, not including assets held for sale.
We observed a steady increase in the value of our industrial properties throughout the quarter, and we believe our office portfolio has also appreciated in value as signs of the pandemic easing emerge.
Several factors are contributing to the ongoing increase in the overall value of our assets.
Capitalization rates are facing downward pressure, replacement costs are rising rapidly, and tenant demand is pushing rents higher.
Our industrial portfolio is reaping the benefits of all these trends, with the most visible indicator being the first quarter industrial base and cash base rent renewal increases of 14.6% and 5.4% respectively.
The factors driving up valuations are also creating a highly competitive investment environment, and we continue to focus our efforts on finding the best risk-adjusted opportunities in our target markets in the Sun Belt and lower Midwest regions.
The industrial acquisitions made during the quarter included two facilities in Indianapolis and one in Central Florida.
Furthermore, we have approximately $206 million worth of assets either under contract or with an accepted offer, which we anticipate closing later this quarter.
After a typical slow start to the first quarter, current deal flow is strong, with over $1 billion of investments under consideration.
We are cautious about pricing, as there is still a lot of capital seeking opportunities in a competitive market.
Regarding development, we are completing the construction of our Atlanta project in Fairburn and have committed to two other projects in our target markets of Indianapolis and Central Florida.
Development and the acquisition of vacant properties continue to be attractive methods for us to generate stabilized yields exceeding those available in the purchase market for fully leased buildings.
We leased 1.5 million square feet during the quarter, and our stabilized portfolio was 97.8% leased at quarter-end.
Our asset management team has done an excellent job in securing both lease extensions and new leases with increasing rents.
In addition to the three lease renewals in our single-tenant industrial portfolio, we increased occupancy at our multi-tenant industrial facility in Antioch, Tennessee to almost 100% while simultaneously raising base rental rates by approximately 16% for the two new tenants within the facility.
Following the end of the quarter, we executed a five-year extension at our 423,000 square foot industrial facility in Lumberton, North Carolina and increased base and cash base rent by 23% and 8.6% respectively.
Our balance sheet remains in excellent condition, with net debt to adjusted EBITDA of 4.6 times at the end of the quarter.
At the end of the quarter, our cash reserves stood at $170 million, including restricted funds, and we had $94.5 million in forward sales through our ATM program.
Our liquidity position improved during the quarter with $58 million in sales at GAAP and cash cap rates of 6.3% and 6.5% respectively, and will be further strengthened by retained cash flow for the remainder of the year.
Following the quarter's end, we divested our industrial property in Laurens, South Carolina for $40 million.
We currently have properties under contract or with accepted offers totaling approximately $135 million in gross price.
Our remaining portfolio of non-core assets for sale comprises 17 properties, which produced $8.2 million in NOI during the first quarter.
We estimate the current value of this portfolio to be around $290 million.
We continue to advance our ESG initiatives and have announced long-term environmental objectives.
We also distributed a survey to tenants to gather data, receive feedback, and identify partnership opportunities.
We became a supporter of the Task Force on Climate-Related Financial Disclosures and joined GRESB as a participant member, with plans to submit our first GRESB real estate assessment report this year.
The two properties we acquired in Indianapolis during the quarter are nearly identical, each being approximately 150,000 square-foot Class A facilities constructed in 2019, strategically located in Northwest Indianapolis within a mile of I-65.
Both properties are fully leased to two tenants each, with an average lease duration of just under five years and 2.5% rental rate increases.
Indianapolis' central location, excellent infrastructure, and large, skilled workforce make it highly appealing to various users, especially e-commerce distributors.
Indianapolis boasts one of the top five cargo airports nationwide, hosting the world's second-largest FedEx hub, and ranks among the top 10 U.S. bulk distribution markets.
Our acquisition in Lakeland, Central Florida, presents an opportunity to increase value by filling some vacant space in the facility.
The property is a newly-built 222,000 square foot Class A warehouse distribution center, primarily leased long-term to Motion Industries, a Genuine Parts Company subsidiary, with 2.5% annual rent increases.
We are in discussions with a potential tenant for part of the remaining space and have multiple interested parties viewing the additional area, aiming for a stabilized cash yield of approximately 5.3%.
Lakeland is a key submarket along the I-4 corridor between Tampa and Orlando, two of Florida's largest and fastest-growing metropolitan areas.
The property is located near the new Amazon Air Hub facility in Lakeland.
Our roughly 320,000 square-foot Rickenbacker project in Columbus, leased to a PepsiCo subsidiary, was finished in the first quarter.
The projected GAAP and cash stabilized yields are 7.9% and 7.7%, respectively.
As mentioned earlier, we continue to have a promising pipeline of ongoing development projects.
In Atlanta, our Class A, 910,000 square-foot development project is expected to be largely completed this quarter.
Atlanta experienced record-breaking positive absorption of over eight million square feet in the first quarter.
The airport South Atlanta submarket, where our property is situated, led the Metro area with over five million square feet of positive absorption.
We currently estimate our development costs to be around $54 million.
Our projected stabilized cash yield is estimated at approximately 5.25%, assuming full occupancy and payment of our core Promote by our tenant.
The asset is situated in a desirable area along the I-85 in Atlanta's southern submarket, where properties are selling at prices significantly higher than construction costs.
I will discuss the two development projects we have started funding in Central Florida and Indianapolis.
The Central Florida project is a high-quality, 1.1 million square-foot distribution center on a 90-acre plot with I-75 frontage, close to our recently acquired Amazon facility. The projected cost is about $81 million.
Ocala is ideally positioned for statewide distribution in Florida, located just above the I-75 and Florida Turnpike intersection, providing access to major cities and coastal areas, as well as routes to Jacksonville and Georgia.
Our Indianapolis project in Mount Comfort, which we began financing after the quarter ended, is located 14 miles east of downtown Indianapolis with convenient access to I-70.
Mount Comfort is one of Indianapolis' rapidly growing modern logistics submarkets, offering a favorable workforce compared to other competing areas.
The 1.1 million square-foot facility is estimated to cost around $60 million.
Similar to our Atlanta development, both projects feature state-of-the-art specifications, including 40-foot clear heights, efficient layouts, ample space for trucks and cars, meeting the needs of e-commerce and other large-scale distributors.
Construction is expected to be completed in late Q1 and Q2 of 2022 for the Ocala and Mount Comfort projects respectively, both with projected stabilized cash yields in the mid-5% range.
We will provide regular updates on the progress of these developments.
We produced adjusted company FFO of about $64 million or $0.22 per diluted common share in the quarter, which would have been approximately $0.19 per diluted common share without the $10.9 million lease termination income.
Quarterly revenues were $93 million, showing an increase compared to the same period in 2020, primarily due to new acquisitions and the aforementioned termination income.
Property operating expenses were around $11 million, with about 88% covered by tenant reimbursements.
First quarter G&A expenses were $8.4 million, and we anticipate our 2021 G&A range to be between $31 million and $33 million.
Overall, same-store NOI grew by 0.6% and would have been about 1.7% excluding single-tenant vacancy, with our same-store lease portfolio at 97.5% occupancy.
Specifically, industrial same-store NOI increased by 1.5% and would have been 2.8% without single-tenant vacancy.
At the end of the quarter, roughly 88% of our industrial portfolio leases had escalations with an average rate of 2.3%.
Regarding capital markets, we increased our ATM program availability to $350 million in the first quarter.
We also entered into forward sales contracts for 3.6 million common shares, which have not yet been settled.
As of March 31, we had 8.6 million unsettled common shares under forward sales contracts with a total settlement value of $94.5 million.
As Will mentioned, our financial position is strong with low debt and ample available cash.
At quarter-end, we had no outstanding balance on our unsecured revolving credit facility, and our unencumbered NOI remained high at 91%.
Furthermore, our consolidated debt was approximately $1.4 billion with an average interest rate of about 3.3% and an average term of 6.7 years.
Summary:
output: q1 ffo per share $0.22.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Melinda will commence and conclude the conference call, while Bob will discuss segment performance and financial details in the middle
We will then allow participants to ask questions
Our actual outcomes may vary significantly from these projections, despite our belief in their reasonableness
The most crucial risk factors that could impact our future results are outlined in our yearly report on Form 10-K
We suggest you examine those risk factors and other essential information provided in our SEC filings
I would now like to hand the call over to Melinda Whittington, who serves as La-Z-Boy's President and Chief Executive Officer
We are executing our plans and managing the aspects within our control, even during these times of extensive global supply chain disruptions
The La-Z-Boy enterprise achieved record-breaking sales of $576 million, surpassing the pre-pandemic fiscal '20 second quarter by 29%
Our company has grown significantly since before the pandemic, and we believe our current momentum can be maintained
We are prepared to expand upon our foundation of nearly $2.1 billion in trailing 12-month sales
As anticipated, operating margins improved sequentially, as our delivered sales for the quarter reflected pricing and surcharge measures implemented to counter unprecedented increases in raw material costs
Overall, we are satisfied with the growth and momentum we are experiencing during these challenging times
Looking ahead, demand remains strong across the company, and our backlog continues to be at record levels, even as we increase capacity to serve our customers and consumers
During the second quarter of last year, businesses were just reopening, and consumers were resuming furniture purchases
At that time, written same-store sales for the La-Z-Boy Furniture Galleries network were exceptionally strong, showing a 34% increase
Compared to that base, written same-store sales for the La-Z-Boy Furniture Galleries network decreased by 6% in the fiscal '22 second quarter
However, when comparing this quarter to the pre-pandemic fiscal '20 second quarter, written same-store sales for the La-Z-Boy Furniture Galleries network grew by an impressive 26%, resulting in a compound annual growth rate of 12% over the two-year period
Similarly, while written same-store sales for our company-owned retail segment decreased by 7% compared to the unusual prior-year period, written sales increased at a compound annual growth rate of 12% over the past two years
Joybird, primarily an e-commerce business, continued its strong growth trajectory, achieving 56% more business this Q2 than in last year's second quarter and delivering an impressive compound annual growth rate of 40% over the past two years
As we focus on addressing this strong ongoing demand and accumulated backlog, we continue to make strategic investments to increase capacity and improve capabilities, producing more units than ever to serve customers
We are continuing to add manufacturing cells and now employ almost 40% more manufacturing personnel than before the pandemic
In Mexico, additional cells are coming online at our SLR facility, and the first cells at our new [Indecipherable] plants are expected to begin operations in January, with that location fully operational by fiscal year-end
We continue to work on minimizing supply chain disruptions, from those associated with a lack of component parts such as electronic chips to those inherent in hiring and training new workers until they reach normal productivity levels
As mentioned last quarter, where possible, our procurement team is significantly increasing inventory for key components to minimize disruption while also working to diversify our supply chain with multiple sources in various geographies to protect against continued supply chain volatility
Early in Q3, we acquired the Furnico upholstery manufacturing business in the UK
Furnico has been manufacturing La-Z-Boy products for sale in the UK and Ireland since 2008
This expansion of in-house manufacturing capability will provide greater certainty of supply to our customers in the UK and is a key step in building an integrated supply chain network for La-Z-Boy International
During the quarter, we continued to return value to shareholders with a dividend payment and $15 million in share repurchases, bringing our total cash returned to shareholders in the first half of the year to $64 million across dividends and share repurchases
Last month, we were pleased to announce the expansion of our Board of Directors to 12 members with the addition of Erika Alexander, who serves as the Chief Global Officer, Global Operations for Marriott International
Erika has held various leadership roles for several of Marriott's largest brands and will bring a wealth of operational experience, perspective, and expertise to La-Z-Boy
While managing current operational challenges across the business, we're also addressing the long term with our work on Century Vision, our winning strategy for growth through our Centennial anniversary in 2027 and beyond
As noted last quarter, Century Vision includes three key pillars
The first is to leverage and reinvigorate the La-Z-Boy brand
This includes leveraging the La-Z-Boy comfort message, a renewed focus on attracting younger core consumers, and accelerating our omnichannel offering
To date, our marketing platform featuring Kristen Bell has been successful in driving brand recognition, including among younger consumers who say the La-Z-Boy brand is relevant to them
Our objective is to build on this sentiment, and last month we produced a new series of commercials that showcase how La-Z-Boy's range of products meet our consumers' needs
Throughout the course of Century Vision, we will expand the vibrant La-Z-Boy Furniture Galleries store base to approximately 400 locations across North America and will strengthen the entire network through remodels and relocations, with some 30 projects planned for this fiscal year
While the purchase journey may start digitally, our consumers like to visit our stores to shop, providing us with a great opportunity to deliver the flagship La-Z-Boy Furniture Galleries store experience
Our primary objective is to engage with customers throughout their buying process via various channels, both digital and physical.
We've achieved great success in managing our Company-owned stores, benefiting from the combined wholesale-retail margin.
We're actively acquiring independent La-Z-Boy Furniture Gallery stores to enhance our portfolio where it's mutually beneficial.
We've recently agreed to purchase five stores in Alabama and Tennessee from a retiring dealer, which will be profitable once we smoothly incorporate them into our portfolio in the third quarter.
The second component of Century Vision focuses on Joybird, where we have a profitable direct-to-consumer model and a dynamic brand with significant growth potential.
We're investing in Joybird to drive substantial profitable growth by increasing digital marketing expenditure, enhancing technology, expanding product range, and opening small urban stores in high-traffic areas.
We're thrilled to launch a new store in LA this month, with more planned to open by the end of this fiscal year.
In areas with Joybird small format stores, we consistently observe an increase in online sales, showcasing the appeal of an omnichannel approach across all brands and retail formats.
We recently introduced a virtual store at Joybird's LA headquarters, allowing online shoppers to interact with a dedicated retail environment via chat, call, or video conference, which has proven highly successful in terms of customer satisfaction and sales conversion.
The third aspect of Century Vision involves leveraging and improving our enterprise capabilities to support our consumer brands' growth and enable potential acquisitions that can benefit from our supply chain expertise and accelerate La-Z-Boy Incorporated's growth.
Enhancing digital capabilities across the entire La-Z-Boy enterprise and improving our supply chain's agility to better support all customer brands will be key priorities moving forward.
Overall, as we implement Century Vision, we anticipate growing our topline faster than industry averages and achieving double-digit operating margins.
We're pleased with our recent performance and optimistic about our future prospects.
On a consolidated basis, our second quarter sales for fiscal '22 increased by 25% to a record $576 million compared to the same quarter last year, showing sequential growth from the first quarter of fiscal '22, reflecting strong demand, increased production capacity, and the effects of pricing and surcharges.
Compared to the pre-pandemic second quarter of fiscal '20, sales were 29% higher, representing a compound annual growth rate of about 14% over the past two years.
Consolidated GAAP operating income rose by $54 million compared to the same period last year, while non-GAAP operating income increased to $52 million.
The consolidated GAAP operating margin was 9.4%, and the non-GAAP operating margin was 9%, showing sequential improvement from the first quarter.
GAAP diluted earnings per share for the second quarter of fiscal '22 was $0.89, compared to $0.75 in the same quarter last year.
Non-GAAP diluted earnings per share was $0.85 in the current quarter, versus $0.82 in the same quarter last year.
From this point forward, my comments will focus on our non-GAAP reporting unless explicitly stated otherwise.
I will now review our results by segment.
Product demand remains strong across all businesses.
In our wholesale segment, delivered sales for the quarter grew by 28% to $439 million compared to the same period last year, and increased by 12% sequentially from Q1.
Compared to the pre-pandemic second quarter of fiscal '20, sales were 25% higher, representing a compound annual growth rate of 12%.
The non-GAAP operating margin for the wholesale segment was 9.1%, compared to 12.2% in the second quarter of last year, primarily due to higher raw material and freight costs, start-up costs for new facilities, and labor challenges, partially offset by pricing and surcharges, fixed cost leverage on higher volume, and lower marketing spend as a percentage of sales.
Overall, we were satisfied with the results and the sequential improvement from the first quarter operating margin of 4.7%.
In the retail segment, delivered sales for the quarter increased by 19% to $192 million.
Delivered same-store sales rose by 17% compared to the same quarter last year.
Compared to the pre-pandemic second quarter of fiscal '20, delivered sales increased by 30%, representing a compound annual growth rate of 14%, demonstrating the strength of the La-Z-Boy brand and our furniture gallery store system in this environment, as well as strong execution at the store level with positive sales metrics across the board.
The non-GAAP operating margin improved to a second quarter record of 12.5%, compared to 9.4% in the same quarter last year, primarily driven by fixed cost leverage on higher delivered sales volume and expense management.
Sales for Joybird, reported in corporate and other, increased by 37% to $40 million compared to the same quarter last year.
On a two-year basis, compared to the pre-pandemic second quarter of fiscal '20, delivered sales increased by an impressive 93%, representing a compound annual growth rate of 39%, reflecting Joybird's growing momentum in the direct-to-consumer marketplace as we continue to acquire customers and strengthen brand awareness through new digital marketing channels.
For the quarter, Joybird increased both its web and in-store traffic, conversion rates, and average ticket size.
Joybird is maintaining profitability, and with a focus on accelerating disproportionate growth, we will continue to invest in Joybird marketing to drive broader brand awareness and customer acquisition.
To summarize, the consolidated non-GAAP gross margin for the entire company for the second quarter of fiscal '22 decreased by 500 basis points compared to the same quarter last year, primarily due to significant increases in raw material and freight costs, start-up costs associated with expanding our manufacturing capacity, and labor challenges in our wholesale businesses.
These factors were partially offset by pricing and surcharges in our wholesale business.
Consolidated non-GAAP SG&A as a percentage of sales for the quarter decreased by 280 basis points, primarily reflecting fixed cost leverage on higher sales volume, mainly in our retail segment, as well as lower marketing spend as a percentage of sales.
Our GAAP-based effective tax rate in the second quarter of fiscal 2022 was 26.6%, compared to 26% in the same period of fiscal 2021
Our effective tax rate differs from the 21% federal statutory rate mainly because of state taxes
We anticipate our effective tax rate for the entire fiscal 2022 to range between 25.5% and 26.5%
We generated $15 million in cash from operations so far this year
We concluded the period with $297 million in cash, no debt, and $31 million in investments to boost cash returns
Year-to-date, we invested $59 million in higher inventory levels to safeguard against supply chain issues and support increased production and sales
We also invested $33 million in capital year-to-date, mainly for retail store improvements, manufacturing and distribution facility upgrades, new upholstery production capacity in Mexico, and technology enhancements
Last month, we secured a new five-year $200 million unsecured revolving credit facility, replacing our previous $150 million ABL facility
The new facility includes a $100 million accordion feature, allowing us to increase our borrowing capacity for future growth
It also offers the option to request two additional one-year extensions beyond the initial five-year term
The facility's borrowings can be used for general corporate purposes and working capital
As of now, we have not borrowed against this facility
During the quarter, we continued our share buyback program, spending $15 million to repurchase over 400,000 shares in the open market, leaving 8.6 million shares in our authorized repurchase program
We have returned $51 million to shareholders through share repurchases so far this year
We paid $6.6 million in dividends to shareholders in the second quarter
After the quarter ended, the Board of Directors increased the regular quarterly dividend by 10% to $0.165 per share, showing confidence in the company's long-term growth prospects
Looking ahead, our long-term capital allocation strategy aims to invest about half of operating cash flow back into the business through capital expenditures and M&A, while returning the rest to shareholders via dividends and share repurchases
Demand trends remain strong across the business, significantly higher than pre-pandemic levels, with a high backlog and plans for increased capacity as new assembly cells come online, we expect a strong year of shipments
We anticipate a continued increase in production capacity, especially in Q4
Raw material and freight costs remain high, and global supply chain disruptions persist
Industry experts predict it will take several quarters to resolve West Coast shipping backlogs
Electronic chip shortages continue to affect our power furniture
We expect ongoing supply chain disruptions in multiple areas, particularly for our Company-owned retail segment, which tends to sell higher-end products
Due to the COVID-related shutdown in Vietnam, we anticipate a significant temporary decline in sales and margin for our case goods business in the third quarter
We will continue to monitor the escalating freight environment to determine if further pricing actions are necessary
We recognize that uncertainty and disruption are likely to continue for the foreseeable future, particularly in the third quarter
Quarterly trends will be affected by our third and fourth quarters containing 12 and 14 production weeks respectively, compared to 13 production weeks in our second quarter
Fiscal 2022 will include 53 weeks of results
Considering these factors, we expect Q3 sales and margin to be similar to Q2, with sales and margin accelerating in Q4, allowing consolidated La-Z-Boy results to finish the fiscal year with a full-year non-GAAP operating margin at or near double digits
We expect capital expenditures to range from $75 million to $85 million for fiscal 2022, supporting various business improvements and investments
We are proud of our organization and business partners for delivering strong results in challenging times
The team is effectively navigating the uncertain environment and positioning us for strong business growth in both the near term and as we execute our Century Vision
We believe the best is yet to come for La-Z-Boy Incorporated as we deliver profitable growth and long-term value for all stakeholders
Summary:
output:
q2 non-gaap earnings per share $0.85.
q2 sales rose 25 percent to $576 million.
q2 gaap earnings per share $0.89.
continue to expect sales and margin momentum to accelerate, particularly in q4.
continue to expect to deliver full-year consolidated operating margin at or near double digits.
qtrly retail segment delivered same-store sales increased 17% in fiscal 2022 q2 versus year-ago period.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:This meeting is being recorded and will be available for playback later.
You can find instructions for accessing the replay on our website at mdcholdings.com.
Various elements that may influence the Company's actual performance are outlined in the Company's Q3 2020 Form 10-Q, which is anticipated to be submitted to the SEC today.
It's important to mention that SEC Regulation G mandates specific information to accompany the use of non-GAAP financial metrics.
M.D.C. Holdings reported another strong quarter, with home sales revenue increasing by 33%, homebuilding operating margin improving by 370 basis points, and net income growing by 96% compared to the previous year.
New orders for the quarter grew by 73% compared to last year, with a sales rate of 6.1 homes per community per month.
These outcomes highlight the excellent housing market conditions we're currently experiencing across our regions and show our capacity to expand our operations while enhancing our profit margins.
Homes are increasingly functioning as offices, schools, and entertainment centers for families, leading people to seek living spaces that can accommodate these new needs.
While this shift has positively impacted the overall housing market, it has been particularly advantageous for the new home sector for several reasons.
There is a limited supply of existing homes for buyers to choose from.
The National Association of Realtors reports that total housing inventory at September's end was 1.4 million units, down 19% from the previous year and representing less than a three-month supply of homes.
A newly built home provides buyers with the assurance that they're the first occupants, which is a significant selling point for many families during these uncertain times.
In addition to the pandemic-driven demand, a demographic shift towards home buying is expected to provide ongoing support for the industry.
More millennials are reaching the age where they typically buy homes, while baby boomers and empty nesters are looking to downsize into homes that suit their changing lifestyles.
MDC is strategically positioned to benefit from these demographic changes due to our focus on developing communities with affordable housing options.
Home buyers of all ages are seeking value in their home purchases, and we've found ways to meet their needs through more efficient floor plans.
While lower interest rates and pandemic-related factors have boosted demand across all product types, we believe the more affordable segments of the market will be the most resilient in the long term.
We are fortunate to have a strong team at MDC.
I'm pleased to announce that Rebecca Givens has agreed to take on Michael's role as Senior Vice President and General Counsel.
In our operations department, David Viger has been promoted to Chief Operating Officer of our homebuilding operations.
Anthony Berris has been promoted to President of our Financial Service operations.
Dawn Huth has taken on additional responsibilities as Senior Vice President of National Finance.
These individuals have all proven themselves to be highly capable leaders during their time at MDC, and I'm confident they will contribute to our continued success in the future.
Lastly, I'd like to congratulate David Mandarich on his election as President and Chief Executive Officer of the Company.
David has been with the Company since 1977, most recently serving as our President and Chief Operating Officer, and is widely recognized as one of the most skilled leaders in the homebuilding industry.
His appointment as CEO is a crucial step in our Company's evolution, and I look forward to continuing to work with him on the Company's strategic direction.
David will join me in our future earnings calls.
Our company experienced robust revenue growth in the quarter, with home sale earnings rising 33% compared to the previous year, reaching $1 billion
The homebuilding operating margin saw an improvement of 370 basis points from the same quarter last year, leading to a 109% increase in pre-tax income from our homebuilding operations, totaling $101.7 million
Moreover, our financial services pre-tax income grew by $10.3 million, representing a 73% increase
This growth was attributed to our mortgage division, which benefited from higher interest rate lock volume, increased capture rate, and improved net interest income on loans originated during the period
Consequently, net income grew by 96% to $98.9 million, or $1.49 per diluted share for the third quarter of 2020
Our tax rate increased from 19.5% to 21.5% in the 2020 third quarter
This rate increase was mainly due to changes in the estimated amount of energy tax credits expected to be received during the respective quarters
We currently project a 25% tax rate for the fourth quarter, excluding any discrete items
The number of homes delivered increased by 25% year-over-year to 2,147, driven by a larger backlog at the start of the quarter and a slight increase in our backlog conversion rate
The average price of homes sold during the quarter rose by 6% to approximately $466,000
This price increase resulted from implemented price hikes across most of our communities over the past year, as well as a shift in the mix of homes closed from Nevada to Southern California
We anticipate home deliveries for the fourth quarter of 2020 to range between 2,400 and 2,600 units
The backlog conversion rate for the fourth quarter will be considerably lower than the same period in 2019 due to the significant year-over-year increase in orders during the 2020 third quarter, many of which are unlikely to be completed this year
We expect the average selling price for 2020 fourth quarter unit deliveries to once again exceed $460,000
The gross margin from home sales improved by 170 basis points year-over-year to 20.5%
Although we have experienced increases in certain construction costs, particularly lumber, due to the pandemic and other factors, we have successfully offset these increased expenses through home price increases
This has resulted in improved gross margins on both custom and speculative home deliveries across all our homebuilding segments
We expect the gross margin from home sales for the 2020 fourth quarter to approach 21%, excluding impairments and warranty adjustments
We continued to show strong operating leverage during the third quarter, with our SG&A expense as a percentage of home sale revenues decreasing by 200 basis points year-over-year to 10.4%
Our total SG&A expense for the 2020 third quarter increased by $10.9 million year-over-year, primarily due to variable commissions and marketing expenses that grew in line with our 33% increase in home sale revenues during the period
Our general and administrative expense slightly decreased compared to the previous year, mainly due to a reduction in stock-based compensation that was largely offset by an increase in salaries and other compensation-related expenses
Our overall workforce has grown by 5% year-over-year as we strive to support the company's strong growth trajectory
For the fourth quarter of 2020, we may see our general and administrative expense rise to between $50 million and $55 million due to the 5% year-over-year increase in headcount, additional bonus accruals in line with strong operating results, and a potential charitable contribution to our Foundation
As previously mentioned, due to the continued expansion of our gross margin and improved operating leverage, our homebuilding operating margin, defined as gross margin from home sales minus our SG&A rate, increased by 370 basis points year-over-year to 10.1%
Driven by this improvement, our last 12 months pre-tax return on equity rose by 560 basis points year-over-year to 21.8%, which is our highest level in 15 years
Let's examine our net new home order information for the quarter on Slide 9
The dollar value of our net orders increased by 89% year-over-year to $1.65 billion, and unit net orders grew by 73%, driven by a 70% increase in our monthly absorption rate to 6.1
The average selling price of our net orders rose by 10% year-over-year, driven by price increases implemented over the past 12 months, as well as a shift in mix to California, which has our highest average price
In the third quarter, our California markets nearly matched our Colorado markets in terms of net new orders.
It's worth mentioning that we concluded the quarter with 194 active subdivisions, slightly more than a year earlier.
Due to the robust sales activity during the third quarter, several of our subdivisions are nearing completion sooner than anticipated.
Consequently, we expect to have approximately 185 active subdivisions by the end of the year.
While this would be a decrease from the third quarter's end, it would remain unchanged from the beginning of the year.
Additional net new order information by month since April is provided on Slide 10.
It's evident that sales activity increased significantly following the initial slowdown related to the COVID-19 pandemic.
Order activity reached its peak in August, but September remained strong and significantly above the previous year, even after we raised prices in most of our subdivisions.
We also observed a continued decrease in the cancellation rate as the months progressed.
We anticipate some seasonal effects during the fourth quarter.
