Nevertheless, October has remained very strong compared to the previous year.
Based on current activity, we expect our October 2020 net orders to surpass our October 2019 orders by at least 50%.
As a result of our strong sales, we ended the quarter with an estimated sales value of $3.1 billion for our homes in backlog, a 47% increase year-over-year.
The average selling price of homes in backlog rose 4% due to price increases over the past 12 months, reduced incentives, and a shift towards California properties.
These factors were slightly counterbalanced by a shift towards lower-priced communities, in line with our ongoing strategy of offering more affordable home options.
I will now discuss land activity as shown on Slide 12.
The number of lots we acquired this quarter grew by 63% year-over-year, reflecting our confidence in market conditions and our focus on expanding our business.
Although the number of lots we approved earlier this year decreased due to COVID-19 uncertainty, we approved over 3,800 lots for purchase during the third quarter of 2020.
Ultimately, despite significant volatility, the number of lots approved over the last 12 months has increased by 34% compared to the previous year.
As a result, our total lot supply at the end of the quarter was 8% higher than at the same time in 2019, supporting our future growth potential.
We anticipate continued strong lot approval and acquisition activity in the fourth quarter, given the robust demand we've seen recently and our confidence in future housing growth prospects.
To summarize, we are encouraged by the housing market's resilience in the third quarter, considering the immense challenges our country has faced in 2020, and we believe we have executed our operating strategy effectively in this volatile environment.
More importantly, we see an opportunity for sustained growth well into the future, supported by solid demographics and changing customer preferences.
Our current backlog not only positions us for a strong end to 2020 but also provides an opportunity for significant year-over-year increases in home sale revenues and pre-tax income at the start of 2021.
With our strong balance sheet and current land pipeline, we are well-positioned to significantly grow our community count in 2021 and have a preliminary target of at least 10,000 home deliveries for the upcoming fiscal year.
We are aware of the many risks to achieving this target, especially with COVID-19 still impacting our daily lives.
These risks will be closely monitored as we work to grow our Company, and the safety of our employees, subcontractors, and customers will remain our top priority.
Following our strong third quarter, our Board of Directors has declared a 21% increase in the quarterly cash dividend from $0.33 to $0.40 per share.
This represents a 33% increase from the previous year and demonstrates our commitment to rewarding our shareholders for their continued support.
Summary:
output:
mdc holdings sees q4 2020 home deliveries between 2,400 - 2,600.
q3 dollar value of net new orders increased 89% to $1.65 billion from $871.7 million (adds period).
sees average selling price for 2020 q4 unit deliveries exceeding $460,000 (not $460,00).
q3 earnings per share $1.49.
quarterly cash dividend of $0.40 per share declared, up 21% from prior quarter and 33% from prior year.
qtrly home sale revenues increased 33% to $1.0 billion from $750.3 million.
qtrly average selling price of deliveries up 6% to $466,000.
mizel will continue his leadership role with mdc as newly appointed executive chairman.
qtrly dollar value of ending backlog up 47% to $3.08 billion from $2.10 billion.
david d. mandarich has been appointed as new president and chief executive officer of mdc.
staci woolsey has been appointed as chief accounting officer of mdc.
sees home deliveries for 2020 q4 between 2,400 and 2,600.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:We will refer to this information during our call today.
The earnings call will commence with Ward Nye discussing our business status considering the Coronavirus pandemic, our current and planned actions, and our strong position to handle the present situation.
Jim Nickolas will then present our Q1 2020 financial results and liquidity status, followed by Ward's concluding remarks.
A Q&A session will follow Ward's closing statement.
We sincerely hope you and your loved ones are and continue to be safe and well as we face the challenges and uncertainties of COVID-19.
I want to express my heartfelt appreciation to our Martin Marietta team.
I'm extremely proud of everyone's collaborative efforts in managing this unprecedented situation and how our employees' character has shone through.
Martin Marietta employees are consistently meeting our customers' crucial needs safely and resolutely.
They're also assisting their local communities in various ways, from donating essential supplies to healthcare workers and first responders, to helping neighbors with grocery shopping and ensuring our colleagues' well-being and safety.
Our team has demonstrated great bravery, determination, and resilience in meeting our stakeholders' needs while maintaining our core values of safety, integrity, excellence, community, and stewardship.
These values are the essence of our character.
We rely on these fundamental principles to guide our daily and long-term actions and decisions, especially during challenging times.
Martin Marietta continues to operate as an essential business.
This designation allows us to continue providing heavy building materials and services to our customers, even in areas with stay-at-home orders.
Communities nationwide must maintain their critical infrastructure, and we're working diligently to support this goal in a safe, efficient, and responsible manner.
Until the end of April, our workforce, operations, and supply chains have experienced minimal disruption.
We believe this is primarily due to our company's prompt and decisive response to the pandemic, our domestic-focused approach to sourcing supplies and materials, and our enhanced safety procedures, all aimed at protecting Martin Marietta employees and the company's organizational health.
During this crucial time, we are focusing on three key areas: communication, resource management, and business continuity.
We have implemented new comprehensive protocols and practices, including remote work, social distancing, and enhanced equipment and facility cleaning, in line with guidelines from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and medical professionals partnering with industrial hygienists familiar with our operations.
These protocols are continuously updated as public experts provide new guidance.
We also formed a COVID-19 Planning and Communications task force, cancelled all non-essential business travel and in-person meetings, established contingency plans for staffing, and have been actively engaged company-wide to improve the content and frequency of our communications to ensure accurate and timely information flow about our operations, keeping our employees, customers, suppliers, and other stakeholders fully informed.
Our operations teams have demonstrated remarkable agility, flexibility, and perseverance in maintaining smooth business operations.
They have taken timely and responsible measures to clean and disinfect facilities while carefully screening necessary third-party visitors to minimize COVID-19 exposure.
For colleagues typically working indoors in close proximity, we're using a combination of social distancing and work-from-home protocols.
Our employees are diligently fulfilling their job responsibilities and remaining fully accessible.
Importantly, whether working at an operating site, office, or remotely, our employees are empowered and encouraged to look out for each other.
With our team's safety ensured and employee engagement high, we can focus on our other stakeholders - customers, suppliers, creditors, shareholders, and communities - as we continue to run our essential business.
Jim will shortly discuss these results with you.
I'd like to first express our pride in these results, which highlight our commitment to operational excellence and disciplined strategies.
While we had a promising start to what we believed would be a record-setting 2020, we recognize this year will now be filled with unprecedented uncertainty as the COVID-19 pandemic and its economic and societal impacts continue to unfold.
Consequently, despite our confidence in the fundamental strength and underlying drivers of our business, we have withdrawn our 2020 full-year guidance issued in February.
We haven't yet observed contractors and customers significantly delaying or canceling building projects.
Although we typically don't comment on intra-quarter trends, these are unusual times.
We're making an exception and, as shown on our supplemental information slides 13 and 14, we're sharing preliminary April shipment and pricing trends to provide greater transparency about what we're seeing in a COVID-19-impacted month.
Specifically, for April, aggregate shipments remained high in most areas but didn't match the near-record April 2019 volumes.
We saw notable growth in North Texas, Colorado, and Indiana.
Cement shipments continue to be strong and are currently trending close to last year's levels.
The main exception is oil well cement shipments, as demand continues to decline due to volatile and historically low oil prices.
Ready-mixed concrete shipments are also trending near April 2019 levels, even as some homebuilders temporarily pause construction activity.
April revenues for the Magnesia Specialties business are $10 million lower than the same period last year.
Demand for our lime and periclase products has significantly decreased as steel-producing customers temporarily closed their facilities in response to the COVID-19-induced shutdown of certain domestic auto manufacturers starting in mid-March.
Regarding April pricing trends, aggregates pricing improved mid-single digits over April 2019 as announced increases were widely implemented earlier in the year.
Cement pricing is up, even with several competitors announcing plans to delay price increases until June 1.
Before the COVID-19 outbreak, we were very confident in achieving the full announced increase of $8 per ton implemented April 1, given strong market support in a tight Texas cement environment.
Ready-mixed concrete pricing is slightly higher than April 2019 levels.
We'll have a clearer picture of ready-mixed concrete pricing trends for the rest of the year as the phased reopening of the Texas and Colorado economies progresses.
Although ours is a fundamental and resilient industry, it doesn't mean we're immune to the disruptions caused by the pandemic.
Martin Marietta's economic performance may be affected by changes in consumer behavior or other industries due to the interconnected nature of the economy.
We expect product demand to decrease in the coming months, with private sector impacts occurring earlier than public sector effects.
The specifics of when, how long, and how severe the reduced demand will be are currently uncertain.
Infrastructure projects, especially those involving highways and streets that require substantial aggregate use, are anticipated to be the most stable of the company's main business areas in the short term.
Most state transportation departments remain active and continue to advertise and award contracts.
However, we anticipate many state DOT budgets will face temporary challenges due to reduced revenue from fuel taxes, tolls, user fees, and other sources as much of the population has been under stay-at-home orders.
The effects of lower funding are expected to become more significant in the latter half of 2020, barring congressional action, and will differ considerably among states.
For instance, Florida's DOT has expedited over $2 billion worth of crucial transportation projects to take advantage of construction efficiencies resulting from reduced traffic, including closing additional lanes and increasing daytime work hours.
To address state DOT funding risks, industry representatives are actively engaging with Congress to include surface transportation in the fourth phase of COVID-19 emergency relief and economic recovery legislation.
The primary recommendation is a federal backstop of nearly $50 billion in immediate flexible funding to offset the estimated 30% loss in state transportation revenues over the next year and a half.
The second proposal is to pass a comprehensive major surface transportation reauthorization package.
We believe our industry is in a better position than in recent years to implement an infrastructure build due to the backlog of fully designed projects.
Ongoing nonresidential construction projects have generally continued in most areas.
However, many commercial projects in the planning or engineering stages are being postponed or canceled, particularly in the office, retail, and hospitality sectors.
Some industrial activities, conversely, are not expected to face significant near-term disruption from COVID-19, with warehouses, distribution centers, and data centers likely to perform relatively well in the current climate as businesses increase e-commerce operations, secure regional supply chains, and become more dependent on cloud and network services.
Similarly, major energy sector projects along Texas's Gulf Coast that are already in progress are expected to continue.
The residential market is anticipated to experience the quickest and perhaps steepest decline due to COVID-19 impacts, as unemployment and general economic instability cause home buyers and developers to delay plans.
However, unlike the Great Recession, we do not expect a prolonged period of reduced residential activity.
Current housing inventories remain near all-time lows despite significant population growth in Martin Marietta states and will benefit from historically low interest rates.
As we prepare for the secondary effects of the economic fallout from the Coronavirus, we rely on our values-driven culture.
As emphasized earlier, the safety, health, and well-being of our employees, customers, communities, and other stakeholders remains our highest priority.
With established protections in place to achieve this, we're focusing on our business priorities of generating cash flow, maintaining liquidity, and adjusting costs to align with product demand.
Our team has developed comprehensive plans for various economic scenarios, and we're prepared to implement them promptly and with integrity as needed.
In addition to strengthening our balance sheet through a timely $500 million bond offering in early March, we've reduced non-essential expenses, cut capital spending for discretionary projects, and implemented hiring restrictions.
We're tightening our belts and aligning our capacity with demand in line with our commitment to being responsible stewards of shareholders' capital.
We will reassess these actions as visibility improves.
Having the right strategy, making appropriate decisions at the right time, and being able to execute them safely is crucial.
Martin Marietta will do exactly that.
We're well-positioned geographically, financially, and otherwise to successfully navigate through today's unprecedented environment and emerge stronger and more capable.
Firstly, Martin Marietta has a much stronger geographic and competitive position today compared to any previous downturn in our over 25 years as a public company.
This is significant, considering we navigated through the Great Recession while remaining profitable, never suspending or cutting dividends, and emerging with a healthy balance sheet.
Currently, we continue to generate record profitability on aggregate shipment levels much lower than our peak volumes in 2005, and with a geographic footprint that we've not only significantly expanded but also enhanced.
Furthermore, we continue to carefully execute our strategic plans, strategically positioning our business through aggregates-led expansion in high-growth markets with attractive fundamentals and leveraging strategic cement and targeted downstream opportunities.
These strategic plans not only provide Martin Marietta with new growth platforms but also opportunities to expand our footprint to complement existing operations and build critical mass.
We now hold leading positions in 90% of our markets, up from 65% a decade ago, which supports favorable pricing trends, economies of scale, and cost flexibility.
Secondly, we have experienced teams with decades of collective industry knowledge and expertise.
Together, their leadership and contributions have produced strong and sustained financial returns for Martin Marietta and our shareholders, as recently demonstrated by our one, five, and ten-year cumulative shareholder return performance.
This is largely the same leadership team that successfully formulated our operational response and prudently addressed our business needs during the Great Recession, the most challenging economic environment our industry has ever experienced.
In uncertain, evolving times, proven cycle-tested leadership and experience are crucial.
In summary, Martin Marietta has the right strategies, priorities, experience, and teams to responsibly guide us through these challenging times.
I will briefly highlight our first quarter results and provide a summary of our financial and liquidity positions, both of which support our near- and long-term strategies.
As detailed in today's release, our first quarter financial and operational performance exceeded our expectations, particularly considering the record-setting prior year quarter that benefited from carryover work from an extraordinarily wet 2018.
On a consolidated basis, total revenues increased 2% to $958 million, a first quarter record.
Gross profit remained relatively stable.
Selling, general, and administrative expenses improved by 10 basis points as a percentage of total revenues.
Diluted earnings per share was $0.41, and adjusted earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, depletion, and amortization (adjusted EBITDA) decreased 6% to $149 million.
The Building Materials business achieved record first quarter revenues.
Product demand remains robust across our service areas, including in Texas and North Georgia where precipitation levels were exceptionally high.
Prices for aggregates, cement and ready mixed concrete saw improvements, with all divisions contributing to robust growth, showcasing our market strength and effective local pricing strategies.
The Building Materials segment experienced a slight increase in gross profit.
Notable points include: aggregates product gross profit decreased by $5 million, primarily due to updating inventory standard costs.
Our per ton production costs have been decreasing over the past year as cost-saving measures and operational improvements take effect.
Under normal circumstances, this would lead to higher operating margins in the future.
However, this quarter it resulted in a $4 million expense as we adjusted our inventory valuation to reflect the lower costs.
In comparison, during Q1 2019, we recorded an $11 million inventory valuation adjustment to account for higher production costs due to weather-related issues in 2018.
While this total $15 million year-over-year inventory standard variance reduced quarterly product gross margin by 260 basis points, the lower unit production costs will provide benefits in the future.
Cement product gross margin increased by 1,170 basis points due to improved cost absorption from higher production levels and increased shipments to San Antonio, Austin, and Houston markets.
Price increases, along with reduced maintenance and energy costs, also contributed to the improved margin.
The ready mixed concrete business saw a $9 million decline in gross profit.
Price improvements and significant shipment growth in Colorado were outweighed by lower Texas volumes due to record rainfall delaying projects in the Dallas/Fort Worth area, as well as increased raw material costs.
In the Magnesia Specialties business, product revenues dropped 13% as expected, with chemicals customers continuing to reduce inventory levels for reasons unrelated to COVID-19.
Notably, product gross margin improved by 500 basis points despite lower revenues, thanks to ongoing cost control measures and reduced energy costs.
We still believe the destocking trend among our chemicals customers will be temporary.
Our consolidated results included several items affecting comparability with the previous year's quarter.
For clarity, we've included a slide in the Q1 2020 supplemental information on our website that shows a normalized view of pre-tax earnings with these items removed from both current and prior year quarters.
In addition to the aggregates inventory standard adjustments mentioned earlier, these items included $6 million in other nonoperating expenses to finance third-party railroad maintenance in exchange for a federal income tax benefit of about $7 million, which led to the low income tax rate for Q1 2020.
We also incurred a $2 million non-cash expense to implement a new paid time-off policy for our employees.
As shown on slide five, first quarter 2020 earnings before income tax, excluding items affecting comparability, improved by $15 million.
Now, let's discuss our capital structure.
Martin Marietta has historically operated with a growth-oriented approach while maintaining a strong balance sheet to preserve financial flexibility.
As a result, we have sufficient liquidity for the foreseeable future.
In the current environment, this is a highly advantageous position.
We will continue to balance our long-standing, disciplined capital allocation priorities to maintain this flexibility.
Our priorities remain focused on value-enhancing acquisitions, prudent organic capital investment, and opportunistic returns of capital to shareholders through dividends and share repurchases, while maintaining our investment-grade credit rating.
Our strategy aims to ensure our cash flows are adequate for a range of scenarios.
In today's uncertain climate, this range of scenarios is broader, and actions to enhance cash flows and maintain liquidity are even more crucial.
Before the full extent of the economic disruption became clear, we repurchased 211,000 shares in the first quarter.
Since then, we have temporarily suspended share repurchases.
We will continue to monitor the situation closely and reassess this pause in our share repurchase program as circumstances evolve.
To further boost cash flows, as Ward mentioned, we are reducing capital spending on discretionary projects.
We now estimate full-year capital expenditures will be between $325 million and $350 million, down from our original guidance of $425 million to $475 million.
We demonstrated our ability to reduce capital spending safely and prudently without long-term damage to the business during the Great Recession, and we are doing so again now as appropriate.
We strengthened the company's balance sheet and cash position with our timely bond offering in early March, issuing $500 million of 10-year senior notes at a 2.5% coupon.
Proceeds will be used to repay the $300 million of floating rate notes maturing later this month, with most of the remaining cash retained on the balance sheet.
Looking ahead, as shown in our supplemental information slides, after the May repayment, we will have no additional bond maturities for over four years.
We are confident in our liquidity position.
Net cash, combined with nearly $760 million available on our existing revolving facilities, provided total liquidity of approximately $880 million at the end of the quarter.
Additionally, with a net debt to consolidated adjusted EBITDA ratio of 2.3 times, we remain well within our target leverage ratio of 2 to 2.5 times at the end of the first quarter.
In conclusion, we are pleased with our solid first quarter performance and improved liquidity.
Regarding our 2020 full-year guidance, we will reinstate earnings guidance once we have sufficient visibility to do so.
Nevertheless, we remain confident that the attractive underlying market fundamentals and long-term secular growth trends in our key geographies, which underpinned the company's record 2019 performance and strong first quarter 2020 results, remain intact and will become evident again as the U.S. economy stabilizes and recovers.
Martin Marietta is well-positioned geographically, financially, and otherwise to responsibly navigate the current extraordinary environment and drive sustainable long-term growth and shareholder value as we move forward.
We have thoughtfully developed and consistently executed our strategic plans, positioning our business as an aggregates leader in attractive high-growth areas, aligning our product offerings to leverage strategic cement and targeted downstream opportunities, and prudently allocating capital while maintaining financial flexibility.
In doing so, we have built a business that is durable, resilient, and stronger than ever.
Summary:
output:
martin marietta withdraws 2020 outlook in light of covid-19 uncertainty.
withdraws previously-issued full-year 2020 guidance in light of covid-19 uncertainty.
shipments and pricing increased across majority of building materials business in q1.
qtrly earnings per share $0.41.
martin marietta materials - while co is not immune to impact of covid-19, believe co is well prepared to meet current & coming challenges.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Today, Ward and I will commence the earnings call by discussing our annual operational performance.
Following that, Jim Nickolas will present our financial outcomes and liquidity status for 2020, after which Ward will address market trends and our projections for 2021.
Subsequently, we will open the floor for questions and answers.
We earnestly wish for the continued safety and well-being of you and your loved ones.
The year 2020 was undoubtedly exceptional for Martin Marietta by all measures.
We take pride in maintaining our longstanding record of financial, operational, and safety excellence, especially during a year marked by unprecedented challenges.
Martin Marietta achieved new performance milestones, delivering our most lucrative year and the best safety record in our company's history.
These remarkable outcomes showcase our resilient business model and our team's dedication to Martin Marietta's vision, as well as the successful implementation of our proven strategic operating analysis and review plan.
As mentioned, our discussion today will concentrate on our full-year results and outlook for 2021.
Before delving into that, I'll highlight a few significant takeaways from our record-breaking fourth quarter.
Notably, we experienced solid growth in shipments and pricing across all product lines as construction activity stabilized following the spring and summer months when COVID-19 had a more significant impact.
These improvements in top-line performance, combined with our unwavering focus on cost management, led to a 7% increase in consolidated total revenues, a 20% growth in adjusted earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization (adjusted EBITDA), and a 40% rise in diluted earnings per share.
For the entire year, we established new records in products and services revenues, profitability, and adjusted EBITDA.
Specifically, full-year consolidated products and services revenues rose to $4.4 billion.
Consolidated gross profit saw a 6% increase to $1.3 billion.
Adjusted EBITDA grew by 11% to nearly $1.4 billion, and diluted earnings per share reached $11.54, an 18% improvement.
Martin Marietta's 2020 results marked the ninth consecutive year of growth in these financial metrics.
Operating our business safely forms the foundation of our long-standing financial success.
Martin Marietta's industry-leading safety performance continues to trend near or surpass world-class safety levels.
We achieved a 25% reduction in total reportable incidents across the enterprise in 2020, and for the fourth consecutive year, we maintained a company-wide world-class lost-time incident rate.
These outstanding financial and safety results are directly attributable to the dedication and adaptability of our nearly 9,000 talented employees.
I'm immensely proud of how our team managed the challenges and disruptions caused by the pandemic while remaining focused on being good teammates, working safely and efficiently together, and seamlessly meeting our diverse stakeholders' needs.
With that overview, let's now examine our full-year operating performance.
Aggregate shipments decreased by 2% to nearly 187 million tons, reflecting anticipated lower infrastructure shipments in parts of North Carolina, reduced energy sector demand, and challenges from COVID-19 disruptions.
However, in line with broader macroeconomic trends, full-year aggregate shipments to the residential market increased, benefiting from robust single-family housing activity.
Aggregates average selling price rose by 4% on a mix-adjusted basis, aligning with our expectations.
Notably, all divisions contributed to this solid growth, demonstrating this product line's resilient pricing power and our leading market positions in attractive geographies.
The disciplined execution of our locally driven pricing strategy, along with favorable underlying market fundamentals, will continue to support sustainable pricing growth moving forward.
Our cement operations set new records for shipments, which increased by 2% to nearly four million tons.
Large project activity supported underlying product demand in both North and South Texas throughout the year, offsetting weakness in the energy sector.
Pricing increased by 3% on a mix-adjusted basis, demonstrating the resilient price fundamentals of core products in the state of Texas.
We anticipate our cement business will continue to benefit from favorable shipment and pricing trends, supported by tight supply and healthy demand in Texas, diversified customer backlogs, and April 2021 price increases.
Regarding our targeted downstream businesses, ready-mixed concrete shipments increased by 3%, excluding shipments from acquired operations and from our Southwest division's former concrete business in Arkansas, Louisiana, and Eastern Texas, which we divested in January 2020.
Concrete pricing increased by 2%.
Our Colorado asphalt and paving division set a new record for asphalt deliveries, with a 15% increase to 3 million tons.
This increase was due to strong product demand and leftover work from weather-related delays in 2019.
The price of asphalt went up by almost 3%.
We finished 2020 with the best full-year adjusted EBITDA margin in Martin Marietta's history.
Our Building Materials division led this achievement, delivering record revenues of $4.2 billion for products and services, a 1% increase, and record product gross profit of $1.2 billion, a 7% increase.
Our primary materials businesses, specifically aggregates and cement, set all-time records for both annual product revenues and gross profit.
The product gross margin for aggregates improved by 130 basis points to a record 30.6%, and unit profitability grew by 8%.
These results, stemming from strong pricing, careful cost management, and reduced diesel expenses, showcase the cost flexibility and resilience of our aggregates-focused business.
The Cement division benefited from the scheduled kiln maintenance that took place at the end of 2019.
This maintenance timing resulted in some costs being recorded in 2019 instead of early 2020.
More significantly, this and other capital improvements have greatly enhanced our cement operations.
We reached 90% kiln reliability this year, up from 82% in 2019, which allowed for increased production and better fixed cost absorption at our Midlothian and Hunter facilities.
These factors, along with pricing strength adjusted for product mix and lower fuel costs, contributed to the 510 basis point improvement in cement product gross margin to 37.8%.
Our specialized downstream businesses also produced solid annual financial results.
Ready mixed concrete product gross margin rose by 10 basis points to 8.4% as price increases offset higher raw material costs.
Asphalt and paving achieved a gross profit of $60 million and a 100 basis point improvement in gross margin, driven by double-digit revenue growth.
Our Magnesia Specialties division returned to revenue and profitability growth in the fourth quarter.
The 12% revenue increase in the quarter wasn't enough to compensate for demand declines earlier in the year.
As a result, annual product revenues decreased by 12% to $221 million.
We expect the fourth quarter strength in chemical demand to continue in 2021, as steel production has recovered from last summer's COVID-19-induced low and our cobalt customers resume operations.
Remarkably, product gross margin improved by 80 basis points to 40.6% due to our proactive cost control measures in response to lower shipments.
Shifting focus to cash generation, capital allocation, and liquidity.
Martin Marietta ended 2020 with the highest cash generation in our history.
Operating cash flow of $1.05 billion increased by 9%, driven by earnings growth.
We continue to balance our long-standing disciplined capital allocation priorities to responsibly grow our business while maintaining a strong balance sheet and preserving financial flexibility to further increase shareholder value.
Our priorities remain focused on value-enhancing acquisitions, prudent organic capital investment, and consistent return of capital to shareholders while maintaining our investment-grade credit rating.
In 2020, we invested $360 million of capital into our business and returned $190 million to shareholders through both an increased dividend and the first quarter repurchase of 211,000 shares of our common stock.
In August 2020, our Board approved a 4% increase in our quarterly cash dividend, demonstrating its continued confidence in our future performance and maintaining Martin Marietta's history of dividend growth.
Since announcing our repurchase authorization in February 2015, we have returned over $1.8 billion to shareholders through a combination of significant and sustainable dividends and share repurchases.
We concluded 2020 with a debt-to-EBITDA ratio of 1.9 times, slightly below our target leverage range of 2 to 2.5 times, providing us the flexibility to pursue profitable investment opportunities.
Our robust balance sheet, combined with $1.1 billion available on our credit facilities, provides Martin Marietta with the financial strength to respond to and execute on disciplined capital allocation priorities and continue growing our business profitably.
Looking forward, we believe 2021 will see a return to more normal conditions as underlying demand fundamentals reset and the nation's economy regains momentum.
We remain confident in Martin Marietta's attractive business drivers and are encouraged by accelerating long-term trends across our three primary end-use markets and key geographic areas.
We anticipate these trends will drive construction-led, aggregates-intensive growth.
Infrastructure activity, especially for aggregates-intensive highways, roads, and streets, continues to show resilience.
The one-year extension of the FAST Act at current funding levels provides state and local governments with the necessary visibility to plan, design, and award transportation projects for the 2021 construction season
Projected fiscal 2021 lettings for our top five departments of transportation are currently at or above previous year levels
Our top five states - Texas, Colorado, North Carolina, Georgia, and Florida - are particularly significant, accounting for 71% of our 2020 Building Materials business total revenues
DOTs recently received almost $10 billion in targeted relief as part of the December 2020 Coronavirus Response and Relief Act to help offset pandemic-related transportation revenue shortfalls
This financial assistance does not require state matching funds
According to initial estimates, over $2 billion of this aid will be allocated to Martin Marietta's top five states
In the medium to long term, we expect voter-approved state and local transportation measures and the passage of a comprehensive federal transportation program to promote multi-year growth in product demand
In November 2020, voters demonstrated strong support for state and local transportation investment, approving 94% of ballot measures, the highest approval rating ever
These initiatives are expected to generate an additional $14 billion in one-time and recurring transportation funding, with 82% of that in Texas, our top revenue-generating state
There is bipartisan support for new surface transportation legislation aimed at increasing funding to levels not seen in over 15 years, with both the House of Representatives and Senate previously advancing proposed bills
We believe the 117th Congress creates an opportunity to advance a significant increase in funding over the FAST Act
We're optimistic that an agreement on a new bill could be reached this summer, generating substantial benefits in 2022 and beyond
We anticipate increased infrastructure investment to provide volume stability and drive aggregate shipments in that end-use closer to our 10-year historical average of 43% of our total shipments
For context, aggregate shipments to the infrastructure market made up 36% of 2020 shipments
Nonresidential construction is expected to continue benefiting from growing e-commerce and remote work trends, which require increased investment in large industrial warehouses and data centers, particularly in our key metropolitan areas
This type of construction tends to be more aggregates-intensive than light commercial construction due to the projects' size, scale, and structure
Light commercial and retail construction will remain relatively challenged until COVID-19 vaccines are more widely distributed
In the long term, light nonresidential activity will benefit from the positive effects of strong single-family residential trends
Aggregate shipments to the nonresidential market accounted for 34% of 2020 shipments
Single-family housing is set for multi-year growth, returning to more normal levels during this economic cycle
We believe Martin Marietta's strong presence in the southeastern and southwestern regions positions the company to benefit significantly from these trends, given underbuilt conditions, favorable population and employment dynamics, land availability, mild climates, and lower cost of living in these areas
Single-family housing requires two to three times more aggregates than multifamily construction, due to the additional nonresidential and infrastructure needs of new suburban communities
Aggregates for the residential market made up 24% of 2020 shipments
We are confident in the fundamental strength and underlying drivers of our business
As stated in today's release, we have resumed providing full-year annual guidance
We currently expect 2021 aggregates shipment growth to range from 1% to 4%, reflecting single-family housing strength, expanded infrastructure investment, and large-scale heavy industrial projects that will support our near-term shipment levels
We remain confident that our favorable pricing trends are sustainable, supported by improved contractor confidence and healthy customer backlogs
For 2021, we expect annual aggregates price increases, effective from January 1 to April 1, to rise in a range of 3% to 5%
Including contributions from our Cement, Downstream, and Magnesia Specialties businesses, we expect consolidated adjusted EBITDA of $1.350 billion to $1.450 billion
When comparing this guidance range to the previous year, we're not anticipating the same level of nonrecurring gains from land sales and divested surplus assets as seen in 2020
We're proud of our 2020 record financial results and industry-leading safety performance
We're also very optimistic about our future
Due to our efforts over the past few years, Martin Marietta is uniquely positioned to capitalize on emerging growth trends expected to support steady and sustainable construction activity in the long term
The disciplined execution of our strategic plan, combined with our pricing discipline, operational excellence, prudent capital allocation, and adherence to robust health protocols, will continue to strengthen Martin Marietta's solid foundation for lasting success
As we move forward, we have the resources, team, and capabilities to drive value-enhancing growth
We're confident in Martin Marietta's ability to build on our successful track record of strong financial, operational, and safety performance, and remain focused on delivering superior returns for investors while meeting and exceeding our commitments to other stakeholders, including customers, employees, and communities
Summary:
output:
martin marietta materials inc - qtrly total revenue $1,179.6 million versus $1,100.4 million.
martin marietta materials inc - remains well-positioned to capitalize on emerging demand in 2021 and beyond.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Mike Hennigan, CEO, Maryann Mannen, CFO, and other executive team members are participating in today's call.
We encourage you to review the safe harbor statements on Slide 2.
Results may vary from what is presented.
We'd like to provide a quick update on the business before delving into our quarterly results.
In Q2, we observed gradual demand increases for our products as COVID vaccination rollouts and eased mobility restrictions led to more economic activity and higher transportation fuel demand.
However, we're nearing the end of the summer driving season, typically our strongest period of the year.
Current gasoline demand is 2% to 5% lower than 2019 levels, with the West Coast lagging further at about 10% below.
Diesel demand remains steady, matching 2019 levels.
Despite rising personal passenger traffic, we continue to observe a lack of long-distance international flights and business travel.
Overall, jet fuel demand remains approximately 30% below pre-pandemic levels.
The complete recovery of aviation fuel demand will likely take more time, especially considering the recent surge in COVID-19 variants.
As we enter the latter half of the year, we remain cautiously optimistic about the recovery and will continue to focus on aspects of our business within our control.
Slide 4 showcases our progress on strategic priorities for the quarter.
On May 14, we finalized the sale of our Speedway business to 7-Eleven.
We announced plans to return $10 billion from the sale proceeds to shareholders through share buybacks.
To swiftly return capital, we immediately initiated a modified Dutch auction tender offer, repurchasing nearly $1 billion worth of shares.
We're continuing to restructure our portfolio.
Dickinson reached its full design capacity this quarter.
With an annual output of approximately 180 million gallons, Dickinson is the second-largest renewable diesel facility in the United States.
We're advancing detailed engineering and permitting at Martinez to convert the oil refinery into a renewable diesel facility.
Based on our progress and discussions with feedstock suppliers, we're confident in our timeline to start producing renewable diesel in the second half of 2022, with an initial capacity of about 260 million gallons per year.
We expect to reach full capacity of approximately 730 million gallons per year by the end of 2023.
We maintain a strong focus on cost and capital management in our challenging commodity business, as being a low-cost operator ensures our competitiveness.
We've continued to scrutinize all aspects of spending, resulting in additional progress.
Our operating results for the first half of 2021 reflect our aim to reduce overall refining cost structure by $1 billion.
Notably, we published our two annual ESG-related reports in June.
Our sustainability report provides a comprehensive look at the company's sustainability approach and performance, aligning with SASB and GRI reporting guidelines.
Our perspectives on climate-related scenarios follow TCFD guidance and analyze the company's resilience relative to climate scenarios proposed by the IEA.
Slide 5 outlines some ways we're challenging ourselves to lead in sustainable energy.
Strategically, we aim to balance current needs while investing in a sustainable, energy-diverse future.
This includes enhancing resilience by reducing our carbon intensity and conserving natural resources, planning for the future by investing in renewables and emerging technologies, and integrating sustainability into decision-making across all aspects of engagement with our people and stakeholders.
We have three well-known companywide targets.
First, reducing our Scope 1 and Scope 2 greenhouse gas emissions intensity by 30% by 2030.
Second, decreasing midstream methane intensity by 50% by 2025.
Lastly, reducing our fresh water withdrawal intensity by 20% by 2030.
The changing energy landscape presents significant opportunities for innovation.
We've allocated 40% of our 2021 growth capital to advance two major renewable fuels projects.
In late 2020, we began renewable diesel production at our Dickinson, North Dakota facility, the second-largest of its kind in the United States, and are progressing with the conversion of our Martinez, California refinery to a renewable diesel facility.
To showcase our commitment to integrating sustainability across all levels of our organization, we tie a portion of executive and employee bonuses to an ESG-related metric.
We recently became the first U.S. independent downstream company to incorporate both diversity, equity, and inclusion goals and greenhouse gas intensity reduction targets into our compensation structure.
Maintaining safety in our operations is crucial for sustainable business practices.
Our teams achieved impressive safety and environmental results in 2020, including significant reductions in serious process safety incidents and environmental issues compared to the previous year.
We continue to outperform industry standards for personal safety in the U.S. refining and midstream sectors.
The sixth slide presents an overview of our financial performance for the second quarter.
Our adjusted EBITDA for the quarter totaled $2.194 billion.
This figure encompasses results from both ongoing and discontinued operations.
Cash flow from continuing operations, excluding working capital changes, reached $1.535 billion, marking a roughly $1 billion increase from the previous quarter.
For the first time in almost a year and a half, our ongoing operating cash flow exceeded our business needs, capital commitments, and covered both dividends and distributions.
We returned approximately $1.4 billion to shareholders this quarter through dividend payments and share buybacks.
The completion of the Speedway sale represents a significant step in our ongoing efforts to enhance our portfolio's competitive position.
We'd like to highlight some key points about the sale on Slide 7.
The total proceeds from the Speedway sale amounted to $21 billion.
Based on our tax basis, our cash tax liability, both current and deferred, will be around $4.2 billion, which is lower than our initial estimate of $4.5 billion.
This amount has been accounted for on our balance sheet.
Additionally, there were closing adjustments of about $400 million.
Consequently, the after-tax proceeds from the sale will total $17.2 billion.
It's worth noting that this figure exceeds our initial projection of $16.5 billion.
Slide 8 outlines how we plan to use the proceeds from the sale.
Since finalizing the transaction, we have reduced our structural debt by $2.5 billion and repurchased approximately $1 billion in stock.
We didn't buy back additional shares during the post-tender period due to regulatory restrictions, including a mandatory cooling-off period and our routine quarterly blackout period before earnings announcements.
However, this temporary pause in repurchases doesn't indicate any change in our commitment to complete the buyback within 12 to 16 months.
In line with this commitment, as Mike mentioned earlier, we are initiating the next phase to complete the remaining $9 billion capital return.
Specifically, we're launching an open-market repurchase program that will allow us to buy shares over an extended period, even when we may possess information that would normally prevent us from trading. We will provide updates on our progress during earnings calls.
Slide 9 demonstrates the progress we've made in reducing our cost structure.
Since the start of 2020, we've significantly lowered our refining operating costs and decreased our overall cost profile by about $1 billion.
While there are quarter-to-quarter fluctuations, our refining operating costs have decreased from $6 per barrel at the beginning of 2020 to an average of roughly $5 per barrel in 2021.
We've applied the same cost-cutting approach to our corporate expenses.
Although corporate costs may vary from quarter to quarter, we believe we've reduced our overall cost structure by more than $100 million, and we continually seek new ways to cut expenses.
Natural gas, a variable cost in refinery operations, has recently increased by nearly $1 per MMBtu, which we expect to be a challenge in the third quarter.
While our results reflect our focus on cost management, we remain committed to safely operating our assets and protecting the health and safety of our employees, customers, and communities.
As we've previously stated, our cost reductions are designed to be sustainable, avoid impacting revenue opportunities, and never compromise the safety of our people or operations.
Slide 10 provides a reconciliation from net income to adjusted EBITDA and shows the quarter-over-quarter change in adjusted EBITDA from Q1 2021 to Q2 2021.
Adjusted EBITDA increased by over $600 million compared to the previous quarter, primarily driven by improvements in refining and marketing.
As mentioned earlier, this quarter's results include the effects of finalizing the Speedway sale.
In this section, the $11.7 billion pre-tax profit from the sale is shown in the adjustments column as $11.6 billion, which includes other adjustments of $79 million for impairment and transaction-related expenses.
The $3.7 billion financial tax provision represents the combined effect of cash taxes and deferred tax impact.
The $8 billion profit from the sale is included in our quarterly net income.
Slide 18 in our appendix details the specific effects of the Speedway sale across the three financial statements.
Let's move on to our segment results.
Slide 11 gives a summary of our refining and marketing segment.
The division reported positive EBITDA for the second consecutive quarter since the COVID pandemic began, with adjusted EBITDA of $751 million.
This was a $728 million improvement compared to the first quarter of 2021.
The improvement was mainly due to higher refining margins, particularly in the Mid-Con region where cracks improved by 57% from the first quarter.
Higher utilization also contributed to the improved results, reaching 94% for the second quarter compared to 83% in the first quarter.
It's worth noting that we shut down two high-cost refineries in 2020.
If adjusted to include that idled capacity from 2020, utilization would have been about 78% in the first quarter of '21 and subsequently rose to 89% in the second quarter of '21.
Operating costs remained relatively stable compared to the previous quarter despite increased utilization, demonstrating the team's commitment to cost control despite rising variable expenses.
Slide 12 illustrates the change in our midstream EBITDA compared to the first quarter of 2021.
Our midstream segment continues to show earnings resilience and stability with results similar to the previous quarter.
Once again, the team is making excellent progress in executing strategic priorities of strict capital discipline, reducing cost structure, and optimizing the portfolio.
By the end of 2021, we estimate that MPLX will have reduced their structural costs by $300 million.
Slide 13 shows the factors affecting our consolidated cash position for the second quarter.
It includes both our continuing and discontinued operations.
We have specifically highlighted items related to the Speedway closure.
Within continuing operations, operating cash flow before working capital changes was $1.5 billion in the quarter.
Changes in working capital were neutral this quarter.
Rising crude prices provided a source of over $500 million, which was mostly offset by the large receivable balance with Speedway becoming a third-party customer and typical seasonal refined product inventory increases.
During the quarter, MPC reduced debt by $3.3 billion.
Additionally, MPLX decreased third-party debt by about $800 million during the quarter.
Regarding capital return, MPC paid $380 million to shareholders through dividends and bought back $981 million worth of shares using Speedway proceeds.
At the end of the quarter, MPC had $17.3 billion in cash and higher-yielding short-term investments, such as commercial paper and certificates of deposit.
On Slide 14, we provide our third-quarter outlook.
We anticipate total throughput volumes of approximately 2.8 million barrels per day.
Planned turnaround costs are expected to be about $195 million in the third quarter.
Most of the activity will be at our Robinson and Mandan refineries in the Mid-Con region.
As previously mentioned, our turnaround activity is concentrated in the second half of this year.
Other operating expenses are scheduled to occur during these periods as well.
This is reflected in our projected cost trends for the third quarter.
Total operating costs are expected to be $5.05 per barrel for the quarter.
Distribution costs are anticipated to be approximately $1.3 billion for the quarter.
Corporate costs are expected to be $175 million, consistent with the second quarter and reflecting the approximately $100 million in costs that have been removed on an annual basis.
We are ready for additional questions.
We will now open the call for questions.
Summary:
output:
commencing next steps towards completing remaining $9 billion return of capital over next 12 to 16 months.
r&m segment income from operations was $224 million in q2 of 2021, compared with a loss of $1.5 billion.
martinez facility is expected to produce 260 million gallons per year of renewable diesel by second half of 2022.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Gregory and Jason will examine our findings with commentary, while Jack and Kelly will participate in the question and answer session.
These documents contain reconciliations between GAAP and non-GAAP measures for your convenience.
These assertions are founded on present-day expectations and presumptions that may be affected by various risks and ambiguities.
Details regarding factors that might cause such discrepancies can be found in today's earnings announcement, in the remarks made during this call, in the Risk Factors portion of our 2020 annual report on Form 10-K, and in our other reports and submissions to the SEC.
I'll begin by offering some thoughts on the overall business before Jason delves into our results and outlook.
The first quarter was exceptional.
We set Q1 records for revenue, operating profit, and cash flow.
We improved operating margins by 220 basis points and concluded the quarter with a backlog of $11.3 billion, an 8% increase from last year.
Moreover, demand remains robust, resulting in the highest first-quarter orders in our company's history.
Our Software and Services division had another remarkable quarter and continues to propel revenue growth and operating margin expansion.
Quarterly sales increased by 15%, driven by growth across our LMR, video security, and command center software technologies.
The division also ended with operating margins 310 basis points higher than the previous year.
Based on the heightened demand we're observing across our business and our strong backlog position, we're increasing our full-year guidance for both sales and earnings per share.
Our Q1 results included $1.8 billion in revenue, a 7% increase, including $48 million from acquisitions and $32 million from favorable currency exchange rates.
GAAP operating earnings were $298 million, with operating margins at 16.8% of sales, compared to 15.6% in the same quarter last year.
Non-GAAP operating earnings were $411 million, up $64 million or 18%, with non-GAAP operating margins at 23.2% of sales, up from 21%, driven by higher sales and improved operating leverage in both segments.
GAAP earnings per share were $1.41, compared to $1.12 in the same quarter last year.
The increase was mainly due to higher sales volume, improved operating leverage, and lower legal fees, partially offset by the gain from selling a manufacturing facility recognized in the previous year.
Non-GAAP earnings per share were $1.87, compared to $1.49 last year, primarily due to higher sales and improved operating leverage in both segments, higher pension income, and a lower diluted share count, partially offset by a higher effective tax rate.
Operating expenses in Q1 were $455 million, up $4 million from last year, primarily due to acquisition-related costs, partially offset by lower discretionary spending.
Regarding cash flow, our Q1 operating cash flow was $370 million, compared to $308 million in the prior year, and free cash flow was $318 million, compared to $260 million in the prior year.
The increase in cash flow was mainly due to higher sales and improved working capital, partially offset by higher cash taxes.
Capital allocation for Q1 included $170 million in share repurchases at an average price of $175.53, $121 million in cash dividends, and $52 million in capital expenditures.
During the quarter, we entered into a new five-year $2.25 billion revolving credit facility, replacing our previous $2.2 billion facility.
After the quarter ended, the Board of Directors approved a $2 billion increase to the share repurchase program.
Let's examine our segment outcomes.
In the first quarter, Products and Systems Integration revenue reached $1 billion, increasing by 2%. This growth was mainly due to increased sales in video security and professional and commercial radio, which was partly counterbalanced by reduced sales in public safety LMR due to supply limitations.
The quarter saw $35 million in revenue from acquisitions.
Operating profits were $131 million, representing 12.9% of sales, an increase from 12.4% the previous year, attributed to higher sales and improved efficiency.
Key achievements in Q1 for this segment include a $300 million agreement with the German MOD for TETRA LMR needs, with an initial $154 million order recorded.
Government customers' video sales totaled $72 million, a 32% increase from the previous year.
A Canadian government agency placed a $37 million order for a P25 upgrade.
A major European customer ordered a $33 million TETRA upgrade.
A large U.S. federal customer placed a $12 million P25 order.
Turning to the Software and Services segment.
First quarter revenue was $758 million, a 15% increase from last year, driven by growth in LMR services, video security, and command center software.
Acquisitions contributed $13 million to the quarter's revenue.
Operating profits reached $280 million, or 36.9% of sales, an increase of 310 basis points from last year, due to increased sales, higher gross margins, and improved efficiency.
Notable Q1 wins in this segment include over $40 million in orders for P25 services, upgrades, and body-worn cameras from Nashville, Tennessee.
A large U.S. customer signed a $35 million multi-year contract for push-to-talk over broadband.
A major Middle Eastern customer placed a $22 million order for P25 and push-to-talk over broadband.
Multiple U.K. customers ordered $13 million worth of body-worn cameras.
We secured our largest cloud-based command center software contract to date, a $5 million deal with St. Lucie, Florida.
We also announced a new integration between our V300 body-worn camera and APX P25 radio platform.
Examining our regional performance.
North American Q1 revenue was $1.2 billion, up 6% due to growth in LMR, video security, and command center software.
International Q1 revenue reached $588 million, a 9% increase, with growth in EMEA, Asia Pacific, and Latin America, primarily in video security and LMR.
Regarding our backlog.
End-of-quarter backlog set a Q1 record at $11.3 billion, an $866 million increase from last year, with $639 million growth in North America and $227 million internationally.
Compared to the previous quarter, backlog decreased by $130 million, mainly due to revenue recognition on Airwave and ESN contracts, partially offset by international growth in LMR products.
Software and Services backlog grew by $548 million year-over-year, with $491 million growth in multi-year LMR services and command center software contracts in North America, and $58 million in international software growth.
The positive impact of foreign exchange on backlog was balanced out by revenue recognition for Airwave and ESN.
The backlog decreased by $269 million sequentially, primarily due to revenue recognition for Airwave and ESN
Products and SI backlog increased by $318 million compared to the previous year
This was mainly caused by LMR growth in both regions
The backlog rose by $139 million sequentially, attributed to international LMR growth
Let's discuss our future projections
We anticipate Q2 sales to increase by 19% to 20%, with non-GAAP earnings per share ranging from $1.90 to $1.95
This projection assumes current FX spot rates, a weighted average diluted share count of about 173 million, and an effective tax rate between 23% and 24%
For the full year, we now project sales growth of 8% to 9%, up from our earlier forecast of 7.25% to 8%
We expect full year non-GAAP earnings per share to be between $8.70 and $8.80, an increase from our previous guidance of $8.50 to $8.62
This updated outlook takes into account ongoing supply chain constraints, mainly in LMR products, and assumes current FX spot rates, a weighted average diluted share count of 173 million, and an effective tax rate of 22.5% to 23%
I'd like to conclude with some observations about the business
To begin with, our quarterly results were exceptional
We achieved record Q1 sales, orders, operating earnings, and cash flow
We improved both gross and operating margins, saw double-digit growth in video security, command center software, and LMR services, and our PCR business returned to growth
Moreover, we ended the quarter with a record Q1 backlog and sustained strong demand, which we expect will drive growth for the rest of the year, despite the supply challenges we face
We also announced today that the Board has approved a $2 billion increase to our share repurchase program
Secondly, demand for our video security business is exceptionally strong
We now expect full-year growth to exceed 20%, up from the high teens we mentioned in our previous call
In fixed video, which accounts for about 70% of total video security revenue, our investments in AI analytics, cloud services, access control, and NDAA-compliant manufacturing are setting us apart from competitors and driving growth faster than the overall market
In mobile video, the call for increased transparency is driving growth for our purpose-built body-worn and in-car camera solutions, and we're gaining market share in an area previously dominated by a single vendor
During the quarter, we secured several large body-worn camera contracts, both in the U.S. and internationally
Additionally, we announced two new offerings: the integration of our V300 body-worn camera with our APX P25 radios, allowing us to leverage our market-leading LMR installed base, and our $49 per month body-worn camera as a service offering, providing affordable access to a video solution fully integrated with our command central software suite for every U.S. police agency
Lastly, I'm very satisfied with our progress in leveraging our leading LMR installed base to expand into command center software, video security, and LMR services
Currently, almost half of our revenue comes from these higher-growth areas, up from 20% five years ago, and our addressable market has tripled during that time
While we've made significant progress, I firmly believe we still have substantial room for growth as we continue to invest capital, both organically and inorganically, in these areas to drive revenue, margin, and cash flow for the company
Operator, could you please remind our callers how to ask a question?
Summary:
output:
sees q2 non-gaap earnings per share $1.90 to $1.95.
sees fy revenue up 8 to 9 percent.
sees q2 revenue up 19 to 20 percent.
q1 sales rose 7 percent to $1.8 billion.
q1 non-gaap earnings per share $1.87.
q1 gaap earnings per share $1.41.
backlog of $11.3 billion at quarter end.
sees fy non-gaap earnings per share $8.70 to $8.80.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:The financial report includes certain non-GAAP financial measures.
Let's examine our fiscal 2022 second quarter results.
We are satisfied with our financial results for the quarter.
Visitor numbers and demand for our resort experiences remain positive, especially among destination guests, with improvements seen after the holiday season as conditions got better, more skiing areas opened, and the impact of the COVID-19 Omicron variant decreased.
As anticipated, this quarter's results significantly surpassed those of the previous year due to the greater impact of COVID-19 and related restrictions during that time.
The 2021/2022 North American ski season had a sluggish beginning.
The combination of weather patterns, workforce issues, and the surge in Omicron variant cases created difficulties during the holiday period, affecting our resorts' ability to open all terrain as planned and negatively impacting guest experiences.
Despite various preparations made before the season, including wage increases, staffing levels were below target at the start of the holiday season, mirroring challenges faced by the broader travel and leisure industry at that time.
During the holiday period, COVID-19 cases linked to the Omicron variant rose dramatically, affecting both travel plans and staff availability, despite having a vaccinated workforce.
At certain resorts, over 10% of our employees were unable to work due to COVID-19 at one point.
To address these issues, the company raised hourly wages during the holidays and for the remainder of the ski season, costing $20 million in fiscal 2022.
After the holiday period, conditions at our resorts improved significantly with better snowfall, stabilization and eventual reduction in COVID-19 cases, and improved staffing, allowing us to open terrain across our resorts close to normal levels for that time of year.
Ski resorts surpassed our expectations, particularly in January.
As expected, Whistler Blackcomb was disproportionately affected by COVID-19-related travel restrictions, resulting in challenging outcomes for U.S. destinations and international visits to the resort.
Excluding the Seven Springs Resorts, total visits for the quarter increased by 2% compared to the second fiscal quarter of 2020.
Compared to the second fiscal quarter of 2020, our ancillary business lines experienced revenue declines, especially in food and beverage, which was significantly impacted by numerous COVID-19-related operational restrictions and overall staffing challenges.
Resort net revenue for the second fiscal quarter of 2022 decreased by 2% compared to the same period in fiscal year 2020, mainly due to challenges in our ancillary business lines and approximately $33 million in pass revenue that would have been recognized in the second fiscal quarter of 2022 but was deferred to the third quarter because of delayed openings at several of our resorts.
Our lodging business performed well during the quarter, with average daily rates exceeding expectations, partially offset by lower-than-anticipated occupancy rates during the early season.
Compared to the second fiscal quarter of 2020, resort reported EBITDA increased by 5% despite challenging early season conditions and COVID-19-related issues.
The resort reported EBITDA margin for the second quarter was 43.9%, an increase from 40.9% in the second quarter of fiscal 2020.
As Kirsten mentioned, we are pleased with our performance for the quarter, especially considering the slow start to the season.
Net income attributable to Vail Resorts was $223.4 million or $5.47 per diluted share for the second quarter of fiscal 2022, compared to net income attributable to Vail Resorts of $147.8 million or $3.62 per diluted share in the previous year.
Resort reported EBITDA was $397.9 million in the second fiscal quarter, compared to resort reported EBITDA of $276.1 million in the same period the previous year.
The increase was primarily due to the greater impact of COVID-19 and related limitations and restrictions on results in the prior year.
Resort reported EBITDA for the second quarter of fiscal year 2020 was $378.3 million.
We will now examine our season-to-date metrics for the period from the start of the ski season through Sunday, March 6, 2022, compared to each of the two prior-year periods through March 7, 2021, and March 8, 2020.
Given the significant impacts of COVID-19 in the prior-year period, including substantial capacity restrictions that limited skier visits and ancillary revenue, we are also providing metrics relative to the comparable fiscal year 2020 season-to-date period, which was before our announcement to close our resorts on March 15, 2020, for the remainder of the 2019/2020 season.
The reported ski season metrics are for our North American destination mountain resorts and regional ski areas and exclude the results of our recently acquired Seven Springs resorts and our Australian ski areas in all periods.
The reported ski season metrics include growth for season pass revenue based on estimated fiscal year 2022 North American season pass revenue compared to both fiscal 2021 and fiscal 2020 North American season pass revenue.
The data mentioned in this release is interim period data and is subject to fiscal quarter-end review and adjustments.
We are pleased with the positive momentum we have observed throughout the post-Christmas period.
Season-to-date total skier visits increased by 2.8% compared to the fiscal year 2020 season-to-date period.
Season-to-date total lift ticket revenue, including an allocated portion of season pass revenue for each applicable period, increased by 10.3% compared to the fiscal year 2020 season-to-date period.
Compared to the fiscal year 2020 season-to-date period, season-to-date ski school revenue decreased by 8.9%, dining revenue decreased by 27%, and retail rental for North American resort and ski area store locations decreased by 2.8%.
The company's performance has continued to show improvement after the Christmas season, particularly in terms of visitor numbers and ski pass sales.
Despite a significant increase in pass program participation this year, visitor numbers for the season to date were only slightly higher at 2.8% compared to fiscal 2020, due to the company's strategy of encouraging lift ticket buyers to purchase advance commitment pass products.
COVID-19-related travel restrictions negatively affected Whistler Blackcomb, resulting in challenging conditions for U.S. and international visitors to the resort.
Auxiliary business lines continued to see revenue decreases, especially in food and beverage, which was disproportionately affected by various operational constraints related to staffing and COVID-19.
It's noteworthy that our 47% growth in season pass units for fiscal year 2022 provided significant revenue stability during a period with difficult early season conditions and COVID-19 impacts.
The increase in pass units did not lead to substantial increases in visitation as the company is encouraging lift ticket buyers to switch to advance commitment products.
In fact, the visitation growth we observed in the period ending March 6, 2022, compared to fiscal 2020 occurred on weekdays and non-holiday periods, which saw a 9% increase in visits, while weekend and holiday periods remained relatively unchanged.
We also noticed that peak daily visitation at our resorts during this period was very similar to previous years.
For the season-to-date period ending March 6, 2022, season pass holders accounted for 69% of our visits, compared to 56% of visits for the same period in fiscal year 2020.
We remain dedicated to our strategy of encouraging lift ticket buyers to switch to advance commitment products, which benefits our guests and provides stability for our employees, communities, and company.
Now let's discuss our outlook for fiscal 2022.
Despite a challenging start to the season through the holidays, we have raised the midpoint of our Resort reported EBITDA guidance compared to our initial guidance in September, demonstrating the resilience of our business model and the advantages of our advance commitment strategy.
The guidance update is primarily due to strong demand from destination guests at our Western U.S. resorts, particularly in lift ticket sales, which we expect to continue for the rest of the season, as well as the contribution from the Seven Springs resorts.
Additionally, our lodging business is expected to significantly outperform our initial expectations for the remainder of the year, with strong results in both occupancy and ADR across our properties and the addition of the Seven Springs Resorts.
Destination and international visitation trends at Whistler Blackcomb, the $20 million investment in frontline staff bonuses, increased wages for our summer operations, and the inclusion of an estimated $6 million in acquisition and integration-related expenses specific to the Seven Springs resorts.
We now anticipate net income attributable to Vail Resorts for fiscal 2022 to be between $304 million and $350 million, and resort reported EBITDA to be between $813 million and $837 million.
We estimate resort EBITDA margin for fiscal 2022 to be approximately 32.9% using the midpoint of the guidance range.
The updated outlook for fiscal year 2022 assumes normal conditions and operations across our resorts for the remainder of the ski season and no additional travel or operating restrictions associated with COVID-19 that could negatively impact our results, including for our Australian resorts in the fourth quarter.
The guidance assumes an exchange rate of $0.79 between the Canadian dollar and U.S. dollar related to the operations of Whistler Blackcomb in Canada and an exchange rate of $0.72 between the Australian dollar and U.S. dollar related to the operations of Perisher, Falls Creek, and Hotham in Australia.
Our financial position remains robust.
As of January 31, 2022, our total cash and revolver availability was approximately $2 billion, with $1.4 billion in cash on hand, $417 million of U.S. revolver availability under the Vail Holdings credit agreement, and $214 million of revolver availability under the Whistler Credit Agreement.
As of January 31, 2022, our net debt was 2.1 times trailing 12 months total reported EBITDA.
We are happy to announce that our board of directors has declared a quarterly cash dividend on Vail Resorts common stock of $1.91 per share.
The dividend will be paid on April 14, 2022, to shareholders of record as of March 30, 2022.
We will continue to be prudent managers of our capital and remain committed to prioritizing investments in our guest and employee experience, high-return capacity expanding capital projects, strategic acquisition opportunities, and returning capital to our shareholders through our quarterly dividend and share repurchase programs.
As we look ahead to the 2022/2023 ski season and beyond, the company will be making its largest ever investment in both its employees and its resorts to ensure we continue to deliver our company mission of providing an experience of a lifetime.
The experience of our employees and our guests is fundamental to our business model, and the company intends to use its financial resources and stability it has created through its season pass program to continue to aggressively reinvest to deliver that experience.
We believe our business model allows us to make these investments and achieve our short- and long-term financial growth objectives.
Our employees are central to Vail Resorts' mission of creating an experience of a lifetime.
We are pleased to announce a significant investment in our employees for the 2022/2023 North American ski season with an increase in the minimum hourly wage offered across all 37 of our North American resorts to USD 20 per hour for all U.S. employees and CAD 20 per hour for all Canadian employees, as well as an increase in wage rates for hourly employees, as we maintain all leadership and career stage differentials.
Positions that require specific experiences or certifications, such as entry-level patrol, commercial drivers, and maintenance technicians, will start at $21 per hour.
Tipped employees will be guaranteed a minimum of $20 per hour.
The company will also be considering targeted increases beyond inflation for our salaried employees.
We will also be making a significant investment in our human resources department to ensure the right level of employee support, development, and recruiting.
Our personnel are our most valuable resource and top priority across all company levels.
We anticipate these investments will significantly improve our employees' experience through better recruitment, retention, and professional development.
Our workforce investments aim to achieve standard staffing levels, deliver exceptional customer service, support our advanced commitment strategy, provide greater business stability, and drive long-term growth.
The wage increase and return to normal staffing will result in an approximately $175 million rise in expected labor costs for fiscal 2023 compared to fiscal 2022, including inflation adjustments.
We maintain our commitment to providing an outstanding guest experience and will continue to invest in enhancing our resort offerings.
We are dedicated to expanding capacity through lift, terrain, and food and beverage projects, and are making a significant one-time investment this year to accelerate this strategy.
As previously disclosed, we are moving forward with our ambitious $315 million to $325 million capital investment plan for calendar year 2022 across our resorts, excluding one-time integration activities, employee housing projects, and real estate developments.
The plan includes $180 million for installing 21 new or replacement lifts across 14 resorts and a major lift-served terrain expansion at Keystone.
In addition to two new lift configurations at Vail and Keystone, the replacement lifts will increase capacity at those locations by over 45%.
