All projects are subject to regulatory approvals and are expected to be completed for the 2022/2023 North American winter season.
The core capital plan is about $150 million above our typical annual budget, accounting for inflation and recent acquisitions, including $20 million to complete one-time plans for Peak Resorts and Triple Peak acquisitions, and $3 million for annual capital expenditures associated with the Seven Springs Resorts.
We remain focused on developing and leveraging our data-driven approach to marketing and business operations.
Our planned investments include network-wide scalable technology to enhance analytics, e-commerce, and guest engagement tools, improving our ability to target guests, personalize messages, and increase conversion rates.
We will invest in broader self-service capabilities to enhance guests' online experience and engagement.
We have announced a $4 million investment plan for Vail Resorts' Commitment to Zero initiative, including investments in high-efficiency snowmaking, heating and cooling infrastructure, and lighting to improve energy efficiency and progress toward our 2030 goal.
We plan to spend about $9 million on integration activities related to the recently acquired Seven Springs Resorts, including one-time investments and $3 million for real estate-related projects.
Our total capital plan is expected to be approximately $327 million to $337 million.
Including our 2022 capital plan, Vail Resorts will have invested over $2 billion in capital improvements since launching the Epic Pass, increasing capacity, enhancing guest experiences, and creating an integrated resort network.
As we plan for fiscal 2023, several COVID-19 and unusual weather-related factors negatively impacting fiscal 2022 need to be highlighted.
Travel trends at Whistler Blackcomb, our Australian resorts, and our group business were significantly affected by COVID-19 in fiscal 2022.
Early season results across our resorts were hampered by challenging snow conditions.
Returning to normal levels would result in an estimated $100 million increase in resort reported EBITDA for fiscal 2022.
The Seven Springs Resorts did not have a full year of operating results and were affected by acquisition and integration expenses.
Full-year results without acquisition or integration expenses would yield an estimated $7 million increase in resort reported EBITDA for fiscal 2022.
Our ancillary businesses were constrained by staffing issues and COVID-19 related operational restrictions in fiscal 2022.
Normalizing our ancillary business would result in an estimated $75 million increase in resort reported EBITDA for fiscal 2022, including revenue and operating expenses associated with normal capacity, but excluding incremental labor costs.
The normalized labor expense for ancillary businesses is included in the $175 million labor investment.
These estimates assume normal conditions throughout ski seasons, continued strong consumer demand, consistent economic dynamics, and no significant ongoing COVID-19 impacts.
The estimated $182 million favorable resort reported EBITDA impact from business normalization is offset by the $175 million labor increase expected for fiscal 2023 to address staffing shortages and current labor market dynamics in resort communities.
These estimates do not account for fiscal 2023 projections for volume, price, or expense growth, which will be evaluated and incorporated into our full-year 2023 guidance planned for September 2022.
We are fully committed to providing an exceptional experience for our employees and guests.
Our team is central to Vail Resorts' mission.
I am profoundly grateful for their daily commitment and excited about the future as we make these important investments in our team and guest experience.
Summary:
output:
q2 earnings per share $5.47.
now expecting resort reported ebitda to be between $813 million and $837 million for 2022.
for 2022/2023 north american ski season, company will be increasing its minimum wage to $20 per hour.
approved an increase in quarterly cash dividend to $1.91 per share.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Aaron Ravenscroft, president and CEO, and Dave Antoniuk, executive VP and CFO, are joining the conference call
Projections may not accurately reflect future outcomes due to various factors outlined in the company's most recent SEC documents
The year 2020 presented significant difficulties
When the COVID-19 crisis began, we focused on three main goals: ensuring staff safety, maintaining financial stability, and preparing for long-term expansion
I'm impressed with our team's handling of these unprecedented circumstances and their success in achieving our three main objectives
Let's begin with safety considerations
We continue to experience a low number of COVID cases across our facilities
Moreover, we achieved the lowest workplace injury rate in our company's history
The injury rate was recorded at 1.34
Next, we concluded the year with a robust financial position
We have $120 million in cash and over $400 million in available funds
Lastly, we reinforced our foundation for future expansion
Despite the pandemic, we continued to develop future leaders within our organization
Throughout the year, about 200 frontline supervisors completed a year-long leadership program covering safety, leadership skills, and LEAN principles
We also initiated a mentoring program for our key female leaders, which has already led to several promotions
Our LEAN journey progressed in 2020, with nearly 900 entries in our global Manitowoc Way Lessons Learned Competition
While there were many worthy submissions, our Wilhelmshaven, Germany facility claimed the top prize
The team is currently working on a multi-year project to enhance production flow on the campus
In 2020, the team created a robotic measuring device that significantly improved our boom assembly process and paved the way for advancements in other aspects of this initiative
Additionally, this year we introduced the Manitowoc Way CEO Award to recognize a team member who exemplified both LEAN thinking and action
I'd like to acknowledge Saleem Ahmed, test field supervisor in Wilhelmshaven
Saleem independently engineered a system to convert manual boom cable drum alignment on the test field to an electronic process during assembly
This type of initiative embodies the values and culture of the Manitowoc Way business system
Moving on to the financial results
Our fourth quarter performance surpassed our expectations
Upon closer examination, it's a story with two distinct aspects
Our fourth quarter profitability significantly exceeded our forecast, primarily due to a favorable product mix
We experienced higher-than-anticipated book and ship demand for our tower cranes in Europe
This also resulted in improved factory absorption at the related sites
However, while our orders and backlog surpassed our forecast, they were heavily influenced by a few large crawler orders and favorable exchange rates
Regarding our balance sheet, we achieved our second-half goal of reducing inventory by $80 million on a currency-neutral basis
I'll hand it over to Dave to provide more details on the financial results, after which I'll wrap up with some remarks on our outlook.
Let's proceed to Slide 4.
Our fourth-quarter orders reached $509 million, growing 8% compared to last year's $472 million.
Adjusting for currency fluctuations, Q4 orders increased by $22 million or 5%.
As Aaron mentioned earlier, the order increase was mainly due to a few large crawler orders in the United States.
Our year-end backlog for 2020 stood at $543 million, up 14% from the previous year and 10% when adjusted for currency effects.
The backlog growth was primarily attributed to increased crawler crane orders and Q4 shipment timing.
Fourth-quarter net sales of $430 million met our expectations but decreased by $33 million or 7% compared to the previous year.
A decline in the Americas segment was partially counterbalanced by stronger performance in the EURAF and MEAP segments.
Net sales benefited by about 4% from foreign currency exchange rate changes.
Our fourth-quarter adjusted EBITDA was $34 million, an 11% increase year-over-year.
We surpassed last year's results and our quarterly projections due to a favorable product mix and reduced discretionary spending.
As a percentage of sales, the adjusted EBITDA margin improved to 7.9%, a 120 basis point increase from the previous year.
We incurred about $1 million in restructuring expenses during the fourth quarter, mainly related to severance costs in India and Europe.
Our GAAP diluted earnings per share for the quarter was $0.05.
On an adjusted basis, diluted earnings per share decreased by $0.16 from the previous year to $0.19 per diluted share.
The year-over-year decline in adjusted diluted earnings per share was primarily due to higher income tax expenses resulting from our jurisdictional mix and the impact of net foreign currency losses, partially offset by improved operating income.
We generated $36 million in cash from operating activities during the quarter.
We achieved our currency-neutral inventory reduction target of $80 million in the second half of the year.
Most of this improvement occurred in Q4, which was the primary source of our cash flow generation for the quarter.
Year-over-year, our cash flow from operating activities decreased due to the timing of accounts receivable collections.
We finished the year with a cash balance of $129 million, a $70 million decrease from the previous year.
Nevertheless, our total liquidity remained strong at $412 million with no outstanding borrowings on our ABL.
Now I'll summarize the financial results for the entire year.
Orders totaled approximately $1.5 billion, a decrease of $127 million or 8% from the previous year.
Foreign currency exchange rates positively impacted 2020 orders by about 1%.
Lower orders in the Americas and EURAF segments were partially offset by gains in the MEAP segment.
Our net sales for the year amounted to roughly $1.4 billion, a 21% decrease from 2019, and were positively affected by $12 million or 1% due to favorable changes in foreign currency exchange rates.
The year-over-year decrease was mainly due to starting the year with a lower shippable backlog, combined with reduced demand related to the COVID-19 pandemic.
Our adjusted EBITDA fell by $74 million or 47% from the previous year, resulting in a 19% decremental margin on nearly $400 million less revenue.
This better-than-expected result demonstrates the dedication of our team members worldwide during these unprecedented times.
We successfully reduced our optional expenses while maintaining investment in new product development and expansion plans.
The team deserves recognition for their excellent performance.
Our adjusted net loss for the entire year of 2020 was $12 million, in contrast to a net income of $67 million in 2019.
The adjusted diluted net loss per share of $0.35 was affected by roughly $0.01 due to our stock buybacks in the first quarter.
As stated before, we halted our share repurchase program in Q1 and don't plan to buy back more shares in 2021.
The full-year cash flows from operating activities showed a deficit of $35 million, mainly due to the timing of accounts receivable collections and the net loss recorded during the year.
As I mentioned earlier, we concluded the year with sufficient liquidity and a robust balance sheet.
Let's proceed to Slide 5.
Looking ahead to 2021, I view it as a transitional year, with progress and setbacks.
Although we believe we've moved past the economic low point caused by the COVID-19 pandemic, we anticipate an uneven recovery.
The recently implemented stimulus measures by various countries and the distribution of COVID-19 vaccines are positive developments.
Nevertheless, there's still a considerable way to go before returning to normalcy.
Unfortunately, some of these actions will have unexpected consequences.
Most importantly, while economic stimulus packages are crucial for recovery, government spending tends to generate inflation, which we're already observing in steel prices.
Furthermore, the substantial debt accumulated in the United States has led to a weaker dollar.
Given the rapid changes in both these factors, I'm worried we'll experience a market disruption, creating short-term cost challenges for us.
Additionally, Manitowoc benefited from significant cost-cutting measures in 2020 that won't be repeated in 2021.
Considering our discretionary spending limits, bonus program expenses, social claim benefits, and rising insurance costs, we'll likely face over $15 million in additional costs.
Moreover, with the increase in crawler cranes, our product mix is shifting towards lower-margin items, and we continue to struggle with low production levels at our German facility, where we manufacture all-terrain cranes.
Please move to Slide 6.
We're continuing to invest in our future growth.
We've allocated $15 million in capital expenditure to further expand our European tower crane rental fleet in 2021.
We're growing our Chinese tower crane business that serves the Belt and Road regions.
We're accelerating our product development programs for our all-terrain product line, which we'll showcase at Bauma in 2022.
We're also actively pursuing acquisitions.
These growth initiatives require more investment than we've made in recent years, but we're confident these strategic moves will drive our future growth as the crane industry recovers.
To conclude, the current economic climate is highly dynamic in terms of demand and costs.
Therefore, we won't provide specific financial guidance for 2021.
Generally speaking, we expect our revenue to increase slightly, but there are clear indications that we'll face margin pressure due to cost increases and product mix changes while investing in future growth.
2021 will be a year of transition.
Summary:
output:
q4 adjusted earnings per share $0.19.
q4 earnings per share $0.05.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Today I'm accompanied by Steve Westhoven, our CEO and President, Pat Migliaccio, our CFO, and other senior executives.
As noted on the first slide, actual outcomes may significantly deviate from our projections.
We'll be discussing certain non-GAAP metrics like net financial earnings (NFE).
We consider NFE to offer a more comprehensive view of our financial performance.
Nevertheless, it shouldn't be seen as a replacement for GAAP.
Our non-GAAP financial measures are elaborated on in Item 7 of our 10-K.
The meeting's schedule is outlined on slide two.
Steve will kick off the call with quarterly highlights, after which Pat will go over our financial results.
New Jersey Resources showed robust performance in Q1.
I'll walk you through the key points on slide three.
We posted NFE of $0.46 per share, primarily due to the strong showing of our main business, New Jersey Natural Gas.
We're maintaining our fiscal 2021 NFE guidance of $1.55 to $1.65 per share and raising our fiscal 2022 NFE projection to $2.20 to $2.30 per share, a $0.15 increase from previous estimates.
At New Jersey Natural Gas, we've finished nearly 90% of the Southern Reliability Link and plan to operationalize it this year.
We received the green light for our Infrastructure Investment Program, a $150 million accelerated recovery initiative spanning 5 years to enhance our natural gas infrastructure's resilience and reliability.
We've also submitted SAVEGREEN 2020, a new energy efficiency initiative aimed at helping customers reduce energy use and costs.
In our Clean Energy Ventures division, we purchased the 2.9 megawatt Mt. Laurel Solar Facility, part of our $165 million investment plan for this year.
In our Storage & Transportation segment, we've begun transforming the southern part of Adelphia Gateway to natural gas and expect it to be operational later this year.
Just yesterday, the U.S. Supreme Court agreed to hear PennEast's appeal.
Despite this positive development, we're still excluding PennEast from our long-term forecasts until we have more clarity on the project.
At NJR Energy Services, we entered into asset management agreements that will yield contracted cash proceeds of $501 million over a decade.
I'll provide more details about this transaction on the next slide.
Moving to slide four.
Energy Services entered into several AMAs with a public utility of investment-grade status.
These deals showcase the value of our natural gas storage and transportation contract portfolio and reflect our talented team's hard work.
The transactions help our counterparty secure needed supply while allowing Energy Services to monetize part of its controlled assets.
Let me break down the specifics.
Starting November 2021, our fiscal year 2022, NJRES will begin releasing portions of our pipeline capacity.
Under the agreement terms, NJRES will receive $261 million in payments over the AMAs' first three years.
Post FY 2024, NJRES will get additional yearly payments of about $34 million through 2031.
NJRES benefits include extracting asset value without relying on weather-related price volatility and reducing operational risks tied to directly managing these transportation assets.
This will lead to more predictable earnings and cash flows and a lower-risk Energy Services business.
These transactions also allow us to raise our fiscal 2022 guidance by $0.15 per share, as shown on the next slide.
Later, Pat will explain other financial impacts of these transactions.
Turning to our fiscal 2022 NFE guidance on slide five, we're increasing our overall projection to $2.20 to $2.30 per share.
This demonstrates the influence of the AMAs and the anticipated cash settlement of our equity forward.
Nevertheless, our long-term yearly growth rate of 6% to 10% remains anchored to our initially communicated guidance of $2.05 to $2.15 per share, which does not include the effect of the AMAs or any other contribution from Energy Services.
As Pat will explain later, the NFE advantages of AMAs will vary from year to year.
On slide six, I'll guide you through some of the operational achievements.
Examining the upper left, we invested $89 million in New Jersey Natural Gas during the first quarter, with approximately one-third of the capital expenditure yielding near-immediate returns.
In spite of the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, we gained over 1,900 new customers, only marginally below the customer additions from the same period last year, which was before the pandemic.
This can be attributed to the favorable growth demographics in our service areas.
Work on the Southern Reliability Link is advancing, and we have now completed almost 90% of the project, with an expected in-service date this year.
We intend to submit our rate case to recover the expenses associated with the project in fiscal 2021.
As I mentioned earlier, we received approval for our IIP program and submitted SAVEGREEN 2020.
On slide seven, I'll guide you through the operational highlights of our other core business, Clean Energy Ventures.
We increased our capacity by 2.9 megawatts this quarter.
As you can see in the top right, we now have a total installed capacity of 360 megawatts.
We have a robust project pipeline with approximately $260 million worth of investments, either under contract or exclusivity, that are targeted for commercial operation in fiscal 2021 and 2022.
Total invested capital at CEV this quarter was $23 million, with $17 million in commercial projects and $6 million in Sunlight Advantage.
The bottom right displays our projected CEV revenue for fiscal 2021, a significant portion of which is secured through our SREC hedging program.
The sustainability agenda we've outlined for our company centers on innovation, emissions reductions, energy efficiency, and transparency.
I'm pleased to report that NJR has made substantial progress.
In the previous quarter, we announced that NJR achieved our goal of reducing our New Jersey operational emissions by 50% of 2006 levels, well ahead of schedule.
We have now set a new, more ambitious target of 60% reduction by 2030.
This is a significant achievement that reflects decades of investment in safety and environmental responsibility.
It demonstrates our strong commitment to sustainability and the hard work of our team.
Our new target ensures our company's goals align with the state's 2050 statutory goals for emissions reduction.
Last month, we released our 12th Annual Corporate Sustainability Report, which is accessible on our website.
For the first time, this year's report includes ESG reporting and disclosures established by SASB, which is another step towards increasing transparency and strengthening our communications with our investors in the financial communities on these issues.
Slide 10 illustrates the main factors influencing our NFE for the first quarter.
As we communicated at our Analyst Day in November, this is the first quarter where we're employing the deferral method of accounting for CEV.
Consequently, we've recalculated our financials for the comparable periods.
Reported NFE of $44.7 million or $0.46 per share compared to NFE of $34.9 million or $0.38 per share in the first quarter of fiscal 2020.
New Jersey Natural Gas experienced an NFE improvement of $5.6 million, primarily due to a full quarter of higher base rates from NJNG's fiscal 2020 rate case settlement compared to a partial quarter a year ago.
CEV decreased by $2, mainly due to increased O&M expenses related to project maintenance costs, particularly with new projects placed in service, which was partially offset by a decrease in depreciation expense.
Storage & Transportation saw a modest increase during the quarter, mostly related to increased operating income from Leaf River, and was offset by interest expense related to the acquisitions of Leaf River and Adelphia Gateway.
Energy services improved by $6.6 million, primarily due to higher financial margin compared to last year, resulting from increased natural gas pricing spreads.
Home Services and Other experienced slightly lower operating revenue and slightly higher interest expense.
We reconfirmed our NFE guidance of $1.55 to $1.65 per share for fiscal 2021, as Steve pointed out.
Slide 11 displays the segment contributions, with our primary businesses, NJNG and CEV, making up 80% of total NFE.
Let me explain how we anticipate NJNG's utility gross margin and CEV's revenues will be distributed to help you understand the quarterly breakdown of our net financial earnings.
We anticipate recognizing about 70% of NJNG's utility gross margin in the first half of the year, consistent with historical patterns.
The bulk of CEV's revenue will come in the latter half of the year, particularly in the fourth quarter when we expect to recognize most of our SREC revenue.
We anticipate that our Storage & Transportation business's net financial earnings contributions will remain relatively steady throughout the year due to fixed-price contracts.
The specifics of our SREC hedging program are outlined on slide 12.
We continue to actively hedge to protect SREC revenues from future price fluctuations.
We've increased our hedge level to 75% for energy year 2023.
For energy year 2024, market fundamentals and pricing remain robust, with SREC trading at over 85% of SACP, and we've now hedged 49% of our 2024 volumes.
Moving to slide 13, I'll clarify some of the intricacies involved in achieving revenue recognition for the AMAs.
According to the agreements, NJR will initially release the transportation capacity to our counterparty before permanently releasing the contracts to the utility.
The accounting standard requires allocating revenue to both the initial and permanent releases, with a disproportionate amount assigned to the permanent releases occurring in fiscal years 2024 and 2032.
This allocation will result in a discrepancy between revenue and cash proceeds.
It's worth noting that while revenue provides a general indication of NFE, it doesn't account for taxes, demand charges, and other factors.
Importantly, the cash proceeds offer additional benefits that I'll elaborate on shortly.
As shown on slide 14, we now project our cash flows from operations to grow at a CAGR of approximately 25% from fiscal 2020 to 2024, up from our previous estimate of 20%.
The chart on the right demonstrates that the strength of our cash flows suggests our dividends are expected to become a smaller percentage, supporting our long-term dividend growth rate of 6% to 10%.
Slide 15 illustrates another benefit of the AMAs: improved credit metrics.
As reported at our Analyst Day, our FFO to adjusted debt ratio is increasing from fiscal 2022 to 2024.
With the positive impact of the AMAs, our metrics are expected to rise to the high teens in fiscal 2022 and reach about 20% by fiscal 2024.
Due to these strong credit metrics, we will cash settle the equity forward established during our December 2019 equity issuance.
At that time, we issued 5.3 million shares and entered into an equity forward to issue an additional 1.2 million shares later, which is no longer necessary.
As mentioned during our Analyst Day, we don't foresee any block equity needs in the near future.
Before taking questions, I'd like to summarize the quarter.
NJR has started fiscal 2021 well and is on track to meet our NFEPS guidance for this fiscal year.
We've raised our fiscal 2022 NFEPS guidance by $0.15 per share and expect strong cash flow to support our dividend growth.
Our key infrastructure projects, SRL and Adelphia Gateway, are progressing and are expected to be in service this calendar year.
Our improved credit metrics allow us to cash settle our equity forward.
As stated at our Investor Day, we don't need further block equity issuances.
We've made significant progress in our commitment to reduce risk in the Energy Services business by providing more stable fee-based revenue.
Summary:
output:
new jersey reaffirms nfe/share outlook of $1.55 to $1.65 for 2021.
reaffirmed nfe per share (nfeps) guidance of $1.55 to $1.65 for fiscal 2021.
increased nfeps guidance for fiscal 2022 by $0.15 to a range of $2.20 to $2.30.
qtrly consolidated net financial earnings of $44.7 million, or $0.46 per share.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:They entail hazards and unpredictability, and actual outcomes may vary significantly.
Our remarks also incorporate non-GAAP financial metrics.
For Q1 2021, NOV reported $1.25 billion in revenue and a $115 million net loss using U.S. GAAP standards.
We will have a Q&A session later in the call.
The oil industry faced a double blow in 2020: an oil price war followed by a pandemic-induced collapse in demand, leading to a steep decline in oilfield equipment and consumables sales throughout the year.
NOV's Q1 2021 results reflect the full impact of these events, which caused an exceptionally severe downturn in an industry known for harsh slumps.
As mentioned in our March 16 update, the quarter was further affected by severe winter weather and power outages in Texas and Oklahoma, causing 63 NOV facilities to close for a week or more.
New pandemic restrictions overseas also shut down several large plants and disrupted supply chains for certain raw materials, particularly fiberglass and resin.
The quarter was also impacted by higher costs on two projects due to poor execution on our part.
A new pipe design proved more expensive to manufacture than anticipated.
An offshore platform component was delayed due to engineering taking longer than expected.
Both issues have been resolved.
Despite these challenges, our final quarterly results slightly exceeded our March forecast due to better progress on cost reductions and increasing signs of recovery in the oil industry, particularly in Wellbore Technologies and North America.
While we still face challenges in many markets, we are increasingly confident that the worst is behind us.
North American oilfield activity continued to recover during the quarter, with March revenues significantly higher than January for certain early-cycle domestic businesses, while international results showed early signs of recovery as well.
However, the first quarter's sequential decline in capital equipment revenues reflects the severe impact on our backlog in 2020, leading to a 6% drop in consolidated revenue.
EBITDA fell to breakeven, which is unacceptable and is prompting further cost-cutting measures.
As a supplier of capital equipment and spare parts to the oilfield, our results typically lag behind those of our customers.
Q1 2021 reflects the previous nine months of plummeting oil demand and virtually no capital spending, offset by substantial downsizing and cost reductions.
We believe this downturn is the most severe our industry has ever experienced.
Oil prices turned negative in April.
The U.S. rig count hit its lowest level since World War II in August.
North American frac fleet utilization dropped to single digits.
By year-end, over 100 North American oil and gas companies had filed for bankruptcy protection with a combined debt exceeding $100 billion.
If not for a few large projects awarded before the lockdown, offshore project FIDs in 2020 would have been the lowest since 1960.
Although recovery has begun in many markets, average first quarter rig counts were down 46% for North America land, 36% for international land, and 31% for offshore year-over-year.
When I say it has been a historically bad downturn, I mean it has been a measurably and provably historically bad downturn.
In this environment, our oilfield service customers are following the tried-and-true survival strategy of cannibalizing equipment, spares, and consumables, postponing maintenance, reducing spending to bare minimum levels, and conserving cash.
NOV's biggest competitor in this environment is idle equipment.
By autumn, every stacked rig had become an additional source of drill pipe, shaker screens, handling tools, etc., and this dynamic applies across all categories of oilfield equipment when utilization collapses and service companies struggle to stay afloat.
A year ago, day rates began rapidly declining to find a bottom at daily cash costs, which were insufficient to cover long-term maintenance expenses, let alone capital consumption costs represented by depreciation.
For many sectors, year-end 2020 day rates reflected desperation, with companies discounting to keep some assets and crews working and spending cash only as a last resort.
As a result, NOV's oilfield backlogs declined throughout the year, and the first quarter annualized revenue run rate is down 45% from just five quarters ago.
Here's the positive news: 160 years of oilfield history shows that this situation is always temporary.
The amount of idle equipment available for cannibalization decreases as activity resumes, and dwindling spares and consumables must be replenished as utilization improves.
We're starting to see early signs of this in certain areas as rigs and frac fleets return to work.
Idle, stripped drilling rigs must have cannibalized pumps and handling tools replaced to resume service.
This rebuilding, restocking, and reactivation phenomenon occurs when service company desperation is fading and optimism is growing with increasing oilfield activity.
We know this because NOV has experienced similar recovery cycles in the past.
As the oilfield becomes busier, customers will soon start to worry about the significant cash investment required to reactivate rigs and equipment.
Consider the courage needed to invest your precious cash in a business that almost bankrupted you last year.
That's the challenge our customers face when it comes to reactivations.
We believe our customers will demand higher pricing on their additional assets returning to work to mitigate risk by achieving quicker paybacks on their reactivation investments.
They'll also need to cover rising wage pressures and other inflationary forces, which I'll discuss shortly.
If oil prices remain favorable, pricing momentum will significantly boost margins and returns, as is typical in the cyclical business we serve.
NOV will be a key beneficiary of this unit reactivation investment.
As various basins and equipment categories pass through the inflection point to emerge into higher day rate regimes, their orders for capital equipment will accelerate.
This is the sweet spot of our business model.
The historic oilfield events of 2020 have predictably led to a massive dismantling of well construction capability by the oilfield services industry, following the tried-and-true playbook I mentioned earlier.
Every surviving oilfield service company has made it this far by downsizing exceptionally well.
Collectively, our surviving customers are the dream team of cost-cutters.
They've been working hard at it for several years, intensifying their cost-cutting efforts threefold in 2020.
It's logical to conclude that the overall capacity to construct wells has been significantly reduced in our view.
If global economies continue to recover from COVID and demand more oil, the oilfield services industry will be challenged to return to normalized levels of wellbore construction sufficient to meet rising oil demand.
We think that's more likely than not.
First, governments worldwide responded to the economic turmoil of the pandemic with unprecedented stimulus packages.
For example, the G10 plus China passed more than $20 trillion in stimulus in total.
This has led to remarkable money supply growth.
The U.S. M2 is up 27% year-over-year, for instance.
Generally, money supply growth and low interest rates inflate asset prices, including commodity prices like oil.
Next, pharmaceutical companies developed vaccines, several in fact.
While there are ups and downs, global vaccination efforts are progressing, positioning the world to emerge from the pandemic lockdown.
Massive economic stimulus and a powerful catalyst, vaccines, to more or less simultaneously reopen economies, combined with significantly improved household balance sheets and a widespread desire to return to normalcy, well, I can't imagine a more compelling recipe for a synchronized global economic recovery of a magnitude we haven't seen since the 1950s post-war boom.
We believe this synchronized recovery will lead to increased oil consumption.
In fact, leading indicators for crude oil, gasoline, and distillate demand already suggest a stronger recovery than many economists anticipated, and global inventory levels appear to be normalizing ahead of schedule.
Overall, this creates a highly favorable backdrop for oil prices in the coming years, in our opinion.
Key risks to this outlook include excess Saudi and OPEC capacity, which is scheduled to gradually increase over the next few months, and the potential return of Iranian crude production.
However, the record levels of crude inventories achieved in the first half of 2020 have, as far as we can tell, largely dissipated.
This only happens because withdrawals have exceeded additions.
So supply, artificially kept low by OPEC, has been less than demand, artificially suppressed by the pandemic lockdown.
The crucial question is what the picture will look like as artificial constraints on both ease.
Another potential concern is the exceptional growth rates achieved by U.S. shale production at various points over the last ten years.
Technological advancements like simultaneous fracturing indicate the domestic exploration and production industry's continuous push for greater efficiency.
However, it's worth noting that the domestic E&P sector previously benefited from abundant cheap capital to fund growth-focused drilling programs, as well as financial pressure on oilfield services that kept pricing below sustainable levels.
Funding, when available, is now significantly more expensive.
This trend seems to be intensifying as environmental, social, and governance factors become more influential in investment decisions.
Additionally, the investments needed to rebuild oilfield service capabilities for well construction will require higher returns.
Consider also the consolidation among domestic E&P companies, the increased cost of attracting workers back to the oilfield during a major economic expansion offering numerous high-paying alternatives, and it becomes clear that achieving substantial production growth from U.S. shales will be more difficult this time.
Beyond the artificial production limits imposed by OPEC, Russia and Saudi Arabia, and the artificial consumption restrictions due to COVID-related economic lockdowns, there is significant depletion occurring.
All oil wells experience declining production over time.
The extent to which these artificial constraints have masked the overall natural decline of oil wells is unclear.
While we can debate the true supply and demand situation, we can all agree that both are far less transparent in 2021 than in any previous year.
After all, we've never experienced an economic shutdown of this magnitude before.
The key point is this: when the industry significantly reduces exploration, development, and the ongoing construction of platforms, projects and wells that produce the oil our global economy depends on, and further dismantles the oilfield services industry that performs this work, there will be consequences.
Throughout this unprecedented period, NOV has consistently focused on: reducing costs, which have decreased by $12.6 billion since 2014, including about $2 billion in annual fixed cost reductions; improving cash flow, which has reduced our debt; and investing in next-generation technologies for both the oilfield and emerging renewable opportunities.
Whether it's advanced rig floor technology like our robotic pipe handling system controlled by our NOVOS digital environment, our ideal e-frac fleet equipped with QuickLatch and FlexConnect systems to reduce emissions and labor in the completion process, or NOV Max, our digital platform that integrates various data sources for operators, NOV remains at the forefront of next-generation oilfield technology.
Our efforts in supporting the energy transition focus on areas where we believe we can establish significant competitive advantages while delivering superior economic returns for our customers in wind, solar, geothermal and other emerging energy sources.
Seven out of eight Wellbore Technologies business units saw sequential growth in the first quarter, indicating rising demand for certain products.
As a result, we began adding manufacturing shifts and achieved the highest level of absorption since the first quarter of 2020.
NOV gained market share for our ReedHycalog bits in West Texas and Saudi Arabia, despite price increases, due to strong performance and increasing activity.
Demand for drilling motors is also rising, and downhole friction reduction tools are completely sold out in some North American markets, with revenues up over 30% sequentially.
We increased drilling motor pricing by double digits in certain areas.
North American rig instrumentation and solids control services pricing has increased by double digits for new work, returning to pre-COVID levels and poised for further increases.
In our international markets, we expect our wired drill pipe jobs to increase by over 25% in the second quarter.
Operators are increasingly recognizing the value of real-time, high-bandwidth data from the bottom of their drill strings, which is only available through our proprietary IntelliServ Wired Drill Pipe technology.
Global OCTG demand appears to be increasing, leading to double-digit sequential growth in NOV Tuboscope's pipe inspection services worldwide.
Despite ongoing day rate pressure on drilling contractors, Grant Prideco achieved a book-to-bill ratio greater than 100% as operators require larger 5.5-inch drill pipe for improved hydraulic performance, prompting drilling contractors to purchase this pipe with our proprietary Delta premium connections.
Overall, higher oil prices and rig counts, particularly in North America, have positioned Wellbore Technologies at the forefront of the oilfield recovery.
In contrast, Completion & Production Solutions and Rig Technology segments continue to face challenges due to low capital equipment backlogs and cautious customer spending.
However, the CAPS segment saw its book-to-bill ratio for new capital equipment orders exceed 100% for the first time since the fourth quarter of 2019, suggesting improved results ahead.
The group's North American quick-turn businesses began to see improvement.
North American production chokes backlog increased by 30% and our reciprocating pump backlog grew 69% sequentially.
We secured another Tier 4 dual fuel fleet upgrade for a domestic pressure pumping service provider, and demand for coiled tubing strings tripled from its low point in the second quarter of last year.
While we lost a large project in Alaska, we won another significant project for Brazil, both indicating that operators may be moving forward with decisions after prolonged COVID-related delays.
Rig Technology faces challenging conditions for rig capital expenditure in the near term, but saw double-digit growth in spare parts orders, following two consecutive quarters of record low spare parts orders.
It is also seeing increasing inquiries for rig engineering related to offshore drilling rig reactivations.
So while our first quarter results were poor, I'm becoming more confident that results will improve significantly as the year progresses.
Our spare parts, consumables, and services businesses tied to activity are already seeing improvement, and our sales force is quickly adjusting pricing to acceptable levels.
Recovery for our capital equipment businesses always begins with rising orders, which we started to see in many businesses for the first time in 1.5 years.
You have effectively positioned the company to support our customers and capitalize on opportunities to serve them better.
Most importantly, throughout a challenging year, you've taken care of each other.
I'm extremely proud to work with you and appreciate all your efforts.
Jose, Blake and I look forward to better times with you as conditions improve through 2021.
NOV's consolidated revenue decreased by $78 million or 6% sequentially to $1.25 billion in the first quarter of 2021.
The sequential decline resulted from ongoing austerity from our customer base, operational disruptions from severe weather, and COVID-19 challenges, which continue to affect global supply chains.
A simple summary of the quarter is that January was extremely slow, February was disrupted by freezing conditions, and in March, orders began to increase significantly, allowing us to recover much of the lost ground and giving us confidence that our results will improve throughout the rest of the year.
Ongoing cost reduction initiatives, a higher-margin revenue mix, and improved pricing limited sequential decremental margins to 22%.
However, we are not satisfied with this performance, given that we are at breakeven EBITDA, which is unacceptable in any market environment.
We continue to challenge our organization to find new ways to increase efficiencies.
During Q1, we realized $52 million in annualized cost savings and identified an additional $31 million in opportunities, bringing the total we expect to achieve in 2021 to $106 million.
In the first quarter, our operations used $27 million in cash and capital expenditures totaled $49 million.
It's typical for the organization to consume cash in the first quarter, and we expect to be free cash flow positive for the year.
We ended the first quarter with $1.61 billion in cash and $1.85 billion in gross debt, or net debt of $244 million.
After the quarter ended, we fully redeemed the remaining $183 million of our senior notes due in December 2022 using cash on hand.
As a result, our next bond maturity is not until December 2029, and interest expense should decrease by approximately $1 million per quarter.
Regarding our segment results, our Wellbore Technologies segment generated $413 million in revenue during the first quarter, an increase of $40 million or 11% sequentially.
Cost reductions, improved absorption in our manufacturing plants, a more favorable sales mix, and better pricing led to 55% incremental margins and a $22 million increase in EBITDA to $34 million or 8.2% of sales.
Our ReedHycalog drill bit business achieved 20% revenue growth with strong improvements across the Western Hemisphere.
ReedHycalog's technology leadership is driving market share gains in most markets, and these gains helped drive modest revenue growth in the Eastern Hemisphere during a quarter that typically sees a seasonal slowdown.
Market share gains, improved absorption, better pricing, and cost-cutting resulted in incremental margins of almost 50%.
We expect our ReedHycalog business to post another solid sequential improvement in Q2, led by growing activity in the Middle East and Asia Pacific markets.
Our Downhole Tool business realized a 13% sequential improvement in revenue, led by sales growth that significantly outpaced the increase in drilling activity in the Western Hemisphere, partially offset by seasonal declines in the Eastern Hemisphere.
Operators working to reduce trips, maximize hydraulic flow, and reduce friction are driving improved demand for our SelectShift drilling motor, fluid hammer, impulse axial pulse technology, and agitator tools.
A more favorable sales mix, higher volumes, improved operational efficiencies, and better pricing allowed the business to deliver 50% incremental margins during the quarter.
Our WellSite Services business realized a 16% sequential increase in revenue, primarily from improving results in its solid control operations.
The business unit has steadily recaptured market share in North America from struggling competitors that have exited the market over the last several quarters and is now starting to improve pricing.
Our M/D Totco business realized low single-digit revenue growth in the first quarter.
Revenue from surface sensor and data acquisition offerings in the Western Hemisphere improved in line with drilling activity but was partially offset by the seasonal decrease in capital equipment sales to the Eastern Hemisphere.
The business unit's eVolve wire drill pipe optimization services achieved record rental service revenue, and as mentioned earlier, secured additional jobs for Q2.
Our track record of improving drilling efficiencies for operators is driving an increasing rate of adoption.
However, the relatively high cost of wire drill pipe in a capital-constrained market has mostly limited the service offering to operators with complex wells and tight drilling parameters.
We believe our new low-cost, next-generation wire drill pipe technology could significantly expand the market and accelerate the adoption of our wired drill pipe enabled services.
Our Tuboscope division saw a 10% sequential rise in revenue for pipe coating and inspection services.
Inspection service demand improved worldwide, with particularly strong growth in the U.S. where steel mill and processor piece counts rose 43%.
Coating operations revenue decreased due to seasonal declines in the Eastern Hemisphere outweighing increased North American demand.
Grant Prideco drill pipe division achieved a high single-digit sequential revenue increase.
A higher proportion of large-diameter premium pipe in sales led to strong margins despite winter storm-related costs, including repairs, overtime, and scrapping due to power outages during heat-treating.
The division achieved a 104% book-to-bill ratio, indicating potential further improvement in Q2.
North American orders comprised 31% of total orders, the highest percentage in some time.
Strong demand for 5.5-inch pipe was driven by operators seeking greater hydraulic efficiencies, aligning with demand for high flow rate drilling tools, while ample supplies of 4.5- and 5-inch customer-owned drill pipe remain in the U.S.
For Wellbore Technologies, we anticipate moderate activity gains in the U.S. and Latin America, with Eastern Hemisphere recovery leading to 8-10% sequential revenue growth in Q2.
We expect continued cost structure improvements and better pricing, potentially allowing for incremental EBITDA margins near 50%.
Completion & Production Solutions generated $439 million in Q1 revenue, a 20% sequential decrease of $107 million.
The decline was primarily due to depleted backlogs, severe weather disruptions, and supply chain challenges.
Cost reduction efforts and operational efficiency improvements limited decremental margins to 30%, with EBITDA declining $32 million to a $4 million loss.
Segment orders improved $57 million sequentially to $338 million, resulting in a 127% book-to-bill ratio, the first over 100% since Q4 2019.
We began including subsurface fiberglass fuel storage tank orders in our capital equipment backlog; excluding this, the book-to-bill would have been 115%.
Fiber Glass Systems experienced a 25% sequential revenue decline.
The unit faced challenges typical of our capital equipment businesses in Q1, including absorption issues from five consecutive quarters with sub-1 book-to-bill ratios, severe COVID-19 and weather-related disruptions.
COVID outbreaks shut down two large Malaysian manufacturing facilities for three weeks, while pandemic-related supply chain issues caused shortages of epoxy resin and glass fiber, limiting production.
Severe winter weather hampered operations and caused customer delivery deferrals due to transportation constraints and installation difficulties.
Despite these challenges, the team maintained positive EBITDA margins.
While supply challenges may persist until August, the business outlook is improving daily.
A significant increase in March orders for fuel handling products resulted in a book-to-bill ratio above 100%.
Demand is returning for marine scrubbers in Asia and fiberglass pipe in the Middle East, suggesting steady improvement throughout 2021.
Intervention & Stimulation Equipment experienced a mid-single-digit sequential decline in Q1, its fifth consecutive quarter of declining revenue.
Despite continued North American market weakness, the segment achieved its second straight quarter with a book-to-bill ratio above 1.
Wireline equipment demand, particularly in the Middle East, Europe, and Africa, has been a bright spot.
Global coiled tubing business saw a sharp Q1 decline, but international market quoting activity remains healthy, and improving U.S. completions activity is driving greater consumables demand.
Pressure pumping activity has increased significantly, but customer service pricing remains well below pre-COVID levels, forcing equipment cannibalization and low-cost purchases of distressed equipment.
Cannibalization opportunities are limited, and equipment auction quality is deteriorating rapidly.
We're seeing a significant increase in quotes for new equipment, albeit from extremely low levels.
Q1 cementing equipment orders doubled compared to the entire second half of 2020.
Demand is increasing for stimulation equipment with enhanced capabilities and reduced emissions.
We booked an order to convert 16 Tier 2 frac pumps to Tier 4 DGB dual fuel units, capable of running on diesel and natural gas, lowering costs and emissions.
Interest is growing in our ideal e-frac stimulation equipment, which recently completed its first field trial, completing over 200 stages at rates up to 22 barrels per minute.
With improved bookings and growing aftermarket service demand, we expect a meaningful Q2 revenue increase for Intervention & Stimulation Equipment.
XL Systems conductor pipe business saw a sharp sequential revenue decline due to a depleted backlog after eight consecutive quarters with a sub-1 book-to-bill ratio.
The team limited decremental margins to 17% and achieved a 143% book-to-bill ratio, indicating improving market conditions.
Customer behavior has been mixed, with some awarding work then delaying deliveries, while others are urgently ordering for near-term spud dates.
Competition remains fierce, with some competitors offering unsustainable pricing and payment terms.
Our technological and quality differentiation allows us to win projects not entirely driven by pricing, such as an award for the industry's first 20,000-psi well development project.
Subsea flexible pipe business experienced a low double-digit sequential revenue decline with high decremental margins due to lower volumes, less favorable product mix, and manufacturing challenges with a new pipe design.
While bookings remained light, customer dialogue and order outlook have improved, particularly in Brazil, where large projects are expected to advance later this year.
Exact timing remains uncertain due to extreme COVID-19-related challenges in Brazil, making coordination and essential engineering work difficult.
We believe offshore production-oriented components of our CAPS segment are at or near bottom.
Some previously delayed offshore production-related projects are starting to move forward, and we're hopeful that stronger oil prices could support more FIDs throughout the year.
For Q2 2021, we anticipate Completion & Production Solutions segment revenue will improve 15-25% sequentially, with incremental margins in the mid-20% range.
Rig Technologies generated $431 million in Q1 revenue, a 1% sequential decrease of $6 million.
A small increase in offshore wind-related capital equipment sales was offset by seasonal declines in aftermarket services.
Less favorable revenue mix and weather-related disruptions led to a $6 million EBITDA decline to $13 million, or 3% of sales.
Segment orders declined $78 million sequentially to $112 million, yielding a 59% book-to-bill ratio, the sixth out of seven quarters below 1.
Rig capital equipment orders remained weak as drilling contractors continued to cannibalize idle equipment and minimize spending.
Despite improving activity and dialogue, customer urgency remains low.
Quotation levels increased 25% sequentially, and quote-to-order conversion improved, but only for small orders.
Larger orders are not being lost to competitors or canceled, but continue to be delayed.
Ongoing COVID-19 outbreaks in international markets and uncertainty around offshore drilling contractor bankruptcy exits are not inspiring confidence.
Middle Eastern and Asian customers express need for newbuild rigs, and offshore customers require meaningful upgrades for reactivations, but lack of urgency is expected to keep the book-to-bill ratio for traditional rig equipment below 1.
We're optimistic that a few more quarters of stable commodity prices and improving activity levels will help move projects forward.
We began manufacturing the first two rigs from our new Saudi Arabian plant, which has a commitment for 50 drilling rigs over 10 years and $1.8 billion in backlog.
We expect to deliver the first rig at the end of this year, one per quarter in 2022, and five per year from 2023.
Aftermarket spare part bookings increased 22%, led by Middle East and U.S. land markets as rig cannibalization opportunities diminish.
Several large offshore customers are in late stages of restructuring, with significant equipment in our shops.
We're optimistic that once capital structures are reset and more FIDs advance, we'll see a meaningful increase in service, repair, and recertification work.
Our renewables business contrasts sharply with the traditional rig business.
We booked an order for design, jacking systems, and crane for a European wind turbine installation vessel.
Q1 offshore wind orders were modest compared to over $400 million in potential projects that could be awarded before year-end.
For Q2, we expect growth in renewables, improving aftermarket activity, and progress on Saudi Arabian rigs to offset weak rig capital equipment orders, leading to Rig Technology segment results in line with Q1.
Summary:
output:
national oilwell varco q1 2021 revenues of $1.25 billion, a decrease of six percent compared to q4 of 2020.
q1 2021 revenues of $1.25 billion, a decrease of six percent compared to q4 of 2020.
completion & production solutions generated revenues of $439 million in q1, decrease of 20% from q4 of 2020.
completion & production solutions new orders booked during quarter totaled $338 million.
new orders booked in rig technologies during the quarter totaled $112 million.
as of march 31, 2021, company had total debt of $1.85 billion.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Bill McDermott, our president and CEO, and Gina Mastantuono, our CFO, are accompanying me.
We will examine our Q3 2021 financial results and provide financial guidance for Q4 and full-year 2021 during this call.
We present non-GAAP measures alongside, not in place of, GAAP-calculated financial measures.
Our website will feature a recording of today's call.
Although ServiceNow's performance consistently exceeds expectations, it remains remarkable.
Our team once again delivered exceptional results, surpassing the upper limits of our guidance across all metrics.
Organic growth in subscription revenues reached 31%.
This level of performance is unmatched in our industry.
Current remaining performance obligations grew by 32%, subscription billings increased by 28%, and operating margin stood at 26%.
We have once again increased our full-year forecast, reinforcing our clear trajectory towards $15 billion-plus in revenue by 2026.
I assumed the role of ServiceNow's CEO over two years ago.
We've all witnessed numerous events since then.
What remains unparalleled is the consistent innovation and execution at a global scale.
And we're just beginning.
Before Gina provides a comprehensive report, let's discuss ServiceNow's dramatic upward trajectory.
The rate of digital investment is growing rapidly.
IDC has consistently valued this opportunity at $7.8 trillion over four years.
Given this vast addressable market, ServiceNow is positioned at the intersection of two generational opportunities: First, the need for new technology infrastructure is intensifying our close collaboration with CIOs.
A recent Wall Street Journal article emphasized CIOs' role as digital business architects.
Ongoing advancements in public cloud and machine learning are ushering in a new era of software innovation.
Technology teams desire a fully integrated software lifecycle: planning, development, deployment, operations, and service.
ServiceNow is spearheading this 20th to 21st century transition for our clients.
The Now Platform, with its immense versatility and scalability, has become the control center for digital transformation.
The second factor propelling ServiceNow is the reorganization of enterprise application platforms for hyperautomation.
Today's leaders recognize that their technology architecture is their business architecture.
Over several decades, enterprises have invested trillions in on-premise and first-generation SaaS applications.
These applications met the business process needs of the 20th century.
Modern business models require a fully connected value chain.
Legacy environments lack the adaptability to enable this change.
As the pioneer of modern digital workflows, ServiceNow is leading the renaissance.
The Now Platform connects various applications and data sources to create intuitive mobile experiences, all at a consumer-grade level.
We don't require businesses to commit entirely to a single system or collaboration tool.
We offer choices that unlock value from our platform and other platform investments.
ServiceNow also enables anyone to develop applications on our platform.
In its report on low-code development technologies, Gartner predicts that 70% of new applications developed by 2025 will use low-code or no-code technologies.
Gartner also recognized ServiceNow as a leader in its Magic Quadrant.
These tailwinds are driving rapid organic growth across our entire solutions portfolio.
The number of deals exceeding $1 million reached 63, up 50% year-over-year, indicating substantial adoption of our platform strategy.
In Q3, IT workflows remained robust.
ITSM featured in 18 of our top 20 deals, while IT Operations Management had 10 deals over $1 million.
The Internal Revenue Service is undertaking a multiyear digital transformation effort.
In Q3, they selected ServiceNow to consolidate 12 complex systems into a single platform supporting the agency's mission-critical operations.
Demand for our entire IT portfolio is strong.
The introduction of Lightstep Incident Response in the third quarter is paving the way for new product-driven growth in monitoring and observability of applications.
HR was a key component in 13 of our 20 largest deals, demonstrating Employee Workflows' exceptional performance this quarter.
In the third quarter, NTT Data will utilize the Now Platform to develop a portal for employee experience, boosting productivity in hybrid work settings and managing vaccine distribution for its entire staff.
Customer Workflows maintains its momentum, with CSM featured in 12 of our top 20 deals and eight transactions exceeding $1 million.
Our industry-specific solutions are spearheading progress with major brands.
Verizon is implementing our telecommunications solution, American Century our financial services solution, and Sunbelt Health our healthcare solution.
Creator Workflows, which enables companies to develop their own applications, performed remarkably well in the third quarter, featuring in 18 of our top 20 deals.
We're collaborating with Stanley Black & Decker to implement ServiceNow's new manufacturing vertical solution with App Engine to revolutionize their customer service approach.
In partnership, we're optimizing facility operational time and providing excellent experiences for distributors, dealers, and end-users.
Fujitsu will also broaden its use of the Now Platform to propel its own digital transformation journey.
We're immensely proud that Uber, Honeywell, Telia, and numerous others chose ServiceNow in Q3.
This represents a comprehensive performance for the company, with robust growth across the Americas, EMEA, and Asia Pacific/Japan regions.
As we anticipate a strong conclusion to 2021 and beyond, several factors give us great optimism about this business.
Firstly, despite the fierce competition for talent, we're greatly encouraged by the record number of professionals choosing to join ServiceNow.
Our new hires, along with our exceptional global workforce, are fostering a uniquely inclusive, motivated, and content culture.
We're also witnessing significant developments in our partner ecosystem.
Just three weeks ago, we revealed a new partnership with Celonis.
Celonis will provide process mining insights, ServiceNow will create improved workflows, and our customers will benefit from this integrated approach.
We've also strengthened our long-standing partnership with Microsoft.
ServiceNow's Employee Center can now be directly integrated into Microsoft Teams, reaching 250 million monthly users.
In collaboration with our expanding partner network, we will simplify processes to enhance work experiences for people.
Lastly, innovation without disruption is a cornerstone of our top-tier engineering tradition.
By 'without disruption', we mean imperceptible, offering a smooth upgrade experience for our customers.
In our Now Platform Rome release, we introduced numerous new features to customers, including Mobile App Builder, an Automation Discovery tool, Employee Journey Management, and new Customer Service Playbooks.
Every business leader globally is contemplating the future of work.
These new features equip the Now Platform with even greater capabilities to shape that hybrid future.
I'll refer to a statement made by industry analyst Josh Bersin, who commented on our Rome Platform release, "This company appears to be able to develop and deploy enterprise software faster than almost any I've ever seen, which is why they're a powerhouse".
Josh, I naturally concur.
In conclusion, the company is operating at peak performance.
The quarterly results speak for themselves.
We exceeded expectations once again and raised our guidance once more.
The secular trends are in our favor.
Our customer base is expanding while our customer NPS is rising.
Our partner ecosystem is energized.
We accelerated our timeline to achieve net zero emissions.
We assist businesses in driving their own ESG initiatives on our platform with a major release.
The list of achievements continues.
Overall, our message to the market couldn't be clearer.
Regardless of your systems, challenges, or opportunities, and however rapidly you need to progress, you have a trusted innovator in ServiceNow.
We aim to improve how the world works for everyone, and we'll never lose sight of the privilege that comes with saying, the world operates with ServiceNow.
Gina, I'll hand it over to you.
The third quarter was another outstanding period with continued outperformance across all of our growth and profitability guidance metrics.
Demand was robust globally across all three of our geographical regions.
The consistency of our quarterly results demonstrates the robustness of our product range and our team's dedication to fostering strong customer connections.
Third-quarter subscription revenue reached $1.43 billion, exceeding our highest projection by $22 million and showing a 31% year-over-year increase, including a 1% boost from foreign exchange.
The remaining performance obligation concluded the quarter at about $9.7 billion, reflecting a 34% growth compared to the previous year.
The current remaining performance obligation was approximately $5 billion, showing a 32% year-over-year increase and surpassing our forecast by 2 percentage points.
Exchange rates had no effect on the year-over-year growth.
Subscription billings for Q3 totaled $1.38 billion, representing a 28% increase from the previous year and exceeding our highest projection by $55 million.
Foreign exchange and duration provided a 1.5% year-over-year boost.
We observed widespread success across the industries we serve, with particularly strong net new annual contract value growth in transportation, logistics, and business services.
Our Q3 renewal rate of 98% demonstrates the value ServiceNow provides to its customers.
We consider our customer relationships as long-term collaborations and continuously innovate to offer new solutions addressing their changing business requirements.
This strategy of gaining and expanding customers has resulted in 1,266 clients paying over $1 million in annual contract value, a 25% increase from last year.
As our product range and addressable opportunities have grown, so have our deal sizes.
We closed 63 deals with over $1 million in net new annual contract value this quarter, an increase of more than 50% compared to last year.
All of our top 20 deals in Q3 involved four or more products.
Our operating margin was 26%, 3 percentage points above our forecast, primarily due to strong revenue performance.
We also experienced savings from delayed return-to-work plans and reduced travel expenses.
Our free cash flow margin was 15%.
These results collectively demonstrate the strength of our business model and our ability to balance growth with profitability.
We're delivering exceptional experiences that drive strong employee engagement, intense customer loyalty, and significant productivity improvements.
By providing more intelligent automation that enhances experiences, we are well-positioned as the workflow standard on our path to becoming a company with over $15 billion in revenue.
We are increasing our full-year guidance.
We're raising our subscription revenue projection by $32 million at the midpoint to a range of $5.565 billion to $5.57 billion, representing 30% year-over-year growth, including a 2% boost from foreign exchange.
We are increasing our subscription billings forecast by $61 million at the midpoint to a range of $6.379 billion to $6.384 billion, representing 28% year-over-year growth.
Excluding early customer payments in 2020, our adjusted subscription billings growth projection would be 32% year-over-year at the midpoint.
This growth includes a net 2% boost from foreign exchange and duration.
We continue to anticipate an 85% subscription gross margin for 2021, and we're raising our full-year 2021 operating margin from 24.5% to 25%.
This reflects our increased top-line growth and savings from delayed return-to-work plans and reduced travel.
We're also raising our full-year 2021 free cash flow margin by 0.5 percentage points from 31% to 31.5%.
We expect 202 million diluted weighted average outstanding shares.
For Q4, we anticipate subscription revenues between $1.515 billion and $1.52 billion, representing 28% year-over-year growth, with minimal impact from foreign exchange.
We expect current remaining performance obligation growth of 27% year-over-year.
This includes a 1.5% foreign exchange headwind due to recent sharp movements in the euro and pound.
On a constant currency basis, we expect current remaining performance obligation growth to be 28.5%.
We anticipate subscription billings between $2.305 billion and $2.31 billion, representing 26% year-over-year growth.
Excluding early customer payments in Q4 2020, our adjusted subscription billings growth projection would be 32% year-over-year at the midpoint.
This growth includes a net 0.5% headwind from foreign exchange and duration.
We expect an operating margin of 22%, which includes accelerated demand generation spending in the quarter to set us up for a strong start in 2022, and we anticipate 203 million diluted weighted outstanding shares for the quarter.
In conclusion, the pace of digital investment is accelerating, and ServiceNow is rising to seize the opportunities before us.
Our team has never been more engaged and focused on addressing the significant needs of our customers.
As ServiceNow evolves into the defining enterprise software company of the 21st century, we remain committed to creating a positive impact on the world.
I'm pleased to announce that in September, we committed to achieving our net-zero emissions goal by 2030, twenty years earlier than our previous target.
We've never been more proud of our employees and their continued dedication to serving our customers, partners, and communities as we strive to improve not only work processes but also make the world function better.
Our culture of ambition and humility is stronger than ever.
Summary:
output:
subscription revenues of $1,427 million in q3 2021, representing 31% year-over-year growth.
qtrly total revenues$1,512 million, up 31%.

EnPro had a prosperous year as we continued to meet the challenges and seize the opportunities that emerged over the last year

I will now transfer the call to Milt for a more in-depth analysis of our Q4 financial performance.
Despite widely reported challenges faced by us and others, we experienced another strong quarter.
Q4 sales reached $280.8 million, showing a 1.7% increase compared to the previous year.
We observed robust demand across semiconductor, heavy-duty truck, aerospace, general industrial, and food and pharma sectors, along with contributions from Alluxa and NxEdge acquisitions, which largely counterbalanced the sales reduction due to divestitures and automotive market weakness.

Excluding divested businesses and foreign exchange impacts, sales grew by 12% compared to the previous year, driven by strong demand in heavy-duty truck, aerospace, nuclear, and food and pharma markets.
Adjusted segment EBITDA decreased by 12.3% due to divestitures in 2020 and 2021.
Excluding divestitures and foreign exchange effects, adjusted segment EBITDA increased by 3% compared to the previous year.
Quarterly results were affected by inflationary pressures on raw materials, labor, and freight costs, particularly in the trucking business.
These costs were offset by pricing initiatives and leverage from organic volume growth in the segment.
Now, let's discuss Advanced Surface Technologies.
Q4 sales increased by 38.5% to $69.1 million, driven by strong semiconductor market demand and the acquisitions of Alluxa and NxEdge.
Excluding acquisitions and foreign exchange effects, sales grew by 16.6% compared to the previous year.
Q4 adjusted segment EBITDA increased by 35.7% due to acquisitions and strong organic sales growth.
Excluding acquisitions and foreign exchange impacts, adjusted segment EBITDA grew by 10.4% compared to the previous year.
EBITDA growth, while strong, was partially impacted by timing delays in advanced node chip launches.
Our ongoing qualification and production work with semiconductor customers gives us confidence in the organic growth and profitability outlook for our semi business, both in the coming year and long-term.
In Engineered Materials, sales decreased by 7.3% due to the divestitures of GGB bushing block and CPI businesses.
Q4 automotive market sales were weak due to chip shortages affecting auto production, particularly compared to the strong auto market in Q4 2020 and the first half of 2021.
Excluding divestitures and foreign exchange effects, sales remained flat.
Compared to the same period last year, fourth quarter adjusted segment EBITDA fell by 21.9%, due to increased raw material costs, supply chain difficulties, and reduced automotive production in Europe and the US.
When not considering divestitures and currency exchange effects, adjusted segment EBITDA decreased by approximately 20.2% compared to the previous year's quarter.
Let's examine the financial position and cash flow.
At the end of Q4, we had $338.1 million in cash, with $310 million located outside the US.
We're working on bringing back some of this overseas cash to pay down debt, where it's tax-efficient to do so.
As of December 31, we had $213.6 million available for borrowing under our credit facility.
In 2021, free cash flow reached $123.2 million, up from $39.3 million the previous year, due to higher operating profits and lower taxes from a refund related to a federal tax audit resolution, partly offset by working capital investments to support increased demand.
We paid a $0.27 per share quarterly dividend in Q4.
Total dividend payments for the year amounted to $22.4 million.
Our directors approved an increase in our quarterly dividend to $0.28 per share, starting with the March payment, marking our 7th consecutive annual increase since initiating dividends in 2015.
Regarding 2022 projections:
We anticipate low double-digit revenue growth compared to 2021's reported sales of $1.14 billion, with adjusted EBITDA expected between $263 million and $275 million, suggesting adjusted EBITDA margins above 20%.
We project adjusted diluted earnings per share from continuing operations to range from $6.70 to $7.25, using a normalized 27% tax rate, down from 30% last year.
The lower 2022 tax rate assumption stems from late 2021 portfolio changes that increased the proportion of US earnings.
Our forecast includes depreciation and amortization expenses, excluding acquisition-related intangible asset amortization, of $37 million to $39 million, and net interest expenses of $30 million to $33 million.
The net interest expense estimate accounts for 425 basis point increases in our variable borrowing rate throughout 2022.
Demand and order trends remain strong entering 2022, despite inflationary raw material costs, omicron variant impacts on labor availability, and supply chain and logistics constraints pressuring early-year growth and margins.
We plan to implement additional pricing measures across the company during the year to address inflationary pressures.
We continue to monitor the COVID situation and prioritize the safety and well-being of our colleagues, who have shown great resilience during challenging times over the past two years.
EnPro had an exceptional year.
I'm proud of our team's achievements in executing our multi-year strategy to transform EnPro into a leading industrial technology company, focusing on our best businesses while investing in markets with faster growth, higher margins, and better cash flow returns.
Our 2022 guidance suggests adjusted EBITDA margins around 21%, up from 14% in 2019 when we began our portfolio reshaping strategy.
We remain committed to delivering strong financial results while supporting our colleagues' development and the communities where we operate.
Our journey is just beginning.
We appreciate your interest in our company.
I'll now take questions.
Summary:
output:
compname reports q4 adjusted earnings per share of $1.23.
q4 adjusted earnings per share $1.23.
q4 sales rose 1.7 percent to $280.8 million.
introducing guidance for 2022: revenue growth in low double-digit range.
sees 2022 adjusted ebitda of $263 million to $275 million.
sees 2022 adjusted diluted earnings per share from continuing operations of $6.70 to $7.25.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:In the third quarter of 2020, we recorded a $99 million impairment charge related to an equity method investment.
We will discuss the quarterly results without including that charge.
A complete transcript and download will be available after the call concludes.
I am pleased to present Norfolk Southern's Chairman, President and CEO, Jim Squires.
Our third quarter performance was exceptional, setting new records for operating ratio, net income, income from railway operations, and earnings per share.
Despite flat volume compared to last year, revenue increased by an impressive 14%, and our 60.2% operating ratio shows a 230-point improvement year-over-year on an adjusted basis, marking our second-best OR performance ever, surpassed only by last quarter's 58.3%.
We are fulfilling our commitments despite significant nationwide supply chain disruptions and labor shortages.
These achievements would not have been possible without the unwavering dedication of our employees, who consistently ensure the safe and efficient movement of our customers' goods.
Let's have Cindy walk us through our operations.
This quarter, we continued to successfully enhance productivity across our network.
We strived for maximum efficiency while adapting to demand shifts in various markets.
This quarter demonstrates ongoing progress as we tackle our cost structure while positioning ourselves for further improvements in both cost and service quality.
The quarterly operating metrics on slide six clearly indicate that we once again generated positive operating leverage on flat unit volumes and a 5% increase in GTMs.
Although we are actively hiring train crews, efficiency improvements across all operational areas, including engineering, mechanical, and communications and signals, allowed us to operate the network with 7% fewer employees compared to the same quarter last year.
Reducing the number of active locomotives was a crucial factor in managing workforce size, as assets drive activity.
Both train weight and length continued to improve, driven by a focus on enhancing productivity in our bulk network.
Coal, grain, and other single commodity unit trains present significant opportunities for improvement through collaboration with customers on operating trains with more cars per set and by combining existing trains for portions of their routes.
