I anticipate further progress in the fourth quarter as we see the results of our efforts.
While strong coal traffic contributed more to train weight than length, train length continued to improve and set another quarterly record.
After seven consecutive quarters of fuel efficiency improvements, we experienced a slight decline this quarter despite the increase in train size, as our horsepower leverage was occasionally challenged due to volatile traffic flows and we had slightly fewer very heavy, highly fuel-efficient trains.
I am urging the team to respond more swiftly to changes, and we are committed to narrowing the gap with our peers over time, redoubling our efforts in this critical area.
As shown on slide seven, train speed and terminal dwell were generally consistent with the second quarter but do not reflect our desired performance levels.
Although Hurricane Ida had some effects, these impacts were localized, and I'm extremely proud of how our team, particularly engineering and signal forces, quickly restored our routes in Louisiana and reopened the New Orleans Gateway.
As mentioned last quarter, we are facing increasingly challenging hiring and retention conditions, especially in some of our more critical locations, which is impacting our network.
Despite ongoing hiring efforts throughout the year, attrition has accelerated in each of the last two quarters in several crucial areas.
In many of these locations, we've managed to absorb the impact by implementing productivity initiatives, which will continue to be a significant part of our strategy as we expand capacity, which I'll discuss further shortly.
We are taking several actions to address these challenges: we've more than tripled our conductor trainee numbers since the first quarter to effectively backfill critical areas; we've introduced incentives such as perfect attendance bonuses, referral bonuses, and signing incentives to improve retention of our current and future workforce; and we continue to utilize valuable Go Teams to quickly respond to business opportunities when needed.
Our employees are the foundation of our railroad, and we must make progress on these initiatives to better manage the effects of a tight labor market.
We are dedicated to having the appropriate resources in the right place at the right time, which will drive both cost control and service quality.
As our business mix continues to evolve, creating capacity across our market segments has become an even more crucial area of focus, as highlighted on slide eight.
Some shippers aim to capitalize on unexpected market opportunities by shipping additional volume.
Others are looking to us to help them adjust to volatility in other parts of their supply chains, and naturally, all place high value on service predictability.
We're adapting our network and operations to generate the various types of capacity that customers require.
For instance, increases in train sizes provide shippers with extra capacity without further demands on our crew base.
Train size increases often require connecting railroads, customers, and Norfolk Southern to modify processes, and we have found that these changes are worthwhile as they improve asset turns and capacity.
We also continue to focus on terminal efficiency, whether by helping to reduce dwell times at our largest hump yard, Elkhart, to very low levels or strategically redirecting trains to intermodal terminals that can unload quickly.
Moving to slide nine, I want to demonstrate how we can use these capacity efforts to drive productivity.
We've had great success over the past two years in increasing train size and, in doing so, have addressed several infrastructure bottlenecks.
We're expediting a set of siding improvements, the first of which became operational at the end of the third quarter, to continue making progress.
Larger trains enabled by siding extensions help improve locomotive utilization by allowing us to fully match train size to available pulling power.
Since locomotives are most efficient when pulling hard, this is a key factor in improving our fuel efficiency.
While I've used locomotives and fuel as my primary example, capacity additions have a similar effect on our crew productivity: more cars per crew, improved asset turns, keeping trains moving with greater train capacity, and also benefiting our customers with enhanced train and car performance.
On slide 10, we are complementing our investment in physical capacity with a comprehensive technology strategy that enhances crew efficiency and asset productivity.
Nearly all of our routine signal and track maintenance is now scheduled via the mobile track authority app, transforming a process that used to take minutes into one that can be completed in seconds.
This approach is inherently more efficient than the previous radio-based process and, most importantly, safer because it reduces transcription errors.
According to our chief engineer, the app has been transformative for the productivity of his teams.
We're implementing a similar approach with our mobile train reporting app, which allows our train crews to quickly report completed work and receive updated customer work requests while en route.
This streamlines the process by eliminating multiple steps, including significant retyping and delays, enabling our crews to be more productive.
The rollout of this application to local trains responsible for most pickups and deliveries is in its early stages.
There are many potential applications for this technology in the field, and promoting its adoption and innovation is a key focus that will enable us to reap additional benefits.
The common theme among these applications is that improved information enables better planning.
Track supervisors can better organize their schedules knowing when tracks are available, while customers can more effectively plan their plant operations and product pipelines with current shipment data.
In Q3, we continued to implement our growth strategy, resulting in double-digit revenue increases across all three of our markets, further showcasing our ability to create value for customers and shareholders.
Starting with slide 12, I will present our Q3 results.
Our total revenue reached $2.9 billion, a 14% increase compared to the same period last year, despite unchanged volumes.
This quarter's revenue performance was fueled by significant increases in revenue per unit and revenue per unit excluding fuel, both hitting record levels with double-digit year-over-year growth.
This reflects the success of our ongoing efforts to improve yields and revenue quality, a strategy that enhances our long-term potential for revenue and margin growth as market conditions improve.
Our merchandise segment saw a 10% year-over-year revenue increase, while volume grew by 5%.
The Chemicals franchise led the growth, benefiting from recovering energy demand that drove higher shipments of crude oil and natural gas liquids.
Strong steel markets, due to record-high commodity prices and increased manufacturing activity, also contributed to merchandise growth.
Steel shipments increased by an impressive 34% compared to the same period last year.
These gains were partially offset by decreased shipments of finished vehicles and vehicle parts due to the ongoing semiconductor shortage.
This limited automotive production and further reduced finished vehicle inventories to new lows.
Both revenue per unit and revenue per unit excluding fuel improved year-over-year due to price increases.
Our intermodal franchise faced several challenges related to supply chain disruptions that negatively impacted volume in both domestic and international business lines.
In both segments, unprecedented demand from inventory restocking and consumer spending exceeded available capacity in the supply chain ecosystem.
Drayage shortages, warehouse productivity issues, equipment availability problems, labor force participation challenges, and rail network fluidity pressures affected intermodal volume throughout the quarter, resulting in a 4% year-over-year decline.
Despite these challenges, we achieved 16% revenue growth in Q3 due to higher revenue from storage services, increased fuel surcharge revenue, and price strength.
Coal revenue rose by 32% in Q3 as both domestic and global economies continued to recover from the pandemic, driving demand for electric power.
Export coal shipments increased significantly as strong demand and record-high seaborne prices created more opportunities for the US.
Utility volumes declined in Q3 as coal supply was limited and some crossover tons moved into the higher-priced export market.
The shift from utility to export coal, combined with price gains, led to a 20% increase in revenue per unit excluding fuel for coal in Q3, setting a new record for the franchise.
Looking ahead to slide 13, we expect the Q3 environment to persist through the end of the year.
Strong consumer demand will continue, while material shortages and labor issues will keep global supply chains under pressure.
Inventory levels remain at historic lows despite ongoing efforts to replenish stock, boosting transportation demand.
We are confident in our ability to leverage our strengths in these market conditions and deliver robust revenue growth for the full year.
We anticipate our merchandise business will continue to benefit from recovering economic activity, as conditions that limited business and recreational activities in Q4 last year have been less impactful in Q4 2021.
We expect higher volumes in our markets for crude oil, natural gas liquids, and waste as a result.
Ongoing demand for steel will also drive growth, with industrial production forecasts up more than 5% year-over-year in Q4 and steel prices currently above $1,900 per ton.
A projected 4% year-over-year decline in US light vehicle production in Q4 will remain a challenge as the industry continues to struggle with the chip shortage.
In the intermodal sector, we continue to see strong demand from consumer spending and tightness in the truck market.
These favorable conditions are offset by constraints from supply chain congestion and equipment availability.
We are collaborating closely with our customers and channel partners to address these challenges.
However, we do not anticipate significant improvement in these headwinds before the end of the year.
Coal demand is expected to remain strong with extremely favorable market conditions, although coal supply will limit year-over-year growth.
Natural gas prices continue to rise, and declining inventory levels leading into the winter months are currently the main concern for utility customers.
Seaborne prices in the export market are at decades-long highs, creating demand that exceeds capacity and supply capabilities.
Overall, we are optimistic about Q4 opportunities and confident in our ability to execute our plan to generate value and grow our business.
Moving to slide 14, several factors are impacting the supply chain we operate in.
These include external factors such as the chip shortage and increasing congestion in the intermodal supply chain.
Coal supply availability continues to constrain meeting higher demand in all markets, as both thermal and metallurgical production remain tight.
NS has taken steps to mitigate some of these factors and effectively position ourselves for revenue growth.
As drayage challenges affected international intermodal, we offered an alternative storage solution to our customers.
We are working diligently to increase chassis capacity to support demand and alleviate shortages across the supply chain.
In the previous quarter, we presented our strategy to fix a section of our chassis fleet affected by a production flaw.
I'm grateful for our team's swift response and efforts, and I'm happy to announce that this problem is essentially resolved as we have fixed and returned about 95% of the recalled chassis to operation.
We are currently in the process of receiving leased chassis to expand our fleet.
We have increased terminal capacity to accommodate growth driven by e-commerce and an improving economy, as well as reduced terminal congestion and enhanced network efficiency.
We continue to concentrate on growth prospects throughout our network.
We are constantly innovating to compete in the $800 billion plus trucking and logistics market, as demonstrated by our Thoroughbred Freight Transfer (TFT) service launched earlier this year.
TFT is one of our initiatives to drive growth by targeting opportunities to shift highway traffic to rail.
This service combines the efficiency of our intermodal trains, the capacity of our boxcar assets, and the flexibility of trucks for last-mile delivery to provide an innovative door-to-door service.
We are also utilizing our sustainability advantage to drive long-term growth.
The choice of transportation mode is one of the most effective ways for any shipper to reduce its carbon footprint, and we are collaborating closely with our customers to provide additional value through sustainability.
We have demonstrated our ability to deliver results despite challenging market conditions by offering innovative solutions that our customers value and position us for future market demands.
On slide 16, as Alan just explained, revenues increased by 14% with flat volumes.
With operating expenses up 10%, we achieved strong incremental margins leading to a 230 basis point improvement in operating ratio, bringing us to a Q3 record of 60.2%.
The improvement in RPU that Alan described, combined with strong productivity, resulted in record Q3 operating income, growing by 21% or nearly $200 million.
Our free cash flow is also at record levels, increasing by 33% during these nine months compared to the previous year.
Moving to slide 17, let's examine the changes in operating expenses in more detail.
While operating expenses grew by $149 million or 10%, it's only up 4% or $67 million, excluding fuel cost increases.
The $82 million increase in fuel costs is primarily due to price, but the 5% increase in GTMs also led to higher consumption.
You'll notice purchase services increased by $35 million, with the majority of the year-over-year increase in certain areas.
We have an increase in technology spending, which aligns with our technology strategy, and Cindy mentioned a couple of project examples in her remarks.
There are also headwinds from Conrail operating expenses.
Additionally, there are increases in intermodal costs.
Specifically, we incurred trucking costs for shuttling longer dwell containers to satellite parking lots to reduce congestion at our terminals and keep freight moving.
Lift expenses actually increased in the quarter despite fewer lifts, primarily due to inflation we absorbed on lift rates associated with contractor labor availability.
We expect continued inflationary pressure in this area going forward.
We also incurred costs related to our chassis repairs during the quarter.
Regarding compensation and benefits, it increased by 5%, but you'll notice the $40 million in savings from a 7% reduction in headcount that more than offset increases in pay rates and overtime.
Meanwhile, incentive compensation comparisons in the quarter are a $43 million headwind, similar to what we reported in the second quarter, reflecting our strong 2021 financial outlook compared to lower accrual rates last year.
Materials, claims, and other expenses all decreased year-over-year.
Turning to slide 18 and examining the rest of the P&L below operating income, you'll see that other income of $14 million is $25 million less favorable year-over-year, mainly due to lower net returns from company-owned life insurance.
Our effective tax rate for the quarter was 23.6%, close to our federal and state statutory rates, unlike Q3 last year when the rate was 21.9% and benefited from tax advantages related to both COLI investment gains and higher stock-based compensation.
Net income grew by 17%, while earnings per share increased by 22%, supported by the 3.6 million shares we repurchased during the quarter.
Concluding with our free cash flow on slide 19, as I mentioned, free cash flow is at a record level through the first nine months of 2021 at $2.3 billion, bolstered by very strong operating cash generation, which translates to a 102% free cash flow conversion.
Although property additions are trending slightly lower than the run rate for our $1.6 billion guidance, capital spending is never linear, and we expect fourth quarter property additions will bring us close to the $1.6 billion target.
We initially demonstrated our commitment to sustainability by appointing a Chief Sustainability Officer in 2007, the first in the industry.
Since then, our efforts to support a low-carbon supply chain have significantly accelerated.
Building on the momentum from earlier this year with the approval of our science-based targets for greenhouse gas emissions reduction and our launch of $500 million in green bonds in the second quarter, we're pleased to report another set of milestones in our sustainability journey.
In August, we released our 2021 ESG report, our 14th annual report on corporate responsibility, highlighting the transformational role sustainability is playing in our business as we further integrate sustainable practices into daily operations.
We celebrated our 500th modernized locomotive unit in partnership with Wabtec in August and announced our collaboration with Progress Rail in September on a first-of-its-kind Tier 4 locomotive prototype for yard and terminal operations.
Earlier this month, we announced our decision to purchase 100% renewable energy to power company operations in Altoona and Reading, Pennsylvania.
Our commercial and sustainability teams work closely together to provide demonstrable low-carbon solutions to a wide range of current and potential customers, offering a compelling value proposition as we shift more freight from truck to rail, simultaneously benefiting our customers, communities, and shareholders.
Before we open the call for Q&A, I'll briefly update our outlook based on the current economic environment.
As previously mentioned, we expect to achieve an operating ratio improvement of over 400 basis points for the full year compared to our adjusted 2020 result.
There's likely upside to the 12% year-over-year revenue growth, as strength in our consumer-oriented and manufacturing markets drive most of the growth.
Near-term upside in coal markets provides a boost for the remainder of the year, although coal remains challenged in the long term.
We are delivering on our financial commitments and remain focused on creating long-term sustainable value for our customers and shareholders.
Summary:
output:
qtrly railway operating revenues of $2.85 billion increased 14%.
qtrly railway operating ratio was 60.2%.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:We thank you for your participation.
Initially, I will explain the specifics of our financial performance for the third quarter of 2020.
Following that, Paul will discuss the main factors influencing our Q3 results, our expectations for the remainder of 2020, and some general thoughts on 2021.
I will then return to present our financial projections for the fourth quarter and an updated forecast for the full year 2020.
We will conclude the call by taking questions from participants.
It's worth noting that some of our discussion may involve non-GAAP financial metrics.
Let's examine our third quarter results, which showed a 21% increase in adjusted earnings per share to $0.91 and a 13% rise in adjusted EBITDA to $58 million compared to Q3 2019.
These outcomes reflect better-than-anticipated performance in worksite employee growth and pricing given the uncertain and challenging business climate, as well as benefits in our direct cost programs resulting from pandemic-related dynamics and the structure and ongoing management of these initiatives.
Regarding our growth metric, the average number of paid worksite employees in Q3 2020 grew by 1.7% sequentially from Q2 to 231,750, surpassing the upper limit of our projected range.
You may remember that employee layoffs in our client base led to a 6% reduction in paid worksite employees from the start of the pandemic in March to the lowest point in May this year.
Since then, worksite employee numbers have increased sequentially as rehires and new hires by our clients have outpaced any additional layoffs.
Furthermore, client retention in both Q2 and Q3 has stayed at our typical 99% level, and new client sales continue to add worksite employees.
Given these recent positive trends, we now anticipate paid worksite employees will return to near pre-pandemic levels by year-end.
Moving on to gross profit, it increased by 8% compared to Q3 2019.
Higher-than-expected worksite employee volume and pricing, combined with advantages in our benefit and workers' compensation programs, resulted in significantly better gross profit than anticipated.
This quarter's benefit costs included some positive adjustments from Q2, a period of highly unusual claim activity due to shutdown order impacts.
Additionally, healthcare utilization began to trend towards more normal levels in the third quarter, although not to the extent we expected.
Looking ahead, we anticipate further normalization along with the resumption of some deferred care and COVID-19 testing and treatment costs, though the extent and timing remain uncertain.
Our workers' compensation program continues to perform well due to ongoing management of safety practices and claims.
Recent favorable claims development has primarily been associated with periods before the pandemic.
Any positive impact from reduced severity of workers' compensation claims related to many of our clients' employees working from home would likely benefit our costs in future periods as this claim experience develops over time.
Regarding our pricing, we charge clients a comprehensive service fee that includes our HR services and direct cost programs.
We entered 2020 with certain pricing targets set before the pandemic began.
We continued to work towards these budgeted targets.
As you may recall, certain savings resulting from pandemic-related disruptions were negotiated with our vendors and passed on to our clients as a comprehensive service fee credit, as reflected in our Q2 financials.
Turning to operating expenses, Q3 costs included continued investment in growth, including expenses associated with a 10% increase in the average number of trained business performance advisors.
Other corporate employee headcount has remained stable over the past three quarters due to our staff's effort and effectiveness in handling increased HR service demands from our client base.
Cost savings have been achieved in other areas of the business, such as travel, training, and other G&A expenses, as we navigate the current business environment.
The 15% year-over-year increase in total Q3 operating expenses was influenced by higher stock-based compensation costs.
This increase was driven by several factors: our outperformance in paid worksite employees and earnings during the pandemic; a shift in weighting towards performance stock awards from performance cash awards for 2020 to better align employee interests with shareholders during challenging times; accelerated expense recognition for employees meeting retirement eligibility requirements under recent plan modifications; and a comparison to the prior year's quarter when earnings and related performance-based compensation were negatively impacted by high healthcare claim activity.
Operating expenses, excluding stock-based compensation and depreciation and amortization, increased by just 4.6% compared to Q3 2019.
Regarding our financial position and liquidity, it remains strong as we manage through pandemic conditions, continue investing in growth, and provide returns to shareholders.
Adjusted cash has grown from $108 million on December 31, 2019, to $213 million on September 30, while we repurchased 1.3 million shares of stock for $91 million, paid $47 million in cash dividends, and invested $69 million in capital expenditures year-to-date in 2020.
Borrowings increased by $100 million over the nine months, and $130 million remains available under our credit facility.
Today, I'll address three topics, starting with thoughts on our significant outperformance in the recent quarter.
I'll then discuss how the primary drivers of our business model responded to the pandemic, resulting in the opportunity suggested by our guidance to achieve double-digit growth in adjusted EBITDA this year.
Lastly, I'll comment on our view of these factors going forward, which will ultimately shape our outlook for 2021.
We are certainly pleased with our execution in the third quarter, which led to various factors contributing to better-than-expected results.
Our client base's resilience, supported by committed service providers and strong sales and retention, led to a notable upturn in sequential growth for our primary metric of paid worksite employees.
Internal growth in worksite employees within our existing client base surpassed our expectations, with clients rehiring furloughed staff and adding new employees earlier and more rapidly than anticipated.
As previously noted, client retention remained at its historical 99% rate, despite the challenging economic conditions facing small businesses in the current climate.
Our sales bookings since the pandemic's onset have reached about 70% of our pre-pandemic sales targets, which we consider a strong performance given the shift to virtual selling.
In the third quarter, paid worksite employees from previously secured sales reached 92% compared to the same timeframe last year, indicating ongoing demand for our offerings and effective onboarding of new clients.
A notable achievement this quarter was our successful pricing strategy for both new and renewing accounts in service fees and allocations for direct costs, including our benefit packages.
Aligning pricing with direct costs is crucial to our business model, and exceeding our goals in this area is significant as pandemic-related direct costs begin to stabilize.
We've successfully continued to expand and enhance our BPA team throughout this quarter.
We provided virtual training to over 350 BPAs in our Level 1, 2, 3, and certified Business Performance Advisor programs during this period.
Our trained BPA count grew by 10% compared to the same time last year, putting us in a strong position for our autumn sales season.
This quarter, we redirected some operational cost savings towards creating client testimonial videos and increasing advertising to support our autumn sales campaign and retention efforts.
These videos effectively captured the intended emotional impact, showcasing the value of a sophisticated HR function during a crisis.
We were able to maintain important technological development beyond addressing the numerous compliance requirements that emerged earlier this year.
We're expanding our People Analytics platform, which has been well-received by our mid-market and enterprise clients, to our emerging growth segment, just in time for our crucial renewal period.
We continue to make progress in enhancing Insperity Premier, our proprietary human capital management system, introducing a new time and attendance user interface and employing new behavioral analytics tools to guide improvements, making Premier more user-friendly and efficient for clients.
The third quarter's bottom line reflected an ideal combination of increased volume and pricing alongside reduced direct and operating costs.
Each of these factors contributed to our strong performance exceeding expectations for the quarter.
We've responded swiftly and effectively to the unusual events of 2020, meeting client needs and achieving growth and profitability beyond our initial expectations.
We've also maintained focus on long-term goals, making progress on numerous important initiatives.
With three quarters completed and our Q4 estimates in place, we can assess how our business model has performed during the pandemic.
When the pandemic began, we didn't anticipate our business model would have the potential to generate the double-digit growth in adjusted EBITDA that's reflected in our current guidance.
The pandemic's impact on our business model ranged from obvious expected negatives to completely unexpected positives.
It's worth summarizing these model-driving factors, as the pandemic is ongoing and its effects are likely to extend into 2021.
One might assume that a health-related pandemic would increase health costs. However, we've observed that rising COVID cases necessitated protecting hospital capacity and limiting elective procedures, which, combined with people's tendency to avoid hospitals, has actually led to significant short-term declines in healthcare expenses.
Long-term healthcare costs may rise due to deferred care or expenses related to COVID treatment or vaccines. So far, we haven't seen these cost increases outpace the overall trend, as other factors like telemedicine and some continued care deferral provide offsetting effects.
Furthermore, many experts, including the CDC, predict that current COVID precautions could significantly reduce flu incidence this year.
An obvious negative impact of the pandemic-related lockdowns was the economic effect on small and medium-sized businesses, which affected us through layoffs in our client base.
We experienced a roughly 6% decrease in paid worksite employees over two months, followed by a steady four-month recovery, supported by fiscal stimulus and easing restrictions.
In hindsight, the CARES Act, particularly the Paycheck Protection Program, was effective in mitigating some layoffs. We believe our swift and effective support in helping clients leverage these programs contributed to fewer layoffs and a quicker recovery.
The shutdown effects also highlighted a specific advantage of our business model: our client selection strategy.
Our risk-based client selection process results in a very small percentage of our client base being in industries most affected by the pandemic and shutdowns, such as entertainment, hospitality, travel, and restaurants.
Another surprising outcome, partly due to our client selection strategy, has been the minimal number of business closures within our client base.
Although we anticipated an increase, our strategy of targeting top-performing small and mid-sized businesses across diverse industries provided some insulation from this factor, as we saw no significant rise in business failures.
Another dramatic effect we experienced was the increased workload, as many pandemic-related issues fell to HR departments.
As mentioned previously, client interactions increased by 300%, and the average duration of these interactions doubled.
The workload has quintupled, and while it has decreased somewhat, it remains high.
Conversely, lockdowns resulted in remote work arrangements.
For us, this led to enhanced efficiency, with our committed employees performing exceptionally well in meeting the increased demand for our offerings.
Our observations suggest that remote work is suitable for routine tasks.
Nevertheless, creativity and teamwork might be negatively impacted in the long run.
A combination of remote and office-based work may provide the best balance of productivity, efficiency, and innovation in the future.
An additional benefit of our model during lockdowns and widespread remote work among our clients is a significant reduction in the frequency of workers' compensation claims.
This reduction has not yet been reflected in our expenses, but should provide some benefits in future periods.
However, these reduced expenses may be counterbalanced by COVID-related claims that may be covered by workers' compensation in certain states.
I was pleasantly surprised by our ability to effectively sell our comprehensive and complex service offerings in a virtual environment.
We now understand the range of sales efficiency under these circumstances.
As we reintroduce face-to-face meetings, we may see a long-term increase in efficiency.
A final observation is our success in retaining clients during the pandemic, even as financial considerations weighed heavily on our client base.
Our services proved indispensable, and clients maintained our premium offerings despite the need for budget cuts.
Now that we better understand the factors influencing our business model during a pandemic, what are the implications for 2021?
Firstly, planning will depend on these factors and drivers, which are likely to fluctuate based on the pandemic's status.
We will closely monitor these new inputs and finalize our budget later than usual to incorporate the most recent information.
Making early estimates is impractical given the numerous possibilities, particularly when considering the pandemic's timing and severity or potential mitigating actions.
For instance, COVID cases are currently increasing, but one or more vaccines may be available by 2021, or an anticipated economic downturn from additional lockdowns may occur.
Furthermore, small businesses may receive support from additional fiscal stimulus.
We have discovered that our business model has many moving parts and offsetting factors in this environment.
If the pandemic worsens, our direct costs may be lower than historical trends, as experienced this year, but growth may suffer.
Conversely, if the pandemic is mitigated or controlled, direct costs may rise, but growth may accelerate as a counterbalance.
What I can say with confidence today is that we have a remarkable organization with the necessary curiosity and intelligence to provide the flexibility and capability to navigate a crisis and achieve impressive results for shareholders, clients, and other stakeholders.
This year, we have demonstrated our competence and level of client care in executing matters within our control, along with inspiring ingenuity and resourcefulness in responding to unexpected events.
We are certainly pleased with our 2020 results to date and our outlook for the remainder of the year, and we look ahead with confidence in the future, regardless of what we face next year.
I will now hand the call back to Doug.
I will now provide our guidance for the fourth quarter and an update for the full year of 2020.
As you know, uncertainty persists regarding the pandemic's duration and conditions, as well as the economic trajectory.
The current political climate and the timing and details of any further government aid add to this uncertainty.
We have considered these factors in our financial guidance for the remainder of 2020 and will take them into account in our budgeting process for the upcoming year.
We typically do not offer formal guidance for the upcoming year at this time, so we will consider any further developments in these areas and the outcome of our year-end selling and renewal season when providing 2021 guidance in our next earnings call.
Based on Paul's recent comments, we continue to anticipate sequential worksite employee growth for the remainder of 2020.
For the fourth quarter, we project average paid worksite employees to range from 236,500 to 238,500, a sequential increase of 2% to 3% over Q3 of 2020.
This translates to an expected decrease in average paid worksite employees of only 1% for the full year 2020, despite significant challenges for small businesses caused by the pandemic and its economic impact.
With an improved outlook for Q4 worksite employee growth, our current pricing strength, and a range of expectations in our direct cost programs, particularly our benefits program, we now forecast Q4 adjusted EBITDA of $21 million to $30 million and adjusted earnings per share of $0.20 to $0.38.
Combined with our Q3 outperformance, we are raising our full year 2020 earnings guidance and now predict adjusted EBITDA of $271 million to $281 million, an increase of 8% to 12% compared to 2019.
For full year 2020 adjusted EPS, we now forecast a range of $4.35 to $4.53, up from our previous guidance of $3.67 to $4.04.
Summary:
output:
q3 adjusted earnings per share $0.91.
share repurchase authorization expanded by one million shares.
sees fy adjusted earnings per share $4.35 â $4.53.
sees fy adjusted ebitda $271 million â $281 million.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:These are founded on managerial predictions, which may or may not come to fruition.
Furthermore, some of our statements today refer to non-GAAP adjusted metrics.
We anticipate submitting our 10-K document later today.
As stated, this conference call is being recorded and will be accessible on our website after the event.
Please be aware that these calls are intended for financial professionals.
Indeed, years pass by, but 2020 was a year unlike any other, as we all recognize.
The global health crisis impacted numerous aspects of our everyday lives, and I'm pleased with how our staff united to deliver exceptional service to our clients.
We effectively managed various obstacles while still meeting our primary financial and operational objectives.
Our reported earnings from ongoing operations were $2.30 per share for the year 2020.
This was primarily due to robust performance in the gas utility sector and a significant contribution from our newly established water utility division.
In terms of gas operations, our field teams successfully handled various challenges, including wildfires, restoring service in multiple towns during the Christmas period, and navigating issues related to COVID-19 and social unrest.
Just a short while ago, our employees in the natural gas system once again demonstrated their capability by providing reliable service during an extreme weather event.
Our storage facilities and overall hedging strategies helped to reduce the amount of gas purchased on the spot market and mitigated the impact on our customers' bills.
This was particularly crucial as prices spiked across the nation due to the widespread cold weather.
Our financial position remains robust with sufficient liquidity.
In 2020, we also implemented one of the largest capital investment programs in the company's history, aimed at enhancing reliability.
We continue to operate one of the most advanced and efficient systems in the country, with no cast iron or bare steel components.
In 2020, we invested over $270 million in our natural gas infrastructure.
From an economic standpoint, 2020 was truly extraordinary.
Before the pandemic, we had a fundamentally sound and sustainably growing economy with record-low unemployment rates both nationally and in our service areas.
We continue to observe economic recovery and steady growth in several key sectors.
Portland's unemployment rate was 6.1% in December, essentially matching the national rate, down from a peak of 14.9% in April.
Single-family housing activity remains robust.
In the Portland metropolitan area, home sales increased by 8.3% compared to 2019, with price growth of approximately 12%.
New single-family building permits issued last year were up 4% compared to 2019 levels.
At Northwest Natural, we continue to experience good customer growth.
New construction and conversions resulted in connecting over 13,000 meters during the 12 months ending December 31.
Consequently, our overall customer growth rate was 1.5% for the same period, driven by strong single-family home construction, partially offset by the loss of some commercial customers due to the pandemic.
The distribution of vaccines is expected to ease pandemic-related restrictions and allow businesses to reopen.
Nevertheless, we recognize that these are challenging times for some customers, and we have worked closely with commissions, staff, and stakeholders to determine the best approach for returning to normal business practices.
We have agreed on timelines for resuming collection processes and continue to evaluate what makes sense for customers given the economic conditions, while also providing financial assistance and payment plans to vulnerable customers.
Enhancing the system includes a bill forgiveness program and collaborating with the Oregon Legislature to secure additional funding for bill relief.
Through various programs and agencies, we have provided over $4 million to more than 10,000 households to help them pay their bills and stay warm during the last heating season.
We also donated approximately $1 million to nonprofits in our communities and initiated a special COVID-19 employee giving campaign.
For Oregon, previously approved new rates became effective on November 1 last year.
Gas bills continue to remain low.
Our customers are currently paying about 40% less for their bills than they did 15 years ago.
Additionally, in June, we returned a record $17 million in storage bill credits to Oregon gas customers.
Safety, reliability, and affordability make natural gas a preferred fuel source.
According to a study conducted in December 2020, eight out of ten homeowners in our service territory prefer natural gas.
There is strong recognition that natural gas is affordable, efficient, and preferable to electricity for heating and cooking.
In fact, over 80% of respondents stated they would pay $50,000 more for a home with gas amenities compared to an all-electric home.
Customers also demonstrated their appreciation by ranking Northwest Natural second among large utilities in the West in the 2020 JD Power residential customer satisfaction survey.
Lastly, our Board approved a dividend increase in the fourth quarter of 2020, marking the 65th consecutive year of annual dividend increases.
We are proud to provide returns to shareholders and be one of only three companies on the NYSE with such a long record.
I will start by discussing the financial impacts of COVID-19 and the highlights of the fourth quarter and full year 2020 results, then conclude with guidance for 2021.
In 2020, our utility commissions approved COVID deferrals and term sheets outlining the types of revenues and costs that may be recovered.
These include personal protective equipment, bad debt expense, financing costs associated with additional liquidity, and certain lost revenues.
Cost reductions related to decreased travel and entertainment expenses should be offset against the deferral
The determination of prudency review and recovery for deferral accounts will be made in upcoming proceedings
Our business model is strong, but we are seeing some financial effects due to the pandemic
We experienced approximately $10 million in pre-tax incremental costs and reduced revenues through December 31 as a result of COVID-19
$4.8 million of this amount was deferred to regulatory accounts
We will recognize $1.3 million in late fee revenue in a future period when we begin recovering foregone fees through rates, as normal collection processes were suspended
The remaining $3.8 million that cannot be recovered via rates is mainly due to reduced natural gas utility margin from customers who ended service and slightly lower usage from non-decoupled customers
We implemented temporary cost-saving measures to further mitigate the pandemic's financial impact, resulting in about $3.5 million in savings for 2020
The total profit and loss impact of COVID-19 in 2020 was $1.6 million
Let's examine our detailed financial results
I will explain earnings drivers on an after-tax basis using the 26.5% statutory tax rate
Year-to-date earnings per share comparisons reflect the June 2019 issuance of 1.4 million shares to fund investment in our gas and water utilities
Northwest Natural's earnings are seasonal, with most revenues and earnings generated during the winter heating season in the first and fourth quarters
For the quarter, we reported $45.8 million or $1.50 per share in net income from continuing operations, compared to $38.3 million or $1.26 per share for the same period in 2019
The gas utility saw a $0.19 per share increase related to new Oregon rates starting November 1, 2020, partially offset by higher depreciation and general tax expense and COVID-19 impacts
Our other businesses contributed an additional $0.05 per share from newly acquired water assets in Washington and Texas and reduced holding company expenses
Gas distribution segment utility margin increased by $11.5 million due to new Oregon rates and customer growth, partially offset by COVID-19 effects
Utility O&M decreased by $500,000 in the quarter, reflecting cost-saving efforts
I'm proud of our employees' hard work and dedication, which allowed us to achieve this while maintaining exceptional service
Depreciation expense and general taxes increased by $2.9 million due to ongoing system investments
For the full year 2020, we reported $70.3 million or $2.30 per share in net income from continuing operations, compared to $65.3 million or $2.19 per share in 2019
The 2019 results included a $0.22 per share regulatory disallowance related to an Oregon Commission order on tax reform and pension expense
Excluding that disallowance, adjusted non-GAAP earnings per share from continuing operations was $2.41 for 2019
The $0.11 per share decline is primarily due to year-over-year expense growth, COVID-19 effects, and the positive impact of weather and pipeline constraints on 2019 results
In the gas distribution segment, utility margin increased by $11.3 million
Higher customer rates in Oregon and Washington, customer growth, and revenues from the Northwest expansion project contributed an additional $21.5 million
This was offset by lower entitlement and curtailment fees related to 2019 pipeline constraints and warmer weather in the first quarter of 2020 compared to 2019, which collectively reduced margin by $4.5 million
Utility margin also declined by $1 million due to lower late fee revenues as we suspended normal collection processes
The remaining $5.2 million decline in utility margin is a result of the 2019 Oregon order
With the exception of the first quarter pension disallowance, this order has no impact on net income as offsetting adjustments were recognized through expenses and income taxes
Utility O&M and other expenses declined by $5.4 million
This decrease is associated with the Oregon order which resulted in $14 million of additional expense in the first quarter of 2019
This was offset by a $6 million increase in underlying O&M related to higher compensation costs, contractor and professional service expenses, and moving costs
This was partially offset by the management-driven cost savings measures mentioned earlier
Pension expenses, included in other expense, increased by $2.8 million, but this expense is now recovered in rates
We have invested in our gas system at historically high levels over the past few years
As a result, depreciation expense and general taxes increased by $10.2 million
Utility segment tax expense in 2019 included a $5.9 million benefit related to the implementation of the Oregon order, with no significant effect on net income
Net income from our other businesses increased by $2.2 million due to higher earnings from wastewater, water and wastewater utilities and lower holding company expenses, partially offset by lower asset management revenues
Regarding capital expenditures, we invested $294 million into the business, with $273 million for gas utility capital expenditures and $38 million for water acquisitions
Our balance sheet remains strong with sufficient liquidity
Concerning the ongoing effects of COVID-19, about 97% of our commercial and industrial customers are up to date with their bills
However, some commercial customers have gone out of business and shut off their meters due to negative impacts
We will continue to closely monitor usage levels and commercial customer losses
We will also maintain disciplined cost management to mitigate these circumstances
Let's move on to our 2021 financial guidance
Capital expenditures for gas utilities this year are anticipated to range from $280 million to $320 million, encompassing major projects for system enhancement, renovating resource centers across the service area, and upgrading technology.
The company has released its 2021 earnings forecast, projecting between $2.40 and $2.60 per share.
The forecast assumes ongoing customer expansion, typical weather patterns, and no major shifts in current regulatory policies, mechanisms, outcomes, laws, legislation, or regulations.
Despite the challenges of the previous year, our priorities remain unchanged: delivering exceptional customer service, maximizing returns from our robust and expanding regulated natural gas utility, and diversifying our portfolio through investments in the water sector.
We made strides in our diversification efforts by divesting two investments that were no longer central to our strategy.
We sold our stake in the Trail West pipeline project in August, and in December, we finalized the sale of the Gill Ranch storage facility in California.
The funds from these sales are expected to be reinvested in our gas and water operations.
The events of the past year reaffirmed our decision to establish a water and wastewater utility platform and showcased the value we can bring to this sector.
Our water and wastewater utilities experienced organic customer growth of nearly 3%, specifically 2.8%, in the 12 months ending December 31, 2020.
We also enhanced infrastructure and submitted our first general rate case for our water utility.
Although the COVID-19 pandemic temporarily slowed acquisition activity, we still managed to add a water and wastewater utility in Washington to our portfolio and made our initial acquisition in Texas.
We continued to make minor acquisitions within our existing service area while exploring new growth opportunities.
I remain enthusiastic about the investment potential in this business.
Another crucial aspect of our strategy involves actively pursuing a renewable future and working to reduce carbon emissions in our gas utility system.
Before delving into our approach, it's crucial to understand our starting point.
Northwest Natural serves approximately 74% of residential square footage in our service area and fulfills 90% of our space and water heating customers' energy needs on the coldest days, yet the emissions from this usage account for only 6% of Oregon's total greenhouse gas emissions.
In the Northwest, gas and electric systems experience concurrent peaks in winter.
The gas system delivers about twice as much energy during peak times compared to the electric system, with even more capacity available.
This advantage positions us well to drive decarbonization in the region while ensuring reliability and affordability.
Recent events have underscored the critical importance of reliability during winter months.
Allow me to outline three components of our vision for carbon neutrality by 2050.
Firstly, we plan to continue pursuing aggressive energy efficiency measures to reduce energy consumption.
Over the past four decades, the number of residential natural gas customers in the US has grown by almost 90%, but demand has remained stable, demonstrating the industry's commitment to promoting efficiency.
Today, our residential customers use half the amount of natural gas they did in 1970, despite consistent growth in average home sizes and more appliances per household.
Secondly, we're aiming to incorporate renewable natural gas from various waste streams into our system.
The technical potential for RNG supply in Oregon alone is estimated at nearly 50 billion cubic feet, approximately equivalent to all residential gas consumption in our state.
Nationally, early estimates indicate about 14 trillion cubic feet of technical potential, or roughly 88% of total throughput.
There's clearly vast technical potential, and now we need to collectively focus on bringing as much as possible to market economically.
We also see potential for adding hydrogen to the pipeline.
We believe there are three applications for hydrogen from the power-to-gas process: blended, methanated, and dedicated hydrogen systems.
We also envision the possibility of blue hydrogen, produced from natural gas and paired with carbon capture, utilization, and storage, playing a role in the US gas system.
We're closely monitoring efforts in Europe, Canada, and Australia in this area.
In 2019, Northwest Natural sent a technical team to Europe to meet with government agencies, think tanks, and gas companies.
We gained valuable insights about new technologies, projects, and policies.
It was evident that Europe was several years ahead of the US in considering gas network systems and the role of green molecules in the energy transition we're all facing.
They recognize that existing gas infrastructure is a significant advantage, with storage being a prime example.
Natural gas infrastructure is designed to provide long-duration energy storage that doesn't degrade.
Existing facilities can store RNG and methanated renewable hydrogen today.
When considering decarbonization strategies across the energy sector, the pre-existing infrastructure and its cost advantages are crucial factors.
For instance, Northwest Natural currently has 20 billion cubic feet of underground storage.
This is equivalent to storing about 6 million megawatt hours of renewables.
At current costs, that would be comparable to a $2 trillion lithium battery.
This is where policy plays a key role in helping us leverage our existing infrastructure in new ways and accelerate our region's decarbonization efforts.
Oregon has implemented Senate Bill 98, groundbreaking renewable natural gas legislation that sets 30-year targets for gas utilities to procure RNG and renewable hydrogen for customers.
We recently announced our first RNG investment under this bill and are actively working on more.
Northwest Natural has begun hydrogen blending tests at our training facility and is collaborating with Eugene Water And Electric Board in Oregon to propose a project that would include methanated hydrogen for our system.
We're excited about these initial steps and are committed to pursuing solutions that incorporate system resilience as part of the energy transition.
Now, more than ever, we recognize the critical role our gas infrastructure plays in advancing our collective climate goals, while ensuring energy system diversification and reliability for the communities we serve.
Summary:
output:
q4 earnings per share $1.50 from continuing operations.
initiated 2021 earnings guidance in range of $2.40 to $2.60 per share.
nw natural capital expenditures for 2021 are expected to be in range of $280 million to $320 million.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:These are based on management's projections, which may or may not come to fruition.
We anticipate submitting our 10-K form later today.
This conference call is being recorded and will be accessible on our website after it concludes.
Please be aware that these calls are intended for financial professionals.
Our company experienced a successful 2021, and we're continuing to enhance our core strengths in our gas and water utilities division, while also launching a competitive renewable natural gas venture.
We reported a net income of $2.56 per share for 2021, representing an 11% increase compared to the $2.30 per share net income from continuing operations in 2020.
The natural gas utility's results were driven by new rates in Oregon and steady customer growth, while our interstate storage business saw increased revenues.
This financial growth is the result of years of effort, a strong focus on our long-term strategy, and evidence that steady progress yields positive outcomes.
We're observing positive trends in our local Portland Metro Area economy.
The unemployment rate in this region dropped to 3.9% in December 2021, down from 7.3% the previous year.
The single-family housing market continues to show significant strength.
In 2021, home sales increased by 10% compared to 2020, with average sale prices rising by 16%.
New single-family building permits issued increased by 12%, while multifamily permits in Oregon rose by 37% compared to the previous year.
Our region experienced robust construction and development activity.
This resulted in over 11,000 new customers connecting to our gas network in 2021, representing a growth rate of 1.5%.
Our water and wastewater utilities also experienced continued growth.
Strong residential construction, primarily in Idaho and Texas, led to a 3% organic customer growth rate.
We also completed four acquisitions in 2021.
Most significantly, we acquired a stake in Oregon's largest privately-owned water company.
The combination of organic growth and acquisitions increased our water utility connections by nearly 30% last year.
On November 1, updated rates for gas utility customers took effect for the current heating season.
This included the impact of the general rate case we concluded in Washington State.
Despite these increases, our customers are still paying nearly 30% less for their natural gas today than they did 15 years ago.
This reflects decreased commodity costs, energy efficiency efforts, prudent expense management, and smart investments in gas storage assets that continue to benefit customers.
As a result, natural gas maintains its position as the preferred fuel choice.
In addition to its performance benefits, natural gas offers up to a 60% price advantage over electric or oil options for the typical home we serve.
Our customers are crucial to Northwest Natural's success.
I'm delighted that Northwest Natural ranked second best among large natural gas utilities in the J.D. Power Residential Customer Satisfaction Study.
This continues our nearly 20-year tradition of outstanding results.
I'm proud of all our employees who deliver this exceptional service every day.
As you know, growth isn't always linear, and some years focus on initiatives that set the stage for future growth.
2022 is such a year for us.
To that end, 2021 and 2022 include substantial capital expenditure plans related to critical spending on safety and reliability, technology system upgrades, and cybersecurity investments.
To recover these long-planned project costs, we took the necessary step at the end of 2021 and filed a rate case.
The request includes a revenue requirement increase of $73.5 million based on a 50-50 capital structure, a 9.5% return on equity, and a cost of capital of about 6.7%.
We filed for an increase in average rate base of $294 million since the last rate case.
The Oregon Commission and stakeholders have 10 months to review the case, and we expect new rates to take effect on November 1.
Simultaneously, we continue to make progress under the landmark Oregon Senate Bill 98 legislation, which supports renewable energy procurement and investment by natural gas utilities.
I'm pleased to report that we signed an agreement with Archaea to procure renewable natural gas on behalf of our customers in the fourth quarter of 2021.
Northwest Natural also recently finished commissioning the first of four renewable natural gas projects with Tyson Foods and BioCarbN.
Construction on our second facility began this month, with commissioning planned for early 2023.
To date, we've signed agreements with options to purchase or develop renewable natural gas on behalf of our customers, totaling about 3% of Northwest Natural's current annual sales volume in Oregon.
We've made significant progress in under two years, which fills me with pride.
Currently, wind and solar comprise approximately 11% of our nation's total electricity supply after years of investment.
We plan to continue taking important measures to increase our renewable energy supply, as we know our customers desire a decarbonized system and clean energy future.
A recent poll by an independent research firm revealed that 77% of voters in Oregon and Southwest Washington want access to all energy types, including renewables, hydro, wind, solar, and renewable natural gas for a balanced, low-carbon future.
About 78% of voters appreciate the natural gas system's crucial role in reducing emissions while maintaining affordability, reliability, and resilience as top priorities.
Nearly 80% of property owners endorse local government initiatives to promote natural gas usage.
Our success across all business areas enabled our board to raise our dividend for the 66th year in a row.
The current annual indicated dividend rate stands at $1.93 per share.
We take pride in providing returns to our shareholders and being one of only three NYSE-listed companies with such a track record.
I'll start by highlighting our fourth quarter and full year 2021 results, then provide guidance for 2022.
I'll explain earnings drivers on an after-tax basis using the 26.5% statutory tax rate.
Remember that Northwest Natural's earnings are seasonal, with most revenues and earnings generated during the winter heating months in the first and fourth quarters.
We reported a net income of $40.5 million or $1.32 per share for the quarter, compared to $45.8 million or $1.50 from continuing operations in the same period of 2020.
The decrease in net income compared to last year was primarily due to our gas utility's performance, which saw a $0.15 per share decline in earnings.
Other businesses experienced a $0.03 per share decrease in earnings, mainly due to higher business development costs.
The gas utility's lower earnings were primarily attributed to increased operations and maintenance and depreciation expenses, partially offset by new rates in Oregon and Washington.
The gas distribution segment's utility margin rose by $4.5 million due to new rates and customer growth.
Utility O&M increased by $5.7 million, reflecting higher expenses for payroll and benefits, contractor and professional services, and IT upgrades.
Utility depreciation and general taxes increased by $1.6 million due to higher property, plant, and equipment investments in our system.
For the full year 2021, we reported a net income of $78.7 million or $2.56 per share, compared to $70.3 million or $2.30 per share from continuing operations in 2020.
This $0.26 per share increase was driven by both the gas utility, which contributed an additional $0.16, and our other businesses, which added $0.10 per share.
The gas utility's higher earnings were primarily due to new rates in Oregon and Washington, along with customer growth.
Utility margin increased by $30.7 million, with higher customer rates and growth contributing $30.9 million.
This was partially offset by a loss from the gas cost incentive sharing mechanism due to purchasing higher-priced gas during the February 2021 cold weather event.
Utility O&M increased by $14.2 million, driven by higher employee compensation and benefit costs, lease expenses for our new operations and headquarters building, and increased costs related to IT system upgrades.
Depreciation and general taxes rose by $9 million.
Net income from our other businesses increased by $3 million, largely due to higher asset management revenues from the February cold weather event.
Cash provided by operating activities in 2021 was $160 million, a $15 million increase compared to the previous year.
We invested $300 million into the business, primarily for gas utility capital expenditures.
Our balance sheet remains strong with ample liquidity.
Regarding 2022 financial guidance, gas utility capital expenditures are expected to range from $310 million to $350 million, including significant projects related to system reinforcement and technology upgrades.
These capital investments, along with higher forecasted expenses for technology and payroll, supported our decision to file the Oregon rate case with rates effective in November this year.
In line with these business drivers, we initiated 2022 earnings guidance today for net income ranging from $2.45 to $2.65 per share.
This guidance assumes continued customer growth, average weather conditions, and no significant changes in prevailing regulatory policies, mechanisms, outcomes, or legislation and regulations.
We continue to see solid long-term growth in our natural gas and water utilities.
As discussed last quarter, we've launched our competitive renewable natural gas business.
As a result, we're now targeting a long-term earnings-per-share growth rate of 4% to 6% from 2022 to 2027.
We made significant progress on our business strategy this past year.
Our focus moving forward is clear: maximizing returns from our strong and growing regulated gas utility and positioning our business for incremental long-term growth by investing in water utilities and the competitive renewable natural gas business.
We'll maintain our focus on the future, making sound investments today to ensure sustainable growth for tomorrow.
To that end, we released our Destination Zero scenario report for the gas facility in November last year.
This report illustrates different possible scenarios to transform into a carbon-neutral energy provider by 2050.
Kim Heiting, our senior VP of operations, will soon provide details about this work.
We believe a diverse energy system offers greater affordability, reliability, and resilience.
Recent events in Texas and California demonstrate the advantages of having dual energy systems.
The electric and gas networks are interdependent in serving communities, each offering unique benefits.
These systems complement each other, with overhead wires delivering renewable electricity and underground pipes transporting renewable gases.
This diversity helps address various energy needs and will become more crucial as climate change brings increased weather risks.
Now, I'll hand it over to Kim for more information on the Destination Zero analysis.
Our Destination Zero study builds upon our 2016 customer carbon savings goal and the 2019 E3 study on Paris Climate Accord targets for 2050.
We've since enhanced our carbon modeling capabilities and considered new developments to refine our system's potential.
This new study examined multiple scenarios using existing technologies, some more advanced in Europe, all of which we're actively pursuing or evaluating.
We modeled three scenarios using supply and demand-side strategies to achieve carbon neutrality for our sales customers' energy use and future growth.
These scenarios incorporate varying levels of renewable natural gas, clean hydrogen, synthetic gas, improved energy efficiency, gas heat pumps, hybrid heating systems, and limited offsets and carbon capture.
We used different assumptions to test our ability to achieve carbon neutrality under various conditions and future technology adoption rates.
The most probable scenario will likely combine efficiency improvements and reduced carbon intensity in our energy delivery.
All scenarios depend on supportive policies to lower costs for innovations like renewable or clean hydrogen.
Northwest Natural and our industry are focusing on promoting such policy support.
While our analysis continues to evolve, we maintain our vision of a transformed gas system distributing renewable molecules, enabling our region to achieve its climate goals reliably, resiliently, and affordably.
I'm proud of our team's efforts, and under Kim's leadership, we're well-positioned.
This is likely one of the first comprehensive decarbonization scenario reports by a gas utility, serving as a crucial planning tool for continued progress.
In addition to transitioning our gas utility to a renewable future, we launched a competitive renewable natural gas strategy last year, forming Northwest Natural Renewables, a new non-regulated subsidiary.
This new organization demonstrates our commitment to leading the energy transition and providing renewable natural gas to various sectors.
We aim to offer cost-effective decarbonization solutions using existing waste streams and renewable energy resources.
We're at the beginning of a historic energy system transformation and expect continued growth in demand for renewable fuels.
We anticipate a significant increase in renewable natural gas demand to meet voluntary and compliance-driven targets set by states and utilities.
We see promising investment potential in RNG, aligning with our core competencies and sustainability efforts.
We're an attractive partner for developers and feedstock owners seeking a reliable, long-term strategic collaboration.
Most RNG projects are appropriately sized for us to effectively manage and provide meaningful growth and cash flow.
We've already taken initial steps with a 20-year RNG supply agreement and a $50 million investment.
I'm pleased to announce that Mike Kotyk joined our team in late January to lead our competitive RNG efforts, bringing over 25 years of sector experience.
We're prepared and resourced to pursue these opportunities.
We'll remain disciplined and focused as we evaluate additional RNG investments to support the energy transition and enhance company earnings and cash flow growth.
Regarding our water utility business, we've solidified our strategy and quintupled our customer base through nearly 20 acquisitions across four states since our initial transaction four years ago.
We've signed purchase agreements that will more than double our total connections.
We've also signed our largest acquisition to date, acquiring Far West Water and wastewater utilities in Yuma, Arizona, serving about 25,000 customers.
We're pleased to expand into our fifth state in a fast-growing region.
The acquisition, pending regulatory approval, is expected to close in Q4 this year and be earnings-accretive after the first full year of operations.
We recently announced agreements to acquire two water utilities near our existing Texas systems.
Strong relationships with regulators are crucial in the water utility business, and we've received support for industry consolidation and investment recovery.
We're excited about this business's investment potential and anticipate more announcements soon.
In conclusion, our company is financially strong, and opportunities in renewables and water sectors have allowed us to increase our long-term earnings-per-share growth rate to 4-6%.
We'll continue pursuing sustainable growth on your behalf.
Summary:
output: q4 earnings per share $2.56.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Go to Page 3.
Similar to other financial institutions, we encountered several pandemic-related obstacles in Q2.
At OFG, we also dealt with the aftermath of January's earthquakes and the ongoing integration of Scotiabank while facing the COVID-19 crisis.
This was undoubtedly a significant challenge.
Through swift and proactive measures, we achieved outstanding outcomes for our clients, communities, and staff, continuing to assist them in improving their financial prospects.
In March, authorities in Puerto Rico and the US Virgin Islands ordered the closure of businesses and restricted personal activities.
Limitations were relaxed towards the end of May.
However, recent increases in COVID-19 cases have prompted Puerto Rico to reimpose some restrictions.
The Federal Reserve reduced interest rates by 150 basis points in March, following a 75 basis point cut in the latter half of 2019.
Our dedication and readiness allowed us to effectively handle these obstacles easily, quickly, and efficiently, as we say at OFG.
All our locations operated safely throughout the quarter, supported by our technological infrastructure.
Our fully-equipped ATMs and ITMs, smartphone application, and internet bill payment services enabled contactless routine transactions.
Web and mobile appointment booking facilitated COVID-safe customer meetings at branch locations.
We implemented a fully digital, user-friendly application and fund distribution process for PPP loans.
Approximately half of our workforce continues to work remotely.
We also introduced comprehensive new safety measures for our on-site customers and employees.
We continued to offer additional benefits to our staff, such as free on-site COVID testing, daily online health check-ins, and incentives.
The outcomes are evident.
We delivered exceptional customer service, safety, and expertise across all channels.
Second quarter loan originations exceeded $500 million.
Customer deposits grew by $760 million.
Our online loan deferment tool and call centers processed relief for over 44,000 retail clients.
We decreased higher-cost wholesale funding, maintained a robust net interest margin, and continued to strengthen liquidity and capital.
We secured $100,000 in Federal Home Loan Bank of New York grants to assist local non-profits and small businesses in Puerto Rico and the US Virgin Islands.
Proceed to Page 4.
We've observed strong technology adoption trends among our retail and business clients since the start of the year, particularly since March.
Online bill pay registrations increased by 12% as of March and 24% as of June.
Mobile banking users increased by 17% from the beginning of Q1 to the end of Q2.
The number of remote deposit capture users rose by 68% since the end of March.
Another success for us was scheduling over 18,000 COVID-safe appointments with our customers through our online and mobile platform during Q2.
We are delighted to observe these trends.
Technology is a fundamental component of our overall corporate strategy.
We are exploring fresh and innovative approaches to utilize it for the benefit of our clientele.
Kindly refer to Page 5.
Regarding our SBA PPP initiative, we are consistently surpassing our market share in Puerto Rico.
We issued a total of $286 million in additional loans.
This allowed us to assist over 4,000 small enterprises in preserving more than 50,000 jobs.
It also facilitated our acquisition of new accounts within this strategically crucial customer segment.
We were capable of distributing these funds electronically within five days of application acceptance.
This exemplifies our capacity to swiftly adapt to changing circumstances, benefiting both existing and new customers, as well as the communities we serve.
Let's examine our results on Page 6.
We announced earnings of $0.39 per share, and $0.37 on a non-GAAP basis.
Total core revenues amounted to $128 million.
This was largely attributed to a substantial increase in interest-earning assets, mainly loans and cash.
This was partially counterbalanced by a decline in yield due to significantly reduced rates on cash and lower yields on variable-rate commercial loans.
Furthermore, we have reduced investment security balances.
Consequently, we produced net interest income of $105 million with a net interest margin of 4.78%.
Banking and wealth management revenues totaled $23 million.
Non-interest expenses were $86 million, primarily due to the incorporation of the Scotiabank acquisition.
The second quarter results encompassed several items.
$9.5 million in revenues from Scotia Bank interest recoveries and bargain purchase gain.
We allocated an additional $5 million in provision for the pandemic.
Within non-interest expenses, we incurred $5 million in merger and restructuring charges and COVID-related operating costs.
Please proceed to Page 7.
The outcome of these results is that we're increasing tangible book value, and our return on assets and return on equity continued to improve sequentially from the fourth quarter.
Kindly turn to Page 8 for operational highlights.
Average loan balances grew 52% year-over-year and 2% quarter-over-quarter.
Average core deposits, excluding brokered, increased 76% year-over-year and 5% quarter-over-quarter.
Loan generation was robust.
Enhanced production from PPP and other commercial loans was partially offset by reduced production in our retail categories, primarily due to the economic shutdown.
We concluded the quarter with strong momentum and promising pipelines in the mortgages and auto businesses.
Loan yield at 6.97% remained relatively stable despite recent Federal Reserve cuts.
The cost of core deposits decreased by 4 basis points year-over-year.
Net interest margin declined to 4.78%.
Refer to Page 9 for an assessment of credit quality.
The rates of net charge-offs and non-performing loans decreased both annually and quarterly, reflecting loan repayments and deferral effects.
The provision for credit losses remained steady at $18 million compared to the previous year.
It's worth mentioning that last year's provision included an additional $9 million for loans moved to held-for-sale status.
Please review our loan deferrals on Page 10.
In response to economic disruptions caused by COVID-19, we implemented various loan payment deferral programs lasting from one to four months.
We've enhanced this initiative by swiftly developing innovative, industry-leading digital tools to assist consumers in applying for individual forbearance.
Our digital loan deferral platform and call centers provided relief to over 44,000 retail clients.
In total, approximately $1.4 billion or 32% of our retail loans are currently deferred.
The frequency of retail deferral requests has significantly decreased.
Additionally, about $685 million or 26% of our commercial loans are on deferral.
Please refer to Page 11.
The allowance for loan and lease losses rose by $70 million year-over-year to $233 million.
We've nearly doubled our reserve levels since December 31, 2019.
Compared to March 31, 2020, the allowance grew by $2 million.
Excluding SBA-guaranteed PPP loans, the second quarter 2020 allowance was 3.49% of loans, an increase of 8 basis points from the first quarter.
Please examine Page 12.
Our capital position is robust.
As shown on the slide, our CET capital ratio of 12.03% has increased by 112 basis points since last year.
Kindly turn to Page 13.
Despite ongoing uncertainties regarding COVID and the economy, we maintain a strong financial position, ready to support our customers during these challenging times.
Once we overcome this situation, Puerto Rico is poised to benefit greatly from COVID stimulus and remaining undistributed funds from Maria and earthquake-related stimulus programs.
At OFG, we believe our performance and track record demonstrate our ability to swiftly respond and adapt to changing economic conditions.
During the second quarter, we continued to build momentum in our core businesses and developed a promising pipeline of new loans.
From liquidity, capital, and balance sheet perspectives, we are well-positioned both financially and strategically.
Our future agenda is clear.
We aim to complete the integration of former Scotiabank operations by the end of this year.
Simultaneously, we must realize the full benefits of the acquisition by the end of 2021.
We also plan to continue investing in the future to further streamline our operations and enhance our customer service capabilities.
Ultimately, we intend to play a significant role in the recovery of Puerto Rico and the US Virgin Islands.
Crises bring out the best in people, inspiring them to help others.
Our team demonstrates this sense of purpose every day.
We will now open the call for the Q&A session.
Summary:
output:

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:During today's call, we'll address certain non-GAAP metrics when discussing Omnicom's performance.
John will provide an overview of our business, followed by Phil's review of our quarterly financial results.
