We're delighted to announce continued year-over-year double-digit growth in our key financial metrics for the third quarter, driven by strong top-line performance.
Our impressive top-line results were consistent across our agencies, geographical locations, and areas of expertise.
Our CRM Precision segment showed particularly impressive growth at 24%.
The CRM Precision Group assists clients with MarTech transformation, digital and e-commerce communications, and direct-to-consumer marketing strategies.
This group has been instrumental in many of our recent successful new business acquisitions, contributing to our strong momentum in Q3.
Improved economic conditions fueled growth across our entire organization.
Omnicom's range of services and capabilities position us competitively in the market to: enhance and reinvent our clients' brands, seamlessly connect them with customers throughout their marketing journey, upgrade their marketing technology platforms, and innovate in e-commerce and emerging media channels.
Our strong revenue performance positively impacted our operating profit and bottom line.
Our third-quarter EBIT margins of 15.8% surpassed our 2020 margins and significantly outperformed the same period in 2019.
The quarter's net income and earnings per share grew by over 13% compared to 2020 and were substantially higher than our 2019 results.
As we approach the fourth quarter, we are in a strong competitive position and anticipate benefiting from continued global economic growth and ongoing cost management.
We currently project our full-year organic growth to be around 9% and our full-year EBIT margin to exceed our year-to-date margin of 15.1% for the nine months ending September 30, 2021.
Moving forward, we remain committed to our key strategic initiatives, focusing on our talent, creativity, and enhancing our already robust capabilities in precision marketing, MarTech consulting, e-commerce, digital and performance media, and predictive data-driven insights.
We made progress on these strategic initiatives in the third quarter with three acquisitions.
Omnicom Media Group acquired Jump 450 Media, a performance marketing agency that uses algorithmic scaling strategies, rapid creative testing, and data analytics to optimize digital media spend and drive customer acquisition.
Jump 450 will serve as the foundation for a dedicated performance media platform within OMG, enhancing its existing performance media offerings with a focus on e-commerce and pure performance marketing.
In late September, we also acquired two German-based companies: antoni and OSK.
antoni, one of Europe's most innovative and creative agencies, was established with data and digital capabilities at its core and will significantly strengthen our European and global capabilities.
OSK, consistently ranked in Germany's top 10 PR and communications agencies since 2008, is the undisputed leader in automotive PR and offers a wide range of services at the intersection of PR and social media, excelling in the convergence of technology, mobility, and communications.
Our ability to combine top talent and data-driven consumer insights from across our organization to deliver comprehensive and integrated brand experiences is proving highly successful in new business opportunities and in serving existing clients.
Following Philips' selection of Omnicom as their global integrated service partner for creative and media communications, Mercedes-Benz appointed Omnicom as their global marketing communications partner in the third quarter.
TMX, a dedicated team from across our groups, will bring together the best talent and capabilities across Mercedes-Benz's customer journey, offering expertise in media, CRM, brand and performance creation, web personalization, content automation, public relations, events, and paid and organic social media.
Last week, we won the Chanel media business globally, adding another iconic global brand to our portfolio.
In all our significant wins and for existing clients, our teams showcase our creativity, superior analysis, predictive insights, and technology capabilities to deliver connected, personalized, and seamless brand experiences for customers at all touchpoints of the consumer journey.
A key differentiator for Omnicom in serving our clients is our cohesive culture that unites us, characterized by creativity, flexibility, and caring values shared across our group.
Clients often cite our people's ability to bring distinct specialized skills while knowing, respecting, and genuinely collaborating with one another as a deciding factor in choosing Omnicom.
Our ability to integrate services across marketing disciplines is supported by Omni, our open operating system that orchestrates better outcomes.
Omni is designed for collaboration, acting as a conductor between different specialists using a single processing workflow from insights to execution.
It empowers our people and clients to make better and faster decisions, maximizing efficiency and ROI.
Omni also provides enhanced intelligence by orchestrating first-, second-, and third-party data sets to present a comprehensive view of consumers.
Our teams can then develop insights to create, plan, and deliver the most impactful messages, content, and communications at each stage of the consumer journey.
Omni is a unique and powerful tool for us, with over 40,000 Omnicom colleagues provisioned on the platform in more than 60 countries.
Hundreds of our clients, including all of our top 20, utilize Omni.
The open-source system allows our practice areas like commerce, health, and PR to customize Omni with different data sources for their clients.
For example, Omnicom Health Group created a custom offering called Omni Health, which has played a key role in expanding the group's omnichannel offering with new and existing clients since its April launch.
In conclusion, even during the pandemic, we enhanced the strength of our services, capabilities, and organization to deliver better outcomes for our clients and win new business.
Our offering is powerful and differentiated.
Our organization boasts exceptional talent and innovation, utilizing cutting-edge systems and technologies.
This approach will continue to yield success for our company.
During one of the most challenging periods in recent memory, our team has demonstrated remarkable creativity, adaptability, and resilience.
We maintain our commitment to investing in comprehensive training and development programs for all employees, ranging from foundational skills to advanced courses at Omnicom University.
We have recently broadened the scope of our diversity, equity, and inclusion initiatives and OPEN2.0 strategies.
As the ongoing pandemic poses significant health risks, the wellbeing of our staff remains our highest concern.
We are implementing measures to ensure a secure work environment and offering various programs to support employee wellness, resilience, and health in the workplace.
I recently visited several of our offices in the U.S. and Europe, meeting with numerous colleagues and clients who expressed satisfaction about returning to the workplace.
We are exploring various options to facilitate a safe return to office for our employees.
As an example, we are currently piloting a private transportation service for our New York City-based staff this week.
In the coming months, we anticipate welcoming more employees back to the office, maintaining our focus on their safety and flexibility.
Our world-class talent and commitment to creativity and innovative solutions are the driving forces behind delivering tangible business results for our clients.
A recent testament to the quality of our talent is Omnicom's recognition as the Most Effective Holding Company in the U.S. according to the 2020 [Technical Issues] report.
We are extremely satisfied with our performance in the third quarter.
I am pleased to see that our strategic focus and decisions made during the pandemic are now yielding positive outcomes.
Our results once again demonstrate Omnicom's ability to adapt to market changes and perform well across economic cycles.
While the pandemic's effects are still felt globally, its impact has significantly diminished, as evidenced by our continued growth in the third quarter.
The third quarter shows improvement across our income statement, with revenue growth and cost control leading to an 8% increase in operating profit.
Our effective tax rate for the third quarter was 24.1%, lower than our estimated rate of 26.5% to 27% for 2021.
This reduction was primarily due to favorable resolutions of uncertain tax positions in certain jurisdictions, resulting in an approximate $10 million impact.
These factors positively affected net income and diluted earnings per share, which reached $1.65, up $0.20 or 13.8% compared to Q3 last year and $0.33 higher than the third quarter of 2019.
This key metric continues to show growth.
Our quarterly dividend of $0.70, increased in February, is 7.7% higher than last year.
Our total revenue growth was 7.1%.
Organic growth for the quarter reached 11.5% or $367 million, a significant improvement compared to Q3 2020 when the pandemic caused an organic revenue decline of 11.7%.
Currency exchange rates increased our revenue by 1.6% in the quarter as the dollar weakened against most major currencies compared to the previous year.
If exchange rates remain at their October 15 levels, we expect foreign exchange to decrease our reported revenue by approximately 1% in the fourth quarter and increase it by 2% for the full year.
The impact of net acquisitions and dispositions decreased revenue by 5.9%.
Based on transactions completed through September 30, 2021, we estimate that the net impact of our acquisition and disposition activity for the rest of the year will decrease reported revenue by approximately 7% in the fourth quarter and 4% for the full year.
While we continue to evaluate our business portfolio as part of our strategic planning, we are largely finished with dispositions, as John has mentioned.
Advertising, our largest discipline accounting for 53% of total revenues, achieved 8.6% organic growth with strong performance from both creative and media agencies.
Note that reported Advertising growth is down 0.4%, primarily due to the disposition of ICON in Q2 2021.
Our agencies focused on direct, digital, and marketing transformation consulting services in our precision marketing discipline also posted strong organic growth at 24.3%.
Except for the second quarter of 2020, this discipline has shown consistent growth and has become a larger portion of our business each quarter.
CRM Commerce and Brand Consulting grew by 18%, led by our branding agencies.
CRM Experiential increased by 50%.
This business declined more than our other disciplines in the third quarter of last year during the pandemic and has not yet recovered to pre-pandemic levels due to various global restrictions.
However, this remains an important area for our clients, and we anticipate further growth as global economies continue to lift social distancing restrictions.
CRM Execution & Support grew by 8.3%, reflecting a recovery in client spending compared to the previous year in our field marketing businesses, while our research businesses continued to lag.
Public Relations increased by 10.5%.
We have a positive outlook for this discipline, especially within our global agencies, as clients adjust to post-pandemic realities.
Our Healthcare discipline grew by 6.6% organically.
Healthcare was the only one of our service disciplines that maintained positive organic growth during the height of the pandemic and continues to perform well.
All of our geographic regions again posted solid organic growth.
Virtually every discipline within each region contributed to this expansion.
In regions outside the United States, overall organic growth reached 16%.
Germany, the UK, Canada, and Australia spearheaded double-digit growth across all regions.
Our advertising, media, and public relations agencies performed exceptionally well with double-digit growth, while our precision marketing agencies made significant contributions and also achieved strong double-digit growth.
Furthermore, experiential growth outside the United States more than doubled in total.
In the United States, we achieved 7.7% organic growth, bolstered by strong double-digit growth in our precision marketing and public relations disciplines, as well as solid performance from our healthcare agencies.
I'd like to present one final perspective on revenue, which can be found on Slide 7, categorized by industry sector.
Compared to last year, there was minimal change in the sector mix of the portfolio on a year-to-date basis.
In conclusion, our revenue performance was robust across all areas, whether analyzed by discipline, geography, or industry sector, on both a reported and organic basis.
To enhance the relevance of our analysis, we've included an additional slide in the appendix that displays the 2021 figures in constant currency.
Starting with our largest category, salary and service costs.
These expenses increased by 7.6% overall and tend to vary in line with revenue changes.
It's worth noting that Q3 2020 salary and service cost figures were reduced by $68.7 million due to reimbursements from government programs.
Looking ahead, we anticipate a favorable outlook for advertising and marketing spending, and strong client demand will necessitate increased staffing.
The competitive labor market will present short-term challenges, but we are confident our management teams will overcome them.
Proceeding down the profit and loss statement.
Third-party service costs, which fluctuate with revenue changes, decreased by 6.9% during the quarter due to our net disposition activity, primarily related to the ICON divestiture, partially offset by organic revenue growth and foreign currency exchange rate effects.
Occupancy and other costs, which are not directly tied to revenue changes, rose by 4.5% year-on-year, or 2.9% when excluding foreign exchange rate translation impacts.
As anticipated, these positive results continue to reflect our efforts to reduce infrastructure costs and also benefited from decreased general office expenses as most of our staff continued to work remotely in Q3.
SG&A expense levels increased by 5.3% year-over-year, or 4.2% when excluding foreign exchange rate translation impacts.
We are beginning to see a resurgence of travel and certain other addressable spend costs as pandemic-related government restrictions ease.
However, based on our use of technology during the pandemic, we're developing practices, particularly regarding travel, that we expect will allow us to retain some of the benefits achieved in reducing addressable spend during the pandemic.
Overall, we anticipate that the increase in addressable spend for the remainder of the year will be partially offset by the benefits we will continue to realize from a hybrid and flexible workforce.
As we consider future expense levels, we certainly expect some areas to increase in line with our business as activity picks up and life returns to normal.
However, we will also continue to explore ways to improve efficiency throughout the organization by focusing on real estate portfolio management, back-office services, procurement, and IT services.
With the strong revenue growth discussed earlier, combined with effective expense control, you can see a significant improvement in our operating profit on a year-over-year basis at the bottom of the slide, up 8% for the quarter and 60.1% year-to-date.
Increasing our operating profit dollars remains one of our top priorities.
This robust growth in operating profit was accompanied by improved margins, which can be seen on Slide 9.
For the third quarter, our operating profit margin was 15.8% in terms of our reported total revenues.
We continue to observe year-over-year operating margin improvement, resulting from proactive management of discretionary addressable spend cost categories, including reduced travel and related expenses, lower costs for operating our offices due to the continued remote work environment, and benefits from some of the repositioning actions taken in the second quarter of 2020.
Lastly on this slide, our reported EBITDA for the quarter was $560.3 million, up 7.4% for the quarter and 56.3% year-to-date.
EBITDA margins also remained strong for the quarter and have expanded significantly year-to-date compared to last year, and we expect this strong performance to continue through the rest of this year.
Let's now examine our cash flow performance on Slide 10, which shows that in the first nine months of 2021, we generated $1.2 billion of free cash flow excluding changes in working capital, a $114 million or 10% increase compared to the same period last year.
There were no significant year-over-year changes in capital expenditures or acquisitions as we continue to manage our cash conservatively.
While stock repurchases have decreased relative to pre-pandemic periods due to curtailment during the pandemic, we resumed our activity during the second and third quarters of this year, and we expect to continue in Q4 and beyond.
You should not anticipate a change in our historical approach to capital allocation and the use of our free cash flow in the future.
We will maintain an attractive dividend.
We have indicated an increased focus on acquisition opportunities and are in the process of finalizing several acquisitions.
Importantly, our acquisition strategy targets the faster-growing disciplines in our portfolio and aims to drive future organic growth for the company.
We will use the remaining free cash flow to repurchase our stock.
Our strong cash generation has once again enhanced our credit and liquidity, as summarized on Slide 11.
Our total debt has decreased by approximately $500 million since this time last year as we eliminated the extra liquidity we added early in the pandemic.
We achieved this through the early retirement in Q2 of $1.25 billion of our 3.65% senior notes, which were due next year, partially replaced with the issuance of $800 million of 2.6% 10-year notes due in 2031.
As shown in the slide, our maturities are well-distributed with nothing due until late 2024 as we have deleveraged to pre-pandemic levels.
Regarding our debt ratios, due to our overall operating improvement compared to Q3 of 2020 and our recent refinancing activity, we've reduced our total debt-to-EBITDA ratio to 2.2 times and our net debt-to-EBITDA ratio to 0.4 times.
Both metrics have improved substantially over the 2020 levels.
While these are just two points in time, it's important to remember our long-term track record of delivering solid returns to shareholders through business execution and the resulting consistent allocation of capital to dividends, strategic acquisitions, and share repurchases.
Summary:
output:
q3 earnings per share $1.65.
operating margin for q3 of 2021 increased to 15.8% compared to 15.6% for q3 of 2020.
qtrly increase in revenue from organic growth of 11.5%.
global economic conditions may continue to be volatile as long as covid-19 remains which could negatively impact clients' spending plans.
organic growth in third quarter of 2021 compared to the third quarter of 2020 increased across all of co's fundamental disciplines.
expect global economic performance of businesses to vary by geography and discipline until covid19 impact on global economy subsides.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:We will include comparisons to our 2019 results due to COVID-19's significant impact on our business in 2020.
I'd like to remind everyone of Oxford's fundamental operational principles before discussing the third quarter results.
Our goal is always to create long-term value for shareholders.
We aim to achieve this by maintaining a collection of influential lifestyle brands capable of generating consistent, profitable growth.
Our mission, both as a company and within each of our brands, is to bring joy to people.
We're pleased to report record-breaking sales and earnings for the third quarter of fiscal 2021.
These exceptional outcomes are directly linked to our brand portfolio's strength, the quality of our products, and our ability to engage with and serve customers across various channels, combined with our teams' excellent work in reinforcing these core elements during the pandemic.
Our sales grew by 41% compared to the same quarter last year.
More significantly, our sales also increased when compared to pre-pandemic levels in fiscal 2019.
Net sales increased by 15% over the same period in fiscal 2019, excluding Lanier Apparel, which effectively ceased operations during the third quarter of fiscal 2021.
The substantial sales growth we experienced in the third quarter was driven by a 40% increase in our full-price direct-to-consumer business, with all our brands showing growth compared to fiscal 2019, including a 13% rise in full-price retail and a 100% increase in full-price e-commerce.
Restaurant sales also contributed to our improved top-line, growing 14% in the third quarter of fiscal 2021 compared to the same period in fiscal 2019, driven by strong increases at existing locations and the addition of five new Marlin Bar venues.
Concurrently, adjusted gross margin rose impressively by 710 basis points to 62% during the third quarter of fiscal 2021 compared to fiscal 2019.
Scott will soon provide more details on these excellent metrics.
However, I'll mention that they resulted in record third-quarter earnings of $1.19 per share on an adjusted basis, compared to an adjusted loss of $0.44 per share last year and adjusted earnings per share up $0.10 during the third quarter of fiscal 2019.
While our third-quarter results undoubtedly benefited from a robust consumer market, we believe the main driver of our outstanding performance was the effective execution of our strategy and purpose.
The closure of Lanier Apparel during the third quarter marked a significant milestone in our long-term strategy, as Lanier was the last of our legacy private label businesses.
Our current portfolio comprises five exceptional lifestyle brands: Tommy Bahama, Lilly Pulitzer, Southern Tide, The Beaufort Bonnet Company, and Duck Head.
These brands are entirely focused on the consumer and making them happy through powerful, clear brand messages, exceptional differentiated products, superior customer experiences (including our e-commerce websites, stores, and restaurants), and strategic wholesale accounts.
Over the past two years, across our brands, we have intensified our commitment to conveying our positive, upbeat brand messages through beautiful creative content and imagery.
These brand messages are resonating with our consumers and are a significant factor in the excellent results we are achieving.
The predominant mix of direct-to-consumer, expected to account for over 80% of our business, enhances our ability to bring happiness to our customers.
The direct model provides us with considerable agility and flexibility in managing the flow of products to our customers.
This flexibility has proven particularly valuable this year, as industry-wide supply chain challenges have required our merchants to be highly adaptable regarding the products featured on our floors and websites at any given time.
The direct business also offers significant margin power and is responsible for a large portion of the gross margin gain we achieved during the quarter.
Lastly, the direct-to-consumer model allows us to deliver an unparalleled customer experience that aligns with the aspirational positioning of our brands.
Our exceptional staff has consistently delivered top-notch service despite the hurdles faced over the past two years.
In recent years, we've focused on improving our digital marketing by enhancing data analysis, generating consumer insights, creating targeted campaigns, and evaluating their effectiveness to grow our customer base, maintain loyalty, and increase overall spending.
I'm happy to report that customer metrics for the 12 months ending in the third quarter of fiscal 2021, including total customers, new customer acquisition rate, retention, and customer lifetime value, were all robust compared to pre-COVID figures.
In terms of product offerings, we continued to see high demand for the relaxed, comfortable styles characteristic of our brands.
Notable examples include ongoing popularity of Tommy Bahama knitwear and shorts, women's loungewear and sleepwear, and Lilly Pulitzer's Luxletic athleisure line.
Simultaneously, we observed a welcome revival in previously struggling categories tied to social events, such as men's trousers and button-up shirts, and women's dresses, as people resumed social activities.
As we approach the year's end, I'm delighted to announce that holiday sales have been strong so far, and I'm confident we'll conclude an exceptional year on a high note.
I'm deeply appreciative of our team and share their sense of accomplishment in what we've achieved for our customers and shareholders.
As Tom mentioned, our brands performed exceptionally well in the third quarter, resulting in significant growth in sales, gross margin, operating margin, and earnings, surpassing pre-pandemic levels.
Demand for our products remained high, with revenue exceeding 2019 figures in our direct-to-consumer channels and across all our brands.
Excluding Lanier Apparel, which effectively ceased operations during the third quarter of fiscal 2021, consolidated sales grew by 15% to $243 million.
We saw improvements across all regions, with particularly strong performance in Florida, the Southeast, and Texas.
Hawaii has shown overall positive results, with strength in most areas except Oahu, which relies more heavily on international tourists compared to other islands.
Our gross margin continued to significantly outperform 2019 levels.
On an adjusted basis, gross margin in the third quarter expanded by 710 basis points over 2019, reaching 62%.
This improvement was driven by a higher proportion of full-price sales, a shift in our sales mix towards higher-margin direct-to-consumer distribution channels, and improved initial markup (IMU).
Increased freight costs, including air freight expenses, partially offset some of the margin gains by approximately 270 basis points.
On an adjusted basis, we achieved 260 basis points of SG&A leverage in the third quarter, improving from 56% of sales in 2019 to 53% of sales in 2021.
Adjusted SG&A dollars decreased slightly from 2019 levels, with reductions in employment costs due to headcount cuts and lower occupancy expenses partially offset by increased marketing spending.
As a result, our consolidated operating margin expanded by 970 basis points, from 1% in 2019 to 11%.
Tommy Bahama, Lilly Pulitzer, and Southern Tide all experienced operating margin expansion.
Regarding our balance sheet, our liquidity position remains strong.
We concluded the third quarter with $188 million in cash and short-term investments, with no outstanding borrowings under our revolving credit facility.
FIFO inventory decreased by 17% compared to fiscal 2020, excluding Lanier Apparel, due to higher-than-expected sales during the first nine months of 2021, ongoing improvements to enterprise order management systems, and cautious seasonal purchasing.
We believe our inventory is well-positioned to meet projected demand throughout the remainder of the holiday selling season.
Looking forward, we are pleased with our holiday season performance thus far and are confident in our ability to deliver a strong fourth quarter.
Our perspective is based on our anticipation of ongoing robustness in premium direct-to-consumer operations
We anticipate growth in premium direct-to-consumer sales and an overall increase in gross margin compared to 2019
Although we've improved our yearly forecast, the year-on-year enhancement in our premium direct business is anticipated to be somewhat counterbalanced by several specific factors in the fiscal year's final quarter
We anticipate Lanier Apparel sales to be roughly $20 million less than the fourth quarter of 2019, as we discontinued the business in this year's third quarter
Furthermore, we expect our branded wholesale business to be approximately $15 million lower than 2019
This is affected by the change in timing of certain initial spring wholesale deliveries
These have typically been shipped in the fourth quarter, but are expected to be delivered in the first quarter of 2022, as we reduced our dependence on air freight for warm weather products
We also anticipate the Lilly Pulitzer fourth quarter flash clearance event to be smaller compared to 2019, due to strong full-price sales throughout the year resulting in less inventory available for the flash sale
For the fourth quarter, we project sales to range between $285 million and $295 million, in comparison to $298 million in sales during the fourth quarter of fiscal 2019
To reiterate, Lanier Apparel generated $20 million in net sales in the fourth quarter of 2019
In the fourth quarter of fiscal 2021, we anticipate adjusted earnings of $1.20 to $1.35 per share, compared to adjusted earnings of $1.09 per share in the fourth quarter of 2019
Our forecast includes robust quarter-to-date performance with a promising start to the holiday shopping season
For the entire year, we now project sales to range from $1.127 billion to $1.137 billion, compared to sales of $1.123 billion in 2019
For the full year, Lanier Apparel sales are expected to be $25 million in 2021, compared to $95 million in 2019
Adjusted earnings per share are projected to be between $7.52 and $7.67
This is in comparison to adjusted earnings of $4.32 per share in 2019
Our predicted effective tax rate for the entire fiscal year 2021 is approximately 22%
We persist in backing our business with investments for future expansion
Capital expenditures are anticipated to be between $35 million and $40 million in fiscal 2021, primarily reflecting investments in IT initiatives, new Marlin Bars, and retail locations
We're thrilled to inaugurate our first company-owned Beaufort Bonnet Company store in Grand Boulevard at Sandestin later this quarter
We continue to generate robust cash flow from operations, including $157 million year-to-date
Our capital allocation priorities include investing in our businesses, acquisitions, and returning capital to shareholders through dividends and share repurchases
We remain well-positioned to return cash to shareholders and are proud of our long-standing history of providing value through dividends, which we have distributed every quarter since going public in 1960
This quarter, our Board of Directors has declared a dividend of $0.42 per share
Additionally, in evaluating our capital allocation strategy, our Board of Directors approved a new share repurchase authorization of $150 million
Summary:
output:
compname reports q3 adjusted earnings per share $1.19.
oxford: strong consumer demand and excellent execution drove record third quarter results, raises full year guidance.
q3 adjusted earnings per share $1.19.
sees q4 sales $285 million to $295 million.
sees fy sales $1.127 billion to $1.137 billion.
sees fy adjusted earnings per share $7.52 to $7.67.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Once more, I'm Mark Kowlzan, the Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of PCA.
Joining me on this call are Tom Hassfurther, who oversees our Packaging division as Executive Vice President, and Bob Mundy, our CFO.
These are undoubtedly the most uncertain and extraordinary times we may ever face in our lives.
There's no guidebook for navigating a public health emergency with such severe economic consequences as the COVID-19 pandemic.
This situation will inevitably alter our daily routines, customs, personal choices, professional and social activities, and numerous other aspects of our lives permanently.
Under various state and local shelter-in-place directives, PCA's operations are classified as essential or critical.
Our executive team is in ongoing discussions about safety measures, operational status, business continuity, and other crucial management issues.
At PCA, our primary duty is to ensure the welfare of our over 15,000 employees and their loved ones.
We must also do our utmost to support our customers and suppliers.
We've enacted various safety protocols and protective measures at all our manufacturing, processing, and office sites nationwide to safeguard our employees while providing goods and services deemed essential for the country's pandemic response.
We've also implemented measures to help our employees cope with the financial impacts resulting from these response efforts.
So far, we haven't experienced any major disruptions in our operations or supply chain due to the virus.
PCA's strategically positioned network of mills, processing facilities, and distribution centers across the United States provides us with operational flexibility to produce and ship products to multiple destinations.
We will maintain close monitoring of developments, take proactive steps to protect our workforce, and continue supplying our customers with necessary products and services.
I am immensely proud of the dedication, responsiveness, and sacrifices demonstrated by all PCA employees, as well as our customers and suppliers.
It has truly been an inspiring sight to witness.
I'll then conclude, and we'll be happy to address any questions.
Yesterday, we announced first quarter net earnings of $142 million, or $1.49 per share.
The first quarter net income included special item expenses of $0.01 per share, mainly related to costs associated with the COVID-19 pandemic.
Excluding special items, our first quarter 2020 net income was $143 million or $1.50 per share, compared to $187 million or $1.98 per share in the first quarter of 2019.
First quarter net sales remained steady at $1.7 billion for both 2020 and 2019.
The company's total EBITDA for the first quarter, excluding special items, was $311 million in 2020 and $371 million in 2019.
Disregarding special items, the $0.48 per share decrease in first quarter 2020 earnings compared to the same period in 2019 was mainly due to lower prices and mix in our Packaging and Paper segments, reduced Paper segment volumes, higher annual outage expenses, increased depreciation, other expenses, and a higher tax rate.
These factors were partially offset by increased Packaging segment volumes, lower operating and converting costs, reduced freight and logistics expenses, and decreased interest and nonoperating pension expenses.
The results exceeded our first quarter guidance of $1.20 per share by $0.30, primarily due to higher volumes in both Packaging and Paper segments, improved prices and mix in the Packaging segment, and lower operating costs resulting from excellent fiber and energy usage and reduced input prices at our mills.
Freight, logistics, and converting costs were lower than anticipated, as were annual outage costs and other expenses.
Let's examine our Packaging business performance.
EBITDA, excluding special items, was $290 million in Q1 2020 with $1.5 billion in sales, resulting in a 20% margin, compared to $334 million EBITDA and $1.5 billion sales with a 23% margin in the previous year
Our containerboard mills set a new Q1 volume record while conducting scheduled annual maintenance at four locations
We maintained our industry-leading integration rate of about 95% by providing containerboard to our box plants, which achieved record total box shipments and a new Q1 daily shipment record
We met higher-than-expected demand through proactive management, adjusting maintenance outage schedules, and excellent execution during these outages
The machine conversion at Wallula Mill enhanced our ability to optimize mix, freight and logistics costs, inventory levels, and customer needs within the containerboard system
Containerboard inventories reached their lowest levels since acquiring Boise's packaging business in 2013
Demand for corrugated products and containerboard was robust during the quarter
Our corrugated products plants set a new all-time record for total box shipments, up 5.6% from last year, and a new Q1 record for daily shipments, up 3.9% compared to Q1 of the previous year
External sales of containerboard were 13% higher than Q1 of last year, mainly due to increased domestic demand and slightly higher export demand
Domestic containerboard and corrugated products prices and mix were $0.54 per share lower than Q1 2019 and $0.06 per share down from Q4 2019
Export containerboard prices decreased by about $0.10 per share compared to Q1 of last year and remained unchanged from Q4 2019
Turning to our Paper segment
Q1 EBITDA, excluding special items, was $42 million with sales of $217 million, resulting in a 19% margin, compared to Q1 2019 EBITDA of $55 million and sales of $240 million, or a 23% margin
Q1 paper prices and mix were lower than last year as anticipated, but remained stable compared to Q4 2019
Paper volume was lower as expected, primarily due to scheduled maintenance at our Jackson, Alabama mill, but was about 3% higher than anticipated
Despite ending the quarter with slightly lower inventory than planned, we announced downtime at our Jackson, Alabama mill for May and June to manage supply according to Q2 demand outlook
The mills excelled in managing fiber and chemical usage and maintained strict control over indirect and fixed expenses throughout the quarter
We achieved record Q1 cash generation with $237 million from operations and record Q1 free cash flow of $166 million
Main cash uses in the quarter included $71 million for capital expenditures and $75 million for common stock dividends
We finished the quarter with $764 million in cash on hand, or $913 million including recently moved marketable securities
Our liquidity of over $1.2 billion as of March 31 is the highest ever for our company
With the Q4 2019 refinancing, we have no debt maturities for the next 3.5 years
The estimated Q2 financial impact of our decision to idle the Jackson, Alabama paper mill in May and June is approximately $30 million or $0.24 per share
I'd like to provide an update on our full year guidance for certain items mentioned in last quarter's call
We managed strong Q1 demand in our Packaging business partly by adjusting the timing and scope of scheduled maintenance outages at our containerboard mills
There are no changes to the scheduled outages at our white paper mills
The actual Q1 impact was $0.22 per share, with estimated impacts of $0.09 per share in Q2, $0.16 in Q3, and $0.34 per share in Q4 for the rest of the year
Our previous projection of $0.81 per share for the full year remains unchanged.
We now anticipate our full year interest expense to be $88 million instead of $81 million.
We've revised our net cash interest estimate to $92 million from $84 million, mainly due to lower expected interest income.
We've slightly reduced our cash tax rate forecast from the earlier 19% estimate, partly because of the announced downtime at our Jackson mill, while our effective tax rate stays around 25%.
After carefully examining our capital expenditure plans, we're maintaining our previously stated spending range of $400 million to $425 million, as well as our full year outlook for pension contributions and depreciation.
These are possibly the most unpredictable and extraordinary times we'll ever face.
Every day brings new and unexpected impacts we've never considered before.
Our long-standing strategy of cautious capital allocation and robust financial management has been beneficial for many years and is particularly valuable in current circumstances.
PCA entered this uncertain period caused by the COVID-19 pandemic with a strong financial position and solid balance sheet.
Our priority has been and will continue to be maintaining this strength through our management team's actions and decisions.
As Bob noted, our company's liquidity is at an all-time high, and we've never been more confident in PCA's future success.
We're well-equipped to navigate whatever challenges lie ahead while meeting the needs and expectations of our employees, customers, suppliers, and shareholders.
However, this confidence doesn't translate to the same level of short-term predictability or specific guidance we usually provide at this time.
Due to the uncertain extent and duration of the pandemic, as well as the timing of global recovery and economic normalization, we're unable to accurately quantify our guidance for the second quarter.
We've announced measures for our Paper business, which we believe will position us appropriately for what we currently anticipate in the second half of 2020.
However, nothing is certain, especially now, and further action may be necessary.
We experienced a surge in demand for our Packaging business in the first quarter, and the second quarter has also started very strong.
Our containerboard inventory is at its lowest levels, both in total and in weeks of supply, since we acquired the Packaging business from Boise.
While recycled fiber prices began rising significantly during the first quarter, our position as a primarily virgin fiber producer minimizes its impact compared to other manufacturers.
It's logical to expect that demand in certain end markets will eventually return to more normal growth trends, although we've successfully secured new business in end markets with stronger demand outlooks compared to markets that may be more negatively impacted.
It's impossible to predict what additional health-related measures will be required or mandated by various state and local governments where we operate.
Such events and actions could negatively affect the operation of our facilities and the availability of services and products from our suppliers.
Nevertheless, it's important to note that our company's products are essential for response efforts, recovery, and the well-being of our country.
The need for our cost-effective, sustainable, and renewable products will persist.
While no one can predict the severity or duration of the virus's impact on the global economy, I believe this need will be even greater as the world recovers from this crisis.
These statements were based on current estimates, expectations, and projections of the company, and involve inherent risks and uncertainties, including economic trends and those identified as risk factors in our annual report on Form 10-K filed with the SEC.
Summary:
output:
q1 earnings per share $1.50 excluding items.
q1 earnings per share $1.49.
q1 sales $1.7 billion versus refinitiv ibes estimate of $1.66 billion.
strong demand in our packaging segment drove q1 results.
due to uncertain scope and duration of pandemic , we are not able to properly quantify our guidance for q2.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Following Tom Dineen's presentation of the third quarter 2021 financial results, I will provide insights into our operations and market conditions.
Copies of these records can be acquired by reaching out to the company, the SEC, visiting ruger.com/corporate, or accessing the SEC website at sec.gov.
We make use of the non-GAAP metric EBITDA.
Tom will now present the company's performance for the third quarter of 2021.
In Q3 2021, the company achieved net sales of $178.2 million and earnings per diluted share of $1.98.
The previous year's comparable period saw net sales of $145.7 million and earnings per diluted share of $1.39.
For the initial nine months of 2021, the company reported net sales of $562.7 million and earnings per diluted share of $6.64.
The same period in 2020 yielded net sales of $399.6 million and earnings per diluted share of $3.31.
The significant improvement in Q3 profitability compared to Q3 2020 was mainly due to increased sales and production, leading to better utilization of fixed costs such as depreciation, engineering, and indirect labor expenses.
Profitability declined from Q2 2021 primarily due to three factors: First, all firearms facilities took a well-deserved week-long shutdown in July, reducing workdays to 59 compared to 64 in Q2.
This production decrease led to lower sales and some unfavorable fixed cost absorption.
Second, after a relatively quiet Q2, COVID-19 cases in our plants tripled in Q3.
This resulted in considerable production losses.
Third, following six quarters of exceptional demand, excess resales decreased from Q2, negatively affecting our overall profitability.
Our robust financial performance generated substantial cash.
In the first nine months of 2021, we produced $117 million in cash from operations.
We reinvested $15.6 million into the company through capital expenditures.
We anticipate 2021 capital expenditures to reach approximately $20 million, primarily for new product development.
Our ability to relocate manufacturing equipment between cells and facilities enhances overall utilization and reduces capital investment needs.
As of October 2, 2021, our balance sheet remained robust.
Our cash and short-term investments, held in U.S. Treasury bills, totaled $192.7 million.
We had a current ratio of 3.8:1 and were debt-free.
Our shareholders' equity totaled $338.1 million, equivalent to a book value of $19.21 per share, with $10.95 per share being cash and short-term investments.
During the first three quarters of 2021, we distributed $45.2 million to our shareholders through dividend payments.
The company's Board of Directors announced a quarterly dividend of $0.79 per share for shareholders on record as of November 15, 2021, to be paid on November 30, 2021.
Shareholders will have received a total of $3.36 in dividends per share for 2021 after this $0.79 quarterly dividend is paid.
As a reminder, our quarterly dividend fluctuates each quarter as it is approximately 40% of net income.
This concludes the financial summary for the quarter.
The demand for our products has continued to be robust.
We managed to ship all manufactured firearms this quarter without resorting to aggressive promotions or discounts, despite a slowdown in overall industry demand as shown by the adjusted NICS figures for the last two quarters.
We've recently begun restocking distributor and retail inventories, which were largely depleted over the past year and a half, positioning us favorably for the typically high-demand fourth quarter.
The estimated unit sell-through of the company's products from independent distributors to retailers grew by 9% in the first nine months of 2021 compared to the same period last year.
For the same timeframe, the National Instant Criminal Background Check System (NICS) checks, as adjusted by the National Shooting Sports Foundation, decreased by 11%.
The company's product sell-through increase outperformed the decrease in adjusted NICS background checks, potentially due to strong consumer demand for Ruger products, increased production in 2021, and the introduction of popular new products.
Innovation in product development continues to drive our success.
The MAX-9 pistol and the Ruger LCP MAX pistol, both launched in 2021, continue to be in high demand.
In the first three quarters of 2021, new product sales accounted for $116 million or 22% of firearm sales, compared to $88 million or 24% of firearm sales in the same period of 2020.
It's worth noting that our new product sales metric only includes major products introduced in the last eight quarters.
We don't include derivatives, extensions of mature product lines, or models introduced more than two years ago in this metric.
We are currently working on some exciting new product initiatives, including the reintroduction of Marlin lever action rifles, which we plan to start shipping later in the fourth quarter.
Since March 2020, our workforce has grown by 370 people, an increase of just over 20%, while our quarterly unit production has risen by more than 160,000 units or 45% during the same period.
This represents a 20% increase in personnel resulting in a 45% increase in production.
Our operations teams at all manufacturing plants have achieved a remarkable feat.
Although production increased towards the end of Q3 2021, our finished goods stock remained near record lows, and Ruger product inventories at distributors were 150,000 units less than pre-pandemic levels in late 2019.
Following an unprecedented 16-month period of intense product demand and continuous monthly production increases, we implemented a week-long shutdown in early July, as Tom mentioned earlier.
This marked our first shutdown in two years, allowing our workforce a well-deserved rest and enabling us to conduct routine maintenance and reorganize some manufacturing operations.
The shutdown impacted our third quarter production, sales, and earnings, but it was a small sacrifice to make.
It was the appropriate decision, and I'm pleased we took that action.
Our committed and industrious staff deserved and required a break.
Following the shutdown, we are better equipped for what we anticipate will be a busy fourth quarter and 2022.
Since the COVID-19 pandemic began in March 2020, we have been proactive in safeguarding our employees' health and minimizing its impact on our operations.
We grant all hourly workers extra paid time off and offer incentives for vaccination.
When feasible, we allow employees to work from home.
We maintain strict cleaning, sanitizing, and social distancing measures to ensure a cleaner and safer work environment.
As COVID-19 cases and positivity rates rise again in the United States, we remain alert and are proactively adjusting our strategies to protect our associates' health and safety while minimizing business disruptions.
Our strong financial position, demonstrated by our debt-free balance sheet, provides us with financial security and flexibility as we navigate challenges like COVID-19 and focus on our long-term objectives and creating shareholder value.
During Q3, we acquired a 225,000 square foot facility in Mayodan, North Carolina, approximately 1.5 miles from our original Mayodan building purchased in 2013.
This new facility doubles our presence in Mayodan and allows for future expansion.
We relocated our finished goods inventory, ShopRuger operations, and customer service call center to the new facility.
This freed up manufacturing space in our original building, in addition to the available space in the new facility.
These are the key points from the third quarter of 2021.
Summary:
output:
compname reports q3 sales of $178.2 million.
compname reports third quarter diluted earnings of $1.98 per share and declares quarterly dividend of 79Â¢ per share.
q3 earnings per share $1.98.
q3 sales $178.2 million.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:We thank you for your time and interest in Raymond James Financial.
Paul Reilly, Chairman and CEO, and Paul Shoukry, CFO, are joining us for this call.
Please direct your attention to the second slide.
These statements cover various topics including future goals, business outlook, financial projections, expected benefits of acquisitions, integration success, litigation outcomes, regulatory changes, pandemic impacts, and economic conditions.
We advise you to review the risks outlined in our latest Form 10-K, subsequent Forms 10-Q, and Forms 8-K, available on our Investor Relations website.
Today's discussion will include non-GAAP financial measures to provide insights into our management's view of ongoing business performance.
I'd like to begin by apologizing for repeatedly using the word "record" throughout this presentation.
The year and quarter were truly exceptional.
Our advisors and associates deserve the credit for these outstanding results, not management.
Their commitment and resilience throughout the fiscal year was remarkable.
We've once again demonstrated that our client-first approach and excellent service to advisors and clients can guide us through uncertain times, achieving record-breaking results.
These exceptional outcomes wouldn't have been possible without everyone's efforts.
Our fiscal fourth quarter concluded a record-breaking year in many aspects.
The company reported unprecedented quarterly net revenues of $2.7 billion and net income of $429 million, or $2.02 per diluted share, reflecting the September three-for-two stock split.
Excluding $10 million in acquisition-related expenses, adjusted quarterly net income was $437 million, with adjusted earnings per diluted share at $2.06.
The increase in quarterly net revenues was primarily due to record-breaking investment banking revenues and assets under management fees, mainly from higher private client group assets in fee-based accounts.
The quarter's annualized return on equity was 21.3%, with adjusted annualized return on tangible common equity at 24.1%, an impressive result considering the near-zero interest rates and our strong capital position.
We concluded the quarter with unprecedented total client assets under administration of $1.18 trillion, up 27% year-over-year and 1% sequentially.
We also achieved record PCG assets in fee-based accounts of $627 billion and financial assets under management of $192 billion.
Our focus on supporting advisors and clients through advanced technology solutions and a client-centered culture has resulted in exceptional advisor retention and recruitment to the Raymond James platform across our multiple affiliation options.
We ended the quarter with a record 8,482 financial advisors, net increases of 243 over the previous year and 69 from the preceding quarter.
During the fiscal year, we recruited financial advisors with approximately $330 million in trailing 12-month production and about $54 billion in client assets to our domestic independent contractor and employee channels.
In the Private Client Group, advisors generated domestic net new assets of roughly $83 billion in fiscal 2021, representing 10% of domestic PCG assets at the fiscal year's start, reflecting our excellent retention and record recruitment.
New account openings and advisor productivity were also strong this year, contributing to the excellent net new asset results.
Raymond James Bank experienced impressive loan growth during the quarter, increasing 5% sequentially to a record $25 billion, driven by securities-based loans to Private Client Group clients and strong corporate loan growth.
The Private Client Group achieved record quarterly net revenues of $1.8 billion and pre-tax income of $222 million, with a 12.3% pre-tax margin showing significant operating leverage over the past year.
The Capital Markets segment generated record quarterly net revenues of $554 million and pre-tax income of $183 million, representing an impressive 33% pre-tax margin to net revenues.
These record results were driven by unprecedented investment banking revenues, strong tax credit fund revenues, and solid fixed income brokerage revenues.
The Asset Management segment produced record net revenues of $238 million and pre-tax income of $114 million, up 29% and 46% over the previous year, respectively.
These results were primarily due to growth in financial assets under management, driven by net inflows to fee-based accounts in the Private Client Group, partially offset by market depreciation and net outflows for Carillon Tower Advisers during the quarter.
Raymond James Bank generated quarterly net revenues of $176 million and pre-tax income of $81 million.
Quarterly net revenues increased 9% compared to the previous year, as higher earning asset levels offset year-over-year compression in the bank's net interest margin.
Sequentially, net revenues grew 4% due to higher asset balances during the quarter.
The year-over-year increase in pre-tax income was attributed to the previously mentioned revenue growth and reduced bank loan provision for credit losses in the current quarter.
The bank's pre-tax income decreased from the previous quarter primarily due to a reserve release in the prior quarter compared to a loan loss provision, mainly related to strong loan growth during the fourth fiscal quarter.
In fiscal year 2021, as shown on slide seven, we achieved record net revenues of $9.76 billion, a 22% increase from fiscal year 2020, and record net income of $1.4 billion, a 73% rise from fiscal 2020.
Adjusted net income, excluding debt extinguishment losses and acquisition-related expenses during the year, was $1.49 billion, representing a 74% increase from adjusted net income in fiscal 2020.
Let's examine the fiscal year results on slide eight.
The Private Client Group, Capital Markets, and Asset Management segments all achieved record net revenues and record pre-tax income, with all segments experiencing significant operating leverage during the fiscal year.
These results once again demonstrate the value of our diverse and complementary business lines.
I'll start with consolidated revenues on slide 10.
Record quarterly net revenues of $2.7 billion increased 30% year-over-year and 9% sequentially.
Record asset management fees grew 8% sequentially, in line with the sequential increase in fee-based assets at the beginning of the quarter.
Private Client Group assets in fee-based accounts increased 2% during the fourth fiscal quarter, providing a slight boost for this line item in the first quarter of fiscal 2022.
Consolidated brokerage revenues of $541 million increased 9% compared to the previous year but decreased 2% from the preceding quarter.
Institutional fixed income brokerage revenues remained strong, although lower than the high levels of the comparison periods.
PCG brokerage revenues rose 17% year-over-year but remained flat sequentially due to reduced trading volumes, which offset the benefit from higher asset balances and associated trailing commissions.
Brokerage revenues for the fiscal year increased 13% to a record $2.2 billion, reflecting records for both PCG and fixed income, which had an exceptional year demonstrating their leading position in the depository segment.
Account and service fees of $170 million grew 21% year-over-year and 6% sequentially, mainly due to higher average mutual fund assets driving increased associated service fees.
As Paul has already discussed our record investment banking results this quarter, I'll focus on other revenues.
Other revenues of $74 million increased 35% sequentially, primarily due to higher tax credit funds revenues.
We also recorded $18 million in private equity valuation gains during the quarter, of which approximately $5 million were attributable to non-controlling interest reflected in other expenses.
Moving to slide 11.
Clients' domestic cash sweep balances, which are the main source of funding for our interest-earning assets and the balances with third-party banks that generate RJBDP fees, reached a record $66.7 billion at the end of the quarter, up 6% from the preceding quarter and representing 6.3% of domestic PCG client assets.
As we continued to experience growing cash balances and reduced demand from third-party banks during fiscal 2021, $10.8 billion of client cash is now held in the client interest program at the broker dealer.
Over time, this cash could be redeployed to our bank or third-party banks as capacity becomes available, potentially earning a higher spread than we currently earn on short-term treasuries.
On slide 12, we saw an encouraging 8% sequential increase in the combined net interest income and BDP fees from third-party banks to $198 million.
This growth was largely due to strong asset growth and a resilient net interest margin at Raymond James Bank, which remained steady at 1.92% for the quarter.
We anticipate the bank's NIM to settle around 1.9% over the next couple of quarters.
The average yield on RJBDP balances with third-party banks remained unchanged at 29 basis points in the quarter.
If banks' demand for deposits doesn't improve from current levels, we expect downward pressure on this yield in fiscal 2022, especially in the latter half of the fiscal year, which is why we have been focusing on generating on-balance sheet growth in assets that could deliver good risk-adjusted returns.
Moving to consolidated expenses on slide 13.
Starting with our largest expense, compensation, the compensation ratio decreased sequentially from 67.2% to 65.8%, largely due to record revenues in the capital markets segment, which had a very low 52% compensation ratio during the quarter.
Given our current revenue mix and disciplined expense management, we are confident we can maintain a compensation ratio of 70% or lower in this near-zero short-term interest rate environment.
As we experienced in fiscal 2021, we can perform significantly better than 70% with Capital Markets revenues at or near these record levels, which is our expectation for at least the next quarter or two.
Non-compensation expenses of $361 million decreased 15% sequentially, primarily due to the $98 million loss on extinguishment of debt in the fiscal third quarter.
Partially offsetting this favorable variance, we had a modest provision for credit losses during the quarter, compared with a bank loan loss reserve release in the fiscal third quarter.
Overall, our fiscal 2021 results demonstrate that we have remained focused on managing controllable expenses while continuing to invest in growth and maintaining high service levels for advisors and their clients.
Although we haven't finalized our budget for fiscal 2022, we anticipate a significant rise in expenses due to various factors.
We plan to heavily invest in human resources and technology to maintain our exceptional growth and high-quality service standards for advisors and their clients.
As travel and conferences resume, we expect business development costs to increase, which our team is enthusiastic about.
To provide context, business development expenses reached approximately $200 million in fiscal 2019, prior to the pandemic.
In contrast to the $32 million net benefit for credit losses in fiscal 2021, we anticipate bank loan loss provisions related to net loan growth in fiscal 2022.
The pre-tax margin trend for the past five quarters is illustrated on Slide 14.
The fiscal fourth quarter of 2021 saw a pre-tax margin of 20.8%.
The adjusted pre-tax margin was 21.2%, boosted by record revenues and relatively low business development expenses.
We set a pre-tax margin target of 15% to 16% in the current near-zero interest rate environment during our Analyst and Investor Day in June.
Given the expected expense growth in fiscal 2022, we believe the upper end of this range is an appropriate target.
However, as demonstrated this fiscal year, our margins can improve significantly when Capital Markets revenues are as robust as they were in fiscal 2021.
Slide 15 shows that total assets reached approximately $61.9 billion at the quarter's end, an 8% sequential increase, reflecting strong loan growth at Raymond James Bank and a substantial rise in client cash balances on the balance sheet.
Our liquidity and capital positions remain robust.
With a total capital ratio of 26.2% and a Tier 1 leverage ratio of 12.6%, both more than double the regulatory requirements, we have considerable flexibility to grow the business opportunistically.
RJF corporate cash at the parent company ended the quarter at $1.15 billion, a 26% decrease during the quarter, as we've set aside cash for the Charles Stanley acquisition, expected to close in the first or second quarter of fiscal 2022, pending regulatory approvals.
Slide 16 outlines our capital actions over the past five quarters.
We repurchased nearly 1.5 million shares, adjusted for the split, for $118 million during the fiscal year.
As of October 27th, $632 million remained available under the current share repurchase authorization.
Due to restrictions following our announced acquisition of TriState Capital Holdings, we don't expect to repurchase common shares until after closing.
Slide 17 presents key credit metrics for Raymond James Bank.
The bank's loan portfolio maintains healthy credit quality, with most trends continuing to improve.
Criticized loans decreased, and non-performing assets remain low at just 20 basis points.
The $5 million bank loan loss provision was primarily due to strong loan growth during the quarter.
The bank loan allowance for credit losses as a percentage of loans held for investment decreased from 1.34% to 1.27% at quarter-end.
For corporate portfolios, these allowances are higher at around 2.25%.
I'm very satisfied with our exceptional results for this quarter and fiscal year, which surpassed many records.
Looking ahead, we're well-positioned entering fiscal 2022 with strong capital ratios, quarter-end records for all key business metrics, and robust activity in financial advisor recruiting and investment banking.
The Private Client Group segment will benefit slightly from starting the fiscal first quarter with a 2% sequential increase in fee-based account assets.
We hope to maintain our current recruiting momentum, as our client-focused values and advanced technology platforms attract prospective advisors.
In the Capital Markets segment, we anticipate strong investment banking activity and solid fixed income brokerage results, driven by demand from depository clients.
If equity markets remain stable, the Asset Management segment should see positive results from higher financial assets under management.
Raymond James Bank is expected to continue growing, as we have sufficient funding and capital to expand the balance sheet.
We'll maintain our focus on lending to PCG clients through securities-based loans and mortgages, while being selective in growing our corporate loan and agency-backed securities portfolio.
Our long-term growth strategy remains centered on driving organic growth in core businesses, expanding technology investments, and pursuing strategic M&A opportunities.
The recent announcements to acquire TriState Capital and Charles Stanley Group demonstrate our commitment to these initiatives and to deploying excess capital over time.
We believe these acquisitions align with our long-standing criteria of cultural fit, strategic purpose, and shareholder value.
These outstanding results are a testament to the dedication of everyone in the Raymond James family.
Summary:
output:
raymond james qtrly earnings per share $2.02.
qtrly net revenues of $2.70 billion, up 30% over prior year's fiscal q4.
qtrly earnings per share $2.02.
qtrly adjusted earnings per share $2.06.
quarter-end private client group assets under administration of $1.12 trillion, up 26% over sept 2020.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:We are thrilled to present these impressive results to you.
I will now read our disclaimers before handing over to Jay Farner.
This call aims to inform you about our performance in Q4 and full-year 2020, as well as our financial outlook.
Our discussion will include non-GAAP financial measures.
I will now pass the floor to Jay Farner to begin.
The outstanding outcomes we're about to discuss and the innovations behind them showcase your commitment during an exceptionally challenging year globally.
Your efforts for our clients and communities exemplified the success of our beyond-profit mentality.
The platform remains crucial to our long-term success in our operating sectors and the record-breaking results we achieved in 2020.
In the coming minutes, you'll see how our decades-refined technology will continue driving success in current products, future extensions, and entirely new sectors.
If asked about our most crucial product, we would say it's the platform itself.
As I review our results, I'll provide updates on the Rocket Platform's key components: our technology, brand strength, Rocket Cloud Force, and data science foundation.
I'll conclude by explaining how our platform enables growth and efficiency in existing business lines while launching and rapidly scaling new ventures.
For decades, we've aimed to simplify life's most complex and stressful transactions using technology.
We offer a straightforward digital process, exceptional client experience, and certainty for transactions like mortgages, real estate, auto sales, and various new initiatives we're developing.
This mission began in 1998 when our founder and Chairman, Dan Gilbert, committed all company resources to moving online in an email.
His vision was straightforward but far ahead of its time.
Most Internet companies then focused on search, advertising, or basic e-commerce.
Dan envisioned something different.
He recognized the potential to use technology to make the most complex consumer transaction - buying and financing a home - accessible online nationwide.
For over 20 years, we've been quietly building our technology platform in Detroit to revolutionize how clients experience life's most significant events.
We continued enhancing our digital products and infrastructure in 2020, implementing nearly 4,500 product features and improving our platform every 28 minutes on average.
Our strong national brand, trusted by consumers and partners, supports our platform.
As we expand, we continue investing and finding new ways to extend our reach and diversify our marketing channels, connecting with more clients.
I'm confident most of you were among the nearly 100 million viewers who watched the Super Bowl recently.
We aired two 60-second ads emphasizing that "certain" is preferable when buying a home.
One commercial highlighted Rocket Mortgage and our technology that brings certainty to home buying, crucial in today's competitive real estate market.
The second showcased mortgage brokers' significant role in American homeownership.
Brokers are key partners as we extend our platform's reach.
This unprecedented national exposure for brokers during a Super Bowl allows them to leverage the Rocket brand's power for local market differentiation.
Our ads ranked first and second on USA Today's Ad Meter, widely considered the most prestigious consumer ranking of Super Bowl ads.
This means our ads not only reached millions of viewers but also gained tremendous visibility through social media, news articles, and free TV network replays.
Overall, our Super Bowl campaign generated over 3.3 billion consumer impressions.
Our areas of excellence and standard-setting attract some of the world's most respected organizations.
We've previously mentioned partnerships with American Express, State Farm, Intuit, Charles Schwab, and others.
In our last call, I hinted at a new partnership announcement.
Today, I'm pleased to share that Morgan Stanley and E*TRADE have partnered with Rocket Mortgage to originate, close, and service conforming mortgages for their clients.
This arrangement allows Morgan Stanley to focus on jumbo lending while Rocket Mortgage provides conforming loan options to their millions of clients.
We're excited about this opportunity, which will launch this year.
Another core element of our business model is the impressive Rocket Cloud Force, now comprising over 6,600 U.S.-based professionals trained to advise clients on complex transactions.
The COVID pandemic demonstrated that our Rocket Cloud Force can operate effectively from anywhere, with team members working remotely across the country.
This team's versatility and expertise allow us to explore new verticals and services.
Our ability to build, train, and license large-scale sales teams provides a significant competitive advantage.
Modern consumers expect simple, powerful digital experiences backed by trusted advisor support and consultation.
The Rocket Cloud Force's seamless integration into the online experience, providing timely, accurate, and actionable information, is a game-changer.
In markets where traditional experiences can be confusing and discouraging, such as buying or selling a home, car shopping, or considering a personal loan, our digital solutions and trusted advisors offer confidence and certainty.
Alongside our powerful Rocket Cloud Force, our company continues rapidly expanding its use of ethical artificial intelligence and machine learning to streamline operations.
We benefit from millions of annual client interactions across various transactions, leveraging this information to create sophisticated models ensuring our brand is visible and top-of-mind when clients are ready to transact.
Since early 2019, data science has driven over $75 billion in application volume.
The significance of data cannot be overstated.
This data enables us to swiftly innovate, predict market trends, and occasionally establish entirely new businesses.
These immediate insights provide a substantial competitive edge and consistently steer us towards optimal decisions with remarkable effectiveness.
Collectively, these core components of our enterprise: our expandable system, our widely recognized brand, our Rocket Cloud workforce, and our tactical application of information, unite to form a technological powerhouse that continues to expand rapidly.
It required a quarter-century for our organization to finalize our initial million loans.
In the year 2020 alone, we've assisted over 1.1 million customers with their mortgage, vehicle, property, or personal financing requirements.
Inventiveness and implementation, coupled with a highly skilled Rocket Cloud team, generates a self-reinforcing cycle that continues to gain momentum rapidly.
I'm even more enthusiastic about our future trajectory.
Merely three years ago, we introduced Rocket Auto, believing we could utilize our platform and Rocket Cloud team to simplify the car buying process.
It's common knowledge that purchasing a vehicle is complex and daunting.
It's an experience most consumers don't eagerly anticipate, but we've managed to make it approachable and pleasant.
Beginning from scratch in 2017, we've organically expanded Rocket Auto to surpass $750 million in gross merchandise value by 2020.
Having proven the concept, we plan to continue investing in accelerating growth in 2021 and beyond.
Our network of partners is becoming an increasingly crucial driver of growth for Rocket Companies.
We are continuously evolving and diversifying from our initial direct-to-consumer business model.
Partner volume constituted 38% of our completed loan volume in 2020, up from 23% just two years prior.
We view this evolution similarly to Amazon's past decision to open its marketplace to third-party vendors.
Like Amazon, we've constructed a proprietary platform capable of processing millions of transactions annually.
The partner network brings expansion and diversification to our enterprise.
To support these efforts, we recently launched a directory of nearly every broker nationwide on rocketmortgage.com in late January.
We then promoted this directory through the Super Bowl advertisement I mentioned earlier.
The impact has been remarkable.
In less than a month since its launch, tens of thousands of consumers have visited the directory and clicked through to contact a broker.
All these elements combined have created an incredibly profitable company that has demonstrated the ability to grow, strengthen, and scale in any market conditions.
The fourth quarter of 2020 was no exception.
All our businesses exceeded expectations, contributing to a full-year adjusted revenue of $16.9 billion and adjusted EBITDA of $11.1 billion.
As a result of our exceptional financial performance, Rocket Companies has generated substantial capital.
We're excited to announce that we're sharing our success with our shareholders today.
As Julie will soon explain, our Board has authorized a special dividend of $1.11 per share for stockholders of record as of March 9, to be paid on March 23.
We're also accelerating our long-term approach of launching and scaling new businesses from the ground up.
I'm pleased to announce the creation of Rocket Labs.
Rocket Labs' mission is to incubate new businesses within Rocket Companies that leverage our platform and provide our clients with services complementing our existing core products.
Our approach empowers small, independent teams to work on big ideas and concepts, which form the core of our future products.
We are excited about Rocket Labs and the possibilities it represents.
Before I turn things over to Julie to share our financial results, I'll take a moment to give her a proper introduction.
Julie and I have worked together within this company for 17 years.
During that time, she has led the finance and accounting teams and done an exceptional job managing all aspects of our liquidity.
Julie's foresight has helped us continue to grow in all market cycles.
Moreover, there's nobody who knows the financial side of this industry better.
We're all fortunate to be working alongside her.
With that introduction, Julie, take it away.
I'm pleased to again report strong financial results for Rocket Companies.
For the full year of 2020, Rocket Companies generated $16.9 billion of adjusted revenue and $11.1 billion of adjusted EBITDA as we concluded a record-setting year.
In discussing today's results, I'll walk through some key advantages of Rocket Companies' business model.
Specifically, I'll highlight the power of our platform to unlock scale, drive efficiency, and serve as a launchpad for new businesses focused on simplifying complicated transactions.
I will also provide some insights on our capital allocation priorities.
Our 2020 results demonstrate true growth at scale.
For the full year 2020, we generated $320 billion of closed loan volume, representing a 121% increase year over year.
Our success in 2020 was broad-based, with consistent increases across both our direct-to-consumer and partner network channels.
Our growth was balanced between new and existing client relationships.
2020 was also a year of robust growth across Rocket Companies, with particular strength at Amrock, our title company, with revenues increasing 124% to $1.3 billion during the year.
Our automotive retail marketplace, Rocket Auto, achieved impressive results by facilitating over $750 million in automotive e-commerce transactions.
In 2020, this amounted to slightly more than 32,000 vehicle sales, representing a growth of over 60% compared to the previous year.
We concluded 2020 on a particularly positive note, with fourth-quarter rate lock and closed loan volumes significantly surpassing our highest projections at $96 billion and $107 billion respectively.
Several factors contributed to the exceptional performance in the fourth quarter.
Notably, consumers are becoming increasingly at ease with completing complex, high-value transactions online.
Continuing the trend observed throughout 2020, our automated, self-service digital platform was our fastest-growing channel in the fourth quarter.
We also experienced growth in Q4 from our branded partnerships and mortgage broker associates following the introduction of the Rocket Pro TPO brand to the broker community and the release of several improvements to our TPO software portal during the fourth quarter.
Rocket Homes also ended the year strongly, assisting clients with nearly $1.6 billion in real estate transactions during the fourth quarter alone.
While current industry estimates of market size vary widely, it is evident that Rocket gained significant market share in 2020.
