Our full-year closed volume growth of 121% substantially exceeded any estimate of the overall industry's growth from third-party sources, which averaged 67%.
Our Platform business model is crucial in enabling our unparalleled growth at scale.
To illustrate this, Rocket Mortgage's additional closed volume of $175 billion in 2020 was more than double the growth of any other market participant.
In fact, our incremental gain in 2020 alone was nearly large enough to surpass the entire closed loan volume of the nation's second-largest originator last year.
Achieving this growth rate in a complex category like home loans requires a platform with extensive reach, scalable infrastructure, and centralized software-driven operations.
The Rocket platform is designed to perform and expand in the largest, most intricate markets.
Our infrastructure also results in a highly efficient economic model with substantial operating leverage.
Our 2020 results demonstrate Rocket's ability to increase scale from a single platform with minimal additional costs.
For the full year 2020, Rocket's adjusted revenue increased by $11 billion compared to the previous year.
We achieved this revenue growth while only adding $2 billion in expenses during the year, or $3 billion of annualized operating expenses based on our fourth quarter.
To showcase the efficiency of our business model, Rocket's transactions per production team member in 2020 were approximately triple the industry average.
While our cost-effective platform model is driving record profitability, we're maintaining our long-term strategy of reinvesting in the business.
Key areas for investment include our brand, product development, and initiatives to boost growth in the purchase market.
We continue to invest in talent acquisition, particularly in technical roles.
For example, our data science team now comprises over 300 professionals.
We're attracting high-performing individuals across multiple teams, including the ongoing expansion of our technology and product strategy departments.
Our brand is another crucial investment priority, including our recent Super Bowl advertisements, which generated significant brand recognition and drove record traffic to our online and mobile platforms.
Among our key product development priorities is Rocket Logic, the next generation of our core workflow management platform.
This new platform guides users through the most effective next action, resulting in faster, more accurate workflows.
We are very pleased with our initial pilot, where we are observing a 20% improvement in processing times within the test group.
Even more exciting is that Rocket Logic can be applied to enhance processes beyond mortgage origination.
We anticipate that Rocket Logic and our numerous automation initiatives will drive continued efficiency in our business model.
The core of our economic flywheel is our constant leveraging of profitability advantages to reinvest in the business, further strengthening our competitive position.
Another key advantage of the Rocket Companies' platform is our ability to test, launch, and rapidly scale new business models.
This entrepreneurial approach is evident in our scaled mortgage operations.
In two years, our partner network has grown from less than $20 billion in closed loan volume to $120 billion annually.
We see similar potential within our early-stage, rapidly expanding businesses such as Rocket Auto, Rocket Loans, and Rocket Homes.
To that end, as Jay announced earlier, the launch of Rocket Labs will further accelerate our focus on expanding the business in ways that leverage our platform and serve our client base.
We believe our clients will greatly benefit from these additional business lines over time.
Regarding our first-quarter outlook, we expect closed loan volume of $98 billion to $103 billion compared to $51.7 billion in the first quarter of 2020.
We anticipate net rate lock volume of $88 billion to $95 billion, up from $56 billion in the first quarter of 2020.
We project gain-on-sale margins of 3.6% to 3.9% compared to 3.25% in the first quarter of 2020.
We're enthusiastic about the continued strength and momentum of the Rocket platform.
We concluded 2020 with a very strong balance sheet, including $2 billion in cash and $7.7 billion in total liquidity.
Total liquidity includes cash on hand, undrawn lines of credit, undrawn MSR lines, and corporate cash used to self-fund loan originations, which could be transferred to funding facilities at our discretion.
As we stated at the time of our IPO last summer, our capital allocation priorities always begin with properly capitalizing and reinvesting in the business.
As I mentioned earlier, we are actively deploying capital with investments in our platform, brand, and talent.
We also aim to deploy capital through add-on acquisitions that would enhance our economic flywheel and bring value to our client base.
Our next priority is to return capital to shareholders through dividends, opportunistic share buybacks, or a combination of both.
Given our record level of profitability in 2020, the Board approved a special dividend of $1.11 per Class A common share, funded by an equity distribution of $2.2 billion.
Our substantial cash generation provides us significant flexibility to drive long-term value for our shareholders.
Additionally, we remain authorized to repurchase up to $1 billion of Rocket Companies' common stock.
Summary:
output:
compname reports special dividend of $1.11 per class a share of common stock.
compname announces special dividend of $1.11 per class a share of common stock.
sees closed loan volume of between $98 billion and $103 billion in q1 2021.
sees net rate lock volume of between $88 billion and $95 billion in q1 2021.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Those who listen to any replay should be aware that the accuracy of statements made may decrease over time.
I trust you and your loved ones are in good health.
The events of 2020 will remain etched in our memories for a long time to come.
COVID-19 has caused unparalleled disruptions to both public health and the economy.
Combined with the social and political turbulence our nation has undergone, 2020 will undoubtedly be remembered as one of the most challenging and significant years in our lives.
While an open-air shopping center REIT faces relatively minor issues compared to the broader challenges of 2020, I take pride in RPT's response and performance during this past year.
RPT demonstrated its dedication to our mission of transforming commercial spaces into community hubs through our tenant support program, charitable contributions, property-level safety measures, and curbside pickup initiatives.
We also acted quickly and decisively to secure our liquidity and maintain access to capital by obtaining our first investment-grade credit rating from Fitch.
Furthermore, I was greatly impressed by the team's relentless efforts in pursuing rent collections, which rose to 91% in the fourth quarter.
After repaying the remaining $100 million balance on our revolver, we now have over $100 million in cash and a fully available $350 million revolver, positioning us to fully leverage our unique and valuable partnership with GIC and opportunistically execute our external growth plans.
We continue to monitor a robust pipeline of potential acquisitions and have observed some recent increase in activity.
I want to emphasize that the underlying real estate remains the primary focus of our acquisition strategy.
We then seek opportunities for growth, which can manifest in various forms such as below-market rents, mismanaged assets, or redevelopment potential.
This growth can occur across different retail formats, including grocery-anchored centers, lifestyle centers, power centers, and community centers.
As previously disclosed, we had five deals in our GIC venture that were either signed or in negotiations in February 2020.
When the pandemic struck, we and our partners decided to withdraw from all of these deals.
We are now fortunate to have the necessary liquidity and a comprehensive pipeline within our core markets, and we believe the growing value disparity between property types, tenant categories, and markets is creating unique opportunities that we aim to capitalize on in 2021.
One of our strengths is anticipating future trends rather than focusing on past developments.
Last year, we entered the Austin market through our off-market acquisition of Lakehills Plaza.
Since our purchase, Tesla announced plans for a new $1.1 billion assembly plant.
Companies like Google, Oracle, and Digital Realty have each announced plans to relocate or expand in Austin.
Additionally, Barshop & Oles revealed plans for a new $1 billion mixed-use development directly across the highway from our property.
Just over a year has passed since our acquisition, and we are more convinced than ever about the potential of this dynamic market that truly represents future opportunities.
We are making good progress in our grocery negotiations and are also discussing deals with various tenant types such as home improvement, wholesale clubs, discount stores, fast food restaurants, and medical facilities.
This quarter, we signed leases for 120,000 square feet, which is a 10% increase compared to the same period last year.
Noteworthy lease signings this quarter included two new agreements with a modern, technologically advanced healthcare provider.
These agreements demonstrate our increased emphasis on health and wellness tenants.
We are also seeing promising activity for the two Stein Mart locations we reclaimed this quarter, presenting an opportunity to significantly upgrade the quality of tenants in both spaces.
With an average base rent of less than $11.50 per square foot, we anticipate a substantial increase in rental income when these spaces are re-leased.
One of the Stein Mart locations is already under lease, while the other has multiple letters of intent being negotiated with well-known national brands.
At the end of the fourth quarter, we had a backlog of signed but not yet operational leases worth $3.2 million, an increase from $3 million in the previous quarter.
We are currently in negotiations for leases worth approximately $2 million in annual base rent, up from about $1.5 million last quarter, providing us some insight into potential offsets for future tenant losses.
The pipeline for new leases is strong, and we are optimistic about its positive impact on our future cash flows.
Furthermore, we are pursuing several redevelopment opportunities that are detailed in our supplementary materials.
These 11 projects involve redesigning, expanding, or combining spaces, similar to the 18 targeted redevelopment projects we completed in 2019.
We expect to achieve attractive returns on our investment for these new projects, ranging from high single to low double-digit percentages, as we did with the previous projects.
Despite the increase in reported COVID cases at the end of the year, our suburban portfolio was less affected by additional lockdown measures implemented since the summer.
94% of our portfolio, measured by annual base rent, remains open, unchanged from the previous quarter, with 4% of our closures related to our movie theaters.
The reopening of our theaters remains uncertain.
Our exposure is almost entirely tied to Regal, whose parent company, Cineworld, recently secured additional financing that they expect will provide liquidity through 2021 and beyond, which is a positive development for this tenant.
While we continue to prioritize our most cost-effective source of capital, retained cash flows, we recognize the importance of dividends as a component of total shareholder returns.
With this in mind, we have set a common dividend of $0.075 per share for the first quarter of 2021.
This quarterly rate reflects a careful analysis of our expected taxable income and liquidity requirements.
We believe the new dividend rate is sustainable and has the potential for growth in line with earnings, while allowing us to preserve cash to support our growth initiatives and providing sufficient buffer to weather periodic future economic downturns.
Today, I will discuss our fourth quarter performance, our robust balance sheet and liquidity position, and conclude with insights to help everyone understand our expectations for how our business will trend in 2021.
In the fourth quarter, our bad debt and rent abatements totaled $4.4 million, approximately the same as the third quarter.
We set aside reserves for about 89% of our uncollected fourth quarter recurring billings, limiting potential further downsides from these categories compared to our fourth quarter run rate.
As of year-end, $18.1 million of recurring billings for the period from April through December 2020 remain unpaid, of which $11.9 million have been reserved.
The majority of the unclaimed $6.2 million is anticipated to be reimbursed during 2021 and 2022.
We remain highly satisfied with our portfolio's resilience and minimal bankruptcy exposure, as our leased rate of 92.8% remained stable in the quarter, decreasing only 50 basis points sequentially, mainly due to reclaiming our two Stein Mart leases mentioned previously.
The quarter's combined rent spreads stayed positive at 3.4%, affected by a few strategic renewals with no increase.
It's crucial to recognize that the releasing spread is just one element of the organic growth profile.
Another crucial factor we consider in lease negotiations is the yearly contractual rent increases.
The leases we executed during the quarter had annual contractual rent increases of approximately 150 basis points, which significantly contributes to establishing a sustainable long-term NOI growth profile.
As we've consistently mentioned, we anticipate some fluctuation in our quarterly statistics given our portfolio's size, but we see an ongoing opportunity to adjust to market rates as we renew older leases over the coming years.
As Brian mentioned regarding dividend policy, we've prioritized free cash flow, enabling us to use our most cost-effective form of capital to capitalize on these opportunities as we restore our portfolio to pre-COVID leased rate levels of nearly 95%.
We were delighted to receive our first investment-grade credit rating from Fitch, underscoring our balance sheet's strength and adaptability.
Given this recognition and increased confidence in our business and access to low-cost debt capital, we no longer saw the need to maintain a large cash reserve and paid off the remaining $100 million balance on our revolving credit facility last week.
We will continue to explore our portfolio for additional capital-raising opportunities to further strengthen our liquidity position and support our external growth plans.
We concluded the fourth quarter with a trailing 12-month net debt to pro forma adjusted EBITDA ratio of 7.4 times, slightly up from 7.2 times in the previous quarter as another COVID-impacted quarter was included in the calculation.
We remain dedicated to bringing our leverage into our long-term target range of 5.5 to 6.5 times and expect to see steady improvement in EBITDA as we return to more normal reserve levels and as our signed leasing backlog starts to take effect throughout 2021.
We are setting our 2021 operating FFO per share guidance at $0.77 to $0.87, which represents an expected improvement over the annualized 2020 fourth quarter operating FFO per share of $0.72.
Key factors contributing to this are a positive impact of $0.03 from interest expense, mainly due to repaying our revolving credit line, and $0.02 from our signed but not yet open backlog, which we expect the majority to open evenly throughout 2021.
Additional upside potential depends on favorable bad debt reserves, which we anticipate will be significantly influenced by the reopening of our theaters, which is contingent on the progress of vaccine distribution and movie production.
While we assume these circumstances will improve over the course of 2021, we felt it appropriate to establish a wider range given the potential varying outcomes for our theater exposure, which accounts for about $0.10 per share of earnings.
If our theaters remain closed and fail to pay their contractual rent, our operating FFO could be at the lower end of the range.
Conversely, if they are open and paying, we should be near the upper end, all other factors being equal.
It's important to note that our guidance doesn't include the net impact of changes to 2020 estimates for bad debt and straight-line rent reserves.
Additionally, while acquisitions are not factored into our guidance range, we plan to reinvest $100 million of cash from our balance sheet into opportunistic acquisitions that meet our strict underwriting criteria, representing potential upside to our range.
Although the short-term COVID trajectory remains uncertain, we are cautiously optimistic that the worst is now behind us.
As we approach a more normal environment and given the conflicting effects of permanent move-outs and rent collection statistics, we hope to refocus on more traditional measures of REIT operating performance such as occupancy, rent spreads, and same-property NOI growth.
As part of our ongoing efforts to enhance our disclosures, we've added a net asset value page to our supplemental on page 14 this quarter to assist in your analysis of our real estate value.
Summary:
output:
rpt realty reinstates quarterly common dividend.
initiated 2021 operating ffo per diluted share guidance of $0.77 to $0.87.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:You can find our 10-Q on Range's website in the Investors section or through the SEC's EDGAR system.
We've posted additional supplemental tables on our website with information to help calculate EBITDAX, cash margins, and other non-GAAP metrics.
In Q1 2021, Range made progress on key strategic goals: improving margins through cost control and marketing, generating free cash flow, enhancing liquidity and extending debt maturities, operating safely and efficiently, and positioning to return capital to shareholders as Appalachia's most efficient natural gas and NGL producer.
I'll briefly discuss each of these before handing it over to Dennis and Mark for more details.
Let's start with unit costs and margin improvements.
Range's Q1 unit costs were on track and better than expected, with G&A, LOE, exploration expense, and production taxes at the low end of guidance.
We also reported a significant gain in marketing activities for the quarter.
As anticipated, GP&T increased from last quarter but was more than offset by major improvements in NGL and natural gas realizations, greatly enhancing Range's margins.
Range's unhedged realized price for Q1 was about $3.20 per mcfe, $0.51 above the NYMEX Henry Hub equivalent of $2.69.
This premium stems from our diverse marketing portfolio and liquids production.
The liquids uplift boosts margins and lowers Range's breakeven costs compared to dry gas production alone.
Range's pre-hedge margin improved by over $1 per mcfe in Q1 versus the 2020 average.
With improved fundamentals for natural gas liquids and about 65% of our activity in liquids-rich areas this year, Range is well-positioned to continue benefiting from this trend.
In Q1, Range also capitalized on better daily natural gas prices, achieving a differential $0.08 better than guidance midpoint, only partially offset by higher transport fuel costs, further improving margins and cash flow.
With this improved pricing, Range generated $193 million in operating cash flow before working capital changes, and with $105 million in capital spending, produced solid free cash flow.
As shown on slide 14, we expect this trend to continue with significant EBITDAX growth this year compared to last.
Combined with absolute debt reduction, this organic free cash flow generation advances us toward our long-term balance sheet goals.
The Q1 all-in capital investment of $105 million demonstrates excellent operational execution.
We continue finding ways to reduce costs, leveraging our large contiguous acreage to complete our operational plan with industry-leading capital efficiency.
After coming in under budget for the past three years, Range is on track to do so again in 2021.
The operations team safely executed this capital-efficient plan while keeping our long-term environmental objectives in mind.
Range ended 2020 with leading emissions intensity, reducing greenhouse gas emissions intensity and progressing toward our 2025 net-zero goal.
This goal begins with efficient operations that minimize our footprint while generating competitive returns.
We believe Range's industry-leading capital efficiency and maintenance capital are key differentiators.
As discussed before, Range's large contiguous acreage provides operational and financial efficiencies in areas like water recycling, infrastructure, rig mobility, and well optimization.
Dennis will illustrate how these combined benefits improve Range's ongoing development and corporate returns while bolstering our environmental efforts.
Our low well costs, strong recoveries, and shallow base decline under 20% result in high capital efficiency, providing a solid foundation for sustainable free cash flow.
Range's ability to maintain this efficiency long-term due to our multi-decade core inventory further sets us apart.
For context, Range is bringing about 60 wells online this year, but we have roughly 2,000 Marcellus locations with EURs exceeding 2 Bcfe per 1,000 feet of lateral.
The average recovery of these wells is very similar to those Range has brought online in recent years, giving us an unmatched decades-long runway of high-quality wells.
This isn't true for many peers, which we believe positions Range as well as any upstream company to benefit from improving commodity prices in the medium and long term.
Before handing over to Dennis and Mark, I'll reaffirm Range's commitment to sustainable free cash flow.
We believe Range will distinguish itself among peers due to our low sustaining capital, competitive cost structure, marketing strategies, and crucially, our multi-decade core inventory, which will become an increasing advantage as other operators deplete their core inventories.
We'll maintain our focus on safe, efficient, and environmentally sound operations, prudent capital allocation, and generating sustainable shareholder returns.
These priorities are reflected in our updated compensation metrics in our latest proxy statement.
Over to you, Dennis.
When we outlined our 2021 operational plans, we focused on improving operational and capital efficiencies, enhancing margins, and further improving our environmental and safety performance.
Looking at Q1 results, our operating teams are off to a strong start in meeting our yearly objectives, with production exceeding guidance and capital spending aligning with our 2021 plan.
Q1 capital spending was $105 million, about 25% of our 2021 program budget.
As discussed previously, our capital spending is front-loaded this year, consistent with past years.
We expect Q2 capital spending to be roughly one-third of the annual budget, mainly due to completion and turn-in-line activity timing shifting to Q2.
Reduced capital investments in H2 2021 align with our activity slowing to one drilling rig and one frac crew during Q3 and Q4.
Our Q1 production of 2.08 Bcf equivalent per day resulted from recent strong well performance and exceptional field run time, largely due to our production operations team's near-perfect winter operations planning and execution.
Q1 production included bringing 16 wells online across our dry, wet, and super-rich acreage.
These Q1 turn-in-lines averaged over 11,500 feet in horizontal length, adding nearly 200,000 producing lateral feet to Range's Appalachia assets.
From Q4 2020 through Q1 2021, our activity shifted toward wells in our processable gas areas.
These turn-in-lines increased Range's average oil production to over 8,000 barrels per day in Q1 and boosted overall liquids production to levels seen in H1 2020.
We expect this wet production contribution to continue through year-end, with Q2 production projected at about 2.1 Bcfe per day.
This positions us to achieve our 2021 maintenance target of 2.15 Bcfe per day with additional margin-enhancing liquids production while spending $425 million or less.
Turning to operational highlights, we drilled 15 wells across our dry, wet, and super-rich areas in Q1.
Four of these rank in the top 20 lateral lengths in Range's Marcellus program history, all exceeding 17,800 feet.
Drilling efficiencies continued, with nearly 75% of new wells drilled on existing production pads, along with a 5% increase in daily lateral footage drilled compared to 2020.
On the completion side, 16 wells were completed during the quarter.
The team completed approximately 1,200 frac stages and set a new efficiency record for first quarter winter operations, averaging over eight stages daily.
This performance surpassed Range's previous best first quarter winter operations record by 14%.
The water operations team achieved a first quarter record by using nearly 2 million barrels of third-party produced water, resulting in cost savings of over $4.5 million for completions.
Despite challenging winter weather conditions, the team achieved some of our best operational results to date.
Safety and environmental performance remained top priorities throughout these operations.
First quarter lease operating expense was comparable to the previous year's Appalachia level, remaining low at $0.09 per Mcfe.
This low LOE was largely due to a well-planned proactive winter operations strategy aimed at minimizing weather-related production impacts and associated costs.
These efforts resulted in a field runtime exceeding 99% with weather-related production impact of less than 0.5 million cubic feet per day for the quarter, which is an impressive accomplishment.
The operational successes and milestones in the first quarter were achieved through a focused, continuous improvement approach centered on four key areas.
The four key areas driving operational and capital efficiency, as well as environmental objectives, are Range's water recycling program, long lateral development, utilization of existing infrastructure, and optimized use of drilling and completions equipment.
These strategies provide benefits such as reduced operating costs, improved efficiency, minimized environmental impact, and lower emissions.
I will now explain how these four strategies are implemented by our operations and support teams, along with their positive impacts, using three wells turned to sales in the first quarter as an example.
These three wells were drilled on an existing surface location with producing wells that were initially developed and brought online in 2013.
The original wells had an average lateral length of just over 3,000 feet per well.
In comparison, the new wells have an average lateral length of nearly 16,000 feet per well, which is more than 5 times longer.
No additional land disturbance was required for developing 5 times the acreage, and no new production, gathering, or processing infrastructure was needed for these new wells.
Range has close to 250 developed pads in Southwest PA, and we have returned to 84 of these locations to drill additional wells.
We plan to drill more wells on these same pad sites and on approximately two-thirds of Range's pads that we haven't yet revisited for additional activity.
We have only begun to tap into this opportunity.
The three new wells were completed late last year using our contracted electric fracturing fleet, which replaced 470,000 gallons of diesel fuel.
This resulted in cost savings of about $300,000 per well and significantly reduced associated emissions.
40% of the water used to complete these new wells was recycled from Range's producing wells and third-party sources obtained through our water sharing process.
The remaining water was pumped from our water pipeline network, installed nearly a decade ago, further reducing emissions by eliminating more than 13,400 truck trips.
The average initial production of these wells exceeded 44 million cubic feet equivalent per day, including more than 9,700 barrels per day of combined condensate and natural gas liquids per well, ranking them among the top wells in our Marcellus program history.
This is just one of many examples we could share from our development in recent years with similar results.
These efforts have underpinned our operational efficiency gains and give us confidence in maintaining our drilling and completion costs below $600 per foot, while achieving our environmental goals and producing top-tier wells.
These benefits highlight the value of having a high-quality contiguous acreage position and a forward-thinking technical team.
Regarding Range's environmental and safety performance, we transitioned to a quarterly leak detection program in 2020, doubling the number of inspections conducted.
This increased inspection frequency resulted in an additional 7,400 metric tons of CO2 equivalent emissions being removed from our program, leading to a 67% reduction for related components.
This effort, along with advancements in production facility design and the use of an electric frac fleet, has further reduced Range's reported emissions to a new low CO2 equivalent level.
Our emissions performance is competitive with any natural gas play in North America and puts Range in an enviable position globally.
Range's safety performance also improved, with a 30% reduction in recordable incidents for the quarter, the best Q1 performance in the past five years.
Regarding marketing, Range's NGL and condensate business benefited from a strong first quarter.
Market prices improved across the board, and our advantaged portfolio of contracts allowed Range to capture premium pricing and achieve the highest pre-hedge NGL realization since late 2018.
The primary driver for improved pricing in NGLs and condensate was strong demand in a market with decreased supply.
Preliminary results show that Q1 2021 domestic demand for US propane and butane (LPG) was 13% higher year-on-year, while supply decreased by 4%.
Condensate supply in the Northeast is estimated to have decreased by 15% to 20% year-on-year.
Due to these improved fundamentals, the market average NGL barrel price increased significantly during the quarter.
Range's Mont Belvieu equivalent barrel price of $24.83 was 38% higher than the previous quarter and 83% higher compared to the first quarter of 2020.
Propane prices led the increase, rising nearly 60% versus the prior quarter and 140% versus Q1 of 2020.
Range's premium to a Mont Belvieu equivalent barrel increased by approximately $1.50 per barrel compared to the previous quarter, reaching the highest premium to Mont Belvieu in the company's history.
Looking ahead, we anticipate propane and butane market prices will continue to show strong year-on-year gains as storage balances for these NGLs are much tighter compared to last year.
This past winter saw the largest seasonal withdrawal of propane in over a decade, leaving end-of-March propane stocks at a 33% deficit compared to last year and a 17% deficit to the five-year average.
Given the strong international demand due to new chemical capacity coming online and recovering global economies, we believe it will be challenging to replenish US propane stocks to a comfortable level by fall.
As a result, we expect propane prices to trade at levels at or above 60% of WTI crude this fall and the upcoming winter.
On the commercial side, Range entered into new and diverse LPG export-related contracts starting April 1st.
These contracts will increase flexibility, reduce costs, and further enhance realized propane and butane prices, continuing Range's momentum in achieving strong price premiums relative to the market.
We are also optimizing Range's condensate sales portfolio by adding flexibility, improving margins, and ensuring product placement.
As this year progresses and optimization continues through a diverse set of counterparties, we expect our condensate differentials to WTI will continue to improve, further benefiting our liquids area development plan discussed earlier.
Regarding natural gas, cold weather during mid-Q1 resulted in the third coldest February in the past 10 years.
Despite milder weather in January and March, the first quarter's gas-weighted heating degree days ended slightly above the five-year average.
Our diverse transportation portfolio resulted in a Q1 differential of $0.14 under NYMEX, including basis hedging.
We anticipate potential improvements in natural gas pricing due to operators targeting maintenance production levels and year-over-year storage improvements, suggesting an undersupplied market.
Range is on track with its differential guidance of $0.30 to $0.40 for the year, given the positive outlook for natural gas.
Our first quarter results demonstrate a strong start to the year, with improved operational and capital efficiency while meeting environmental and safety goals.
Range's core strategy is to consistently deliver on stated objectives.
The team successfully executed efficient operations, maintained production levels, conducted drilling and completions activities within budget, and implemented margin-enhancing expense management, resulting in significant free cash flow.
We aim to replicate this performance every quarter.
The first quarter's results showcase the advantages of dependable operations, productive wells, and diverse sales points for natural gas, natural gas liquids, and condensate.
Operating cash flow before working capital adjustments was $193 million, compared to $105 million in capital expenditures.
Free cash flow improved significantly compared to previous periods, driven by a 50% increase in pre-hedge realized prices per unit of production, reaching $3.20 per mcfe in Q1.
The realized price per unit exceeded NYMEX Henry Hub by $0.51, due to improved natural gas basis and a 77% increase in NGL price per barrel, which reached $26.35 pre-hedge.
NGL and condensate realizations equate to $4.39 and $8.17 per mcfe respectively, contributing to the premium over Henry Hub.
Range's NGL prices surpassed Mont Belvieu NGL barrel by $1.52, thanks to our unique portfolio of domestic and international sales contracts.
Range consistently focuses on reducing unit costs to enhance margins.
Operating expenses decreased by over 40% year-over-year to $0.09 per unit, due to efficient Marcellus operations and the sale of higher-cost assets.
Cash G&A expenses fell to $28 million or $0.15 per unit in Q1, primarily due to lower compensation costs and targeted spending on essential areas.
Cash interest expense was approximately $55 million, reflecting recent refinancing activities that improved the company's debt maturity profile and liquidity.
Gathering, processing, and transportation expenses increased, but this is a positive result of higher NGL prices leading to improved NGL margins.
Range's processing costs are based on a percentage of NGL revenues, so higher NGL prices result in higher processing costs but also greater overall margins.
Due to rising NGL prices, GP&T expenses for 2021 are trending towards the high end of guidance, but this is more than offset by expected higher NGL revenue at current pricing.
Range has successfully managed its debt profile, reducing bond maturities through 2024 by almost $1.2 billion while improving liquidity to nearly $2 billion.
In Q1, we issued $600 million in new bonds due 2029, which, combined with the reaffirmation of our facilities, provides substantial liquidity and demonstrates our asset value.
We expect to use cash flows to retire upcoming debt maturities, supported by ample liquidity.
In Q1, we redeemed $63 million in near-term senior and senior subordinated notes.
The debt markets have improved significantly, as evidenced by the trading levels of Range's bonds, indicating better access to and cost of capital.
Future debt retirement will primarily be funded by organic free cash flow.
We will manage debt retirement cost-effectively while considering potential refinancing risks.
We may opportunistically redeem bonds if early redemption options become economically viable on a risk-adjusted basis.
Recent liability management has temporarily increased interest expenses but avoided more costly forms of capital that would have diluted shareholder ownership.
Improving our balance sheet remains a key objective, with leverage metrics incorporated into long-term compensation criteria targeting a debt to EBITDA ratio of 1.5 times or better.
Our focus is on creating shareholder value through free cash flow generation and prudent redeployment.
At current commodity prices, we expect to approach our target leverage levels by the end of 2022.
Regarding hedging, we follow a glide path to add positions throughout the year.
We intentionally moved at a deliberate pace in 2020 when adding 2021 hedge positions and plan to follow similar principles this year for 2022 and beyond.
Our goal is to balance prudent cash flow risk management while avoiding hedging away improved supply-demand balance in backward-dated price curves.
Our strategic actions over the past three years have focused on reducing risk while maintaining and enhancing the intrinsic value of our asset base.
We believe Range possesses the largest portfolio of quality inventory in Appalachia, and our actions have preserved and enhanced per-share exposure to that inventory.
We've made significant progress in positioning Range as a more resilient business, as evidenced by our first quarter results, which demonstrate our readiness to capitalize on improved market dynamics.
Summary:
output:
compname reports q1 adjusted non-gaap earnings per share of $0.30.
production for full-year 2021 is expected to average about 2.15 bcfe per day, with about 30% attributed to liquids production.
q1 adjusted non-gaap earnings per share $0.30.
range's 2021 all-in capital budget is $425 million.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Despite global challenges in 2020, we are proud of our team's strong performance across all areas of our company, demonstrating the resilience of Reliance's business model.
I commend everyone for swiftly adapting to changing circumstances, prioritizing customer care, and maintaining an unwavering focus on health and safety, our top core value.
Since 2017, we have been working to integrate our safety culture throughout our entire organization through our SMART Safety initiative.
In 2020, we united as one company to address the unique challenges posed by the COVID-19 pandemic with unprecedented focus.
We not only implemented new protocols to combat virus spread but also improved our overall safety performance, reducing our incident rate by about 23% compared to 2019.
Although this is a significant achievement, we will continue striving until we reach our goal of zero incidents.
I'd like to recognize Karla Lewis and Arthur Ajemyan for their recent well-deserved promotions.
As part of our Board's executive succession plan, Karla was elevated from CFO to President and appointed to our Board of Directors on January 15.
Since joining Reliance in 1992, Karla has consistently displayed excellent leadership and judgment, earning respect from employees and shareholders alike.
Karla's promotion acknowledges her valuable contributions to Reliance.
This new role will allow her to expand her knowledge of our field operations and diversify her experience.
Arthur Ajemyan was also promoted to Vice President and Chief Financial Officer on January 15.
Arthur has excelled in various roles within Reliance's finance and accounting department for over 15 years.
I extend my congratulations to both Karla and Arthur on their new positions and look forward to our continued collaboration in their new capacities.
Let's now review our 2020 performance.
We achieved solid financial results in 2020, driven by consistently strong operational execution despite significant market volatility.
Our performance highlights the strength and resilience of our people and unique business model, as well as our ability to succeed in both favorable and challenging conditions due to our diverse products, markets, and geographical presence.
Our decentralized structure enabled us to quickly adapt to changing market conditions and demand trends.
These factors, combined with pricing discipline and ongoing improvements in our value-added processing capabilities, allowed us to achieve record annual gross profit margins for the second consecutive year at 31.5%, a 120 basis point increase from 2019 and surpassing our estimated sustainable range of 28% to 30%.
We maintained healthy profitability levels despite extremely volatile and challenging market conditions.
For the full year, we generated non-GAAP earnings per share of $7.71, resulting from strong margin discipline and effective expense management, which helped mitigate our decline in profitability.
Following a record year in 2019, we maintained robust cash flow from operations of $1.17 billion in 2020, driven by our profitability and focus on working capital management.
We achieved our company-wide inventory turn goal of 4.7 times based on tons for 2020, thanks to our ongoing efforts to align inventory with current demand levels and our unique advantage of cross-selling inventory among our family of companies.
Consistent with historical trends and our business model's foundation, we source a significant portion of our metal from domestic suppliers.
It is crucial that we continue to support our mill partners, who have consistently stood by Reliance during challenging times.
Our countercyclical cash flow generation allows us to remain flexible and opportunistic in pursuing growth initiatives while simultaneously returning value to our stockholders.
We invested $172 million in capital expenditures in 2020, including various growth opportunities such as our recent toll processing expansion in Texas and Kentucky.
We are introducing our 2021 capital expenditure budget of $245 million, which includes new buildings and projects to expand, upgrade, and maintain many of our operating facilities.
We are installing energy-efficient lighting and solar panels in certain facilities.
Our 2021 budget also includes innovative processing equipment to provide customers with top-quality products and services.
Although COVID-19 has slowed acquisition activity overall, we continue to see a healthy pipeline of potential candidates as we broaden our view on prospective growth opportunities.
We evaluate opportunities based on strict criteria to ensure a strong fit within our family of companies.
Regarding stockholder returns, we repurchased $337.3 million worth of common stock at an average cost of $91.80 per share and paid $164.1 million in dividends to shareholders in 2020.
We have maintained regular quarterly dividend payments for 61 consecutive years without suspension or reduction.
We have increased our dividend 28 times since our 1994 IPO, including the most recent 10% increase for the first quarter of 2021.
Looking ahead to the remainder of 2021, Reliance will continue to execute and refine our proven model that has led to industry-leading results for many decades.
During the past 12 months, we've streamlined our operations to be more efficient while maintaining our competitive advantage and the key aspects of our business that make Reliance a dependable partner.
We'll continue to prioritize enhancing our products, expanding into new markets and regions, while maintaining strict pricing policies, careful cost management, strategic inventory control, organic expansion, and innovation.
Throughout the previous year, it became clear that our clients depend on us to provide increased support during challenging times, often requiring more frequent and substantial assistance.
I frequently state, and will reiterate, that America will need to rely on Reliance for its rebuilding efforts.
As a crucial business, we were able to continue operations throughout the COVID-19 crisis, with our 2020 sales volume decreasing by only 10.8% compared to the previous year.
Our average selling price dropped by 9.6% in 2020 compared to 2019, due to declining factory prices for most of our products during the first three quarters of the year.
Despite these negative factors, we achieved a record-high gross profit margin in 2020.
In the final quarter of 2020, strong demand in most of our target markets resulted in our sales volume declining by only 1.3% compared to the previous quarter.
This was the smallest fourth-quarter seasonal decline we've seen in a decade and significantly exceeded our projections.
Despite typical holiday-related customer closures and fewer shipping days in the fourth quarter, we experienced robust demand throughout the period as economic recovery gained momentum.
Driven by solid demand and increasing input costs, metal prices improved as factory price increases for many of our products accelerated throughout the fourth quarter, with some carbon steel products nearly doubling in price, leading to a 4.6% increase in our average selling price compared to the third quarter of 2020, surpassing our expectations.
The favorable demand and pricing conditions in the fourth quarter contributed to our record gross profit margin of 33%, a 60 basis point improvement from the third quarter of 2020.
On a non-GAAP FIFO basis, which we believe best reflects our daily operating performance, our gross profit margin of 33.6% increased by 180 basis points from 31.8% in the third quarter of 2020.
Our record gross profit margin demonstrates the exceptional performance of our field managers who effectively implemented price increases when mills announced them, before receiving higher-cost inventory, pushing our gross profit margin above already strong levels resulting from our focus on higher-margin orders.
While we are very pleased with our record fourth quarter and full-year gross profit margin, we still believe our estimated sustainable gross profit margin range of 28% to 30% is appropriate as we navigate the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic and operate in this uncertain environment.
Nonetheless, maintaining our strong gross profit margin remains a fundamental aspect of our business model.
We are confident that our managers will continue to capitalize on the significant investments we've made to expand and improve our value-added processing capabilities.
In fact, one of the key factors contributing to our record gross profit margin for the full year was our value-added processing capabilities, which have expanded in recent years due to our substantial investments in cutting-edge equipment.
Although the percentage of orders with value-added processing decreased to approximately 49% from 51% in 2019 due to pandemic-related changes in product mix, processed orders continue to stabilize our margins in challenging markets with declining demand and pricing trends.
I will now provide a brief overview of the conditions in our key end markets.
Demand in nonresidential construction, our largest market, remained relatively stable during the fourth quarter due to ongoing healthy bidding activity for new projects and the resumption of projects that had been suspended earlier in the year.
We've observed quoting activity in expected areas such as infrastructure projects, schools, utilities, water and power, strip malls, and data and distribution centers.
Demand for our automotive toll processing services was strong, with activity returning to pre-pandemic levels in the fourth quarter as automotive manufacturers and steel and aluminum mills continued to increase production following reopenings after COVID-19 shutdowns in the second quarter of 2020.
We began operations at our new facility in Kentucky in late November and recently started construction on a new greenfield tolling facility in Texas, both focusing on carbon steel tolling to support increased capacity for our toll processing customers, who are primarily metal producers and their end users.
Demand in heavy industry for both agricultural and construction equipment rebounded to solid levels in the fourth quarter as production schedules continued to ramp up following customer reopenings from COVID-19-related shutdowns and to meet equipment dealer restocking needs.
Semiconductor demand steadily improved from the third quarter of 2020, and the market continues to be one of our strongest performers.
Demand in commercial aerospace further declined in the fourth quarter as a direct result of reduced air travel due to COVID-19, which has lowered airplane production rates.
We believe the fourth quarter represented the lowest point for this sector.
However, demand in the military, defense, and space segments of our aerospace business remained stable at solid levels throughout the fourth quarter.
Lastly, demand in the energy sector, primarily oil and natural gas, remained under pressure in the fourth quarter of 2020.
Throughout 2020, we implemented prudent cost-reduction measures, including the closure of certain facilities, which helped improve our overall efficiency and position us to support a recovery in this market.
We are optimistic about both demand and pricing trends in the first quarter of 2021, as we have experienced strength in both areas so far this quarter.
Arthur will now review our financial results.
I'll begin with our sales discussion.
Fourth quarter 2020 sales decreased by 12.8% compared to the same period last year as our markets continued to recover following the reopening of the economy.
Approximately half of the decline in our sales can be attributed to our businesses supporting the commercial aerospace and energy end markets, as evidenced by the disproportionately larger decreases in our sales of aluminum and alloy products.
For the full year of 2020, sales decreased by 19.7% compared to 2019.
About half of the sales decline was due to lower shipping volumes across all major end markets we serve, and the remaining half was due to lower average selling prices.
Nonetheless, the rebounding demand and improved pricing during the latter half of 2020 helped offset the yearly decrease in our revenue.
We achieved a record-breaking quarterly gross profit margin of 33% in Q4 2020, which was 60 basis points higher than both Q3 2020 and Q4 2019, as well as a full-year record gross profit margin of 31.5% for 2020, surpassing our previous annual record of 30.3% in 2019 by 120 basis points.
Our non-GAAP FIFO gross profit margin in the last quarter of 2020 increased by 450 basis points compared to the same period in 2019, and for the entire year 2020, it rose by 280 basis points from the previous year.
We experienced a LIFO expense of $15.5 million in Q4 2020 due to rapidly rising mill costs for most of our products.
Nevertheless, for the full year 2020, we still recorded LIFO income of $22 million as our inventory cost at year-end remained below the levels at the beginning of the year.
This is in contrast to the LIFO income of $81 million and $156 million recorded in Q4 and the full year of 2019, respectively.
We concluded 2020 with a LIFO reserve of $115.6 million on our balance sheet.
Given current market conditions, we anticipate an annual LIFO expense of $340 million in 2021.
In line with our accounting practices, we distribute our annual estimate proportionally across each quarter.
Therefore, our current projected LIFO expense for Q1 2021 is $85 million.
As we've done in previous years, we will revise our expectations each quarter based on inventory cost and metal pricing trends.
Our Q4 non-GAAP SG&A expenses decreased by $51 million or 9.9% compared to Q4 2019, while shipments reduced by 7.9%.
For the entire year, same-store SG&A expenses dropped by $241 million or 11.5%, alongside a 10.8% reduction in shipments.
The reduction in SG&A expenses was observed across all major expense categories.
As we've mentioned before, about 60% to 65% of our SG&A expenses are related to personnel.
Regarding the 11.5% year-over-year decrease in same-store SG&A expenses, approximately half of the reduction was personnel-related, with our headcount falling by 14% compared to the previous year.
Additionally, lower incentive pay due to reduced gross profit and pre-tax income levels contributed to the decrease in our compensation costs.
Although we're starting Q1 2021 with a more efficient expense structure, we expect our expenses to increase from Q4 2020 due to strong volume and pricing trends, in line with seasonal patterns.
I will discuss our Q1 2021 outlook for demand and pricing shortly.
For the full year 2020, our effective income tax rate decreased to 22.1% from 24% in 2019, primarily due to our lower pre-tax income in 2020.
We currently expect our full year 2021 effective income tax rate to be 24%.
Our robust gross profit margin and effective expense management resulted in earnings of $2.01 per diluted share in Q4 2020, significantly exceeding our projected range of $1.30 to $1.40 per diluted share, but down 17.6% from $2.44 in Q4 2019, mainly due to reduced demand related to the pandemic, with commercial aerospace and energy end market sales significantly contributing to the decline.
Compared to Q3 2020, Q4 non-GAAP earnings per diluted share of $2.01 increased by 7.5% from $1.87, owing to improved pricing, strong gross profit margin, and recovering demand in most end markets.
Shifting focus to our balance sheet and cash flow.
We generated strong operational cash flow of $230.2 million in Q4 due to profitable operations and effective working capital management, including our focus on optimizing inventory levels.
At year-end, our total outstanding debt was $1.66 billion, resulting in a net debt-to-EBITDA ratio of 1.1 times.
Additionally, at year-end, we had no outstanding borrowings on our $1.5 billion revolving credit facility.
As mentioned in the previous quarter, we significantly enhanced our liquidity position through the successful completion of both our $900 million senior notes offering and amended/restated $1.5 billion five-year unsecured revolving credit facility.
The facility amendment, combined with the proceeds from the notes offering, provides us with ample liquidity and an improved debt maturity profile.
I'll now discuss our outlook.
While economic uncertainty due to the COVID-19 pandemic persists, favorable market conditions have continued into Q1 2021, with improving demand and additional mill price increases on many carbon and stainless steel products.
This environment allows us to maintain higher gross profit margins as we increase our selling prices before receiving higher-cost metal in our inventory.
We expect these favorable conditions to persist throughout Q1.
Given these favorable conditions and typical seasonal improvements, we estimate our Q1 2021 sales volume will increase by 10% to 12% compared to Q4 2020.
We also anticipate our average selling price in Q1 2021 will rise by 12% to 14% compared to Q4 2020.
Based on these expectations, we currently project non-GAAP earnings per diluted share in the range of $3.40 to $3.50 for Q1 2021.
In conclusion, we are very satisfied with our Q4 2020 financial and operational results.
The exceptional performance of all our employees greatly contributed to our success in 2020.
Their efforts, combined with our resilient business model and disciplined strategy execution, resulted in another quarter of solid profitability and cash flow, enabling us to continue supporting our growth and stockholder return priorities.
Summary:
output:
reliance steel & aluminum q4 earnings per share $2.01.
q4 non-gaap earnings per share $2.01.
qtrly average selling price per ton sold $1,683 up 4.6% versus q3.
sees q1 non-gaap earnings per share $3.40 to $3.50.
qtrly diluted earnings per share $2.01.
experienced ongoing improvements in demand in nearly all of end markets it serves in quarter.
cautiously optimistic demand for non-residential construction activity in co's space will continue at q4 levels in q1.
maintains its positive outlook for aerospace defense market.
cautiously optimistic that demand in commercial aerospace may begin to slowly recover in latter half of 2021.
demand in energy market remained under pressure in q4 with modest improvement expected in q1.
estimates that tons sold will be up 10% to 12% in q1 of 2021 compared to q4 of 2020.
estimates its average selling price per ton sold for q1 of 2021 will be up 12% to 14% compared to q4 of 2020.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Alternative financial measures not conforming to GAAP should not be used alone or as replacements for GAAP-based performance indicators.
Please be aware that information shared during this call is only current as of today.
The company has no plans or obligation to provide updates on this information in light of future events or circumstances.
This call is being recorded and will be made available on the company's website later today.
While monitoring the Delta variant closely, we're encouraged by economic reopening, housing market strength, and our business's exceptional growth and performance.
Robust operating income and increased portfolio values led to outstanding Q2 financials, with GAAP earnings of $0.66 per diluted share, far exceeding our $0.18 per share dividend.
This resulted in a 6.5% rise in our GAAP book value, reaching $11.46 per share by June 30th.
Our 2021 performance so far demonstrates our ability to grow profitably while fulfilling our mission of providing quality housing access to all Americans.
This mission focuses on borrowers underserved by government loan programs or potentially excluded entirely.
Our residential and business lending teams focus on the non-agency mortgage market, a sector largely overlooked recently due to lack of Federal Reserve stimulus.
The non-agency market encompasses residential mortgages outside government-backed programs.
By targeting this market rather than specific borrower profiles, our business isn't tied to homeownership rate trends.
Redwood now offers a comprehensive product range serving both consumers and housing investors in a large market.
Many predict significant increases in residential non-agency origination volumes for 2021, up from $435 billion in 2020.
This increase is just starting to reflect potential benefits from regulatory pullback on non-owner occupied loans, which could significantly boost our sector.
We maintained strong Q2 results despite more challenging market conditions than Q1.
Interest rates rose in residential lending, largely due to uncertainty about potential changes in Fed support for the agency mortgage market.
Resulting intense competition and declining refinance activity led to industry-wide margin contraction.
Strong competition effects were amplified by pro-cyclical and supply chain inflation signs, with yield curve shifts causing significant hedging and execution costs for large mortgage pipeline managers, including us.
Despite these challenges, we locked nearly $4 billion in jumbo loans in Q2 at margins in the upper range of our historical targets.
The business purpose lending market became more competitive in Q2, with new entrants using rate sheets to enter the space, particularly for smaller bridge and rental loan products.
The trend of moving from apartments to single-family homes shows no signs of slowing, despite recent reopening of major metropolitan areas.
This has led to a scarcity of high-quality homes, with strong demand from both investors and consumers.
In many regions, rent growth has significantly lagged behind home price appreciation, highlighting the scarcity value of quality housing and multiple groups' focus on acquiring single-family homes.
Capitalizing on its reputation as a flexible and dependable lifecycle lender, CoreVest, our BPL platform, surpassed $500 million in fundings for the quarter, balancing single-family rental and bridge originations.
Our continued strong performance in this challenging environment showcases our strategic foundation and what makes Redwood unique.
Our mortgage banking businesses offer complementary products that generate stable earnings streams.
Our investment portfolio continues to show significant potential as the economy recovers.
Our credit discipline and ability to create our own assets remain key differentiators.
Our strategic foundation has enabled returns significantly outpacing our growing dividends.
In the first half of 2021, about 70% of Redwood's adjusted revenue came from mortgage banking operations, with the remaining 30% from our investment portfolio.
We expect mortgage banking and our taxable subsidiaries to continue driving strong earnings in the future.
The revenue generated through mortgage banking is nearly double the percentage contribution of recent years, highlighting the ongoing shift in our business model as we adapt to changing market conditions.
This also supports continued book value expansion over time, with retained earnings providing a zero-cost avenue for capital formation, reducing our marginal funding needs and contrasting with others in the space managing their balance sheets.
By continuously reinvesting in our infrastructure, both organically and through partnerships, we have a clear path to achieving transformative scale.
Across our enterprise, we've cultivated a talented and motivated workforce and embraced technology to serve our customers more efficiently than ever before.
A prime example of this approach is last quarter's launch of our early-stage investment platform, RWT Horizons, which Dash will discuss in more detail.
Looking ahead, we continue to improve, invest in our people and infrastructure, and approach our markets with a service standard that sets us apart from competitors.
We're excited by recent regulatory changes that have made the non-agency mortgage market more relevant than it has been in years.
Our aim is to build a business that serves an important public mission, scales profitably, and generates attractive returns for our shareholders.
Our Q2 results demonstrate continued strategic progress and strong operational momentum.
While our comprehensive non-agency market presence benefited from ongoing strength in housing and credit markets, we combined these macro tailwinds with both new and familiar homegrown elements.
Our team's typical efficient execution was enhanced by significant advancements in our technology infrastructure, both organic and through new partnerships already showing results.
The end product was another quarter of substantial outperformance.
As Chris mentioned, benchmark rates remain a key focus for the markets.
The Q2 rate increase has almost completely reversed, but uncertainty around government support levels for agency mortgages may moderate borrower refinance activity typically seen in such a rally.
Given this context, it's crucial to examine the main profitability drivers across our platforms.
As Chris noted, our target markets continue to expand as home price trends, evolving consumer housing demand, and significant regulatory shifts drive growth in non-agency's true potential market.
While we're not immune to MBS price movements versus benchmark rates, our diverse distribution channels and unique product mix allow us to benefit from various demand drivers.
For instance, despite margin compression elsewhere during Q2, we maintained strong margins and volumes across both residential and business purpose lending.
In fact, reduced demand for agency mortgages represents another potential advantage for our business.
Mortgage originators are still expanding capacity to meet pent-up jumbo borrower demand, and as nationwide home prices rise along with preference for single-family detached rental housing, our BPL offerings remain highly sought after and our residential business continues to expand geographically.
Our equity is now at its highest level in at least a decade, pushing more loan demand above conforming loan limits and into Redwood's target market.
Our updated investor supplement indicates that 13 states now have significantly more loans year-to-date compared to the two years before the pandemic.
These states account for 35% of our year-to-date volume in locks, a trend we are monitoring closely.
Market analysts now predict single-family home price appreciation for 2021 to reach 14% for existing homes and 16% for new homes.
Even if this growth slows as expected in 2022, we anticipate more areas across the country will become non-agency markets.
The regulatory landscape is another crucial factor.
The changing regulations are expected to substantially increase the Qualified Mortgage (QM) cohort, significantly benefiting high-quality expanded credit borrowers.
Moreover, restrictions implemented earlier this year on GSE purchases of non-owner-occupied loans could expand the non-agency market by an estimated $25 to $35 billion annually.
There is potential for the non-agency market to further improve access to credit, particularly impacting first-time homebuyers and low-to-moderate income borrowers.
The availability of high-quality rental housing, including single-family detached homes, is also crucial, partially addressed by an increase in custom-built projects.
As previously discussed, housing supply has not kept pace with demand, and building material costs remain high despite some moderation, contributing to significant home price increases.
Single-family rental homes can satisfy the demand for more space in desirable neighborhoods at a monthly cost that more consumers can afford.
These supply-demand dynamics are reflected in record-high single-family rental occupancy rates, averaging 95% across the US, with single-family rents consistently exceeding multifamily rents since early last year.
Our second quarter results support this broader market context.
Operational highlights for the quarter included achieving our second-highest level of jumbo locks ever and our highest BPL volume since late 2019.
As Brooke will explain, book value increased by 6.5%, driven by asset appreciation through fair value changes and retained earnings from mortgage banking income at our taxable REIT subsidiary.
Our platforms collectively distributed $3.6 billion of loans through direct sales and four securitizations.
Following a record-breaking first quarter, our residential business recorded $3.9 billion in lock volume in Q2.
As expected, purchase money loans were a key driver, representing 60% of the quarter's lock volume.
Despite interest rate challenges and competitive pressures affecting GSE-eligible production, the business achieved margins at the high end of our historical target range of 75 to 100 basis points, reflecting our diverse distribution channels and strong pipeline management amid broader market volatility.
In the second quarter, we sold $1.8 billion of loans and completed three Sequoia securitizations totaling $1.5 billion.
Despite rate fluctuations during the quarter and a dramatic flattening of the yield curve after the June Fed meeting, our teams' end-to-end coordination and efficiency remained a true competitive advantage.
The flexibility of our securitization program combined with whole-loan distribution allows for further scaling by enabling us to be consistently present in the market.
Once again, we were quicker to market than our competitors in distributing our pipeline during the second quarter.
Another encouraging metric was the contribution of Redwood Choice, our expanded prime product, to overall volumes.
Choice accounted for 15% of our locks in the second quarter, a significant increase from 5% in Q1.
Pre-pandemic, Choice represented up to 40% of our locks, reminding us of this channel's potential significance.
In recent public statements, we've continued to emphasize changes to the QM rules that we believe will be a key driver for Choice's resurgence.
If safely adopted, the new rules focusing on mortgage rate as the determinant of QM status will allow another segment of high-quality borrowers to more easily qualify for competitive rates, an important step highlighting the non-agency market's true potential to serve a broader range of consumers.
We are actively engaging with our seller base to bring this to fruition.
These macro trends also present significant opportunities for CoreVest, our business purpose lending platform.
The second quarter was particularly productive in BPL as we advanced several key initiatives, most notably completing our strategic investment in Churchill Finance.
CoreVest originated $527 million overall in the second quarter, a 37% increase from Q1.
Our funding mix consisted of $312 million in single-family rental loans and $215 million in bridge loans.
Bridge production increased by over 60% from Q1, marking the fourth consecutive quarter of growth, driven by increased borrower usage of credit lines and several build-for-rent and multifamily loans becoming available for funding.
The second quarter's BPL origination mix reflects the strength of our multi-product strategy, resulting in high levels of repeat borrowers, including those using more than one of our loan products.
In total, 67% of originations in the second quarter were from repeat customers, and the pipeline remains strong with a consistent mix of new loans and refinance opportunities.
SFR production remained strong in the second quarter, with fundings up 23% from Q1.
As discussed in our previous call, the pipeline remains robust, and execution has benefited from an increasingly favorable securitization market.
We completed our first broadly syndicated CoreVest securitization of the year in April, achieving all-time low credit spreads with a deep bench of investors.
That record was short-lived, as last week's follow-on transaction once again priced at all-time lows, including a spread of 57 basis points on the AAA-rated securities.
As we've often seen, this type of execution inevitably attracts additional competition, which we view as an opportunity for CoreVest to further distinguish itself as the BPL market's preferred lender.
We have high expectations for our upcoming refreshed client portal, particularly its new user interface, which will simplify document uploading and loan progress tracking for our clients.
Additionally, we continue to leverage our advantages as a flexible lifecycle lender, refining our product suite to meet the end-to-end needs of an expanding group of sophisticated housing investors.
Highlighting this progress is our partnership with Churchill, which we expect will diversify our sourcing channels, particularly focusing on smaller-balance single-family rental and bridge loans.
We have now closed our first purchase of bridge loans and SFR loans from Churchill and see an attractive near-term pipeline to complement our direct lending products.
During periods of increased competition, it's crucial to emphasize the value of an institutional platform like CoreVest in a market that is still developing in many ways.
We have now completed optional calls on two CoreVest securitizations, refinancing many of the underlying loans made 5 or more years ago.
Many borrowers have been with the platform for at least that long as CoreVest continues to support their growth and development.
Such a track record is significant and holds immense intangible value in the competitive landscape.
Our newest initiative, RWT Horizons, is keeping pace with our enterprise-wide progress.
Since formally launching Horizons earlier this year, we have completed five investments and are evaluating an exciting pipeline of new opportunities.
Our recent direct investments include a platform using blockchain technology for the non-agency market and a tech-enabled residential construction management company.
It's encouraging to see concrete progress with our new collaborators at this early stage.
Liquid Mortgage has secured a crucial patent covering most of its business plan, a significant advancement in our joint efforts to apply blockchain technology to the non-agency ecosystem.
Rent Room and Rent Butter have had productive quarters, meeting or surpassing their planned product development and rollout goals.
These partnerships exemplify the intellectual collaboration that generates true alpha for all involved parties.
We are working directly with Liquid Mortgage to develop the necessary processes for safely putting mortgages on blockchain, and jointly engaging other key industry stakeholders.
For Rent Room and Rent Butter, two investments sourced through CoreVest's borrower network, we are creating synergies with our broader client base.
We're excited to work closely with those at the forefront of innovation in our markets.
As previously mentioned, our second quarter 2021 results demonstrate the resilience of our model and continued strength across our entire platform.
We reported a GAAP book value per share of $11.46 as of June 30th, representing a 6.5% increase from the previous quarter.
The main factors contributing to the $0.70 increase in book value per share were GAAP earnings of $90 million or $0.77 per basic share, partially offset by our quarterly dividend of $0.18 per share.
We're pleased to have maintained strong momentum from the first quarter, achieving a total economic return on book value of 19% for the first half of 2021.
Our economic return highlights not only our growth in book value but also our dividend growth, which we increased by another 13% in the second quarter.
This quarter saw particularly strong results from our business purpose mortgage banking operations, delivering a 52% after-tax operating return on capital with a net operating contribution of $20 million, an 80% increase from Q1 on a 37% rise in origination volumes.
Income from residential mortgage banking operations decreased from the historic first quarter level but still delivered an after-tax operating return of 17%.
Even though loan purchase commitments were down 22%, Q2 still marks our second-highest volume on record.
To reiterate Dash's point, gross margins remained at the high end of our historical target range despite challenging macro conditions that affected securitization execution and increased hedging costs compared to the first quarter.
Regarding the investment portfolio, we had $49 million of positive investment fair value changes, primarily from our RPL assets, due to further spread tightening and improved credit performance this quarter, which I'll elaborate on shortly.
Net interest income increased by approximately 20% or nearly $5 million from the first quarter of 2021 due to higher average loan balances and inventory at our operating businesses, increased yield maintenance income from SFR securities, growth in our bridge loan portfolio, and reduced interest expenses from our investment portfolio.
On the tax front, we had REIT taxable income of $0.11 per share compared to $0.09 in the first quarter, mainly due to higher net interest income.
Our taxable REIT subsidiaries earned $0.27 per share in Q2, down from $0.47 in Q1.
The decrease was primarily caused by lower mortgage banking income, partially offset by reduced operating expenses, resulting in a $5 million lower tax provision for the quarter.
Combined, our operating businesses generated an annualized after-tax return of over 28% in Q2, utilizing $483 million of average capital.
As a reminder, these earnings can be reinvested into our operating businesses or paid as a dividend to the REIT.
This quarter, we continued to focus on higher-margin businesses that produce strategic assets for our investment portfolio.
Specifically, we allocated $45 million of capital to Brisbane during the quarter and $50 million to SFR securities in core loans.
Year-to-date, we've reduced the size of our third-party investment portfolio through opportunistic sales.
Working capital for our mortgage banking businesses represented less than 30% of our allocated capital but produced approximately 65% of our adjusted revenue for the second quarter.
As Chris mentioned, the proportion of adjusted revenue from our mortgage banking operations has been growing in recent years, facilitating returns that significantly outpace our increasing dividends.
Total portfolio returns rose due to improved credit and faster prepayment speeds on securities we hold at a discount to face value.
Higher prepayment speeds continue to benefit these portfolios and allow us to accelerate our call options within Sequoia and CoreVest Securities.
We exercised call rights on three Sequoia securitizations and one CoreVest securitization during the second quarter, acquiring $83 million of seasoned jumbo loans and $45 million of seasoned SFR loans, all at par, which benefited book value by $0.05 per share.
We estimate about $250 million to $300 million of expected call activity across CoreVest and Sequoia through the remainder of the year, and at current market conditions, we expect the underlying loans can generally be sold or resecuritized well above their par value, potentially creating further upside to earnings and book value of approximately $0.68 per share for 2021.
Furthermore, we project another $2 billion of loans that could become callable by the end of 2024, with the majority expected to occur by the end of 2022, potentially adding another $0.63 to $0.65 per share on average to book value, depending on execution.
Net delinquencies in our portfolio continue to improve, with new forbearance requests near zero.
Specifically, Choice and RPL securities experienced improved 90-day delinquencies during the quarter, with Select remaining flat from Q1 at very low levels of 80 basis points.
It's worth noting the improved delinquency trends, with our RPL securities portfolio experiencing 60-day delinquencies now below pre-COVID levels, and voluntary prepayment speeds continuing to exceed our original modeled expectations.
LTVs in the portfolio are low and continue to improve or remain stable, and average coupons exceed our current mortgage rate, which should provide options to help distressed borrowers and keep actual losses low.
At quarter-end, our balance sheet and funding profile were in excellent shape following several liability and capital management actions taken during the quarter.
We added over $750 million of financing capacity to support growth of our operating platforms, including the refinance of a $242 million bridge loan financing, which contributed to a roughly 100 basis point cost of funds improvement for our overall investment portfolio.
Importantly, the second quarter marked another record for Redwood with combined $3.3 billion of residential whole loan sales and securitizations, underscoring our ability to source and distribute in size.
Our recourse leverage was slightly higher at 2.2 times at the end of the second quarter as we incurred additional warehouse borrowings to finance higher loan inventory.
At June 30th, our unrestricted cash was $421 million, which is over half the size of our outstanding marginable debt, and at quarter-end, our investable capital was $175 million, not including $100 million of incremental capital generated from a secured term financing we closed in early July.
To conclude, I'll provide an update on our 2021 financial outlook.
