We continue to see potential for growth in our book value, both from anticipated call activity in our investment portfolio and through our ability to grow and retain earnings at our taxable REIT subsidiary.
We encourage you to review the supplemental quarterly materials we published earlier today, which provide more detailed and updated guidance for the remainder of the year to highlight some of the key factors that support our financial narrative.
Our confidence in achieving our guidance is based on sustainable trends we're observing across our businesses.
As Chris and Dash have outlined, the key themes driving our performance include increasing our market share, using technology to improve efficiency, allocating more capital to our higher ROE operating platforms, continuing to create value through the investment portfolio, and using partnerships, M&A, and other growth strategies to further our efforts in our target markets.
Looking ahead, we remain on track to maintain the robust volumes we've seen through the first half of the year, anticipating another $6 to $8 billion of jumbo locks and approximately $1 billion of BPL originations for the second half of the year, which would nearly double the volume of that business year-over-year.
For perspective, the second half volumes on the residential front approach our full-year volume from just a couple of years ago.
We've demonstrated our ability to successfully grow not only our origination volume but also our market share, and we believe we can continue to do that across our platform and in each of its underlying channels.
Small changes in market share can significantly impact our overall profitability and scale, and that's what we plan to achieve over time.
For the remainder of the year, we anticipate generating an adjusted return on allocated capital between 20% to 25% from our mortgage banking operations, and 10% to 12% for the investment portfolio.
As credit spreads have tightened significantly and fair values have since increased, this forward yield on the investment portfolio, which aligns with our forecast at the beginning of the year, reflects improvements in our financing costs and capital optimization.
Finally, regarding potential sources of book value upside, we began the year with $444 million of net accretable discount in our portfolio, and even after growing book value by $1.55 per share or roughly $175 million since then, we have approximately $2.60 per share or $300 million of remaining discount in the portfolio that we have the potential to recognize over time.
Summary:
output:
q2 gaap earnings per share $0.66.
gaap book value per common share was $11.46 at june 30, 2021, up 6.5% from march 31, 2021.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:I will be giving a presentation today alongside Eric Thornburg, who serves as Chairman of the Board, President and CEO, as well as Andy Gere, who holds the position of President and COO at San Jose Water Company
Accompanying slides for our presentation can be found on our company website at www
These statements are based on the company's estimates and assumptions, considering its experience, historical patterns, current situation, and anticipated future developments, as well as other factors deemed appropriate by the company given the circumstances
I will now hand the call over to Eric
My name is Eric Thornburg, and I have the privilege of serving as Chairman, President and CEO of SJW Group
We have now been dealing with the COVID-19 pandemic for over 13 months
There's a growing sense of guarded optimism that we've seen the worst of the pandemic, and we're beginning to plan for a safe return to our offices and work locations
Throughout the past year, we've gained valuable insights about our teams, our company culture, our adaptability, and what we can accomplish through remote work
Despite facing numerous challenges, our employees have embodied our mission as trusted professionals who are passionate about providing essential, high-quality water and exceptional service to families and communities, while also protecting the environment and ensuring a fair return for shareholders
Looking forward, we are preparing for a gradual return to our offices and work sites, building upon the risk-based approach that has served us well over the past year
We will follow the safety guidelines provided by our national, state, and local health authorities
Our primary objective remains unchanged throughout the pandemic: to fulfill our public health mission as a water service provider while protecting our employees, customers, and communities
The executive leadership team and I eagerly anticipate the day when we can personally express our gratitude to all employees and meet the new team members who have joined us over the past year without having physically been in our offices
We are dedicated to implementing a safe return that capitalizes on the benefits of remote work while providing a secure physical environment that fosters collaboration and nurtures our company culture
The extreme cold and winter weather that hit Texas in February demonstrated the advantages of being a pure-play water and wastewater utility with national reach, geographic diversity, and locally focused operations
SJW Group was able to utilize resources from our East and West Coast operations to support our Texas operation during the event
Our communications teams from both coasts assisted with customer notifications, website updates, social media posts, and news media communications, while our operations and safety teams provided crucial incident support
The direct experience of our Connecticut and Maine teams in dealing with cold weather events proved valuable in our response
In California, the majority of the rainfall season is now behind us
We have experienced below-average precipitation for the second year in a row, which is impacting our available surface water supplies from our watershed
The extremely low precipitation in the Santa Cruz Mountains this winter has significantly affected our local surface water operations, both in terms of storm runoff collected at creek intakes for immediate treatment and the volume of water we've been able to store in our Lake Elsman reservoir for later release
For the first time in my 25-year tenure at San Jose Water, we are temporarily shutting down our Montevina Water Treatment Plant due to low supply
We will resume operations at the plant when hydrologic conditions permit
To provide context, the chart on Slide 10 illustrates the historical surface water production in blue compared to the associated rainfall at Lake Elsman in red over the same period
As you can see, there has only been one other year, 2014, where we observed such low levels of rainfall and surface water production
Fortunately, the regional water supply situation is somewhat better, and despite the low rainfall and snowpack this winter, the total groundwater storage at the end of the first quarter remained at Stage One or normal of Valley Water's water shortage contingency plan
Based on available recharge and the current rate of withdrawal, Valley Water reports that it expects to remain in the normal range through year-end by supplementing normal supplies with additional imported water
This is positive news for the upcoming summer months when demand is typically highest, and we anticipate adequate supplies to serve our customers
Due to the water supply situation in California, we expect increases in our operating costs as we rely more on purchased water from our wholesaler to meet customer needs in 2021
Currently, every billion gallons of purchased water costs the company an additional $4.2 million compared to using our own supply sources
As a direct result of the water supply outlook and in the interest of full transparency, we are announcing guidance of $1.85 to $2.05 per diluted share for 2021
This projection assumes no additional company-produced surface water in California for the remainder of 2021
We are currently updating our strategic water supply plan to evaluate current and future supply reliability and resiliency
Our ongoing California general rate case proceeding will address the impact of surface water availability
Prudent management of our business and financial resources continues to be essential to our growth and ability to return capital to shareholders
We take pride in having consistently paid a dividend for over 77 years and increasing the annual dividend for each of the past 53 years, delivering value to our shareholders
Following Jim's comments, I will discuss regulatory and other business-related issues.
Our Q1 operational results reflect newly approved revenues from our 2019 California general rate case.
Revenue increases were authorized in Connecticut and Maine for water infrastructure improvements, and customer growth occurred in Texas.
These gains were counterbalanced by reduced customer usage, the effects of a February ice storm in Texas, and decreased availability of affordable surface water due to dry conditions in California, as Eric and Andy mentioned earlier.
Q1 revenue reached $114.8 million, representing a 1% increase compared to Q1 2020.
The quarter's net income was $2.6 million, or $0.09 per diluted share, showing an 8% rise from the $2.4 million, or $0.08 per diluted share, reported in Q1 2020.
The quarterly increase in diluted earnings per share was mainly due to cumulative rate hikes of $0.08 per share, accumulated cost reductions of $0.04 per share, a $0.04 per share tax benefit, and a $0.03 per share rise in nonregulated income.
This per-share increase was partially mitigated by a $0.08 per share decline in customer usage.
Customer rebates in Texas amounting to $0.02 per share related to the February ice storm, a $0.02 per share reduction in surface water availability, and a $0.06 per share increase in depreciation and amortization also offset the gains.
Our revenue decrease resulted from a $2.8 million drop in customer usage.
Additionally, customer rebates in Texas lowered revenue by $700,000, and net adjustments in certain balancing and memorandum accounts reduced revenue by $600,000.
These decreases were partly offset by $2.8 million in cumulative rate increases and $500,000 in revenue from new customers.
Total water production costs for Q1 2021 were slightly lower compared to Q1 2020.
This minor reduction was primarily due to $800,000 in lower average per-unit costs for purchased water, groundwater extraction, and energy charges, along with reduced usage, partially counterbalanced by a $700,000 increase from purchasing additional water supplies to compensate for the lower surface water production during the quarter.
Other operating expenses rose by $1.6 million or 2% for the quarter, mainly due to $2.1 million in higher depreciation related to utility plant additions, and $200,000 in increased maintenance expenses, partially offset by $400,000 in reduced general and administrative expenses.
Furthermore, in Q1 2020, we incurred $400,000 in merger-related expenses, which were not present in 2021.
The effective consolidated income tax rates were approximately negative 52% and 15% for the quarters ending March 31, 2021, and 2020, respectively.
The lower effective tax rate for Q1 2021 was primarily due to excess tax benefits related to share-based payment awards, state tax credits, and other discrete tax items.
Regarding our capital expenditure program, we added $46.7 million in company-funded utility plant during Q1 2021.
This represents 20% of our total planned capital expenditures for 2021.
From a financial perspective, Q1 2021 cash flows from operations increased by 321% compared to Q1 2020.
This change was mainly due to an $8.3 million decrease in accounts payable and accrued expenses, a $2.2 million increase in accounts receivable collections, and a $1.5 million rise in net income adjusted for non-cash items.
Additionally, in 2020, we made a $5 million upfront payment to the city of Cupertino for our service concession agreement and refunded $8.4 million to California ratepayers from our 2017 Tax Act Memorandum Account, which did not occur in 2021.
In March 2021, SJW Group issued approximately 1.2 million new shares in an offering that raised net proceeds of about $66.9 million.
The proceeds were used to repay outstanding balances on the company's credit facilities and for general corporate purposes.
Moreover, in April 2021, the company's California subsidiary entered into a $140 million credit agreement, and the Texas subsidiary entered into a $5 million credit agreement, both with JPMorgan Chase Bank.
These new credit agreements replaced the existing JPMorgan Chase credit agreements, which were paid off and set to mature and expire on June 1, 2021.
At the end of Q1, we had $138 million available on our bank lines of credit for short-term financing of utility plant additions and operating activities.
The average borrowing rate on line of credit advances during the quarter was 1.42%.
SJW Group continues to implement our core growth strategy of investing in high-quality water systems to provide safe and reliable water service to customers and communities while earning a fair return on those investments.
As Jim mentioned, we have already invested approximately 20% of our planned 2021 capital spending by the end of Q1.
We maintain high-quality water systems throughout our service areas and are investing to sustain them for the benefit of customers, communities, and shareholders.
Other regulatory developments in Q1 include the filing of general rate cases for both San Jose Water and Connecticut Water in January.
San Jose Water's GRC application proposes a $435 million capital program for 2021 through 2023, supported by our award-winning enterprise asset management system.
Updated rates are anticipated to take effect in the initial three months of 2022.
California utilizes a forward-looking test year, authorizing capital expenditure levels during each general rate case cycle.
Connecticut, Texas, and Maine use a historical test year approach, where capital investments and expenses not recoverable through surcharge mechanisms are recouped in subsequent general rate case filings after they've been made.
Connecticut Water's current general rate case is their first since the previous ruling in 2010.
A key factor driving the case is the $266 million invested in infrastructure that is currently benefiting customers but not yet reflected in rates.
The Connecticut Public Utilities Regulatory Authority (PURA) is expected to deliver a verdict in the third quarter.
Connecticut Water's rate case also proposes tiered pricing for residential customers to encourage water conservation.
In Connecticut, PURA-regulated water utilities can collect their authorized revenues regardless of usage through a water revenue adjustment mechanism, which reduces the risk of such a rate design and supports state conservation policy goals.
PURA approved a 1.1% increase in the Water Infrastructure and Conservation Adjustment (WICA) surcharge earlier this year, which became effective on April 1.
This covers $8.7 million in qualified infrastructure investments and will generate additional annual revenue of approximately $1 million.
The existing cumulative WICA surcharge will be incorporated into base rates, and the surcharge will be reset to zero as part of the general rate case.
Maine Water submitted a general rate case application for its Biddeford Saco rate division to the Maine Public Utilities Commission (PUC) in March, requesting a $6.7 million increase in annual revenues.
The application is motivated by a $60 million replacement of the 1884 vintage drinking water treatment plant.
Maine Water's proposal includes an innovative approach to spread the increase over three years in roughly equal amounts.
A decision on the rate smoothing mechanism to authorize a customer surcharge beginning in the third quarter of 2021 is anticipated in the second quarter, with a ruling on the requested revenue increase expected in the second quarter of 2022, coinciding with the completion of the new water treatment facility.
These various state regulatory filings include capital investments that provide long-term benefits to customers, communities, and shareholders by enhancing our ability to deliver safe, high-quality, and reliable water service while increasing the rate base, which drives company earnings.
We are aware of the economic impact that COVID-19 has had on some of our customers over the past year.
Connecticut Water is suggesting a 15% discount on water bills for income-eligible customers, similar to a program offered by San Jose Water since late 2005.
San Jose Water plans to propose a debt forgiveness plan for its Water Rate Assistance Plan (WRAP) low-income customers.
The proposal includes tracking the forgiven amount in San Jose Water's WRAP balancing account for potential future recovery.
On April 9, SJWTX, our Texas Water and Wastewater Utility, finalized the agreement to acquire the Clear Water Estates Water System.
This marks the first acquisition completed by a regulated water utility under the state's new fair market value regulation.
The acquisition added 230 new customers, secured additional water supplies for current and future customers, and increased the rate base to reflect market value for future rate-making purposes.
More significantly, the acquisition demonstrated that the fair market value process functioned as intended.
This was the 13th acquisition completed by SJWTX, which has tripled its customer base since 2006.
The company serves two of the four fastest-growing counties in the United States.
With a diverse portfolio of water supplies and continued growth in customer base through organic expansion and acquisitions, we remain optimistic about SJWTX's prospects and its increased contributions to consolidated earnings.
We are dedicated to investing in our culture, diversity, and the environment.
Our diversity, equity, and inclusion council has sincerely and authentically guided our commitment to further develop our diverse and inclusive culture.
We aim to expand our supplier diversity programs to extend our efforts into the broader community.
At the Board level, SJW Group is one of only 154 companies in the Russell 3000 to achieve a gender-balanced board rating in 2020, according to the 50/50 Women on Boards Gender Diversity Index.
We have established the groundwork for creating a comprehensive greenhouse gas inventory across all our operations, which will allow us to set meaningful reduction goals for the future and develop prudent plans to achieve those goals.
Bob has been a Director of the company since 2006 and Lead Independent Director since 2015.
Bob's expertise in the water industry is unparalleled, and his contributions to our company and stockholders are extensive.
Furthermore, you would be hard-pressed to find a person in business with more integrity, character, and genuine commitment to serving our company, customers, employees, and communities than Bob.
On behalf of the Board and all our employees, we extend our best wishes to him.
Summary:
output:
sees fy earnings per share $1.85 to $2.05.
q1 earnings per share $0.09.
q1 revenue $114.8 million.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:This teleconference is the intellectual property of SYNNEX Corporation and cannot be recorded or broadcast without prior authorization.
I will now highlight key points from the third quarter and provide guidance for the fourth quarter.
Despite ongoing economic uncertainty in these challenging times, our revenue, net income, and diluted earnings per share all surpassed our projections, demonstrating our resilience and expertise.
Our reported GAAP results, while still affected by COVID, have not been adjusted to account for COVID-19 related expenses.
When relevant, I will mention the financial impact of COVID-19 on our third quarter performance.
Overall, our total revenue reached a third quarter record of $6.5 billion, representing a 4% increase from $6.2 billion in the same period last year.
Adjusting for currency fluctuations, revenue grew by 5% compared to the previous year's quarter.
Our total consolidated gross profit amounted to $708 million, a decrease of 2% or $18 million from the previous year, with gross margin at 11% compared to 11.7% a year ago.
Total adjusted selling, general, and administrative expenses were $448 million, or 7% of revenue, a reduction of $8 million from the same quarter last year.
Consolidated non-GAAP operating income was $260 million, a decrease of $10 million or 4% from the previous year.
Non-GAAP operating margin of 4% was 34 basis points lower than the same period last year.
Let's now examine the third quarter operating performance by business segment.
Technology Solutions revenue reached $5.3 billion, an increase of 5% or $258 million compared to the same quarter last year.
The gross margin for Technology Solutions was 5.6%, which was 37 basis points lower than the previous year's quarter, mainly due to changes in product mix.
Operating income for this segment was $132 million, a decrease of $6 million from the previous year.
Non-GAAP operating income for Technology Solutions was $142 million, a 5% or $7 million decrease from the same quarter last year.
The non-GAAP operating margin was 2.7%, which is 29 basis points lower than a year ago.
Technology Solutions incurred approximately $8 million in COVID-19 related net additional expenses for the quarter, primarily consisting of increased allowances for doubtful accounts, staffing costs, and work-from-home expenses.
Turning to Concentrix, its revenue was $1.2 billion, a slight increase of 24 basis points compared to the same quarter last year.
Concentrix's gross margin was 35.5%, showing a 308 basis point improvement sequentially, but a 126 basis point decrease compared to the same quarter last year, mainly due to COVID-19 impacts.
Non-GAAP operating income for Concentrix this quarter was $118 million, a decrease of $3 million in absolute terms or 2% compared to last year.
The non-GAAP operating margin for Concentrix was 10.1%, compared to 5.9% in the second fiscal quarter and 10.4% a year ago.
Concentrix faced approximately $13 million in net additional expenses related to COVID-19 for the quarter.
Returning to our consolidated results, the third quarter net total interest expense and finance charges were $29 million, a $14 million reduction compared to the same quarter last year.
This decrease was due to lower average outstanding borrowings compared to the previous year's quarter, as well as a lower interest rate environment.
We anticipate interest expenses of approximately $29 million for the fourth quarter.
Total non-GAAP net income was $173 million, an increase of $3 million or 2% over the same period last year, and non-GAAP diluted earnings per share were $3.33, an increase of $0.03 or 1% compared to the same period a year ago.
The effective tax rate for the third quarter was 25.2%, compared to 25.3% a year ago.
We expect the effective tax rate for the fourth quarter of fiscal 2020 to be approximately 25%.
Examining the balance sheet, our accounts receivable totaled $3.6 billion and inventories amounted to $2.8 billion as of August 31, 2020.
Our cash conversion cycle for the third quarter was 38 days, 11 days shorter than a year ago and 8 days better than last quarter, resulting in preliminary cash flow from operations of $321 million.
This improvement was achieved through continued collaboration with our partners and faster inventory turnover.
At the end of the third quarter, SYNNEX had approximately $2.8 billion in total available liquidity to fund operations, including cash and credit facilities.
I'd like to provide an update on the Concentrix spin-off.
We're on track for a spin-off in the fourth quarter of the calendar year, with December 1 being the most likely date.
This aligns with our year-end and provides a clean start for both Concentrix and SYNNEX in 2020.
Based on current estimates, SYNNEX Corp's gross debt will be approximately $2.6 billion, with Concentrix receiving about $1.1 billion and SYNNEX receiving about $1.5 billion.
The majority of cash on hand, estimated to be around $700 million at the time of the spin-off, will be held by SYNNEX.
Cash usage in the fourth quarter will be for normal seasonal purposes and debt reduction.
As previously discussed, we aim to position both companies favorably among their peers in terms of leverage and liquidity.
These debt figures are estimates and may change based on fourth-quarter performance.
We have made significant progress with our bankers in securing third-party financing for Concentrix and are confident in the capital structure of both businesses.
Both SYNNEX and Concentrix will have sufficient resources to support growth and potential M&A opportunities.
Looking ahead to our fourth quarter forecast, we anticipate revenue to fall between $6.45 billion and $6.65 billion.
We project non-GAAP net income to range from $191 million to $204 million.
Our estimate for non-GAAP diluted earnings per share is between $3.68 and $3.93 per diluted share, based on approximately 51.5 million weighted average shares.
The guidance for non-GAAP net income and non-GAAP diluted earnings per share does not include after-tax expenses of about $37.5 million or $0.72 per share, associated with intangible amortization and acquisition-related and integration costs.
We've previously informed you about an important customer transitioning to a consignment model.
The exact date for this transition remains uncertain and won't occur in early 2021.
We'll update you as soon as we have a clear start date.
I'd like to express my gratitude to all our global stakeholders for their ongoing support and collaboration as we've jointly navigated numerous challenges and economic issues throughout 2020.
Our team delivered exceptional results in the third quarter, for which I'm deeply thankful.
While we're all feeling the strain of the ongoing pandemic, the SYNNEX spirit and determination continue to be a source of inspiration.
I observe the positive influence we're having on our communities and the strong backing our teams provide to each other, our partners, and customers.
In addition to achieving great quarterly results, the team made significant progress on our planned spin-off of Concentrix into an independent public company.
The Concentrix F-10 document is now available for review.
Third-party financing is nearly complete, and most remaining spin-related activities are close to finalization.
Consequently, we believe we're well-positioned to conclude this transaction in the fourth quarter of the calendar year.
Regarding our third quarter performance, our TS distribution business saw better-than-expected revenue driven by strong demand in education, state and local government, and e-commerce sectors.
This was fueled by ongoing needs for remote work, learning, and shopping.
We also saw a slight improvement from the second quarter in office environment and SMB sales.
Similar to Q2, we experienced higher demand for notebooks, Chromebooks, cloud services, collaboration tools, and security products.
Compared to the previous year, we saw some weakness in products supporting office environments, such as desktop PCs, printers, supplies, and on-site datacenter equipment.
Geographically, North America was the top performer, but all regions exceeded expectations during the quarter.
Overall, TS distribution experienced year-over-year growth.
Our TS Hive business showed sequential improvement and year-over-year revenue growth as we continued supporting our largest customers in Q3.
The mix of programs delivered leaned towards higher volume, lower margin products, but we're generally satisfied with the Q3 results.
Our Concentrix business also surpassed expectations in Q3, despite known challenges.
I'm very pleased with our performance, and I'll now hand over to Chris to provide more details about Concentrix.
We're very satisfied with our continued momentum, both in terms of business execution and readiness for the spin-off, which as Marshall mentioned, is set for early December.
We achieved solid results, returning to pre-COVID revenue growth rates and double-digit adjusted operating margins.
Concentrix's third quarter revenue totaled $1.16 billion, slightly higher than the same period last year.
Sequentially, third quarter revenue increased across all our delivery regions.
This achievement was possible due to our aggressive approach to addressing COVID-19 challenges in three key areas.
First, we provided a flexible, safe workplace incorporating both at-home and in-office elements to meet our clients' needs.
Second, we leveraged our robust technology solutions to support clients across all channels.
Third, we fostered a culture of security and integrity, backed by innovations like our recently announced SecureCX platform.
SecureCX is a proprietary platform that uses advanced technology to ensure nearly equivalent security levels at home as in an office setting.
This is the latest innovation from our team of over 1,000 skilled engineers and developers.
Concentrix has been developing technology-driven solutions like this for more than a decade, and we plan to continue leading through investment in this area.
We're also pleased with our progress in diversifying our vertical mix.
The communications vertical now accounts for about 21% of revenue, representing a 4% impact on our year-over-year growth rate, but resulting in a more balanced portfolio.
As anticipated, our clients in the travel, transportation, and tourism sectors were impacted by COVID-19, causing an additional 2% impact on growth.
These headwinds were more than offset by strong growth from clients in our technology, healthcare, financial services, and e-commerce verticals, which collectively represent about two-thirds of our business.
New business signings were very encouraging in the quarter, reaching a record level of expected annualized contract revenue.
This increased demand reflects the value our clients place on the strengths of our best-in-class CX platform and our ability to meet their evolving needs.
We are expanding our market presence with robust acquisitions across our key sectors and securing new contracts that were traditionally handled in-house.
Despite our record-breaking deals, our business prospects remain robust and expanding.
We are closely monitoring COVID-19 developments and are prepared to adjust our strategies with our clients as their requirements evolve.
Regarding profitability, our adjusted operating income for the quarter reached $118 million or 10.1%, nearly matching last year's performance.
The return to double-digit operating margin reflects revenue outperformance and reduced variable expenses, despite an additional $13 million in net COVID-19 related costs.
Operating cash flow in the third quarter amounted to roughly $91 million.
Capital expenditures totaled approximately $37 million.
We achieved positive free cash flow, notwithstanding the impact of previous quarter's revenue reductions that decreased our collections in the third quarter.
We anticipate capital expenditures to be slightly higher than usual to support growth and reconfigure some of our facilities due to COVID-19.
For the fourth quarter outlook, we remain committed to ensuring our staff's safety, exceeding client expectations to remain their preferred partner, and emerging stronger from the pandemic to drive sequential improvements in both revenue and profitability.
In the fourth quarter, we anticipate greater sequential revenue growth compared to last year, stemming from strong new business signings in the third quarter and seasonal increases.
Consequently, we project fourth quarter revenue to rise by at least 2% year-over-year on a constant currency basis, with an expected adjusted operating margin above 12.5%.
We remain confident in our ability to surpass industry growth rates while improving our adjusted operating margin over time.
Regarding our separation from SYNNEX, scheduled for December 1, we believe we are fully prepared.
We plan to announce our Board of Directors in an updated Form 10 Registration Statement in early October.
We take pride in the fact that our Board will reflect the diversity present in our business.
As Marshall mentioned, our debt to EBITDA ratio will be less than approximately two times upon separation, providing strong liquidity and significant flexibility for investing in organic and inorganic growth.
We maintain a disciplined approach to both organic and inorganic growth strategies.
We believe the spin-off will yield benefits for shareholders, team members, and clients alike.
An analyst event will be held in early November before the spin-off, followed by one-on-one investor meetings shortly after.
I'm eager to update you in the coming weeks about the extraordinary opportunity and our superior capability to lead in the customer experience industry.
The effort, resourcefulness, and dedication demonstrate the strength of our people, culture, and diversity, which we'll leverage as we begin this new chapter of Concentrix.
Regarding our fourth quarter outlook, our main priority remains the safety and well-being of our associates.
For our business overall, we observe positive signs of continued recovery as economies further reopen.
However, we remain cautious due to significant variations between and within geographical regions.
For Technology Solutions, we anticipate an overall seasonal improvement in Q4.
We expect TS distribution to increase sequentially, partially offset by a decline in TS Hive.
TS distribution growth will be driven by ongoing strength in remote enablement, the federal buying season, progress in delayed on-premise projects, and continued investment in digital transformation.
We anticipate a solid quarter for TS Hive, although we'll be comparing it to an exceptional Q4 last year.
Given the unpredictability of this business, we tend to use conservative internal expectations in our guidance calculations.
As Marshall indicated, COVID-related expenses decreased in Q3 and are expected to decline further in Q4.
As mentioned in our previous call, a portion of these costs will become part of our normal TS operating expenses going forward.
Over time, we expect to find ways to offset these costs while maintaining the most effective and efficient business operations possible.
For Concentrix, as Chris mentioned, we anticipate a seasonally strong Q4.
Our return to growth, positive cash flow, and robust pipeline are among the many aspects I'm pleased about as Concentrix approaches independence.
I'm also excited about the independent TS, our ongoing opportunities to enhance our core operations, the numerous investments we've made to organically grow our business, and the potential for inorganic investments, all of which give me confidence in our business and the services we provide to our partners.
Additionally, we will continue to pursue our goal of outpacing market growth and increasing our profit at a higher rate.
We are grateful for your support of SYNNEX during these challenging times.
Our thoughts remain with those affected by COVID-19; please stay safe and healthy.
We also stand with those working towards positive change on social issues.
I appreciate the SYNNEX team members who have been of service in these and other important areas.
Summary:
output:
compname reports q3 adjusted earnings per share of $3.33.
sees q4 2020 non-gaap earnings per share $3.68 to $3.93.
sees q4 2020 revenue $6.45 billion to $6.65 billion.
qtrly adjusted earnings per share $3.33.
qtrly technology solutions revenue was $5.3 billion, up 5.1%.
qtrly concentrix revenue was $1.2 billion, up 0.2%.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Certain projections and assumptions form the basis of these declarations, which are subject to various risks and uncertainties.
We recommend reviewing the risk factors outlined in the company's publicly available documents and reports, accessible on the SEC website or the company's official website.
Let me now hand over the conference to Karen Colonias, who serves as Simpson's President and Chief Executive Officer.
I'll start by summarizing our results for the entire year of 2020, then move on to discuss the key factors and initiatives that influenced our fourth quarter performance.
Brian will then provide a more detailed explanation of our financial results and our business outlook for fiscal 2021.
I'm incredibly proud of our outstanding financial and operational achievements in 2020, which we accomplished despite the challenging operating conditions brought on by the COVID-19 pandemic.
Our net sales grew by 11.6% compared to 2019, reaching $1.28 billion, the highest in our company's history, driven by strong sales volume.
Consequently, we achieved record earnings of $4.27 per diluted share, a 43.3% increase from 2019.
These accomplishments wouldn't have been possible without the dedication and hard work of all our Simpson employees.
Their diligence, including strict adherence to protocols aimed at minimizing the spread of COVID-19, has allowed us to continue operating our business with minimal disruptions from the pandemic.
On behalf of the entire Simpson management team, we commend them for their extraordinary efforts.
Ensuring the health, safety, and well-being of all our employees remains our top priority, and we will continue to strive for improvements to make Simpson a safe and rewarding workplace.
Our record-breaking 2020 results were further bolstered by our commitment to positioning Simpson for long-term, sustainable, and increasingly profitable growth.
In October 2017, we introduced a three-year plan for 2020 with ambitious targets to maximize our operational efficiencies and enhance long-term shareholder value.
Since then, we've made significant progress towards our goals, some of which we updated in July 2019 to reflect changes in the macroeconomic landscape.
Although we decided to withdraw these financial targets in April 2020 due to the significant uncertainty surrounding COVID-19, we continued to execute based on the same underlying principles, focusing on operational efficiencies and cost savings to guide us through the pandemic.
Simultaneously, our business experienced certain advantages due to the COVID-19 related macroeconomic conditions, specifically favorable steel prices, temporary reductions in travel and related operating expenses, and an increase in repair and remodel activity.
The combination of these factors allowed us to meet or exceed nearly all of our ambitious 2020 plan objectives.
We are very proud of these achievements and I'd like to take a few moments to discuss them with you.
Our primary 2020 plan objective was to maintain a focus on organic growth.
We aimed to achieve a compound annual growth rate in net sales of approximately 8% from 2016 to 2020.
By the end of 2020, we had significantly surpassed this target, achieving a compound annual growth rate of over 10% relative to our 2016 baseline.
Key milestones supporting this goal included a price increase for most of our US wood connector products in the third quarter of 2018, signing one of the largest US homebuilding companies to our builder program (resulting in 23 of the Top 25 US builders now participating in our program), strong repair and remodel trends associated with the COVID-19 pandemic, and the return of Lowe's as a home center customer in mid-2020.
Our second objective involved streamlining our cost structure to enhance company-wide profitability.
We aimed to reduce our total operating expenses as a percentage of net sales from 31.3% in 2016 to a range of 26% to 27% by the end of 2020.
We approached this through a combination of zero-based budgeting, reducing our indirect procurement costs, and implementing other cost-cutting measures in both Europe and our concrete business.
Additionally, in 2020, we experienced significant cost savings from our expense management practices as well as one-time benefits from reduced travel and trade show costs due to COVID-19 restrictions.
These factors, combined with strong topline growth, enabled us to exceed our operating expense target.
For the full year of 2020, we recorded operating expenses as a percentage of net sales of 25.6%, representing a 570 basis point improvement compared to 2016.
Our next goal was to improve our operating income margin to a range of 16% to 17% by the end of 2020.
We surpassed this target as our gross margin significantly benefited from lower material costs and limited spending on operating expenses due to COVID-19 restrictions.
We reported an operating income margin of 19.9% for 2020, a 350 basis point improvement compared to 16.4% in 2016.
At the consolidated level, our gross margin improvement was supported by enhanced gross margins in our concrete business, another 2020 plan goal.
Following the unveiling of the 2020 plan, we implemented a new concrete strategy in late 2017 by focusing on six distinct product categories.
By concentrating on these higher margin products to increase profitability, we exceeded our goal of improving our global concrete gross margin from 34.7% in 2016 to 42% in 2020.
Our final profitability goal was to improve our operating income margin in Europe.
We've made substantial progress in Europe over the past few years, including introducing our fastener lines in the Nordic region and France, consolidating our European management team to create efficiencies, and implementing significant cost-cutting initiatives.
As a result, we achieved an operating income margin of 7% in 2020, excluding our SAP costs of approximately $2.5 million.
While this is lower than our original target range of 8% to 9%, we are pleased with the results, which reflect approximately 350 basis points of improvement compared to 2016.
Our third objective focused on enhancing our working capital management and overall balance sheet discipline.
Since the beginning of the 2020 plan, we've made progress in this area, primarily through inventory reductions and the implementation of lean principles throughout our operations.
We completed a three-phase SKU reduction program, eliminating over 12,000 non-moving or slow-moving items and transitioning our customers to replacement products.
Additionally, we conducted rapid improvement events at many of our US production facilities, resulting in efficiency enhancements and improved management of inventory and purchasing practices.
Moving forward, we remain committed to driving continuous cost management and improved efficiencies through our lean initiatives.
Aligning with our approach, it's vital to strike a balance between inventory acquisitions and cash requirements to uphold our product availability standards and deliver exceptional customer service.
The last component of our 2020 strategy aimed to enhance shareholder value by boosting our return on invested capital from 10.5% in 2016 to between 15% and 16% by 2020's end.
Through effective operational execution and the implementation of the 2017 US Tax Cuts and Jobs Act, which reduced our effective tax rate starting in 2018, we exceeded this goal, concluding 2020 with a 20% return on invested capital.
Additionally, we continued to distribute capital to our shareholders through dividends and stock repurchases.
In 2020, we distributed $116.2 million to our stockholders, comprising $40 million in dividends and $76.2 million in share buybacks.
Since the 2020 plan's inception, we have returned over 83% of our operational cash flow to shareholders, far surpassing our 50% target. I'm incredibly proud of our achievements over the past three years. By implementing the 2020 plan, we achieved substantial organic growth, streamlined our cost structure to boost company-wide profitability, and enhanced our working capital management and balance sheet position, thereby creating value for all key Simpson stakeholders.
Let's now briefly review our fourth quarter results and operational initiatives.
Our fourth quarter consolidated net sales grew 12% year-over-year to $293.9 million, driven by significantly higher volume.
Gross margin increased to 42.1% from 41.9% in the previous year's quarter, primarily due to strong performance in Europe, where we experienced lower material and warehouse costs.
Our robust gross margin, combined with effective expense management and reduced costs from travel and other restrictions due to COVID-19, led to a 7.8% year-over-year increase in our operating income to $39.5 million and earnings of $0.68 per diluted share.
The fourth quarter sales volume increase was mainly attributed to ongoing momentum in the home center distribution channel, which includes both our home centers and co-op customers.
We continue to observe a shift in consumer behavior towards home renovations as a result of the pandemic.
Sales from home center distribution channels, where much of our repair and remodel business occurs, improved compared to the prior year period.
Growth was supported by our product rollout of connectors, mechanical anchors, and fastener solutions into all 1737 Lowe's stores, completed during the fourth quarter.
As a reminder, Lowe's returned as a home center customer beginning in the second quarter of 2020.
Our sales were further bolstered by strong US housing starts, as we typically experience a multi-month lag in demand from the time of the start. In the fourth quarter, we benefited from robust third quarter 2020 housing starts, which grew over 11% year-over-year.
Moreover, while we usually see lower seasonal sales in the fourth quarter due to holiday closures and winter conditions, 2020's fourth quarter experienced a very mild winter.
This allowed construction activity to continue late into the year, further boosting our net sales.
Regarding Europe, sales continued to recover well following government-mandated shutdowns of our operations in the UK and France due to COVID-19 in late March.
Sales were aided by strong demand trends and our ability to meet customer needs through effective inventory management practices.
We believe our European sales benefited during the fourth quarter as many competitors faced supply chain issues.
During this time, we were able to offer customers essential products to keep up with demand and maintain job site schedules.
It's worth noting that while the UK has reimplemented shutdowns due to the recent COVID-19 surge, we have been designated an essential business. All our major production and distribution facilities remain open and operational, with remote work promoted where possible, such as in our corporate offices.
Regarding SAP implementation, the rollout continued to progress despite travel limitations related to COVID-19.
In the fourth quarter, we completed the SAP rollout at our UK branch and Gallatin, Tennessee locations, both of which are now live.
Most recently, we successfully transitioned our entire Canadian-based sales organization to SAP, thus completing the full SAP rollout in North America, a significant milestone.
This year, we will continue working on the SAP transition in our European locations and the rest of the world. We currently anticipate company-wide completion in 2022 and will continue to monitor and update our timeline if circumstances change.
I'd like to briefly discuss our capital allocation structure.
We are grateful to operate as a supplier to other essential businesses with minimal disruptions due to the pandemic.
As our business continues to generate strong cash flow, we remain focused on appropriately balancing our growth and stockholder return priorities.
We are pleased to be in a position to pay off our line of credit borrowing in full and declare our quarterly dividend, as we have done consistently since 2004.
While COVID-19 pandemic challenges continue to impact the broader economy, we feel confident in the bright future we believe lies ahead for Simpson as we exit 2020.
With another quarter of strong year-over-year growth in housing starts, up over 11% in the fourth quarter of 2020, we believe housing will continue to be a key element of economic recovery in the coming years, and we are well-positioned to capitalize on this environment.
Simultaneously, we continue to pursue our diversification strategy, positioning our business to be less vulnerable to the US housing market through key investments in adjacent products and markets. We also remain focused on growth, including M&A opportunities that would complement our existing product offering, manufacturing footprint, or strengthen our software capabilities.
Our success in achieving the 2020 plan targets has created a strong foundation for Simpson, successfully positioning our company for long-term sustainable and increasingly profitable growth.
We are now ready for our next chapter.
Today, I'm pleased to announce that on Tuesday, March 23, we plan to host a Virtual Analyst and Investor Day to provide more insight and details about our business strategy for 2021 and beyond.
Additional information about this event will be released in the coming days.
I'm pleased to discuss our fourth quarter financial results with you today.
Now turning to our results.
As Karen highlighted, our consolidated net sales were strong, increasing 12% to $293.9 million.
Within the North America segment, net sales increased 9.8% to $249.1 million, primarily due to higher sales volumes in our home center distribution channel, which includes our home center and co-op customers.
Sales volumes were supported by the return of Lowe's along with increased repair and remodel activity.
Our net sales benefited additionally from alternative distribution channels, which saw increased demand due to new housing construction and renovation activities.
In Europe, revenue grew by 24.9% to $41.8 million, primarily due to higher sales volumes in local currencies.
Wood construction products made up 85% of total sales, up from 83%, while concrete construction products accounted for 15%, down from 17% the previous year.
Overall gross profit rose by 12.4% to $123.7 million, resulting in a stronger fourth quarter gross margin of 42.1% compared to the previous year.
Gross margin improved by 20 basis points, mainly due to reduced material and warehouse expenses, partially offset by increased labor costs.
In North America, our gross margin decreased to 43.2% from 43.9%, while in Europe, it increased to 25.3% from 29.9%.
For wood products, our fourth quarter gross margin was 41.8%, up from 40.8% in the same quarter last year, while for concrete products, it was 39.6%, down from 43.7%.
Let's now examine our fourth quarter costs and operating expenses.
Research, development, and engineering expenses grew by 10% to $12.9 million, primarily due to increased personnel costs, stock-based compensation, product testing, and cash profit sharing expenses.
Selling expenses decreased by 1.2% to $27.8 million, owing to reduced travel, entertainment, advertising, and trade show costs, partially offset by higher personnel expenses, cash profit sharing, sales commissions, and stock-based compensation.
In North America, selling expenses declined by 2.1%, while in Europe, they remained largely unchanged.
General and administrative expenses increased by 10.9% to $43.6 million, mainly due to higher cash profit sharing, stock-based compensation, and software subscription and license costs.
Total operating expenses amounted to $84.3 million, an increase of $5.1 million or approximately 6.5%.
As a percentage of net sales, total operating expenses were 28.7%, an improvement of 150 basis points compared to 30.2%.
Our strong top-line performance, improved fourth quarter gross margin, and careful management of costs and operating expenses contributed to a 7.8% increase in consolidated income from operations, reaching $39.5 million compared to $36.6 million.
Income from operations in North America decreased by 1.8% to $36.1 million.
The fourth quarter of 2019 North American income from operations included a $5.6 million gain from the sale of a selling and distribution facility.
In Europe, income from operations grew by 145.8% to $1.3 million, primarily due to increased gross profit.
Our consolidated operating income margin of 13.4% decreased by approximately 50 basis points.
The effective tax rate increased to 25.6% from 22.3% due to the release of foreign valuation allowances in 2019.
Consequently, net income reached $29.6 million or $0.68 per fully diluted share, compared to $28.1 million or $0.63 per fully diluted share.
Let's now examine our balance sheet and cash flow.
Our balance sheet remained robust with sufficient liquidity for daily operations.
As of December 31, cash and cash equivalents totaled $274.6 million, an increase of $44.4 million compared to December 31, 2019, after repaying the remaining $75 million on our revolving credit facility during the quarter.
The full $300 million on our primary line of credit was available for borrowing as of December 31, 2020.
Our inventory position of $283.7 million at December 31 increased by $23.6 million from our balance at September 30, as we continue to experience higher levels of construction activity and unprecedented demand during the pandemic.
We remain highly selective in our inventory purchases through careful management and purchasing practices while maintaining high levels of customer service and on-time delivery standards.
Due to improved profitability and effective working capital management, we generated strong cash flow from operations of $77.5 million for the fourth quarter of 2020, an increase of $21.1 million or 37.4%.
For the full year of 2020, we generated $207.1 million of cash flow from operations, an increase of nearly $1.5 million.
We allocated approximately $17 million for capital expenditures during the fourth quarter.
For the entire year of 2020, capital expenditures totaled approximately $37.9 million, aligning with our reduced expectations due to our focus on cash preservation in mid-2020 in response to COVID-19.
We were pleased to have distributed $40.4 million in dividends during fiscal 2020, including $10.2 million in the fourth quarter.
Additionally, we repurchased about 1.05 million shares of our common stock in 2020 at an average price of $72.33 per share, totaling $76.2 million.
This includes approximately 151,000 shares of our common stock repurchased during the fourth quarter at an average price of $89.49 per share, totaling $13.5 million.
As our authorization for common stock repurchases expired at year-end, our Board of Directors approved the repurchase of up to $100 million of our common stock on December 16, effective from January 1, 2021 through December 31, 2021.
Furthermore, on January 22, our Board of Directors declared a quarterly cash dividend of $0.23 per share, payable on April 22, 2021 to stockholders of record as of April 1, 2021.
Based on current business trends and conditions as of February 8, we are providing guidance for the full year ending December 31, 2021 as follows.
We estimate the operating margin to be between 16.5% and 18.5%.
The effective tax rate is projected to be between 25% and 26%, including both federal and state income taxes.
Capital expenditures are estimated to be between $50 million and $55 million, with approximately $10 million to $13 million allocated for maintenance capex.
As of today, the extent and duration of the COVID-19 pandemic and its impact on general economic conditions remain uncertain.
It's important to note that potential economic impacts related to COVID-19 on our operations, raw material costs, consumers, suppliers, and vendors may significantly affect our 2021 financial outlook if conditions change substantially from the current environment.
We will continue to monitor the impact of COVID-19 on our operations, which were not significantly affected in the fourth quarter of 2020.
In conclusion, despite COVID-19-related challenges in the market and ongoing uncertainty, we were very pleased with our fourth quarter financial results and operational performance.
Our industry-leading position, geographic reach, and diverse product offerings, combined with our strong balance sheet and liquidity, give us confidence in our ability to maintain operational excellence and support current and future demand trends.
As mentioned by Karen, we look forward to updating you on our future business strategy for 2021 and beyond during our Virtual Analyst and Investor Day on March 23.
Summary:
output:
compname reports q4 earnings per share $0.68.
q4 earnings per share $0.68.
q4 sales $293.9 million versus refinitiv ibes estimate of $276.1 million.
sees fy 2021 operating margin is estimated to be in range of 16.5% to 18.5%.
capital expenditures are estimated to be in range of $50 million to $55 million for 2021.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:We'll be reviewing findings that were made public yesterday evening after market close.
To access the audio stream, please visit the stewart.com site and locate the conference call link.
Since these statements are based on anticipated future financial performance rather than established facts, actual outcomes may differ considerably from projections.
Shortly, David will provide a comprehensive breakdown of this quarter's financial outcomes.
However, before that, I want to address Stewart's operational progress to date and our ongoing implementation of long-term objectives.
Two years ago, we embarked on a mission at Stewart to become the leading provider of title services.
We recognized it would require time, but we were also aware of our valuable brand, robust financial position, and employees eager to contribute and make a difference.
Since then, we've dealt with the significant effects of COVID-19 as well as an unprecedented real estate market that continues to show strength.
What is our current position in this journey?
What have been the key areas of focus and advancement?
We've substantially enhanced our operational capabilities by expanding our presence in key markets, complementing our core business with crucial real estate technology and services, and introducing fresh talent and enthusiasm into a company with 125 years of history.
I often describe us as a 125-year-old startup.
Initial targets of achieving double-digit margins have been reached and surpassed, albeit with assistance from a particularly strong market.
As David will elaborate, Stewart's operating revenues have increased by nearly $240 million or 40% compared to last year.
Operating income rose by over $30 million or 55% in a quarter where the Mortgage Bankers Association predicts a 12% year-over-year decrease in purchase originations and a 25% decline in overall mortgage originations.
Therefore, we believe we are significantly outperforming the market and generating substantial value.
At this point in our journey, we can confidently state that much has fundamentally changed and improved, but there is still more to accomplish.
Through acquisitions, we have increased our presence in many crucial markets where our previous size limited profitability and hindered efficient daily operations management.
Scale and adaptability are vital in an industry that is both seasonal and cyclical.
We expedited our restructuring during a period of high transaction volume.
We shuttered offices where we anticipated future challenges.
We also entered two markets we believe will be focal points of real estate activity in the future.
Regarding talent, we are becoming an attractive destination for exceptional individuals.
Half of the senior leadership team at Stewart consists of new hires or recently promoted individuals.
Our bold entrepreneurial initiatives have drawn exceptional talent from various sectors of the real estate industry, not just title operations.
Our investment, dedication, and adaptability in real estate technology have attracted numerous skilled leaders to our organization.
This influx of talent and improvement in our operations will support our long-term growth strategy.
We have enhanced our value to customers by simplifying their experience with our services.
We've implemented new technologies and services for our larger lending partners, increasing efficiency in both current and future digital markets.
Our smaller clients appreciate how we simplify their daily operations through our tools, technology, services, and security measures.
The security aspect is crucial, as wire fraud has become a significant concern for agents, prompting our partnership with Certified.
I'd like to leave you with a couple of key points to consider.
While we've benefited from the current robust real estate market, Stewart is focused on building a business that can thrive throughout all market cycles and leverage technology to revolutionize the closing process.
We are committed to driving digital innovation to deliver an exceptional closing process now and in the future, and I'm confident our investments have positioned us for ongoing success.
Although we aim for a fully automated and digitized closing process in the future, it's important to recognize that title insurance remains a technology-enhanced but execution-driven business, where title clearing mitigates risk for customers making the biggest purchase of their lives.
This fact is of utmost importance.
We continue to progress towards our objectives, now one quarter closer to our target.
David will now present the quarterly results.
Despite entering a typically slower real estate season, market conditions remain strong, driven by demand and favorable interest rates.
The commercial sector is showing signs of recovery, particularly in industrial, energy, and multifamily segments.
Several factors could impact future business performance, including government policies, mortgage delinquency rates, ongoing pandemic concerns, rising inflation, and supply chain disruptions.
In line with our strategy and Fred's remarks, we're concentrating on areas that will have the most significant and lasting impact on our long-term performance: expanding in key direct markets, improving our agency and commercial operations, broadening our lender services, and enhancing our digital capabilities to improve user experience across all business areas.
For Q3 2021, Stewart reported net income of $89 million and diluted earnings per share of $3.26, with total operating revenues of $830 million.
Adjustments to our Q3 net income were primarily due to a gain related to an acquisition contingent liability adjustment.
Compared to the previous year, total title revenues for the quarter increased by $205 million or 37%, driven by strong performance in our residential agency and commercial operations.
The title division generated $119 million in pre-tax earnings, surpassing last year's quarter by $37 million due to revenue growth and focused management.
The segment's pretax margin improved by 90 basis points to 15% compared to the previous year.
In our direct title operations, residential revenue grew by $55 million or 23%, driven by an increase in purchase transactions and improved efficiency.
The average residential fee per file reached approximately $2,400, a 24% increase from last year, attributed to a higher proportion of purchase transactions.
Domestic commercial revenue rose by $28 million or 76%, due to increased transaction volume and a higher average fee per file of $15,400, up from $9,700 in the previous year's quarter.
Overall international revenue increased by $17 million or 49%, mainly due to improved volumes in Canadian operations.
Total opened and closed orders in the third quarter decreased by 13% and 3% respectively, primarily due to fewer refinancing transactions, aligning with market trends.
Nevertheless, commercial and purchase closed orders increased by 11% and 8% respectively compared to the third quarter of 2020.
Agency operations, in line with our direct title business, had a strong quarter with revenues increasing 42% to $402 million from $283 million the previous year.
The agency remittance rate for the third quarter was 17.9%, down from 18.2% last year.
Year-to-date, the remittance rate remained steady at 17.8% for both 2021 and 2020.
Total title loss expense increased by $2 million or 7%, primarily due to higher title revenues, partially offset by favorable claims experience.
Title loss expense as a percentage of title revenues in the third quarter was 4%, down from 5% in the prior year quarter.
Total operating expenses increased primarily in relation to higher revenues.
Employee costs as a percentage of operating revenues improved to 24% from 26% last year, while other operating expenses increased to 18% from 17% due to higher pass-through appraisal and service costs.
Excluding these pass-through costs, our overall other operating expense ratio would have remained similar to last year.
The Informative Research transaction closed at the end of September, with the company showing $85 million in run rate revenues and a 15%-plus pre-tax margin.
Our financial position remains robust, with approximately $585 million in total cash and investments over regulatory requirements, and about $74 million available on our existing credit facility.
Stockholders' equity attributable to Stewart increased to $1.2 billion as of September 30, 2021, with a book value of approximately $45 per share.
Net cash provided by operations for the third quarter rose to $107 million, up from $91 million in the same quarter last year.
We remain thankful for and motivated by our customers and associates, advocating for improved safety and prosperity for all, and confident in our support of real estate markets.
Summary:
output: qtrly diluted earnings per share of $3.26 ($3.17 on an adjusted basis).

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:I'll now hand things over to Mike.
Let's begin with an overview of how we're addressing the ongoing COVID-19 situation.
We're implementing all required steps to safeguard our employees' wellbeing, including adopting protocols that align with guidelines from health authorities and government agencies to protect our staff and contractors.
Our dedicated COVID-19 team continuously assesses the changing circumstances and adapts our approach accordingly.
Now, let's discuss our performance in the third quarter.
Despite operating at reduced levels, our cokemaking facilities performed admirably.
All our operations demonstrated exceptional cost management and achieved results matching our projections, even in the face of challenging market conditions.
A noteworthy accomplishment for SunCoke this quarter was the two-year extension of our Haverhill II contract with AK Steel, now set to conclude on June 30, 2025.
This extension underscores the robustness and longevity of our customer relationships.
In our last earnings call, we announced SunCoke's plans to enter the foundry coke market.
We're making good progress on the testing, development, and capital investment needed for profitable foundry coke production, and we're enthusiastic about introducing our high-quality product to this new market.
We've conducted tests of our foundry coke in Cupolas with several potential clients, yielding promising results.
We're now in a strong position to profitably enter the foundry coke market in 2021.
We're continuing to work towards our revised 2020 goals and are on track to meet our full-year adjusted EBITDA guidance.
Let's now examine our third quarter results.
As shown on slide four, we reported a diluted loss per share of $0.03 in Q3 2020, compared to a $1.81 loss per share in Q3 2019.
The previous year's figure included a $1.94 per share impairment charge related to our logistics goodwill and CMT's long-lived assets. Excluding this non-cash charge, earnings per share decreased by $0.16 quarter-over-quarter, primarily due to reduced volumes across all segments.
Regarding adjusted EBITDA, we achieved $47.8 million in Q3 2020, down from $66.7 million in Q3 2019.
Adjusted EBITDA from coke operations fell by $11.8 million compared to the same period last year.
Domestic sales volumes were roughly 190,000 tons lower than the previous year due to customer cutbacks.
The impact of decreased volume was partially mitigated by lower operating expenses.
The Logistics segment's Adjusted EBITDA fell by $5.3 million compared to the third quarter of 2019
CMT and domestic terminals experienced a reduction in throughput volumes of about 1.4 million tons compared to the previous year
The fifth slide compares the adjusted EBITDA figures from the third quarters of 2019 and 2020
As mentioned in our previous conference call, we collaborated with our coke customers to address their immediate coke requirements in response to a difficult and unprecedented situation
We consented to decrease our coke production by roughly 550,000 tons in 2020 in return for extending several coke contracts
The majority of this reduction will take place during the third and fourth quarters of 2020
This decrease in volume led to lower adjusted EBITDA from coke operations in the third quarter of 2020 compared to the previous year
Effective cost management partially mitigated the impact of these reduced volumes
Logistics operations experienced a $5.3 million decrease quarter-over-quarter due to lower volumes and pricing, which was counterbalanced by reduced operating costs
The quarter's corporate expenses include approximately $1 million in foundry-related research and development costs
These expenses were also affected by period-over-period mark-to-market adjustments in deferred compensation, influenced by fluctuations in the company's stock price
Slide six presents the performance of Domestic Coke operations
We sold 868,000 tons of coke during the quarter
The volume relief provided to our customers affected sales volumes across all facilities
The adjusted EBITDA per ton for Q3 2020 was about $56, compared to $57 per ton in Q3 2019
The decrease in adjusted EBITDA per ton was attributed to lower sales volume but was mostly offset by favorable cost recovery and efficient cost management
Our plants have been conscientious in reducing costs where possible by managing supplies and services, overtime, contractor usage, postponing capital work, and various other measures
Transitioning to slide seven
Logistics adjusted EBITDA for Q3 2020 was $4.3 million, compared to $9.6 million in Q3 2019
CMT contributed $1.7 million to Q3 2020 adjusted EBITDA, down from $7.4 million in Q3 2019, despite comparable volume
The decline in CMT's adjusted EBITDA is primarily due to lower pricing
The domestic terminals handled about 2.2 million tons in Q3 2020, down from 3.4 million tons in Q3 2019
The decreased activity at domestic logistics hubs was counterbalanced by cost-cutting initiatives, including significant staff reductions.
Let's proceed to the next presentation slide.
The diagram indicates our cash reserves stood at $86 million at the quarter's end.
During the quarter, operational activities generated $74.5 million in cash flow, while we invested $16.5 million in capital expenditures.
We reduced our revolving credit facility debt as working capital changes provided cash this quarter.
We anticipate a reversal in working capital during the fourth quarter as we accumulate coal stocks for winter and prepare for increased production in 2021.
Furthermore, we distributed a $0.06 per share dividend, utilizing $5 million in cash, and have announced the third quarter dividend.
We set the dividend at a level we believe can be maintained even in challenging market conditions.
Although our Board of Directors makes this decision quarterly, we believe we have sufficient liquidity to sustain this dividend.
At the quarter's end, our trailing twelve-month gross leverage ratio was 3.37 times, and our net leverage ratio was 2.98 times.
We aim to continue implementing our long-term capital allocation strategy, primarily focusing on reducing gross leverage to three times or below.
To achieve this, we bought back $7.5 million face value of SXCP notes in the third quarter and an additional $33.2 million in the fourth quarter.
Let's conclude with slide nine.
As we continue to operate in these unprecedented times, our top priority remains the safety and welfare of our employees and contractors.
We will continue to take all necessary measures to ensure they are well-equipped, protected, and able to perform their duties confidently.
We remain committed to our core businesses and optimizing our operations, including our logistics assets.
As announced last quarter, we've made significant progress in reducing costs and enhancing near-term stability by collaborating with customers to address current market challenges and long-term supply needs.
We also continue to maintain our assets to ensure efficient long-term operations, even if short-term activity levels fluctuate.
We take pride in our investments, which have created the industry's highest quality assets, and we are committed to fully utilizing and maintaining them.
Lastly, we are confident in our revised financial targets, and our entire organization is focused on achieving these results.
We can now open the floor for questions and answers.
Summary:
output:
compname reports q3 loss per share $0.03.
q3 loss per share $0.03.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:This data is accessible in the Investor Relations portion of the site.
On the call, we'll discuss non-GAAP financial metrics when evaluating the company's performance.
A comparison of these metrics to GAAP financial measures can be found in our call materials.
Synchrony Financial does not edit or guarantee the accuracy of third-party transcripts of our earnings calls.
Synchrony's model demonstrated its strength in our Q3 financial results.
We expanded our reach to more partners and customers.
New accounts increased by 17% to 6.2 million, while average active accounts grew by 5% to 67.2 million in the quarter.
This growth is largely due to our effective combination of data-driven insights, smooth customer experiences, and top-tier product offerings, which strongly appeal to customers.
Synchrony's multi-channel capabilities allow our partners and customers to interact wherever and whenever they prefer, while our diverse financing options and value propositions provide them with flexibility.
As we continue to anticipate and meet the needs of our partners and customers, we generate more value and increase usage.
This led to an 11% rise in purchase volume per active account and a 16% increase in total purchase volume compared to the previous year in Q3.
However, this strong purchase volume was mostly offset by consistently high payment rates resulting from government stimulus and industry-wide forbearance measures, leading to a modest 2% growth in loans, including those held for sale.
The net interest margin of 15.45% was 165 basis points higher than last year, mainly due to reduced excess liquidity.
Operating costs decreased by 10% year-over-year and 7% year-to-date as our cost-cutting initiatives progress as planned.
We're on track to reduce our expense base by about $210 million by year-end while continuing to invest in our business.
The efficiency ratio for the quarter was 38.7%, largely unchanged from last year.
Credit performance remained strong.
Net charge-offs were 2.18% for Q3, a decrease of 224 basis points from the previous year.
Net earnings were $1.1 billion or $2 per diluted share, including a $0.33 benefit from the reserve release related to reclassifying the Gap portfolio as held for sale.
Regarding our balance sheet, deposits decreased by $3 billion or 5% compared to last year, reflecting our retail deposit rate actions to manage excess liquidity.
Deposits made up 82% of our funding mix at quarter-end, a slight increase from last year due to debt retirement.
During the quarter, we returned $1.4 billion in capital through $1.3 billion in share repurchases and $124 million in common stock dividends.
We continue to reinvest in our business.
As highlighted at our recent Investor Day, our ability to stay agile and adapt to the changing consumer finance landscape is driven by ongoing investment in our product suite and innovative digital capabilities.
Over the past decade, the introduction of digital wallets, point-of-sale financing, and a wider range of installment options has shown the importance of diversity, accessibility, and utility in both products and customer experience.
Synchrony has continuously evolved by adding new financing options, enhancing our technology platform, and expanding our channels and distribution networks to reach and serve more partners and customers in sustainable ways that create greater value for all.
In addition to launching new products and partner programs, we're focusing on innovative ways to scale the distribution of our product suite.
We recently announced an expanded strategic partnership with Fiserv, allowing small businesses to access Synchrony products and services and accept private label credit card payments through Fiserv's Clover point-of-sale and business management platform.
This will enable accelerated growth for small businesses, helping merchants attract more customers and generate more revenue by offering our customers greater flexibility and choice in making purchases.
We'll also explore additional opportunities to cross-sell Synchrony products to existing Clover merchants.
This strategic partnership deepens Synchrony's ecosystem and supports our growth strategy to expand and accelerate innovative product offerings through additional distribution channels.
It builds on our momentum to bring our products to merchants faster and leverages Synchrony's leadership in financing, analytics, and services.
We're excited to use Clover's point-of-sale innovations to continue transforming the way people purchase while helping merchants grow.
As we and our partners strive to provide more comprehensive customer access to financial products and resources, we're excited to expand our partnership with PayPal.
As announced in late September, Synchrony will launch PayPal Savings, a new PayPal-branded savings account.
This unique opportunity will allow us to expand the distribution of our savings product to a specific set of customers with features and functionality within the PayPal app, delivering an enhanced customer experience while also diversifying our deposit base at an attractively low acquisition cost.
In addition to expanding our product suite and distribution network, we also aim to enhance partner and customer engagement through customized value propositions and omnichannel capabilities.
We recently launched two industry-first retail health and wellness credit cards: the myWalgreens Mastercard and myWalgreens private label credit card, which reward customers with savings on future health and wellness purchases.
MyWalgreens credit cardholders can earn 10% Walgreens cash rewards on eligible Walgreens branded products and 5% Walgreens cash rewards on other eligible brands and pharmacy purchases.
