MyWalgreens Mastercard holders can also earn 3% Walgreens cash rewards on eligible grocery and health and wellness purchases elsewhere, including healthcare providers, and 1% Walgreens cash rewards on eligible purchases anywhere Mastercard credit cards are accepted.
In a world where consumers are increasingly responsible for a larger share of their health-related costs, we believe these value propositions will drive considerable value while providing greater financing flexibility for health-related needs and enhancing loyalty over time.
Synchrony's digital capabilities allow us to seamlessly engage with customers wherever they are.
We have deep digital integration across Walgreens' web, mobile, and native app channels, enabling customers to apply and instantly buy through all these channels.
We've launched frictionless customer experiences, leveraging technology capabilities like QR codes, quick screen (a real-time pre-screen of one), customer-initiated pre-qualification, a direct-to-device in-store application process, card servicing integrated seamlessly into the Walgreens app, and API integration with the myWalgreens loyalty program.
Although it's still early, initial data suggests that both the value proposition and dynamic customer experience we've achieved with Walgreens are resonating well with cardholders, driving spend both inside and outside of Walgreens in categories such as grocery, health, and wellness.
By empowering our partners and customers with best-in-class wallet optionality and compelling outcomes, Synchrony is increasingly well-positioned as the partner of choice.
With over 65 million active accounts, Synchrony has market-leading reach and deep, diverse lending insights that enable us to better anticipate customer needs and determine which financing options will optimize utilization and drive lifetime value.
Whether it's our dual, co-branded and private label credit cards, our various SetPay installment products, or our Synchrony Mastercard, we have a deep understanding of when, why, and how customers seek financing solutions for their everyday purchases.
We're particularly excited about the opportunity we see for our Synchrony Mastercard, which allows us to tap into the $500 billion general purpose credit card market.
We're taking a measured approach to growth, but by leveraging our scale and underwriting expertise, we've been able to identify better-performing customer segments, acquire more customers at lower CPAs, and refine our channel strategy over the past two years.
Presently, Synchrony Mastercard provides diverse value offerings, which we combine with our pricing approach to broaden our customer base and enhance conversion rates, while also offering excellent digital functionality through dApply, Apple Wallet integration, and our mobile application.
Customers can view their various banking products, including money market and high-yield savings accounts, as well as credit card balances and transaction histories.
This combination of value and seamless digital experience strongly appeals to our customers, resulting in a 36% increase in purchase volume compared to the same period in 2019.
We're also noticing increased engagement with the product and brand, as spending per active account has risen by 40% compared to 2019.
We're very enthusiastic about our Synchrony Mastercard.
It's a crucial component of our product suite strategy that we believe will help us capture a larger share of customers' primary spending and should drive scalable growth and above-average returns for our business in the long run.
Synchrony's third quarter financial performance showed widespread strength across our operations, characterized by a double-digit increase in purchase volume and continued loan growth, a significant improvement in our net interest margin, historically low losses and delinquencies, and ongoing cost management.
These results combined to produce $1.1 billion in net earnings or $2 per diluted share, a 4.9% return on average assets, and a 40.1% return on tangible common equity.
These outcomes clearly demonstrate the effectiveness of Synchrony's unique business model, which builds on our extensive expertise in consumer lending and utilizes advanced digital capabilities through our comprehensive multi-product suite to reach and serve a wide and diverse range of partners and customers.
Examining our third quarter performance more closely, starting with purchase volume, which grew 16% compared to last year and 16% compared to 2019 excluding Walmart, indicates clear widespread strength in consumer demand.
This is also reflected in our purchase volume per account, which rose 11% compared to last year.
Dual card and co-branded cards made up 40% of the purchase volume in the third quarter and increased 29% from the previous year.
In terms of loan receivables, excluding the impact of reclassifying the Gap portfolio as held for sale, dual and co-branded cards accounted for 24% of the portfolio and grew 4% from the previous year.
The number of average active accounts increased 5% compared to last year, and new accounts rose 17%, totaling over 6 million new accounts in the third quarter and more than 17.5 million new accounts overall.
In late August, we reached an agreement to sell the Gap portfolio, resulting in the reclassification of $3.5 billion of loan receivables as held for sale, which reduced our ending loan receivables balance.
Excluding the impact of this reclassification, loan receivables would have grown by 2% compared to the previous year, as the period's strong purchase volume growth was largely offset by a consistently high payment rate.
The payment rate for the third quarter was approximately 200 basis points higher compared to last year.
Interest and fees on loans grew 2% compared to last year, reflecting similar growth in average loan receivables.
Net interest income was 6% higher than last year, primarily due to a decrease in interest expense resulting from lower benchmark rates.
RSAs were $1.3 billion in the third quarter and 6.38% of average receivables.
The $367 million year-over-year increase mainly reflected the impact of lower provision for credit losses and continued strong program performance, including growth and improvement in net interest income.
To provide context, remember that RSAs are designed to align interests between ourselves and each of our partners.
This means driving growth in attractive risk-adjusted returns and enhancing program profitability.
This allows each partner to share in the program's performance, so when profitability expands, our partners benefit from that upside.
When considering the combined $1.4 billion year-over-year improvement in net interest income, net losses, and the reserve change, we shared $367 million of that through the RSA.
Regarding our credit performance, the provision for losses was $25 million.
This quarter's provision included a reserve release of $407 million, which incorporated our continued strength in credit performance, an optimistic macroeconomic environment, and the impact of reclassifying our Gap portfolio loan receivables as held for sale.
This resulted in a reserve reduction of approximately $247 million.
Other income decreased by $37 million, generally reflecting higher loyalty program costs due to increased purchase volume during the quarter.
Other expenses decreased by $106 million compared to the previous year.
As you may recall, last year we recognized an $89 million restructuring charge, and we continue to see benefits from lower operational losses.
Moving to our platform results, we observed widespread purchase volume growth across all five platforms, indicating strong consumer demand.
Our Home & Auto, Diversified & Value, Digital, and Health & Wellness platforms each experienced double-digit year-over-year growth in purchase volume.
The 10% year-over-year increase in Home & Auto was generally driven by strong retailer performance across almost all verticals, while purchase volume in Diversified & Value increased 25%, reflecting the continued return to in-person retail experiences.
In Digital, the 21% increase was due to widespread growth across our partners coupled with growth in our new programs with Verizon and Venmo.
In Health & Wellness, the 10% growth in purchase volume primarily reflected consumers feeling more comfortable with the environment and undergoing planned procedures.
Meanwhile, purchase volume grew a more modest 2% in Lifestyle, reflecting widespread growth across the platform but facing a tough comparison to last year's strong growth in power sports.
Loan receivable growth trends by platform generally showed modest growth rates compared to the previous year, as higher purchase volume was largely offset by elevated payment rates.
The exception was in our Diversified & Value platform, which was impacted by store closures in 2020.
Average active account trends varied by platform, increasing by as much as 10% in Diversified & Value and 7% in Digital, while Home & Auto and Health & Wellness average active accounts were generally flat.
The active account growth in Diversified & Value largely reflected the return to in-store retail experiences.
Digital active accounts increased compared to the previous year due to greater engagement across our existing customer base as well as the impact of recent program launches.
Interest and fee trends generally improved across the platform, with the exception of Diversified & Value, which decreased due to lower receivables.
Moving on to net interest income and margin trends, the accumulated savings by consumers resulting from stimulus, forbearance, and lower discretionary spending continued to impact payment rates during the third quarter.
Payment rates were approximately 260 basis points higher than our five-year historical average.
However, we've started to see some signs of moderation in certain groups, as the payment rate was about 200 basis points higher year-over-year compared to almost 300 basis points higher in the year-over-year comparison for the second quarter.
We expect the payment rate to gradually normalize as consumer spending remains robust, excess savings peak, and widespread forbearance diminishes.
Interest and fees increased approximately 2% in the third quarter, reflecting average loan receivable growth.
Net interest income rose 6% from last year, reflecting the year-over-year improvement in interest and fees as well as lower interest expenses for the period.
The net interest margin was 15.45% compared to last year's margin of 13.8%, a 165 basis point improvement year-over-year driven by the mix of interest-earning assets and favorable interest-bearing liabilities costs.
The proportion of loan receivables as a percentage of total earning assets rose by 550 basis points from 78.3% to 83.8% due to reduced liquidity held during the quarter
This led to a 106 basis point increase in our net interest margin
The cost of interest-bearing liabilities was 1.31%, a 59 basis point improvement year-over-year mainly because of lower benchmark rates and changes in funding mix
This resulted in a 51 basis point rise in our net interest margin
The yield on loan receivables was 19.59%, a 10 basis point improvement compared to the previous year
This caused an 8 basis point enhancement in our net interest margin
I will now discuss our key credit trends on Slide 10
Let's first examine our delinquency trends, where increased payment rates have continued to drive year-over-year improvements
Our 30-plus day delinquency rate was 2.42% compared to 2.67% last year
Our 90-plus day delinquency rate was 1.05% compared to 1.24% last year
It's worth noting that if we remove the impact of the Gap program from the third quarters of this year and last year, the 30-plus day delinquency metric would have decreased by about 40 basis points instead of 25 basis points, and the 90-plus day metric would have dropped by about 25 basis points instead of 19 basis points
Regarding our portfolio's loss performance, our net charge-off rate was 2.18% compared to 4.42% last year
This year-over-year improvement was mainly driven by the strong delinquency trends we've experienced
Our allowance for credit losses as a percentage of loan receivables was 11.28%
Let's move to Slide 11 to discuss expenses
Overall expenses decreased by $106 million or 10% from last year to $961 million, primarily reflecting the impact of the previous year's restructuring charge of $89 million and lower operational losses
The efficiency ratio for the third quarter was 38.7% compared to 39.7% last year
This metric remains elevated compared to our historical average due to lower revenue resulting from the impact of higher payment rates and lower average receivables
We continue to maintain a disciplined focus on cost containment while making strategic investments in our business to enhance our competitive advantage and create long-term value for shareholders
Moving to Slide 12, given the reduction in loan receivables in 2020 and early 2021, along with the strength of our deposit platform, we continue to maintain a higher level of liquidity
While we believe it's prudent to keep a higher liquidity level during uncertain and volatile periods, we continue to actively manage our funding profile to mitigate excess liquidity and optimize our funding structure
As a result of this strategy, there was a shift in our funding mix during the third quarter
Our deposits declined by $3.2 billion from last year and our securitized and unsecured funding sources decreased by $3 billion
This resulted in deposits comprising 82% of our funding, compared to 80% last year, with securitized and unsecured funding each making up 9% of our funding sources at quarter-end
Total liquidity including undrawn credit facilities was $18.4 billion, which equated to 20% of our total assets, down from 28% last year
Before I provide details on our capital position, it should be noted that we chose to take advantage of the transition rules issued by the joint federal banking agencies, which has two main benefits
First, it delays the effect of the CECL transition adjustment for an additional two years
Second, it allows for a portion of the current period provisioning to be deferred and amortized with the transition adjustment
Under this framework, we ended the quarter with a CET1 ratio of 17.1% under the CECL transition rules, 130 basis points above last year's level of 15.8%
The Tier 1 capital ratio was 18% under the CECL transition rules compared to 16.7% last year
The total capital ratio increased 120 basis points to 19.3% and the Tier 1 capital plus reserves ratio on a fully phased-in basis decreased to 26.6% compared to 27.3% last year
During the quarter, we returned $1.4 billion to shareholders, which included $1.3 billion in share repurchases and $124 million in common stock dividends
Our business generates strong returns and substantial capital due to our commitment to drive growth at appropriate risk-adjusted returns, the scalability of our technology platform, and our ongoing cost discipline
We will continue to take an opportunistic approach to returning our excess capital to shareholders as our business performance and market conditions allow, subject to our capital plan and any regulatory restrictions
While there are several external variables that are difficult to predict precisely, we generally expect the third quarter's key operating trends to remain stable in the fourth quarter
Our forecast is based on a stable and improving macroeconomic environment and the pandemic continuing to be largely under control
We anticipate strong consumer demand through the holiday season to support continued strength in purchase volume
This strength, partially offset by continued elevation in payment rates, should lead to modest growth in receivables
Our net interest margin will likely be consistent with the third quarter of 2021
Our provision for credit losses will continue to reflect the impact of asset growth, credit performance, and macroeconomic factors, as well as continued reserve reductions related to the Gap portfolio
As credit losses begin to normalize, we expect the RSA as a percentage of average loan receivables to start moderating
Lastly, regarding our operating expenses, we expect the acceleration in purchase volume to contribute to a slight sequential increase in absolute dollars for the fourth quarter
However, we still anticipate full-year operating expenses to be lower compared to 2020
As we conclude the year and look to the future, we're excited about the opportunities we see to continue driving strong financial results and shareholder value
We are well-positioned to execute on the strategy we outlined during our Investor Day and drive sustainable growth and attractive risk-adjusted returns simply by continuing to leverage our inherent core strengths, the breadth and depth of our business model, the scalability of our innovative digital capabilities, and customer lifetime value expansion we drive through our diversified product suite and powerful value propositions
I'm truly proud of the results that we as a team continue to deliver for Synchrony's partners, customers, and stakeholders
We have a unique understanding of the wide range of needs that our partners and customers seek to address at any given time, and our differentiated approach to addressing those needs enables us to deliver solutions and experiences that deeply resonate
Whether it's through the optionality embedded within our diverse product suite and customized value propositions or the many ways in which we power the connection between our partners and customers, Synchrony continues to reach, engage, and serve more customers and drive greater, more sustainable outcomes for our stakeholders
We will now begin the Q&A session
To accommodate as many participants as possible, I'd like to ask the participants to please limit themselves to one primary and one follow-up question
If you have additional questions, the Investor Relations team will be available after the call
Operator, please start the Q&A session
Summary:
output:
third quarter 2021 net earnings of $1.1 billion, or $2.00 per diluted share.
q3 net earnings included a $187 million post-tax benefit, or $0.33 per diluted share.
q3 net interest income increased $201 million, or 6%, to $3.7 billion.
q3 provision for credit losses decreased $1.2 billion, or 98%, to $25 million.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Check our website at transdigm.com for additional presentation materials and call replay details.
During this call, we will reference non-GAAP financial metrics including EBITDA as defined, adjusted net income, and adjusted earnings per share.
I'll begin with a brief overview of our strategy and quarterly performance before handing over to Kevin and Mike for more in-depth analysis.
We stand out in the industry for maintaining a consistent strategy and focus on creating shareholder value throughout all stages of the aerospace cycle, in both good and challenging times.
Let me summarize the key reasons we believe this to be true.
Proprietary products generate about 90% of our sales, with over 75% coming from products where we are the sole supplier.
The majority of our EBITDA is derived from aftermarket revenues, which typically offer higher margins and greater stability during downturns over extended periods.
We adhere to a consistent long-term strategy.
Our focus is on owning and managing proprietary aerospace businesses with significant aftermarket potential.
We employ a straightforward, proven value-based operational approach.
Our organization is decentralized with a unique compensation structure aligned closely with shareholder interests.
We target acquisitions that fit our strategy and offer potential for private equity-like returns.
Our capital structure and allocation strategy are integral to our value creation approach.
We aim to provide our shareholders with private equity-like returns combined with public market liquidity.
This requires meticulous attention to value creation details and careful capital allocation.
The commercial aerospace market remains challenging, but we're seeing some positive signs.
We observed another significant sequential increase in commercial aftermarket bookings during Q2, marking the second consecutive quarter of substantial growth.
The air travel recovery, which concerned us last quarter, appears somewhat improved, though still inconsistent, potentially delaying the ramp-up by a quarter or so.
We've prioritized two key operational areas during this downturn that we can somewhat control: tight cost management, which we believe is well-handled, and ensuring substantial liquidity, which also seems secure.
Barring any major disruptions or shutdowns, we should emerge from this situation with considerable financial flexibility.
We continue to explore potential M&A opportunities and remain attentive to our capital allocation.
Both M&A activity and capital markets are challenging to predict, particularly in the current climate.
In Q2, we acquired the Cobham Aero Connectivity business for an enterprise value of $965 million.
Regarding divestitures, we've recently signed agreements to sell three additional, less proprietary and primarily defense-focused businesses for approximately $240 million.
These businesses collectively generate revenues of about $180 million with EBITDA margins in the low 20% range.
We expect to receive all proceeds in Q3.
We are currently considering the sale of one more primarily defense-oriented business.
At present, I don't anticipate making any significant dividend payments or share repurchases for the next three to four quarters, or at least until the commercial market shows stronger signs of recovery and our leverage stabilizes, but we'll continue to monitor the situation and adjust our approach if necessary.
We believe we're in the best possible position given the current circumstances and will remain vigilant, ready to respond to market developments as they occur.
Now, I'll hand over to Kevin to review our performance.
I'll begin with my usual overview of our quarterly results by key market and business profitability, followed by comments on recent acquisition activity and our fiscal 2021 outlook.
Our Q2 fiscal 2021 performance continued to be significantly impacted by reduced travel demand due to the pandemic.
However, the commercial aerospace industry has shown signs of recovery in recent months, driven by COVID-19 vaccine distribution and increasing air traffic, particularly in certain domestic markets.
Our business experienced another quarter of sequential improvement in commercial aftermarket revenues, with total commercial aftermarket revenues up 12% compared to Q1.
I'm pleased to report that we continued to sequentially expand our EBITDA as defined margin, thanks to careful cost structure management and adherence to our operating strategy in this challenging commercial environment.
Let's review our revenue by market category.
For the remainder of the call, I'll provide commentary on a pro forma basis, comparing to the prior-year period in 2020 as if we owned the same mix of businesses in both periods.
This market discussion now includes the recent Cobham Aero Connectivity acquisition and excludes the impact of any divestitures completed by the end of Q2.
In the business sector, which typically accounts for nearly 65% of our earnings, we'll divide our analysis into original equipment manufacturers and aftermarket segments.
Our overall commercial OEM market earnings decreased by about 43% in the second quarter compared to the same period last year.
We anticipate that demand for our commercial OEM products will remain significantly lower throughout the latter half of 2021 due to decreased OEM production rates and airlines postponing or canceling new aircraft orders.
The long-term outlook for the commercial aerospace industry is uncertain and continually changing.
We expect a suppressed commercial OEM end market for an indefinite period compared to pre-pandemic levels.
Nevertheless, recent statements from Airbus regarding potential A320 production increases in 2022 and beyond are quite promising.
On a brighter note, second quarter orders showed strong sequential growth of over 20% compared to first quarter orders and significantly exceeded sales.
As we noted in our previous report, the improvement in orders we're observing likely indicates a slowdown in OEM inventory reduction.
Shifting our focus to our commercial aftermarket business discussion.
Overall commercial aftermarket revenues fell by roughly 39% in the second quarter compared to the same quarter last year.
This quarterly decrease was mainly caused by reduced demand in our passenger and interior submarkets.
However, our commercial transport freight market experienced slight growth, partially offsetting this decline.
To reiterate, sequentially, total commercial aftermarket revenues grew by approximately 12% in the second quarter, another positive indicator.
Commercial aftermarket orders were still lower this quarter compared to the same period last year.
However, the decline in orders was less severe than the observed decrease in flight traffic, with freight and business jet orders continuing to show improvement.
Second quarter orders sequentially improved by almost 30% and significantly outpaced sales.
This is likely due to a slowdown in airline inventory reduction, increased flight activity, and future planning.
To highlight a few key considerations, global revenue passenger miles remain low, though they have bottomed out and are now recovering.
IATA's most recent forecast predicts that calendar year 2021 revenue passenger miles will be 57% below 2019 levels, but we are cautiously optimistic.
There was an increase in domestic air travel in March and April, and airlines are seeing strong bookings that will drive summer flight schedules.
Some airlines have already announced domestic wide-body routes to meet the expected demand this summer.
IATA predicts a strong second half of calendar year 2021 with a rebound in domestic travel in the U.S. returning to 2019 levels of revenue passenger miles and China exceeding that level.
There is also potential for more international travel as governments consider revising travel restrictions.
Regarding cargo demand, this was weaker before the COVID-19 crisis as freight tonne kilometers (FTKs) declined from the peak in 2017.
However, a reduction in passenger belly cargo capacity and an increase in e-commerce have helped cargo operations recover more quickly than commercial travel.
Business jet usage data has shown that activity in certain regions has returned to pre-pandemic levels or better.
This is currently due to personal and leisure travel rather than business travel.
It remains uncertain whether business jet usage will continue to grow, but current trends are encouraging.
We believe there is a global pent-up demand for travel.
We see evidence of this demand through the recovery in domestic travel, particularly in the U.S. and China, and the optimism of airlines for the summer season.
Domestic travel is currently benefiting from international travel restrictions and could compensate for some lost international travel in the market.
Eventually, with vaccine distribution and the lifting of travel restrictions, passenger demand worldwide will increase.
Historically, personal travel has accounted for the largest percentage of revenue passenger miles.
Forecasts still indicate a more significant increase in personal travel in the latter half of this calendar year, followed later by business travel, and we are hopeful this will be the case.
Let me now discuss our defense market, which traditionally accounts for 35% or less of our total revenue.
The defense market revenue, which includes both OEM and aftermarket revenues, increased by approximately 8% in the second quarter compared to the same period last year.
Our defense order book remains robust, and we continue to expect our defense business to grow throughout the remainder of the year.
Turning now to profitability.
I will primarily discuss our operating performance or EBITDA as defined.
EBITDA as defined of about $519 million for the second quarter was down 23% compared to the same quarter last year.
EBITDA as defined margin in the quarter was approximately 43.5%.
We were able to improve our EBITDA as defined margin by nearly 100 basis points sequentially despite the acquisition dilution from the recent Cobham purchase of about 100 basis points as well.
I'll provide a brief update on our recent acquisition.
The integration of Cobham is progressing smoothly under the guidance of our experienced EVP, Joel Reiss.
We've owned Cobham for just over four months and are satisfied with the purchase so far.
Cobham has been divided into two operational divisions: Canyon AeroConnect in Prescott, Arizona, and Chelton Limited in Marlow, U.K. Two seasoned TransDigm presidents are overseeing the integration of these divisions.
Let's discuss our projections for 2021.
We're not yet ready to provide official fiscal 2021 sales EBITDA and net income guidance at this time.
We'll resume providing guidance when we have a clearer view of the future.
Like most aerospace suppliers, we're optimistic about a significant increase in activity during the second half of the calendar year.
Currently, we're encouraged by the recovery in our commercial OEM and aftermarket orders in the first half of our fiscal year, as well as the improvement in our commercial aftermarket revenues.
Regarding the defense market and our previous comments on defense revenue growth from the Q4 and Q1 earnings calls, we now anticipate defense revenue growth in the mid-single-digit percentage range for fiscal 2021 compared to the previous year.
Our earlier expectation for fiscal 2021 defense revenue growth was low to mid-single-digit growth.
Furthermore, due to the ongoing uncertainty in commercial market channels and in line with our previous statements, we are not providing an expected dollar range for fiscal 2021 EBITDA as defined.
We anticipate a steady increase in commercial aftermarket revenue going forward and expect full-year fiscal 2021 EBITDA margin to be approximately 44%, which may fluctuate depending on the pace of commercial aftermarket recovery.
This includes a dilutive effect on our EBITDA margin from the Cobham Aero Connectivity acquisition.
Mike will provide details on other fiscal 2021 financial assumptions and updates.
To conclude, I'm pleased with the company's performance during this challenging period for the commercial aerospace industry and our commitment to creating value for our stakeholders.
The commercial aerospace market recovery is underway, and current trends are promising.
There's still uncertainty about the speed of recovery, but our team remains focused on controlling what we can.
We're closely monitoring ongoing developments in the commercial aerospace industry and ensuring we're prepared to meet demand as it returns.
We're looking forward to the second half of 2021 and expect our consistent strategy to continue delivering the value you've come to expect from us.
I'll quickly address a few additional financial matters for the quarter and the full fiscal year.
For the quarter, organic growth was negative 20%, due to declines in our commercial end markets, despite healthy defense growth.
Our tax expectations for the full year remain unchanged, with GAAP cash and adjusted rates expected to be in the 18% to 22% range.
Regarding tax rates beyond FY '21, we're monitoring potential changes in the U.S. tax code under the new administration and will provide guidance on future rate expectations once any legislation is finalized.
We now expect the full-year interest expense to be $1.06 billion, reduced from prior guidance, primarily due to refinancing activities completed this year.
Regarding cash and liquidity, we had another quarter of positive free cash flow.
Free cash flow, which we define as EBITDA less cash interest payments, cash capex, and cash taxes, was approximately $146 million.
For the full fiscal year, we expect to continue generating positive free cash flow as we define it.
In line with our November guidance, we still expect this amount to be around $800 million, possibly slightly better, for our fiscal '21.
We ended the second quarter with $4.1 billion in cash, down from $4.9 billion at the end of last quarter.
Note that last quarter's $4.9 billion balance was before the Cobham acquisition, which closed on January 5 for an enterprise value of $965 million.
Accounting for this acquisition, our Q2 net debt-to-LTM-EBITDA ratio was 8.2 times.
With our last pre-COVID quarter now out of the LTM EBITDA calculation, we believe the net debt-to-EBITDA ratio as of our second quarter end is at or very close to its peak.
In subsequent quarters, it should either remain relatively stable or, more likely, start to show gradual improvement as our commercial end markets recover.
From an overall cash liquidity and balance sheet perspective, we believe we're in a good position and well-prepared to withstand the current depressed commercial environment for an extended period.
Lastly, I'd like to provide a brief update on our ongoing U.S. DoD IG audit.
We've been actively engaged with the IG office, with some fluctuations, and continue to work through the audit process.
Based on our assessment and what we've observed, this ongoing audit appears to be similar in scope to our previous audits.
While it's difficult to predict exactly when a final report will be issued publicly, we anticipate this might occur sometime during Q3 or Q4 of our fiscal '21.
Summary:
output: fiscal 2021 financial guidance remains suspended at this time.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:During this call, management will reference estimated COVID-19 impacts on Q2 2020 results and discuss July business performance.
Management is sharing these insights to provide additional context, but may not continue this practice in future quarters.
I'm glad to be speaking with you today.
I want to acknowledge our Teleflex employees globally for their extraordinary efforts during these challenging times to ensure our products reach those who need them most.
Regarding our Q2 results, given the pandemic's escalation, we're pleased with our performance as it exceeded our expectations and showed improving trends in areas most affected by procedure postponements.
Q2 revenue was $567 million, down 12% year-over-year on a constant currency basis, with COVID-19 causing an estimated 20% negative impact.
Excluding COVID effects, we estimate underlying growth of about 8% constant currency, near the high end of our initial 2020 guidance range.
Our adjusted EPS of $1.93 also significantly surpassed our expectations, reflecting procedure recovery and careful expense management.
We've initiated a workforce reduction plan to enhance long-term profitability, primarily targeting EMEA sales and marketing and OEM manufacturing.
Q2 revenue declined 12% constant currency and 13.1% as reported, mainly due to COVID-19's estimated $144 million impact across several categories, partially offset by $14 million in higher vascular access and other product demand.
Adjusted gross and operating margins were 53.9% and 21.8%, down 380 and 340 basis points respectively, due to lower volumes and unfavorable mix, partially mitigated by cost containment efforts.
While revenue and profitability declined year-over-year, our overall financial performance demonstrates our diversified portfolio's resilience.
COVID-19 negatively impacted Interventional Urology, Surgical, Interventional Access, Anesthesia and OEM revenues, somewhat offset by tailwinds in Vascular Access and other categories.
We saw encouraging sequential improvements in May and June for the most affected businesses after a difficult April.
Despite improving trends into July, we remain cautious due to renewed pressure on hospital capacity in some areas and are not reinstating 2020 guidance at this time.
Americas revenue declined 16% to $312.5 million, with growth in vascular access and respiratory products outweighed by other declines.
EMEA revenue fell 8% to $131.6 million, with similar trends to the Americas.
Asia revenue decreased 7.8% to $67.1 million.
OEM revenue declined 0.7% constant currency to $55.8 million, reflecting lagged COVID-19 impacts on customer orders for non-emergent procedure products.
The acquisition of HPC is progressing well with integration efforts, and the business is performing satisfactorily under our management.
We will now examine our revenue by global product categories.
Comments on global product category growth will be based on constant currency, in line with our reportable segments discussion.
We'll begin with Vascular Access.
Q2 revenues rose 8.8% to $164.9 million, driven by growth in our central venous catheter and EZ-IO products.
We believe COVID-19 boosted our vascular products' growth rates by about 5% in the second quarter.
Next is Interventional Access.
Revenue for the second quarter was $82.6 million, a 20.3% decrease from the previous year.
The decline was primarily due to COVID-19-related postponements of certain non-emergency procedures.
We estimate underlying growth was in the mid-single digits, after accounting for an approximate 24% COVID-19 impact.
Q2 revenues were $64.9 million, a 23% decrease from the previous year.
The revenue drop was caused by reduced sales of laryngeal masks and regional anesthesia products.
We estimate COVID-19 had a negative impact of about 22% in the quarter.
Revenue fell by 28.4% to $67.3 million, primarily due to lower sales of our ligation portfolio and instruments.
We estimate a substantial 30% impact from COVID-19 during Q2.
However, we've observed monthly improvements since the April low point.
Next is Interventional Urology.
Q2 revenue decreased 40.9% to $40.1 million.
We estimate a COVID-19-related impact of approximately $58 million during Q2.
This product line was the most affected by the cancellation of elective procedures in our portfolio.
However, as the UroLift procedure is typically performed in outpatient settings, we anticipated it would be among the first procedures to resume as the U.S. reopened, which has been confirmed by sequential improvements from April to May, May to June, and June into July.
Lastly, our other category, comprising respiratory and urology care products, grew 5.4% to $91.4 million.
We believe the quarter's growth was largely due to increased demand for certain humidification and breathing products related to COVID-19.
Excluding the estimated COVID-19 benefit, we believe the other category would have shown a slight decline compared to the same period last year.
This concludes my remarks on second quarter revenue performance.
Moving on to clinical and commercial updates.
Our clinical evidence for UroLift expanded in the second quarter with data from two studies presented at the AUA 2020 Virtual Science Event and another study published in the Canadian Journal of Urology.
The first AUA 2020 study was a meta-analysis comparing sexual function in patients treated with UroLift versus medical therapy, while the second study analyzed patient outcomes from the Real World Retrospective study compared to the L.I.F.T. pivotal trial and P.U.L.S.A.R. urinary retention trial.
The first study compared sexual function outcomes in 849 sexually active men receiving daily treatments with alpha blockers or 5-alpha-reductase inhibitors to 190 men from UroLift System clinical studies at 12, 24, 36, and 48 months.
The analysis showed that UroLift patients experienced significant improvements in ejaculatory function, erectile function, and overall sexual satisfaction, while medical therapies did not improve these functions and sometimes reduced them.
The second study revealed similar IPSS scores and safety profiles among non-urinary retention and urinary retention patients treated with UroLift in both real-world and controlled studies.
Most retention patients became catheter independent by the study's end.
A study published in the Canadian Journal of Urology compared patient experiences with UroLift to those treated with steam injection tissue ablation.
Early postoperative results favored UroLift, showing better sexual function outcomes, less interference with daily activities, and higher patient satisfaction.
We continue to expand our clinical evidence, which should encourage adoption of UroLift as the standard of care for minimally invasive BPH treatment in a large global market.
Regarding commercial updates, we received FDA clearance for the UroLift Advanced Tissue Control (ATC) system, designed to optimize UroLift for treating obstructive median lobe.
We plan to test market acceptance for this product in late 2020.
Although only 5-10% of the market has an obstructive median lobe, this enhancement demonstrates our commitment to R&D and expanding our BPH leadership.
As non-emergent procedures resumed in Q2, we launched a pilot national DTC campaign in early July, building on our successful regional efforts.
The campaign will run from July to December, aiming to reach the 50% of 12 million men treated for BPH who believe prescription medications are their only option.
Initial patient response has been strong, with increased call volumes and web traffic to urolift.com.
Physician feedback has also been positive.
We submitted UroLift 2 for FDA 510(k) approval at the end of Q2.
Lastly, our interventional urology team has surpassed 200,000 patients treated with UroLift.
With U.S. DTC campaigns, about 2,700 trained urologists, and upcoming major market launches, we've only begun to address the estimated 100 million men globally with BPH.
Here are the paraphrased sentences:
Let's discuss some clinical updates in our Interventional business unit.
We've initiated enrollment for a prospective single-arm IDE study involving 150 patients across about 15 U.S. sites to assess the effectiveness of Teleflex's coronary guidewires and specialty catheters in chronic total occlusion percutaneous coronary intervention procedures.
The research will evaluate the performance of Teleflex's entire range of complex PCI products in chronic occlusive coronary disease, which presents the most challenging PCI environment.
We consider PCI a high-growth area within Interventional Cardiology, and we'll continue to invest in sectors that will enhance our weighted average market growth rates over time.
We persist in investing in clinical and commercial catalysts to maintain our upper single-digit revenue growth goals in a normalized environment.
Considering the previous discussion on the company's revenue performance, I'll start with the gross profit section.
In the quarter, adjusted gross profit decreased by approximately 19%, from $376.6 million in the previous year to $305.8 million.
The adjusted gross margin for the quarter was 53.9%, a decrease of 380 basis points compared to the same period last year.
The gross margin decline was mainly due to COVID-19-related impacts, including unfavorable product mix, reduced sales volumes, and increased manufacturing costs.
The impact on product mix was considerable for the quarter.
The negative revenue impact from COVID-19 tended to affect higher gross margin products more, including UroLift, Surgical, and Interventional Access.
We estimate that COVID-19 negatively impacted our adjusted gross profit by about $100 million in the quarter.
Due to the reduced revenue and gross profit resulting from COVID-19, we continue to seek opportunities to mitigate the earnings impact while maintaining Teleflex's ability to quickly recover once non-emergency procedures resume.
As such, operating expense reductions focus on non-revenue-generating and discretionary categories, including savings from meetings, travel, and management variable and performance-based compensation.
As a result of these efforts, we estimate that operating expenses were reduced by approximately $35 million in the second quarter.
While we expect the actions taken to continue providing opex savings through the second half of the year, the largest quarterly benefit will be realized in the second quarter.
Adjusted operating profit decreased by approximately 25%, from $164.7 million in the previous year to $123.9 million.
The second quarter operating margin was 21.8%, down 340 basis points year-over-year, due to gross margin declines and loss of operating leverage, partially offset by reduced operating expenses.
For the quarter, net interest expense decreased by approximately 24% to $15.5 million compared to the previous year quarter.
The decrease in interest expense primarily reflects lower interest rates associated with our variable rate debt, partially offset by higher average debt balances in the second quarter of 2020 compared to the same period last year.
During the quarter, we improved our liquidity by issuing $500 million of 8-year senior notes at 4.25%.
The proceeds from the note issuance were used to repay revolver borrowings.
Let's move on to taxes.
In the second quarter of 2020, our adjusted tax rate increased to 15.8% from 13.4% in the same period last year.
The year-over-year increase in our adjusted tax rate is primarily due to less benefit from stock-based compensation compared to the previous year period.
At the bottom line, second quarter adjusted earnings per share decreased by 27.4% to $1.93.
This result includes an estimated adverse impact of $1.18 from COVID-19 and a foreign exchange headwind of approximately $0.04.
Now I'd like to discuss our recently introduced workforce reduction plan.
In the second quarter of 2020, we committed to a workforce reduction plan designed to improve profitability by streamlining certain sales and marketing functions in our EMEA segment and certain manufacturing operations within our OEM segment.
We estimate that we will incur aggregate pre-tax restructuring charges between $10 million and $13 million, primarily consisting of termination benefits, which will result in future cash outlays.
We expect that most of these charges will be incurred before the end of 2020.
Once the plans are fully implemented, we project annual pre-tax savings between $11 million and $13 million, with savings expected to begin in 2020.
I will also provide a summary of all our ongoing restructuring and cost savings programs.
Including the latest workforce reduction plan, savings across all programs are expected to be between $59 million and $72 million.
Approximately half of the savings are expected to be realized in 2020 and 2021, with the remaining half over the period 2022 through 2024.
As such, we have a clear view of non-revenue-dependent margin expansion in the foreseeable future.
This also reinforces our confidence that our prior LRP financial targets of 6% to 7% revenue growth, 60% to 61% gross margin, and 30% to 31% operating margin remain the appropriate goals for Teleflex.
The question is not if we achieve them, but when.
Let's quickly review select balance sheet and cash flow highlights.
For the first half of 2020, cash flow from operations decreased by $23.3 million to $134 million, compared to $157.3 million in the same period last year.
The decrease is attributed to a $10 million pension contribution made in the first half of 2020 that was not made in the first half of the previous year, and a $54 million increase in first half 2020 contingent consideration payments compared to payments made in the first half of 2019.
Overall, the balance sheet remains healthy.
At the end of the second quarter, our cash balance increased to $553 million from $406 million at the end of the first quarter.
Net leverage at quarter end was approximately 2.6 times, providing comfortable headroom compared to our covenant, which requires that we stay below 4.5 times.
Lastly, we have no significant near-term debt maturities.
Before concluding, I'd like to inform you of a matter that will be disclosed in our 10-Q filed today.
In June, we began producing documents and information in response to a civil investigation demand received by our subsidiary, NeoTract, from the U.S. Department of Justice through the United States Attorney's Office for the Northern District of Georgia.
The DOJ is seeking information about communications with and certain rebate programs offered to a single NeoTract customer as part of their investigation of that customer.
Subsequently, in July, the DOJ informed us that they had opened an investigation under the Civil False Claims Act regarding NeoTract's operations broadly, in addition to the customer investigation.
We maintain policies and procedures to ensure compliance with the Anti-Kickback Statute, False Claims Act, and other applicable laws and regulations.
While we intend to cooperate with the government's investigation and request for information, we will vigorously defend our programs, practices, and conduct, which we believe are lawful and in line with industry best practices and standards.
We cannot currently predict the duration, scope, or outcome of this matter with certainty.
In conclusion, we delivered solid second quarter results as our diversified portfolio helped mitigate the impact of COVID-19 during April, and procedures have shown month-over-month improvement in May, June, and into July.
However, it remains challenging to predict the shape and duration of the recovery path.
While the next several quarters will have elements of uncertainty, we remain confident in our long-term underlying fundamentals and see great opportunities to serve our key constituents in the future.
As an organization, we will continue to focus on serving the majority of hospitals that remain open for procedures while closely monitoring select regions that are temporarily shut down.
We continue to adapt our business and opportunistically shift towards greater emphasis on digital tools, both internally and with our customers.
We will manage the business prudently while staying focused on capitalizing on the long-term potential of our global product portfolio.
Summary:
