compname reports q2 adjusted earnings per share $1.93 from continuing operations.
q2 adjusted earnings per share $1.93 from continuing operations.
q2 revenue $567 million versus refinitiv ibes estimate of $537.9 million.
new workforce reduction plan to further improve company cost structure announced.
not reinstating 2020 financial guidance due to covid-19 pandemic.
will incur aggregate pre-tax restructuring charges of $10 million to $13 million.
expect to begin realizing plan-related savings in 2020.
expect to achieve annual pre-tax savings of $11 million to $13 million once restructuring plans are fully implemented.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:During this conference call, management will discuss current business performance between quarters
The company is sharing these insights with investors to provide additional context, which may not be available in future quarters
We're glad to be speaking with you today
Teleflex achieved significant revenue growth in constant currency and a 27% increase in adjusted earnings per share year-over-year in Q3, despite greater challenges from rising COVID-19 cases due to the Delta variant
All of our global product categories saw growth in constant currency compared to last year, except for the "other" category due to selling respiratory assets to Medline
While macroeconomic conditions changed from Q2 expectations, Teleflex's strong Q3 2021 performance highlights the benefits of our diverse business and broad portfolio of essential medical products where we have market leadership
Our six main product categories and global presence helped offset declines in elective surgery-related revenues that were impacted by pauses in Q3
Investors may be aware that elective surgeries were restricted in up to 28 states during Q3
However, as we've seen throughout the pandemic, our diverse portfolio provides protection during COVID surges, with over 60% of our business either benefiting from or being relatively unaffected by pandemic disruptions
Although we don't usually provide updates within quarters, I'll share some Q3 details given the larger-than-expected increase in Delta variant cases
Compared to our Q2 earnings guidance, we saw a bigger pause in elective procedures than anticipated across parts of the US, Europe and Asia
However, as COVID-19 cases declined, we saw daily sales improve for products tied to elective surgeries as we progressed through September
In Q3, our Americas, EMEA, Asia and OEM segments showed resilience with all regions achieving constant currency revenue growth over 2020 despite Delta variant headwinds
This underscores the advantage of our diverse product portfolio
Q3 gross and operating margins exceeded levels from comparable periods in 2020 and 2019
Our continued margin expansion in 2021 has allowed us to increase targeted investments in growth drivers, an important part of our long-term strategy to enhance sustainable growth
We remain aware of uncertainty around COVID-19 as colder weather approaches in the Northern Hemisphere, new variants emerge, and healthcare worker shortages persist
As such, we think it's prudent to assume COVID-19 will remain a headwind and that a broad return to normal elective surgery volumes is unlikely in Q4
We expect these factors to be temporary, with a more normal environment likely in 2022
Based on year-to-date results and Q4 outlook, we're lowering our constant currency revenue growth forecast to 8-9% from 8.5-9.75% previously
This revision is mainly due to lower growth expectations for products used in elective procedures
However, given strong operating margin performance and balance sheet improvements, we're raising earnings per share guidance to $13.15-$13.35 from $12.90-$13.10 previously, implying 23-25% year-over-year growth
Now for a more detailed review of our Q3 results
Q3 revenue was $700.3 million, up 10.3% year-over-year in constant currency
This increase reflects our diverse portfolio's benefit and contributions from all segments, offset by COVID-19 impacts and the respiratory asset sale to Medline
Compared to Q3 2019, revenue increased 5.8% with accelerating growth in Vascular, OEM and Anesthesia, offsetting slowdowns in areas more exposed to the COVID-19 surge like Interventional Urology, Interventional and Surgical
Q3 growth and operating margin exceeded expectations, showing our diverse portfolio's strength, partially offset by greater-than-anticipated COVID-19 headwinds
Our year-to-date margin performance is encouraging for our long-term profitability goals
Q3 adjusted earnings per share of $3.51 increased 26.7% year-over-year, exceeding internal expectations
Despite higher COVID-19 headwinds, Q3 earnings performance reflects growth in our diverse portfolio, modest price increases, expanded gross margins and better-than-expected expense management
We continue executing our strategy for sustainable growth by investing in organic opportunities, innovation, margin expansion and using capital to reduce debt and pursue M&A
I'm proud of how our team continues to perform in a challenging environment
Our Q3 financial results demonstrate our diverse global portfolio's resilience, targeted growth investments in areas like UroLift and MANTA, and progress toward long-term margin goals
Now for a deeper look at revenue results
I'll start by reviewing our reportable segment revenues
Americas revenues were $417.3 million in Q3, up 10.9% year-over-year
Growth came from Surgical, Vascular and Interventional, partially offset by elective procedure pauses
EMEA revenues of $143.9 million increased 3.6% year-over-year, led by Interventional and Vascular products
EMEA benefited from improved procedure volumes compared to last year as countries reopened, despite some COVID-19 disruptions
Asia revenues were $75 million, up 6.3% year-over-year
Japan performed strongly, growing over 30%, but was partially offset by COVID-19 impacts in Southeast Asia
Now let's discuss Q3 revenues by global product category
As with segment reporting, global product category growth will be discussed in constant currency and ranked by business unit size
There were no significant differences in year-over-year selling days in Q3
Starting with Vascular Access, Q3 revenue increased 8.5% to $175.5 million
Our leadership in central venous catheters and midlines, along with our innovative coated PICC portfolio, continues to drive reliable growth
Vascular Access products remain important for COVID-19 patient treatment, contributing to Q3 strength due to increased infections
Our PICC portfolio continues to perform well, growing 10% year-over-year
We're investing in our differentiated PICC portfolio and gaining market share
Intraosseous also performed well in Q3, growing 12% year-over-year
Q3 revenue for Interventional was $104.3 million, up 10.4% year-over-year
We executed well in Q3, though increased COVID-19 cases slowed complex PCI and TAVR procedures
We continue investing in our interventional portfolio, including complex catheters and MANTA, our large-bore closure device
MANTA momentum remains strong globally, with over 80% growth year-over-year in Q3
Given MANTA's year-to-date performance, we're confident in achieving 8% share in 2021 of the $200-300 million global market opportunity
Let's now discuss Anesthesia.
In Q3, revenue reached $97.1 million, showing a 26.6% increase compared to the previous year.
Z-Medica products were responsible for approximately 85% of the growth, aligning with our projected revenue of $60-70 million for 2021, while tracheostomy product sales decreased.
The Surgical division's revenue totaled $92.8 million, reflecting a 10.9% year-over-year increase.
Our major product categories experienced significant growth in ligation clips and instruments sales due to a more favorable elective surgical procedure environment than the previous year, partially counterbalanced by the Delta variant's impact in certain areas.
Urology's Q3 revenue amounted to $83.1 million, a 1.5% year-over-year increase, which fell short of our expectations from the Q2 conference call.
The quarter was affected by elective surgery cancellations due to state restrictions and ICU capacity limitations as Delta variant cases surged in specific U.S. regions, along with ongoing pandemic-related business disruptions.
We are carefully observing trends in our UroLift business.
Notably, our analysis of commercial and Medicare billing claims over the past six months shows that UroLift has maintained its market share against competing minimally invasive BPH treatments and remains the leading procedure.
COVID-19 continues to have the most significant impact on UroLift utilization, with physician office staffing shortages also affecting the business.
We view both of these impacts as temporary and anticipate a more normalized environment in 2022.
The preference for UroLift is sustained by strong clinical outcomes, with studies demonstrating rapid symptom relief and recovery, no new sustained sexual dysfunction, and long-lasting results.
Our analysis reveals that very few of our experienced users offer alternative technologies for BPH treatment due to their confidence in UroLift.
The UroLift system remains unique among device-based BPH treatments, and we aim to maintain our leading position in day surgery treatments for this condition.
We continue to focus on patients suffering from BPH who have either failed or are dissatisfied with drug therapy, estimated to be 1.5 million men in the United States.
Looking ahead to Q4 2021, we expect a relatively stable macro environment compared to our September trends, given persistent COVID-19 challenges for elective surgical procedures.
Considering the lower-than-expected UroLift revenues in Q3 and our revised Q4 projections, we are reducing our 2021 Interventional Urology revenue growth guidance to 15-17% year-over-year.
We anticipate a more normal environment for elective surgical procedures to emerge in 2022.
We remain encouraged by physician engagement, as measured by our active users, new physician training, and the ability to perform UroLift procedures in all relevant care settings.
Our OEM business, representing about 9% of total sales, grew 29.4% year-over-year to $64.1 million in Q3.
We continue to see strength in our OEM business as customer ordering normalizes, and we remain well-positioned in our markets with customers valuing our design and manufacturing capabilities.
Lastly, our other category, comprising respiratory products not included in the Medline divestiture, manufacturing service agreement revenues, and Urology Care products, decreased by 4.3% to $83.4 million year-over-year.
The decline primarily reflects the loss of revenue due to the respiratory products divestiture, partially offset by manufacturing service agreement revenues and growth in Urology Care.
We expect manufacturing service agreement revenues to phase out by the end of 2023.
This concludes my remarks on the Q3 revenue performance.
Shifting to commercial updates, starting with UroLift.
In Q3, we trained 124 urologists.
Interest in UroLift remains strong, and with over 355 doctors trained year-to-date, we are on track to meet our training target of 450-500 urologists in 2021.
Regarding our consumer marketing efforts.
We continue to view direct-to-consumer as a multi-year catalyst for UroLift in the United States.
We have maintained funding for our DTC campaign to prepare for the recovery in elective procedures and will continue investing in Q4.
We recently received a bronze award for best new branded television campaign from DTC perspective, a significant achievement given 13 finalists.
Search interest for UroLift remains high and well above other minimally invasive BPH treatments, with most urologist surveys indicating patients inquiring about the UroLift System.
Moving to UroLift 2.
We are proceeding with a full rollout in the United States.
We officially launched the product and the UroLift ATC to the broader urology community at the AUA meeting in September.
We are well-positioned to transition the majority of physician customers to UroLift 2 by the end of 2022, driven by improvements in tissue compression, reduced storage space, and increased manufacturing capacity.
UroLift 2 remains an important margin driver, as we are on track to achieve 400 basis points of UroLift gross margin expansion once the revenue base is fully converted.
Regarding Japan, we continue to make progress towards an upcoming commercial launch for UroLift.
Recently, the three major Japanese urology societies agreed on guidelines for UroLift usage, which is a positive development.
Concerning reimbursement approval, we remain highly engaged with the MHLW and have been officially notified that UroLift will be reviewed at an expert panel in November.
Although we cannot control the regulatory pathway's timing, the panel confirmation is a crucial milestone towards reimbursement in Japan, marking one of the final steps in the process.
Our baseline assumptions for the commercial ramp beginning in 2022 remain unchanged.
Japan remains an important long-term opportunity for UroLift with a $2 billion TAM, and we are excited about our upcoming launch.
We continue to expect our sales in the region to ramp up similarly to the U.S. in a market that is 1/3 the size.
Beyond Japan, our international regulatory and commercialization efforts for UroLift remain active.
On a positive note, we are excited about our initial commercial activity in Brazil.
Although we had been expecting to enter Brazil in late 2022, we have shortened our timeline with a limited market release late in Q3 2021.
We have made good progress with select key opinion leader training, and initial UroLift cases have already been performed in hospital and office settings.
Although it is early, and the market will take time to develop, Brazil remains an important geography in our expansion of UroLift outside the United States, and we are encouraged by the early experience.
Regarding U.S. reimbursement, and as a reminder, CMS published its proposed physician fee schedule for calendar 2022 on July 13, 2021.
The proposed rule would negatively impact reimbursement for approximately 600 procedures performed in doctors' offices across a wide range of surgical specialties, with a disproportionate effect on device-heavy procedures like UroLift.
Teleflex provided a detailed response to CMS during the public comment period regarding our position on the proposed rule.
We believe that the changes to the physician fee schedule would restrict healthcare access for Medicare patients and shift procedures to more expensive sites of service.
Teleflex, along with numerous other stakeholders, have urged CMS to delay the implementation of the proposed physician fee schedule until additional analysis can be performed, given the unintended consequences of the current proposed route.
We expect the final rule to be published in November, consistent with historical timing.
We are satisfied with the success of our recently introduced Arrow ErgoPack kit, which generated over $5 million in revenue during Q3.
The new kit configuration for our CVC catheters includes a kink-resistant nitinol guidewire, which is an improvement that medical professionals appreciate.
Our dominant market position in CVCs is reinforced by this launch, which serves as a trade-up strategy to increase gross profit and maintain our leadership.
Regarding our acquisition of Z-Medica, which was finalized in December 2020, the integration is progressing slightly faster than our internal expectations, and we are content with the progress.
We have finished enrolling patients in a 231-person IDE study to evaluate the effectiveness of QuikClot Control+ hemostatic devices for mild-to-moderate bleeding in cardiac procedures compared to standard methods, with the aim of expanding the hemostat portfolio's label.
We plan to submit a 510(k) application for expanded use of QuikClot Control+ after the study is completed.
Following the previous discussion of the company's revenue performance, I will start with the gross profit section.
In Q3, adjusted gross margin reached 59.5%, an increase of 230 basis points compared to the same period last year.
The improvement in gross margin year-over-year was attributed to product and regional mix, cost-saving initiatives, favorable pricing, M&A, and foreign exchange effects, partially offset by increases in raw material and distribution costs.
Q3 adjusted operating margin was 28.5%, a 340 basis point increase year-over-year, driven by improved gross margin and careful expense management, partially offset by planned business investments.
Net interest expense for the quarter was $11.8 million, down from $16.4 million in the same period last year.
The decrease in net interest expense is due to savings from redeeming the 2026 notes and the impact of debt reduction using proceeds from the respiratory divestiture and operating cash flows.
Our Q3 2021 adjusted tax rate was 11.3%, compared to 7% in the same period last year.
The increase in our adjusted tax rate is mainly due to a reduced benefit from stock-based compensation compared to the previous year.
Q3 adjusted earnings per share grew by 26.7% to $3.51.
This result includes an estimated positive impact of approximately $0.13 per share from foreign exchange compared to the previous year.
Year-to-date cash flow from operations totaled $450.5 million, a $209 million increase from $241.5 million in the same period last year.
The increase was primarily due to improved operating results, lower contingent consideration payments, reduced payroll and benefit-related payments, and proceeds from the manufacturing supply agreement with Medline.
Our financial position remains strong.
At the end of Q3 2021, our cash balance was $481.2 million, up from $375.9 million at the end of Q4 2020.
We made a $259 million payment in July against our revolving credit facility, using funds mainly generated from the initial close of the respiratory business divestiture.
At the end of Q3, we had $342 million drawn on our revolver, and net leverage was approximately 2 times.
We are updating our 2021 constant currency revenue growth guidance to 8% to 9% year-over-year, down from 8.5% to 9.75% previously.
This outlook reflects the benefits of our diversified portfolio, offset by lower UroLift revenues due to a slower recovery in elective surgical procedures than previously assumed.
We continue to expect a 2% positive impact on reported revenue from foreign exchange rates in 2021, unchanged from our previous assumption.
As a result, we are revising our as-reported revenue growth guidance to 10% to 11% year-over-year, down from 10.5% to 11.75% previously.
The updated guidance would equate to a revenue range of $2.791 billion to $2.186 billion.
We are lowering the top end of our 2021 adjusted gross margin guidance by 25 basis points to a range of 59.25% to 59.5%.
Year-over-year gross margin expansion is expected to be driven by a favorable mix of high-margin products, manufacturing productivity improvements, and benefits from previously announced Footprint restructuring programs, partially offset by inflation.
The revised outlook is associated with lower UroLift revenues and higher-than-expected inflation.
Our expectation that Z-Medica will add approximately 50 basis points to gross margin for 2021 remains unchanged.
We continue to experience increased cost pressures in raw materials, freight, and to a lesser extent, labor.
Most of our sea freight lane contracts expired at the end of September, with the remainder expiring at the end of the year.
Due to expiring shipping contracts and increasing inflation, we now estimate that inflationary costs will be roughly $3 million higher in Q4 than in Q3.
This impact is reflected in our revised gross margin guidance.
We are increasing our 2021 adjusted operating margin guidance range to 27.5% to 28%, up 75 basis points at the low end and 50 basis points at the high end compared to previous guidance.
The increase in adjusted operating margin reflects year-to-date performance, partially offset by the lower gross margin outlook.
We now expect interest expense to be roughly $57 million, down from our previous guidance of $60 million to $62 million.
The decrease in net interest expense for 2021 largely reflects a reduction in debt, funded by proceeds from the respiratory divestiture and strong cash flow generation.
We now expect our adjusted tax rate for 2021 to be roughly 12% to 13%, down from the prior range of 13% to 13.5%.
We are raising our adjusted earnings per share outlook for 2021 by $0.25 at both ends of the range to $13.15 to $13.35, representing a 23.2% to 25.1% year-over-year increase.
Our diversified product portfolio enabled Teleflex to achieve double-digit constant currency growth in Q3, despite greater-than-expected disruption from COVID-19.
We continue to execute our strategy to drive durable growth across our diversified portfolio by investing in organic growth opportunities, expanding margins, and deploying capital for M&A.
We have raised our earnings per share guidance for 2021, reflecting 23% to 25% earnings growth year-over-year.
We are pleased with our overall performance in the quarter, supported by our diversified portfolio of medically necessary products.
Our balance sheet is strong with leverage at 2 times, providing ample financial flexibility for our capital allocation priorities.
We remain confident in our future and our ability to continue meeting commitments to patients, clinicians, communities, and shareholders.
Summary:
output:
teleflex q3 adjusted earnings per share $3.51 from continuing operations.
q3 adjusted earnings per share $3.51 from continuing operations.
q3 revenue $700.3 million.
2021 constant currency revenue growth outlook reduced to 8.00% to 9.00% from 8.50% to 9.75% previously.
2021 adjusted earnings per share outlook raised to $13.15 to $13.35 from $12.90 to $13.10 previously.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:I'm William Prate, leading Global Financial Planning and Analysis and Investor Relations as Senior Director.
Our COO, Dave Huml, is unable to participate in the call due to a family situation.
Chris will update you on our operations and our progress towards our company strategy, followed by Andy presenting the financial details.
We'll then open the floor for questions after their presentations.
These potential risks and uncertainties are outlined in today's press release and in our SEC filings.
We urge you to examine these documents, particularly our safe harbor statement, which describes potential risks and uncertainties that could impact our results.
During this call, we'll also discuss non-GAAP measures that either include or exclude certain items.
We sincerely hope you and your family are staying healthy during this pandemic.
As you may have noticed, we recently commemorated Tennant's 150th year in business this September.
Although our current business environment is vastly different from what our founder George Tennant faced in 1870, the company has consistently maintained a tradition of innovation and adaptability, as evidenced by our ability to evolve and remain relevant to our customers.
When the pandemic began, we acted swiftly and established three key principles: ensuring the safety of our employees and customers, managing our expenses and cash flow, and maintaining readiness to scale up operations when markets recover.
Simultaneously, we fulfilled our commitment to provide our customers with innovative solutions to maintain clean and safe facilities.
We maintained this approach in the third quarter and observed promising signs of recovery across all our regions.
Our teams worldwide have worked diligently to overcome the unprecedented sales and operational challenges caused by the pandemic, collaborating closely with our customers, supply chain partners, and carriers to prevent operational disruptions.
Moreover, the implementation of our Enterprise Strategy resulted in improvements in our operating performance, with third quarter EBITDA growth, despite a year-over-year decrease in organic sales due to COVID-19.
Although the pandemic continues to create significant macro-level uncertainty, particularly as some markets experience increases in COVID-19 cases, we are highly confident in our near-term business outlook.
As Andy will explain shortly, we are reintroducing our full-year guidance for 2020, which reflects not only our revenue and profitability expectations but also our commitment to investing in our business to support our long-term enterprise strategy.
This strategy encompasses winning in areas where we have a competitive advantage, simplifying processes and building scalable systems, and innovating for profitable growth.
While the global economic impact of the pandemic was unforeseen a year ago, it hasn't diminished our ability to execute our enterprise strategy, as the key elements are all within our control.
For instance, while innovating for profitable growth may seem like an ambitious goal, for Tennant it represents our approach to leveraging customer insights and our exceptional engineering capabilities to solve real-world problems.
A recent example of this commitment is our October 1st launch of the new T380AMR, which complements our existing robotic lineup by offering a smaller-sized machine that improves maneuverability and navigation for customers with smaller spaces.
This new product and our ongoing partnership with Brain Corporation enabled us to finalize agreements in the third quarter to supply two national retailers and a separate regional retailer with our complete range of autonomous floor scrubbers.
Furthermore, we are beginning to achieve success in additional sectors such as logistics, education, and aviation.
After our initial launch with Walmart earlier this year, these successes show how we continue to innovate and provide value to a wider range of customers.
As part of our company-wide strategy, we recently brought on Dan Glusick as our new Senior Vice President of Operations, who will report directly to our Chief Operating Officer, Dave Huml.
With over 25 years of experience in global operations leadership, Dan brings extensive enterprise management skills and in-depth expertise across manufacturing operations, supply chain management, and company-wide transformation.
Dan's appointment is crucial and he will play a key role in implementing our Enterprise Strategy as we enhance our supply chain and streamline our operations to support our product standardization and localization initiatives.
To sum up, this is a critical area of focus as we prepare Tennant for success in the post-pandemic era.
Finally, given the improving demand trends we've observed since May and our confidence in our business's improved trajectory, we recognize the need to make strategic investments to support ongoing strategy execution, fill key leadership positions, and recognize and retain our top talent.
This aligns with the guiding principles we established at the beginning of the pandemic.
We started making these investments in the third quarter and will continue to do so in the fourth quarter.
These investments are crucial for supporting our customers, emerging strong as markets recover, and continuing to create value for shareholders.
Please be aware that any references to earnings per share in my comments today, both GAAP and non-GAAP, are on a fully diluted basis.
As Chris mentioned, while Tennant's third quarter results continued to show the impact of the pandemic, we observed some positive trends across all our regions.
For the third quarter of 2020, Tennant reported total net sales of $261.9 million, a decrease of 6.7% compared to the same period last year.
Organic sales, which don't include the effects of currency fluctuations, dropped by 7.1%.
This represents a significant improvement in our sales performance compared to the 27% decline we saw in the second quarter.
In the third quarter, we reported net earnings of $11.7 million or $0.63 per share, down from $14.6 million or $0.79 per share in the same period last year.
Adjusted EPS, which excludes certain non-operational items and amortization, was $0.90 compared to $0.85 in the previous year.
Let's now examine our third quarter sales results by geographic region, which we divide into three areas: The Americas, including all of North America and Latin America; EMEA, covering Europe, the Middle East and Africa; and Asia Pacific, which includes China, Japan, Australia and other Asian markets.
Sales in the Americas decreased by 9.9% year-over-year and fell 8.8% organically.
Decreases in direct Industrial business sales and distributor sales were partially offset by the ongoing success of Tennant's AMR platform and strong growth in Brazil.
Sales in EMEA declined by 0.3%, or 4.5% organically, in the quarter due to market weakness across the region.
The declines were primarily in the United Kingdom and the Iberian Peninsula, which counteracted growth in France and Italy.
Sales in the APAC region decreased by 0.8%, or 2.3% organically.
Declines in Southeast Asia and Korea were partially balanced by growth in direct sales in Australia.
The Company's service, parts, and consumables business continued to be a strong point overall.
Despite a 12% decrease in equipment sales compared to the previous year's quarter, aftermarket revenue increased by 6% over the same period, reflecting our efforts to assist customers with their evolving cleaning requirements during the pandemic.
The adjusted gross margins for the third quarters of 2020 and 2019 were 40.2% and 40.8% respectively.
The year-on-year decrease is attributed to various strategic investments and reduced leverage due to lower volume, which were partially mitigated by cost-cutting measures driven by strategic initiatives.
Regarding expenses, our adjusted S&A costs were 29.8% of net sales in the third quarter, compared to 31.2% in the same period last year, primarily due to cost-saving efforts and adjustments to management incentives.
We made several strategic investments during the quarter.
Due to the economic uncertainties caused by the pandemic, careful management of S&A expenses remains a crucial part of our strategy.
Our EBITDA for the third quarter of 2020 was $32.6 million, or 12.4% of sales, compared to $31.4 million, or 11.2% of sales, in the third quarter of 2019.
The increase in percentage of sales was due to adjustments in management incentives and reductions in discretionary spending implemented during the quarter.
The Company's adjusted effective tax rate for the third quarter was 11.3%, compared to 16.1% in the same period last year.
The lower tax rate was primarily due to an increase in discrete tax items and a favorable earnings mix.
Let's now discuss cash flow, capital allocation, and balance sheet items.
Tennant generated $48.9 million in cash flow from operations in the third quarter of 2020, mainly driven by business performance and improvements in working capital.
We repaid an additional $17 million of debt in the third quarter.
As of September 30th, we had $124.7 million in cash and cash equivalents, and approximately $172 million in undrawn funds on our revolver.
Now, let's address guidance.
In April, we withdrew our full-year guidance provided in February due to the pandemic's uncertainty.
Although uncertainty remains in the market, we now have more confidence in our short-term projections and are reintroducing full-year guidance for 2020.
Our full-year 2020 guidance, as stated in today's earnings announcement, is as follows: Net sales of $995 million to $1,005 million with organic sales declining 12.5% to 11.5%; GAAP earnings of $2.00 to $2.20 per share; adjusted earnings per share of $2.80 to $3.00, excluding certain non-operational items and amortization expense; adjusted EBITDA between $116 million and $121 million; capital expenditures of about $35 million; and an effective tax rate of approximately 17%.
It's important to note that our guidance includes approximately $5 million to $8 million in government benefits, primarily from wage subsidies mentioned in our second quarter results.
As Chris mentioned, this guidance includes continued investment in our business to support our enterprise strategy.
While we believe underlying business performance is improving and expect revenue to increase sequentially quarter-over-quarter, it's important to note that organic sales will face a challenging year-over-year comparison, as Q4 2019 was Tennant's second-highest revenue quarter ever.
As a result, we anticipate that our implied fourth quarter organic decline will be greater than the third quarter, and due to continued strategic investments, our expected EBITDA dollar and percent of revenue will be lower than previous quarters.
We will now open the call for questions.
Summary:
output:
q3 adjusted earnings per share $0.90.
q3 earnings per share $0.63.
sees fy 2020 adjusted earnings per share $2.80 to $3.00.
sees fy 2020 gaap earnings per share $2.00 to $2.20.
sees fy 2020 sales $995 million to $1.005 billion.
q3 sales $261.9 million versus refinitiv ibes estimate of $237.7 million.
reinstates 2020 guidance for net sales, adjusted ebitda and eps.
sees 2020 capital expenditures of approximately $35 million.
