Context:Furthermore, David Bray, Noelle O'Mara, Shane Miller, and Chris Langholz, who are group presidents of various divisions, will participate in the live Q&A portion of the event.
We disclosed our financial results for the first quarter of fiscal year 2022 earlier today.
Tyson Foods has again produced impressive financial outcomes.
During our Investor Day, I outlined our strategy for significant growth in both revenue and profit over the next three years.
This strategy aimed for high single-digit growth in earnings per share compared to 2019, as well as volume growth surpassing market rates.
Our performance this quarter puts us on track to achieve these goals.
We experienced growth of over 10% in both sales and earnings, driven by sustained strong demand, efficiency gains, and enhanced execution across all segments.
Our success can be attributed to our diverse protein offerings, multi-channel capabilities, well-known brands, and value-added products.
Strong performance in beef, a quicker-than-anticipated recovery in prepared foods, and improvements in chicken and pork all contributed to robust earnings.
Our core retail product lines, which include our well-known brands like Tyson, Jimmy Dean, Hillshire Farm, and Ball Park, maintained their market share despite price increases to offset inflationary pressures.
In foodservice, our Focus 6 product lines gained market share year-over-year in broad-line distribution.
This growth was largely due to value-added chicken products outperforming industry recovery, and improved supply of breakfast sausage.
Notably, despite the ongoing impact of COVID-19, our overall volumes slightly increased compared to the same quarter last year.
Chicken was a standout, with volumes improving by 3.6%.
While this is a good start, we haven't yet reached our desired volume levels.
We're implementing specific strategies in each segment to boost our volume performance.
These strategies include investing in our workforce, expanding capacity, and developing new brands and products.
As mentioned at Investor Day, we're also constructing 12 new facilities.
Each of these projects is progressing and will help Tyson address capacity limitations and meet the growing global demand for protein.
Ultimately, we're committed to improving our overall company volumes throughout the year.
We're also ensuring that our pricing reflects the inflationary cost pressures on our business.
In the first quarter, our cost of goods sold increased by 18% compared to the same period last year.
We're experiencing higher costs across our supply chain, including increased input costs such as feed and ingredients.
We're also managing higher labor and transportation costs due to strong demand and limited availability.
To address these higher costs, we work closely with our customers to ensure fair pricing for our products.
As a result, our average sales price for the quarter rose by 19.6% compared to the same period last year.
This helped us recover some of the costs that were previously unrecovered due to the lag between inflation and price adjustments.
Our strong balance sheet and overall liquidity position provide us with flexibility to pursue strategic growth priorities and invest across our portfolio.
We take a disciplined approach to capital deployment, supporting capacity expansion while aiming for improved returns on invested capital.
Our first-quarter results clearly show that we're making progress on our growth objectives, remaining focused on outpacing the overall market, improving operating margins, and delivering strong returns for our shareholders.
As we grow our business, we remain mindful of our corporate responsibilities regarding environmental, social, and governance goals.
For instance, we're committed to investing in and supporting rural communities in America and around the world.
Last year, Tyson Foods donated over 16 million pounds of protein, equivalent to 64 million meals, to combat hunger.
We're extremely proud of this work and the people who make it possible.
Tyson is an excellent company with a great team doing important work, and we're pleased that Fortune Magazine recognized this by ranking Tyson Foods No. 1 in our sector for the sixth consecutive year in their list of the world's most admired companies.
Let's review some key financial highlights from the first quarter.
Our results showed double-digit growth in both top and bottom lines.
We delivered strong operating income performance, up 40% for the quarter.
This performance was broad-based across segments, with continued strong consumer demand and effective pricing to mitigate inflation driving higher earnings.
Our volume increased slightly overall.
While we're working to achieve optimal throughput across segments, labor challenges are still impacting our volumes and our ability to achieve the best product mix across our network.
Compared to pre-pandemic levels, our volume performance is outpacing our competitors.
In retail, despite significant market pressures, our core business lines maintained market share in the first quarter, led by strong performance in lunch meat, hot dogs, snacks, and bacon.
We also saw strong e-commerce results, with Tyson Foods outpacing total food and beverage growth in our core lines and gaining market share in the quarter.
However, customer demand continues to exceed our production capacity.
We have targeted actions in each segment to improve volumes, which is crucial to meeting our commitments.
To achieve our volume goals, we must be able to fully staff our plants across the company.
We continue to take significant steps to become the most desirable workplace.
For example, we provided our hourly team members with over $50 million in bonuses during the first quarter.
We're piloting subsidized and on-site childcare, and we're adjusting schedules to accommodate workforce needs.
These efforts are showing results as we see some improvement in labor conditions.
While we experienced some labor challenges during the Omicron surge, we're generally seeing lower turnover and absenteeism.
Our chicken volumes grew by 3.6% in the quarter, driven by strong fundamental demand and improved live production.
Importantly, we grew faster than the market and gained market share.
In prepared foods, volumes decreased by 2.6% in the first quarter.
About half of this decline was due to the divestiture of our pet treats business.
We expect to gradually improve these results over the remainder of fiscal year 2022 as we take actions to expand and improve capacity utilization.
In beef, volumes decreased by 6.2%, primarily due to the labor shortages mentioned earlier.
Additionally, port congestion has affected export volumes in this segment.
We expect these volume headwinds to normalize over the course of fiscal 2022.
In pork, we have sequentially improved our capacity utilization.
We are still working to refine our product mix.
In our international and other segments, despite starting from a small base, our investments in capacity, innovation, and branding are supporting our goal of market share expansion.
We anticipate growing our overall company volumes by 2-3% in fiscal year 2022, surpassing the growth rate of protein consumption.
Improving our chicken segment remains a top focus, and we're executing our plan to reach an operating income margin of 5-7% on a run-rate basis by mid-fiscal 2022.
I'm confident we will achieve this target.
In the first quarter, we've begun to see improvements in profitability as a result of our actions.
For instance, we're heavily investing in automation and technology to address some of the most challenging positions to fill.
This isn't a collection of isolated projects, but a well-planned program using common designs and equipment across our facilities to optimize costs, maintenance, and asset utilization.
The second key objective is to enhance operational performance, with a critical focus on maximizing our fixed cost leverage by ensuring we have enough resources to run our plants at full capacity.
Since September, we've observed an improvement in our hatch rate that has exceeded our expectations.
We continue to anticipate a full recovery this year.
We were satisfied with our volume growth in the quarter and expect further improvements as we increase our harvest capacity utilization from an average of 37 million head per week in fiscal year 2021 to 40 million head per week by the end of the year.
We've previously mentioned that strong spot prices for commodity chicken products put our buy versus grow program at a comparative disadvantage.
As a result, we've reduced our reliance on external meat sources.
We are committed to staffing our plants, serving our customers, growing our volumes, and becoming the industry leader.
Our current plan remains the right approach, and our dedication to succeeding with our team members, customers, consumers, and operational excellence is yielding results.
Last year, we announced a new productivity program aimed at creating a more efficient, agile organization supported by a culture of continuous improvement and faster decision-making.
The program targets $1 billion in recurring productivity savings by the end of fiscal year 2024 compared to the fiscal 2021 cost baseline, focusing on three key areas: operational and functional excellence, digital solutions, and automation.
We're making good progress in this area.
I recently mentioned our investments in automation, but we've also addressed other issues.
In our Prepared Foods segment, we're utilizing supply chain digitization and advanced analytics.
Our digital manufacturing platform enables us to analyze real-time data to optimize process conditions, resulting in better yields, lower costs, consistent quality, and increased output.
In transportation and logistics, we've established ongoing optimization of our private, dedicated, and third-party fleet mix and allocation, mitigating inflationary pressures and improving on-time deliveries to our customers.
We've also continued expanding our direct shipment program, reducing miles driven and product handling in our supply chain.
These projects have put us on track to achieve $300 million to $400 million in savings for fiscal year 2022.
At our Investor Day, we shared our plans to accelerate growth and drive disciplined return on invested capital.
The five key imperatives shown here outline how we'll meet our commitments and create value.
Our primary focus is on our team members, ensuring their health, safety, and well-being, as well as fostering an inclusive and equitable work environment.
We're proud of the COVID-19 vaccine policy we implemented in the U.S. last year and the broader investments we've made to protect our team members, their families, and our communities.
Our policy has resulted in better protection for our team members, with any cases we do see being mild or asymptomatic, leading to very few hospitalizations.
We're strongly encouraging booster shots and hosting clinics to make it easier for our team members and their families to get boosted.
Secondly, we're working to improve our portfolio and capacity to better meet demand, including increasing the proportion of branded and value-added sales.
As a result, we expect our volume growth to outpace the market.
Third, we're aggressively working to restore competitiveness in our chicken segment, starting with returning our operating margin to the 5-7% range by mid-fiscal 2022.
Fourth, we're focusing on operational and functional excellence and investing in digital and automation initiatives as part of our new productivity program.
We're working hard to eliminate waste, reduce bureaucracy, and improve decision-making speed across the organization.
Fifth, to address projected demand growth over the next decade, we're using our financial strength to invest in our business.
We plan to invest $2 billion in capital expenditures in fiscal year 2022, with a significant portion focused on new capacity and automation objectives.
We're also continuing to return cash to shareholders, having returned over $500 million in dividends and share repurchases during the quarter.
In conclusion, we're committed to succeeding with our team members, customers, and consumers, as well as achieving operational excellence.
I'm increasingly optimistic about Tyson Foods' future with each passing day.
Let me begin by summarizing our overall company financial results.
We're pleased to report a strong start to the year, with first-quarter sales up approximately 24%, primarily due to our pricing initiatives to offset inflationary pressures.
Volumes also increased slightly, though they were impacted by ongoing labor challenges.
Examining our sales results by channel, retail drove almost $350 million in top-line improvements compared to last year.
Improvements in foodservice channel sales led to a $1 billion increase, and our export sales were nearly $333 million stronger than the same period last year as we leveraged our global scale to grow our business.
First-quarter operating income of $1.4 billion was 40% higher than the same quarter last year, driven by increased earnings in beef, pork, and chicken segments.
The strong operating income led to a 48% increase in first-quarter earnings per share, reaching $2.87.
Higher operating income resulted in higher adjusted earnings per share compared to the same period last year.
First-quarter earnings per share also benefited from lower net interest expense and taxes.
Slide 10 illustrates the year-to-date operating income, which was $407 million higher than fiscal 2021.
Volumes increased slightly during the year, primarily due to improvements in chicken, pork, and international/other segments, offset by declines in beef and prepared foods.
Declines in beef and prepared foods were largely attributed to ongoing labor challenges in those segments.
Our pricing actions resulted in approximately $2.1 billion in sales and price/mix benefits during the quarter, offsetting the $1.6 billion increase in cost of goods sold.
We experienced continued inflation across the business, with some instances seeing increases of 20% to 30%.
Notable examples included labor, grain costs, live cattle and hog costs, and freight costs.
Lastly, SG&A was $88 million less favorable compared to the same period last year, largely due to cycling a $55 million benefit recorded last year for the recovery of cattle.
Let's examine the beef division.
Quarterly segment revenue exceeded $5 billion, a 25% increase from the previous year's same period.
Strong demand for beef products fueled sales growth, supporting higher average prices.
Higher capital costs in the first quarter compared to last year partially offset increased sales prices.
Sufficient livestock was available during the quarter due to strong early supplies.
We have good insight into cattle availability through fiscal 2022 and expect it to meet customer needs.
The segment's operating income reached $956 million, an 81% increase from the same period last year.
This improvement resulted from strong global demand for beef products and higher cutout prices, partially counterbalanced by increased operating costs.
Our 19.1% operating margin was significantly higher than last year's same quarter but decreased sequentially compared to the previous two quarters as cost increases narrowed the spread.
Now we'll discuss the pork segment.
Quarterly segment sales surpassed $1.6 billion, a 13% increase from the previous year's same period.
Key sales drivers included higher average prices due to strong demand and increased hog costs, partially offset by a challenging labor environment.
Average sales price rose 12.8% with slightly higher volumes compared to last year's same period.
The segment's quarterly operating income was $164 million, a 41% increase from the comparable period.
Overall, the segment's operating margins improved to 10.1% for the quarter.
Higher spreads in the business drove the operating income improvement.
Now let's discuss prepared foods.
Quarterly sales reached $2.3 billion, a 10% increase from the previous year's same period.
Total volume decreased, with strength in retail and continued foodservice recovery outweighed by labor and supply chain challenges.
Sales growth outpaced volume growth due to inflation-justified pricing.
During the quarter, retail core business lines maintained market share, driven by consumer demand for our brands and strong team execution.
The segment's operating margins were 8% or $186 million for the first quarter.
The decline in segment operating margins compared to last year's same quarter was due to significant increases in raw material and other input costs that we couldn't fully recover through pricing during the quarter.
Raw material costs, logistics, ingredients, packaging, and labor have increased our production costs.
Our pricing lagged behind inflation, but we expect to recover cost increases during fiscal 2022.
In addition to pricing, we've implemented productivity, revenue management, and commercial spend optimization initiatives while ensuring continued brand equity development through marketing and trade support.
Now let's examine the chicken segment's results.
Quarterly sales were $3.9 billion, a 37% increase.
Volumes improved 3.6% due to strong consumer demand and increased live production.
Our teams have focused on streamlining plants to deliver higher volumes, and we expect substantial volume improvements in fiscal 2022 as hatch recovers and we continue to seek ways to operate our plants more efficiently.
Average sales price improved around 20% in the first quarter compared to last year's same period.
This increase is due to favorable product mix and price recovery to offset cost inflation.
We've made significant progress in shifting our pricing mechanisms toward more variable structures and are now seeing the benefits.
We restructured our pricing strategies based on our fiscal 2021 experience to ensure flexibility in responding to market and inflationary conditions.
Chicken delivered adjusted operating income of $117 million in the first quarter of fiscal 2022, representing a 3% operating margin.
Operating income in the quarter was negatively impacted by $185 million in higher feed ingredient costs.
Our capital allocation approach focuses on building financial strength, investing in our business, and returning cash to shareholders.
To build financial strength and flexibility, we used improved earnings to retire debt in fiscal 2021 and expect to do the same this year.
Continued earnings strength this quarter has further improved our leverage ratio to 1.1 times net debt to adjusted EBITDA.
Investing in organic and inorganic growth remains an important priority and will help Tyson increase production capacity and market capabilities.
This will support strong returns for our shareholders.
We are committed to returning cash to shareholders through dividends and share buybacks.
We ended the quarter with a strong balance sheet and continued capital allocation flexibility.
We are maintaining our total company sales guidance of $49 billion to $51 billion but expect to perform at the upper end of the range.
We still anticipate 2% to 3% year-over-year volume growth as we optimize our existing footprint and run our plants at full capacity.
In chicken, we expect to achieve 5% to 7% run rate profitability by mid-year and full-year margins in the same range.
Prepared foods is expected to deliver margins of 7% to 9% during fiscal 2022, likely at the upper end of the range.
We maintain our beef AOI margin at 9% to 11% but expect to perform at the upper end of the range.
We anticipate a stronger first half of the year as industry and labor conditions are expected to normalize partway through the year.
In pork, we expect similar performance to fiscal 2021, with margins between 5% and 7%.
We anticipate the first quarter to be the strongest due to normal seasonality.
In international/other, we expect margins of 2% to 3% as capacity expansions and strong global demand support volume growth and improved profitability.
We anticipate capex spending of approximately $2 billion during fiscal 2022 to pursue projects with strong return profiles.
We now expect lower net interest expense due to lower anticipated average debt balances during the fiscal year.
Our expectations for productivity savings and tax rate changes remain unchanged.
We expect net leverage to remain well below two times net debt-to-adjusted EBITDA, providing flexibility for inorganic investment and additional cash returns to shareholders throughout the year.
We've had a strong start to the fiscal year with a great team, growing product demand, strong portfolio diversity, and the differentiated asset footprint needed for market success.
We set ambitious goals at our Investor Day and expect to achieve them.
Summary:
output:
compname reports q1 adjusted earnings per share $2.87.
q1 adjusted earnings per share $2.87.
currently on track to achieve our planned productivity savings for fiscal 2022.
expect sales to be at upper end of $49 billion to $51 billion in fiscal 2022.
expect capital expenditures of approximately $2 billion for fiscal 2022.
tyson foods - targeting $1 billion in productivity savings by end of fiscal 2024, $300 million to $400 million in fiscal 2022.
tyson foods - qtrly beef sales volume decreased due to impacts associated with a challenging labor environment and increased supply chain constraints.
qtrly pork sales volume was up slightly as strong global demand was offset by impacts associated with challenging labor environment.
qtrly chicken sales volume increased primarily due to increased live production and a strong demand environment.
tyson foods - qtrly prepared foods sales volume decreased due to divestiture of our pet treats business in q4 as well as lower production throughput.
anticipate improved results from our foreign operations in fiscal 2022.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:I will begin by recognizing the tragic and unsettling recent occurrences in the Minneapolis-St. Paul area and nationwide, stemming from the terrible loss of community member George Floyd.
We extend our deepest sympathies to Mr. Floyd's loved ones and the directly impacted communities.
Unfortunately, these incidents reflect broader societal and systemic problems.
As our societies navigate through these tragic circumstances, we must advocate for what is just.
The Toro Company has long emphasized the significance of respecting everyone in our workplace, business practices, and the communities we operate in.
In addition to last week's events, we continue to grapple with the impacts of COVID-19.
We sincerely hope you and your loved ones are staying safe during these challenging times.
It was inspiring to witness how numerous individuals and organizations immediately sprang into action to assist others as the COVID-19 crisis spread globally.
In addressing the coronavirus, we made the safety, welfare, and assistance of our employees, customers, and communities our top priority.
Along with our previously mentioned value of respecting all, some of our other fundamental people-centered values include nurturing relationships, trustworthiness, and integrity.
Despite considerable personal and family hardships, our team has adapted our work methods to ensure each other's safety, support our customers, and aid our communities.
I am profoundly appreciative of all our global employees, many of whom come to our facilities daily to develop, evaluate, manufacture, and distribute our products.
The team's adaptability, ingenuity, and determination are evident in our actions to secure our facilities and implement remote work policies.
Simultaneously, we are sustaining the crucial aspects of our manufacturing operations.
This is all essential, given The Toro Company's status as a vital business.
To support our communities, we initiated a special COVID-19 giving program called Together We Can Do More.
Through this initiative, we make direct donations and match all employee contributions to COVID-19 relief efforts.
Furthermore, The Toro Foundation donated $500,000 to organizations aiding families and communities most directly affected by the pandemic.
Acknowledging the financial strain on our employees and their families, we broadened the availability of the Melrose/Hoffman Employee Critical Need Fund.
Additional voluntary contributions were made to this fund by our leadership team and Board of Directors.
To quote our legendary former Chairman and CEO, Ken Melrose, who sadly passed away last month, everyone has the capacity to contribute to achieving the company's goals.
If you unleash that potential, success will naturally follow.
These words carry significant weight coming from Ken, who successfully guided The Toro Company through some of its most challenging periods.
I will now shift to our business and financial review.
From a business standpoint, we have focused on maintaining sufficient liquidity, expanding our market position, and balancing short-term and long-term objectives.
Our results this quarter showed net sales of $929 million, a 3.4% decrease from the previous year, primarily due to reduced Professional segment retail demand resulting from COVID-19.
We reported adjusted diluted earnings per share of $0.92, a 21.4% decrease from the previous year.
To provide specific information by business segments, the Professional segment's total net sales were $661 million, an 8.6% decrease.
Sales benefited from additional contributions from the Charles Machine Works and Venture Products acquisitions.
This quarter marked the one-year anniversary of the Charles Machine Works acquisition.
We are fortunate to have this business and its employees as part of our company.
Charles Machine Works added scale and diversification to our portfolio, provided access to new markets, and created additional opportunities for synergy and value creation across the company.
We are on track to meet or exceed our stated synergy targets.
Offsetting the gains from acquisitions were declines in most of our Professional businesses due to weak retail demand caused by COVID-19.
The declines were most prominent in commercial golf and grounds, which saw fewer shipments of turf equipment and irrigation products.
This was driven by budget deferrals at golf courses and municipalities, landscape contractor businesses which had fewer shipments as our channel partners aligned field inventory levels with reduced retail demand, and rental specialty and underground construction businesses which have experienced reduced sales volumes due to the global economic slowdown and its impact on the construction and oil and gas markets.
It's important to note that the Professional segment performance was in line with our expectations of modest growth until mid-March.
In April, we experienced additional and significant declines in most of our Professional markets.
We typically don't discuss the current quarter in our earnings calls.
However, we recognize that this quarter is unique.
So, we'll provide some insight into what occurred in May.
For the Professional segment, it was largely a story of new equipment purchase deferrals and a focus on service and repair.
We're seeing ongoing challenges across golf and grounds, landscape contractor, and rental specialty and underground construction businesses.
These challenges stem more from lower budgets and deferred purchases than from temporary facility closures.
For golf, most play has resumed and demand for rounds has been strong.
However, lower food and beverage and event revenue has negatively affected club budgets, putting pressure on new equipment purchases.
For our municipal grounds customers, budgets have been reduced or redirected to non-ground support, resulting in decreased equipment demand.
The repair and defer story is similar with landscape contractors.
However, with the easing of stay-at-home restrictions, there were some improvements in these categories starting in late May.
In rental, specialty and underground construction, 5G infrastructure and broadband spending increased slightly in May with high demand for system capacity due to stay-at-home orders.
Underground infrastructure, rehabilitation and repair projects remained steady.
However, this is being offset by continued construction and oil and gas project weakness, reduced capital spending from national rental accounts resulting in new equipment purchase deferrals, and lower dealer retail.
In the Residential segment, sales increased by 12.9% in the second quarter.
This was primarily driven by additional shipments to our expanded mass retail channel and strong retail demand.
Some of the demand drivers were favorable spring weather, new products, and consumers focusing on home and garden improvements during stay-at-home orders.
Our product sales through captive and partnered e-commerce sites increased significantly in the second quarter.
For May, Residential segment momentum continued, driven by the same trends.
Regarding operations, all of our facilities are currently open, with some operating at reduced capacity.
During the second quarter, some sites closed temporarily due to government orders or to manage inventory levels.
We will adjust production to match customer demand, follow government directives, and prioritize team safety.
There were no supply chain disruptions during the quarter.
Our financial position remains robust with a healthy balance sheet and sufficient liquidity.
We implemented measures this quarter to ensure adequate cash reserves given the current economic situation.
For the rest of fiscal 2020, we are implementing company-wide salary reductions including leadership, canceling merit increases, and suspending discretionary retirement plan contributions.
We also cut expenses and limited new hiring to essential positions only.
We have maintained jobs and kept key employees despite these measures.
We continue to realize benefits from efficiency initiatives and synergies resulting from recent acquisitions.
We have experience navigating economic challenges and know how to leverage our strengths.
Our organizational culture and management approach are well-suited to handle external uncertainties.
While some factors are beyond our control, our diverse portfolio and adaptability allow us to adjust to changing conditions while maintaining long-term growth and cash flow.
We remain committed to investing in the future for all stakeholders' benefit.
The Toro Company offers a balanced range of products that boost customer productivity across different seasons.
The company's strong financial position allows for effective capital allocation across various options like product development, acquisitions, dividends, debt reduction and share buybacks.
The second quarter was no different.
Although COVID-19 impacted our results, we adapted our operations and continued to progress.
We achieved net sales of $929 million this quarter, down 3.4% from the same period last fiscal year.
Earnings per diluted share were $0.91 for the quarter compared to $1.07 in the previous year.
Adjusted earnings per diluted share were $0.92, a 21.4% decrease from the second quarter of fiscal 2019.
For the first half of fiscal 2020, net sales grew by 8.4%.
Earnings per diluted share were $1.55 compared to $1.62 in the first half of fiscal 2019.
Year-to-date adjusted earnings per diluted share were $1.56 versus $1.69 a year ago.
Before discussing segment results, I'll address our liquidity situation.
In March, we secured a three-year term loan for $190 million.
This loan refinanced our revolving credit facility borrowings used for the Venture Products acquisition that closed on March 2.
With this new term loan, the company now has about $800 million in liquidity, including $200 million in cash and cash equivalents and roughly $600 million available under our revolving credit facility.
We have no major debt maturities until April 2022.
We maintain close communication with our banking partners and monitor credit markets closely.
Our receivables collection remains consistent with last year's trends.
These factors give us confidence in our ability to withstand the current and potentially prolonged period of economic uncertainty.
I'd like to provide more details on the actions we've taken to maintain the company's strength given the unprecedented speed and severity of the pandemic.
From a demand perspective, we've implemented business continuity plans and worked to ensure product availability in areas with strong demand, such as our Residential segment.
We've also reduced production in areas with weaker demand.
As Rick mentioned, we've taken steps to align costs with near-term demand and will continue seeking ways to make our cost structure more flexible and competitive.
Meanwhile, we're focusing on maintaining productivity and synergy initiatives driven by recent acquisitions and extended across the company.
Now, let's review the segment results.
In the second quarter, Professional segment net sales decreased by 8.6% to $661 million.
The top line benefited from the Charles Machine Works and Venture Products acquisitions, which together added $142 million in incremental net sales.
Professional segment sales declined compared to the second quarter of 2019 due to lower shipments caused by COVID-related demand reduction.
Until mid-March and the impact of COVID-19, sales were on track for modest growth in line with our expectations.
We saw a slight sales decline in the second half of March and a more significant reduction in April compared to the previous year's performance.
For the year-to-date period of fiscal 2020, net sales increased by 6.6% compared to the same period in fiscal 2019.
Professional segment operating earnings for the second quarter decreased by 29.2% to $106 million, reflecting a 460 basis point decline in segment operating earnings as a percentage of sales.
This was primarily due to manufacturing variances resulting from COVID-19 related facility closures and social distancing measures, increased marketing, engineering, and administrative costs from the Charles Machine Works and Venture Products acquisitions, higher warranty expenses, and unfavorable product mix.
These factors were partially offset by favorable net price realizations, productivity and synergy gains, lower commodity and tariff costs, and decreased incentive compensation expenses.
Year-to-date Professional segment operating earnings declined by 12.3% compared to the same period in the previous fiscal year.
Professional segment operating earnings as a percentage of sales decreased by 360 basis points to 16.6%.
Residential segment net sales for the second quarter increased by 12.9% to $262 million, primarily driven by increased shipments of zero-turn riding and walk power mowers to the expanded mass retail channel, as well as strong retail demand.
Year-to-date fiscal 2020 net sales increased by 13.4% compared to the same period in fiscal 2019.
Residential segment operating earnings rose by 68.5% to $37 million.
This represents a 470 basis point year-over-year increase in segment operating earnings to 14.2% of sales.
This improvement was largely due to productivity and synergy gains, lower commodity and tariff costs, reduced freight costs, and SG&A leverage.
These benefits were partially offset by unfavorable manufacturing variances and higher warranty expenses.
Year-to-date Residential segment operating earnings increased by 67.2% to $58.7 million.
As a percentage of sales, segment earnings increased by 440 basis points to 13.7%.
Regarding our overall operating results, we reported a gross margin of 33% for the second quarter, a decrease of 40 basis points from the prior year period.
Excluding acquisition-related charges and one-time costs associated with the inventory writedown of the Toro branded underground business, adjusted gross margin decreased by 100 basis points to 33.4%.
The decrease in adjusted gross margin was primarily due to manufacturing variances caused by production downtime and inefficiencies resulting from COVID-19 related closures, as well as product mix with higher Residential segment net sales compared to Q2 of 2019.
These factors were partially offset by productivity and synergy gains, favorable net price realizations in our Professional segment, and lower commodity and tariff costs.
During the initial half of fiscal 2020, the gross margin reached 35.1%, an improvement from 34.3% in the previous year's corresponding period
The adjusted gross margin stood at 35.3%, up from 34.9% in the first six months of fiscal 2019
In the quarter, SG&A expenses as a percentage of sales rose by 40 basis points to 19.5%, primarily due to increased marketing and engineering expenses from Professional segment acquisitions and higher warranty costs
These expense increases were partly mitigated by reduced incentive compensation and lower transaction and integration expenses
For the first half of fiscal 2020, SG&A expenses as a percentage of sales reached 22.3%, a 130 basis point increase from the previous year
The second quarter saw operating earnings as a percentage of net sales decline by 80 basis points to 13.5%
Adjusted operating earnings as a percentage of net sales dropped by 240 basis points to 14%
In the first half of fiscal 2020, operating earnings as a percentage of net sales were 12.8%, down from 13.3% a year earlier
Adjusted operating earnings as a percentage of net sales for the first six months of fiscal 2020 decreased to 13.1% from 14.7% in the previous year
Interest expenses increased by $2 million and $5.4 million for the second quarter and year-to-date, respectively, compared to the previous year
The rise in interest expenses was attributed to higher debt related to Professional segment acquisitions
The company anticipates interest expenses of approximately $34 million for the full year
The effective tax rate for the second quarter was 18.9%, while the adjusted effective tax rate was 20%
For the first half of fiscal 2020, the effective tax rate was 18.8%, and the adjusted effective tax rate was 20.4%
The company expects an adjusted effective tax rate of about 20.5% for the full year
Shifting focus to the balance sheet and cash flow
Accounts receivable amounted to $400 million
This represents a 6.6% decrease from the previous year, primarily due to lower Professional segment sales at the end of the second quarter, caused by reduced demand from COVID-19
The decrease was partially offset by increased Residential segment sales to the expanded mass retail channel and additional receivables from the Venture Products acquisition
Inventory increased by 16.8% to $714 million compared to the previous year, mainly due to higher finished goods in the Professional segment resulting from COVID-19 related sales reduction, increased raw materials and work in process due to production downtime, and additional inventories from Venture Products
Accounts payable decreased by 16.4% to $327 million compared to the previous year
This reduction was primarily due to decreased material purchases to align production levels with reduced sales volume
The decline in purchases was partially offset by incremental payables from Venture Products
The company anticipates depreciation and amortization for fiscal 2020 to be around $100 million, including approximately $3 million of fair value step-up related to acquired inventory from Venture Products
Capital expenditures are now estimated at $80 million, lower than the previous expectation of $100 million
Free cash flow for the quarter was lower than the previous year, mainly due to decreased net earnings, lower accounts payable, and higher inventory
The company's disciplined capital allocation strategy involves investing in organic and M&A growth opportunities, maintaining an effective capital structure, and returning cash to shareholders
The focus on near-term liquidity has reinforced the company's capital allocation priorities for the year
Following the Venture Products acquisition, the company will continue to prioritize debt repayments to manage its leverage target, curtail share repurchases for the year, and consider strategically compelling acquisitions
The company declared its regular quarterly dividend in May
Based on the current outlook and strong financial position, the company expects to maintain its dividend
Due to the numerous and evolving COVID-19 related factors discussed and potential future developments, the company cannot predict the impact on its businesses and financial results
However, the company anticipates the most significant year-over-year sales and earnings per share percentage declines in the third quarter of fiscal 2020
Negative year-over-year fourth quarter sales and earnings per share growth are also expected
These expectations assume continued changes in customer behavior, including lower capital outlays and cash preservation, primarily in the Professional segment
On a positive note, the company's products have a natural replacement life, suggesting net sales will recover in future periods
Factors that could impact these expectations include the company's ability to continue operations or adjust production schedules due to governmental actions, supplier risk and the ability to obtain materials and components in a timely manner at anticipated costs, and prolonged economic stress affecting customer liquidity and buying patterns
The company anticipates an easing of these pressures as it enters fiscal 2021
In summary, the company has taken necessary steps to position itself for growth entering fiscal 2021, including preserving jobs, lowering costs, strengthening its financial position, serving partners well, and continuing to invest in technology and innovation
The company remains prepared to take further actions to serve customers in various potential economic scenarios
Despite limited near-term visibility, measures have been taken to ensure a solid financial position moving forward
The company is confident in its ability to continue serving global customers throughout and beyond the pandemic
Looking ahead, the company is optimistic about exciting opportunities, with investments in alternative power, smart connected products, and robotic and autonomous technologies driving a new cycle of innovative products across markets
The company continues to expand its portfolio of battery-powered products as customers seek convenience and reduced emissions
It is expected that customers who deferred new equipment purchases will return to historic buying patterns as the economy improves
In construction, the buildout of 5G and rural broadband is expected to benefit sales of underground equipment
In golf and grounds, the company will continue to innovate to increase productivity and solve customer challenges
The company continues to support contractors with an expanded line of high productivity equipment solutions
Continued homeowner interest in home and garden improvement is expected
The company has an exciting array of new products, including an expanded portfolio of 60-volt solutions, refreshed brand content and marketing, and a new channel partner broadening its reach
The company's strategic priorities remain focused on accelerating profitable growth, driving productivity and operational excellence, and empowering people
Summary:
output:
compname reports q2 earnings per share of $0.91.
q2 adjusted earnings per share $0.92.
q2 earnings per share $0.91.
all of company's facilities are currently open with some operating at reduced capacity.
will not be providing detailed financial quarterly or full-year guidance until visibility into market conditions has improved.
expects most pronounced year-over-year sales and earnings per share percentage declines in q3 of fiscal 2020.
also expects negative year-over-year q4 sales and earnings per share growth.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Prior to commencing, I should note that we'll be addressing future projections and anticipations during our discussion today.
Joining us for today's conference are Scott Donnelly, Textron's CEO and chairman, along with Frank Connor, our CFO.
Textron's quarterly revenue was $3.7 billion, representing a decrease of $368 million compared to the previous year.
In the fourth quarter of this year, we recorded $23 million in pre-tax extraordinary charges, primarily associated with restructuring initiatives in the industrial and Textron Aviation sectors, equivalent to $0.07 per share after tax.
We also acknowledged a one-time favorable tax advantage related to the TRU Canada sale, amounting to $0.04 per share.
After excluding extraordinary charges and the one-time favorable benefit, the adjusted net income was $1.06 per share, compared to $1.11 in the fourth quarter of the previous year.
Manufacturing cash flow before pension contributions amounted to $467 million, a decrease of $183 million from the fourth quarter of the previous year.
For the entire year, revenues totaled $11.7 billion, down from $13.6 billion in the previous year.
The adjusted net income was $2.07 per share, in contrast to $3.74 the previous year.
Manufacturing cash flow before pension contributions totaled $596 million, compared to $642 million in the previous year.
Our company concluded the year with robust operational performance in the fourth quarter, as we observed margin improvements in Systems, Industrial, and Bell, leading to an increase in Textron's manufacturing margin to 8.8% despite lower revenues.
At Bell, margins of 12.6% increased by 30 basis points compared to the previous year, despite reduced military revenues and commercial volume.
We delivered 57 commercial helicopters, a decrease from 76 in the fourth quarter of the previous year.
In the military sector, Japan officially commenced V-22 flight operations in November.
This contributes to the expansion of the global fleet of operational aircraft, which has accumulated over 560,000 flight hours.
Regarding Future Vertical Lift, Bell commemorated the third anniversary of the V-280's inaugural flight in December, with the aircraft now having logged more than 200 flight hours.
Army leadership and Congress have been highly supportive of Future Vertical Lift, and we anticipate this support will persist under the new administration.
In December, the U.S. Army provided the preliminary RFP for the FLRAA program for review and feedback.
The Army continues to expect a down-select and FLRAA program award in mid-2022.
At Systems, revenues decreased primarily due to lower volume in the TRU Simulation + Training business.
In November, Systems announced the sale of its commercial air transport simulator business to CAE.
This transaction was finalized in January.
During the quarter, ATAC secured the renewal of the U.S. Navy and Marine Corps flight, fighter jet training services program.
This contract expands the scope of services we currently provide for the program and is valued at up to $440 million over the next five years.
Additionally in the quarter, unmanned systems was awarded a $66 million contract from the U.S. Army for 36 Shadow aircraft.
The Shadow platform has now accumulated over 1.2 million flight hours globally.
Revenues declined primarily due to decreased demand in the ground support equipment business within Specialized Vehicles.
For Kautex, the automotive production outlook has steadily improved since its low point in May, and demand from our customers continued to increase in the fourth quarter as revenues approached their previous year's levels.
Transitioning to Textron Aviation's performance
The quarter saw a decline in revenue, mainly due to reduced jet deliveries and aftermarket activity
We delivered fewer jets compared to last year, but slightly more commercial turboprops
Textron Aviation introduced the new King Air 360, delivering eight units, and announced the King Air 260
The Cessna SkyCourier program is advancing, with three aircraft undergoing certification testing
Over 400 flight hours have been completed in the test program, with the aircraft on track for service entry in late 2021
2020 presented numerous operational challenges, but our teams responded admirably
Our focus on working capital and cost management resulted in strong manufacturing cash flow for the year
Our defense businesses maintained operations, fulfilling customer obligations and achieving strong results
Despite temporary shutdowns and market disruptions, our commercial side delivered strong fourth-quarter results, building momentum for 2021
We anticipate revenues of approximately $12.5 billion for Textron's 2021 fiscal year
Aviation expects growth from increased aircraft deliveries, new product launches, and higher aftermarket revenues due to increased fleet usage
Systems projects higher revenues and improved margins, driven by growth in ATAC and Marine and Land Systems
Bell anticipates solid margins despite lower military and commercial revenues, while investing in Future Vertical Lift
Industrial expects revenue growth and margin improvement at Kautex as automotive demand recovers to pre-COVID levels
Textron Specialized Vehicles anticipates revenue and margin growth as we expand our powersports business with Bass Pro Shops
We forecast adjusted earnings per share between $2.70 and $2.90
Manufacturing cash flow before pension contributions is expected to range from $600 million to $700 million
Quarterly segment profit decreased by $16 million compared to last year, with revenues dropping by $368 million
Textron Aviation's revenues fell 10% to $1.6 billion, mainly due to lower Citation jet and aftermarket volumes
The segment's profit declined to $108 million, primarily because of reduced volume and mix changes
Bell's revenues decreased to $871 million, mainly due to lower military and commercial volumes
Bell's segment profit dropped by $8 million, largely due to lower volume, partially offset by favorable performance adjustments
Textron Systems' revenues decreased to $357 million, primarily due to lower volume at TRU Simulation and Training
Systems' segment profit increased by $16 million, mainly due to improved performance
The segment's backlog reached $2.6 billion at the quarter's end.
Industrial earnings decreased to $866 million, dropping $61 million from the previous year, mainly due to lower demand in the Specialized Vehicles' ground support equipment sector.
Profits in the segment rose to $55 million, a 25% increase from Q4 2019, primarily because of favorable pricing, inflation effects, and improved performance, which was partially counterbalanced by reduced volume and mix changes.
The Finance segment generated $13 million in revenue and $2 million in profit.
Below segment profit, corporate costs totaled $50 million, while interest expenses amounted to $36 million.
The quarter saw $23 million in pre-tax special charges related to restructuring efforts.
Following strong cash performance, the year concluded with roughly $2.3 billion in cash on the balance sheet.
The $2.3 billion cash reserve is higher than usual, including a $500 million prefunding for 2021 debt maturities.
During the quarter, $350 million of floating rate notes due in November were paid off, along with $362 million of outstanding borrowings on corporate-owned life insurance policies drawn in Q1 for additional liquidity.
The share repurchase program was reactivated in the quarter, with approximately $129 million of shares bought back.
Textron Aviation is projected to have increased revenues of about $4.5 billion, reflecting higher jet and turboprop deliveries and improved aftermarket sales.
The segment margin is anticipated to be around 5.5%, due to higher volume and increased production.
Bell is expected to see slightly lower revenues of about $3.1 billion, due to reduced military revenues from lower H-1 production and aftermarket volume, as well as fewer commercial deliveries.
A margin of about 12.5% is forecasted, mainly reflecting decreased military and commercial revenues and increased R&D investments in FLRAA and FARA.
Systems is estimated to have higher 2021 revenues of about $1.4 billion.
The segment margin is projected to be around 12.5%.
Industrial segment revenues are expected to reach about $3.4 billion, showing higher revenues at Kautex and Textron Specialized Vehicles.
The segment margin is anticipated to be approximately 6%.
The finance segment is forecasted to generate a profit of about $10 million.
We estimate 2021 pension income to be about $30 million compared to a pension cost of $33 million in the previous year.
The 2021 pension reflects a strong 17.4% return on pension assets in 2020 and a change in the amortization period for accumulated actuarial losses for one domestic plan, resulting in a longer amortization period.
These positive changes are offset by a 75-basis point decrease in the discount rate to 2.7% and a 50-basis point reduction in the estimated long-term asset return to 7.25%.
R&D expenses are expected to increase to about $600 million from $545 million in 2020.
Capital expenditures are estimated to rise to about $400 million from $317 million last year.
Below the segment line, we project about $120 million in corporate expenses, $135 million in interest expenses, and a full-year effective tax rate of approximately 18%.
The full-year 2021 adjusted earnings per share guidance is $2.70 to $2.90, excluding $20 million to $30 million of pre-tax special charges for completing the previously announced restructuring plan and a pre-tax gain of about $10 million from the sale of TRU Canada.
Our outlook assumes an average share count of about 227 million shares as we continue to allocate most of our free cash to share repurchases in 2021.
Summary:
output:
q4 adjusted non-gaap earnings per share $1.06.
textron aviation backlog at end of q4 was $1.6 billion.
bell backlog at end of q4 was $5.3 billion.
forecasting 2021 revenues of about $12.5 billion, up from $11.7 billion in 2020.
expects full-year 2021 adjusted earnings per share from continuing operations in range $2.70 to $2.90.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Let me begin by acknowledging our associates at Optum and UnitedHealthcare for their outstanding performance throughout 2021 and creating momentum as we enter this year.
Two key aspects of our growth strategy, namely accelerating patient transitions to Optum-led value-based care and robust United Healthcare growth in Medicare Advantage, are progressing in line with the projections we shared at our recent investor meeting.
These developments, along with overall enterprise performance, reinforce our confidence in advancing our growth strategies and maintaining our long-term 13% to 16% earnings per share growth target.
Reflecting on 2021, we see a narrative of accelerating growth, strong collaboration between Optum and UnitedHealthcare and external partners, which facilitated expansion in commercial and government markets, sparked innovation, introduced integrated products and services, and significantly increased participation in value-based care models.
In the past year, we utilized our technological capabilities to assist medical professionals and hospitals in better serving their patients and communities.
We also intensified our focus on consumers, striving to enhance the overall experience.
Collectively, these initiatives helped us add over $30 billion in revenue for the year, surpassing our initial forecast by approximately $10 billion.
Similar growth can be anticipated in the coming year.
We observe an increasing demand for integration to unify the fragmented healthcare system, harness market innovations, improve alignment of incentives for providers, payers, and consumers, and organize the system around value.
Our vision is for a healthcare system that is more interconnected, informed, compassionate, and responsive to individual needs.
At our investor conference, we outlined five key growth areas and differentiated experiences across our portfolio, which will guide our strategy this year and beyond.
The first focus is on care delivery, particularly value-based care, which for UnitedHealth Group extends beyond primary care to include our expanding behavioral, home, ambulatory, and virtual care capabilities.
Our second growth area involves health benefits, enhancing the quality, innovation, and consumer appeal of our offerings while implementing our value-based strategy.
We begin 2022 with strong consumer growth in Medicare Advantage, progress in Medicaid, and increasing momentum in our commercial business.
Our major partnerships nationwide assist health systems in improving their performance and returns, ultimately supporting their missions.
We're excited about the potential to extend these comprehensive, tailored solutions to more system partners in 2022 and beyond.
The fourth area is health financial services, aiming to significantly improve the health payment sector by streamlining and simplifying transactions for providers, payers, and consumers while reducing friction and increasing speed and convenience.
Lastly, we focus on pharmacy services, where people interact most frequently with the healthcare system.
We aim to leverage our extensive pharmacy services and data capabilities, integrating medical, pharmacy, and behavioral services to provide comprehensive care, support new drug discoveries, and promote value-based care models.
In conclusion, we enter 2022 with increased confidence in our ability to achieve the objectives we set forth in late November.
I'd like to provide additional details on our primary growth priority: value-based care, our preparations, investments, and our vision for its near-future implementation.
This initiative has been in development for a decade.
Significant operational groundwork and investment were necessary to support the half-million new patients for whom OptumHealth will become accountable in 2022.
Successful execution requires extensive planning, investment, and development.
This has become a distinctive competency of our enterprise, which we can now apply on a larger scale.
Let's explore what's involved in preparing for a fully accountable arrangement.
Investments can be substantial.
In 2021, we spent over $100 million in preparatory expenses.
This preparation involves three main areas: training medical staff, upgrading technology and data systems, and coordinating networks.
The initial focus is on educating doctors.
This process begins more than a year in advance.
It's crucial to equip physicians with the necessary resources and information to change their approach to patient care.
They start addressing their patients' overall health long before taking on more responsibility.
We've found this shift from traditional fee-for-service practices to be essential but sometimes challenging.
In addition to education, we increase our workforce by hiring more doctors, nurses, and other healthcare professionals to meet our business needs.
The second area concentrates on implementing technology systems and gathering information to support patient care and effective clinical management.
This includes developing patient portals, utilization management systems, and reporting tools for teams to manage effectively.
The final area involves planning and coordinating networks to ensure comprehensive clinical oversight and true continuity of care.
This includes identifying high-need patients, ensuring smooth transitions to intensive clinical care services that improve health, and quickly connecting patients with personal care navigators to help with complex health needs, appointment scheduling, and timely medication support from day one.
These fundamental preparations and investments have been crucial in achieving strong results across various locations and practices we've transitioned.
We anticipate that this expertise will be valuable as we transition even larger groups of patients in the coming years.
Before passing the discussion to John, I'd like to provide an update on how COVID has affected our operations.
Similar to other companies, we've experienced slightly higher turnover rates and more unexpected absences.
We prepared for this situation by increasing our recruitment capacity and significantly improving our digital capabilities to enhance customer experience and reduce call volumes.
As a result, during the first two weeks of 2022, typically our busiest period, we were able to meet the needs of our patients and customers.
Simultaneously, we quickly responded to the federal mandate for free COVID tests for consumers, which was a highly complex task.
With only four days' notice, UnitedHealthcare developed a digital customer experience for easy reimbursement and established partnerships with Walmart and Rite Aid, eliminating upfront costs for consumers at the point of purchase.
We anticipate more partnerships in the near future.
Looking ahead, we believe we have the appropriate capacity to execute our business priorities and meet our customers' expectations.
I'll begin by elaborating on Dirk's comments regarding the COVID impacts we're observing.
In recent weeks, inpatient hospitalization rates for our members are comparable to January 2021 levels, despite national COVID case rates being about four times higher.
For those requiring inpatient care, the severity appears to be lower, as we're seeing shorter hospital stays compared to the earlier period.
Concurrently, we're noticing familiar patterns in care activity related to other periods of high infection rates experienced over the past two years.
For instance, in early January, we're observing a slowdown in primary care, elective visits, and procedural volumes.
Recent activity shows primary care visits have decreased by about 10%, with an even higher decline rate in specialist visits.
Our main priority remains ensuring individuals receive necessary medical attention when required.
Let's now examine our specific business results.
OptumHealth saw a 30% increase in revenue per customer in 2021, primarily due to the growing number of patients we serve under value-based agreements.
In line with our late November projections, we had a robust beginning to the year and still anticipate adding 500,000 new patients in accountable value-based relationships, benefiting from years of preparatory work.
OptumInsight's earnings increased by 25% in 2021, with operating margins nearing 28% for the year.
We finished the year with a revenue backlog of $22.4 billion, which is $2.2 billion more than the previous year.
Our expanding partnerships with health systems have been a key factor in this growth, and we expect these collaborations to continue growing in 2022 and beyond.
OptumRx earnings grew 6% for the year, driven by ongoing expansion of our pharmacy services businesses, supply chain initiatives, and effective cost management, as well as strong customer retention.
Furthermore, we continue to observe the impact of OptumRx's shift towards a higher-value pharmacy care and specialty services orientation.
Total revenue for the year reached $223 billion, an 11% increase.
As mentioned, our 2022 Medicare Advantage membership growth outlook is very positive and aligns with the goals we set at our November investor conference.
Of the up to 800,000 new members we will serve in 2022, approximately three-quarters will be in individual and group Medicare Advantage plans, with the remainder in dual special needs plans.
Given our steady progress in quality performance, we have the opportunity to enroll people in our newly rated five-star plans throughout the entire year.
Our Medicaid membership outlook for 2022 continues to include an expectation that states will resume eligibility redeterminations, resulting in modest net attrition.
In January, we began serving Minnesota residents and continue to support Missouri's expansion this year, as well as renewed relationships with Ohio, Tennessee, and Nevada.
Throughout the year, we will aim to expand upon the nearly 8 million individuals we serve across 31 states.
We ended 2021 with commercial membership about 200,000 people higher than the original outlook provided.
This momentum is driven by the strong response we're seeing to new innovative products we've discussed, such as NavigateNOW, which uses the Optum virtual network as a primary option.
Our financial capabilities remain robust.
Full-year 2021 cash flow from operations was $22.3 billion, or 1.3 times net income, about $2 billion above the initial outlook we shared a year ago.
We continue to anticipate our 2022 cash flow will approach $24 billion, about 1.2 times net income.
We concluded 2021 with a debt-to-total capital ratio of 38%.
These substantial financial resources allow us to accelerate our investments while maintaining our commitment to an increasing shareholder dividend and supporting our expected repurchase of between $5 billion and $6 billion of stock in 2022.
Our 2022 adjusted earnings per share outlook of $21.10 to $21.60 aligns with the projection we offered seven weeks ago.
From this perspective, and unlike the past two years, we expect the seasonal pattern to more closely resemble our historical experience, with slightly less than 50% of full-year earnings in the first half and the first two quarters being relatively equal.
Before we move to the Q&A session, I hope you've already sensed the strong confidence John, Dirk, and I share in this company's growth potential, based on the increasing number of people we're serving in value-based models, the deep relationships we're building with local health systems, our pharmacy capabilities, and the innovation and consumer focus driving growth across our government programs, individual and commercial businesses.
As demand for innovation and integrated solutions, products, and services continues to grow, we've never been better positioned to help unify the fragmented aspects of healthcare and create more value for those we aim to serve.
Please limit questions to one per caller.
Summary:
output:
affirmed 2022 growth and performance objectives established at its november 30, 2021 investor conference.
unitedhealth - confirmed 2022 growth forecast elements provided at its investor conference, including for people served through medicare advantage.
unitedhealth - cash flows from operations for the full year 2021 were $22.3 billion or 1.3x times net income.

Context:We are eager to talk about Vector Group dividing its operations through spinning off Douglas Elliman.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Michael Happe, the president and CEO, and Bryan Hughes, the senior VP and CFO, are accompanying me on the call today.
I urge you to review our SEC filings, which outline these factors.
We greatly value your interest in Winnebago Industries and appreciate you joining us to discuss our Q4 and annual 2021 financial results.
We concluded fiscal 2021 with a robust Q4, marked by unprecedented revenue and profitability, driven by three key elements.
Sustained enthusiasm for outdoor activities continued to fuel demand for Winnebago Industries' premium offerings.
Winnebago Industries' Q4 revenue increased by 40.4% compared to the previous year, and by 56.8% organically excluding Newmar, relative to Q4 of fiscal 2019.
Winnebago Industries' market share growth accelerated in Q4, gaining 2.1 percentage points during the three months ending in August.
This growth is attributable to both new and experienced consumers who recognize the superior quality and innovation of Winnebago Industries' product range.
We are known for providing exceptional service in collaboration with our dealers.
Our team's unwavering commitment to operational excellence allowed us to efficiently and profitably meet consumer and dealer needs during a challenging period of supply constraints and inflation.
Consequently, we improved margins in both our motor home and towable divisions during Q4.
I'd like to acknowledge the outstanding Winnebago Industries employee team.
Our workforce, now over 6,800 strong with the addition of Barletta, has worked tirelessly to deliver the high-quality products and exceptional service our customers and dealers expect.
While managing record-high backlogs to meet the tremendous product demand, their dedication has been crucial to our success this year.
The pandemic has undoubtedly accelerated the demand for outdoor experiences.
We believe this shift, which was already underway before COVID-19, will have a lasting impact as more families discover the great outdoors.
In 2020, over 10 million households went camping for the first time, and we expect another 4.3 million households to have their first camping experience in 2021.
Besides newcomers, a new wave of enthusiasts, particularly millennials and younger generations, are investing more time and money in outdoor activities.
Even as pandemic restrictions eased over the summer, potentially allowing for a wider range of vacation and leisure options, our performance during the summer selling season was strong.
We set revenue records in both our fiscal Q3 and Q4.
Our record order backlog continues to grow, and we're seeing rapid sell-through of inventory provided to dealers.
We're confident that the diverse groups creating memories outdoors will form the foundation of our growth in the coming decades.
We're optimistic about the broader recreation economy and are investing to expand our reach beyond RVs, in line with our strategy to become a premier outdoor lifestyle company.
We completed our acquisition of Barletta Boat Company early in Q1 of our fiscal 2022.
Building on our previous marine investment in the Chris-Craft brand, Barletta's premium pontoon boats significantly expand our marine platform into one of the fastest-growing boating segments.
We're excited to discuss the opportunities in our new marine reporting segment in future quarters.
Due to the strength of our overall offering, we've successfully capitalized on the industry-wide demand for outdoor lifestyle products and delivered net total growth.
Winnebago Industries is increasingly winning with customers, and we're proud that a disproportionate share of new outdoor enthusiasts have chosen to join the Winnebago Industries community.
As of August 2021, our RV fiscal year-to-date market share is 12.5%, up 140 basis points from the same period last year.
We've achieved these gains while maintaining record low levels of discounting.
Our performance and ability to capture market share at full product value in a competitive market underscores the unique appeal of our diverse brand portfolio.
Continued investment in our products and brands, unified by our commitment to quality, innovation, and service, ensures we're positioned to meet consumer demands for technology and capabilities, driving share gains now and in the future.
Our world-class team expertly translated demand growth and market share gains into strong financial performance in Q4, demonstrating enterprise-wide commitment to operational efficiency despite ongoing pandemic challenges, including supply chain disruptions and inflationary pressures.
These operational efforts are evident in our record consolidated annual gross margins of 17.9% for the fiscal year.
A key element of our operational excellence is the success of our enterprise-wide operations and sourcing teams, who quickly adapted to component shortages and supply disruptions.
Our team has remained flexible, using creative and strategic material sourcing strategies to keep our assembly lines moving.
We'll continue to monitor supply chain issues and provide updates with our results as long as they persist.
Our efforts to improve communication across our supply chain have allowed us to better anticipate and plan for disruptions in partner component availability.
We're continuing to strengthen our relationships with our dedicated dealer network as we focus on replenishing their inventories as quickly as possible.
We're incredibly proud of our team's performance in Q4 and throughout fiscal 2021.
Our results demonstrate that we're executing well on our proven value creation strategy.
The new heights we achieved in revenues and profitability showcase the unique strength and appeal of our growing platform, as well as our world-class team.
I'll discuss Q4 and annual highlights, recent capital allocation announcements, and several items affecting future reporting.
This information is available on our investor relations website.
As Mike mentioned earlier, our fiscal Q4 was a strong conclusion to an outstanding fiscal 2021.
Q4 revenues reached a record $1 billion, a 40% increase compared to Q4 of fiscal 2020.
Q4 consolidated gross profit margin of 18.1% was up 150 basis points year-over-year due to leverage, pricing adjustments, lower discounts and allowances, and profitability initiatives.
Record Q4 revenues and strong margins resulted in record earnings per share.
Q4 earnings per diluted share reached a record $2.45, a 96% increase versus the same period last year.
Q4 adjusted earnings per diluted share hit a record $2.57, up 77% year-over-year.
Turning to the full-year fiscal 2021 results, consolidated record revenues of $3.6 billion increased approximately 54% from $2.4 billion in fiscal 2020, driven by strong consumer demand for Winnebago Industries products and continued RV market share gains.
Revenues were also positively impacted by pricing adjustments implemented throughout the year to offset inflationary input costs, as well as lower levels of discounts and allowances.
The yearly gross profit margin saw a significant improvement of 460 basis points, reaching a record 17.9%, mainly due to effective cost management, profitability measures, higher pricing with reduced discounts, and a favorable product mix.
Consistent with the fourth quarter results, the strong annual revenue and healthy profit margins led to unprecedented levels of profitability.
The full-year earnings per diluted share reached a record $8.28, showing a 350% increase compared to the previous fiscal year.
The adjusted earnings per diluted share for the full year also hit a record $8.55, representing a 231% increase from $2.58 in the previous year.
Let's now examine the performance of individual segments.
The Towable segment's fourth-quarter revenue was $560 million, showing a 35% increase from $414 million in the previous fiscal year, primarily due to high consumer demand and price adjustments made to counter rising input costs.
The segment's adjusted EBITDA for the fourth quarter rose by approximately 36% year-over-year to $83.4 million, mainly driven by higher revenue.
The fourth-quarter adjusted EBITDA margin increased by 10 basis points to 14.9% compared to the same period last year, primarily due to operational efficiencies, which was partially offset by a shift in product mix favoring travel trailers over fifth wheels.
For the entire fiscal year 2021, the Towable segment's revenue reached a record $2 billion, a 64% increase from fiscal 2020, driven by strong demand for towable products and price adjustments to offset rising input costs.
The segment's full-year adjusted EBITDA was $289 million, a 95% increase from fiscal 2020.
The segment's adjusted EBITDA margin for the full year improved by 230 basis points to 14.4% compared to fiscal 2020.
Now, let's examine our Motorhome segment.
In the fourth quarter, the Motorhome segment's revenue was $448.9 million, approximately 49% higher than the previous year, driven by strong consumer demand, especially for Class B and Class A motorhomes, and price adjustments to counter inflation.
The segment's adjusted EBITDA increased by about 159% from the previous year to $50.4 million.
The adjusted EBITDA margin rose to 11.2%, an increase of 480 basis points year-over-year and 150 basis points sequentially, due to improved cost management and profitability initiatives.
For the full fiscal year 2021, the Motorhome segment's revenue was $1.5 billion, approximately 46% higher than fiscal 2020, due to increased unit sales and pricing.
The segment's full-year adjusted EBITDA was $169.2 million, a 414% increase from fiscal 2020.
The segment's adjusted EBITDA margin for the full year was 11%, an improvement of 790 basis points over fiscal 2020.
Let's now look at the balance sheet.
At the end of fiscal year 2021, the company had outstanding debt of $528.6 million, consisting of $600 million in gross debt, minus a convertible note discount of $60.4 million and debt issuance costs of $11.1 million.
The working capital stood at $651.6 million.
Our current net debt to adjusted EBITDA ratio is 0.4, which is below our target range of 0.9 to 1.5, providing financial flexibility and a strong balance sheet to support ongoing investment in our strategic priorities and deliver returns to shareholders.
We continue to maintain a robust liquidity position.
Our cash balance increased to $434.6 million at the end of fiscal 2021, and we have not drawn on our $192.5 million ABL.
This liquidity of approximately $627 million provided the necessary funding for the Barletta acquisition, which was completed at the start of fiscal 2022.
We also repurchased about $45 million worth of shares throughout the year, with approximately $35 million occurring in the fourth quarter.
Combining share repurchases and dividends paid, Winnebago Industries returned a total of $62 million to shareholders in fiscal 2021, while also significantly growing the business.
The effective income tax rate for the full year was 23.3% compared to 20.5% for fiscal 2020, due to relatively consistent year-over-year tax credits on higher pre-tax income in fiscal 2021.
Looking ahead to fiscal 2022, we anticipate our tax rate to be between 23.5% and 24.5%, barring any unforeseen discrete items or changes in tax law.
Our balance sheet and financial health have never been stronger.
With this in mind and looking to the future, I'd like to discuss our capital allocation priorities.
First, we will continue to invest in our business and advance our strategic priorities focused on growth and meeting the robust demand we continue to expect.
We are planning investments to increase capacity, including new facilities, implementing production flow redesigns, and optimizing our operational capabilities.
These improvements will support continued production output, as well as product innovation, and they demonstrate our confidence in Winnebago Industries' future and the vitality of our end markets.
We continuously seek areas for improvement across our Winnebago, Grand Design, Newmar, Chris-Craft, and now Barletta manufacturing and assembly facilities, and plan to add significant square footage in the coming year.
Our acquisition of Barletta, completed at the beginning of fiscal 2022, was primarily funded with cash but also included newly issued shares.
This effective deal structure maintains our strong liquidity position and low leverage ratio, allowing us to continue pursuing M&A opportunities as they arise.
Issuing shares also aligns all parties on driving a successful integration and our collective future success.
On August 18, 2021, our board of directors approved a quarterly cash dividend of $0.18 per share, payable on September 29, 2021, to common stockholders of record at the close of business on September 15, 2021.
