This quarter's dividend declaration represents a 50% or $0.06 per share increase from the previous quarter, further demonstrating our confidence in future business performance while also delivering financial returns to our shareholders.
As mentioned earlier, we returned approximately $45 million to shareholders through share repurchases during the year, with about $35 million occurring in the fourth quarter.
To enable further repurchase activity in the future, our board approved a new share buyback program on October 13, authorizing us to repurchase up to $200 million of our shares in the future.
This should be seen as a sign of our confidence in our future, and we will continue to use our share repurchase program as another way to return cash to our shareholders.
Before concluding my remarks, I want to highlight three changes to our reporting beginning with the first quarter of our fiscal year 2022.
First, as previously announced, our acquisition of Barletta Boat Company significantly increases the scale of our marine platform.
Starting next quarter, Q1 of fiscal 2022, Winnebago Industries' public reporting will include a new reporting segment, the Marine segment, comprising Barletta and Chris-Craft.
Comparisons will be made to fiscal 2021, which will only include Chris-Craft results, and we will report the same key data points for the Marine segment as we do with our RV segments, specifically revenues, units, adjusted EBITDA, backlog, and field inventories.
Second, going forward, we will be adjusting for 100% of intangible amortization within our adjusted earnings per diluted share metric.
We are taking this step to ensure that our adjusted earnings per share best reflects the core operations of our business.
Third, the tax rate for adjusting items that impact reported earnings per share to arrive at adjusted earnings per share will be 24.2%.
We have historically used the federal statutory 21% rate.
This modification will be implemented moving forward, without restating previous years' data.
In summary, our fourth quarter and full year 2021 financial results demonstrate our strong market position and the valuable contributions of our diverse business portfolio and dedicated workforce.
We are immensely satisfied with these outcomes and have high hopes for our future performance.
This completes my overview of our quarterly and annual financial reports.
Looking back on 2021, as Bryan mentioned, we're pleased with the financial, strategic, and cultural progress we've achieved together with our talented team.
Besides delivering robust financial results and expanding our market share, Winnebago Industries also maintained our deep commitment to corporate responsibility towards our communities and shareholders.
As part of our dedication to the Winnebago Industries family and all stakeholders, we've made significant progress in enhancing our ESG initiatives across the organization.
Jill collaborates with company leadership to advance DEI programs and initiatives, guiding the implementation of our overall DEI strategy and roadmap.
As an illustration of supporting others, we established a year-round Go Together fund to assist employees facing natural disasters and personal hardships.
For instance, we recently mobilized resources to support earthquake relief efforts in Haiti, which is closely connected to many of our valued Chris-Craft team members.
At Winnebago Industries, we are devoted to promoting outdoor adventures while striving to be active protectors of the environment.
It is crucial to our mission that our employees and customers can enjoy the beautiful natural spaces our planet offers.
To reduce our environmental impact for future generations of outdoor enthusiasts, we recently reinforced our commitment to sustainability by joining the Business Ambition for 1.5 degrees Celsius, a UN-backed global coalition of business leaders.
As part of this program, we are pledging to help mitigate climate change by setting a goal to achieve net-zero greenhouse gas emissions by 2050.
We also announced additional targets for water conservation, waste reduction, and product sustainability.
We anticipate collaborating with the Science Based Targets initiative and external validators to develop a concrete plan for achieving this net-zero goal, which represents a key focus of our corporate responsibility strategy.
As we enter the upcoming year, you can expect us to continue prioritizing corporate responsibility in our investments and partnerships.
Looking ahead to the future.
The unprecedented demand for our products and optimistic industry outlook have provided us with a very promising outlook for fiscal 2022.
In addition to leveraging the strength of our RV and Chris-Craft brands, we are thrilled to incorporate Barletta, the fastest-growing brand in the rapidly expanding pontoon segment of the marine category.
Barletta's quality brand and high-caliber dealer partners enhance our existing portfolio of premium brands, providing more families access to the long-term value of Winnebago Industries' quality products.
Together, our brands exemplify quality, service, and innovation for our dealers and end consumers.
These are the key factors that will drive market share gains for us in the RV and marine industries during fiscal 2022 and beyond.
Consumer interest in outdoor activities remains robust.
Campground reservations, just one indicator, continue to be strong due to more households camping and camping more frequently.
Website traffic on our sites is as high as ever, and dealers continue to observe steady interest in outdoor lifestyles involving RVs and boating.
As mentioned earlier, over 14 million households will have experienced camping for the first time during 2020 and 2021.
Many of these experiences have resulted in families purchasing their first RV.
As these new households explore the outdoors and further define their preferences, our dealers are already witnessing the upgrade cycle taking place.
While some new customers from 2020 are leaving the lifestyle, which is not historically unusual, our broad dealer conversations across all RV brands indicate dealers are also seeing an accelerated pace of users trading up, a trend that favors our premium brands as we tend to outperform the broader market when consumers upgrade.
In the long term, we believe the influx of new customers into the outdoor lifestyle in 2020 and 2021 will benefit the industry.
We're particularly excited about the number of children who experienced RV and boating, as these experiences have been shown to foster a lifelong love for the outdoors.
Regarding supply, we continue to face material and component cost increases from suppliers, and we continue to manage out-of-stock situations or late deliveries on a weekly basis.
There is limited visibility as to when these trends will significantly diminish.
Despite these challenges, we continue to deliver record-level revenues and margin growth as our teams work diligently to implement effective sourcing and production strategies.
Given the levels of cost input inflation we've experienced over the past year, we are carefully working to mitigate these cost increases through internal cost-saving initiatives.
However, it has also been necessary for us to implement price increases to offset inflationary pressures while ensuring our products are perceived as having exceptional value in the marketplace.
The magnitude of price increases year-over-year across our brand portfolio varies from mid-single digits to over 20%.
There is no single price increase figure for our entire business.
Each of our outdoor brands is blending a price-to-market and price-to-cost approach that protects profitable market share growth.
Consequently, consumers are seeing higher prices for boats and RVs, as retail pricing is a combination of OEM pricing and improved dealer margins due to high demand levels.
Retail pricing is not solely determined by OEM pricing strategy.
Despite higher prices, we are still maintaining a higher double-digit percentage retail pace currently compared to two years ago.
Before we open the call for questions, I want to briefly address expectations for the RV industry in the upcoming year.
We agree with the recently released RVIA forecast for calendar year 2022, which predicts 600,000 wholesale shipments, representing a 4% growth compared to the calendar year 2021 forecast of 577,000 units.
For Winnebago Industries' fiscal year 2022, the RVIA forecast translates to 605,000 wholesale industry shipments, or 6% growth compared to the fiscal 2021 figure of 569,000 units.
RV retail sales for the industry in our fiscal year 2021 were approximately 585,000 units, a record number that will likely be adjusted upwards as SSI adjustments occur in the coming months.
Looking ahead, we anticipate strong RV industry retail sales for fiscal 2022.
Although they may not reach the record fiscal 2021 retail results, we fully expect industry retail sales for our fiscal 2022 period to achieve the second-highest level on record.
Given this outlook, it is highly unlikely that industry field RV inventories will be adequately replenished by the end of our fiscal year 2022, suggesting that the restocking phase will continue into our fiscal 2023.
As we approach inventory normalization in the future, we've previously mentioned that some dealers, though not all, may work with lower inventory levels and higher turns.
In line with historical trends as markets normalize, dealers will rationalize the quantity of OEM brands on their lots, and we believe we are competitively advantaged in that scenario with our brands.
We also anticipate that dealers will return to more normal or historical levels of profitability, implying that pricing to end customers may ease as this occurs and as general inflation subsides in the future.
Summary:
output:
compname reports q4 earnings of $2.45 per share.
q4 adjusted earnings per share $2.57.
q4 earnings per share $2.45.
compname posts q4 adjusted earnings per share $2.57.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Brian Casey, our President and CEO, and Terry Forbes, our CFO, are joining us on today's call.
We trust you're staying safe during these challenging times for everyone.
I'll review our quarterly results and discuss how the COVID-19 crisis is affecting our company, as usual.
The previous quarter was truly unprecedented.
The worldwide COVID-19 outbreak spread rapidly, causing a sharp decline in liquidity and returns, with March being particularly devastating.
The S&P 500 experienced its worst first-quarter performance since 1928, and global equity and fixed income markets were similarly impacted.
Investors are closely monitoring the potential peak in new virus cases for indications about the future, although the path to economic recovery remains uncertain.
In our U.S. Value Equity offerings, the unprecedented equity sell-off was significant in absolute terms, but higher-quality companies across all market capitalizations performed relatively better.
All of our U.S. Value strategies outperformed their respective passive benchmarks, demonstrating the clear advantages of active management.
Our primary LargeCap Value strategy demonstrated resilience during the market downturn, experiencing only about 85% of the decline and outperforming the Russell 1000 Value Index by nearly 400 basis points.
LargeCap Value is outpacing the benchmark over various time frames, and its ranking among institutional LargeCap Value peers remains strong.
As of the first quarter, our LargeCap Value strategy ranked in the top 10% for the trailing three-year period and in the top 25% for the trailing one-, five- and seven-year periods.
Our LargeCap Select strategy also ended the quarter ahead of the Russell 1000 Value benchmark and now ranks in the top 10% among institutional peers in the eVestment large-cap value manager universe for the trailing three-year period.
Our SMidCap strategy outperformed the Russell 2500 Value Index by over 400 basis points and now has returns surpassing the benchmark in most trailing year periods.
Rankings among institutional peers were also impressive.
The strategy now ranks in the top half for the trailing five and seven years and in the top 25% for the trailing one- and three-year periods.
Our portfolio managers have diligently worked to enhance the track record, and we're observing increased interest in the strategy from institutional clients.
SmallCap was the most severely impacted sector of our U.S. Value strategies, but our portfolio managers maintained their focus on identifying companies with strong fundamental qualities and finished the quarter approximately 260 basis points ahead of the Russell 2000 Value benchmark.
Our institutional strategy also maintained favorable peer rankings, placing in the top third for the quarter and trailing one-year period.
SmallCap's longer-term performance places it in the top 10% over the trailing seven-, 10- and since inception periods.
As we navigate the economic situation created by COVID-19, market volatility will present attractive investment opportunities for high-conviction, actively managed portfolios centered on quality and value.
While the value style, which focuses on companies with low valuation levels, has historically performed best following a recession, many companies today have higher debt levels than in previous cycles and may find themselves with limited options.
Financial distress is particularly severe in the energy sector, and we're already witnessing several companies filing for bankruptcy protection.
As the market pays more attention to balance sheets, the strongest companies will thrive while those burdened with debt from the previous cycle will struggle.
Our investment process has always included a thorough analysis of a candidate's balance sheet, which has historically benefited our clients during times of stress.
Many index funds have over one-third of their portfolios invested in companies with no profits and high debt levels.
Mounting losses and debt will be detrimental to many of these companies, and we believe this is an opportune time for investors to move away from index funds and towards active managers who can skillfully navigate the landscape of winners and losers.
Shifting focus to our Multi-Asset group, our product range in Multi-Asset includes various strategies aligned across the risk and return spectrum, tailored to meet specific client risk profiles and investment objectives.
Income Opportunity, our largest strategy in the group, displayed attractive characteristics compared to equity markets.
However, investors' rush to perceived safe assets drove treasury returns up and hindered our relative performance.
Asset classes such as preferred stocks, convertible bonds, and mortgage-backed securities experienced significant declines during the quarter.
The drop in convertible securities has created opportunities not seen since the global financial crisis.
This has created a favorable environment for investors to consider strategies like our Global Convertible and Alternative Income strategies, which have historically delivered strong risk-adjusted results.
Our Global Convertible and Alternative Income strategies performed as expected and acted as diversifiers in asset allocation mixes during a highly challenging and volatile period.
Correlations across capital markets converged to one, and volatility reached levels last observed during the global financial crisis.
Compared to similar institutions, our Alternative Income approach ranked in the top fifth for the past year and top tenth for the past five, seven, and ten years.
For Emerging Markets, valuations remain attractive, especially when compared to developed markets after the asset class's recent underperformance.
Our strategies underperformed mainly because we had less exposure to China and Hong Kong than the benchmark.
Emerging Markets worldwide experienced unprecedented volatility, with reactions to COVID-19 being quick and widespread.
Investors sought any available liquidity, and these markets were particularly affected by this rush to cash and safety.
This reaction also led to significant currency devaluations in several emerging market countries we invest in, including Brazil, Indonesia, Mexico, and Chile.
We anticipate that this volatility will continue.
The extent and duration of the economic impacts are yet to be determined and will differ across regions.
Many large emerging markets outside China are currently under lockdown, and governments are still formulating their economic responses.
As with our other strategies, market disruptions have created opportunities to invest in companies with strong leadership, cash flow, and financial stability.
Our focus on high-quality companies has helped us navigate past crises and gives us confidence that our holdings will be well-positioned for the long term.
In Wealth Management, our Dallas and Houston teams have been proactively reaching out to clients to help them navigate market uncertainty.
Many of our wealthy clients are choosing to increase their investments during this time to capitalize on the market downturn and prepare for an eventual recovery.
We have expanded Westwood Private Bank's services for our high-net-worth clients, improving our ability to keep clients within the Westwood brand ecosystem.
The combination of banking services integrated with Westwood's existing financial planning, trust, and investment services is being well-received by our clients.
Looking ahead, Westwood Trust will begin introducing our new digital portal to enhance client engagement.
The Select Equity strategy, managed by the Westwood Trust Houston office, saw its risk management measures perform as expected this quarter, outperforming its benchmark.
Select Equity and its tax-efficient version are designed to provide a high-quality, low-turnover portfolio with risk controls for downside protection.
At the market's lowest points this quarter, both strategies held up well due to their emphasis on risk control and investments in companies with strong balance sheets.
Both versions of our strategy recently reached their three-year milestone and are outperforming their global benchmark.
Furthermore, we conduct tax-loss harvesting throughout the year instead of waiting until year-end, which helps reduce our clients' tax liabilities and has provided over 200 basis points of additional annualized alpha over the past three years.
In our institutional and intermediary sales group, we had inflows of nearly $400 million and $950 million in outflows, resulting in total net outflows of $560 million.
The majority of outflows were from our sub-advisor relationships in LargeCap Value, Global Converts, Alternative Income, and Emerging Markets.
SmallCap was again our most successful strategy, with net inflows for the quarter as existing clients added funds to their accounts and new clients invested in our mutual fund.
Given the strong relative performance of our U.S. strategies, we believe we're well-positioned to attract sales in the current environment.
Our investments in distribution infrastructure and alignment of investment teams, vehicles, pricing, product definitions, risk guidelines, and messaging have allowed us to create a unified message that positions our sales teams for success.
Our intermediary and institutional investment teams continue to work on gaining consultant approvals, and overall, our pipeline remains healthy and diverse across several strategies.
New opportunities were added in SmallCap and Income Opportunity during the quarter, and a significant portion of our pipeline is in the mid- to late-stage, with decisions expected throughout the year.
We have made significant progress in obtaining approvals for our SmallCap fund at several major wirehouses.
Although COVID-19 has disrupted markets and slowed the sales cycle with prospects, our distribution teams continue to execute our plan to build a broader, more sustainable distribution business, and our client services teams continue to provide excellent service to our clients.
While face-to-face meetings are not possible, our teams are functioning relatively normally.
We recently conducted an online campaign targeting 25,000 advisors and were pleased to see over 10,000 views.
Conference calls, portfolio updates, RFPs, and questionnaires are proceeding as usual.
We understand that clients and consultants require timely and relevant communication.
They need information on how the pandemic is affecting portfolios and our investment decisions, and they want to know how our business continuity plan is functioning and adapting.
Our remote work success is a crucial area of investigation for clients seeking to understand how we've maintained our business integrity in the current environment.
The asset management sector was already facing challenges such as reduced fees, shrinking margins, and rising costs for data and technology before the COVID-19 pandemic.
In the past, I've mentioned that Westwood has made significant technological investments to cut costs, improve operational efficiency, prepare for disruptions, and enhance our flexibility.
These investments have proven valuable, allowing us to increase efficiency and transition to a fully operational remote work environment with minimal disruption.
We will persist in evaluating our business and implementing significant measures to reduce our expenses.
We have identified and are implementing or processing over $750,000 in cost reductions throughout the remainder of the year.
For the past six months, we've been investigating the outsourcing of trading and have recently decided to proceed with this initiative.
We plan to transition to an outsourced trading model in late summer and anticipate annual savings of over $1 million starting in 2021.
We will continue to use technology to shape our future state and improve efficiency wherever possible.
We will shut down or eliminate unprofitable funds and focus on deploying our best products and personnel.
Despite disappointing financial results over the past year, we continue to implement numerous initiatives to strengthen our foundation for the future.
Our collaboration with InvestCloud continues to yield operational advantages.
The U.S. Value and Multi-Asset strategies are generating alpha, and we have secured commitments from private wealth clients for a new credit opportunities fund launched recently.
We anticipate ongoing industry disruption, and the steps we've taken to reinvent ourselves have positioned us to survive and grow.
I want to stress that our top priority is the health and safety of our employees and their families.
All our staff members are healthy, working remotely, and completing their tasks efficiently.
We recognize our responsibility to run the business while balancing company needs with employees' personal requirements.
I'm extremely proud of everyone at Westwood for their excellent collaboration, despite working apart, during these challenging times.
Our clients still have objectives and priorities, and we will continue to serve them to the best of our ability.
We reported total revenues of $16.7 million for Q1 2020, compared to $18.6 million in Q4 2019 and $23.9 million in Q1 2019.
The decrease from the previous quarter and the same quarter last year was mainly due to lower average assets under management.
Q1 net income was $1.1 million or $0.13 per share, compared to $2.5 million or $0.30 per share in Q4 2019.
The decrease was primarily attributed to lower total revenues and unrealized losses on private investments, partially offset by reduced operating expenses and income taxes.
Economic earnings, a non-GAAP measure, were $4.2 million or $0.50 per share in Q1 2020, versus $5.4 million or $0.64 per share in Q4 2019.
Q1 2020 net income of $1.1 million or $0.13 per share compared to $0.4 million or $0.05 per share in Q1 2019.
The increase was mainly due to lower operating expenses, particularly employee compensation and benefits, foreign currency transaction gains, and income taxes, partially offset by lower revenues and unrealized losses on private investments.
Economic earnings for Q1 2020 were $4.2 million or $0.50 per share, compared to $4.1 million or $0.49 per share in Q1 2019.
At the end of the quarter, firmwide assets under management totaled $11.6 billion, consisting of $6.3 billion (55%) in institutional assets, $3.8 billion (33%) in wealth management assets, and $1.5 billion (12%) in mutual fund assets.
During the quarter, we experienced $3 billion in market depreciation and $0.6 billion in net outflows.
Our financial position remains strong, with $82.4 million in cash and short-term investments at quarter-end and no debt on our balance sheet.
In Q1, we bought back approximately 272,000 shares of our common stock for a total of $4.9 million.
In April, we repurchased an additional 407,000 shares for approximately $8.1 million.
This completed the authorized amount under our share repurchase program.
Summary:
output:
q1 earnings per share $0.13.
q1 revenue $16.7 million versus $23.9 million.
q1 non-gaap earnings per share $0.50.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Joining me as co-host are our Executive Chairman, Bill Berkeley, and our Group CFO, Rich Baio.
We'll stick to our usual format, with Rich providing an overview of the quarter and highlighting key points shortly.
After that, I'll share some brief comments before we open the floor for questions.
Rich, please take it from here.
Our business continues to show strong growth, as evidenced by increased premiums and improved underwriting profits, reflecting higher rates and additional premiums from increased exposure in our financial statements.
We achieved a new record in underwriting profit for the second consecutive quarter in Q2 2021, along with robust net investment income, resulting in a 15% annualized return on equity at the beginning of the year.
The company reported $237 million in net income, equivalent to $1.27 per share.
This includes $219 million in operating income ($1.17 per share) and $18 million in after-tax net investment gains ($0.10 per share).
Examining our quarterly underwriting performance, gross premiums written increased by $529 million (24.8%) to nearly $2.7 billion.
Net premiums written grew by $472 million (27.2%) to over $2.2 billion, with increases in both segments.
Our overall cession rate decreased this quarter due to changes in outward reinsurance arrangements, reduced reinstatement premiums, and shifts in business mix.
In terms of segment production for net premiums written, the insurance segment grew 29.2% to almost $2 billion, with increases across all business lines.
Professional liability led the growth at 64.8%, followed by commercial auto at 31%, other liability at 28.7%, short tail lines at 21.2%, and workers' compensation at 15.6%.
The reinsurance and Monoline Excess segment increased by about 11% to $218 million, with Monoline Excess growing 20.9% and casualty reinsurance 17.5%, partially offset by a 13.8% decrease in property reinsurance.
Underwriting income improved due to compounding rate increases above loss cost trends, exposure growth, and lower claims frequency in certain business lines.
We experienced higher-than-average non-weather related property losses this quarter, which partially offset these benefits.
Additionally, our current accident year catastrophe losses decreased significantly from $146 million (8.7 loss ratio points) in the previous year to $44 million (2.2 loss ratio points) in the current quarter.
Consequently, quarterly underwriting income rose by almost 800% to a record $202 million.
The reported loss ratio for the current quarter was 61%, compared to 67.7% in 2020.
Prior-year loss reserves developed favorably by approximately $0.5 million in the current quarter.
As a result, our current accident year loss ratio, excluding catastrophes, was 58.8% compared to 59.2% for the same quarter last year.
The continued growth in net premiums earned has improved the expense ratio, which was 28.7% in the current quarter compared to 31% a year ago.
Net premiums earned surpassed underwriting expenses by more than 8.5%.
We continue to benefit from reduced travel and entertainment costs, but anticipate some of these savings will diminish as the economy fully reopens.
To summarize the underwriting performance, our current accident year combined ratio, excluding catastrophes, was 87.5% for the quarter, compared to 90.2% for the same period last year.
Regarding investments, net investment income increased by 96.9% to $168 million, driven by strong performance in investment funds.
The fixed maturity portfolio showed a decline quarter-over-quarter due to the lower interest rate environment, although the quarterly gap is narrowing.
We maintain an above-average level of cash and cash equivalents as of June 30, 2021, which has been decreasing over recent quarters as we identify opportunities to invest at attractive risk-adjusted returns.
Our duration remains steady at 2.4 years while maintaining a high credit quality of AA minus.
The quarter's pre-tax net investment gains of $24 million mainly consisted of $39 million in realized investment gains, an $18 million decrease in unrealized equity securities gains, and a $3 million reduction in expected credit loss allowance.
The sale of two real estate properties largely contributed to the realized gain, also resulting in a reduction of approximately $102 million in debt associated with one of the properties.
Corporate costs rose by about $13 million, attributed to $8 million in debt extinguishment expenses related to hybrid securities redemption on June 1st, along with increased incentive compensation costs.
We established a new operating unit in the second quarter, with its expenses currently reflected in corporate until it begins operations and is subsequently moved to underwriting expenses.
Stockholders' equity grew by $164 million to roughly $6.6 billion in the quarter, following regular and special dividends totaling $112 million.
Book value per share grew 2.5% in the quarter, while book value per share before dividends increased 4.3%.
Operating cash flow remained robust, with approximately $700 million year-to-date.
I'll now hand it back to Rob.
Let me share a few brief observations before we move on to your Q&A, where we can discuss any topics you'd like.
By almost any standard, the company had an excellent quarter.
From my viewpoint, this success has been building for some time.
Furthermore, there's mounting evidence suggesting more positive developments are on the horizon, which is quite encouraging.
Delving deeper into the market, we're seeing rate increases that surpass our loss trend estimates across major product lines, except for workers' compensation, even as we factor in higher financial inflation.
For workers' compensation, there are early indications that the rate of decline is slowing, although we're closely monitoring wage inflation and its potential impact on the comp economic model.
Rich outlined the top line growth of over 27%, which is substantial.
It's worth noting that in Q2 2020, our top line didn't drastically decrease; we were roughly flat.
So this growth isn't simply a return to normal levels, but a significant increase.
As Richard mentioned regarding the Excess and reinsurance segment, we chose not to participate in a few domestic treaty deals where we felt the rates weren't sufficiently attractive.
Breaking down the 27% overall growth, about a third comes from rate increases, with the remainder from exposure growth, given the rate increase excluding comp was just under 10%.
It's crucial not to over-interpret the rate increase or compare it too closely with previous quarters or years.
Our economic model is multifaceted; we consider available margins in the business.
As margins become more attractive, we may shift focus from pushing for higher rates to prioritizing exposure growth.
While we're still pursuing and achieving rate increases that generally outpace trends (excluding comp), we're also capitalizing on opportunities for exposure growth as margins in much of our portfolio become increasingly appealing.
Regarding the top line, it's worth noting that our specialty businesses, particularly our E&S operations, are experiencing a flood of submissions.
The economy is opening up, which is benefiting us across the board, and the market continues to reassess its appetite.
The reopening economy is having a positive impact on workers' compensation.
We've previously expressed concerns about that product line and its rate trends.
However, our release shows growth in that product line, driven primarily by increased payroll.
This growth reflects the ongoing recovery and health of the US economy.
Shifting focus to the combined ratio, I'd like to add a few observations from my perspective.
The expense ratio of 28.7% is satisfactory, with room for improvement.
As travel and entertainment activities increase, we may see changes in expenses.
The COVID-related expense benefit of about 50 basis points is likely to diminish and eventually disappear.
However, the increasing earned premium should provide more benefits over time, as written premium typically precedes earned premium.
The loss ratio is favorable at 61%, with the ex-cat accident year at 58.8%.
Non-cat property loss activity added just over two points compared to last year's figures.
We experienced a series of fires, which some might attribute to bad luck, but we're investigating to ensure it's not a new trend.
The paid loss ratio was an attractive 44.3.
Regarding our investment portfolio, the duration is 2.4 years, with a book yield also at approximately 2.4.
We remain highly focused on inflation, which we believe is already present.
Some suggest inflation is transient, but regardless of duration, costs are currently higher.
Even if inflation settles at 2.5% to 3%, we believe a 10-year yield at 1.30% or lower is unsustainable in the long term.
We've made significant efforts to restructure aspects of our balance sheet and capital structure, including calling certain securities.
The earnings potential of the business, particularly in 2022 and 2023, will benefit significantly from savings in capital costs.
In summary, it was a very good quarter, and the outlook for the coming quarters and years is even more encouraging.
Our organization is well-positioned to benefit from broader macroeconomic conditions.
Summary:
output:
compname reports qtrly earnings per share $1.27.
qtrly earnings per share $1.27.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Certain risks are mentioned in our SEC filings.
Joining me on today's call are Paul McDermott, Steve Riffee, Taryn Fielder, Drew Hammond, and Grant Montgomery, who hold various executive positions in our company.
I wish you and your loved ones good health and safety.
Yesterday evening, we published our fourth quarter financial results, concluding a year focused on stabilizing our core operations and safeguarding future growth opportunities amid one of the most challenging business environments in recent memory.
As vaccine distribution began towards the end of last year, we are observing increased activity in both our multifamily and commercial portfolios.
For our urban multifamily properties, net applications increased by 30% year-over-year in January, and year-to-date trends already show improved occupancy as we approach the spring leasing season.
Our aim is to increase occupancy to begin reducing concessions and raising rents.
Multifamily occupancy currently exceeds 95%, not including our two rent-controlled properties where we are not prioritizing occupancy gains due to limited rent growth potential in the current market conditions.
Credit performance in our multifamily sector remains exceptionally strong at both urban and suburban properties, consistently outperforming the national average by a significant margin over the past year.
Although multifamily lease rates decreased by 3.6% and 5.7% on a gross and effective blended basis during the fourth quarter, we believe December represented the peak of rental rate pressure, as lease rate changes improved in January month-over-month and concessions decreased.
Moreover, new and renewal lease agreements with February and March start dates indicate continued improvement and effective lease rate growth.
Our renewal rates were robust during the fourth quarter and have maintained that strength into 2021.
Urban and suburban renewal lease rate growth both increased by 90 basis points during the fourth quarter to 1.7% and 3.1% respectively, with these renewal rate increases remaining stable through January.
The ongoing pricing power we're experiencing at our suburban properties, combined with the ability to influence lease terms through concessions, has allowed us to shift more leases to future spring and summer expirations at our newest multifamily assets.
Due to strategic management of our lease expiration schedule, only 20% of our leases expired during the fourth quarter and only 17% expire in the first quarter.
We believe December marked the lowest point for pricing, given the improving year-to-date trends we're observing.
We anticipate that the vaccine-led recovery will lead to a turning point in 2021 heading into 2022.
However, it's too early to determine the exact timing and extent of this benefit in 2021.
About two-thirds of our multifamily leases expire during the stronger spring and summer months, and we expect these leases will benefit from an increased number of vaccinations.
In the meantime, we plan to continue focusing on increasing occupancy and maximizing our retention rates, which continue to surpass our regional average.
Regarding our commercial properties, credit performance continues to hold up very well, as Steve will discuss in more detail.
We anticipate that the majority of our commercial credit losses are behind us.
Our projections suggest that commercial occupancy could increase by nearly 4% by year-end, although there is still too much uncertainty to accurately predict occupancy gains throughout the year.
Nevertheless, our outlook is improving, and we're seeing indications that tenant decision-making is accelerating.
Leasing activity increased significantly in January, and active long-term renewal discussions with major tenants are progressing well.
For instance, in January, we received a signed letter of intent from Sunrise Senior Living to renew their space at Silverline, which currently represents about 1.5% of office revenue.
We also have signed letters of intent with B. Riley and an accredited third party at Arlington Tower.
B. Riley has a termination option in December 2022 and will exercise this option on only one of its three floors, allowing the third party to enter into a sublease for this entire floor through 2022 and then sign a direct lease with us through 2029.
B. Riley will extend the lease for the remainder of their space through 2026.
Additionally, in January, we signed a 45,000 square foot, five-year lease renewal with Giant Food at Takoma Park, which is our second-largest retail tenant and accounts for over 6% of other rental income.
We also signed a 15,000 square foot, 10-year lease renewal with our grocery anchor at Montrose Shopping Center.
These two lease renewals represent approximately 10% of our retail rental income.
As we enter the recovery phase, our office portfolio offers substantial growth potential, given that much of the available space is high-quality, move-in ready, and located in our best assets.
We have a weighted average lease term of about five years, limited near-term lease expirations, and our price points and floor layouts are well-suited for our market.
The average tenant size in our market and the space requirement that sees the most demand is about 4,000 to 6,000 square feet, which aligns with both our median tenant size and the tenant size with the highest demand in the current environment.
We have no exposure to co-working operators, no co-working tenants, and no single-tenant risk.
We continue to see good traction with Space Plus, our proprietary flexible office program that is managed in-house with spaces strategically located throughout our portfolio.
Space Plus represents approximately 3% of our office portfolio and is well-positioned for when decision-making picks up.
Space Plus offers move-in ready, private spaces that allow tenants to control the health and safety of their environment and provides more flexibility than traditional leases.
Furthermore, Space Plus offers premium pricing compared to traditional leases and, on average, has much longer terms than co-working providers achieve, allowing us to capitalize on the increasing demand for flexible office space while maintaining our weighted average lease term and opportunities for future portfolio transformation.
While uncertainty about the timing and pace of reopening persists, the resilience of our region provides relative stability compared to other major metropolitan areas.
Since the start of the pandemic, the Washington Metro area has experienced fewer job losses than other major metropolitan areas and has already regained roughly 180,000 jobs, or 56% of the jobs lost from February to May.
Moreover, these job losses have been largely confined to non-office-using sectors, as office-using sector employment in the Washington Metro market declined only 2% year-over-year in 2020, according to BLS data.
As we progress towards a vaccine-driven recovery, our region has several unique catalysts to accelerate the rebound in demand.
The growing, high-tech labor pool, federal investments in cloud, cyber, and artificial intelligence, as well as affordable office rents, continue to drive information sector leasing activity in Northern Virginia.
Amazon continues to expand its regional office footprint and remains on schedule with HQ2 hiring.
Throughout 2020, the tech sector contributed 36% of total leasing volume and more than 800,000 square feet of occupancy growth in Northern Virginia, according to CBRE.
Tech-driven leasing demand led to positive absorption for the sector in the fourth quarter, and that momentum has continued into January with Microsoft's announcement of a new 180,000 square foot sales headquarters in Rosslyn, adjacent to Arlington Tower and strategically located at the intersection of four bridges, five major road networks, and three metro lines, offering easy access to the Pentagon and Downtown DC.
Government contract awards are expected to remain at record highs in 2021, and the cloud market alone is forecast to grow 9% to 10% annually over the next three years, according to JLL.
Northern Virginia's diversification over the past decade, blending government contracting with direct federal leasing, technology sector growth, investments in higher education, and medicine, has positioned it for a quicker-than-average office market recovery in 2021 and beyond, according to Newmark.
With the arrival of our newly aligned administration, the Washington Metro market is poised to benefit from a surge in activity.
Historically, alignment between the executive and legislative branches has resulted in a higher number of legislative bills passed, with increased lobbying and legal presence in DC to influence, write, and then implement legislation, leading to higher absorption in the DC office market.
The historical correlation between office absorption and years with aligned branches of government is very strong.
Additionally, the election should have a positive effect on our local partner market and may even accelerate a shift back into the city for renters.
Data analyzed by CBRE over the past six Presidential elections indicates that, on average, DC Metro rent growth was more than double the US average during the six months following each election.
Furthermore, market-level data suggests that urban submarkets, which have underperformed suburban areas during this downturn, will likely benefit the most from the boost in activity associated with the Presidential election.
It's worth noting that these catalysts are historically unique to the Washington Metro area compared to other gateway metropolitan markets.
This past year has been eventful and unexpected, and alongside the challenges we have successfully navigated, we continue to make progress on derisking and improving our portfolio.
The COVID-19 crisis has reinforced our dedication to and focus on our capital allocation strategy as we transform WashREIT.
After our Q4 office property sales and including stable income from Trove, multifamily now makes up 53% of our NOI, while office and retail account for 41% and 6% respectively.
I'll begin by examining the balance sheet before discussing our Q4 and full-year financial results and future prospects.
Amid the market uncertainty of 2020, we took measures to bolster our balance sheet and enhance operational flexibility, positioning us better for the pandemic recovery phase.
We ensured ample liquidity at the pandemic's start by securing a $150 million one-year term loan with extension options.
We issued a $350 million 10-year Green Bond at 3.44% in December, using the proceeds to repay the new $150 million term loan and another $150 million term loan due in March 2021.
These actions addressed all our debt maturities through Q4 2022 and extended our maturity schedule.
We fully unencumbered the balance sheet, allowing maximum flexibility as we continue investing in multifamily growth.
We increased our financial flexibility for 2021 through strategic office asset sales and issuing equity via the ATM program, preparing us for future capital allocation when recovery becomes more certain.
At year-end, we had only $42 million outstanding on our fully available $700 million credit line, demonstrating our increased liquidity during the pandemic.
All our covenant ratios remained strong, and we maintained our investment-grade ratings with Moody's (Baa2) and S&P (BBB flat).
Regarding cash collection performance, our multifamily collections continue to excel, surpassing national averages.
We collected 99% of cash and contractual rents in Q4, with January collections following this trend.
We've offered payment deferral programs to pandemic-affected residents, with only about $15,000 in deferred multifamily rent remaining.
Our office and retail collections improved sequentially in Q4, continuing the trend of steady improvement since the pandemic's onset.
We collected 99% of cash rents and over 99% of contractual rents from office tenants in Q4.
Deferred rent for office tenants totaled $1 million as of January 31, with expectations to collect about 75% by year-end.
We collected 94% of retail cash rents in Q4, or approximately 97% excluding deferred rent.
Net deferred rent for retail tenants was $1 million as of January 31, 2021, with expectations to collect 40% by year-end.
Overall, we've deferred a small portion of rent, with the expected cumulative cash NOI impact less than $0.01 per share through year-end 2021.
Regarding financial performance, we reported a net loss of $15.7 million or $0.20 per diluted share for 2020, compared to net income of $383.6 million or $4.75 per diluted share in 2019.
The decrease primarily stems from net gains on asset sales in 2019 versus small losses on sales in 2020.
Core FFO of $1.45 per diluted share for 2020 aligned with our guidance range midpoint.
Year-over-year, core FFO per share declined by $0.26 due to 2019 strategic transactions and pandemic impacts on leasing, parking income, and credit losses.
Overall same-store NOI declined 5.4% year-over-year on a GAAP basis and 4.9% on a cash basis for 2020.
Multifamily same-store NOI fell 0.9% and 1% on GAAP and cash bases for the year, and 7.2% and 7.3% for Q4.
The declines were primarily driven by new lease rate decreases at our urban assets, which comprised our entire same-store portfolio in 2020.
We maintained occupancy at 94.3% in Q4, excluding Trove.
Office same-store NOI declined 7.1% and 6.4% on GAAP and cash bases for the year, and 12.7% for Q4.
These declines resulted from lower parking income, move-outs, increased credit losses, and lease intangibles write-offs related to COVID-19.
Retail same-store NOI decreased by $2.1 million and $1.8 million on GAAP and cash bases for the year, and $0.7 million for Q4.
These declines were primarily due to COVID-19 related credit losses and lease intangibles write-offs.
Commercial credit losses reduced our core FFO by about $0.02 per share this quarter, higher than Q3 but in line with Q2.
The sequential increase was mainly due to lease intangibles write-offs, not indicative of overall portfolio credit performance.
We believe we've addressed apparent credit risks and expect steady improvement in credit performance over the coming year.
In Q4, we signed about 9,000 square feet of new office leases and 22,000 square feet of office renewals.
Office rental rates declined for new leases but increased for renewals.
Lease renewal negotiations increased substantially in December, continuing into January.
We signed about 8,000 square feet of new retail leases and 3,000 square feet of renewals in Q4, achieving rental rate increases.
Since year-end, we've signed about 60,000 square feet of retail leases, representing 10% of our retail portfolio revenues.
Looking ahead, growth prospects have improved with vaccine rollouts, but the timing of the inflection point remains uncertain.
We expect rapid improvement once we reach that point, carrying over into 2022.
While we believe the most disruptive part of the pandemic is behind us, the timing and pace of economic reopening remain uncertain.
We can provide FFO guidance for Q1 but lack sufficient visibility for full-year FFO guidance.
We are providing full-year guidance ranges for financial performance metrics we can forecast with reasonable accuracy.
Though we can't predict the full pandemic impact before the anticipated inflection point, we'll discuss portfolio areas expected to be most responsive and offer the most upside growth potential once the economy recovers.
At the end of the year, the total occupancy rate for the operating portfolio of multifamily properties reached 94.3%, which aligns with expectations and shows a relatively consistent trend since the second quarter's conclusion.
As a positive development, occupancy has increased since the year's end, and leading indicators suggest a steady improvement in occupancy as we approach the peak leasing season.
Occupancy has risen to slightly above 95%, not including our two rent-controlled properties, and we're observing effective lease rates moving in a favorable direction.
Furthermore, there has been a significant year-over-year increase in net application volumes for urban properties.
We previously anticipated substantial multifamily growth in 2020, but this growth is now likely to be postponed until the economic recovery, driven by widespread vaccination, takes hold.
Although we anticipate a seasonal uptick in the second quarter, we expect broader inflections to occur at some point in 2021, extending into 2022.
It's crucial to have a more significant impact on 2022.
We have a five-year plan for value-add renovations ready to resume when conditions improve.
We continue to expect future NOI growth in the Trove, which I'll discuss next.
Regarding our renovation pipeline, we're continuously assessing the health of each submarket for rent growth and renovation potential, and we're encouraged by the metrics we're seeing, particularly in our newly acquired suburban portfolio.
Some submarkets in the metro area are experiencing widening rent gaps between Class A and Class B rents, which is an early indicator of renovation potential, while other submarkets continue to see rent gaps narrowing.
We are tracking these trends and will resume renovations when submarket fundamentals allow for rent increases that deliver appropriate ROI and when we know that capital allocation is accretive.
The final phase of Trove was delivered in the fourth quarter, and leasing momentum continues to build.
Despite the lease-up process being interrupted by social distancing measures that halted on-site tours in April, we've made substantial progress and maintained a monthly lease-up rate above the long-term regional average in an extremely challenging environment.
We achieved breakeven in December and remain on track to reach stabilization in early 2022.
We project Trove to contribute $100,000 of income in the first quarter, increasing each quarter to approximately $1 billion by the fourth quarter of 2021, with significantly higher growth in 2022 compared to 2021 levels.
Shifting focus to commercial properties.
As anticipated, occupancy remained relatively stable through year-end.
While we have only a small amount of signed new leases that haven't yet commenced rent (approximately 20,000 square feet) and about 20,000 square feet of signed LOIs for new leases expected to commence rent during 2021, we have minimal lease expirations in 2021.
Our 2021 office lease expirations represent less than 3% of our overall revenue.
We believe that renewals are likely or we are in negotiations for renewal for over 60% of that space.
We lack sufficient visibility on the timing of the inflection point for new office leasing, but it will be driven by a combination of widespread vaccine distribution, school reopenings, and the general community returning to more normal activities.
When that occurs, it will impact the timing of new lease commencements.
We have a forecast that could result in occupancy growth of up to 4%, but this forecast is at risk if new leasing is delayed.
For instance, that forecast includes slightly over $3 million of new leasing revenue in the fourth quarter.
This would be at risk if the inflection doesn't happen sooner.
Therefore, we're not prepared to provide a guidance range yet without more visibility.
Following two retail renewals executed in January, which represent 10% of our retail NOI, less than 3% of our retail revenue is set to expire in 2021.
Although we're seeing recent signs of increased activity across our office portfolio, one of the most challenging predictions for us is when sentiment will improve and decision-making will accelerate to even higher levels, and when those additional lease commencements will begin.
That said, we believe we are well-positioned once activity improves.
We expect our office portfolio to be highly responsive to the economy reopening.
The majority of our vacancy is in high-quality space, some of which is in move-in ready condition.
Nearly 60% of our current vacancy is in Northern Virginia, where job growth and absorption rates were strongest and where we're seeing the most touring and leasing activity.
Parking revenue improved slightly over the course of 2020, driven by an increase in transient parking, but remains below normal levels.
Compared to other major metropolitan areas, our parking coverage is higher, allowing more of our tenants to choose driving over public transportation.
Our parking garages' capacity could serve over 50% of our building population before the pandemic on average, and we still currently have at least 50% parking capacity available, providing an option for companies wanting to encourage employees to return to the office before sentiment toward public transportation improves.
We are projecting a core FFO per share range of $0.29 to $0.32 for the first quarter.
We anticipate multifamily NOI to range from $20.25 million to $20.75 million, office NOI to range from $17.75 million to $18.5 million, and other NOI of approximately $3 million.
G&A is expected to range from $6 million to $6.25 million; interest expense is projected to range from $10 million to $10.25 million; and development expenditures are anticipated to range from $5 million to $7.5 million.
We expect NOI to reach its lowest point in the first quarter, primarily due to our year-end asset sales.
After the first quarter, barring any major setbacks to the current gradual reopening pace, we anticipate sequential growth throughout the year, driven by the lease-up of the Trove, the benefit of more favorable multifamily leasing seasons following the winter months, the phased resumption of unit renovations, and commercial rent commencements.
Consequently, we expect our full-year results for 2021 to surpass the first quarter annualized results.
Since our previous earnings call, we've sold two office assets and issued approximately 2 million shares through our ATM program at an average price of $23.86 per share to strengthen our balance sheet and position us to further enhance our capital allocation once visibility aligns with opportunities to increase multifamily holdings.
Currently, we don't plan to reinvest those proceeds in the near term.
Thus, we estimate that these two initiatives, net of their interest impact, will further strengthen our balance sheet and reduce full-year 2021 core FFO by approximately $0.09 per share.
For the full year, we project G&A to range from $22.25 million to $23.25 million and interest expense to range from approximately $41.5 million to $42.5 million.
These ranges don't assume any acquisitions are completed during the year.
Additionally, assuming leasing activity and utilization continue to increase and we achieve occupancy growth by year-end, we expect commercial operating expenses to rise by approximately $1 million by the fourth quarter from the first quarter expected range of $11.75 million to $12.25 million.
We believe that during 2021, vaccine distribution should create a positive recovery inflection point.
From that point forward, we should see improvement with more to follow in 2022.
During a challenging and unexpected year, we supported and protected our residents and tenants, stabilized our operating fundamentals, strengthened our balance sheet, and preserved long-term growth opportunities.
While the timing of when we'll reach an inflection remains uncertain, we believe it will occur sometime in the second half of 2021 and that we're positioned for rapid improvement once we reach that point.
Our region has several unique catalysts to accelerate the rebound in demand, including a strong economy and favorable demographics.
Historically, we've observed Washington office absorption increase significantly when the White House and both branches of Congress are aligned with one party, correlating with increased legislation, lobbying, and law implementation.
This presents promising opportunities that we'll be monitoring.
We also expect the apartment market in the region to receive a relative boost compared to other markets over the next six months based on historical patterns following Presidential elections, which should coincide with our strongest seasonal leasing months.
Long-term, our research indicates that we should expect sustained growth in Northern Virginia, driven by government contracting, technology sector growth, and investments in higher education.
While we certainly haven't emerged from the pandemic at this point, we're seeing signs of our multifamily occupancy strengthening, concessions starting to decline, and improvement in effective lease rates, all of which are positive trends heading into our stronger, seasonal leasing months.
Summary:
output: qtrly nareit ffo was $26.7 million, or $0.32 per diluted share.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:We will cover non-GAAP financial metrics, and a reconciliation to GAAP can be found in our online earnings materials.
After excluding a special item with a net after-tax benefit of $32 million, our earnings were $450 million or $0.60 per diluted share.
In Q3, we achieved strong performance across all business units despite challenges from weather disruptions, the ongoing pandemic, and supply chain issues.
Our staff did an outstanding job managing these obstacles, and I'm extremely grateful for their combined efforts and dedication to safely running our operations and maintaining customer service.
Excellent execution throughout the entire supply chain in a challenging environment has led to record profits and cash flow in 2021.
So far this year, we've produced over $3.4 billion in adjusted EBITDA and $2.4 billion in adjusted funds available for distribution.
Let's now examine our third quarter business results.
I'll start by discussing Timberlands, which can be found on pages six to nine of our earnings presentation.
Timberlands profits rose by $20 million in the quarter, including a $32 million gain from the previously announced sale of our North Cascades Timberlands.
Adjusted EBITDA fell by $15 million compared to the previous quarter.
In the Western region, adjusted EBITDA decreased by $13 million compared to Q2.
Western domestic log markets began the quarter favorably despite declining lumber prices and sufficient log supply.
Demand remained high as mills continued to increase log inventories during peak wildfire season, but weakened somewhat in September due to COVID-related disruptions affecting some producers and above-normal finished lumber inventories.
Despite these challenges, our Q3 domestic sales realizations were similar to Q2, driven by strong domestic log prices in July and August.
Salvage operations from the 2020 Oregon wildfires continued in the third quarter.
Our teams have done an exceptional job managing these salvage efforts over the past year.
We've completed about 80% of our planned salvage harvest to date and expect to finish most of this work by year-end.
As anticipated, during the warmer and drier summer months, we shifted to higher elevation and more costly operations.
Although we experienced minimal wildfire damage to our timberlands, active fires and dry conditions across the region limited our harvest activity in the quarter, especially in Oregon.
Consequently, our fee harvest and domestic sales volumes were slightly lower in Q3, and per unit log and haul costs increased.
Regarding our export markets, demand for our logs in Japan remained strong in Q3.
Lumber imports from Europe to Japan continue to be limited by the ongoing global shipping container shortage.
This situation is increasing market share for our customers and creating robust demand for our logs.
As a result, our Japanese log sales realizations moderately increased compared to Q2, and sales volumes were similar.
In China, demand for our logs remained favorable in the quarter despite seasonally lower consumption, COVID impacts on construction activity, and other supply chain disruptions.
Imports of lumber and logs into China continue to be constrained by global shipping container availability and the ban on Australian logs.
Consequently, sales realizations for our China export logs moderately increased compared to Q2, but were outweighed by higher ocean freight rates.
Sales volumes to China were comparable to Q2.
In the Southern region, adjusted EBITDA for timberlands was similar to Q2.
Southern sawlog and fiber markets continued to strengthen as log supply was limited and mill inventories remained low due to ongoing wet conditions and significant weather events.
As a result, our sales realizations were slightly higher than Q2.
Fee harvest and sales volumes increased slightly in Q3, but fell below our planned activity level due to persistent wet weather and operational disruptions from Hurricane Ida.
Per unit log and haul costs increased slightly in the quarter, as did forestry and road costs.
On the export side, we continue to see growing demand for our Southern logs.
Our export log pricing increased substantially in Q3, but volumes were lower than Q2 as we continue to face challenges related to container availability and increased freight rates.
In the Northern region, adjusted EBITDA decreased slightly compared to Q2.
Sales volumes were significantly higher following spring breakup conditions, though sales realizations were lower due to mix.
Shifting to Real Estate, Energy and Natural Resources on pages 10 and 11, this segment contributed $45 million to Q3 earnings and $60 million to adjusted EBITDA.
Q3 adjusted EBITDA was $31 million lower than Q2 due to timing of transactions, but comparable to the same quarter last year.
Similar to 2020, our 2021 real estate sales activity has been heavily concentrated in the first half of the year.
Q3 earnings more than doubled compared to Q3 2020 due to the mix of properties sold.
We continue to take advantage of strong demand for HBU properties, resulting in high-value transactions with significant premiums to timber value.
Looking at Wood Products, pages 12 through 14, earnings and adjusted EBITDA decreased by about 60% compared to the previous quarter as lumber and OSB pricing declined substantially from record levels earlier in the year before stabilizing later in the quarter.
Additionally, weather events in the U.S. South, including Hurricane Ida, caused temporary downtime and lost production in our lumber business.
These issues, combined with COVID-related staffing disruptions, further aggravated transportation challenges in the region.
Despite these obstacles, our teams performed well and delivered strong results.
Our EWP business set a new quarterly EBITDA record in Q3, and the overall Wood Products segment has achieved year-to-date adjusted EBITDA of more than $2.8 billion.
The timber industry entered the third quarter with high inventory levels at home improvement stores and wood treatment facilities due to reduced DIY home repair and renovation activities.
Consequently, prices continued to fall in July and much of August.
The market started to recover later in the quarter as retailers and treatment facilities depleted excess stock and consumer spending on DIY projects increased after Labor Day.
This coincided with steady demand from new home construction and professional repair and remodeling activities, which remained strong throughout the third quarter.
The lumber division's adjusted EBITDA fell by $686 million compared to the previous quarter.
Our sales prices dropped by 52% in the third quarter, while the framing lumber composite price decreased by 61%.
We experienced a moderate increase in sales volume during the third quarter, and log costs rose slightly, mainly for Canadian logs.
The OSB market significantly weakened at the beginning of the third quarter due to a decline in DIY repair and remodeling activities.
This situation led to reduced sales and higher inventory levels at home improvement stores.
As a consequence, we saw a rapid decrease in prices from the record highs reached in July.
Pricing then stabilized above the historical average in August, as demand from robust new home construction continued and the market faced supply limitations due to ongoing resin availability and transportation issues.
This situation, along with a late-quarter improvement in DIY repair and remodel demand, caused prices to gradually increase through September.
The OSB division's adjusted EBITDA decreased by $128 million compared to the second quarter.
Our sales prices fell by 24% in the third quarter, while the OSB composite price dropped by 43%.
This relative outperformance was primarily due to our higher proportion of premium OSB products.
Our sales and production volumes improved slightly in the third quarter due to less downtime for scheduled maintenance.
Unit manufacturing costs increased marginally, mainly due to higher resin expenses.
Engineered Wood Products' adjusted EBITDA rose by $23 million compared to the second quarter, a 43% improvement.
Sales prices improved significantly for most products, and we continue to benefit from previously announced price increases for solid section and I-joist products.
This was partially offset by higher raw material costs for OSB webstock, resin, and veneer.
Sales and production volumes were moderately lower for most products due to planned annual maintenance during the quarter.
In the Distribution segment, adjusted EBITDA fell by $53 million compared to the second quarter.
Despite lower sales volumes for most products and significantly reduced margins resulting from the commodity price correction, our teams performed exceptionally well, delivering $22 million of adjusted EBITDA in the third quarter.
I'll start with our key financial items, which are summarized on page 16.
We generated $659 million in operating cash flow during the third quarter, bringing our year-to-date total to nearly $2.7 billion, our highest year-to-date operating cash flows on record.
Adjusted funds available for distribution (adjusted FAD) for the year-to-date third quarter 2021 totaled over $2.4 billion, as shown on page 17.
Year-to-date, we have returned $382 million to our shareholders through our quarterly base dividend payments, and we will supplement the base dividend annually with an additional cash return to achieve the targeted 75% to 80% of adjusted FAD.
This year, we plan to accomplish this entirely through a variable supplemental cash dividend.
In future years, we may also use opportunistic share repurchases for a portion of this cash return.
The supplemental dividend is typically paid in the first quarter of each year based on the previous year's cash flow.
However, due to the record year-to-date performance, we accelerated a portion of the supplemental dividend by returning $375 million to our shareholders through a previously announced $0.50 per share interim supplemental dividend earlier this month.
We anticipate returning the remaining portion of the supplemental dividend with a substantial payment in the first quarter of 2022.
During the third quarter, we also returned $26 million to shareholders through share repurchases.
Additionally, as previously announced, we authorized a new $1 billion share repurchase program.
As always, we will consider repurchasing shares opportunistically when we believe it will create shareholder value.
Regarding the balance sheet, we ended the quarter with approximately $2.3 billion in cash and just under $5.3 billion in debt.
After the quarter ended, we repaid our $150 million 9% note at maturity, reducing our debt balance to $5.1 billion.
Following this repayment, we have no additional maturities until 2023.
Looking ahead, key outlook items for the fourth quarter are presented on page 18.
In our Timberlands business, we expect fourth quarter earnings and adjusted EBITDA to be similar to the third quarter.
Focusing on our Western Timberland operations, although domestic log inventories were higher than normal at the end of the third quarter, demand for finished lumber and logs has improved following a brief downturn in September.
We anticipate this trend continuing for most of the fourth quarter.
Consequently, we expect our domestic sales prices to improve from the lower levels experienced in September.
For the fourth quarter, we anticipate our average domestic sales prices to be moderately lower than the elevated third quarter levels.
As Devin mentioned, we have made significant progress in our salvage operations in Oregon and expect our salvage volumes to decrease in the fourth quarter.
As a result, we expect fourth quarter fee harvest volumes to be moderately higher with lower per unit log and transportation costs.
Regarding export markets, log demand in Japan remains favorable.
We anticipate our fourth quarter sales prices to be comparable to the elevated third quarter levels, partially offset by moderately lower sales volumes due to vessel timing.
In China, despite high log inventories at ports, demand for our logs is expected to remain favorable as construction activity increases seasonally and imports of lumber and logs continue to be limited from other countries.
We anticipate our fourth quarter sales volumes will exceed those of the third quarter, though this may be partially counteracted by slightly reduced sales prices.
High shipping expenses and labor costs for loading vessels continue to pose challenges.
Weather conditions in the South improved at the beginning of the fourth quarter.
We expect a slight increase in fee harvest volumes compared to the third quarter.
Mills are actively working to replenish low inventories due to ongoing wet conditions and reduced log availability, leading to sustained strong log demand.
We predict slightly higher sales prices in the fourth quarter as a result.
This increase is expected to be balanced out by marginally higher per unit log and transportation costs, as well as moderately increased forestry and road expenses, as some planned third-quarter activities were postponed due to weather disruptions.
Due to persistent wet conditions in 2021 and significant weather events in the third quarter, we now expect full-year Southern fee harvest volumes to be similar to those of 2020.
In the North, we anticipate slightly lower sales prices due to mix changes and slightly reduced fee harvest volumes compared to the third quarter.
Shifting focus to our Real Estate, Energy and Natural Resources division.
Fourth quarter earnings and adjusted EBITDA are expected to be considerably lower than the third quarter due to the timing of transactions.
We maintain our prediction that full-year 2021 adjusted EBITDA will be around $290 million, and we now expect the basis as a percentage of real estate sales to be approximately 25% to 30% for the entire year.
For our Wood Products division, new residential construction activity remains robust, and demand from the repair and remodel sector continues to grow following the improvement in do-it-yourself activity in September.
This trend is expected to persist for most of the quarter before seasonally weakening as winter approaches.
Disregarding changes in average sales prices for lumber and oriented strand board, we expect fourth quarter earnings and adjusted EBITDA to surpass those of the third quarter.
For lumber, production volumes are anticipated to be similar to the third quarter.
However, we expect our sales volumes to be slightly lower due to the inventory reduction experienced in the third quarter.
We anticipate this will be offset by slightly reduced log costs and improved unit manufacturing expenses.
As indicated on page 19, our current and quarter-to-date prices for lumber are slightly higher than the third quarter average.
For oriented strand board, we anticipate moderately higher sales volumes and improved unit manufacturing costs, primarily due to less downtime for planned maintenance during the fourth quarter.
We expect this will be partially counterbalanced by moderately higher fiber costs.
As shown on page 19, our current and quarter-to-date prices for oriented strand board are significantly lower than the third quarter average, but still elevated compared to historical norms.
For engineered wood products, we expect sales prices for solid section and I-joist products to remain stable, while prices for plywood will decrease.
We anticipate this will be more than offset by significantly lower raw material costs, primarily for OSB webstock.
For our distribution business, we're expecting higher adjusted EBITDA in the fourth quarter, mainly due to improved commodity margins, partially offset by seasonally lower sales volumes.
I'll conclude with a few additional comments on our total company financial items.
We now expect our full-year capital expenditures to be slightly below our previous guidance of $460 million due to supply chain and contract labor constraints, with $15 million to $25 million potentially at risk.
The $90 million tax refund associated with our 2018 pension contribution was approved during the second quarter.
However, we are still awaiting the refund.
We anticipate receiving it by the end of the fourth quarter of 2021.
Excluding this refund, we now expect our full-year cash taxes to be slightly lower than tax expenses.
Despite a slight decrease from the previous quarter, U.S. housing activity remained strong in the third quarter, with total housing starts and permits averaging around 1.6 million units on a seasonally adjusted basis.
Although housing starts in 2021 continue at a robust pace, the time between starts and completions has extended as homebuilders face ongoing supply chain and labor availability challenges.
Despite these obstacles, our customers inform us that they continue to expect strong demand for new home construction for the remainder of 2021.
The latest new home sales figures released earlier this week further support our positive view on the current state of the housing market.
Given favorable long-term demand fundamentals, including a decade of underbuilding and positive demographics, we maintain an optimistic outlook on U.S. housing activity well into the future.
Regarding repair and remodel, we've continued to see strength in large professional projects throughout 2021 and expect that to persist for the rest of the year and into 2022.
While we did observe some softening in the smaller do-it-yourself segment during the summer, demand has improved significantly since Labor Day, and we've continued to see strong demand from the repair and remodel segment through October.
Overall, we maintain a favorable long-term outlook for repair and remodel activity, supported by numerous demand drivers, including an aging housing stock, rising home equity, and low interest rates.
Lastly, we hope you had the opportunity to participate in our virtual Investor Day on September 22, where we outlined a series of multiyear strategic growth targets, including expanding our Timberlands portfolio, developing our new Natural Climate Solutions business, and organically growing our lumber business.
We also announced several capital allocation actions and enhanced our ESG leadership by releasing our carbon record and announcing new greenhouse gas emission reduction targets.
Our strategy, as outlined at Investor Day, is straightforward.
We aim to increase the value of our portfolio, improve our cash flows, build on our competitive advantage in the marketplace, and establish Weyerhaeuser as a premier ESG investment opportunity.
These actions will ensure that we generate superior returns for our investors, including returning significant amounts of cash to shareholders through a growing base dividend, a variable supplemental dividend, and opportunistic share repurchases, all while continuing to invest in our businesses and maintain an appropriate capital structure.
We're enthusiastic about Weyerhaeuser's future and are well-positioned to capitalize on strong macro trends driving continued growth and demand for our products and new opportunities for our businesses.
We greatly appreciate Beth's contributions to our IR function and look forward to her next opportunity at the company.
With Beth's transition, Andy Taylor has taken over the lead role of our Investor Relations program.
Andy joined Weyerhaeuser in October of last year after an 18-year career in the energy industry, where he served in numerous leadership roles, including Investor Relations.
He's been a valuable addition to the Weyerhaeuser team, and we're excited to have him take on this new role.
Summary:
output:
q3 sales $2.3 billion.
q3 earnings per share $0.60 excluding items.
expects q4 earnings and adjusted ebitda will be comparable to q3 for timberlands.
