sees q4 earnings and adjusted ebitda will be higher than q3 for wood products.
sees q4 earnings, adjusted ebitda significantly lower than q3 due to timing of transactions for real estate, energy & natural resources.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:We eagerly anticipate discussing our exceptional third quarter results, recent changes to our capital allocation priorities, and providing an update on our strategic progress.
Accompanying me today are Dave Burritt, U.S. Steel's President and CEO; Christie Breves, Senior Vice President and CFO; and Rich Fruehauf, Senior Vice President and Chief Strategy and Sustainability Officer.
I'll now hand over the call to U.S. Steel President and CEO, Dave Burritt, who will begin with slide four.
As Kevin mentioned, we achieved unprecedented results in the third quarter, including record-breaking net earnings, EBITDA, EBITDA margin, and quality and reliability metrics.
Our outstanding performance in the third quarter and throughout 2021 has significantly transformed our operations and showcases our progress towards excellence.
By the end of the year, we will have restructured our balance sheet by paying off over $3 billion in debt, achieving our deleveraging goal ahead of schedule.
We anticipate having approximately $5 billion in total liquidity, establishing a solid foundation to confidently implement our strategy and invest in our competitive advantages, positioning us for another strong year in 2022.
Our improved balance sheet, ability to fund crucial strategic investments, and continued optimism about our business gives us confidence to return capital to shareholders while implementing the next phase of our Best for All strategy.
We believe the market is significantly undervaluing our progress and the value our strategy is creating, making now the ideal time to adopt a more balanced approach to capital allocation.
Our strategy truly benefits everyone, including our shareholders.
We're delivering strong results year-to-date.
A continued positive outlook for 2022 and beyond, along with expectations of an ongoing super cycle, allow us to accelerate the next phase of our strategy execution while beginning to reward shareholders with direct returns.
Our primary challenges remain reducing our capital and carbon intensity.
Investments in mini mill steelmaking, such as constructing a second mini mill while investing in our competitive advantages, can help us achieve these goals and reposition the company for the future.
The solution involves moving towards a more balanced capital allocation strategy by successfully executing our Best for All strategy, including a second mini mill and an electrical steel line and coating line at Big River Steel.
We are swiftly progressing on our path forward by expanding our competitive advantages through strategic investments that help us achieve our objectives aligned with long-term value creation, improved through-cycle earnings and cash flow, and reduced capital and carbon intensity.
Whether considering next year or our ability to build long-term value, we believe investors are undervaluing our progress and potential.
Our customers, however, are noticing the transformation taking place at U.S. Steel and the importance of a regional supply chain.
Our industry-leading finishing line capabilities are enhancing our value proposition, and customers are excited about the opportunities we are creating together.
Whether it's advanced high-strength steels, differentiated electrical steels, or green and sustainable steels, discussions with customers are shifting from transactional to strategic.
We continue to create long-term value with customers by prioritizing innovation, differentiation, and strategic goals, and we look forward to building deeper relationships that unlock U.S. Steel's value for our customers and provide them with a reliable regional supply chain.
Slide six further highlights our progress and performance.
We are encouraged by our record-setting performance, which is outpacing even the records achieved by direct competitors.
However, there is still room for improvement.
As we've stated, our goal is to be the best steel competitor.
While there are certainly more opportunities ahead, we've made significant progress quickly.
At U.S. Steel, we always prioritize safety, and I'm pleased with our team for continuing to emphasize safety and embodying our steel principles daily.
Regarding our margin performance, our enterprise EBITDA margin reflects the disciplined, value-focused approach we've taken to our footprint.
With nearly $6 billion in quarterly revenue, our earnings quality demonstrates a business model increasingly built on capability and cost differentiation.
From our iron ore advantage to our integrated assets, and from the newest mini mill in the country to the most efficient mill in Eastern Europe, our diversified footprint is extracting significant value from today's stronger for longer market.
While competition isn't standing still, the actions we've taken over recent years to invest in our assets, streamline our footprint, and add capabilities have created significant value, leading to outperformance versus peers this quarter.
Our mini mill performance continues to lead the industry, further widening its advantage over other mini mill producers.
Our position as a mini mill leader creates the perfect platform for high-return investments in capabilities that expand our margins, reduce our carbon and capital intensity, and enhance our customer value proposition for sustainable green steel solutions.
These investments continue to be supported by strong liquidity, and we are moving forward with investments that create enduring value while rewarding stockholders for our progress so far.
Slide seven expands on what makes U.S. Steel unique and why Best for All will continue to grow our competitive advantages.
We are investing to improve, not just expand, and are enhancing our three competitive advantages that differentiate us from competitors.
These advantages are: low-cost iron ore, lower greenhouse gas emission mini mill steelmaking, and best-in-class finishing capabilities.
These competitive advantages are built on a foundation of research and innovation and deep customer relationships.
We are pleased to report the first step in our metallic strategy, which shifts our iron ore advantage in Minnesota towards our growing fleet of EAFs.
We are finalizing an agreement with a strategic partner to produce up to 500,000 tons of pig iron annually at Gary Works.
Under the proposed deal, our potential partner would fund, install, and operate pig iron production assets, which we would supply with excess liquid iron production.
The proposed collaboration would improve Big River Steel's cost structure by insourcing valuable metallics while boosting blast furnace efficiency at Gary Works.
Pig iron production at Gary is expected to commence in early 2023, with permitting already underway.
This strategy efficiently expands our iron ore advantage to mini mills, and we're exploring additional ways to derive more value from iron ore.
Additional information about our investment in mini mill number two is provided on slide nine.
We recently began the process of selecting a site for constructing a new cutting-edge mini mill.
This new facility will offer specialized steelmaking supported by comprehensive finishing capabilities, including advanced high-strength steel galvanizing, hot-rolled galvanizing, painting, and slitting.
We're increasing our mini mill steelmaking capacity as we shift towards sustainable, lower-emission steel production.
This investment allows us to provide customers with more of the environmentally friendly steel they desire from like-minded partners such as U.S. Steel.
We're currently submitting permits in multiple states and aim to start construction as early as the first half of 2022.
The same experienced team that built Phase 2A of Big River Steel ahead of schedule, under budget, and fully operational in record time will construct mini mill number two.
We anticipate the value-added capabilities of mini mill number two will generate approximately $650 million in additional EBITDA contribution once fully operational.
We also announced plans yesterday to construct a new coating line at Big River Steel.
Details about this new line are available on slide 10.
This line will have an annual capacity of 325,000 tons and will sustainably produce both Galvalume and galvanized products.
We expect this investment to add another $60 million in annual run-rate EBITDA to Big River's already industry-leading results.
The line is projected to produce a mix of 75% Galvalume and 25% hot-dip galvanizing.
Galvalume capabilities create opportunities to target the higher-value construction market, including exposed building panels.
Hot-dip galvanizing capabilities create additional opportunities to serve the appliance, automotive, and construction markets.
Our investments at Big River are natural extensions of the campus and further utilize the state-of-the-art capabilities of the facility as we provide customers with sustainable steels to help meet their own decarbonization goals.
As we continue to showcase our industry-leading position at Big River, we're excited to expand our mini mill footprint, invest in downstream capabilities, and further enhance the commercial mix of our business model.
Our progress in 2021 is undeniable.
We've transformed our balance sheet over the past several quarters.
At the beginning of the year, when we finalized the Big River Steel acquisition, we had $7 billion in debt and expect to end the year with $3.9 billion.
We've extended the maturity profile and anticipate next year's run-rate cash interest expense to be approximately $225 million.
Our pension plan is overfunded, a favorable position that others in our industry are far from achieving.
We are in a clear position of strength.
While we'll continue to consider further deleveraging as debt becomes callable, we're confident that this level of debt puts us in a sustainable and manageable position to support investments in our business.
We continue to believe that the greatest source of long-term value creation comes from investing in expanding competitive advantages that reshape our earnings profile and reduce our capital and carbon intensity.
Our cash and liquidity position more than supports these high-return projects and allows us to execute with confidence.
Given the undeniable progress we've seen over the past several quarters, we are announcing enhancements to our capital allocation priorities that begin to directly reward stockholders with the improvements we've made to the business.
We believe the market is not fully valuing our expected strong performance in 2022 and has not yet recognized the long-term value creation potential of our Best for All strategy.
Our strong financial performance and the significant returns we believe we can generate by buying our own stock is the reason we are accelerating direct returns to stockholders.
Reinstating the $0.05 per share quarterly dividend and quickly implementing a $300 million stock buyback demonstrates our commitment to ensuring our strategy is indeed best for all.
We aim to make direct returns an enduring part of our capital allocation strategy, and we believe there are catalysts that could drive additional buybacks in the future.
Besides additional free cash flow generation, we believe there are near-term opportunities to divest non-core assets, primarily real estate, which could further accelerate or increase future authorizations.
Additionally, Stelco's option to acquire 25% of Minntac remains valid through January 2027 and presents an opportunity to return up to $500 million of additional capital to stockholders.
Christie will now provide details about our quarterly performance before I share some thoughts on 2022.
Let's begin with slide 12.
As Dave mentioned earlier, the third quarter was a record-breaking period.
We achieved adjusted EBITDA and EBITDA margin of over $2 billion and 34%, respectively.
This represents a nearly $750 million or 58% increase compared to the second quarter.
Adjusted earnings per share for the quarter was $5.36 per diluted share.
We also generated approximately $1.3 billion in free cash flow during the quarter, including a $400 million investment in working capital.
We anticipate another quarter of robust cash flow generation in Q4.
Allow me to elaborate on some crucial aspects of the balance sheet.
Since the start of the year, we've paid off about $2.7 billion in debt and anticipate ending the year with $3.9 billion in debt on the balance sheet, an amount we believe is manageable and supports our business investments.
The quarter ended with a net debt to last 12 months EBITDA ratio of 0.6, and we expect to finish the year at 0.2.
With an improved balance sheet, 80% of our remaining debt due in 2029 or later, and a fully funded pension plan, we are in a strong position for future value creation.
Now, let's discuss individual segments and fourth quarter expectations.
Our Flat-Rolled segment achieved record EBITDA and EBITDA margin of over $1.1 billion and 32%, respectively.
This represents about a 60% improvement compared to Q2.
The positive impact of higher selling prices through our contract structure in Q3 is likely to continue into Q4.
We anticipate lower volumes due to our planned blast furnace outage at Gary Works and higher energy costs to offset this.
We currently predict Q4 Flat-rolled EBITDA to be close to our record Q3 performance.
Our mini mill segment also set records for EBITDA and EBITDA margin.
Q3 EBITDA was $464 million, or an industry-leading 42% EBITDA margin.
Increased prices continued to be reflected in the segment results, partially counterbalanced by higher scrap and other metallics costs.
In Q4, we expect higher prices to continue impacting the segments, mainly through monthly contracts.
We currently anticipate Q4 to be another record for our mini mill segment, potentially surpassing $500 million in EBITDA.
USSK also achieved record EBITDA and EBITDA margin in Q3.
EBITDA reached $418 million, or a 33% EBITDA margin.
A 60-day outage is planned for the number one blast furnace starting in November through year-end.
This will remove about 250,000 tons of steel equivalent capacity from the market in Q4.
Operational challenges due to the planned outage, slightly lower shipments, and changes in European pricing dynamics are expected to result in lower Q4 EBITDA compared to Q3.
I'd like to commend the USSK team for securing Slovakia's first revolving credit facility with sustainability-related performance targets.
The new â¬300 million unsecured sustainability-linked credit agreement reinforces our commitment to profitable sustainable steelmaking solutions and replaced the previous â¬460 million credit facility.
Our Tubular segment reported similar results quarter-over-quarter.
Improved commercial performance was largely offset by higher scrap and energy costs and continued high import levels.
Imports still account for roughly half of the U.S. tubular market.
Earlier this month, we and the USW filed new OCTG trade cases.
We expect Q4 performance to be similar to Q3, as higher selling prices are offset by elevated scrap costs for the Fairfield EAF and ongoing high import levels.
We anticipate Q4 enterprise earnings to continue reflecting the strong market conditions as we end the year, and we currently believe our Q4 results will be close to our record Q3 performance.
We're entering 2022 in an excellent position to create value for stockholders and deliver value to customers.
We're conducting a thorough contract process with customers, often starting discussions 90 days earlier than usual.
Our strategy is paying off.
Based on the forward curve, which we consider a pessimistic view of spot prices, we fully expect average selling prices to be higher in 2022 than 2021 for our Flat-rolled segment.
We've also responded to customer feedback and in some cases, signed agreements beyond 12 months.
This creates longer-term benefits and supply continuity while fostering collaborative product development opportunities to address their most challenging issues.
We continue discussions on commercial terms beyond just price.
We're leveraging strong interest in advanced high-strength steels, our planned NGL electrical steel line, and other future sustainable steel offerings from U.S. Steel.
Customers value domestic supply chains, and we value their partnership.
We're pleased to hear from multiple auto customers that the worst of the chip shortage may be behind us.
They're starting to add to Q4 and Q1 build schedules and indicating increased usage rates as early as next week.
Kevin, let's move on to the Q&A session.
We request that each person limit themselves to one question and a follow-up to ensure everyone has a chance to ask a question.
Summary:
output: q3 adjusted earnings per share $5.36.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Kristin Peck, our CEO, and Glenn David, our CFO, are with me today.
Our discussion will include references to non-GAAP financial measures.
We will also mention operational results that don't account for foreign exchange impact.
I trust you and your family are staying safe as we all continue to deal with the COVID-19 crisis.
Despite the uncertainties surrounding the COVID-19 situation, we exceeded expectations in the second quarter.
Our revenue grew by 4% operationally, with 6% growth in the U.S. and 3% internationally.
Our business performance is primarily driven by companion animal products, which saw 13% operational growth, while livestock products decreased by 5%.
In the second quarter, our adjusted net income grew by 4% operationally.
We've developed a robust companion animal portfolio in recent years through our in-house innovation.
These offerings have helped mitigate some of the more severe challenges currently faced in the livestock market.
Our newly introduced parasiticides, Simparica Trio, ProHeart 12 and Revolution Plus, along with our key dermatology products Apoquel and Cytopoint, provide a strong foundation that has maintained its performance this year.
We continue to be impressed by the performance of Simparica Trio, our new triple-combination parasiticide for dogs, as well as the overall strength of the Simparica line.
Glenn will provide more information in his presentation.
Our ongoing commitment to meaningful innovation and our diverse portfolio across species, products, and regions remain key advantages for Zoetis during economic uncertainty.
We've also observed that the essential nature of animal health has played a crucial role in the resilience of our business and industry during this time.
Regarding COVID-19, our veterinary and producer clients are facing increased pressure to provide crucial animal care and maintain a stable global food supply, and we're fortunate to be able to support them in this mission.
We prioritize the safety of our employees and customers during this pandemic, and we're pleased with our team's ability to maintain productivity despite safety measures and social distancing adjustments at our facilities, as well as the continued use of remote work arrangements for most of our staff.
Our field teams have resumed customer meetings in many areas based on local guidelines and practices.
We monitor and adjust these plans daily based on local feedback and changes in markets that may be experiencing increased COVID-19 cases.
Our teams are eager to reconnect with customers in person, but we're also incorporating the lessons learned from effective online interactions, webinars, and e-commerce to improve our sales and support methods.
Zoetis has maintained a reliable supply of essential medicines, vaccines, and diagnostics for our customers and distributors in over 100 markets worldwide.
Our research and development programs remain on schedule in terms of filings, clinical trials, and interactions with regulatory agencies.
We're confident in the progress of regulatory reviews for our monoclonal antibody candidates for pain in cats and dogs.
Our submissions are proceeding as expected.
This year continues to present unprecedented challenges due to COVID-19 and related trends affecting our customers.
However, the underlying demand for healthy pets and a reliable protein source remains fundamental to the global economy.
In the second quarter, we benefited from U.S. veterinary clinics recovering from the COVID-19 impact much faster than anticipated.
Veterinary practices in the U.S. quickly adapted to curbside visits and mobile clinics to provide essential care and maintain client relationships.
We also witnessed an increase in companion animal product sales through e-commerce channels due to lockdowns in many states.
Veterinarians and pet owners are embracing online options more readily as a means to fill prescriptions for parasiticides and other medications.
We've also noticed that people are spending more time at home with their pets.
They may be observing conditions like itchiness or pain that previously went unnoticed.
As a result, we're seeing an increase in spending per visit at U.S. clinics.
Outside the U.S., companion animal veterinary clinic performance has met expectations despite significant variations between markets based on local conditions.
For Zoetis, we anticipate our overall revenue growth for the rest of the year will be primarily driven by companion animal products, particularly our parasiticides and key dermatology portfolio.
We plan to continue investing in direct-to-consumer advertising and digital marketing to support these products.
The livestock sector presents a very different scenario and remains significantly challenged by the pandemic, especially in the U.S. Producers are adapting to new market demands and distribution needs, shifting from foodservice and restaurant channels to more grocery and retail channels, while also managing ongoing labor, safety, and trade issues.
As anticipated, U.S. livestock saw a significant decline in the second quarter, and we expect this to remain a challenge for the rest of the year.
The speed at which foodservice and restaurant demand returns, along with increased export opportunities, will be the most crucial factors in the recovery of U.S. livestock producers.
Internationally, livestock grew and performed as expected across various markets.
We saw very positive results in places like China, which is further along in its COVID-19 recovery, but we'll be watching closely to see how Latin America and markets like Brazil perform in the remainder of the year due to COVID.
Looking ahead, we remain focused on advancing our five key priorities to ensure long-term success: driving innovative growth, enhancing customer experience, leading in digital and data analytics, cultivating a high-performing organization, and championing a healthier, more sustainable future.
We've continued to make significant investments in products and innovations across the continuum of care, from prediction and prevention to detection and treatment of disease.
Supporting successful launches, as well as new life cycle innovations and expansions of major products into new markets, continue to be the cornerstones of our durable and steady performance.
In the second quarter, we expanded major vaccine franchises with the approval of Vanguard B Oral for dogs in Brazil and our Fostera Gold PCV MH and Fostera Gold PCVMetastim vaccines for pigs in Australia.
We continue to enhance our diagnostic and digital capabilities, building upon recent acquisitions in point-of-care and reference laboratories, as well as additional investments.
We intend to introduce a new diagnostic platform for veterinary care called VetScan Imagyst in the third quarter.
We are thrilled about the potential of this groundbreaking innovation, which will be the pioneering system to bring clinical pathology directly to the point of care.
This innovative multipurpose platform combines image recognition technology, algorithms, and cloud-based AI to provide swift testing results in clinics.
Its initial application will be for analyzing fecal samples to detect parasites, enabling quick testing and treatment of pets during the same visit.
We will provide more information in the upcoming weeks as we prepare for a worldwide launch.
We also consider diagnostics to play a crucial role in the comprehensive care of fish.
In the second quarter, we acquired Fish Vet Group to expand our aquaculture portfolio with additional diagnostic tools, including environmental testing, which is vital for fish farming.
At Zoetis, our main focus on high-performing teams is linked to fostering a culture where all employees feel appreciated and included, reflected in our dedication to promoting inclusion, diversity, and equity throughout our organization.
Our leadership and Board are committed to being catalysts for positive change globally to promote greater equity and inclusion.
We have allocated financial resources and personnel to achieve this goal.
I'll now pass it over to Glenn, who will discuss our second quarter results and revised guidance for the entire year.
I hope everyone is well, in good health, and adjusting to what is undoubtedly an unprecedented period for us all.
Today, I will offer additional insights on our Q2 financial performance, provide an update on our liquidity status, and review our improved full-year 2020 forecast.
Let's start with the second quarter results.
We achieved revenue of $1.5 billion, which remained flat on a reported basis but grew 4% operationally.
Adjusted net income of $427 million decreased 2% on a reported basis but increased 4% operationally.
Foreign exchange had a negative impact of 4% on revenue in the quarter.
This was primarily due to the strengthening of the U.S. dollar against the Brazilian real, Australian dollar, Mexican peso, and euro.
The 4% operational revenue growth was driven by 2% price and 2% volume increases.
The 2% volume growth includes 3% from new products, 3% from key dermatology products, 1% from acquisitions, and a 5% decline in other in-line products.
Companion animal products led species growth, increasing 13% operationally, while livestock declined 5% operationally.
Companion animal performance was driven by our parasiticide portfolio, including sales of Simparica Trio in the U.S., Canada, and certain European markets, as well as our key dermatology products, Apoquel and Cytopoint.
Revenue from the acquisition of Platinum Performance and its nutritional products, acquired in the second half of 2019, drove growth in the equine sector.
Livestock declines in the quarter were due to challenges in our U.S. livestock portfolio.
Supply chain disruptions caused by reduced animal processing capacity and shifts in consumer demand from restaurants and foodservice to grocery stores affected our customers' purchasing decisions.
This decline was partially offset by strong international performance with growth in swine, fish, and poultry.
New products contributed 3% to overall growth in the quarter, driven by Simparica Trio, ProHeart 12, Revolution Plus, and our Alpha Flux parasiticide for salmon in Chile.
We remain optimistic about the launch of Simparica Trio and are reaffirming the range of $100 million to $125 million for full-year incremental revenue.
Trio has been more robust, and cannibalization of Simparica has been less than anticipated.
Global sales of our key dermatology portfolio reached $224 million in the quarter, growing 24% operationally and contributing 3% to overall revenue growth.
Recent acquisitions contributed 1% growth this quarter, including Platinum Performance and our reference lab expansion strategy.
Now let's examine the revenue growth by segment for the quarter.
U.S. revenue increased by 6%, with companion animal products growing 19% and livestock products declining by 18%.
Companion animal growth in the quarter was driven by sales of the Simparica franchise, our key dermatology products, and the impact of recent acquisitions.
U.S. key dermatology sales were $160 million for the quarter, growing 26%.
The continued strength of this portfolio was driven by expanded usage of both Cytopoint and Apoquel, benefiting from our direct-to-consumer campaign, uptake in e-commerce channels, and pet owners spending more time with their pets due to COVID-19.
Simparica Trio performed well in the U.S. with sales of $36 million despite challenging market conditions in Q2.
We are observing several positive trends, including rapid uptake in clinics that have adopted Trio, smaller-than-expected cannibalization of Simparica, sales coming from new patients to the category, and taking market share from current oral flea and tick competitors.
Diagnostic sales increased 18% in the quarter, largely driven by our reference lab acquisitions.
Additionally, previous instrument placements created a solid foundation for consumables growth in the second quarter.
U.S. livestock declined 18% in the quarter, driven by lower sales across all species.
In the second quarter, we faced challenges with significant declines in feedlot placements, reduced demand from the foodservice industry and the effects that had throughout the food supply chain and our customers, in addition to increased competition.
In summary, the U.S. showed robust performance despite challenging market conditions.
The varied nature of our product range proved advantageous, with growth in pet care offsetting difficulties faced by our livestock division in the U.S.
Our International division experienced a 3% operational revenue increase in Q2, with balanced growth across both pet care and livestock sectors.
Pet care operational revenue grew by 2%, while livestock operational growth was 4%.
The rise in pet product sales was due to expansion in our main dermatology line and our Simparica brand, including the introduction of Simparica Trio in Canada.
Although European markets were heavily impacted by COVID-19, the decline was counterbalanced by significant growth in other regions, such as Japan and China.
The diagnostics sector struggled as widespread clinic closures due to COVID-19 hindered equipment placement and reduced consumable usage.
International livestock growth in the quarter was led by increases in swine, fish, and poultry sectors.
Swine experienced double-digit growth, primarily driven by a 25% increase in China, as major clients expanded their herds and production shifted from smaller farms to larger operations.
Our fish products had another successful quarter.
Favorable conditions in Chile and Norway led to vaccinations being moved up to Q2.
Additionally, we continue to see increased adoption of the Alpha Flux parasiticide in Chile.
Overall, our international division once again contributed positively to revenue growth, with performance in swine, pet care, fish, and poultry more than making up for the decline in cattle due to the COVID-19 pandemic.
Now let's look at the rest of the financial statement.
Adjusted gross margin slightly increased to 71.1% compared to last year, due to pricing, favorable manufacturing costs, and product mix, partially offset by foreign exchange, recent acquisitions, and higher inventory charges.
Adjusted operating expenses remained flat operationally.
The additional advertising and promotion costs for Simparica Trio, recent acquisitions, and R&D increases were mostly offset by reductions in travel, entertainment, and compensation-related expenses due to COVID-19.
The adjusted effective tax rate for the quarter was 22.3%.
The increase from last year is due to the mix of earnings across jurisdictions and the impact of specific tax benefits recorded in Q2 2019.
Adjusted net income for the quarter grew 4% operationally, mainly driven by revenue growth, and adjusted diluted earnings per share increased 6% operationally.
I'd now like to discuss our liquidity position and capital allocation priorities.
We concluded the second quarter with about $3.4 billion in cash and cash equivalents, including proceeds from our $1.25 billion long-term debt issuance in May, of which $500 million is set aside for repaying our November 2020 maturity.
We have access to a $1 billion revolving credit facility and a corresponding commercial paper program, both currently unused.
Given our strong cash flow and balance sheet, we remain committed to our capital allocation priorities for internal investment, mergers and acquisitions, and returning excess cash to shareholders.
As mentioned last quarter, we still expect higher capital expenditures this year to support investments in manufacturing, information technology for our recent acquisitions, and capabilities in digital and data analytics.
Regarding returning excess cash to shareholders, we remain committed to our 2020 dividend, which is a 22% increase over 2019.
In Q1, we bought back $250 million in Zoetis shares before pausing the program in the second quarter to conserve cash.
We have approximately $1.4 billion remaining in our multi-year share repurchase program.
Now let's move on to our revised guidance assumptions for 2020.
Our past performance has consistently given us confidence that the essential nature of our business, our diverse portfolio, and our continuous innovation would position us well during challenging market conditions.
After evaluating recent trends and our second quarter performance, we are further refining and increasing our full year 2020 guidance.
We anticipate that recent positive trends in companion animal care in the U.S. will continue, although veterinary clinic revenue may moderate somewhat as pent-up demand is satisfied.
The recent resurgence of COVID-19 cases in parts of the U.S. and increasing infection rates in international markets continues to create uncertainty about the duration, scope, and economic impact of the pandemic.
Please note that our guidance reflects foreign exchange rates as of mid-July.
Given our global presence, changes in foreign exchange have impacted revenue and adjusted net income since we issued our previous guidance in May.
Our current guidance includes a favorable foreign exchange impact of approximately $50 million on revenue and about $10 million on adjusted net income compared to May guidance.
For revenue, we are raising and narrowing our guidance range with projected revenue now between $6.3 billion and $6.475 billion, and operational revenue growth between 3% and 6% for the full year, compared to the negative 2% to positive 3% range in our May guidance.
Adjusted net income is now expected to be between $1.685 billion and $1.765 billion, representing operational growth of 1% to 5%, compared to our previous guidance of negative 9% to negative 2%.
Adjusted diluted earnings per share is now expected to be between $3.52 and $3.68, and reported diluted earnings per share to be between $3.14 and $3.32.
In conclusion, while the COVID-19 pandemic has certainly presented unprecedented challenges, we are extremely proud of our colleagues and their commitment to our customers, our company, and animal healthcare.
During this time, we have demonstrated the diversity and durability of our portfolio and the resilience of our industry.
We are confident in our ability to continue executing our strategy during these uncertain times.
